title: Made in Israel
description: In 165 B.C., the Maccabees were victorious over the Syrians and rededicated the Temple that had been desecrated by the Syrians.

title: Mrs. Ford Plans Party
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)Betty Ford will be the hostess at a champagne buffet brunch Monday for volunteers who helped her answer the thousands of getwel messages she received after breast cancer surgery in September. The 220 guests at the party, to be held iin the state dining room, will include the wives of Congressmen who volunteered their help in answering the notes and members of the American Cancer Society, the American Red Cross and the G.O.P. club.

title: No more dirty tricks
description: While the rest of Bermuda takes the January sun, a rumpled crew of redeyed men will soon be celebrating the start of 1975 in smokefilled rooms inside the island's Southampton Princess Hotel. Seated in silence, four at a table, they will decide the fate of several nations, but delegates from the same country will not be able to communicate directly with one another, even by gestures, because screens on each table will prevent Americans from seeing Americans or Italians from catching other Italians' attention with a wink or a shrug.

title: Jean Barbara Mackenzie Is Bride

title: Islanders Defeated By Canucks, 3 to 0
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 30 (AP)Leon Rochefort, Bobby Lalonde and Greg Boddy scored goals to back Gary Smith's 27save shutout as the Vancouver Canucks scored a 30 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: Christmas Books
description: RICHARD ADAMS'S Watership Down (Macmillan, $6.95) is the Odyssey and Iliad of rabbits, for people of all ages  a splendidly written adventure story, a rather broad allegory, meditation on bravery, a text on ecology, a lecture against totalitarianism and a passionate act of imaginative projection. Fiver, Hazel and Bigwig, in the English fantasy tradition of Tolkien's Lord of the Rings and C. S, Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia, are original and quite moving creations.

title: V.A. Chief Says Congress Will Override G.I. Bill Veto

title: News Summary and Index
description: India and Pakistan moved to end their 10year ban on trade relationsdating from the 1965 war over the Kashmir issuewith the signing of a protocol stating that the ban would be lifted Dec. 7. The decision to end the ban fulfills a crucial aspect of the peace agreement signed by the two countries in July, 1972, that provided for a renewal of relations broken when the two countries fought over the new nation of Bangladesh. Indian and Pakistani officials told newsmen that the question of resuming diplomatic relations was being considered but the resumption of trading need not wait for that. [Page 1, Columns 23.]

title: Pays Bill, Tips and Robs

Then he robbed the place. Alfredo Eyzaglirre, the manager, said the customer had taken $1,770 and said; Don't force me to kill you before the holidays. He then fled.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The history of recording in Russia dates back to the turn of the century, just as it does here in the West, but our knowledge of exactly what the Russians have achieved in terms of technology and recorded repertory over the years has always been somewhat spotty. International copyright snafus, differences in economic ideologies, cold and hot wars have all contributed to the cloudy situation, which only began to clear up when Angel gained exclusive rights to distribute Soviet records in this country eight years ago. Since then, the Melodiya/Angel label has built up a catalogue of some 250 new disks devoted to Russian music and performances by major Russian artists. Angel's contract with Mezlidtinarocinaya Kniga (the official name, for Melodlya, the Soviet stateowned record industry) expired recently, but Columbia has stepped in to pick up the ball, so we may now expect to see the latest MK releases on that label.

title: Chrysler Layoffs Shatter Tranquility of of a Town in Michigan
description: LYONS, Mich., Nov. 30Sonny and Doris Wheeler got the final word two days before Thanksgiving. After the holiday they would no longer ave their jobs at the Chrysler Corporation's Lyons trim plant. There is a good chance that anyone who has bought a Chrysler, Dodge or Plymouth during the Jest decade has sat on upholstery cut to size by the 46yearold Mr. Wheeler and sewn by his wife.

They blame the completion of Interstate 80 for much of the change that has taken place, insisting that the highway has made them accessible.

title: Bang Bang, Balthazar
Dance

Last season, its threeweek spring engagement was so successful that it had to be extended for an additional two weeks to accommodate enthusiastic crowds. The theater was sold out every night. It was an extraordinary turn of events for a company that began its life in 1970 playing to empty houses in Brooklyn, even while critics were hailing its brilliance and originality.

title: A Fifth of Leonardo
description: The accidental rediscovery, some 300 years after they last disappeared from sight, of two codices of Leonardo da Vinci's notebooks (now called Madrid I and Madrid II) created a major sensation in arthistorical circles when it was first reported in 1967. The number of Leonardo's writings that had already been discovered was suddenly increased by a fifth, and the number still to be discovered fell to about one half of those mentioned by Leonardo himself. Scholars from all over the world rushed to the Biblioteca Nacional in Spain, and descriptions of what they saw were soon broadcast to the public in a special issue of Life, in seven stories in The New York Times (between February 15 and March 5, 1967), and in a steady stream of learned books and articles ever since. Now, seven years after he was granted the great privilege of becoming the first Leonardo scholar to hold in his hands these marvelous codices (Burlington Magazine, JanuaryFebruary 1968), the late Ladislao Reti's promise has at last been fulfilled. A team of Italian and American philologists, Spanish printers, Swiss photographers, English designers, German bookbinders, and an American publisher has made available an offset reproduction of the original manuscripts, together with an accurate transcription, an English translation and a textual commentary, all bound and boxed in a handsome fivevolume set: THE MADRID CODICES (McGrawHill, Deluxe Edition, $750; Regular Edition, $400).

title: News of the Screen

title: Discovering Land and Sea and Ice
description: Not until the time of Columbus did the peoples of Europe begin to discover how much of the planet was covered by water and to discover, too, that the water paths covering the earth promised new treasures of gold, of knowledge, and of adventure. These highways of the oceans; unlike any known before, could take men from almost anyplace to almost anyplace else. World history from then until the time of Winston Churchillthe discovery of New Worlds, the rise and fall of colonies and empires, and several World Warswas a revelation of the opportunities and dangers peculiar to a planet more than 70 per cent covered with water. Perhaps we may finally give up our misleading Earthly emphasis, and rechristen our planet with its proper name, Water.

title: Photographers In and Out Of History
description: Looking through some of the recent volumes of photographs that are now pouring from the presses in happy profusion, one is easily persuaded that photographers can be divided into two classes: those who eagerly seek out the history of their time, and those who are consciously and programmatically in flight from it. The flight need not, of course, be negatively motivated. It may, indeed, be engendered by the deepest spiritual or esthetic aspiration. Yet a division of this order does seem to separate the kind of photographic imagination that is inspired, not to say seduced, by its contact with the flux of history and that which carefully isolates, either in nature or in the realm of private experience, a repertory of images felt to be immune to the pressures of that flux.

Well, that is what New York has just had the opportunity to investigate when the Royal Swedish Ballet paid its first New York visit with a week's season that ended at City Center last Sunday.

title: Photography as Art
description: Past its first youth now, photography seems to be entering its adolescence: it is an art whose early accomplishments are still unclear, and whose expressive possibilities are, for many, only beginning to be realized. There is a wideopen optimistic, experimental spirit in current photography, and it's pinpointed in PRIVATE REALITIES: Recent American Photography (New York Graphic Society, $15), the catalogue of the first major exhibition of contemporary photography held at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. The pictures in Private Realities don't represent an innovative breakthrough in the art, exactly; they're important because they show that photography is pulling into its orbit people who, a few years ago, might have been engaged with movies, poetry, theater, or painting, and who believe it's as possible to have a distinct, personal style in making photographs as it is in writing fiction. There have always been figures who believe that the photograph is a serious, esthetic object; usually they've worked in isolation, or, like Andre Kertesz in the twenties and thirties, in the company of (and with encouragement only from) painters and poets. Photographers aren't so isolated any more, and one sign of this is that museums, which come complete with catalogues, checklists and bibliographies, have taken over the encouragement.

They are the despair of the senior Sheridans, straightarrows up out of hard times, living now on East End Avenue. Three of them  the Kranz book, plus Flight Through the Ages and Eureka!  clearly fall into the coffeetable format, although the Kranz book, which was produced in Japan, will appeal to a relatively specialized audience.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: When Franz Liszt was giving recitals, in the 1840's, ladies would faint, strong men would turn pale and students, after the performances, would drag the hero through the streets in a fiacre. Liszt was a great pianist. He also was one of the greatest showmen ever to set foot on a concert stage. Vladimir Horowitz, who gave his first New York concert In six years two weeks ago today, is not that kind of showmannot on the stage, at least (though his return was as carefully orchestrated as a Ravel score). He sits quietly at the piano, letting his fingers do the work. Yet the atmosphere in the hail on Nov. 17, one Imagines, resembled that of a Liszt concert its excitement and electricity. Indeed, the. excitement was too much for one listener in the dress circle, who passed out.

description: AT GARDEN

title: Fires Kill 9 in 2 Families In 2 Northern Maine Towns
description: HOULTON, Me., Nov. 30 (AP) Nine members of two families died today in separate fires that destroyed a home and a store over which one of the families lived.

title: Challenge, Profit and a Sense of Romance Bringing Back the Buffalo Herds
description: HARTSEl ColoOne hundred years after they were slaughtered by hunters to the brink of extinction, buffalo are making a comeback.

title: ATHENS PREMIER MEETS CYPRIOTES
description: ATHENS, Nov. 30 (Reuters) Greek and GreekCypriote leaders opened talks here today to seek a common stand on further handling of the Cyprus problem.

title: Canada Seeks Mideast Cooperation on Aid
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 30Canada is preparing to propose a new international developmentaid partnership with the Arab oilproducing statesthe Arabs would provide the money and Canada the expertise.

title: Hijacker of Jet Needs 2 Years to Avoid Jail
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 30 (AP)It has been three years since Dan Cooper parachuted from a Northwest Airlines jet that he had hijacked with $200,000 in ransom money. Two more, and he'll be home freeif he's alive.

title: 3 Men to Receive Awards for Valor
description: NEWARKA state trooper and a Newark policeman and fireman have been named to receive the annual valor awards presented by the 200 Club, a business organization that gives financial assistance to the families of publicsafety officers killed in the line of duty.

title: Black to Head Alabama Political Group
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 30 Chris McNair, whose Daughter was one of four blacks killed in September, 1963, in the bombing of the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, has been elected chairman of the Jefferson County delegation to the Alabama House of Representatives.

title: 4 Die in California Crash
description: THERMAL, Calif., Nov. 30 (UPI)A tractortrailer rig loaded with citrus crates collided with a car on a desert highway early today, killing all four persons in the auto. The names of the victims were not immediately known.

title: Plan for Sound in Doubt
description: Vast new vistas of parklands, scenic beachfronts, entire new islands in Long Island Sound; clean water for bathing, shellfishing and recreational use; new industries attracted by better transportation, shipping and a plentiful supply of pollutionfree energyall these and more are in the panorama of possibilities painted by the longawaited draft report of the Long Island Sound Regional Study.

title: A Camper's Tour Of 3 Florida Parks
description: SPANNING the lower half of the Florida peninsula are three state parks that display a rich variety of tropical wildlife: tangled forested hammocks, an occasional alligator lolling on a sunny riverbank, herds of whitetailed deer grazing among wild orange trees. Jonathan Dickinson State Park near West Palm Beach on the Atlantic coast, Highlands Hammock State Park outside Sebring in central Florida, and Myakka River State Park southeast of Sarasota on the Gulf of Mexico are among the most spectacular of Florida's 37 state parks for camping.

title: Playoff Victory To Delaware
description: NEWARK, Del., Alov. 30 ((P)Bernie Ebersole, safety, and Curt Morgan, a linebacker, turned intercepted passes into secondhalf touchdowns today to lead Delaware to a 3514 victory over Youngstown in a college football playoff game.

title: Corfu: A Loving Pursuit of Empire
description: RUMMAGING one summer day through an antique shop on the Greek Ionian island of Corfu, I came across a curious coin, grimy with a century's handling and a bit squashed around the rim. Polishing this unprepossessing object on the seat of my jeans, and assisted by the spits and handkerchiefs of the shopkeeper, I discovered it to be inscribed with two majestic devices. On the one side there mysteriously emerged from our attentions the grandest of medieval national emblems, the Lion of St. Mark. On the other appeared the most magisterial of Victorian political images, Britannia, holding a trident and a laurel leaf, the emblazoned her shield.

title: RollsRoyces Purchased For Over $1Million
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 (UPI)Charles Schmitt, a RollsRoyce dealer, sold one man seven of the cars this week for more than $1million.

title: Stony Brook President Discusses China Visit
description: STONY BROOKChinese universities are in many ways similar to American universites, according to Dr. John S. Toll, president of the State University center here, who recently returned from a five  week tour of the People's Republic of China and other Asian countries.

title: Mary Warner Is Remarried
description: Mary Stoll Warner of Louisville, Ky., and Theodore L. Cross, a New York lawyer, were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church in Peewee Valley, Ky. The Rev. Robert W, Estill of Alexandria, Va., performed the ceremony.

title: GERMANS CHARGE C.I.A. INTERFERED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The West German Government has complained to the United States that the actions of a Central Intelligence Agency operative monitoring the activities of Soviet officials in West Germany constitute unwarranted interference in German affairs.

title: Endpaper
description: A short story by Joyce Carol Oates

title: The Games People Watch
description: When the Book Review asked me to comment on these sports books those not otherwise reviewed during the year that might make useful Christmas gifts it was suggested rather sadly that on quick glance they seemed routine but perhaps might find a gem or two among them.

title: Ella Es La Mejor Maestra
description: CHESTER TOWNSHIP Silencio, por favor, and a raised hand. That's the way New Jersey's Outstanding Teacher of the Year keeps classroom order.

title: Meredith Willson Has Winning Song To Fight Inflation
description: A few measures of introduction, a cymbal's crash, and Win! Win! Win!  shouted, not sung  begin a marching theme song written by Meredith Wilson for President Ford's WIN campaign.

title: High Court Is Asked to Rule On Missouri Textbook Law
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) The United States Supreme Court has been asked to review a Missouri Supreme Court ruling denying the loan of textbooks to students attending churchrelated schools while allowing loans to students in public and nonsectarian private schools.

title: New Plants For Pots
description: Greenhouse growers can Just about keep up with the demand for house plants. The more homeowners buy, the more they want. Growers are learning that the buyers are becoming more sophisticated in their selections. No longer do they ask for the tired old philodendron, a sure grower, Hobbyists now look for plants with interesting foliage, unusual growth habit, trailers and hangers and those with fancy flowers. Nurserymen are constantly seeking new, unusual plants to please. They know if they offer customers plants that will thrive easily in the average home climate, buyers will be back for more. Some of these new plants are shown on Page 49 with a few tips for their care.

title: $10,000 3Day Medical Bill For Man Who Died Queried
description: YREKA, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP) Emil A. Liloiva accrued a medical bill of more than $10,000 in the last 70 hours of his life, and the administrator of his estate wants doctors to justify every cent.

title: New & Novel
description: Marooned in a crevasse between the elevated lanes of a giant traffic interchange: that's what happens to Robert Maitland, a London architect en route in his Jag from paramour to spouse. When his car goes off the road, Maitland is at first uninjured, and climbs back up an embankment to flag down a passing motorist. But there are no Samaritans during the rush hour. In fact, one speeding sports car clips Maitland and hurls him back down into the island, too badly injured to climb back up.

title: The Past May, or May Not, Be a Guide to the Future
description: WASHINGTONIt is no secrete that Israel is be conking: more and more isolated diplomatically, and it is no secret either that If it came, as it might, to the question of preserving Israel's existence, that nation could and would turn to the United States for an answer.

description: PARIS, Nov. 30 (Reuters)A consignment of 44 diamonds worth $300,000 has been stolen at Charles de Gaulle Airport near here, the police said today.

title: Letters: Butlin's Was Our Only Salvation
description: To the Editor: William D. Smith's article on Britain's Butlin's: Fun by the Numbers (Travel Section, Nov. 10) was both hilarious and nostalgic for me, having once, worked there as a teenage waitress. Everything Smith pointed out was true. It really a poor man's holiday, and in these ??ard times we need more places like this places where families can get unlimited pleasure without having to keep paying more and more.

title: School Aid: Still No Answers
description: TRENTON  With the State Supreme Court deadline now only a month off, Senate Democrats have scheduled a twoday conference, starting tomorrow, in an effort to come up with a new system for financing public schools in New Jersey.

title: Bebop, Cool Jazz Fill a Joint Concert Of Haig and Raney
description: Al Haig's reputation as a jazz pianist stems from the bebop period of the nineteenforties, when he played in the quintet of Char:lie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie, while Jimmy Raney, the guitarist, was more closely tied to the subsequent cool jazz era. Therefore, it was not surprising to find bebop numbers and monochromatic cool jazz touches popping up throughout a concert given by Mr. Haig and Mr. Raney on Friday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: The recipient of a heartthe hollow muscular structure in vertebrate animals that by its rhythmic contraction acts as a force pump to maintain circulation of the bloodhas a greater chance of surviving longer than he did in the earlier days of transplant surgery. (Louis B. Russell Jr., an Indianapolis school teacher, was until his death last week more than six years after a heart transplant, the longest lived.)

title: Schmidt Urges British to Back Market
description: LONDON, Nov. 30Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany appeared before the Labor party conference here today and urged Britain to remain in the Common Market.

description: Any Santa trying to slip down the chimney this year without a creature stirring will find it difficult for his bag is likely to be filled with toys that slam, snap, swish and thump.

title: Some Are Even Talking of Simply Walking Away from It
description: LONDON  When the British Government announced its tough new measures against the Irish Republican Army in Britain last week, a member of Parliament wanted to know whether they would help end the sectarian warfare in Northern Ireland. No, said Roy Jenkins, the Home Secretary, that solution has to be found in Northern Ireland.

title: Cameron Farquhar MacRae 3d Marries Ann Wooster Bedell
description: The marriage of Ann Wooster Bedell, a doctoral candidate in architectural history at Columbia University, to Cameron Farquhar MacRae 3d, deputy superintendent and counsel of the New York State Banking Department, took place yesterday afternoon at Governor's Harbour, Eleuthera, the Bahamas.

title: ROCKEFELLER BACKS FORD ON MIDEAST
description: Responding to a demand by the American Jewish Congress that he correct his statements on the Middle East, Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson ARockefeller said yesterday that he Supported President Ford's policy regarding Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Africa And Paris And Russia
description: Of the three new photography books, lying on my desk, Leni Riefenstahl's THE LAST OF THE NUBA (Harper & Row, $18.95) is unique; and the making of it is a story. Mrs. Riefenstahl, a wellknown film maker and actress in Germany before and during the Hitler years (she directed The Triumph of the Will and Olympiad), was seduced into going to Africa by reading Hemingway's Green Hills of Africa. A projected documentary on the slave trade served to get her there, but didn't point her to the tribe of perfect human beings still living in innocence and harmony that she came to find. On the day she was leaving, she chanced upon a photograph of a magnificent naked athlete riding the shoulders of another, with the caption: A Nuba of Kordofan. She would have to come back.

title: For Katherine Litz, Whimsey in Dance Is An Art of Its Own
description: Whimsey is a most demanding theatrical art, and Katherine Litz has made a long career of it. She has mastered the preoccupied dither, the expression of perpetual questing and unruffled acceptance of even the bizarre. Her Friday performance at the Cubiculo was a small retrospective of her works, and it contained few gems.

title: Four Decades of Poetic Chronicling of the Commonplace
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  According to the readers of True Story magazine, Mary E. Chase is the fifth most outstanding Woman of the Year, ranking behind Loretta Lynn, Julie Eisenhower, Pat Nixon and Billie Jean King, but ahead of Mary Tyler Moore, Rose Kennedy, Dale Evans and Susan Hayward.

title: What's Doing in JERUSALEM
description: DEVALUATION  Jerusalem has become a more economical place to visit this winter, following the 43 per cent devaluation of the Israeli pound last month. The rate of exchange is now 6 Israeli pounds to the dollar, compared with 4.2 pounds before devaluation. Though some prices are continuing to rise, a visitor should find that he is spending between 20 and 43 per cent less than he would have before devaluation. For example, a dinner that cost $9.50 before Nov. 10 now costs $8, and a $2.50 lunch is now $1.80. Hotel prices, standardized in dollars, remain the same, although package deals arranged through agents abroad are cheaper. A rise in bus and taxi fares, approved by the Ministry of Transportation, is expected this month. At most, the transportation rates, in dollars, will be back up to what they were in early November. But for the next several months, other expenses are likely to remain considerably lower.

title: BONN LEADER DUE IN U.S. THIS WEEK
description: BONN, Nov. 30In the view of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, there are, if I see correctly, no bilateral problems between Germany and the United States minister going to Washington, let along the Chancellor, but for me, the reason for going is to talk about economic problems with President Ford.

description: CAIRNS, Australia  In May and June, they fish for blackfin tuna in the Bahamas; in July, they sail out from Florida into the Gulf Stream for blue marlin, and in August they trek to Newfoundland for the giant bluefin tuna.

The company is presently installed at the Manhattan branch of the Chelsea Theater, high up on 43d Street, where it is playing Bertolt Brecht's The Mother some nights of the week and its own joust with sciencefiction, The Great Air Robbery, on the others (you check), and what I was most grateful for at the first performance of the Brecht teaching play was the factorysmoke. When the fourwheeled vehicle stops, it remains upright. The twowheeler stops, and it falls over.

Among the special items on primetime tap this week: Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward treking through The Wild Places, a new version of The Red Badge of Courage, a showing of John Huston's The African Queen, all on NBC; a CBS Reports study on water problems; and, over at ABC, a a repeat of Man Without a Country and, jumping the holiday gun, Yes, Virginia, There Is a Santa Claus.

He was about to get into a ricketylooking pontoondinghy equipped, with an outboard that was bobbing alongside the plush boat.

title: Strikes and Strikers Down In U.S. Report on October
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)The Labor Department says that 195,000 persons took part in 650 strikes during October. The number of strikes was the lowest in nine months.

title: The American Scene
description: About the only useful thing that might be claimed for the term, The American Scene Painters, is that it applies to a large, disparate group of artists who, around the 1930's and 1940's, turned to the American social scene and the American landscape as the source of their inspiration. Beyond that, the term simply falls apart: it defines no specifically native style of painting; it represents no cohesive program of art; it encompasses artists who, for reasons of political or esthetic persuasions, were barely compatible in their interests and ambitions.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP)The State Bureau of Consumer Protection has filed separate suits against four concerns that it has termed phony charities.

description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 30 (UPI)  The police said today that some Alabama motorists could be riding around in a time bomb because they bought fake antifreeze containing methyl alcohol.

The amateur committee of the International Soccer Federation, otherwise known as F.I.F.A., declined to accept late entries last Friday when the committee held a meeting in Zurich to finalize plans for the 1976 Olympic tournament.

If so, passengers flying coach on all carriers between New York and Miami and on a few other routes will probably continue to be offered free drinks or free glasses of champagne along with their air passage.

title: Country Cousin
description: It is the poor relation of the maple family, the country cousin that has softshelled beetles in its hair. Its common name makes no mention of its distinguished kinfolk. It is the boxelder. Botanists and others of scientific bent do speak of it as the ashleaf maple or Acer negundo; but that doesn't repair its reputation. It grows with, little encouragement all over the Northeast, over the mountains into the Midwest and far out across the Great Plains. It has its virtues.

description: PARIS, Nov. 30  Rodrigo Valdes retained the World Boxing Council version of the middleweight boxing title tonight by knocking out Gratien Tonna in the 11th round. The finish set off a controversy that almost evolved into a free for all in the ring.

Rockefeller commutedd the sentence to life imprisonment.

title: Words and Pictures
description: As between art history and the art book, the standoff continues. It is to their mutual disadvantage. Art history and the art book should justify, sustain and complement one another. An art book untouched by art history is amateurish pap. Art history which sticks in the learned magazines leads an almost clandestine existence, midway between menace and myth. Publish and be damned! may have been a famous cry in the 19th century, but Publish or be damned! should be our attitude to those who sit on a great subject and don't come up with a great book.

title: Design
description: Meaningful holidays seem to develop their own art forms. Hanukkah, the ancient Jewish holiday that is celebrated each year starting on the 25th of Kislev (this year it falls on Dec. 6), is no exception. Its art form, littleheralded but absolutely intrinsic to the observance, is the Hanukkah lamp. The holiday celebrates the victory of Judah the Maccabee over the Syrians in 165 B.C., when the Temple of Jerusalem was reclaimed and rededicated. According to legend, there was only enough oil to keep the temple lamp burning for one dayyet, miraculously, the lamp burned for eight long days. Each year, this event is observed with the Festival of Lights, an eightday celebration. On the first evening at dusk, one light of the Hanukkah lamp is lit. On each following evening, another light is lituntil, on the eighth night, all are glowing. The Hanukkah lamps shown here are part of an exhibit, Hanukkah Lamps: Past and Present, that will be on view at The Jewish Museum at 1109 Fifth Avenue starting tomorrow. In their rich diversity of design, these little lamps (they are rarely more than 7 inches high or 5 inches wide) reflect the movement of Jewish culture through many lands and many centuries.

title: Turf History Is Repeated At $95 Less
description: MIAMI, Nov. 30Last May 11 at Calder Race Course, a 3yearold named Commanding Lead won the Boca Raton Handicap and paid $100 for a $2 ticket to win. He was so lightly regarded that day that he was part of the pailmutuel field.

title: Reports of Desperate Acts in Ghettoes of the Region
description: While the rich sustain paper losses in their portfolios, and the middle class undergo a real loss of purchasing power and the conveniences it buys, the chief victims of inflation in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are those already poor. Necessities have risen in price at least as much as luxuries, and there are widespread reports from poverty workers and governmental agencies that the poor are becoming desperate. One involved official, welfare director Dick Rathjen of Bridgeport, says unqualifiedly: Many people are actually starving.

title: The Philharrnonic Meets an Electronic Piano
description: A visit to Charles Wuorinen at his upper West Side brownstone home found what used to be called the front parlor almost exclusively occupied by an enormous concert grand piano. It was not just any grand but the electronic instrument produced by the Baldwin Piano and Organ Company five years ago. It was where it was because Wuorinen, the PulitzerPrizewinning composerpianist, needed it to practice on. This Friday afternoon he will be soloist with the New York Philharmonic in the first performance of his Second Piano Concerto (for Amplified Piano) with Erich Leinsdorf conducting.

title: Waters Off Jersey Will Become Terminus of Northwest Passage
description: New Jersey waters are destined to become the southern end of a new and important tanker routethe Northwest Passage.

title: Ramapo Students Work in Community
description: MAHWAHThose Ramapo College juniors and seniors who spend their classroom hours studying the varied aspects of community and regional problems have taken to the field to see, firsthand, what these problems are all about.

title: Fred Wisetnan's Primate Makes Monkeys of Scientists
description: Frederick Wisemanlawyer, social critic, master of cinema verite and, in the opinion of many, this country's most interesting filmmakeris about to subject television audiences to an unsettling hour and a half of primetime viewing. Wiseman's latest documentary, Primate, will be shown this Thursday at 10 P.M. on WNET/13 and most other PBS stations across the country.

title: Hong Kong Returns 5 to China
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 39The Hong Kong Government today reverted its policy of permitting refugees from China to remain in Hong Kong. It anflounced that five persons had been turned over to the Chinese authorities, the first such action in seven years.

title: Park Service Gets Hearing Tomorrow on Bid to Build in Delaware River Woods
description: BUSHKILL, Pa. Except for a shovelful of earth that was dug up on a rainy day in October, a peaceful, 10acre segment of oakandhemlock woods north of here has been little disturbed for ages.

title: Jane A. Potter Stuart Graham Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harmon S. Potter of Heliport, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Allison Potter, to Stuart W. Graham. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Graham Jr. of Fitchburg, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Last yearin chronological 1973, that isthere was a singularly large number of books on Watergaterelated matters. Evil Presidents taking over. High jinks in high places. The underbelly of America. But since then, certain things have happened, and that source has dried up. So in 1974, the Enemy was once again the Russians, as witness Ted Allbeury's SNOWBALL (Lippincott, $6.95), Duncan Kyle's THE SUVAROV ADVENTURE (St. Martin's, $6.95) and THE PLATINUM BULLET by Richard L. Graves (Stein and Day, $7.95). In each of these our old antagonists play a prominent part; it's Us against Them, and these three good writers will have the readers at the edge of their chairs.

title: JOBLESSNESS HITS MIDDLECLASS TOO
description: The recession has become a painful reality to Robert De Vilbiss, Henrietta Valor, Susan Partier, Melody Fairbanks, Jan Tomere and a Former Executive Who Doesn't Want His Name Usedsix residents of Manhattan's Upper West Side who were interviewed recently.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Anyone who thinks that the explosion of Federal spending in the last five or six years is a major cause of the nation's economic troubles can take little comfort from the elaborate program of expenditure reduction set to Congress by President Ford last week.

title: News of the Stage
description: Jon Voight, film and stage luminary, and Susan Bloom, producer and music publisher, have joined forces for the presentation of The Hashish Club, a play by Lance Larsen at the Bijou Theater on Jan. 5.

title: Kissinger Role on U.N. Force Related
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30An extension of the mandate for the United Nations peacekeeping force on the Golan Heights was first proposed by Syria's President Hafez alAssad 10 days ago and was negotiated at long distance by Secretary of State Kissinger, authoritative diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: ART VIEW
description: Art Clearly, the photographic image has now acquired a cultural prestige of extraordinary proportions. (Hilton Kramer)

title: How to Grip and Release The Ball While Bowling
description: While several techniques are involved in rolling a bowling ball into the pocket, there is only one way to make certain to hold, then release the ball properly.

title: WasteDumping Suit Filed Against Exxon and Texaco
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 (UPI)The Exxon Corporation and Texaco, Inc., face criminal charges for allegedly dumping oilrich wastes into the Gulf of Mexico from their offshore oil rigs.

title: InTown Renovators Hurt by Inflation
description: Was it a pipe dream or a realistic gamble on the future of New York? By late December, those involved may know whether the vision they shared in 1969 can still become an actuality.

title: $19.40 El Pitirre Captures Remsen
description: Handicappers who play percentages might do well to draw a circle around El Pitrirr in their early figuring for next year's Kentucky Derby.

title: Federal Funds Used in Behavior Control Tests
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Federal Government finances experiments to control antisocial human behavior with brain surgery, drugs, computers, radio transmitters implanted in the head and other means, a Senate report said today.

title: POINTS OP VIEW
description: WASHINGTONAccording to a recent Louis Harris poll, 65 per cent of the people in the United States think the country is now in a recession. Administration officials have acknowledged that we are in a recession, and most economists and newspaper correspondents now take it for granted.

title: Subject: The Universe
description: The universe, says Dr. Mortimer J. Adler, in the introductory volume of the new ENCYCLOPEDIA BRITANNICA. (Fifteenth Edition. Illustrated. Encyclopedia Britannica/WilHam Benton. $798, $698, $598.) embraces not only everything that is, but everything that is knowable. And the encyclopedia sets for itself the goal of reporting everything that is and can be known about the universe

title: INVESTING
description: After Weis Securities, Inc., became in 1973 the only major brokerage firm to go into, liquidation under the new Federallychartered organization called Securities Investor Protection Corporation, it became painfully clear that the legislation was inadequate.

title: Donald Cushing McGraw 3d Is Fiance of Sacha Mahaffey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Reeves Mahaffey of Daytona Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sacha Adele Mahaffey, to Donald Cushing McGraw 3d, whose greatgrandfather, the late James H. McGraw, was founder of McGrawHill, Inc., here. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. McGraw Jr. of New York and Wianno, Mass. His father is a group president of McGrawHill.

title: Killing of Carolinar charged to Woman, Raises Question of Abuse of Inmates
description: RALEIGH, N.C.The icepick slaying of Clarence Alligood, the 62yearold night jailer at the Beaufort County jail, might have appeared a simple case of murder and escape by a woman inmate except for what one law enforcement official termed the peculiarities in the way he was dressed.

title: Manhattan's other island
description: When Ed Logue gets up in the morning and looks out of the windows of his apartment at 1 East End Avenue, he sees what any prosperous eastfacing EastSider (living between Gracie Square and the U.N.) can see, which is a twomilelong rocky sliver of an island splitting the fierce currents of the East River. Once Welfare, now Roosevelt Island, it is straddled by the nineteenhundred's erectorset steelwork of the Queensboro Bridge and in the last year or so has been surmounted by what looks like steps made from giant browngray blocks, in fact a spine of buildings on which, at 8 A.M., cranes are beginning to turn and hardhatted figures start to move.

title: Assembly to Vote On Probate Laws
description: TRENTONA package of bills designed to protect widows is about to come up for consideration by the Legislature.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT SCARSDALE, N.Y. BOULDER BROOK EVENT

title: Lucy Guerlac Fiancee of E. B. Battersby
description: Henry Guerlac, Goldwin Smith Professor of the History of Science at Cotnell University, and Mrs. Guerlac of Ithaca have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Anne Guerlac, to Edmund Bonavia Battersby of New York and Blue Hill, Me., son of Dr. and Mrs. Brian J. Battersby of Bethesda, Md.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: The Great and NearGreat
description: It's an appealing idea to picture cneself under the Christmas tree chindeep in picture books. With all this seasonal ?? piled about, the first thing to do, of course, is look each volume gladly in the eye, abashed to be found deserving of such company. The next thing (and a few miss this simple trick) is to go ahead and read it.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WELLINGTON, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP)Law enforcement offica?? searching for Melvin's Woe, the winner of the Little Brown Jug pacing classic in 1973, theorized today that the horse was hidden not far from the tarm where he was stolen.

title: India Woes Turn Young To Violence
description: CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 25  The retired businessman tilts in his secondfloor epart ment, each evening, reading Bengali novels and listening to music on die radio. Late at night; when his wife has allen asleep, he removes a photograph album from a desk drawer and stares at pictures of his daughter.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Two major bottling concerns have taken space in the Hunts Point Industrial Park, which is being developed by Abraham J. Rodolltz.

title: Six Council Meetings Will Be Open to Public
description: The following City Council hearings, which are open to the public, will be held this week. Unless otherwise noted, they will be held in the Council's chambers.

title: Illinois School Keeps Degrogatory Nickname
description: PEKIN, Ill., Nov. 30 (UPI) Derogatory or not, Pekin High School students want to remain the Chinks.

title: RENOVATION WORK BEGINS AT CAPITOL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Painters, masons and carpenters began major renovation work on the Capitol during the recent Congressional recess. In the Great Rotunda, which is being painted for the first time in 25 years, a forest of scaffolding now greets visitors. The only way to cross the vast domed hall is through an enclosed plywood walkway.

title: Towne of Smithville Getting Arts Village
description: SMITHVILLE  Some 25 years ago, a freelance artist and his wife sold their antiques shop in this Ocean County community and bought a vintage inn and seven acres for $3,600.

title: ITALY SETS REFORMS FOR BROADCAST UNIT
description: ROME, Nov. 30The Government tonight approved reforms for the Italian radio and television agency thaton paper at leastherald major changes for the state broadcasting monopoly.

title: Learn With the Proper Stranger
description: For $650,000 this Christmas you can learn the secrets of oddsmaking and gambling from Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker whose betting lines appear in over 200 American newspapers. The Greek estimates that it might take a year to learn his system, but adds that You could make back the half million in three or four years if you apply what I teach you.

title: Haircut Order Is Upheld
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has upheld a lower court order requiring. Jacksonville firemen to get short haircuts.

title: Film of Cup Races at Boat Show
description: Seeing the film documentary, The 1974 America's Cup, the Grandest Prize, may turn out to be more rewarding than having been aboard a yacht in the spectator fleet at the actual races last September. The event that has been described as being as exciting as watching grass grow can only have benefited from the editing in the film documentary; which will be shown continuously and free of charge at the 65th National Boat Show Jan. 11 to 19 in the New York Coliseum. The film had its premier on national television and won first prize for best sports documentary at the Chicago Film Festival.

title: Police Sergeant Aiding Young
description: TEANECKFred Greene's formula for keeping youngsters out of trouble is a mixture of motivation, selfrespect, responsibility, talented guidanceand a little money.

title: Poll Goes Extra Lap to Pick Bobby Unser as Driver of '74
description: Bobby Unser, the United States Auto Culub's national champion, has been voted driver of the year by the Martini & Rossi racing panel of experts  partly because there was only one trophy to be handed out. Unser finished in a tie with Cale Yarborough, who won 10 Grand National stock car races this season, after the panel's fourth and last quarterly vote, taken last week as usual by a conference phone call with panelists on the line from all around the country.

title: In praise of la panade
description: La panade. Few Americans are acquainted with this peasant dish and, in fact, this bread soup, which has been described as the best, the cheapest and the most digestible of soups, has all but disappeared from contemporary French cookbooks. This is a shame. Not only is it a thrifty dish, using up every last slice of leftover bread, but it can be an excellent one.

title: BRIDGE
description: All experienced players occasionally make bids that cause the other three players to raise curious eyebrows. Once or twice in a lifetime at bridge a player may do something that is not simply strange but so impossible and ludicrous that the whole table dissolves in helpless laughter.

title: Region Retires as Times Officer But Will Still Write His Column
description: James Reston, who won two Pulitzer Prizes during a 35year career as reporter, editor and columnist of The New York Times, retired today as a vice president of the company, having reached the mandatory retirement age for executives of 65.

title: Elizabeth Cole Jersey Bride
description: Elizabeth Igoe Cole, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Ashley Cole of Short Hills, N. J., and Gregory Phillip Kinch, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Kinch of Murray Hill, N. J., were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. John Ryan at Bonneventura Hall Chapel at the School of the Holy Child in Summit, N. J.

title: 865 Jobs Open in Boston
description: BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The city of Boston is accepting applications for 865 new jobs under a $7.7million Federal grant. The jobs, funded by the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, will be in the $7,000$10,000 range in various city departments. At least 34 per cent of the jobs are reserved for veterans.

title: Ford Signs SexEquality Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. (UPI)President Ford has signed into law a bill that forbids sex discrimination in the Naval Sea Cadet Corps. The White House announced today. The Naval Sea Cadet Corps is a federally chartered organization for youths of high school age.

title: In Trinidad: A Naturalist's Dream
description: EVEN without the help of one of Celine's celestial rum punches, the view of Arima Valley from the south veranda of the main house at Asa Wright Nature Centre, 1,200 feet high in the rain forests of Trinidad's Northern Range, can make me a little giddy.

title: Why was no one else concerned about finding out promptly whether the right man had been arrested?
description: New Yorkers are regularly inundated with distressing information about their criminal justice system, and some of it is significant. Last year, for example, the New York Police Department claimed that its clearance ratethe number of crimes solved in relation to the number of complaintswas 15 per cent for robberies and 11 per cent for larcenies. Although these rates are low, they are, according to most observers, wildly inflated. Among other things, they include cases in which a person was arrested yet never convicteda state of affairs which some cite as proof that overly permissive judges allow the guilty to escape punishment on legal technicalities. Others, however, regard the lowconviction rate as confirmation of lowquality police work which victimizes society's despised classes.

title: SCIENTISTS FIGHT BIRD'S EXTINCTION
description: The world's rarest bird, the Mauritius kestrel, may yet be send from extinction.

title: Major Changes Have Long Since Been Abandoned
description: WASHINGTONSeveral thousand Democrats will gather in Kansas City Friday to write a charter, or party constitution, and thereby complete the reform assignment the party's 1972 convention.

title: Miss Taylor Wed To T. D. Jones 3d
description: Elizabeth, Mercer Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Mills Taylor of WinstonSalem, N. C., was married there yesterday noon to Thomas David Jones 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of Hanover, Va. The Rev. Dr. David Burr performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Somozo to Take Office
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 30 (UPI)  Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle takes office tomorrow for a sixyear term as President of Nicaragua, a post he previously held from 1967 to 1972. He was elected on Sept. 1.

title: The Ballet: Short Dybbuk Variations
description: Presumably the best way to think of Dybbuk Variations, Jerome Robbins's most recent work for the New York City Ballet, is as an abstract narrative. The description is ambivalent and so is this ballet, originally seen in May and for the first time in a shortened version given Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Home Rule on Vocational Aid Will Start Next Year
description: TRENTONAll of New Jersey's counties will usea new home rule plan next year to distribute their allocations of state and Fedoral vocational education money. The institution of the decentralization plan on a statewide level is the result of its success in five pilot counties this year.

title: An Editor in Mozambique Is Arrested and Deported
description: BEIRA, Mozambique, Nov. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Manuel Fernando Magalhaes, editor of the Lourenco Marques newspaper A Tribuna, was arrested and forced to board a Portuguese airliner to Lisbon on Thursday, the daily Noticias de Beira reported today.

title: A Defeated Governor Reports An Unofficial Cabinet Offer
description: BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has been informally asked to Join President Ford's Cabinet when he leaves the governorship, according to an interview published in The Sunday Herald Advertiser.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Words that haunt: Diron Talbert, Redskins' defensive tackle, discloses before Washington's key game with the Dallas Cowboys: If you knock Roger Staubach out, you've got that rookie (Clint Longley) facing you, That's one of our goals. If we do that, it's great. Longley's sensational passing pulled out a 2423 victory.

title: The Calamity Howlers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The dilemma in Washington these days is that half the politicians seem to be evading the harsh economic facts while the other half are exaggerating the gloom and almost talking us into a depression.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
description: FRANK WATERS: THE COLORADO The quaking aspen is the ascetic of the forest. No other tree is so fragile in appearance ... and so susceptible to the slightest breeze. In spring the new small leaves are a bright electric green whose undersides soon turn a pale silver.

title: The Giant Target of Trustbusting '74
description: The Justice Department having filed its biggest antitrust action everagainst the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the biggest corporation the world has to offerit should come as no surprise that just about everything on the subject comes out in superlatives.

title: Nutcracker Tour Planned by Ballet
description: NEWARK The Garden State Ballet, under the direction of Fred Danieli, will present Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker at Symphony Hall next Sunday. The performance will mark the beginning of the company's third annual tour of the state.

title: Annsley Chapman Is Wed on Coast
description: Annsley Palmer Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dotted John Chapman of Kentfield, Calif., formerly of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to George Gordon Strong Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs., Strong of Canton, Ohio, and Fembroke, Bermuda.

title: The Mercedes Mystery: Saudis in German Deal?
description: BONN, Nov. 30What Middle Eastern oilproducing country bought up to 14.6 per cent of DaimlerBenz, manufacturers of MercedesBenz automobiles? The mystery was as deep as ever today, but Saudi Arabia was added to Iran in the speculation.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Diplomats Married in Peking
description: PEKING, Nov. 30 (Reuters)Two foreign diplomats, Arnold Moebius of Austria and Elizabeth Wright of Britain, were married here today in a Chinese ceremony.

title: The Nation
description: The question of whether Richard Nixon would ever testify at the trial of his former aides has now been answered, at least tentatively: He probably will not.

title: Soviet Navy Visit Morocco
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30 (Reuters) Two Soviet destroyers and a submarine are to make a fourday visit to the Moroccan port of Casablanca beginning Monday, Tass the Soviet press agency reported today.

title: TAIWAN DEDUCING ITS BRAIN DRAIN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 30Chang Che  chung returned from the United Stated eight months ago with a master's degree in electrical engineering and since then, he says, he is constantly asked, Why did you come back?

title: Little Red Schoolhouse Is Saved in Cranbury
description: CRANBURY  A 10yearold battle to save the old schoolhouse in this picturesque Middlesex County town has ended in at least a temporary victory for preservationists.

title: The dream of a society where money would play almost no role led to the verge of economic collapse, but sugar, the hated symbol of colonialism, is about to make Cuba rich.
description: HAVANA. I had not been in Cuba since the summer of 1963, when the country was an armed camp. After the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961 and the missile crisis in 1962, Cubans were suffering, with some cause, from invasion hysteria. In every other Havana doorway there stood an armed militiaman in verde olivo (olive green uniform). From the Malecon (Havana's seaside boulevard) on a clear day, you could see the U.S. Navy ship Oxford lying just outside Cuba's territorial waters, observing Soviet ship movements. In the Escambray mountains, counterrevolutionary bands hoped to overthrow Castro as Castro had overthrown Batista.

title: Symphony to Offer Hispanic Program
description: NEWARKThe New Jersey Symphony Orchestra will present An Evening of Hispanic Music at Symphony Hall Saturday night. This marks the first time that the symphony has given a concert for any Hispanic community in the state.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  The Palestine Liberation Organization has appointed a representative to the Soviet Union and will soon open an office in Moscow, a Palestinian source said here today.

title: Dr. Jacob Finkelstein Is Dead; Yale Professor of Assyriology
description: Dr. Jacob Joel Finkelstein who had been William Laffan Professor of Assyriology and Babylonian Literature at Yale University since 1965, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in New Haven. He was 52 years old.

title: Son to Mrs. Engelhardt
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Engelhardt of Glen Cove, L.I., on Nov. 14 in the Klingenstein Pavilion. Mrs. Engelhardt is the former Fran Lang of Philadelphia. The child, the couple's second and their first son, is named Adam Erik. His father is a vice president of Shields Model Roland, Inc., investment bankers and stockbrokers.

title: Seminar Scheduled On SelfBreast Test
description: SCOTCH. PLAINS  Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield will sponsor a seminar on self breast examinations on Dec. 9. It will be held at the Scotch Plains Library, starting at 10 A.M.

title: Clive Howard, Advertising And Publicity Man, Is Dead
description: Clive Howard, head of the public relations organization of his name since 1970, died Thursday of a heart attack in Beth Israel Hospital. He lived in Tenafly, N. J.

title: Legislative Notes Mrs. Kuykendall Calledon Checks
description: TRENTON  The Senate Judidary Committee has put off, at least temporarily, its vote on the nomination of Penelope L. Kuykendall to head the state's Division on Women. The delay, the second within a. threeweek period, stems from new disclosures involving alleged badcheck charges against the nominee.

title: Police Assist Heiress In Eviction of Fiance
description: VILLANOVA, Pa, Nov. 30 (UPI)Rachel Fitler, the 77yearold millionaiere heiress and aunt of Margaretta Rockefeller, has ordered ber 29yearold fianc out of ber mansion, and apparently out of her life.

title: Warnings on Transmissible Diseases
description: Diseases transmissible from animals to man was the subject of a talk by Dr, Martin V. Zipkin of Hewlett, L, to the Long Island chapter of the OwnerHandler Association of America, at Hempstead recently. If you include skin diseases, we have thousands of cases cropping up across the country of disorders contracted from pets, said Zipkin, sectarytreasurer of the Long Island Veterinary Medical Association and a voluntary consultant to the Nassau County Board of Health.

title: Psst! Get Your Hot Glen Campbell Tapes Here
description: Los ANGELES Last January, F.B.I. agents in Los Angeles broke into a onestory building which, they had excellent reason to believe, was the center of a largescale tapepirating operation. Sure enough, they found $100,000 worth of tapeduplicating equipment. Behind a bookcase, they came upon a secret movable panel leading to a hidden room equipped with a bank of telephones on which nationwide orders were taken for tape recordings by such performers as Carly Simon, Carole King, Glen Campbell, Santana, Charlie Pride, Tammy Wynette, Blood, Sweat and Tears, Chicago and Cat Stevens.

title: Topless Sugar Pot
description: When Federal price analysts conclude that everybody in the sugar industry is getting huge windfall profits out of the skyrocketing price of sugar, it is no surprise to find that old Marxist, Harry Bridges, deciding it is time to embrace profitsharing as a way to sweeten the pot for his union members in Hawaiian sugar plantations.

title: SCHOOLS' QUALITY BELIEVED IN PERIL
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 30The schools of this affluent ??ommunity, which are considered so good that for years parents living outside Beverly Hills have lied about their addresses to get their children enrolled here, are believed to be in danger.

title: Marijuana Plan in Capital Canceled by U.S. Attorney
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)United States Attorney Earl J. Silbert has canceled his order not to prosecute persons with small amounts of marijuana in the District of Columbia.

title: Or a Reasonable Facsimile
description: Whether or not THE BOOK OF KELLS (Knopf, $55, until Dec. 31, thereafter $65) is the finest art book of the year, it's my favorite. With its facsimiles of every full page illustration from the eighth or early ninthcentury manuscript in the Library of Trinity College, Dublin, along with a representative selection of ornamented text pages, this handsome volume is as close as you are going to get to sitting down with the original on your lap and thumbing through it.

title: Dining Out in jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as Mir, two stars asgood, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Afghanistan: Tour Buses Among the Camels
description: WEDGED at the tapering end of a fertile valley and shadowed by the jagged peaks of the Hindu Kush, Kabul, Afghanistan, has long been the capital of one of Asia's most isolated societies. Yet within the last decade it has become the major stoppingplace for travelers on the overland route from Istanbul to India and has appropriated Katmandu's former status as the Asian mecca for alienated Western youth. Over the city's tattered and ancient core today lies a strange, almost surreal Western veneer.

title: CONNECTICUT ACTS TO TRIM ARRESTS
description: HARTFORD, Nov., 30Fo reasons of compassion and common sense, the state polic in Connecticut have been cutting back in stages on the arrests they make, according to Police Commisinoner Cleveland B. Fuessenich.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: No Splendor Without Grass
description: To the Editor:

title: The Official Recession
description: Continued evidence of serious recession has altered the public stance of the Ford Administration, whose officials are now addressing that problem with attention at least equal to their concern over inflation. There is no clear sign, however, that Mr. Ford will alter the basically conservative proposals he has made for righting the economy, and the Democrats in control of Congress have not yet produced their promised package of counter proposals.

title: The Gods That Are Failing
description: PARISI have recently been struck by the number of Europeans who profess puzzlement at American gloom about the world economic situation and who argue that the United States is a strong superpower, richly endowed with resources, that has no logical reason for taking such a pessimistic view. Europe, they insist, would be far more justified in assuming attitudes even more negative than is actually the case.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: The darkroom enthusiast who would like to try something different will find high contrast printing an interesting challenge. Although not new, this black  and  white printing technique has become quite popular in recent years as an exciting and useful process that can heighten impact, subdue extraneous matter, intensify a mood, or create unusual effects that resemble etchings.

title: Headliners
description: The case of Seabee Leon L. Louie, is over and it has established a precedent: It is the first court martial for pie throwing. Seabee Louis was charged with assault because he tossed a pie in the face of a Chief Warrant Officer at morning muster. Enlisted men at Port Hueneme, California, thought the bit of slapstick might serve as a moralebooster and nominated Seabee Louie to do the deed. At a hearing last week, the charge was dismissed on a technicality, but the military prosecutor said he may have it refiled. If it is, said Mr. Louie's lawyer, he may call to the stand an expert witness on piethrowing, Soupy Sales. Mr. Sales, said the lawyer, has received more pies in the face than any other individual in the United States.

title: Oratorios to Keep Conductor on Go
description: MORRISTOWN  David Randolph, music director of the Masterwork Music and Art Foundation and conductor of the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, is expected to make musical history on Dec. 15. On that date, he will conduct two different Handel oratorios, with two different choruses, in two of New York's major concert halls.

title: Ouida Bergere Rathbone Dies; Dramatist Was Actor's Widow
description: Ouida Bergere Rathbone, a writer for stage and screen, as well as an actress and theatrical agent, died Friday in Roose?? Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived at 15 West 72d Street.

title: Valerie Perrine, or, The Return Of the Hollywood Sex Kitten
description: She looks and sounds like a sensual Betty Boop, with her cherubic blue eyes, button nose and rosebud lips strangely coexisting with a snugfitting blouse unbuttoned almost to the navel and a lispy way of speaking Very Frankly, expletives included. Her name is Valerie Perrine, it rhymes with marine, and I will risk the feminists' darts by revealing that her measurements are 372436 only because she is one of the first avowed sex kittens to come down the Hollywood Freeway since Raquel Welch.

title: Macao Race Crash Kille 1
description: MACAO, Nov. 30 (UPI)  A child was killed and six people were injured today when is racing car hurtled into a crowd from the racetrack in Macao.

title: N.Y.U. TO INCREASE AID TO MINORITIES
description: New York University will inmasa its sholarship aid to graduate and doctorallevel minority students in the science fields through a rise in the Martin Luther Xing Fund, which the university established in 1988.

title: COAL PACT FOUGHT IN KEY UNION AREA
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., Nov. 30In, a protest caravan through the narrow streets here today, members, of the United Mine Workers' largest and most politically volatile district honked automobile horns and hooted disapproval of the proposed strike settlement they are being asked to ratify.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Music in Review
description: Margot Nystrom chose unbeaten paths in her. New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. The Swedish pianist not only included three contemporary works (by Maurice Karkoff, Hilding Rosenberg and Goffredo Petrassi) but also offored comparatively neglected pieces by Haydn and Schubert. In prospect, it made an interesting program, and Miss Nystrom proved to be a technically wellschooled pianist.

title: World Population To Be Discussed
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Dr. Barry Commoner, environmentalist and author, will be among the speakers at a conference to be held here Friday on world population.

title: Whites Kept in Chicago Schools By Money Woes, Report Shows
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 30The Chicago Board of Education said this Week that fewer white students left the city's public school system this year because many white families have been unable to obtain mortgages to buy homes in the suburbs.

title: 1974: A Selection Of Noteworthy Titles
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 2, 1973. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.

title: Big Store Is Turned Into Little Ones
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION  What was once a Billy Blake discount store on Nesconset Highway here will open tomorrow as 250 small shops.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stook market ended en abbreviated week in dull fashion on Friday with most Issues showing only minor price changes.

title: U.S.C. Routs Irish, 5524, With 490 Half
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30In a truly fantastic turnabout that will rank among the most retold legends of an already legendary rivalry, the University of California spotted Notre Dame a 24.0 lead in the first 29 minutes of play and then demolished the Irish in a 5524 victory.

title: Point of View
description: What are community planning boards and why is everybody saying such harsh things about them? If criticism from all quarters is a sure sign of arrival, New York City's community boardsthe neighborhood councils chartered by the city to advise officials on the public welfare of their communities  are fast approaching immortality.

title: STATE AND CANADA IN DISPUTE ON DAM
description: ALBANYNew York State is embroiled in an international dispute involving the proposed construction of a dam in Canada that might lower the water level of Lake Champlain.

title: College Is Offering Noncredit Courses
description: PEMBERTONThe Office of Community Services at Burlington County College will offer a variety of noncredit courses during the winter semester. They will be taught both on campus and at various offcampus locations throughout Courses county.

title: Churchill Family Quietly Marks 100th Anniversary of His Birth
description: BLADON, England, Nov. 30 (AP)The family of the late Sir Winston Churchill gathered in this quiet Oxfordshire village today for a simple service commemorating the statesman's birth 100 years ago.

title: Natural Things
description: If one really loves natural history books there is an intriguing fantasy about coming down on Christmas morning say in 1838 and finding a set of the Audubon Double Elephant Folio under the tree. (Fewer than 200 complete sets four volumes  were printed and Audubon had trouble selling even them.) The price was less than $1,000. Today, the price is edging up on a half a million dollars so it would not only have been a nice gift but a wise investment. Of course, sets of John Gould's bird books now sell in the hundreds of thousands of dollars too, so Audubon wasn't the only one.

title: Martinique: A Vain Quest for Quiet
description: PRELUDE. I am walking down Broadway with a loaf of Zabar's French bread under my arm. The wind is so cold it makes my fore head ache. A fire engine screams by spraying me with sooty slush. I am sud denly overwhelmed with desire for warn sunshine, haute cuisine and tranquillity According to the nearest travel agent the only place where these three things are currently available is Martinique. It about as much time as it took to buy the French loaf, I commit my wife and my self to a sevenday vacation.

title: POPULATION CURB IS BACKED IN POLL
description: A national opinion survey indicates that a majority of people in the United States think population and economic growth will have to be regulated, both globally and in the areas where they live, to avert resource shortages, pollution and a lowered quality of life.

title: Brooklyn Marine Pilot Killed
description: ARITON, Ala., Dec. 1 (AP)A Marine pilot from Brooklyn lied yesterday, apparently while trying to parachute from his jet airplane near here. He was identified as Lieut. Robert H. Dobrow, 27 years old. He had apparently tried to bail out of the plane before it crashed in a wooded area.

title: Crash of 727 in Harriman Park Kills 3
description: A Northwest Airlines 727, flying without passengers to pick up the Baltimore Colts football team in Buffalo, crashed into a rugged forest area near Bear Mountain last night, killing all three crewmen. It was the second fatal crash of a Boeing 727 within eight hours.

title: Alabama Doctor Honored
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 1 (UPI)Dr. Robert Parker, a pediatrician from Montgomery, Ata., received the first American Medical Association award for citizenship and community service today. Dr. Parker, who has practiced medicine in Alabama for 45 years, received the award and a $5,000 prize at the opening session of a meeting of the association's House of Delegates.

title: FORD URGED TO LOOK AT HIGHER GAS TAX
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1 (AP)The chairman of the Republican Governors Association said today that President Ford should look very carefully at proposals for an increased gasoline tax to reduce United States reliance on Middle Eastern oil.

title: $48.2Million Budget Cut Outlined by School Board
description: The Board of Education has given Mayor Beame a letter outlining $48.2million in fiscal changes it said it would make to help the city cope with budget problems.

title: 2 Churches Sign Accord Vowing a Joint Liturgy
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, Dec. 1The congregations of neighboring Episcopal and Roman Catholic parishes signed a covenant of mutual concern today at a joint service held at Our Lady of the Mountain Roman Catholic Church in this Morris County community. The covenant is believed to be the first signed in New Jersey, though similar agreements have been made between churches in other states.

title: House Reform Faces Action Today in Party Caucuses
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The biggest game of Congressional musical theirs in a quarter century opens tomorrow when members of the House of Representatives meet to jockey for the seats, of influence and power.

title: Rangers Tie Blues, 44, on Gilbert's Goal
description: Beating a young and inexperienced hockey team like the St. Louis Blues is no major achievement, but the New York Rangers couldn't do that last night on their home ice at Madison Square Garden, and so they had to settle for a 44 tie.

title: Vikings, Cardinals Qualify for Playoffs; Steelers and Patriots Falter
description: In yesterday's action around the National Football League, two teams qualified for the playoffs next month, which was the primary goal of all 26, another dropped out and two more lost again to increase anxiety among their expectant fans. Furthermore, the weather was bad in several places and customers stayed away in large numbers. Minnesota, by beating New Orleans, qualified, as did St. Louis, although the latter lost to Kansas City. Green Bay, defeated by Philadelphia, was eliminated. Pittsburgh was upset by Houston while New England bowed meekly out in Oakland.

title: Personal Finance: Flood Insurance
description: When Rapid City, a town in the Black Hills of South Dakota, was struck by heavy rains and thunderstorms twoandahalf years ago, 700 homes were destroyed and 1,700 were damaged. Yet only 27 of the houses were covered by flood insurance.

title: New Books
description: A Sounder of Swine by Patrick Buchanan (Dodd, Mead, $5.95). Tracking down a maniacal kidnapper.

title: Iran Offers to Fully Back Resumed Output of C5A's
description: Highlevel IranianAmerican talks were held in Washington last week on a recently sweetened offer by the Shah of Iran to pay for reopening the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's C5A production line and to buy 10 of the $55million military cargo planes, industry sources said yesterday.

title: SUBWAY HOLDUPS LAID TO 11 YOUTHS
description: Bronx Gang Is Said to Have Stolen $60,000 in Daily ChangeBooth Robberies

title: A.M.A. HEAD WARNS OF U.S. INTERVENTION
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 1 (UPI)Dr. Malcolm Todd, president of the American Medical Association, urged America's doctors today to uphold their professionalism but to fight Federal intervention in any proposed national health insurance programs.

title: McCrane Slated to Go on Trial Today For Third Time on TaiFraud Charge
description: Joseph M. McCrane, the former New Jersey State Treasurer, faces a new setting but some old charges today when he goes on trial for the third time.  this time in Scranton, Pa.

title: German Party Aide Narrowly Escapes Shots in His Sauna
description: FANKFURT, West Germany, Dec. 1 (Reuters)The treasurer of the Opposition Christian Democrat Party escaped unhamed in the sauna of his home at Kronberg near here when a gunman fired three short at close range through the door last night.

title: AL MOORE
description: Al Moore, an outfielder with John McGraw's Giants here in 1926 and 1927 and later, until his retirement last year, a member of the public relations department of Rheingold Beer, died of a heart attack Friday. He was 72 years old and lived in Muttontown, L. I.

title: Growing Sikh Community Celebrates 505th Anniversary of Founder's Birth
description: The metropolitan area's Sikhs, a growing community of Indian and American adherents of the 16th4entury Guru Nanak Dev Ji, celebrated the 505th anniversary of the founder's birth yesterday with hymns of praise and a feast of brotherhood.

title: Boardwalk Show Honor
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1A powerful, retriever, with a coat of rich gold, struck paydirt today at the Boardwalk Kennel Club show. The retriever, Ch. Cumming's GoldRush Charlie, was named best of 3,809 dogs at Convention Hall.

title: Democrat Wants Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) Representative Peter Kyros, Democrat of Maine, said today that he would try to force final Congressional hearings on a bill to, extend the territorial waters of the United States to 200 miles. The bill has been sponsored by several Congressmen who are afraid fishing stocks off the country's coastlines will be permanently depleted by foreign fleets that fish as close 12 miles from the shoreline.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: ROCKEFELLER IN LINE FOR ADVISORY JOB
description: President Ford has disclosed that he plans to appoint Nelson A. Rockefeller to head the Domestic Council following his expected confirmation as Vice President.

title: Boitano Captures Coney Island Walk
description: Dr. Jack Boitano of Stratford, Conn., who teachs psychology at Fairfield University, won the 64th annual 10mile Coney Island walk yesterday. The 42yearold Boitano, aided by a 32minute handicap, triumphed in 1 hour 34 minutes 43 seconds Arsene Engliss of the Short Athletic Club of West Long Branch, N.J., was second.

title: U.S. STILL WEIGHS TURKEY AID ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1After more than a month's delay, the State Department still declines to rule for Congress on whether Turkey violated United States militaryaid laws during the Cyprus conflict. Such a legal determination now would jeopardize Cyprus peace efforts, the State Department contends.

title: Flights Reported at 90% Despite Texas Airline Strike
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 1 (AP) Texas International Airlines spokesmen said that about 90 per cent of its scheduled flights were operating today despite a strike by ground personnel.

title: 80 Guests From Balanchine Country
description: They are my people, said George Balanchine, explaining why he was giving a private dinner party for 80 dancers and singers from the Soviet Republic of Georgia.

title: U.S.Golfers Win From Japanese
description: WAKAYAMA, Japan, Dec. 1 (Reuters) The United States won the fourth United StatesJapan golf tournamenk today by nine strokes but Teruo Sugihara of Japan edged Hubert Green of Birmingham, Ala., for the individual title.

title: New Mexico Starts Project to Contain Space Hall of Fame
description: ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Dec. 1 Ground was broken today for a $10million International Space Hall of Fame complex in what Gov. Bruce King described as the birthplace of the first atomic space age as he turned over the first spadeful of earth.

title: CasellatoLamberti in Debut At the Met as Cavardossi
description: The Metropolitan Opera has a new tenor, Giorgio CasellatoLamberti, and there were moments during his debut performance as Cavaradossi in Puccini's Tosca on Saturday night when he sounded as though as he might be an extraordinary acquisition.

title: Gregg Wips Auto Title At Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) John Greenwood drove his $100,000 Corvette to an easy victory in a 250mile road race here today, but Peter Gregg, who limped home far to the rear, won the International Motor Sports Association series for big bore sports cars for the second straight year.

title: RHODESIA LEADER MEETING BLACKS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec, 1Prime Minister Ian D. Smith gave a clear indication in an interview today that he is engaged in fresh talks to achieve settlement with the black majority in Rhodesia as well as an improvement of relations with his southern African neighbors.

title: Kissinger and Peking: Chinese Tactics Are Weighed.
description: TOKYO, Dec. 1  In case there is any lingering doubt, only one senior American official normally briefs newsmen on the progress of Secretary of State Kissinger's sundry negotiations.
