description: Primate, Frederick Wiseman's eighth documentary in an outstanding series examining American institutions, will be offered, on the Public Broadcasting Service tonight at 10 o'clock. Filmed at Atlanta's Yerkes Primate Research Center, a division of Emory University, the documentary uses its 105 minutes to observe researchers carrying out experiments with gorillas, orangutans, chimpanzees and monkeys. It is generally powerful. Portions are certainly memorable. And it is already embroiled in controversy.

title: Newburgh News Is Sold
description: The Gannett Company, owner of 53 daily newspapers in 17 states, said yesterday that it had sold The Newburgh (N.Y) Evening News to Thompson Newspapers, Inc., of Canada for $8million in cash and notes. The paper has a daily circulation of 30,000.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS CONFER IN ZAMBIA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 4 (Reuters)Three black African Presidents were meeting here today amid intense speculation about moves toward a Rhodesian settlement.

title: Maheu Awarded $2.8Million In Damage Suit Against Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  A Federal jury awarded Robert A. Maheu $2,823,333.30 damages today in his defamation suit against the billionaire Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation. It was one of the largest compensatory damage awards in United States judicial history.

title: CONGRESS STUDY URGES AID SHIFT HIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4(AP) tax credits, new subsistence allowances and work incentives.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Gift Contest Winner
description: Doubleyourmoneyback offers have been used over the years by packagedgoods manufacturers seeking new markets. Now one agency, Marsteller, Inc., is making a doubleyoursalary offer to Federal Trade Commission regulators of nutritional disclosures in advertising.

title: AUTO SALES FELL 33% FOR NOV.213
description: DETROIT, Dec. 4Domesti car sales fell 33.5 per cent 178,497 units in the Nov. 21to 30 period from 268,459 units year earlier, indicating no eas ing of the newcar sales slump

title: First Watergate Panel Thanked and Dismiseed
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 4 (AP)The grand jury that indicted the Watergate burglars and then the top aides of former President Richard M. Nixon was discharged today with official thanks after two and a half years of service.

title: MILLS PANEL TOLD TO BOW TO REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4With Representative Wilbur D. Mills hospitalized and effectively removed as chairman, the other Democrats on the House. Ways and Means Committee discussed this morning what appeared on its face to be a plan to counter reform and lock themselves into influential positions.

title: SenatorElect Asks Court To Oar Opponent's Appeal
description: CONCORD, N.H. Dec. 4 (UPI) SenatorElect, John Durkin, Democrat victor by 10 votes after a recount, asked a Federal judge today to block the New Hampshire Ballot Law Commission from considering an appeal from the man he defeated, Republican Louis Wyman, RN.H.

title: Esposito Assesses His Political Future
description: Amid speculation among some politicians that his days as Brooklyn Democratic leader are numbered, Meade H. Esposito insisted this week that he intended to serve until his term rends in September, 1976.

title: Two Symbionese Seeking Their 2d Change of Venue
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec, 4 (UPI)Two members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army have asked that their murder trial be moved from Sacramento to Los Angeles.

title: French Sell Saudi Arabia $800Million in Weapons
description: PARIS, Dec. 4France has signed a contract to supply $800million in arms to Saudi Arabia.

title: Albert Says Mills Won't Keep Key Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4House Speaker Carl Albert made clear today that Representative Wilbur D. Mills would not be returned as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee when the 94th Congress convents in January.

title: Martin To Fight Banning
description: Lawyers for Frank (Pancho) Martin said yesterday they would take some affirmative action before Sunday in an effort to block the horse trainer's 60day suspension.

title: 3 Guards Are Cleared in Rikers Inquiry
description: A Bronx grand jury has reported that it found no cause to indict correction officers accused of beating all 16 inmates in one section of the Adolescent Remand Detention Center on Rikers Island after an escape attempt there last January by three inmates.

title: New Governor Is Named to Head Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency
description: RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaAbdulaziz al Quraishi, an Americaneducated public administrator, has been appointed governor of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency, which manages this oil country's enormous financial reserves.

title: Advance Is Registered by Corporate Bond Prices
description: Prices moved up yesterday in the corporate, municipal and Government bond markets recovering some of the ground lost on Monday and Tuesday. The Government market was strong throughout the day with gains ranging from oneeighth of a point in the short term maturities to as much as onehalf a point in the longer maturities.

title: Hundreds of Gifts Went To School Board Employes
description: An owner of a payrollprocessing company whose dealings with the Board of Education are under state investigation has declared that the company gave Christmas gifts of perfume, umbrellas and radios to hundreds of board employes.

title: Plan of U.S. to Sell Gold Erodes Dollar And Bullion Abroad
description: PARIS, Dec. 4The American decision to auction 2 million ounces of gold from its reserve stocks on Jan. 6 depressed both gold and the United States dollar in Europe today.

title: Coal Strike Reports a Factor in Spurt
description: A report that the United Mine Workers Union had approved their new coal contract enabled the stock market to mount brief rally and finish mixed in slower trading following three losing sessions in a row.

title: STEINGUT FAVORS STATE AID TO CITY
description: ALBANY, Dec. 4 Assemblyman Stanley Steingut of Brooklyn, who is expected to be the Speaker of the Assembly after Governorelect Hugh L. Carey takes office, suggested today that the state seek to help ease the fiscal problems of New York City.

title: Trudeau Tells Ford He Plans Protective Oil Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau told President Ford today that Canada intended to pursue a more protectiver nationalist policy on energy re sources, ultimately ending the export of oil to the United States.

title: Maheu Awarded $2.8Million In Damage Suit Against Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  A Federal jury awarded Robert A. Maheu $2,823,333.30 damages today in his defamation suit against the billionaire Howard R. Hughes's Summa Corporation. It was one of the largest compensatory damage awards in United States judicial history.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MINIGLOBE TROT Today at noon the World Trade Center's annual winter festival of music, dance and exhibits from many lands opens with the 28voice Newark Boys Chorus in a onehour performance. An array of exhibitions will depict holiday traditions in Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Britain, Haiti, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malta, New Zealand, Norway, the Philippines, Poland, Rumania, Sweden and Russia.

title: SUGAR LEADS RISE IN FOOD COST HERE
description: Food prices in the city increased 1.2 per cent last week, the largest rise since list Jan. 24, when the rise was 1.4 per cent, the Consumer Affairs Department announced yesterday.

title: 14 Million Italian Worker Stage a Brief Walkout
description: ROME, Dec. 4About 14 million Italians walked off their jobs today to demand guaranteed employment, more social security benefits and higher costofliving adjustments.

title: Court Is Moot, Efforts Real In U.S. Competition Finals
description: Although the lawsuit was fictitious, the issue was timely, and hundreds of law students across the country spent weeks preparing the case. The mythical facts were these.

title: Court Is Moot, Efforts Real In U.S. Competition Finals
description: Although the lawsuit was fictitious, the issue was timely, and hundreds of law students across the country spent weeks preparing thee. case. The mythical facts were these.

title: ExAddict Lauds CourtReferral Plan
description: By and large, Richard LaManna does not think he got much out of his years in jail.

title: Baseball Talks Focusing On Seattle, Other Issues
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4The Seattle problem Is among several topics to be taken up tomorrow as the formal meetings of baseball's big leagues begin.

title: CITY PAYROLL ROSE 12,950 IN 4 MONTHS
description: The number of fulltime employes on the payroll of the City of New York increased by 12,950 in the first four months of the current fiscal year, a new set of figures from the Controller's Office showed yesterday.

title: Kuwaiti Unit in Brazil Mill
description: KUWAIT, Dec. 4 (Reuters)The Kuwait Foreign Investment Company, a nongovernmental concern, will take at least a onesixth share in a $400million wood and paper mill to be built in Brazil, the newspaper AlQabas reported today. The daily said two other countries would be involved in contributing half the capital with the Brazilian Government providing the rest.

title: Excerpts From Partial Transcripts of Conversations Between Nixon and Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4Following are excerpts from four partial transcripts of conversations between former President Richard M. Nixon and his aides that were entered into evidence today by the Watergate special prosecutor at the coverup trial:

title: EARTHY ROCKBLUES BY GREGG ALLMAN
description: Gregg Allman comes presold. The audience Wednesday night at the Felt Forum was immediately on its feet in tribute to the mystique of the Allman musical family however many Matchesthe usual endofconcert tributewere even being lighted during the opening performance by the accompanying group, Cowboy.

title: Installment Credit Shows a Small Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5Consumer installment credit rose by the smallest amount this year in October and the increase in total consumer credit was the smallest in four years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: State Enters Deer Hunt Suit
description: TRENTON, Dec. 5 (AP)The Department of Environmental Protection said today it would enter a Federal court case to protect the scheduled Great Swamp deer hunt in Morris County. Several conservation organizations have filed an injunction to block the hunt scheduled to be held Tuesday. The department contends that the killing of 300 deer is needed to reduce the deer population to a level guaranteeing their natural, survival in the Great Swamp.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Board of Estimate voted $140,000 to finance a program that employs former narcotics addicts to monitor the effectiveness of streetcleaning efforts around town.

title: Reopening of Sugar Futures Market Ordered in Paris, but Is Not Effected
description: PARIS, Dec. 5Resumption of trading in sugar futures here, halted Tuesday because of heavy speculative losses and the expulsion of a broker from the Paris Commodity Trader Association, was ordered today by Vincent Ansquer, Minister of Commerce.

title: TV Here Won't Carry Meeting of Democrats
description: No radio or television station in the New York area will provide gaveltogavel coverage of the Democratic charter convention that opens today in Kansas City, Mo.

title: Bronx Boy, 14, AccusedIn 2d Murder of a woman
description: A 14  year  old boy was charged yesterday with the multiplestabbing death of a 49yearold man during a mugging last New Year's Eve as the victim left a subway station in the South Bronx.

title: Missing Captain
description: If the court please, said John J. Wilson, attorney for H. R. Haldeman, are we trying Mr. Nixon here or Mr. Haldeman? In the context of the latest testimony, Judge John Sirica may be forgiven for initially responding: I really don't know. The Watergate trial now resembles a sinking ship whose captain has long since fled to safety. His crew is left to fend for itself. It is a case of sauve qui pent.

title: EUROPEANS WEIGH USE OF OWN ARMS
description: PARIS, Dec. 5Suggestions for a West European defense policy based on the purchase of European arms were made today at a meeting of a consultative assembly attended by Cabinet ministers and Members of Parliaments.

title: BUSINESS LOANS CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Business loans at major New York City banks continued to increase in the week ended Wednesday, but their rise was smaller than a week earlier, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: PROGRESS IS SEEN IN AFRICAN TALKS
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 5 (Reuters)Talks between three African presidents and Rhodesian black leaders were held today amid speculation that a breakthrough was near in Rhodesia's dispute with Britain over progress toward blackmajority rule.

title: Richard Whitney, 86, Dies; Headed Stock Exchange
description: Richard Whitney, the onetime president of the New York Stock Exchange who was credited with halting the Wall Street panic of 1929 but later went to prison for embezzlement, died yesterday at the home of a daughter in Far Hill's, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: Orange Restores Its Water Supply, Ending Emergency
description: ORANGE, Dec. 5 (UPI)A 34.5hour water emergency here ended today as repairmen fixed six broken sixinch water pipes and restored full water service to this Essex County city of 32,000.

title: Americans Win World Bowl
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 5The Birmingham Americans held an to win the World Football League's first championship game here tonight, the World Bowl, defeating the Florida Blazers, 2221. The Americans had run up a 220 lead in the first three quarters before the Blazers scored three touchdowns in the final period.

title: NEW COAL ACCORD VOTED AND SIGNED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5Officers of the United Mine Workers signed a new threeyear labor contract with the coal industry today, officially ending the 24day miners' strike at midnight tonight.

title: Milk Substitutes Provide Public With a Way out
description: Supermarkets in the New York area made big displays of milk substitutes yesterday, an ticipating that there may be a big demand for them as a result of the milk strike. But many had refrigerator cases full of milk and cream cartons.

title: Democrats Draft a Charter for Party
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 5 A key committee of the Democratic charter conference, beat back today all attempts to disturb a fragile spirit of conciliation on, the eve of the socalled miniconvention's opening session.

title: Mrs. William Randolph Hearst, Widow of Publisher, Dead at 92
description: Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Sr., the widow of the publisher who died in 1951, died yesterday afternoon at her home, 4 East 66th Street. She was 92 years old.

title: CHALLENGE TO BID BY HUNTS DENIED
description: Attorneys for Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt of Dallas said yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit had denied a petition by the Great Western United Corporation to restrain the brothers from buying 910,000 shares of Great Western stock at $27.50 a share.

title: Charles Webster d'Autremont Marries Elena Beatriz Bellizzi
description: Elena Beatriz Bellizzi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horacio G. Bellizzi of Buenos Aires, and Charles Webster d'Autremont, son of Mrs. Eustis Dearborn of New York and Sandwich, Mass., were married Wednesday evening in Buenos Aires in the Basilica del Santisimo Sacramento, where the bride's parents and grandparents also were married.

title: Business Briefs
description: Two major oil companies announced yesterday wage increases of 7 per cent and 8 per cent for all nonunion employes, The Associated Press reported.

title: STATE URGED TO END MEAT INSPECTIONS
description: TRENTON, Dec. 5 (AP)The state Consumer Health Services Director, Dr. Oscar Sussman, says New Jersey could save about $500,000 a year by scrapping its meat and poultry inspection program and letting the Federal Government do the job.

title: DELEGATES REJECT PROPOSALS
description: The American Medical Association's House of Delegates has rejected a series of recommendations by the association's board of trustees, including proposals to eliminate advertising in its professional journals, increase membership dues and disband a number of A.M.A. councils and committees.

title: Italy's Senate Gives Vote of Confidence To New Government
description: ROME, Dec. 5The Italian Senate today voted its confidence in the Government of Premier Aldo Moro. The vote was 190 to 113.

title: Index Is Within 3 Points of Its Lowest Close in More Than 12 Years
description: The stock market continued yesterday to react to negative economic news, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing within less than 3 points of its lowest close in more than 12 years.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Beame to Seek a Budget Minimizing City U. Cuts
description: Mayor Beame has agreed to work for a $654.4million expense budget for the City University of New York next year, an increase of $69million over the current budget, but $38million less than the Board of Higher Education requested.

title: State Ranks Insurers of Cars According to Valid Complaints
description: More justified consumer complaints were lodged against the Government Employees Insurance Company's handling of auto insurance claims in 1973 than against any other company, the New York State Insurance Department said yesterday in releasing what it called a hit parade.

title: As Pianists Vary, JPJ Quartet Puts Others to the Fore
description: For a group that has been together for more than four years, the JPJ Quartet has had surprising difficulty in settling on an identity. The root of the problem goes back to the ensemble's origin: Budd Johnson, tenor and soprano saxophonist; Bill Pemberton, bassist, and Oliver Jackson, drummer, who had been the supporting members of a quartet formed by Earl Hines for an overseas tour, decided to stay together after the tour with another pianist taking Mr. Hines's place.

title: Black Judge Rejects Move To Bar Him From Race Case
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (UPI) A black Federal judge today rejected a union petition that asked that he disqualify himself from trying a racial discrimination suit without a jury on the ground he could not give unbiased resolution of the issues.

title: Canadian Arts Centre Orchestra Fine but Cool Here
A PROFESSOR SUES TO GET F.B.I. FILES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) A Smith College professor has accused the Federal Bureau of Investigation director, Clarence M. Kelley, of ignoring a Justice Department rule and his own promise to yield secret files on the Alger Hiss and Julius Rosenberg cases.

title: SIRICA BARS DELAY IN COVERUP TRIAL; NIXON IS EXCUSED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 5 United States District Judge John J. Sirica ruled today that former President Richard M. Nixon need not testify either on the witness stand or through deposition in the Watergate coverup trial.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE RACE ONCE AGAIN IN DOUBT
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 5 (AP) Apparently defying a Federal court order, New Hampshire's allRepublican Executive Council rescinded today the certification of John A. Durkin, a Democrat, as the state's new United States Senator.

title: PIETRO GERMI, 60, ITALIAN DIRECTOR
description: ROME, Dec. 5Pietro Germi, the film director who gained; fame in the United States for his Oscarwinning Divorce, Italian Style, died of hepatitis today in a clinic here. He was 60 years old.

title: VIRGINIA C. LAVELLE
description: Virginia C. Lavelle, executive assistant in the Ford Foundation's division of humanities and arts, died of cancer Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital, She was 43 years old and lived at 45 Tudor City Place.

title: Railincrease Authorized
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the nation's railroads yesterday to increase freight rates by 4 per cent on recyclable commodities, such as iron and steel scrap. The increase, which can be applied on 15 days' notice, has applied on other commodities since last March. The March increase, which had been on an interim basis, was made permanent yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: LIONS AND FOXES: Men and Ideas of the Italian Renaissance. By Sidney Alexander. 375 pages. Illustrated. Macmillan. $12.95. First, the good news: We are all creatures of the Renaissance. Etymologically, all Americans are Florentines. This is a warm thought, while crossing the East River on the BMT instead of the Arno River on foot rover the Ponte Vecchio. Now the news that, may not be ass good: More fundamentally, we are all Creatures of the Renaissance mentality. That takes some thinking over: Can we Medicis stand you Borgias?

title: Sabotage Laid to Industry On Securities Reform Bill
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 5Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, accused the securities industry here today of sabotaging a reform bill that, among other things, would have forced stock brokers to stop charging fixed commission fees.

title: McCrane's Jury Is Told By I.R.S. of Tax Violations
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 5 (AP) An Internal Revenue Service agent testified today that money identified as contributions to former New Jersey Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign was deducted as business expenses from the tax returns of nine corporations.

title: Students Continue Protest Over, Jobs at Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L. L, Dec. 5 More than 300 students protesting budget cuts at the State University here continued their sitin at the administrative office despite a promise by afftclais to restore cuts affecting student jobs and housing for married students.

title: BRITISH MAY RAISE AID TO ROLLSROYCE
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP)The British Government today announced further financial aid to RollsRoyce, Ltd. for development of a more powerful version of the controversial RB211 engine for use in Boeing jumbo jets. But it made the offer conditional on further sales.

title: State Democrats Convene on Flight 95
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 5 Flight 95 from New York had roast chicken and pizza on the menu, and Robert F. Wagner, Stanley Steingut and Albert Shenker in the passenger compartment.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Governorelect Hugh Carey presented the Lambert Trophy, symbolic of Eastern football supremacy, to Joe Paterno, coach of Penn State's football team, yesterday. This ceremony at a luncheon in the Roosevelt Hotel marked the 11th time Penn State had won the big trophy.

title: Red Smith
description: Pancho Martin had saddled 133 winners at New York race tracks this year before the stewards gave him two months off to read up on apothecary medicine, so even the suspension stands he will still wind up with more victories in a single season than any other trainer who ever worked the big wheel. The record he broke, 129 winners, was set 38 years ago by the late Hirsch Jacobs not long after that little redhead had joined Isidor and Phil Bieber in one of racing's most successful partnerships. Jacobs had been training for Louis Mascia of Hamilton, Ontario, and in order to get him the Biebers bought Mascia's whole string of 14 horses.

title: Knick's LineUp
description: AT PHILADELPHIA TVCHANNEL 9,8 P.M.

title: Cavaliers, Top Kings By 12491
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 5 (AP) Dwight Davis and Bobby Smith combined for 43 points to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 12491 victory over the Kansas City  Omaha Kings in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: G.M. Layoffs Set at Two Units; Closings Planned by Burlington
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Dec. 5 (AP) The Saginaw Steering Gear division of the General Motors Corporation will lay off 458 hourly employes indefinitely tomorrow. It represents 5 per cent of the division's work force.

title: Spain Sentences Croatians In 1972 Hijacking of Jet
description: MADRID, Dec. 5 (AP)  A military court sentenced three Croatian nationalists today to 12 years in prison for having hijacked a Scandinavian Airlines System jetliner from Sweden to Spain two years ago.

title: West Virginia's Miners Could Prolong Walkout
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., Dec. 5 many younger miners who voted against the new coal contract, Fred Linksweiler guessed he would go back when his mine opened. But that did not mean he was praising the contract the United Mine Workers signed this morning.

title: Concert
description: The Guarneri String Quartet hardly needs assistants to guarantee the effectiveness of its performances, but Wednesday night at Tully Hall the group had Barry Tuckwell, the born virtuoso, and Walter Trampler, the violist, as guests for a concert in the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series.

title: Two Suicides Follow Arrest
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 5 (UPI) A 50yearold mother and her 21yearold son committed suicide Tuesday, the day after he was arrested for possession and conspiracy to sell cocaine, the police said. James Henry Hebb and his mother, Mary F. Hebb, were found on the floor of their home after a friend telephoned the police.

title: Advertising
description: In their public and private pronouncements, advertising agency executives seem to agree that in the financially troubled times ahead clients are going to be demanding more and better service from their agencies.

title: MobileHorne Owners Mobilizing Info Suffolk's
description: HOLBROOK, L.LThe mobilehomeowners were not activists when they started. Mostly they were people of limited income, trying to solve their housing needs as best they could. But some of them are activists now.

title: 6 Firemen Injured in a Blaze In Bronx Apartment House
description: A threealarm fire swept through the top two floors of a sixstory brick apatment building in the Tremont section of the Bronx last night, injuring six firemen, one seriously.

title: SUIT ON 3 CONCERNS IN TRANSPORT FILED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) The Justice Department today accused three major transporters of mobile homes with illegal price fixing and monopoly.

title: Congress Urged by Burns To Delay Gold Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5Disagreeing with the Secretary of the Treasury, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board told Congress today that it was a mistake to permit Americans to own gold starting Dec. 31.

title: Store Sales Off 6%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Department of Commerce said today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.04billion, down 6 per cent from the year earlier $1.05billion. Total retail store sales were about $10,27billion, up 6 per cent from last year's $10.02billion.

title: BANG, BOOooom, ThumP, EEEK, tinkle
description: The popular concept of noise pollution is a dangerously misleading one. In reality, dangers to hearing do exist in prolonged, excessively loud sound levels. However, the residue of the idea that has ended up in the mind of the public because of misleading pubs licity is that sound in general is harmful to people.

title: Questions and Answers on the Vladivostok Strategic Arms Deal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The SovietAmerican nuclear arms agreement negotiated two weeks ago at. Vladivostok has been hailed by the. Ford Administration as a cap on the arms race and attacked by its critics as, in effect, permitting that race to continue.

title: Books of The Times
description: LIONS AND FOXES: Men and Ideas of the Italian Renaissance. By Sidney Alexander. 375 pages. Illustrated. Macmillan. $12.95.

title: People and Business
description: Gumersindo Rodriguez, Minister of Planning for Venezuela, said yesterday that his nation was using some of its oil revenues to support the price of coffee.

title: Islanders Tie With 0:09 Left
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 5Coach Red Kelly should have lent his bullwhip to Al Arhour, the Islander coach, tonight as New York barely managed a 33 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs. Ralph Stewart scored the equalizing goal for New York with nine seconds left before a crowd of 12,423.

title: Stocks Drop on Amex and OT C For the Fourth Time in a Row
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the OvertheCounter market fell again yesterday for the fourth session as bullish news continued to be scarce.

title: CHOU SERIOUSLY ILL, AIDE TELLS VISITOR
description: TOKYO, Dec. 5 (Reuters)Premier Chou Enlai's health has been found worse than originally thought and he is limited to dealing with very important issues, Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping was quoted today as having told a visitor.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Sworn In
description: LONDON, Dec. 5 (Reuters) The Most Rev. Donald Coggan was confirmed and sworn in today as the 101st Archbishop of Canterbury and spiritual leader of the world's 65 million Anglicans.

title: Milk Out
description: The strike that has shut off the city's supply of fresh milk hits hard at the health of children and invalids, even though such walkouts no longer bring the kind of emergency they did in the days before powdered milk and other substitutes had become easily available.

title: Albert W. Harris Jr. Dies at 45; Chief Angela Davis Prosecutor
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Dec. 5 (AP)Albert W. Harris Jr., the California assistant attorney general who was chief prosecutor in the trial of Angela Davis, died last night. He was 45 years old.

title: Wiseman to Make Yes Yes, No No, First Fiction Film
description: Frederick Wiseman, the producerdirector whose documentary Primate was seen last night on Channel 13, is preparing to make his first fiction film in the style of his often, controversial factual movies.

title: Harvester Dividend Raised
description: The International Harvester Company announced yesterday that it was increasing its regular quarterly dividend to 42 cents a common share from 37 cents. The dividend is payable Jan. 15 to shareholders of record Dec. 16.

title: Aid for Novice Skiers On Way
description: Convinced that recreational skiing's growth is being curtailedat least partlyby the large number of beginners who become dropouts because of impersonal early contact with the sport a top official of a major skiwear tre??ment in their and equipment importing firm is doing something about it.

title: Howard C. Harder, 58, Of CPC International
description: Howard C. Harder, chief executive officer until last year of CPC International, Inc., food manufacturers, died at Fort Worth on Monday at the age of 58.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1974

title: Owners Picked for 2 New N.F.L. Clubs
description: The National Football League awarded its expansion Seattle franchise yesterday to a group, of businessmen headed by Lloyd W. Nordstrom and gave the Tampa franchise to a Florida, attorney, Hugh F. Culverhouse.

title: House Panel Ends Rockefeller Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The House Judiciary Committee completed its hearings today on the VicePresidential nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller, which now seems certain to be approved by both houses of Congress.

title: Marilyn Dubow a Standout Violinist
description: Players in symphony orchestras frequently lose their musical identity, but this doesn't seem to be the case with Marilyn Dubow. A violinist with the New York Philharmonic, Miss Dubow not only returns to the recital stage from time to time but also clod so with her artistic temperament intact and her powers of personal projection undimmed.

title: TV: Looking at Those That Weren't Specials
description: Following the bombardment of specials over the last few weeks, it's time to comment on. several programs that, for a variety of reasons, were overlooked in this space:

title: Major Leagues Set Up Expansion Committee
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5The American and National Leagues created their first joint committee on baseball expansion today to avoid what one club owner denounced as the stupidity of the past.

title: Trial of a Seabee Who Tossed a Pie Hears Soupy Sales
description: PORT HUENEME, Calif., Dec. 5A young Seabee who threw a chocolate cream pie in his company commander's face to relieve the battalion's boredom and raise morale went on trial here today on charges of assault and battery. The first witness was the comedian Soupy Sales, who said he was an expert on the entertainment value of plethrowing.

title: Weekly Rail Freight Traffic Off 25% From '73 Level
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Association of American Railroads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Nov. 30 totaled an estimated, 12.8 billion tonmiles, 25.6 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. The week was affected by the Thanksgiving Day holiday, and also by the coal strike.

title: RALPH E. BEVER
description: Ralph Emerson Bever, of The Observer, a weekly newspaper in Kearny, N. J., died there yesterday at West Hudson Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Bob Hope got tied up in traffic yesterday and arrived at a WaldorfAstoria lunch almost too late to receive the Salvation Armys 1974 Citation of Merit. More than 2,500 members of the. Salvation Army and their guests were on hand for presentation of the award, which has gone in previous years to such recipients as Bernard M. Baruch, Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Rev. Billy Graham, Lyndon B. Johnson, David Sarnoff and Helen Hayes. The citation lauded Mr. Hope for his courage and gaietya man happy inside himself; for his love of church, family, nation and world. Serious as the occasion was, the comedian couldnt resist telling his audience. I am deeply grateful to the Salvation Army for handout.

title: Thompson Gets 57 for N.C. State
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 5 (AP)David Thompson broke an Atlantic Coast Conference individual scoring record for a single game tonight with 57 points, and topranked North Carolina State rolled over Buffalo State, 14488.

title: BEEF STEW RECALLED AFTER WOMAN DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The Department of Agriculture warned consumers today against eating a beef stew sold under the Kroger label that could have been contaminated with botulism. A can of the product caused the death of a woman in Georgia.

title: DECONTROL URGED BY GAS INDUSTRY
Nutley Mother Alters Plea In Beating Death of Infant
description: NEWARK, Dec. 5A 23yearold Nutley woman, who with her husband is charged with murder in the beating death of the couple's 13monthold son last June, today amended her plea of not guilty to not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: French Diplomats Seized In Mexico, Then Released
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 5A gunman held three French diplomats hostage for five hours in the French consulate here today before he was disarmed by police.

title: CapesSwirling, Floating, Sailing Before the Wind
description: Long, monastic capes. Sumptuous fur ones. Neat gray flannel or camel hair ones. Bright fringed ponchos knitted by loving hands at home. Although on a windy day, they tend to propel the wearers like sailboats, women love the swashbuckling drama of lots of material to toss around. This year, when designers are being especially prodigal with fabric, there are capes galore to be had.

title: Mills Panel Is Told By House Leaders It Can Reorganize
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5Senior Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee reasserted their temporarily dormant power today to quell further efforts within the House to limit their authority.

title: Garden StateKeystone Battle A Losing One for Both Tracks
description: With both sides accusing the other of greediness, New Jersey and Pennsylvania prepared yesterday for a fivemonth continuation of their thoroughbredracing conflict.

title: MRS. C. J. REID. JR.
description: Frances Hardin Reid, wife of Cornelius J. Reid Jr., chairman of the board of RBH/Reid & Carr, Inc., died yesterday at her home on Horseshoe Road in Mill Neck, L. I. She was 43 years old.

title: SEARS AND PENNEY HAVE LAG IN SALES

Yesterday the journalistchronicler  novelist  lecturer was at a great divide, 75 years into his own century, and forgetting thee surpassing moment as though birthdays were commonplaces on life's long match.

title: Kissinger's Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 5Henry Kissinger seems a bit depressed these days, and no wonder. Things are not going well for him in the Congress. He got very little help from Leonid Brezhnev at Vladivostok on the deepening crisis in the Middle East. His latest trip to Peking was less productive than any of the others, and even where he felt real progress was made on the strategic arms talks and the Japanese visithe got a poor press.

title: Curbing Urban Cutups

Lazar has announced planslong overdueto crack down on utility companies that have been cutting up city streets with scant concern for the convenience and comfort of the people who have to use them.

description: ROME, Dec. 5Pietro Germ the film director who gain fame in the United States to his Oscarwinning Divorce Italian Style, died of hepatiti today in a clinic here. He was 60 years old.

title: Screen: 'The Hostages':Molinaro Directs an Action Thriller
description: Building apprehension in an audience requires a particular skill; quite often, we need to be nervous about the combination of personalities and their sudden responses to one another, their capacity for violence of craziness, in order to give a hoot about who gets chased or shot. Edouard Molinaro's "The Hostages," playing today and tomrrow at the First Avenue Screening Room, is an unusually intelligent action picture, partly because it stresses how dangerous a self-destructive persons can be.The movie is based on a recent case in France. A drifter with a fearfully short fuse falls in and out of prison; between assaults and armed robberies, he marries a call girl and the hold-ups continue until they're arrested. Then, they take a judge hostage to bargain for their release. Their ruthless teamwork has none of the sentimentally that oozed through "Bonnie and Clyde." Here, the tension between the hard-headed practicality and the extreme carelessness of the outlaws yields an intriguing characterization.Daniel Cauchy and Bulle Ogier are first-rate as the pair on the prowl. His forlorn ??? face when he pulls a weapon or gets nabbed, established the deadly unpredictability of his character. Meanwhile, she's deceptively cherubic; that sweet little face masks a completely brutal nature. This beguiling waif is even more lethal than her husband, even though he's crazed and she is not.The plot thins in invention toward the end, so the suspense is muted. But there are many fine details, including a scene where some hoods devastate a bar with gaudy spray paint, to punish the proprietor. And I liked the man who's reluctant to surrender his beloved new car to the famous fugitives; as he protests that it's not broken in, that the monthly payments aren't finished, it's clear that his wheels are more important to him than his life. It's that kind of deft absurdity that gives "The Hostages" its special dimensions.

title: G.I. WHO RESISTED HAIR RULE FREED

Sheila Lynn Morales will get an initial $235,000 payment, $15,000 a year for life and guaranteed payment of medical bills. The defendanis are three pharmaceutical companies and four doctors.

title: Scouts' Wing Suspended
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 5 (UPI)The Kansas City Scouts today suspended and fined a rookie left wing, Glen Burdon, for leaving the National Hockey League club without permission while on a road trip.

title: Islanders Tie With 0:09 Left
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 5Coach Real Kelly should have lent his bullwhip to Al Arbour, the Islander coach, tonight as New York barely managed a 33 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs. Ralph Stewart scored the equalizing goal for New York with nine seconds left before a crowd of 12,423.

title: Congemi Triumphs In Figure Skating
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 5Ken. Congemi, a 12yearold from Commack, L.I., won the juvenile boys title today in the North Atlantic figure skating championships at the Twin Rinks Arena.

title: ALLEGED RAPIST, 22, WOUNDED BY VICTIM
description: WHITTIER, Calif., Dec. 5 (UPI)A woman who said she had been raped chased the alleged assailant through her home, firing five pistol shots Into him, in the third such incident in California in recent months.

title: Doar Opposes Broadcasts
description: NEW NEW HAVEN, Dec. 5 (AP), John M. Doar, who served as, majority counsel for the House Judiciary Committee during its impeachment proceedings earlier this year, said tonight that he was opposed to the broadcast of White House tapes that have been played at they Watergate coverup trial.

title: London Assurance Storms the Palace
description: The British occupation of the Broadway theater continues apace. The Royal Shakespeare Company, which already has a Manhattan detachment playing Sherlock Holmes, last night captured the Palace Theater with its London assurance. Or rather its play,London Assurance, opened at the Palace Theater. In February, yet a third Royal Shakespeare Company is to advance into Brooklyn. How many companies can it have left in England.

title: Ford Sets Day of Prayer
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. (UPI) President Ford today designated Dec. 18 as a national day of prayer and urged Americans to observe it by praying for the strength and will to meet the challenges that face us. Mr. Ford took the action in a Presidental proclamation at the request of Congress, which has directed similar actions annually since 1952.

title: ProTransactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Major Leagues Set Up Expansion Committee
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5The American and National Leagues created their first joint committee on baseball expansion today to avoid what one club owner denounced as the stupidity of the past.

title: Bridge: Midwesterner Is Far Ahead For 2d Title at San Antonio
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 5  An expert from the Middle West headed confidently for his second title in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: Horowitz to Give Recitals In April but Not on Dec. 15
description: Vladimir Horowitz had at one time hoped to repeat his Nov. 17 recital program at the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 15, with the first tickets to be made available for the approximately 1,000 people who had stood in line and failed to get seats for the first recital.

title: 3 Coast Guardsmen In a '57 Car Killed On East River Drive
description: Three young Coast Guardsmen stationed on Governors Island were killed in an automobile accident last night on East River Drive in Lower Manhattan.

title: Queens Nursing Home's Profit Studied
description: The State Welfare Inspector General, William F. Meyers, made public yesterday a report on a Queens nursing home that he estimated was, averaging 40 per cent a year in profit on investment.

title: RALPH E. BEVER
description: Ralph Emerson Bever, of The Observer, a weekly newspaper in Kearny, N. J., died there yesterday at West Hudson Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: EXPERTS DISCUSS PIONEER'S FINDINGS
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Dec. 5  From evidence collected by Pioneer 11 in the last few days it appears that, if the envelope of magnetically enslaved particles around Jupiter were visible from the earth, it would cover an area of the sky at least four times as large as the moon.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A Danish Election Is Called as Parties Rebuff Wage Plan
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 5 (UPI)  Premier Poul Hartling today called for general elections on Jan. 9.

title: ETHICS UNIT DELAYS HONSERRAT INQUIRY
description: The city's Board of Ethics announced yesterday that it would await the outcome of other investigations now under way before proceeding with its own inquiry into whether Joseph Monserrat, a member of the Board of Education, was involved in a conflict of interest in connection with the award of a board contract in 1971 to a company for which he had been a paid consultant.

title: COMMUNISTS ATTACK POST NEAR SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 6 (Reuters)Communist troops attacked an outpost 10 miles southwest of the center of Saigon, then ambushed a Government relief column trying to reach it early today, military sources said.

title: U.S. URGED TO END TIE TO FOSSIL FUEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5The United States should begin now to prepare for the day when the nation can no longer depend on oil and natural gas, a Government expert on energy research said today.

title: Fewer Feel Byrne is Doing Job Well, Institute Poll Finds
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 5Fewer New Jerseyans believe Brendan T. Byrne is doing an excellent or good job as Governor, according to a survey by the Eagleton Institute of Politics.

title: Moscow and Peking Clash At U.N. Debate Charter
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5Some of, the strongest exchanges of charges and countercharges heard during the current General Assembly session are taking place between the Soviet Union and China in the usually staid Legal Committee this week.

title: Suns Down Warriors In Overtime
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., (AP)Dennis Awtrey's 18foot shot with 1 minute 29 seconds to go in the second overtime proved to be the margin that gave the Phonix Suns a 108106 National Basketball Association victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight.

title: Coal Strike. Impact Diminished By Already Depressed Economy
description: The nationwide coal miners's strike, which halted production of nearly 70 per cent of United States coal for three weeks, had only a slight impact upon the economy over all, Government officials and business economists said yesterday.

title: Soft Numbers Figure in BudgetDeficit Fight
description: For ordinary citizens of New York, the art of making budget projections, as practiced by their public officials, is as arcane as the technique of spinning prayer wheels in Tibetan lamaseries.

title: CECILE B. WERTHEIM
description: Cecile Berlage Wertheim, widow of Maurice Wertheim, investment banker, died here Tuesday at the age of 73. She lived at 43 East 70th Street.

title: WILDERNESS AREAS PROPOSED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)President Ford virtually wrapped up yesterday the executive branch's role under the 1964 Wilderness Act by urging Congress to add nine million acres to the federally owned property set aside to be kept in a wild, unspoiled condition.

title: Ford, Schmidt Confer
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6West German Chancellor Helmunt Schmidt said today President Ford had told him the Administration expected the current recession in the United States to reach its lowest point by next summer and then begin to turn upward after that.

title: BICENTENNIAL PANEL PLANS PHOTO MATCH
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The New Jersey Bicentennial Commission has announced a statewide competition for professional and amateur cameramen.

title: Sugar Workers Back Pact
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (UPI)Sugar field workers in Hawaii have approved a wage reopener settlement that would give them a $33.50 weekly increase during the next 26 months, the International Longshoremen's and warehousemen's Union reports. The union newspaper, The Dispatcher, said yesterday the settlement would provide an immediate $1,000 bonus, a similar bonus next year and an additional 65centsanhour rise in February, 1976.

title: Cattlemen Begin Drive to Protest U.S. Farm Policies
description: PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 6 (UPI)A caravan of ranchers and 47 head of cattle hit the concrete trail to Washington today to carry their protest against high costs, low profits and Federal farm policies to Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz.

title: 3 Foods Face Curbs On Contaminants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Food and Drug Administration proposed today a set of food regulations designed to control the contamination of fish by mercury and reduce the contamination of evaporated milk by lead and of peanuts by cancercausing substances called aflatoxins.

title: INCREASE LOOMS IN PRICE OF COAL
description: As a result of the new coal miners' contract agreement, electric utilities and steel producers will be asked to pay producers $3 to $10 more per ton of coal than at present, the head of the Bituminous Coal Operators Association said yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States warned the United Nations that support for it in Congress and among the American people is eroding. Speaking in the General Assembly, John A. Scali, the chief United States delegate, criticized the recent organization's drift toward dominance by a broad coalition of developing countries, including very small ones, backed by the Communist powers, Mr. Scali asserted that a recent trend in the United Nations to adopt onesided, unrealistic resolutions that cannot be implemented was accelerating, and he said there was a new threata growing tendency by the United Nations to flout its own charter. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 6 (AP)Bjorn Borg played his best tennis since arriving in Australia from Sweden and gained a straightset victory today over Uli Marten of West Germany in the quarterfinals of the South Australian lawn tennis championships. Borg, the topseeded player, won, 61, 61, to join Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, Onny Parun of New Zealand and Colin Dibley of Australia in the semifinals. Dibley beat Bob Giltinan of Australia, 76, 46, 97; Metreveli defeated Chris Letcher of Australia, 67, 75, 97, and Parun ousted Uli Pinner of West Germany, 62, 64.

title: People and Business Banker Sees Hope Amid Gloom
description: A French banking visitor to the United States, shunning the gloom that marks most current economic talk these days, has delivered an encouraging word for a change. Pierre Ledoux, chairman of the Banque Nationale de Parts, sees at least three, factors that brighten the outlook.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Students Protest Stony Brook Cutbacks

title: Expiration Due Dec. 31
description: A lastditch effort is expected to be made next week by the House Agriculture Committee to keep the expiring Sugar Aci alive. According to industry reports yesterday, a threeor sixmonth extension is to be proposed in order to maintain existing quotas on sugar imports and subsidies to domestic sugargrowers.

title: Detroit Will Not Buy Any More A.M.C. Cars
description: DETROIT, Dec. 6 (UPI)Mayor Colemin A. Young said today the City of Detroit will no longer buy American Motors Corporation cars because the company is moving its headquarters from the city.

title: Plain Dealer Talks Resume
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 (UPI)Negotiations between the management of The Cleveland Plain Dealer, Ohio's largest newspaper, an dstriking members of the Newspaper Guild resumed today following a 14day break. The Guild struck the morning newspaper on Nov. 1 after Union members voted to reject management's only contract offer, a threeyear pact providing for a total weekly pay raise of $62 for topscale newsmen.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: MILK SETTLEMENT PROVING ELUSIVE
description: Milk dealers and their striking employes were reported late yesterday to be close to an agreement on a new contract following the second day of the walkout, which has seen New Yorkers scurrying to buy diminishing milk supplies.

title: Italy Clears U.S. Newsman Of Faking His Kidnapping
description: ROME, Dec. 6A Rome court today acquitted an American newsman, Jack L. Begon of charges of Paving faked his own kidnapping.

title: Pentagon Chief Sees Pact Leading to Arms BuildUp
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the proposed new arms agreement with the Soviet Union would lead to larger strategic forces than previously planned by the United States,

title: Man With a Cause Tells It in Signs
description: Harry Britton is one of those people who stand out in a crowd. First and foremost, there are his signsloud orange and chartreuse signsthat he wears from head to toe on the streets of Manhattan, proclaiming his belief in Husband Liberation.

title: Layoffs Increasing In Variety of Fields
description: Layoffs in a wide variety of industries were disclosed yesterday.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Dec. 6, 1974

title: PRICE INDEX ERROR MAY LOWER WAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) The Labor Department said today that it had discovered an error in its Consumer Price Index calculations that could mean that the takehome pay for millions of workers in future months will be lower than expected.

title: A New a Must Be Found to Safeguard Medical Privacy
description: In a curious way, the publicity given to the breast surgery of Betty Ford and Margaretta Rockefeller seems to be related to the Watergateinduced need to tell the truth and nothing but the truth, instantly and preferably on color TV

title: Christmas Tree Is Hit By Car at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI)The state of Michigan presented the 1974 White House Christmas tree to Betty Ford today.

title: Effort Pressed to Unify Rhodesia Blacks
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 6 Three African Presidents today continued efforts to bind Rhodesia's splintered black nationalist movement into a unified front that could hold new constitutional talks with the white minority Government of the former British colony.

title: Wife Sued Over Sex Change
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 6 (AP)  A 54yearold, Lodi man thought he married a 24yearold North Bergen woman last April, but now he wants a divorce because he found out he married a 24yearold North Bergen man. In court papers filed here, Louis J. Davenport, sued for divorce, saying that he had been unaware that his wife, the former Brenda A. Adams, had undergone a sex change operation and was not capable of having marital relations.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN MILK WALKOUT
description: Milk dealers and their striking employes reached tentative accord early today that brought prospects for an end of the twoday walkout tomorrow and resumption of deliveries to the city and Long Island by Monday.

title: AMBROSE J. KENNEDY
description: Ambrose J. Kennedy of 7915 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, an advertising art director and a member of the Pratt Insitute staff for 20 years, died Wednesday at the Veteran's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Minneapolis Editor Named
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 6 (UPI) Lee Canning, managing editor of The Minneapolis Star since 1972, was named executive editor of the newspaper effective today.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 6.5 PER CENT, HIGHEST SINCE '61
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The nation's unemployment rate shot up in November for the third consecutive month and reached 6.5 per cent of the labor force, the highest rate in 13 years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Likely Heir to Mills
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6It's kind of like running a relay race, Representative Al Ullman said a few years ago when Representative Wilbur D. Mills was in the hospital and Mr. Ullman was in charge of the House Ways and Means Committee. As long as I have the baton, I run with it, and when the chairman comes back, I'll pass the baton to him.

title: Water Tunnel Work Is Halted; 1,100 to Be Laid Off Monday
description: Builders of the city's Third Water Tunnel halted work yes terday after refusal by the Board, of Estimate on Thursday to approve greatly increased payments to the sixcompany consortium that is digging the 13.7mile tunnel 600 feet be low ground.

title: Miss Austin, Judy MeisterShoot 69's for Golf Lead
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 (AP)Two American outsiders, Debbie Austin and Judy Meister, broke the women's course record with 69's today for the openinground lead in the Far East golf tournatnent.

title: Defiance in District 9
description: The defiant rhetoric of those parents and auxiliary school employes who hive occupied the offices of Community School District 9 in the Bronx cannot obscure the fact that it Is they, and not the central Board Education, whose actions violate the principle of school decentralization.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX CONTINUE DECLINE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market continued their downward trend for the fifth straight session yesterday.

title: Loughlin Runners Win
description: Bishop Loughlin High School swept three events in the Monsignor Farrell Catholic schools winter relays yesterday on Staten Island, Loughlin won the fourmile relay in 18 minutes 19.1 seconds. and and also captured the sophomore fourmile and freshman twomile events. The fastest onemile split was a 4:25 by John Dowicyan of Sacred. Heart.

title: Britain Plans Partial Nationalization And Massive Help for Leyland Motor
description: LONDON, Dec. 6  The Government announced plans today for partial nationalization and massive financial assistance for the British Leyland Motor Corporation, one of the nation's largest industrial enterprises, to a, alleviate the company's severe cash shortage.

title: Retroactive Benefit Checks Will Go to Veterans Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The Veterans Administration is preparing to distribute $300million in retroactive G.I. education benefits and says it hopes to deliver most of the 1.2 million checks by Christmas.

title: U.S. WARNS U.N. ON TREND TO TYRANNY OF MAJORITY AND SAYS SUPPORT WANES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 6  The United. States warned the United Nations today that support for it in Congress and among the American people was eroding.

title: Bills' Ferguson Wants No. 1
description: Through a maze of criteria that seemed to be based on a combination of hieroglyphics and cuneiform, the Buffalo Bills have assured themselves of a spot in the American Conference playoffs. Now they'll try and dethrone the Miami Dolphins, who have been Eastern Division champions the last three years.

title: Bridal in Vermont For Nancy Conklin
description: Nancy June Conklin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard K. Conklin of Burlington, Vt., was married last evening to Dr. James A. Malcolm 3d of Burlington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Jr. of Jericho,

title: RAYMOND STITES, LEONARDO EXPERT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Raymond S. Stites, for more than 20 years the curator of education at the National Gallery of Art here and a leading scholar on Leonardo da Vinci, died tolay of a heart attack at his suburban Maryland home. He was 75 years old.

title: Narcotics Program in Harlem Is Under Scrutiny by Scoppetta
description: The City Investigations Commissioner, Nicholas Scoppetta, said yesterday that his office was looking into alleged fiscal irregularities in United Harlem Drug Fighters, a fouryearold detoxification and rehabilitation program based at Harlem Hospital.

title: HEAD OF PORT QUITS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)Edward J. King, the highest paid public official in Massachusetts, resigned his $59,500 post as executive director of the Massachusetts Port Authority today.

title: Brick Township Football Victor
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6Tony Aulisi's third placement kick provided unbeaten Brick Township High School with its 10th victory and the South Jersey Group 4 championship, a 2120 triumph over Camden tonight before 5,200 at Convention Hall.

title: BURGLARY SUSPECT LISTED AS CRITICAL
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UPI)Ralph Marrera, a suspect in the $4.3million Armored Express Company vault burglary who last week attempted suicide twice, was in critical condition today from a drug overdose.

title: SOYBEAN FUTERES DECLINE SHARPEY
description: Grain prices took a tumble, yesterday. Soybeahs led the decline in futures prioes. Traders cited the sharp, drop in the stock market as one factor, along with the increase in the unemployment rate to 6.5 per cent. Also, some Democratic party leaders, meeting in Kansas, City, indicated that they would pass a resolution urging passage of wage and price cone trols.

title: TOUGH LAW URGEDFOR JERSEY AIDESStudy of Lindenwold Graft Prompts Call for Statute
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6  The chairman of the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation declared today that the facts of official corruption in Lindenwold, a suburban borough of Camden, symbolize the democratic process of local government operating at its worst.

title: Reserve to Permit Issuing of New Bank C.D.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve Board said, today it would permit commercial banks to issue a new longterm consumer certificate of deposit paying up to 7 per cent interest a year.

title: NEW SAL CHIEF DEFENDS POLICIES
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 6One of Wall Street's chief spokesmen defended the industry here today against the strong attack made yesterday by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. The New Jersey Democrat charged that the industry had sabotaged the reform bill that would have ended price fixing.

title: Antiques: Paperweights
description: As a paperweight collector Paul Hollister may, as he insists, have been surpassed by others.

title: The Race Is On for Democrats
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6Each is going at it in his own way this unfamiliar business running for President at a convention that is not quite a convention.

title: Pentagon Chief Sees Pact Leading to Arms BuildUp
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the proposed new arms agreement with the Soviet Union would lead to larger strategic forces than previously planned by the United States.

title: Lindenwold Inquiry Told Jersey Needs Tough Conflict Law
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6  The chairman of the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation declared today that the facts of official corruption in Lindenwold, a suburban borough of Camden, symbolize the democratic process of local government operating at its worst.

title: Sampling at N.A.M.
description: Executives attending the National Association of Manufacturers annual meeting said yesterday they did not expect the current recession to bottom out until the third or fourth quarte of 1975.

title: Britain Lifting Port Fees
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)The British Transport Docks Board said today that it would raise charges at all ports by an average of 9 per cent beginning Jan. 1. The increase applies to all international traffic and will include dues on ships, goods and passengers and charges for cargo handling, the board announcement said.

title: Miller Ties for Golf Lead
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan, Dec. 6 (AP)Johnny Miller, the top moneywinner on the American tour, moved into a fourway tie for the lead today after 36 holes of the $166,666 Dunlop Phoenix golf tournament.

title: Overcharges to Medicaid Laid to 14 Nursing Homes
description: The State Health Department said yesterday that it had conducted partial audits of 14 nursing homes that it considered to be affiliated with the Bernard Bergman syndicate and had found $1,186,933 in overcharges to Medicaid.

title: Manila Reports 18 Killed
description: MANILA, Dec. 6 (AP)Official sources said today that 18 persons had been killed and 10 wounded in an ambush in central Mindanao about 500 miles south of Manila. The sources said the ambush occurred Nov. 24 in an area that has been the scene of frequent fighting in the last two years between Moslem rebels and government forces.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (Reuters)Victor Galindez of Argentina and Len Hutchins of Kalamazoo, Mich., meet here tomorrow night for the vacant World Boxing Association lightheavyweight title. It will be the third attempt by an Argentine light heavyweight in less than six months to win the title, but the first time in front of a home crowd. Jorge Ahumada lost the previous title bidsagainst Bob Foster, now retired, in Albuquerque, N.M., and against John Conteh of Britain in London for the World Boxing Council crown.

title: British Plan Control of North Sea Oil
description: LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)The British Government announced today, longterm plans to control the rate of oil production from the North, Sea, but made it clear that it wanted to leave the exploration companies a return on investment sufficient to keep them active in the area.

title: Zaharia Stancu Dies at 72; Leading Rumanian Writer
description: BUCHAREST, Dec. 6 (AgenceFrance  Presse)  Zaharia Stancu, leading Rumanian writer, died here yesterday after a long illness, the official Rumanian press agency reported today. He was 72 years old.

title: Giscard and Brezhnev Sign FiveYear Trade Pact
description: PARIS, Dec. 6President Valry Giscard d'Estaing said today that his talks here with Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev had produced agreement on all essential points.

title: Braves Conquer Blazers
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 6 (AP)Bob McAdoo scored 18 of his 38 points in the third period and Gar Heard tallied 10 of his 22 in the final period as the Buffalo Braves held off a secondhalf Portland Trail Blazers comeback for a 114105 National Basketball Association victory tonight.

title: Debate Over Proposed Standards That Would Result in Leaner Beef
description: Beef on the family dinner table may be leaner in the future, if the United States Department of Agriculture has its way.

title: 3 Foods Face Curbs On Contaminants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Food and Drug Administration proposed today a set of food regulations designed to control the contamination of fish by mercury and reduce the contamination of evaporated milk by lead and of peanuts by cancercausing substances called aflatoxins.

title: Officers' Deaths Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) A total of 119 local, state and Federal law enforcement officers were killed in the line of duty during the first 11 months of 1974, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today. This compared with 123 in the same period last year.

title: U.S. Protests Ban on Two Skiers
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 6A committee of the International Skiing Federation announced today that it had yoted to disqualify two American men skiers from the next World Cup giant slalom race because of an alleged violation of the rules before the event here yester day.

title: SAMUEL J. KAUFMAN
description: Samuel J. Kaufman, a lawyer and former chairman of the appeals board for the New Jersey Selective Service program, died yesterday. He lived at 707 North Broad Street, Elizabeth, N.J., and was 77 years old. He is survived by his widow, Anna Schwartz; a son, Norman; two brothers, and four grandchildren.

title: San Juan Paper Struck
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 6 (A.P.)The San Juan Star, Puerto Rico's only Englishlanguage daily newspaper, was shut today by a strike called by the Puerto Rico Newspaper Guild.

title: Kevin Madden Weds Christine Casson
description: Christine Casson, director of publicity for Farrar, Straus & Giroux, book publishers, was married yesterday afternoon to John Kevin Madden, advertising director of New York magazine. The Rev. Ignatius Rodrigues performed the ceremony in St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Efforts to Block Deer Hunt Fail
description: NEWARK, Dec. 6Efforts by conservationists to block a sixday deer hunt scheduled to start Tuesday in the Great Swamp of Morris County failed today when a Federal District Court judge refused to grant an injunction preventing the hunt.

title: Beame's Budget Bureau Finds a Drop In FullTime Employes Under Mayor
description: Mayor Beame's Budget Bureau said yesterday that the number of fulltime employes under mayoral jurisdiction had declined in the first four months of the current fiscal year during an austerity drive and had not increased as indicated in a computer printout produced by the Controller's office.

title: Norton Simon in Accord to Sell A Drug Unit to CarterWallace
description: Norton Simon, Inc., a diversified, company in the food spirits, and packaging field, announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its Denver Chemical Manufacturing Company subsidiary to CarterWallace, Inc. for approximately $30million in cash and notes.

title: Court Denies Bid to Halt 6Day Jersey Deer Hunt
description: NEWARK, Dec. 6Efforts by conservationists to block a sixday deer hunt scheduled to start Tuesday in the Great Swamp of Morris County failed today when a Federal District Court judge refused to grant an injunction preventing the hunt.

title: WINE TALK
description: Alfred A. Knopf Sr., We publisher, held a small lunch last week as an occasion to try some very rare clarets of the 1945 vintage. A few days later, Peter Sichel gave a dinner party for Emile Peynaud, a famous French oenologist.

title: The Insistent Theme in China Now Is Unity
description: Notes on China

title: California Police Discover Thieves Are Stealing Sugar
description: OAKLAND, Calif. (UPI)The high cost of sugar is creating new brand of thievery.

title: Trial of '71 Charges is Ordered For 4 ExJackson Twp. Aides
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6 (AP)A state appeals court ruled today that four former Jackson Township Committeemen accused of extortion have not been denied a speedy trial, though it has been nearly four years since they were first charged and the case has still not gone to trial.

title: SCHOOL TRUSTEE STILL LOCKED OUT
description: School principals and the district superintendent in Community School District 9 in the Bronx pledged loyalty yesterday to Chancellor Irving Anker's appointed trustee, but he remained locked out of the district's headquarters by parents and employes protesting his takeover.

title: Federal Reserve Cuts Key Rate To 7%, Signaling Credit Ease
description: WASHINGTON, Dee. 6The Federal Reserve Board announced today a reduction in the discount rate it charges on its loans to banks. The action was interpreted as being the clearest message since late August that the central bank wants to make credit conditions easier.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Baseball Meetings End Amid Detente
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6Convinced that they had made a historic breakthrough toward cooperation and had achieved a detente between the American and National Leagues after decades of Jealously guarded sovereignty, the major league club :owners adjourned their annual winter meetings today with little to announce but much to anticipate.

title: Mrs. Peron Asks Wide Powers For Drive Against Subversives
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (UPI) President Isabel Martnez de Pern asked Congress today for broad powers to call up the armed forces to fight subversion and to set up a centralized national defense program under the presidency.

title: Matthew Says That Rockefeller Helped Keep His Hospital Open
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the black selfhelp advocate who is currently appealing a prison sentence, said yesterday that Nelson A. Rockefeller had been a tremendous factor in keeping open Interfaith Hospital in Queens in 1972, in the face of findings by state health inspectors of deplorable and substandard medical conditions there.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MIDDLESEX,.Dec. 6With Rich and Laura Thomasey, track and field is an all in the family proposition.

title: BOARD OF EDUCATION TO RECORD ITS VOTES
description: The Board of Education has modified its voting procedure to record individual ayes and nay of members on all items that come before it, board ofsaid last night.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MENOTTI MENU New Yorkers who traditionally await one of the loveliest of all Christmas musical packages can relax. GianCarlo Menotti's one  act opera, Amahl and the Night Visitors, is back, today and tomorrow at 5 P.M. at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, where the onehour work won acclaim last year. The performance has a new Young hero in Michael St. Claire, with Mary Lesnick as his mother and the three kings sung by Douglas Perry, Paul Straney and Christopher Deane, John Weaver is the musical director, and Joe Sutherin, the excellent pilot or those musicals by the St. Bart's Players, has staged the production.

title: As You Like It, Thieves To End Runs on Broadway
description: Two Broadway productions, one longlived and one shortlived, are closing.

title: Democratic Panels Begin Work on Platform for 76
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6 The Democratic party began work on the basis of its 1976 campaign platform today, 18 months before the delegates will meet to choose a Presidential candidate.

title: 4 Aboard Bus to Riverdale Rob Passengers of $3,000
description: Four men in their twenties, at least one of whom was armed with a gun, held up the passengers of a homewardbound commuter express bus last night on the Major Deegan Expressway and escaped with about $900 in cash and an estimated $2,100 i nassorted jewelry, the police reported.

title: The Dance: Phoebe Snow
description: Talley Beatty's explosive dance work The Road of the Phoebe Snow was a staple for many years of the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater. Sometimes it was not so well danced, and at other times it was danced very well. Thursday night at the City Center, as revived in a socalled new production, it was danced superbly.

title: Hanukkah to Begin Tomorrow; Jewish Leaders Recall Its Origin
description: Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights, begins at sundown tomorrow and Jewish leaders drew a parallel yesterday between the ancient Maccabees quest for religious and political freedom with Israel's determination to remain secure.

title: N.C.A.A. Soccer Title On Line
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6Howard and St. Louis, the schools that will clash for the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer title tomorrow afternoon, did not play up to their potential in the semifinals last night and disappointed the small crowd of 2,900 fans at Busch Stadium and the winning coaches.

title: Water Tunnel Work Is Halted in Dispute; 1,100 to Be Laid Off
description: Builders of the city's Third Water Tunnel halted work yesterday after refusal by the Board Of Estimate on Thursday to approve greatly increased payments to the sixcompany consortium that is digging the 13.7mile tunnel 600 feet below ground.

title: SOUTH KOREAN SITIN CONTINUES A 2D DAY
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 6 Opposition legislators extended their sitin in the South Korean parliament into the second day today.

title: Butz Slips in Poll
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UPI)More than half of the Illinois farmers interviewed in I survey approve of Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz's performance, but the 25 per cent who disapprove is the highest percentage since the twoyear survey began. The survey, taken this fall for Prairie Farmer magazine, was conducted through personal interviews ?? 500 Illinois farmers and 00 ??milers in Indiana.

title: Scientist Angrily Cancels TV Discussion of Primate
description: Dr. Geoffrey H. Bourne, director of the Yerkes Primate Research Center in Atlanta, yesterday called off a scheduled televised discussion of the controversial documentary Primate with its producer, Frederick Wiseman. The discussion was to have been taped Monday at the studios of WNET /13 here and televised over the Public Broadcasting Service that night.

title: Attempt to Block Vote Review Denied In New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 6 (AP) A Federal judge today denied a second attempt by John A. Durkin, the Democratic candidate in New Hampshire's United States Senate race, to block state review of his razorthin victory.

title: Storm Damage Halts Cape May Shellfishing
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The state today shut down shellfish beds off the coast of Cape May County because of pollution from raw sewage.

title: Manila Reports 18 Killed
description: MANILA, Dec. 6 (AP)Official sources said today that 18 persons had been killed and 10 wounded in an ambush in central Mindanao about 500 miles south of Manila. The sources said the ambush occurred Nov. 24 in an area that has been the scene of frequent fighting in the last two years between Moslem rebels and government forces.

title: A Triangular Summit
description: PARISLeonid Brezhnev's current visit to Paris is part of a curious triangle of summitry at least indirectly related to nuclear affairs although in France this week the subject is unlikely to have been more than mentioned in passing.

title: SOYUZ ASTRONAUTS FINISH SPACE TESTS
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 6 (UPI)The two Soyuz16 astronauts said today that they had completed their experiments in space to prepare for next July's llinkup with an American Apollo crew and were about to start packing for their homeward journey.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. IS STUDYING 10 BIG INDUSTRIES
description: Attorney General William B. Saxbe disclosed last night that 10 major industries were being studied by the Justice Department's antitrust division for evidence of pricefixing and monopoly behavior.

title: Economic Recovery Plan Is Offered by Democrats
The Text of the Address by Scali Before the United Nation General Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6Following is the text of the speech by Joint A. Scali, the United States representative, to the General Assembly today:

title: Woman Robbed and Raped In Brooklyn IND Station
description: A 50yearold woman was robbed and raped in a deserted section of the IND station at Jay Street in Brooklyn at 10 A.M. yesterday, the transit police reported.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He lives alone not far from Central Park West in an old brownstone on a quiet street. Outside it is stately and traditional. But inside it is decorated creatively in soft reds and blues. Earl Monroe reflects his home. He is quiet and reserved on the outside, almost shy. When he is playing basketball for the New York Knicks, his expression seldom changes. But inside, he is creating moves and shots that are unique. So unique that not even he really knows why he does what he does. For much of the previous three seasons his creativity was somewhat suppressed. He was adjusting to collaborating with Walt Frazier in the Knicks' backcourt after four spectacular seasons as a virtuoso with the team now known as the Washington Bullets. His style with the Knicks also was cramped from surgery on his left foot for bone spurs. But now, with the departure of Willis Reed, Dave DeBusschere and Jerry Lucas, his creativity has been liberated. He is Earl the Pearl again, spinning and whirling and flicking the soft onehanded shot that appears to hypnotize defenders.

title: Seabee Guilty of Tossing Pie in Officer's Face
description: PORT HUENEME, Calif., Dec. 8 (UPI)T'he Navy found a 19yearold seabee guilty of assault and battery today for hitting his commanding officer in the face with a chocolate cream pie despite testimony from Soupy Sales, the comedian, that the incident was a harmless joke.

title: FORD WILL REVISE FUELSAVING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Acknowledging that voluntary efforts to curb oil imparts were not going as well as had been hoped, a White House spokesman said today that President Ford planned to announce new energyconservation proposals next month.
