title: Orchestra Strike At the City Ballet Averted by Accord
description: A strike by the orchestra of the New York City Ballet was averted yesterday after the musicians and management settled a misunderstanding about a contract negotiated year ago.

title: SUPERVISORS ASK CITY PAY PARITY
description: It's degrading and humiliating for a supervisor to supervise people who make more money than he does, Raymond Diana, president of the New York City Managerial Employees Association, told the City Council's Civil Service and Labor Committee yesterday.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Concedes India Is Lagging in Population Control
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 6Prime Minister. Indira Gandhi, in rare speech on birth control, conceded today that India's familyplanning program had not been very impressive.

title: Cornell Six Tops Yale
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Dec, 6Cornell defeated Yale, 52, in an Ivy League hockey contest in Ithaca, N. Y. Junior Dave Groulx had two goals and two assists for the winners, The Eli goalie, Gerry Stenson, had 40 saves.

title: 2 Quakes Jolt California; Minor Damage Is Reported
description: CALEXICO, Calif., Dec. 6 (UPI)A fairly strong earthquake jolted a largely rural area along the CaliforniaMexican border early today, shaking people awake and causing minor damage.

title: Martin Plea Is Shifted to State Board
description: Frank (Pancho) Martin, New York's leading horse trainer, agreed yesterday to withdraw his court challenge to a 60day suspension and let the State Racing and Wagering Board hear his appeal. He is seeking relief against the action of the stewards who penalized him for alleged illegal use of medication on two of his horses.

title: Unemployment 7% Here But Skilled Jobs Are Open
description: In a tight job market, with more than 7 per cent unemployment in New York City, thousands of jobs are still to be had.

title: Mystery of Bill Walton's Future Deepens.
description: The elusive Bill Walton permitted the mystery of his future to deepen yesterday, leaving club officials to wait until tomorrow to discover whether or not he will walk away from a $2million contract.

title: Gray, Grimy Wooster St. Emerging As Little Avenue of Performing Arts
description: Wooster Street, a gray and grimy vestige of bluecollar Manhattan, carefully camouflages its emergence as something of a performing arts center of SoHo.

title: Dow Stock Average Drops 9.46 Points To 12Year Low as Volume Increases
description: The stock market fell sharply yesterday in heavier trading as more depressing economic news sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest closing level in more than 12 years.

title: 2 AMERICANS DEAD AT TEHERAN AIRPORT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 6 (AP) The bodies of two Americans were among the 17 bodies recovered so far from the ruins of the Teheran airport passenger lounge, where a snowcovered roof collapsed yesterday, officials said today. Another American was injured.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FATAL BOMB IN MAIL SENT TO CYCLE SHOP
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6  The police said today that a package bomb that exploded at the United Parcel Service here yesterday, killing one employe and injuring 10 others, was addressed to the Spectrum Custom Cycles Shop in Leechburg, Pa., about 35 miles northeast of here.

title: Makarios Is Returning to Cyprus Today
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 6When President Makarios returns tomorrow from five months of exile, he will find a Cyprus in which the balance of power on the ground has shifted dramatically in favor of Turkey.

title: G.W.U. Earnings Surge
description: The Great Western United Corporation, the country's largest beetsugar producer, reported figures yesterday that indicated a substantially higher net income of approximately $35.5million in the third quarter ended Nov. 30 compared with $230,000 in the period a year ago.

title: Q's Put To Rout By Nets
description: UNIONDALE, L.I, Dec. 6The New York Nets starting five came alive in a 64.44 second half tonight and defeated an undermanned San Diego team, 11392, in the Qs first visit of the season to Nassau Coliseum.

title: WIFE OF A U.N. ENVOY MUGGED ON E. 92D ST.
description: Two youths under police surveillance attempted to rob the wife of the Pakistani Ambassador to the United Nations last night on an Upper East Side street.

title: Title Skate Lead To Miss Salomon
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 6The senior women's event, the main competition of the North Atlantic figure skating championships, began today at the Twin Rinks With Barbara Salomon of Hempsead, L. I., holding a solid lead.

title: Woolworth Leaving Times Square Area
description: The Woolworth store at 44th Street and Broadway, a Times Square landmark for nearly 40 years, will close on Jan. 25 because it cannot afford the additional costs of a new lease, according to the F. W. Woolworth Company.

title: Valenti in Scarlatti Series
description: Three recitals of Scarlatti sonatas in three weeks might seem a large order for most harpsichordists, but for Fernando Valenti, it is nothing. Mr. Valenti is the man who played five such recitals in five days at Carnegie Recital Hall a year ago.

title: Reforming the Assembly
description: If words were as good as deeds, the lower house of the New York State Legislaturedescribed recently by Common Cause, the national citizen's lobby as one of the most secretive, unresponsive and oligarchical in the nationwould be well on its way to revolutionary reform,

title: Music: New Wuorinen
description: Charles Wuorinen's Second Piano Concerto, which was given its premiere yesterday afternoon by the New York Philharmonic, begins and ends on a plain, unvarnished C. In the 25 minutes that the work takes, a great deal happenssome of it of interest to the mind and almost none of it appealing to the senses. That is the problem.

title: Offshore Hearing Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) A hearing in Trenton originally scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday on the environmental impact of expanded offshore oil and gas leasing will be reset in February, the Interior Department said today.

title: People in Sports
description: Rewards keep piling up for Grant Teaff. Baylor University's head coach, who guided the Bears to their first Southwest Conference football championship In 50 years was named coach of the year yesterday by the United Press International.

title: Rescuing Europe From the Precipice
description: WASHINGTON PREOCCUPIED WITH its own problems, the United States is unconsciously contributing to Europe's greatest crisis since the war. For better, for worse, the consequences are ours to share. Europe's ills are political and economic. Inflation at doubledigit rates threatens the social order and democratic institutions, stirring class warfare, for instance, in England.

title: Incentive Payments to Concerns May End Tank Production Snag
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6At an unexpected cost of $18.4million, the Defense Department believes it has broken a production bottleneck that has sharply limited the supply of tanks for the United States Army and for Israel.

title: Unemployment 7% Here But Skilled Jobs Are Open
description: In a tight job market, with more than 7 per cent unemployment in New York City, thousands of jobs are still to be had.

title: Notes on PeopleU. S. Abandons Fight to Imprison Lansky
description: The Federal Government has quietly given up its long fight to put Meyer Lanky, reputed to have served as a financial wizard for the underworld, behind bars. Dougald McMillan, the Federal prosecutor, confirmed in Miami that the Justice Department would not appeal a decision by the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit that threw out the only conviction the Government ever obtained against Mr. Lanky The ailing Mr. Lansky had been given a year and a day in prison, in June, 1973, for failing to comply with a grand jury subpoena served on him in Israel, his home before he was expelled. The recent reversal was Mr. Lanaky's third major victory over the courts, and it meant that the Government has run out of charges. with which to prosecute him. He is now living in Miami.

title: Clerk Replaces Hostage, Gets Robbers to Give Up
description: A 20yearold grocery clerk brought a peaceful end to an armed robbery of a busy Harlem supermarket yesterday when he first persuaded two gunmen to take him hostage instead of the tearful pregnant woman they were holding and then convinced the robbers to lay down their arms.

title: Federal Judges Ethics Bill Is Signed by the President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) President Ford signed legislation yesterday amending the United States Legal Code to toughen a provision requiring disqualification of Federal judges in cases where they are shown to have a bias or conflict of interest.

title: ExMinister in Uganda Freed of House Arrest
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Dec. 6 (Reuters)  Uganda's former Foreign Minister, Elizabeth Bagaaya, has been released from house arrest, according to a Government statement issued here today.

title: Father of Battered Infant Blames Wife for Slaying
description: NEWARK, Dec. 6A father attempted today to shift to his wife blame for the death of their 13monthold son, who was found beaten to death in, his playpen in their Nutley home last June.

title: Ballet: The Nutcracker
description: The first crystalline flakes of the Christmas season Nutcracker cascade fluttered merrily down at the New York State Theater on Thursday. The New York City Ballet returned with its lush annual production of the children's classic, and now there are only 22 performances left until Christmas.

title: Business Briefs;Arcan Sees Syncrude Tax Writeoff
description: ALGARY, Alberta, Dec. 6 (UPI)Atlantic Richfield Canada, Ltd., said today its decision to withdraw from the Syncrude oil project in the Athabasca tar sands in Alberta probably will result in an aftertax writeoff of $20million.

title: Citibank Prime Unchanged
description: The, First National City Bank yesterday kept its prime rate on corporate loans unchanged at 10 per cent. Citibank, which recently has been the first bank to lower its lending rates, customarily decides each Friday morning what its base rate will be for the next week.

title: Federal Reserve Cuts Key Rate To 7%, Signaling Credit Ease
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The Federal Reserve Board nounced today a reduction in the discount rate it charges on its loans to banks. The action was interpreted as being the clearest message since late August that the central bank wants to make credit conditions.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1974

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Guerrillas Raid a Kibbutz Near Lebanon
description: ROSH HANIQRA, Israel, Dec. 6 (AP)Palestinian guerrillas raided this kibbutz just south of the Lebanese border early today and wounded two Israelis. An Israeli soldier shot and wounded one of the terrorists and then burned him to death with a phosphorous grenade, an Israeli officer said.

title: Wallace Handicap Cited As Problem by Shriver
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 6 (UPI)Sargent Shriver said today that Alabama Governor George C. Wallace's paralysis from the waist down would present a handicap to his performance as President.

title: LIFO TO BE ADOPTED BY TEXACO AND AVON
description: Texaco, Inc., has announced that it is adopting the lastin, firstout method of inventory accounting for its domestic inventories of crude oil and petroleum products, effective Jan. 1.

title: A. F. DI RUFFANO
description: Agostino Ferranta di Ruffano, a retired Italian diplomat who had served as Consul General in Boston, Philadelphia and Ottawa and had been Ambassador to Paraguay, died Wednesday at the home of his son Roberto in Mendham, N. J. He was 89 years old.

title: Title Skate Lead To Miss Salomon
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 6The senior women's event, rile main competition of the North Atlantic figure skating championships, began today at the Twin Rinks with Barbara Salomon of Hempsead, L. I., holding a solid lead.

title: Stocks at 12Year Low
description: The stock market tumbled yesterday to its lowest closing level in more than 12 years. The Dow Jones industrial average went down 9.46 points to 577.60. Depressing economic news was cited as a factor. Page 39.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two men and a construction company were indicted by a Federal grand jury for allegedly masterminding a scheme to swindle four international airlines out of $36,650. United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said the scheme involved arranging for a travel agency to receive 25 airline tickets to various parts of the world and declare itself bankrupt before the tickets were paid for.

title: Coral Sea Begins Tour
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) The 65,000ton aircraft carried Coral Sea sailed through the Golden Gate yesterday, hound for a sevenmonth tour in the western Pacific. For the last year, the 27yearold ship had been berthed at Alameda Naval Air Station, where it underwent repairs and painting.

title: N.A.A.C.P.'s Problem: Leadership Wanes
description: The death of Stephen G. Spottswood, chairman of the board directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, aggravates the problem of diminishing leadership in the association. His death on Dec. 1 came at a time when the nation's oldest and largest civil rights organization was seeking new directions in attacking art old foe, segregation, that seemingly will not go away. The chairman of the board plays a key role in setting policy.

title: U.S. Interests Send Aides to the Talks On Bid for Aramco
description: Representatives of the American partners in the Arabian American Oil Company have left for London for what may well be the final act in the long drawn out 100 per cent takeover by the Saudi Arabian Government of what is said to be the world's most important petroleum operation.

title: Shah's Iran: Moving Unevenly Toward a Persian Renaissance
description: TEHERAN, IranAfter canturies of stagnation and submissiveness, Iran is now moving unevenly toward the ambitious goals set for her by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahleve Western majorpower prosperity at bome and majorpower status in the world.

title: Retail Price Tags Fail to Reflect Drop in Wholesale Food Costs
description: The Municipal Service Administration reported yesterday that wholesale prices of fresh foods bought by the city declined 4.2 per cent last month, with meat dropping 2.7 per cent beef falling from an average of 74 to 71 cents a poundand fresh produce declining 2.9 per cent.

title: The Mills Picture Book
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6  Captions for a Washington picture book:

title: Schlumberger Dividend Up
description: Schlumberger, Ltd., an oilindustry service concern and electronic  systems manufacturer, has raised the dividend paid quarterly on its common stock to 22.5 cents a share from 18 cents a share. The dividend will be paid Jan. 15, 1975, to shareholders of record Dec. 20.

title: For State Democrats, a Lasting Hurrah
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6 New York Democrats had the chance to compare their old and new leaders at a ate party caucus last night Mere at the national midterm convention.

title: Gray, Grimy Wooster St. Emerging As Little Avenue of Performing Arts
description: Wooster Street, a gray and grimy vestige of bluecollar Manhattan, carefully camouflages its emergence as something of a performing arts center of SoHo.

title: Jurors Call on Sirica Not to Hurry Trial for Holidays
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The jury at the Watergate coverup trial informed Federal Judge John J. Sirica today that it did not want the trial to be hurried unduly just so that it could be released from sequestration in time for Christmas.

title: Flyers Tie Scouts, 33, With Goal in 3d Period
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6 (AP)  Philadelphia scored twice in the first five minutes but it took Reggie Leach's thirdperiod goal to give the Flyers a 33 National Hockey League tie with the Kansas City Scouts tonight.

title: Bridge:
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec., 6A dramatic reversal of fortune in the final session of the blue ribbon pair championship here last night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals ended the hopes of all the leading contenders.

title: Football Player, 17, Dies
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 6 (AP)Henry Francke Jr., a linebacker for Riverhead High School's football team, died eight weeks after he was injured during an intrasquad scrimmage. Francke, 17 years old, suffered a broken neck Oct. 8 and was placed in traction, He died Wednesday, in Suffolk Central Hospital, a few hours after an attempt to graft bone from his pelvis to his neck.

title: WILLIAM K. O'CONNELL
description: William K. O'Connell, merchandise manager of B. Altman & Co. here, died yesteday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived in Larchmont, N. Y.

title: Converter Projects 3  D Movies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6A New York company manufactures and rents to theaters apparatus that converts standard projectors so they display threedimensional motion pictures. The apparatus, trademarked Polarator, was patented this week for the Marks Polarized Corporation, Whitestone, queens. About 40 Polarators are now being operated in, this country and abroad, each bringing the company $150 a week in rental. The Marks company also sells the theaters 3D viewers, or glasses, intended for onetime use by members of the audience.

title: ETHIOPIA REPLACES 14 IN TOP POSITIONS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 6 (Reuters)Ethiopia's military rulers today announced a shuffle of 14 top civilian and military posts, a move apparently aimed at purging opponents.

title: Art: Twain Meet in New Rivers
description: For a decade and more Larry Rivers has been coming to high art by way of the back door. We remember in this Context his more than free versions of Ingres, Czanne and the 17thcentury Dutch masters. In each case the admiration, although heartfelt, was masked by wit and Irony, and the emulation, although genuine, was carried out at one or more removes.

title: AllStar Football
description: OFFENSE

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: FORD WILL REVISE FUELSAVING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Acknowledging that voluntary efforts to curb oil imports were not going as well as had been hoped, a White House spokesman said today that President Ford planned to announce new energy conservation proposals next month.

title: Questions on Dr. King's Murder Likely to Remain, Whether or Not Ray Wins Current Plea for 2d Trial
description: A Federal Court judge in Memphis is nearing a decision on Jemes Earl Ray's petition for a new trial in the killing of the Rew Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But whatever form the decision takes, it is not likely to answer many of the questionsthat have lingered ever since We lingered ever since the 1968 assassination.

title: ExAide to Nixon Resigns G.O.P. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) Harry S. Dent, a White House aide under President Nixon, resigned today as general counsel to the Republican National Committee.

title: SKITCH HENDERSON DENIES TAX COUNT
description: Skitch Henderson denied on the witness stand yesterday that he had backdated any documents to make his donation of a music library eligible for large deductions on his Federal income returns for 1969 and 1970.

title: Mangling a Promise
description: Only a decade has passed since the enactment of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 for which so many worked so long and so hard both in the streets of the South an in the halls of Congress. Though many of the ills which the legislation was designed to remedy still haunt this country, the Senate is currently faced with the task preventing a major evisceration of that law and another patterned on it.

title: Richard Wilbur Will Head Arts and Letters Academy
description: The poet Richard Wilbur was elected 13th president of the American Academy of Arts and Letters yesterday at the organization's annual meeting. He succeeds the composer Aaron Copland, who had served the usual threeyear term.

title: Back to Geneva?
description: President Ford's cautious suggestion this week that a Geneva Conference might be useful in furthering ArabIsraeli negotiations contains the possibility Of a flexible new approach to cut through the present impasse.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, the black selfhelp advocate who is currently appealing a prison sentence, said that R. Rockefeller had been a tremendous factor in keeping open Interfaith Hospital in Queens in 1972 in the face of findings by state health inspectors of deplorable and substandard medical conditions there.

title: People in Sports
description: Rewardi keep piling up for Grant Teaff. Baylor University's head coach, who guided the Bears to their first Southwest Conference football championship in 50 years was named coach of the year yesterday, by the United Press International.

title: Saigon Reports It Repulsed Raid on Mekong Delta Town
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 7 (AP)Communistled forces mounted shelling and ground attack yesterday against a district capital in the Mekong Delta and radio contact with the town was cut off for more than 24 hours, military sources here reported.

title: Stocks at 12Year Low
description: The stock market tumbled yesterday to its lowest closing level in more than 12 years. The Dow Jones industrial average went down 9.46 points to 577.60. Depressing economic news was cited as a factor. Page 39.

title: Opera: Jenufa at the Met
description: Much of the cast was new for the fourth Jenufa performance of the season on Thursday night, including Margaret Tynes, who was making her Metropolitan Opera debut in the title part. It would be pleasant to be able to report that Miss Tynesan American soprano who has had considerable success in European houses, swept all before her. Unfortunately, she seemed seriously miscast, and only intermittently could one detect real quality In the voice or much evidence of dramatic grasp.

title: President of Iraq Reported Critically Ill
description: BEIRUI, Lebanon, Dec.6 President ahmed Hassan alBakr of Iraq, who has been absent from official fonctions for three weeks, is critically ill after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage, according to Arab and Communist diplomatic sources.

title: Misleading Meat Labels Allowed for '75
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The Agriculture Department has given food processors more than a year to use up existing supplies of packaging labels for meat and poultry products, although the labels include advertising terms that a Federal court says are misleading.

title: Six Million Jobless
description: The human toll of the recession is starkly reflected in yesterday's announcement that nearly six million workers are now unemployed, an increase of almost two million over the total a year ago. With the figures rising day by day, the need is immediate for action by the Ford Administration and Congress to ease hardship, and revive the jobgenerating potentialities of the economy.

title: John A. Clements, Headed Public Relations for Hearst
description: John A. Clements, former publicrelations director for the, Hearst Corporation, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Hotel St. Moritz, 50 Central Park South. He was 73 years old and lived in Washington.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP TO 6.5 PER CENT, HIGHEST SINCE'61
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6The nation's unemployment rate shot up in November for the third consecutive month and reached 6.5 per cent of the labor force, the highest rate in 13 years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Clerk Replaces Hostage, Gets Robbers to Give Up
description: A 20yearold grocery clerk brought a peaceful end to an armed robbery of a busy Harlem supermarket yesterday when he first persuaded two gunmen to take him hostage instead of the tearful pregnant woman they were holding and then convinced the robbers to lay down their arms.

title: Supporters Seize Thant's Body Before Funeral Rites in Rangoon
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 6 (AP) Thousands of students and Buddhist monks seized the body of U Thant, former Secretary General of the United Nations, yesterday as an official funeral procession was about to start, placed it on a truck and took it to Rangoon University.

title: Nigeria Welcoming U.S. Merchant Banks
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 6Near a coconutpalm fringed beach on fashionable Victoria Island here a $20million 500room luxury hotel is talcing shape.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Library Given $261,20
description: BOSTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The nation's oldest public library has become the first to receive a Federal grant for free courses on its community. The National Endowment for the Humanities announced a $261,260 grant yesterday to the Boston Public Library to give the courses for 50 students.

title: For 1,500 FifthGraders, This Is a Shool Away From School
description: BANTAM LAKE, Conn.  Hanging over the rails of the corral, the fifthgraders from P.S. 33 in Chelsea, Manhattan, held out handfuls of hay to the young steers and the little calf inside. Anthony Gonzales, Mark Lalljee, Chinhon Huang, Lisa Fischer, Mark Kornegay and most of the others strained forward ardently, trying to pat or even touch steamybreathed animals.

title: Profit and Dividend Raised by Esmark
Dominica Is Given New Powers To Combat Black Guerrillas
description: Roseau, Dominica, Dec. 6 (NPI)The House of Assembly today approved emergency legislation giving the. Government new powers in its drive against the black power guerrillas who rave been blamed for a series of attacks on whites on this Caribbean island.

title: HENRY WADSWORTH, STAGE, FILM ACTOR
description: Henry Wadsworth, the perennial juvenile stage and screen actor, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hotpital. He was 72 years old andlived here.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: SCHOOL TRUSTEE STILL LOCKED OUT
description: School principals and the dis trict superintendent in Commu nity School District 9 in the Bronx pledged loyalty yester day to Chancellor Irving An keg's appointed trustee, but he remained locked out of the district's headquarters by parents and employes protesting his takeover.

title: Tina Fisher and Tim Holvick Are Married in Grosse Pointe
description: Christina F. Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Fisher Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., was married there yesterday afternoon to Olaf Holvick 2d, son of Mrs. Olaf Holvick, also of Grosse Pointe, and the late Mr. Holvick. The bride is known as Tina and her husband as Tim.

title: Boryla Has Eagles in Air Again
description: Along with the backslapping he received after an impressive first start last week, Mike Boryla took a verbal poke from a Philadelphia Eagle teammate, Roy Kirksey, the right offensive guard.

title: PICKETING MARS COALSTRIKE END
description: WYCO, W. Va., Dec. 6Despite picketing in at least four states by mine construction workers, the nation's 120,000 miners began trickling back to work today after their 25day strike ended.

title: Art: Two Against the Current
description: The effort to emulate the methods of the old masters as a means of exploring contemporary experience is a good deal less common on today's art scene than it once was, yet the effort still persists among the small band of dedicated artists who command both the requisite technical skill and the no less necessary conviction of its importance.

title: DONATION ADVICE IS LAID TO THE GOP
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 6 (AP) The former general manager of a large contracting company testified today that it had made a $15,000 donation to the 1969 campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahaill's campaign after Republican fund raisers offered a way of deducting the gift on Federal income taxes.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE EAGLE AND BROOKLYN: A Community Newspaper, 18411955. By Raymond A. Schroth, S. J. 304 pages. Illustrated. Greenwood Press. $12.95.

title: Alan Wood Extra Payout
description: An extra dividend of 60 cents a share was voted yesterday by the Alan Wood Steel Company, payable Dec. 27 to holders of Dec. 17. A previously declared quarterly dividend of 20 cents is payable next Wednesday. No extra was declared a year ago.

title: Temple Israel Names First Woman President
description: For the first time, Temple Israel of the City of New York has named a woman to serve as its president.

title: ISRAEL TAKES ISSUE WITH UNESCO VIEW
description: PARIS, Dec. 6The Israel delegation to UNESCO today took strong issue with recent statements bythe Parisbased organization attempting to play down actions taken against Israel.

title: Auditorium Reflects Convention Mood
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6 The deeper meaning of the Democratic miniconvention under way here may lie in the building where the 2,038 delegates have gathered.

title: MISS MORROW SINGS; EVERYTHING WORKS
description: Karen Morrow has come into Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street, with a failsafe act hedged with so many elements that at least one of them has to work. In her case, however, everything works, and the evening becomes a joyride that swerves back and forth between an amusing, chatty, personal monologue and songs delivered in an easy, smoky voice that has resources of depth and range and color.

title: Fund Asks Court To Void Settlement In Steel Bias Suit
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (UPDThe NAACP Legal Defense and Educatipnal Fund, Inc., told a Federal Appeals Court today that a $30million steel industry discrimination settlement should be abandoned because it had blocked individual suits against the companies.

title: Parent and Child
description: I believe that birth is too important an event to be left to the obstetricians, that a newborn and his mother need a loving artist's attention, not the impersonal manipulation of a highly trained engineer. These are the words of Frederick Leboyer, a French obstetrician who has perceived and practiced a controversial new method of child delivery that many people believe has had a profoundly beneficial effect on children he has delivered. Leboyer, 56, who graduated trom the Facult de Mdecine in the Universit de Paris in 1937 as an advanced scholar and later attained the rank of chef de clinique with teaching privileges before he set up his private practice, has brought an estimated 1,000 children into the world by this radical technique. His critics regard it as, It best, foolish, at worst, dangerous; his followers think it may well be an important new contributing factor to good human health.

title: United Hospital Fund
description: The United Hospital Fund's 96th annual campaign seeks to raise money to help its 55 member voluntary hospitals during a time of economic crisis. These nonprofit hospitals, long underfinanced, are caught in the current inflationary difficulties.

title: Letters: A Ruble For a Wrong Turn
description: To the Editor: As a veteran of two summer trips through the Soviet Union in a Volkswagen bus, I must comment on Daniel Vergin's article, How to Rent a Car in the U.S.S.R. and Survive (Travel section Nov. 17).

title: CAR REPAIRS RISE AS NEW SALES DIP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The decline in new car sales means that cars now on the road are getting older and spending more time in the nation's repair shops, where consumers can expect only modest official protection against incompetence and fraud.

title: A Political Convention, Sort of
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 7 Robert Frost once said that writing free verse was like playing tennis without a net. The Democrats are proving here that much the same can be said for a political convention that is not trying to pick a candidate.

title: Lee Kinsolving, 36, Actor, Son of ExSt. James' Rector
description: Arthur Lee Kinsolving Jr., the actor son of the Rev. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, retired rector of St. James Episcopal Church here, died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 36 years old.

title: Swamp Gardeas: Beauty in Winter
description: BASKING RIDGE  A swamp garden is a garden for all seasons, said Mrs. Elfreda Finch, whose garden is surely among the most unusual in the state.

title: Trailers to Be Used as School
description: WEYMOUTHEver since their school was destroyed by a fire in September, grammar school pupils in this rural Atlantic County township have been attending makeshift classes in a firehouse and a church.

title: Social Security Tax Estimated To Rise 75% in Next 50 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) A study commissioned by the Treasury Deportment has estimated that current trends point to a 75 per cent increase in Social Security taxes over the next 50 years if the program continues to operate on its current basis.

title: Canada Intends to Keep Her Own Lights Burning
description: MONTREALOne day, when the Arab oil embargo was a threat but not yet a reality, Canada's Minister of Energy, Donald S. Macdonald, was asked to what extent the United States could count on continuing to share this country's energyreserves.

title: Vocational Center Gets Dented Cars
description: SCOTCH PLAINS  Automotive students at the Union County Vocational Center will receive firsthand training on some new foreign cars, thanks to the gift of two 1974 Opels from General Motors. The cars, which were damaged in shipment, have been presented to school officials by representatives of G.M.'s Buick Motor Division.

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: AT GARDEN

title: From Political Ordeal To Dance Debut
description: Valery Panov and his wife, Galina Ragozina, are at this moment one of the most celebrated ballet teams in the United Statewhich is remarkable, considering how very few balletgoers have seen these two former stars of the Kirov Ballet perform.

title: Bus Order Divides Lakewood
description: LAKEWOODDespite advice to the contrary from the Board of Education, a group of white parents here is planning a townshipwide fund drive to combat a school desegregation order imposed by the state.

title: Susan Strickland, Student, Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank William Strickland of Yardley, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lawrence Strickland, to James Bartley Given 4th, son of Dr. and Mrs. Given of West Hartford, Conn., and New Suffolk, L, I.

title: Letters
description: As a cardcarrying retired wife I read Robert C. Alberts's Report from the twilight years (Nov. 17) with relish and general agreement. Like Mr. A's wife, I hear complaints from discontented retired wives, but they are so apt to be the same ones who bitched about their husbands before they retired.

title: Montclair State Seeks to Aid the Aged
description: MONTCLAIR A young college graduate and a retired banker are working together at Montclair State College on a program designed to make life better for older people.

title: YALE SEX BOOKLET STIRS A DISPUTE
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7A new edition at the sexinformation booklet that has become somewhat of a trademerk for Yale University's nationally known sexeducation program is going to press this week, and the revisions have apparently caused the school's administration to weaken its support of the booklet.

title: Problems as Varied as Human Experience
description: Executive Director, Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service

title: Meeting Scheduled on Medical Center
description: A meeting to hear community views over the controversial relocation of the Queens Hospital Center has been scheduled for tonight at 7:30 by Community Board in the hospital's nurses' residence auditorium at 164th Street and Grand Central Parkway.

title: If Businesses Wrong Him, This Consumer Makes Them Pay
description: Business beware! Do NOT Trifle with Prof. David Klein. Professor Klein looks like a nice, upper Middleclass type. Most of the time he is. Sometimes he's not. Nice,that is.

title: WOMEN IN MEDIA HOLD PARLEY HERE
description: Marlene Sanders, a network television producer who was the first woman to anchor a network news show, told a conference of 400 women in publishing and broadcasting yesterday that the women's movement in the industry must focus on both employment and image.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Those Fordham. Runners/Those Woody Hayes Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Watchdog Group Plans to Grow
description: MINEOLA  AWARE, the small watchdog that has stimulated several investigations into allegations of corruption in Nassau County, will soon seek to expand its activities by attempting to enroll thousands of families as duespaying members of the organization.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD lowered the discount rate at Federal Reserve banks in New York and Philadelphia from 8 per cent to 7 per cent. . . . Coal miners ended their 24day strike by voting, 58 per cent to 44 per cent, to accept a new contract. It provides for an 18 per cent wage increase by 1976. . . The Labor Department reported that unemployment last month rose to 6,5 per cent of the work force, up from 6 per cent In October. . . . Brookings Institution said unemployment would reach 8 per cent by middle to late 1975.

title: Princeton's Grande Dame Reminisces
description: PRINCETONNMrs, Gerard B. Lambert, who drives around Princeton in a venerable black Humber sedan, is a familiar figure to townsfolk in Palmer Square and along Nassau Street.

title: Caroline Bogatay Marries
description: Caroline Anne Bogatay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bogatay of Nutley, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Allen Redwood. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude G. Redwood of Flushing, queens. The Rev. Gerard Walsh performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Nutley.

title: BRIDGE
description: Betting on the results of tournament events is strictly forbidden by the American Contract Bridge League, although the prohibition is not easy to enforce. However, the game offers scope for financial speculation other than the obvious course of playing for stakes.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Textile people say it's difficult to recall a time in their experience when a strong market in manmade fibers has taken such a drastic downward turn.

title: Ford to See 9 Inducted at College Football Hall of Fame Dinner
description: With President Ford on the dais, the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame will hold its 16th annual dinner Tuesday evening, honoring nine new members elected to the hall and 11 scholarathletes.

title: The Continental Op By Dashiell Hammett. 287 pp. New York: Random House. $7.95.;Short Hammettexciting, ugly, beautifully made
description: Seven detective stories by Dashiell Hammett, written between 1923 and 1930, are collected in The Continental Op with an introduction by Steven Marcus. He reviews Hammett's exciting, miserable life and the distinctive qualities of his fiction.

title: $1,000 Reward Offered For Clues to Druggers
description: The American Horse Shows Association still is concerned that reserpine, a potentially lethal tranquilizer, is being used and the group has taken the unusual action of offering a $1,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of persons administering it. I don't recall that we ever have put up a reward for the conviction of drug users, said Albert E Hart Jr., president of the A.H.S.A., the other day. But we regard the use of reserpine as a very serious matter. It's no secret that the drug is difficult and expensive to detect. We have several scientists and laboratories working on the problem and it shouldn't be too long before they come up with a simple and inexdetection device.

title: Music in Review
description: Although Margaret Mills is a pianist of considerable experience to judge by the program notes for her appearance on Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, she had not previously given a solo recital here. She proved to be a fairly dependable technician and a thoughtful musician, even though bland in temperament.

title: Miller, 207, Leads Golf By 3 Shots
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan, Dec. 7 (UPI)Johnny Miller, shooting a threeunderpar 69 for the third straight round, grabbed a threestroke lead in the $170,000 Dunlop Phoenix golf tournament today.

title: Words and Motions At Odds in Dances In Windmills Piece
description: Words, words and more words interfered with movement Friday evening at the Construction Company Dance Studio., Jacques Brouwers presented Windmills  in which he recited texts of his own devising and Charley Stanley declaimed poetry but both more or less tended to ignore motion.

title: Rose Elder: A Woman Aiding Lee's Success
description: ?? Elder, wife of Lee ?? the black golfer, doesn't subscribe to the ?? that behind every successful man there's a woman. But she does believe a woman can help. Lee would have been successful with cessful with or without me, simply because he is a great golfer, said Mrs. Elder, but she adds: I believe my background as a former golfer enabled me to understand his problems and stick behind him when times were hard. I think that, more than anything else, helped get him where he is today.

title: Linda S. Auerbach Sets June Wedding
description: The engagement of Linda Susan Auerbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hays Auerbach of Scarsdale, N. Y., to Richard Barry Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Friedman of Worcester, Mass., has been announced by Miss Auerbach's parents. A wedding in June is planned.

title: UNESCO IS FACING BITTER BACKLASH
description: PARIS, Dec. 7The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is in trouble.

title: Study Cites Election Fund Role Of Lobbyists
description: TRENTON  Contributions from New Jersey specialinterest groups provided nearly a third of the funds expended in last year's legislative elections, with almost half of the money coming from lobbyists who attempt to influence legislation here.

title: Rights Study Says U.S. Funds Are Denied to Maine's Indians
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 7Federal agencies have denied Maine's nearly 4,000 Indians more than $5million a year in services, an advisory committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights has reported. It said this denial constituted invidious discrimination.

title: Gail Ennis Fiancee of D. J. Sheehan 3d
description: Gail Patricia Ennis, who graduated this year sununa cum laude from the Catholic University of America in Washington, and Dennis J. Sheehan 3d, assignment editor for WCBSTV News here, plan to be married May 25.

title: Red Cedar Shingles for Use on Inside Walls
description: Those who prefer a rustic or outdoor look on one or more inside walls should be interested in a new type of wall panel which actually consists of real cedar shingles that are glued on to a inch thick insulating board. This greatly simplifies the job of installing wood shingles on any wall and makes it an easy doityourself project.

title: Miss Luayon Bride of Joseph Bartley
description: Concepcion Mascarinas Luayon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Simeon Luayon of Tubigon, Bohol, the Philippines, and Joseph Francis Bartley, son of Mrs. James Joseph Bartley of Upper Darby, Pa., and the late Mr. Bartley, who was a food broker with Walter A. Scion and Sons in Philadelphia, were married here yesterday morning. The Rev. Paul McKenna performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: You Play to Win, but If You Are Not Enthusiastic You May Lose
description: Vince Lombardi used to say, Winning isn't everything, it's the only thing. Grantland Rice often quoted a famous line about it's not mattering whether you win or lose, but how you play the game. My own view of the subject, is Somewhere in between these two.

title: Lorraine Longo Engaged
description: Mrs. Sylvester J. Longo of Bernardsville, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lorraine Longo, to Mark D. Hughston, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Hughston of McKinney, Tex. Miss Longo, daughter also of the late Mr. Longo, is a graduate of George Washington University. Her fianc is a senior at Southern Methodist University.

title: Solutions to Last Week's Puzzles
Early Warnings Saved Lives
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The state's Deputy Director of Civil Defense says he is convinced that the sophistication of New Jersey's stormwarning system helped the shore areas to weather the worst storm in 12 years without loss of life.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Queens Is Getting Ellington Premiere
description: Coincidence, tragedy, dedication and love will all have played their parts when Duke Ellington's Third Sacred Concert receives its American premiere next Sunday at the Queensborough Community College in Bayside.

title: The many moods of fantasy
description: Edmund Dulac's beautiful maiden has a halo of dazzling golden hair . . . Howard Pyle's pirate ship sails through a glowing, otherworldly haze ... Arthur Rackham's trio of raging Valkyries fly against a burnished copper sky . . . and W. Heath Robinson's hushed, humble children make their way toward a dusky castle, drawn by a candle that burns silverywhite in the window. All 40 pictures in David Larkin's A Collection Illustrations From the Golden Days of Storytelling, THE FANTASTIC KINGDOM (Ballantine, $4.95), are flooded with light. At once magical and mystical, at times terrifying as well, their vision summons up images of myth and fantasyfrom the Impenetrable forests of folklore and the dreamland ballrooms of fairytale to the ice palace of Andersen's Snow Queen. There are a artists represented, all of whom illustrated children's books more than 60 years ago. The roll call of their title credits (Waterbabies, Mrs. Doasyouwouldbedoneby, Little Boy Lost, Aladdin. and His Wonderful Lamp et al.) reads like a litany of childhood memory, or, as Mr. Larkin puts it, they conjure up a very tangible world of makebelieve. Some of the illustrators (Jessie Willcox Smith, Dorothy Lathrop, Maxfield Parrish, Kay Neilsen) are still well known; others (T. Mackenzie, Harry Clarke, Edward J. Detmold, Charles Robinson, Jean de Bosschere, Paul Bransom) are not. Were they romantic realists? Or sentimental idealists? Or masters of the clich? Does it matter? Look again at these reproductions in rich jeweltone colors (they are the result of an international search) and you find that their enchantment still casts a potent spell. Informative notes have been provided by Margaret Maloney.

title: Mall to China Must Carry People's Republic Address
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) The Postal Service yesterday said that China was rejecting mail unless it was addressed to the People's Republic of China.

title: Snapshots From The Career of Eugene List
description: As one who has been in the public eye more than most performers of his generation, Eugene List has a right to celebrate the 40th anniversary of his debut, and he will be doing just that in Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night. As part of the observance, a brochure has been put together, which includes photographs of high points of his career. It is a miniature album with considerable nostalgic impact, and a few of the pictures made a useful basis for reminiscent comments by the pianist in a recent conversation.

title: Waterloo Village Primps for Holiday
description: WATERLOO VILLAGEHerb trees, spice boxes, handcut cookies, rooms garnished with ropes of princess pine, candles burning in tin chandeliers and other reminders of the 19th Century will mark the two weeks before Christmas at Waterloo Village Restoration.

title: Paterson College Is Increasing Its Courses on Bicentennial
description: WAYNE  New Jersey, known as the cockpit of the American Revolution because of the number of battles fought on its soil, may win the reputation of Bellwether of the Bicentennial as the result of the interest of the faculty and students at William Paterson College.

title: West Orange Offers Art of MidCentury
description: WEST ORANGEArt executed by Matisse, Picasso, Mir, Raoul Dufy, Chagall and Jackson Pollock is among the offerings at an exhibition and sale that opened last night at the Y.M.Y.W.H.A., 760 Northfield Avenue.

title: State Acting to Help Its Abused Children
description: TRENTON New Jersey is developing a new program to hep abused children and provide therapy for their parents

title: Movie Revivals
description: Movie theater attendance has been dwindling for decades. Not so the readership for books about the movies: every year, lately, a flood of such books is loosed on the market. What does this mean? Perhaps that absence makes the heart grow fonder. Of course, television has a lot to do with it, but so does the complex phenomenon inadequately termed nostalgia. We may have reached a point where people's memories of the movies are so warm and precious to them that the actual experience of seeing a new film in a theater palls by comparison.

title: The Needle's Eye
description: A little over a year ago I stopped buying every book published on crafts. I suddenly found the number of books so overwhelming that neither shelf space nor checkbook would accommodate all of them. I also realized that though there were still many good books being published in the craft field, there were many that really didn't deserve the space they took up. Needlework seems to be holding its own as the most written about craft.

title: Headliners
description: For 24 years his cry of Mistah Speakaaah rang out in the House of Representatives. But no more. William M. (Fish Bait) Miller has lost his job as House doorkeeper. From that post Mr. Miller ran a small Congressional empire of 300 employes in minor jobs, and took care of the legislators' everyday errands. Though publicly it was suggested that his age, 65, was the reason for his ouster, privately there were reports that some libera! Democrats felt he favored the conservatives, and others regarded him as too flamboyant. When Gerald R. Ford appeared in the House for the first time as President, Mr. Miller screeched Jereeee and wrapped his arms around him.

title: Inland Sites Are Threatened by the Loss of Grasslands
description: HACKENSACKThe winddriven rainstorm last Sunday renewed concern about how to prevent flood damage in a state that lies along major storm corridor and where, officials say, floods of great magnitude could occur at any time.

title: Lack of Cars, Not Leg Injury, Threatens Leonard's Career
description: Joe Leonard, the United States Auto Club national driving champion in 1971 and 1972, kept saying, I don't want sympathy. His wife said, To be honest, I'd be pleased if Joe retired. He may have to retirethere are. few cars left to drive.

title: Lynn DeSilvey, Artist, to Marry Feb. 15
description: Lynn Susann DeSilvey, a commercial artist with Brandegee Associates, Inc., a group of writers, editors and graphic designers in the communications field, in Pittsburgh, will be married Feb. 15 in New Wilmington, Pa., to J. Douglas Maynard Jr. of Chappaqua N.Y., a teacher at the Hawthorne CedarKnolls School in Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: Cleveland: Council Ends Free Water  To Nonprofit Units
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 7Nonprofit institutions within the Cleveland city limits have received nearly a $1million jolt from the City Council, which has ordered them to begin paying for city water effective Jan. 1.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The question of how the nation's steel industry is going to finance needed expansion appears to have run head on into Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin. Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee. Steel industry spokesmen have indicated they need higher prices to get their profits to the level where they can finance expansion.

title: JURY CAN'T DECIDE IN PROSTITUTE CASE
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 7A 12member jury was unable to reach an agreement yesterday on whether men should be arrested for patronizing prostitutes, and a district court judge declared a mistrial.

title: The Flowering Of Vincent Gardenia
description: NEW HAVEN. It's a character actor's face, no mistake. Jowly  owlish, thinning red hair, a little stunnedlooking, a blank to be filled in to fit the partcab driver, cop, gunman, judge, the guy next door. It belongs to Vincent Gardenia, until recently an actor's actor who got consistently good reviews but whose name the audience forgot from one movie, play or TV show to the next.

title: Pittsburgh, After Studying Fair In Spokane, Ponders One, Too
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7  A proposal that a world's fair be held in Pittsburgh in the 1980's was set forth this week at the 100th annual meeting of the Greater Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Renovators The Target of Protests By Unions
description: With an unemployment rate more than double the national average, unionized construction workers are becoming increasingly militant about the use of nonunion labor on renovation jobs.

title: Music/The plain truth is that Messiah has a universal appeal. (Denis Stevens)
description: When the nation proceeds to brag of these unwiedly choral Impostures, these attempts to make the brute force of a thousand throats do what can only be done by artistic insight and skill, then I really lose patience, wrote George Bernard Shaw in 1891. He continued: Why does not somebody set up a thoroughly rehearsed and exhaustively studied performance of the Messiah in St. James's Hall with a chorus of twenty capfable artists? Most of us would be glad to hear the work seriously performed once before die.

title: The Ballet: Journey
description: The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater is in great shape and working like crazy. Friday night it gave the first performance of one of its major revivals of the season, Joyce. Trisler's Journey. It may seem strange to describe a solo lasting some 10 minutesperhaps even lessas a major revival, but the pungency and passion of this miniature have nothing to do with the size or its length. It is, in its way, an almost perfect choreographic realization of an emotional concept.

title: Dani McGrath, Horsewoman, Engaged to William M. Tate Jr.
description: Daniale Cushing McGrath, an exhibitor in the hunter divisions of horse shows, plans to be married to William Manson Tate Jr., a trainer with Nimrod Farm, showhorse farm in Weston, Conn. The wedding will be Jan. 25 in Weston.

title: A Correction
description: In an article in this section on Nov. 24, the first name of Joseph Brockett, artistic director of the Performing Arts Foundation in Huntington, L. I., was given incorrectly.

title: DIGNITY STRESSED IN NEW U.S. JAIL
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 7An old man who has been in and out of prisons and jails since he was 15 years old looked about him in disbelief this week when be checked in as one of the first residents of the Government's new $12.8million correctional center in downtown San Diego.

title: Klein Shares His Views With Residents of Suffolk
description: MIDDLE VILLAGE  Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein met with 450 residents of the Town of Brookhaven here Wednesday night in what he termed a gloves off, no holds barred session of three hours to answer questions on a dozen issues.

title: Dog, Near Death, Rescued by Neighbors Who Cared
description: Last Sunday, when trying Silvertein's pet dog stumbled upon something in the grass of Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, closer inspection revealed a very ill, very weary, very lonely female dot. But her rescue would not be easy, as her ?? benefactors soon discovered.

title: Gifts for the Holiday With Touch of the Unusual
description: Holiday gift shopping need not mean ties, perfume, handkerchiefs and another pair of socks. Museum shops and stores selling small handmade craft items in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island are stocked with unusual itemsfrom the functional (pottery mugs and cheese sets) to the bizarre (a 2foothigh garden sculpture of Little Orphan Annie) that make shopping a discovery and receiving a surprise.

title: Notes: Rome Braces For Holy Year Influx
description: DESPITE worldwide economic troubles, including those in Italy, itself, it is estimated that more than 6 million visitors will stream into Rome during the 1975 Holy Year. That figure, offered by, the city's tourist officials, is about 100 per sent higher than the 1974 tourist inflow and seems likely to cause an overcrowding problem. But it's a problem other European nations would welcome, since so many travelers have decided to fight inflation closer to home rather than attempt to cope with it on major trips. (Some travel officials in the United States predict that the number of Americans crossing the Atlantic in the next few months will be 50 per cent below last winter.)

title: WEST GERMAN TEST IN SPACE SET TODAY
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 7 (UPI)The first of two Helios spacecraft, designed to study the sun at a closer range than any satellite has in the past, will be launched here tomorrow morning, starting West germany's most ambitious and expensive space project.

title: Bullets Defeat Pistons
description: LANDOVER, Md. Dec. 7 (UPI) Phil Chenier scored 31 points and Elvin Hayes 22 tonight as the Washington Bullets held off the Detroit Pistons for a 9489 victory.

title: Program for Gifted Students
description: STONY BROOK  Every Saturday morning at 8:45, 277 high school students gather in basement of the Earth and Space Sciences building on the campus of the State University of New York here. They greet, each other with sleepy smiles, exchange a few quiet jokes along with their notes, then shuffle into a huge lecture room where they settle into silence, pens in hand.

title: Pamela Browning Has Nuptials
description: Pamela Rea Browning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Browning of Saucon Valley, Pa., was married last evening to David William Durrant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald W. Durrant of Micheldever, England.

title: Miss Williams Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs, Herbert Philip Williams of New Vernon, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jo Anne Williams, to Peter James Coutrakon, son of Judge and Mrs. Basil Hatton Coutrakon of Springfield, Ill.

title: The Retired Now a Force in Jersey Counties
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J.Retirement communities, which have mushroomed in central New Jersey during the last decade, have become a significant social, financial and political force.

title: NIXON REPORTED SELLING 2 HOMES
description: MIAMI, Dec. 7  The two houses owned by former President Richard M. Nixon in the fivehouse Key Biscayne Presidential compound are expected to be put on sale within the next few days, according to several local real estate dealers.

title: Restoration Is Reviving Imlaystown
description: IMLAYSTOWNThis small Monmouth County village of 50 persons is reliving its past. Thanks to the architectural  landscaping firm of Zion & Breen, the town's buildings, which had been deteriorating over the centuries, are being restored to their original splendor.

title: Rural Eastern Shore Debates Plant for Oil Industry Equipment
description: CAPE CHARLES, Va.When the autumn sun is warm, as it ofen is here on Virginia's Eastern Shore, John Satchell, who is 76 years old, drags his wooden platformchair out onto the sidewalk of Mason Avenue and shines shoes. The price is 25 cents. One of his customers the other day was S. H. Holland, a retired auto mechanic. While Mr. Satchell applied the polish and the cloth, he and Mr. Holland talked with a bystander about the controversial proposal of a Houston company to build a largescale industrial plant on 980 acres of farm land and shoreline just south of this old, sleepy Chesapeake Bay town of 2,000 persons.

title: Texas Legislature Ordered to Investigate Wiretap Allegations Against Southwestern Bell
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 7 Allegations that illegal telephone wiretaps have been used to send innocent men, to prison, to learn political plans and to gather information for extortion have prompted Lieut. Gov. William Hobby to order an investigation by the Texas Legislature.

title: What's Doing in LISBON
description: AFTER THE REVOLUTION Lisbon has managed better than most European capitals in preserving its past charms. This is, one of the Merits of the underdevelopment that Portugal has suffered, from for so long. But something new has been added. Its is the revolution that began April 25 and which set the country on the road to becoming a modern democracy. There is a noticeable new spirit of uplift now in the formerly downtrodden Poruguese, and if you raise your voice and express impatience in a cafe or bar, you are apt to get a scornful look from a waiter, followed by a remark such as That must be a man of the 24th of April. Lisbon's old monuments and buildings are covered with political posters and graffiti, despite a Sunday cleanup a few weeks ago, and even if they are not pretty, they do impart a flavor of the political ferment and excitement here. Apparently, tourists were a little apprehensive about the revolution, and this, plus worldwide racession local cholera, has reduced tourism in Portugal this year by 20 per cent. The cholera is over (it never really affected tourists), and although inflation is still a factor in Portugal, costs are reasonable compared with the rest of Europe. As for the revolution, it has been remarkably free of violence; as someone has noted about the peaceful Portuguese temperament, In Portugal they don't kill the bull.

title: French leave
description: ACROSS

title: Her Heart Belongs To Pop And Jazz, Folk, Rock, Country, Blues ...
description: Maria Muldaur, a new cynosure of pop/rock aficionados, was gyrating to the beat at the back of the stage at Avery Fisher Hall one evening last month. Out front, a succession of crack jazz musicians, nearly all of them considerably older than Maria, who is 32, soloed with hot precision. When it was time for Maria, the headliner on the program, to step forward, she sang with jubilant assurance, and her voice became another swinging horn. So flawless was her time that her elder colleagues in the band started nodding to her beat; and the leader of the ensemble, Benny Carter, the most elegantly inventive of alto saxophonists and an incisive arranger, too, beamed at the singer like a proud uncle.

title: Encounter: A. Cantetbitry Pilgrim Lament
description: OUR plan was simple. My wife and Would tent neat in London and drive out to Canterbury and back. The lefthand drive times no Prob. I'd done it in Ireland. But it tinned out, there were problems.

title: GROUPS CRITICZE L.I. MENTAL CENTER
description: Expressing indignation at what they called horrible conditions at Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brent, wood, L. I., two citizen groups have called for the ouster of its board of visitors its regional mentalhygiene; director and the State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.

title: Shakeout Time for Calculators
description: Consumer delight with pressing the little buttons and reading the litup numbers on pocket calculators is reflected in the fact that one out of 10 Americans now owns one.

title: Desperation of Aged: Two Cases Updated
description: Mrs. M. and Miss V.two old women in the city. They have never met.

title: A. F. DI RUFFANO
description: Agostino Ferranta di Ruffano, retired Italian diplomat who ad served as Consul General in Boston, Philadelphia and Ottawa and had been Ambassador to Paraguay, died Wednesday at the home of his son Roberto in Mendham, N. J. He was 89 years old.

title: JaiAlai Rings Quiet Bell On the Las Vegas Scene
description: LAS VEGASBilled as the world's fastest game, jaialai has caught on here as a refreshingly slow way to lose your money.

title: Iron of Martin Sostre
description: It would be ironic indeed if Martin Sostre, of all people, should win a new trial on grounds that he had been convicted on a trumpedup charge for which the sole supporting witness has now recanted his testimony. But just that will be argued tomorrow in Federal Appeals Court in New York.

title: Arkansas Papers to Merge
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark, Dec, 7 (AP)The Hot Springs New Era, an afternoon newspaper, announced plans Tuesday to merge with its sistr publication. The Sentinel Record, effective Jan. 1.

title: Health Plan's Ombudsman Sells Insurance to Medical Groups
description: Jack Bigel, the union consultant who serves as ombudsman for subscribers to the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, is also the broker handling malpractice insurance for the medical groups that treat these, subscribers.

title: Gloucester Class Helps Foster Parents Help One Another
description: SEWELLNatural parents have their Dr. Spock and his bringing up baby books to help them over the rough spots. Foster parents in South Jersey have their Dr. Fred Zubrack and his own special version of bringing up literature.

title: Resch Foils Scouts in 41 Decision
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Dec. 7 With rosetinted eyes on a possible start in Philadelphia tomorrow night, Glenn Resch, the Islanders' backup goalie, redeemed himself tonight as the New Yorkers downed the Kansas City Scouts, 41, before 11,929 fans in Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mohonk: Rest, Chat, Rest, Stroll, Rest
description: The setting: Mohonk Mountain House, large and rambling Victorian hotel in the Shawangunk Mountains near New Peitz, N.Y.

title: WIDOW OF NOVELIST DIES IN A CAR CRASH
description: PRINCETON, Dep. 7 (UPI)Katherine O'Hara, wife of the late novelist John O'Hara, was killed tonight when her car ran off a rainslicked road and hit a untility pole here, the police said.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these letters pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whole actual letters may not be published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers printed below; Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improve ment Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page.

title: Solzhenitsyn in Sweden To Receive Nobel Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Sunday Dec. 8 (Reuters)Exiled Soviet author Aleksander T. Solzhenitsyn arrived here today to collect the Nobel Prize for literature that he won in 1970.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market continued to react to negative economic news last week. It fell sharply in light trading.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Here is an armful of magazines that traffic in color photographs of bare people. One draws the line at nothing these days in the quest for significance. In an avalanche of meaningless events, who is to say that those fetchingly undraped thighs and pectorals have less to tell us about The Times In Which We Live than the economic pronouncements of Gerald Ford the crop analyses of Earl Butz?

title: Remember the Neediest  Share Blessings With Others
description: The effects of recession and inflation have touched virtually everyone, but for one million New Yorkers who are the victims of poverty, old age, illness, family turmoil and neglect, 1974 has been a devastating year. And the prospects for 1975 are not encouraging.

title: Britain's Defense Cuts
description: The critical condition of Britain's economy is primarily responsible for the new tenyear plan for a major reduction in London's defense spending, the first since an earlier Labor Government in 196768 accelerated Britain's withdrawal from military power East of Suez. However, the projected cutbacks are more moderate than expected. The gradual military withdrawal East of Suez that has accompanied the end of empire is to be virtually completed, except for Hong Kong and, for the time being, Oman. But Britain's 55,000man force assigned to West Germany under the North Atlantic alliance is not to be touched, nor is the Royal Air Force commitment there.

title: Mrs. Fuller Is Married to F. H. Heath
description: The marriage of Leonore Reynolds Fuller of Boston to Fuller Haskell Heath, a widower, of Manchester, N. H., took place at neon yesterday. Justice of the Peace Emil N. Winkler of Boston performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When Julian Semyonov's PETROVKA 38 (Stein and Day, $1.95) was published here in 1965, it attracted quite a bit of attention. It was about crime in Moscow, written by a Russian. and it was the first Russian procedural that anybody had ever come across. Now this novel about three efficient, humanistic Moscow cops is out in paperback. It is surprising how closely it resembles American proceduralswith its combination of slogging footwork, chasing down clues and even protecting the innocent. These Russian cops are definitely Good Guys. A welcome novelty.The various crime series in paperback continue, for better or worse, mostly worse. Our friend the Baroness is with us in THE SONIC SLAVE by Paul Kenyon (Pocket, 95 cents). Here the female James Bond is located in an Arabian emirate, with a bloodthirsty ruler and a mad scientist who has developed a death ray. Lots of sex, too, as usual. Idiocy, but wellwritten, and the hell of it is that you find yourself hooked. Then there is the Peacemaker series by Adam Hamilton; the third release is THE XANDER PURSUIT (Berkley, 95 cents), all about a Caribbean republic, a threatening dictator nearby, ambling and the Mafia. Who resolves everything? The 32yearold Barrington HewesBradford, one of the world's richest men. Pretty bad, this. Not much better is the second in The DC Man series, as represented by James P. Cody's SEARCH AND DESTROY (Berkley, 95 cents). Dead Senator; suicide (say the cops); senatorial investigation into crime; dirty work in the Senate. Brian Peterson cleans this one up.

title: Miss Lansburgh to Wed Charles V. McAdam 3d
description: Cynthia Lloyd Lansburgh and Charles Vincent McAdam 3d, grandson of Mrs. Frank E. Gannett of Rochester, and the late Mr. Gannett, founder of the Gannett newspapers, plan to marry Jan. 25.

title: Sack, again, to ballet
description: The name Jerome Robbins, to most theatergoers, is stuck like an indelible label onto a variety of surprisingly designed and brilliantly made packages. Some people remember Robbins as the man who choreographed the intricate, hilarious Mack Sennett ballet in High Button Shoes; others think of the sophisticated naivet of the Small House of Uncle Thomas sequence in The King and I; still others associate him with the nostalgic warmth of Fiddler on the Roof. His TV Peter Pan, starring Mary Martin, delighted millions of American childrenatheart. Everyone knows his first produced choreography, the ballet Fancy Free; everyone knows that West Side Story opened up new possibilities in American musical theater. It didn't have an upbeat ending; its characters were tough and contemporary, and a lot of them didn't have hearts of gold. West Side Story not only stitched acting, singing, and dancing into an almost seamless whole, but all of its irritable, edgeofviolence atmosphere seemed produced by the tensions between movement and dance.

title: Jet Game to Be Picketed
description: Members of a cameramen's union will picket the Buffalo BillsJets game at Shea Stadium today to protest the failure of N.F.L. Films to sign a contract with the unions. Members of Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture Industries, contend that N.F.L. Films, owned by the National Football League, agreed last June to recognize the union as bargaining agent but still had not signed a contract.

title: Suggestions to Ease Fuel Crisis
description: The acute fuel oil problem faced by New Yorkers [Oil Dealers Warn of Wintertime Cutoffs, Nov. 24] might be eased if the city takes immediate action. Here are some possible remedial steps:

title: Late TV Listings
description: The folowing information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: COLUMBIA OPENS NEW GYMNASIUM
description: Six years after Columbia University's attempt to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park sparked a violent community protest and the worst student riots in the school's history, a new $12.7million gym was dedicated yesterday in the northwest corner of the campus.

title: Epilogue
description: Alderman Thomas Keane, second in power to Mayor Richard J. Daley in Chicago's city government, has been sentenced to five years in prison on 17 counts of mail fraud and a single count of conspiracyone more indication of the disintegration of the Daley political machine. The conviction of Mr. Keane, who became a multimillionaire during his 30 years as a Democratic alderman, arose from his real estate transactions while chairman of the city council finance committee. Mr. Keane is the highest ranking member of Mayor Daley's city government to be prosecuted by the office of United States Attorney James R. Thompson, a Republican

title: REPORTERS TOUR ACADEMY OF F.B.I.
description: QUANTICO, Va., Dec. 3Step into our version of Reno said Charlie Parsons, stringing open a door to reveal a roulette wheel of the finest quality, slot machines, blackjack table and craps tableall orated by the Federal Bureau Investigation.

title: When 60,000 Governments Try to Decide On Land Use
description: In a historic irony, the nation's bicentennial in 1976 could well find the country facing constitutional questions as knotty as those that beset the Founding Fathers.

title: 2 Major Sponsors Quit U.S. Powerboat Racing
description: The two major liquor concerns sponsoring offshore powerboat racingHennessy and Martini & Rossihave disassociated themselves from racing in the United States. Martini & Rossi will campaign Dry Martini, its 36foot Cigarette, solely on the European circuit. This decision will enable Carlo Bonomi, the 1973 and 1974 world offshore powerboat champion, to continue piloting the boat that brought him the two titles. The millionaire banking entrepreneur from Italy was having difficulty finding time for the numerous transAtlantic trips on the Union of International Motorboating (U.I.M.) circuit.

title: 3 Killed in Crash of Light Plane at Bear Mountain
description: A singleengine light plane carrying three persons crashed and burned last night in Harriman State Park Near Bear Mountain, N.Y., killing all aboard.

title: Yonkers Man Reappointed
description: ALBANY Dec. 7 (UPI)Edward J. Freeman of Yonkers has been reappointed to the State Law Revision Commission, Governor Wilson's office announced today. The commission examines laws and makes recommendations for changes. Members are paid $13,936 a year.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In view of the deepening recession it is distressing that Congress has not already acted to repeal the unfortunate new law allowing United States citizens to own gold after Dec. 31.

title: OPPOSITION LOSES SUIT IN SINGAPORE
description: SINGAPORE, Dec. 7  A recent slander and libel case continues to have loud repercussions in Singapore and to demonstrate this island nation's firm attitude toward dissent or opposition.

title: Music: Berlioz Oratorio
description: Berlioz's Christmas oratorio L'Enfance du Christ is a muted, devotional work. It is full of exquisite beauties and includes some extraordinarily subtle instrumental touches, yet it ends raptly with an a cappella chorus.

title: The World/confinued
description: This scenario is sometimes offered for the future of the United Nations: The United States, upset at defeats in the General Assembly by the underdeveloped nations, stops all contributions to the world organization. Middle East oil countries rush to fill the 25 per cent hole in the budget. The General Assembly votes, on a motion by Cuba and Equatorial Guinea, to move United Nations headquarters Algiers. Saudi Arabian investors buy the desirable East River real estate with its 2,000car underground garage.

title: Women Plan Rally For Soviet's Jews
description: SHORT HILLS  Women's demonstrations in support of Soviet Jews will be held herer and in 50 other target locacations throughout the United States on Tuesday, Human Rights Day.

title: 1924 When the Best Was Not Good Enough
description: The seven significant books of 1974 announced on our frontpage last week were selected by the Book Review editor and staff after considerable deliberation and genteel haggling from among some 2,000 books reviewed in these pages during the past year. Fifty years ago, this same journal, reviewing several hundred more titles (in its elongated pages, with minuscule type), was offering no list of the year's best. Had it ventured to do so, deliberations could well have gone far into the night, haggling might not have been so genteel, and the final choices might barely have squeezed onto a front page twice the size. It was that kind of yeara time of plenty in every respect but one (Prohibition's repeal was nine years away!)

title: Movement in Africa
description: A historic development is under way in southern Africa. Despite a tight security screen, it is clear that some leaders of the new black African states are negotiating seriously for the first time with Prime Minister Vorster's white South African Government and Prime Minister Ian. Smith's white minority regime in Rhodesia. Some observers expect agreement shortly on a blueprint for resolving the problem of blackwhite power sharing in Rhodesia.

title: World News Briefs
description: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 7 (UPI)Ignoring a minor shooting incident between police and intruders, several LatinAmerican leaders began a weekend meeting here today to draw updeclaration calling for a new era of authentic independence.

title: ECONOMIC SLIDE VEXES CANADIANS
description: OSHAWA, Ontario, Dec. 5At Harry's Hideaway Lounge which is usually a happy place there is apprehension these days among the assemblyline workers who stop in for a draft beer on the way home from the General. Motors plant down the street.

title: RHODESIA REJECTS BLACKS' DEMANDS
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Dec. 7Hopes for a quick settlement of the prolonged Rhodesian dispute, and of a general whiteblack dtente in southern Africa, were seriously dimmed today when the white minority regime of Rhodesia rejected proposals put forward by black leaders meeting here.

title: A ROMMEL WINS PLACE IN POLITICS
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Dec. 4The new Mayor of this Swabian city is Manfred Rommel, son of Field marshal Erwin Rommel, the famed desert fox of World War II.

title: The Concord: Eat, Swim, Eat, Rest, Eat
description: MY passage to Europe on the S.S. France was canceled in the wake of a mutiny this autumn, so I went to the Catskill Mountains instead. I spent 11 days at the Hotel Concord in Kiamesha Lake, N. Y., and discovered that the food, rates, entertainment compared favorably with those on an ocean cruise. And as a bonus, I viewed the Seven Wonders of the Concord with a fastmoving, fasttalking tour leader:

title: Miss Andes Affianced to Barry Spodak
description: Elizabeth Dare Andes and Barry Neil Spodak of Washington plan to marry Dec. 21.

title: Bills Seek to Stop Jets' Streak
