The cabana, which would rent for about $400 a year, according to Mr. Caso, attracted wide public interest three years ago when Mr. Caso asked for an appropriation from the County Board of Supervisors for repairs to 1,216 cabanas at Nassau Beach. Despite considerable criticism from the Democrats, the money was appropriated and the repairs made. A beach toolshed was also renovated to house Mr. Caso's bodyguards.

title: WNEW Buys Mets' Radio Rights
description: The radio rights to New York Mets baseball have been purchased by WNEW, Metromedia's 50,000watt local outlet, for a threeyear period. George Duncan, president of Metromedia Radio, said that except in instances where prior programing commitments prevent broadcasts of weekday afternoon games, WNEW will carry the entire schedule, in addition to a number of preseason games, from its 1130 position on the AM dial. And to insure unbroken continuity of Mets' baseball on radio, added Duncan, arrangements will be made to utilize other facilities for Weekday afternoon games, and Possible preemptions created by other, sports carried by the stations.

title: A West German Satellite Built To Orbit Sun Launched by U. S.
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 10The United States joined with West Germany early this morning to place into an elliptical orbit of the sun an 815pound satellite that will record data on the earthsun relationship.

title: 46 Arrested in Drug Raids
description: ABINGTON, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP) The police arrested 46 persons in the AbingtonCheltenham area of Montgomery County today in a series of drug raids. Police Chief Herbert Mooney of Abington Township warrants had been issued for 62 persons suspected of drugrelated offenses.

title: RAYMOND J. NOLAN
description: Raymond J. Nolan, a member of the Plant Protection Department of The New York Times for nine years, died at home yesterday, He was 58 years old and lived at 107 Vermilyea Avenue here.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Dr. Gordon Oppenheimer Dies; Urologist and Surgeon Was 74
description: Dr. Gordon D. Oppenheimer, urologist and surgeon, died Monday at Mount Sinai HospiItal. He was 74 years old and lived on Furnace Dock Road, Peekskill, N. Y.

title: 43 Heed Appeal for the Neediest
description: The first contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since the annual Christmas appeal began Sunday have arrived at The Times and the eight private social agencies that are helped by the campaign.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Nelson G. Gross, former New Jersey Republican chairman, asked a threejudge panel of the Federal Court of Appeals in Philadelphia to overturn his conviction earlier his year on charges of criminally masking, as a Federal tax deduction, a $5,000 contribution to the 1969 election campaign of former Gov. William T. Cahill.

title: Seaman to Return to Israel
description: BEAUMONT, Tex., Dec. 10 (AP)A Russian seaman who left an Israeli ship here believing he could get political asylum will be allowed to return to Israel voluntarily. An Immigration and Naturalization Service judge granted Anatoli Sverdlin yesterday the right to return voluntarily within two weeks.

title: Giammona Nation's Top Rusher
description: Louie Giammona of Utah State won the majorcollege rushing title for 1974, a couple of years after his uncle, Dick Vermeil, now the coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, told him he'd have to convert to split end if he wanted to make it in bigtime football. But I wanted to show my uncle I can run for a major college team, said the junior tailback. He gained 1,534 yards in 10 games for a 153.4yardspergame average, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: REPORTED REBUFF BY ARABS DRIVES
description: PARIS, Dec. 10Market reports suggesting that Persian Gulf oilproducing states were no longer willing to take sterling in payment for their stateowned oil drove the pound to historic lows today and forced the Bank of England to spend an estimated $250million in an effort to support the currency.

title: Double at Aqueduct Pays $1,671 And Only Onie Favorite Scores
description: On an afternoon in which the first three races were won by thoroughbreds returning better than 201 and a $2 daily double ticket on the combination of 6 and 6 was worth $1,671, chalk players in the crowd of 13,326 at Aqueduct yesterday put in a long vigil before being rewarded.

title: U.S. AIR PIONEER KILLED IN BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 10Humphrey W. Toomey, a retired vice presideut of Pan American World Airways, has been found shot to death in an apartment here, a spokesman for the airline said today.

title: Cadillac Sales High in Contrast to Auto Industry Slump
description: DETROIT, Dec. 10Joseph Gaspar and Lincoln Griffin probably have never met Maceo Thomas and Ray Mikula. But they are all linked together, unwitting partners in an economic success story that runs counter to the recession that is gripping both the auto industry and the country.

title: Whirlpool in LIFO Method
description: The Whirlpool Corporation announced yesterday that directors had approved a change ??n accounting for substantially all of its inventories to the ??astin, firstout (LIFO) method from the firstin, firstout (FIFO) basis for the year 1974. The change will increase cash low by about $20million to $25million equivalent to 55 to $9 cents a share, while reported ??arnings for the full year would be reduced in the range of 55 to 60 cents a share, the company ??aid.

title: Party for Childrenand Animals, Too
description: Christmas parties aren't just for people. At least not as far as members of the Friends of the Zoo are concerned. They're holding A Christmas Party Central Park Zoo Saturday from 1 to 4:30 P.M. and the event's almost as much for the residents of Central Park Zoo and the Lehman Children's Zoo as is for the children who drop by.

title: City, With Little Money to Build, Is Assailed on Design Expenses
description: City officials were sharply criticized yesterday for proposing to allocate $380milliononefifth of the 197576 capital budget of $1.79billionfor architectural design, planning and other staff expenses when almost nothing will be available to start new building projects.

title: G.O.P. State Leader to Quit
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec, 10 (AP) David Sullivan, under fire from other Republicans since the party sustained big losses in the November elections, said today he was resigning as Republican state chairman effective Dec. 19.

title: Holdup Victims at Store Include African Official
description: The Third Secretary of State of the African country of Sierra Leone was among 10 customers and sales personnel held up yesterday in a midtown clothing store by four gunmen who escaped with more than $3,600 in cash and an undetermined amount of personal jewelry, the police reported.

title: Makarios Endorses Communal Parley By Cyprus Leaders
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 10 Archbishop Makarios gave his endorsement today to a continuation of meetings between representatives of the Greek Cypriote and Turkish Cypriote communities.

title: Rabin Rejects Criticism Of Peace Terms Remarks
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 10Premier Yitzhak Rabin, replying to critics said today that his guidelines in promoting peace with the Arabs were expressed in policies approved by Parliament not in newspapers.

title: 5% Tax Surcharge Weighed in Trenton; Vote Set Tomorrow
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The State Senate will vote Thursday on a 5 per cent state tax on Federal income taxes.

title: U.S. WON'T DELAY ON SPACE MISSION
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 10Even if Soviet scientists fail to orbit their Soyuz spacecraft next summer for a rendezvous with a threemen American team for a joint mission, the United States plans to go ahead with an alternate mission of ifs own.

title: Aliens Taking 1.2 Million Jobs In Nation, House Member Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Ap) Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California, contended today that illegal ailens were the greatest single factor in the economic recession on the ground that they were taking 1.2 million jobs from American citizens.

title: Large Spanish Realty Company Has Difficult Financial Problem
description: MADRID, Dec. 10Spain's biggest real  estate investment and tourist promotion company appears to be on the point of collapse after suspending payments both to employes and investors.

title: Shippers' New Boris Is a Mussorgsky First
description: Opera productions in this modern age have long gestation periods. Plans for the Boris Godunov that the Metropolitan Opera is presenting Monday, night date three years, from the present BlissChapin regime back through the Chapin regime to the Gentele regime. And now that the opera is actually about to go before the public, its conductor, Thomas Schip pers, is showing all the signs of a nervously expectant parent.

title: MID75 FOOD COST EXPECTED TO RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Food prices are likely to continue to rise at an annual rate of 15 per cent, at least through the first half of next year, and the outlook could be worse if another year of bad weather should hamper crop production, a top economist at the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The stage rights to Merie Miller's bestseller, Plain Speaking, An Oral Biography of Harry S. Truman, have been acquired by Harlan Kleiman and Paul Caravatt. A Broadway presentation is being planned for next fall.

title: Carranza Case Postponed
description: Justice Jack Rosenberg yesterday postponed until Friday the armedrobbery case against Daniel Carranza, a police informer who told The New York Times that the District Attorney's office had granted him immunity to confess to 200 crimes committed since 1968. For the second day in a row, no assistant district attorney appeared in court to present the state's case.

title: Gas Spokesman Sees Cut in Oil Use Slowing Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  A natural gas industry spokesman told Government officials today their effort to cut oil consumption 1 million barrels per day would slow the economy about 3 per cent and impose austerity on the nation.

title: Schmidt in Key Role at Market Meeting
description: PARIS, Dec. 10West Germany came to the Common Market conference here as the strongest economic power in Europe and, because of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's recent visit to Washington, a broker between Europe and the United States.

title: 125 Begin Deer Hunt After U. S. Court Gives Approval
PROF. EDMOND BOOTH
description: NORWICH, Vt., Dec. 10 (AP) Edmond H. Booth, a Dartmouth College processor emeritus, died at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: MINNIE W. BOEHM
description: Minnie W. Boehm, a former pianist who had accompanied a number of performers, died yesterday at her home. She was 89 years old and lived at 179 East 79th Street.

title: Mills Quits as Chairman; Young Democrats Advance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas; relinquished today the chairmanship of the House Ways and Means Committee that he has held since 1958. House Democrats began making good on promises to name younger Congressmen to important committees.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: Jerrold to Move Plant
description: CHICOPEE, Mass., Dec. 10 (AP)The Jerrold Electronics Corporation, a manufacturer of cable television components, will begin transferring its Chicopee operation to, Nogales, Mexico, Jan. 1, company officials said today. The shift will mean the loss of nearly 300 jobs.

title: MINES AND UNION IN A NEW ACCORD
description: A tentative contract agreement for 4,000 striking mine construction workers raised hopes yesterday that the country's coal production would be back in full swing next week for the first time in a month.

title: Schools to Get Milk
description: Milk industry and union officials agreed yesterday to supply milk for hospitals, nursing homes, daycare centers and schools, reopening three milk processing plants as the metropolitan area milk strike moved into its sixth day. Page 40.

title: Ford Stresses Winning z As American Tradition As America
description: President Ford, who has shown that football centers do not have to live in anonymity all their lives, spoke about winning as a great American tradition as he addressed 1,300 people at the 17th annual National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame awards dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel last night.

title: People and Business
description: Criticizing what he termed the hodgepodge of bank regulation as it has evolved in this country, John E. Sheehan, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, yesterday supported the idea of a single Federal banking regulatory agency.

title: Job Action by Traffic Agents Causes Cut in Parking Tickets
description: A job action by Traffic Department employes in their contract dispute with the city has substantially reduced the number of parking and traffic violation summonses issued and has resulted in a loss of revenue to the city.

title: Russian Astronauts Ready For an Apolio Rendezvous
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (UPI)The Soyuz 16 astronauts said today that their sixday flight went without a hitch and pronounced their improved spacecraft ready to rendezvous with an American Apollo.

title: 3,000 MORE CITY WORKERS EXPECTED TO BE LAID OFF, INCLUDING 400 IN UNIFORM
description: Mayor Beame is expected to announce today the dismissal of 3,000 more city workers, in cluding an estimated total of 400 members of the city's three uniformed services and 125 highlevel appointed provisional employes.

title: Cahn Says He Paid an Informer With Funds From D. A. Group
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 10District Attorney William Cahn of Nassau County said today that he had used $18,000 in expense money given to him over the last five years by the National District Attorneys Association to pay a confidential informer.

title: ITT Continental: Giant in Sales but Not So Brilliant in Earnings
description: The ITT Continental Baking Company, the world's largest bread baker, has been an important part of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's empire since 1968.

title: Wine Industry Told To Go Metri?? '79; Fifths to Be Liters
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI), The Treasury Department today gave the wine industry five years to go metricoffering liters instead of fifthsand said a similar order would be issued to distillers in a few weeks.

title: Giammona Nation's Top Rusher
description: Louie Giammona of Utah State won the majorcollege rushing title for 1974; a couple of years after his uncle, Dick Vermeil, now the coach at the University of California, Los Angeles, told him he'd have to convert to split end if he wanted to make it in bigtime football. But I wanted to show my uncle I Can run for a major college team, said the junior tailback. He gained 1,534 yards in 10 games for a 153.4yardspergame average, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Trade Bill Fate in Senate Is Linked to Amendments
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Senate delayed again today its consideration of the sweeping Administration trade reform bill, but despite approaching Congressional adjournment the legislation still is given a fair chance of passage. Once the bill reaches the floor its fate will depend, according to numerous Congressional sources, on the willingness of the Senate to defeat unrelated amendments, particularly those involving taxation of oil companies and deregulation of the price of natural gas.

title: 8 of 26 Democrats in State Senate Seek Post of Minority Leader
description: Eight of the 26 Democrats in the State Senate yesterday indicated a preference for himself to be the next minority leader.

title: Mary Lou Williams Uses Musical Past In Her New Pieces
description: According to the records, Mary Lou Williams is now 64 years old. Seeing her at the Cookery, University Place and Eighth Street, where she is playing piano Mondays through Saturdays to Jan. 23, this seems unlikely and, on hearing her, it is obviously beside the point. Both Miss Williams and her music are timeless and contemporary.

title: Injunction Ends District 9 SitIn Over Appointment of Anker Aide
description: The sitin at Community School District 9's offices in the Bronx, ended after six days Yesterday as a State Supreme Court justice issued an injunction against the protest and as its leader conceded that she did not see any purpose in continuing it.

title: Federal Warranty Standards And Consumer Aid Agreed On
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 10A Senate and House conference committee agreed today on legislation that would set Federal standards for product warranties and make important changes in Government consumerprotection activities.

title: F.C.C. Judge Renews WPIX License
description: An administrative law judge of the Federal Communications Commission, in an initial decision yesterday, granted WPIX, Inc., the renewal of its license to operate on Channel 11 here and disqualified the application of the challenging group, Forum Communications, Inc., which has contested the license in a tempestuous proceeding that has lasted more than five years.

title: Violence in Oslo Marks Nobel Award to Sato
description: OSLO, Norway, Dec. 16 (UPI)Demonstrators hurled rocks and bottles when Eisaku Sato, the former Japanese Prime Minister, arrived at Oslo University to receive the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize today in a ceremony attended by King Olav of Norway.

title: Bridge:
description: Victory in the Reisinger team championship in San Antonio, Tex., Sunday night may presage a return to the international arena of Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J. His team has now qualified for the international playoff matches that will eventually determine, the United States representatives in the 1976 World Team Olympaid.

title: TEARGAS POLICY IS MODIFIED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Administration announced to day that it was prepared to renounce most military uses of tear gas and herbicides to obtain Senate approval of the 1925 Geneva protocol banning chemical and bacteriological warfare.

title: YOUTH JOB TRAINING AUDITED IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Dec. 10 (UPI)Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that a Federal audit of the city's $5million youth job training program would be completed and open for discussion by the end of the month.

title: FORD IS PLEASED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Senate approved today the nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller to be Vice President, by a vote of 90 to 7.

title: ASCAP and Soviet Sign Royalties Pact
description: The first agreement between the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the Soviet Union's new Copyright Agency obligating the Russians to pay royalties for live performances of American music was signed here yesterday.

title: FUNDS FOR HEALTH APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  Compromise legislation to continue five health programs and to establish several new ones, including a national research effort to combat rape, was approved today by the House.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: DEBATE ON TERROR DELAYED AT U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10The General Assembly's Legal Committee recommended today that proposals for United Nations action against international terrorism be put off for consideration for another year.

title: What Price Glory in NATO?
description: PARIS  Sandwiched between summit meetings and diplomatic negotiations, this week is supposed to mark significant events in the 25yearold North Atlantic alliance. Gen. Alexander Haig assumed command over NATO forces in Europe yesterday and the coalition's defense and foreign ministers gathered in Brussels for their annual winter conference.

title: Saigon's Casualties Top 2,000 in 5 Days Of Intensified Battle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 (AP)South Vietnamese casualties rose to a total of more than 2,000 today in the fifth day of intensified fighting, the Saigon command reported.

title: Food and Security
description: From all accounts, the Administration's decision on the level and purposes of this country's food assistance program for the coming year is finally to be made this week. Along with budgetary questions affecting aid levels, there is a debate within the Administration which, roughly, stated, is between those who want American food aid to be used for political purposes and those who want it to be used for humanitarian purposes.

title: Two More of Sextuplets Dead; 3 Surviving Reported Improved
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP)Charlotte Lange lost two more of her premature sextuplets today, but the three surviving infants showed minor improvement as they struggled for life in respirators.

title: One Wrinkle Left In Playoff Picture
description: Not quite every National Football League question was answered by Monday night's 2317 victory the Washington Redskins scored at Los Angeles, but many were.

title: Newcombe Is Upset By Vilas
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 10 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas toppled John Newcombe today, 64, 76, in the opening round of the $100,000 Commercial Union Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: HELEN GOLDSTEIN
description: Helen Ungerleider Goldstein, who until her retirement two years ago was a psychiatric social worker and an education adviser to the Girls Scouts of America, died Monday in Miami Beach. She was 68 years old and lived in that city.

title: President Rebuffed by Congress In First Test on Spending Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) Congress gave final approval today to only 18 per cent of a multi  million  dollar spending cutback proposed by President Ford as an antiinflationary move and directed him to spend the rest of the funds.

title: About New York The Life of the Party
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke was singing, smiling gently, looking through steelrimmed glasses, and offering a rendition of Love Makes the World Go Round. He was doing it in a voice that was neither tenor nor baritone, but something in between, and out in the darkness of the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria, 1,200 people were listening. Mostly, they seemed to love it.

title: Krishan Bhatia, 49, Author, A Correspondent in Capital
description: Krishan Bhatia, an Indian newspaperman and author, died Monday in Washington, where he was correspondent for The Hindustan Times of New Delhi. He was 49 years old and lived in Sumner, Md.

title: Fed Clears TakeOver Of Ritter by Hanover
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board granted approval today to Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, of the nation's fourth largest bank, to acquire the Ritter Financial Corporation of Wyncote, Pa.

title: CONGRESS AGREES TO RUSH ATESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Congress today approved a program to accelerate the testing of atomic weapons before a new atomictest treaty with the Soviet Union went into effect, but provided less than half the money requested by the Administration.

title: Retail Sales Sag Continues
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Retail sales continued to sag in November, a preliminary Commerce Department estimate disclosed today.

title: New Jersey Sports The Jersey Bounce
description: WEST ORANGE, Dec. 10The Soviet national trampoline team, which has never lost a dual meet, and the United States team, which has never been beaten in a World championship, meet tomorrow night at the South Mountain Arena and a 13yearold New Jersey girl, Della Shell, may be in the lineup for the United States.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: New Senate Election Weighed in New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., Dec. 10 (AP)A legal snarl surrounding New Hampshire's disputed United States Senate seat increased today as Representative Louis C. Wyman, the Republican candidate for the seat, clung to a twovote lead in a review of the state's official recount.

title: DeBeers Accused Of Helping to Fix Abrasives' Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) A Federal grand jury indicted a South African company and two United States companies Coda on charges of conspiring today on charges of conspiring illegally to fix prices and allocate customers and territory for sales of industrial diamond abrasives.

title: Phillips Prosecutor Said To Have Known of Job Bid
description: The prosecutor who tried the murder case of William R. Phillips knew one week before the verdict that a member of the jury had applied for a job in the District Attorney's Office but did not report it to the judge or defense attorneys, testimony in State Supreme Court disclosed yesterday.

title: Willard Hotel Backers Lose
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) An appeals court ruled today that the historic Willard Hotel at 14th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue could have its interior corn out and its facade demolished in the course of remodeling it as an office building. A threeJudge panel of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals ruled in favor of the owners despite opposition in Congress and from Mayor Walter E. Washington, the Fine Arts Commission and the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation.

title: Clues Sought in Hotel Robbery From Glove Left by a Gunman
description: One of the five gunmen who robbed the SherryNetherland Hotel Monday of jewels, cash and travelers' checks, now estimated to be worth $300,000, left behind a white vinyl glove, the police said yesterday.

title: Judge in McCrane's Trial Dismisses 7 of 11 Charges
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 10 (UPI) A Federal judge today dismissed 7 of 11 counts against Joseph M. McCrane, former Treasurer of New Jersey who is on trial here on tax fraudconspiracy charges.

title: British Win Pledge of Easier Terms Within Common Market
description: PARIS, Dec. 10Britain succeeded today in winning pledge on easier terms from her Common Market partners that appeared to insure her continued membership in the ninenation community.

title: INDUSTRY TESTIFIES ON MARKET IN SUGAR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) Tight supplies, the impending expiration of the Federal Sugar Act and rising production costs all have played a part in forcing up sugar prices, members of a House Agriculture subcommittee were told today.

title: YOUTH, 16, SEIZED IN A BRONX RAPE
description: The police said yesterday that a 16yearold youth who had spent almost all of his life in institutions for the mentally ill raped and mutilated a 20yearold girl in Crotona Park in the Bronx last Friday eve? ning.

title: Followers View Coffins Of Juan and Eva Peron
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 (UPI)Followers of former President Juan D. Pern and of his first wife, Eva, filed today through a simple modern chapel where their coffins lay side by side, his sealed shut and hers open. Following her death in 1952, Eva Perns body went on display in Buenos Aires. It was removed after the overthrow of President Pern in 1955 and shipped to Italy for secret burial. It was returned to Argentina last month.

title: Deer Hunt Starts
description: More than 125 hunters began killing deer in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge yesterday after a threejudge Federal Appeals Court panel in Philadelphia decided not to block the hunt as requested by conservationists. Details, Page 49.

title: Books of The Times
description: BADMEN OF, THE WEST. By Robert Elman. 256 pages. Illustrated. A Ridge Press/ Pound Book. $14.95.

title: No Major Progress Reported in MilkStrike Talks
description: Officials of the milk industry and the striking teamsters union worked yesterday to devise a contract proposal that would be acceptable to a disgruntled membership that rejected a tentative pact last Sunday.

title: Manuel Komroff Is Dead at 84; Author of 45 Novels Was Editor
description: Manuel Komroff, novelist and writer, died yesterday in Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N.Y. He was 84 years old, and lived in nearby Woodstock.

title: JOSEPH HOFFMAN, ATOMIC SCIENTIST
description: BUFFALO, Dec, 10 (AP) Dr. Joseph G. Hoffman, a scientist who helped develop the atomic bomb in World War II and later did cancer research, died here Sunday at his home. He was 65 years old.

title: Mexican Raiders Kill 5 In $200,000 Robberies
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 10 (AP)Fifteen bandits, including three women, robbed two banks of $200,000 today, killing five policemen and wounding two, the authorities said.

title: LADY WILKINS
description: Lady Wilkins, widow of Sir Hubert Wilkins, the Australian (polar explorer by plane and (submarine, died Sunday in the Orange View Convalescent Home in Anaheim, Calif. She was 73 years old.

title: LOWER 1974 PROFITS ARE SEEN BY DU PONT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (Reuters)E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., expects lower earnings in 1974 despite at least a 15 per cent Increase in sales, the chairman of the giant chemical maker, Irving Shapiro, told analysts today.

title: House Tax Unit, in Shift, Allows SavingsExemption Bill Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation today that would make some of the interest on savings accounts taxexempt, But it also paved the way for its bill to be amended on the floor of the House.

title: XEROX TO LAY OFF 6,000 EMPLOYES
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 (Reuters)The Xerox Company said today it would shut down its Webster, N. Y., manufacturing facility and secondary equipment refurbishing and machine conditioning centers elsewhere in the United States, laying off 6,000 workers.

title: TALKS ARE HALTED IN ARAMCO BID
description: LONDON, Dec. 10Negotiations for full nationalization of the Arabian American Oil Company by Saudi Arabia were suspended here today, and no plans for a resumption were announced.

title: Deere Profits Rise 13.4% On 37.8% Sales Increase
REPORT ATTACKS BRONX PADDLING
description: A citizens commission called yesterday for the dppointment of an ombudsman and other measures to protect the city's public school pupils against corporal punishment and improper suspensions.

title: U.S Gallery Drops Preview Over Demand by China
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 The National Gallery of Art canceled the press preview today of an exhibition of Chinese archeological finds rather than agree to Peking's demand that Chinese Nationalist, South Korean, South African and Israeli newsmen be barred.

title: AHMED MEDEGHRI, 40, ALGERIAN MINISTER
description: ALGIERS, Algeria, Dec. 10Interior Minister Ahmed Medeghri died here today at his home after what an official bulletin called a tragic accident. He was 40 years old.

title: Braves Subdue 76ers
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 10 (AP)Randy Smith and Garfield Heard led a thirdquarter rally that helped the Buffalo Braves gain a 10191 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Red Smith
description: Wayne Woodrow Hayes, architect of young manhood, student of military history and defender of the oldtime faith, held a press conference yesterday. Nobody explained why. However, Ohio State's football coach was in New York for last night's dinner of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame and tomorrow night's presentation of the Heisman Trophy to the Ohio State tailback, Archie Griffin, and he had some time free so the Tournament Roses people from'Pasadena got him to talk about the Rose Bowl, where he and his players are wont spend New Year's Day. Not having lost game in several weeks, he didn't try punch anybody but just stood up all scrubbed and brushed and buttoned and the charm hang out. After the first 50 minutes he entertained several questions but to repeat them here would be the same as interrupting him. He said in part:

title: ATTICA DEFENDANT CHARGES BEATING
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 10 (AP) A physician testified here today that he had found multiple bruises all over the body of Charles Pernasiiice, a defendant in the Attica prison rebellion trials who contended that he had been beaten senseless by jail guards earlier in the day.

title: CREDITORS BACKED ON REPOSSESSION
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a creditor can repossess goods purchased on installments without granting the buyer any formal court hearing.

title: Schlesinger Warns NATO Against Cuts in Strength
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 10  Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger warned the Atlantic allies today against any stamped to cut back military strength for economic reasons on the supposition that American power would be sufficient to protect them.

title: CURB DRAWS FIRE OF NURSING HOMES
description: The nursinghome industry yesterday attacked a state effort to limit its profits from realestate deals as confiscation of our property without due process.

title: Civil Liberties Union Assails Slaying of Long Branch Youth
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10The New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union assailed today the use of hollownose bullets and unjustifiable deadly force in the fatal shooting of a 16yearold high school junior by the Long Branch police early Sunday morning.

title: DEALERS ASK FORD TO CUT CAR PRICES
description: Contending that its members Shad been forced to absorb too much of the losses resulting from plummeting new car sales, a national association of Ford dealers called on the Ford Motor Company yesterday to cut wholesale car prices by hundreds of dollars to stimulate sales.

title: HENRY W. WIESE
description: Henry William Wiese, who had been a Broadway theatrical agent since the early nineteenforties, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 350 West 55th Street. He was 70 years old.

title: Firm Rein on Intelligence Units Urged by 2 ExC. I. A. Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 140Two former high officials of the Central Intelligence Agency today declared their public support for proposals to increase Congressional control over domestic and foreign intelligence activities.

title: PAY AND HOURS CUT AT CAPITAL PAPER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10In an alternative to largescale layoffs, The Washington StarNews announced today that 560 employes, including reporters and editors, will work a fourday week for four days pay.

title: Energy: Growth...
description: Opening public hearings this week to help design a substantive national energy policy for the Ford. Administration, Interior Secretary Morton touched on a pervasive myth when he asked, How much conservation can the economy stand?

title: ACCORD REACHED IN INDIA SCANDAL
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 10A compromise was reached today in a dispute over opposition demands that the Government publish the results of an inquiry into charges that a Cabinet minister and a member of Parliament from the governing Congress party were involved in an importlicense scandal.

title: MARIAN K. BRYAN, 74, EXDANCE TEACHER
description: Marian Knighton Bryan, who started the moderndance program at Sarah Lawrence College in the nineteenthirties, died Monday in New York Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 200 Boulder Trail in Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Issues in the Milk Strike
description: PARTICIPANTSLocal 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing 3,000 drivers and plant employes who process and deliver milk to 10 million consumers in the metropolitan New York area.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Ford, in City, Hears Views Of Nominee's Study Panel
description: President Ford held an unusual session here yesterday with key associates of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to hear their views on world energy, rawmaterial and food problems.

title: National 1976 Primary Advocated by Wallace
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 10 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace called today for the creation of a national Democratic primary to let the people decide the party's 1976 Presidential nominee.

title: Strip Mining Bill Is Stalled in House As Panel Recesses
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Efforts by backers Of the Federal stripnine control bill to get it finally passed by the House of Representatives before Congress adjourns in about 10 days suffered a further setback today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE INCOMPARABLES Tis the season for Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, as if any season weren't. The joyous spirit and festive sparkle of the holiday period somehow demand a reappearance of Hollywood's great dance team, whose buoyantly melodie and sophisticated vehicles cheered a tired world from the midDepression era up to the war years. The nine AstaireRogers movies live on, of course, on television, along with some atrocious cuts and those blasted commercials. They are very much alive, in their original form, at the snug, enterprising East Village showcase, Theater 80 St. Marks (2547400), the revival house off First Avenue, which first brought back Flying Down to Rio (1933) and Roberta (1935) two years ago to capacity crowds. As a Christmas gift, the theater has now reshuffled a quartet of double AstaireRogers double features in four days starting today: Admission is $2.50.

title: PAIN FELT BY VATICAN AT CAPUCCI SENTENCE
description: ROME, Dec. 10The Vatican expressed pain and grief today at the sentencing by an Israel Court of the Most Rev. Hilarion Capucci, Greek Catholic Archbishop of East Jerusalem, for smuggling arms to Palestinians. The Vatican statement said:

title: U.S. JUDGE DROPS 7 M'CRANE COUNTS
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec 10 (UPI)A Federal judge today dismissed 7 of 11 counts against Joseph M. McCrane, former Treasurer of New Jersey who is on trial here on tax fraudconspiracy charges.

title: Federal Warranty Standards And Consumer Aid Agreed On
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 10A Senate and House conference committee agreed today on legislation that would set Federal standards for product warranties and make important changes in Government consumerprotection activities.

title: AMEX ENDS MIXED AFTER 6 DECLINES
description: Halting a sixsessionslide, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed in steppedup trading yesterday. In the overthecounter market, prices were higher also in increased trading.

title: 71 SENATORS SEE U.N. HURT BY P.L.O. VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)Nearly threefourths of the Senate today sent President Ford a letter saying that United Nations support for the Palestine Liberation Organization undermined the world body as well as American foreign policy.

title: Carey Sees Willowbrook Hope and Despair
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey brushed away a fly from a 16yearold youth whose hands were tied to the bed above his heada mentally retarded hemophiliac who was being prevented from hitting himself. Then Mr. Carey had to flick the fly away again.

title: JOSEPH E. DYNAN, A.P. REPORTER, 62
description: PARIS, Dec. 10 (AP)Joseph E. Dynan, a longtime foreign correspondent for The Associated Press, died today at the American Hospital in suburban Neuilly. He was 62 years old.

title: SAFETY CHANGES IN DC10'S ADVISED
description: Concern about the danger from fragmenting DC10 engine blades prompted the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday to propose new directives to cope with the hazard.

title: Jets Vote Namath No. 1 Man
description: HEMPSTEAD, L I., Dec. 10 Like statements by Leonid Brezhnev and Mao Tsetung, the words of Joe Namath. have become a hot subject for dissection and interpretation. But seldom have Soviet and Chinese watchers had as much fun poring over words as Namath watchers are having these days.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL TO CUT SUGAR PRICE
description: CPA International, Inc.'s industrial division said that, effective Monday, it would reduce the price of its industrial sugars by $5.75 a hundred pounds. The cut will bring CPC's price for 100 pounds of, extra fine granulated sugar to $61 and the price for 100 pounds of its bulk granulated and liquid sugar to $60.60.

title: Drop Comes Despite a Hint of Further Easing by Fed
description: Weakness in New York City issues hit the taxexempt market again yesterday, despite further indications of credit easing by the Federal Reserve.

title: 3 Boys Among 29 Cited for Heroism In Aiding the Police
description: Three young boys who pursued a robber were among 29 civilians who were presented at Police Headquarters yesterday with commendation certificates and bartype badges for out standing acts of heroism in going to the aid of police officers.

title: Ford, in City, Hears Views Of Nominee's Study Panel
description: President Ford held an unusual session here yesterday with key associates of Vice Presidentdesignate Nelson A. Rockefeller to hear their views on world energy, rawmaterial and food problems.

title: EUROPE TALKS END WITH HINT OP GAINS
description: PARIS, Dec. 10Leaders of the nine European Common Market countries ended their twoday conference here tonight with a declaration reflecting moves toward compromise on the key issues of oil diplomacy and the terms of Britain's membership.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1974
description: Reports that the Persian Gulf oilproducing states would stop taking the pound sterling in payment for their oil touched off a run on the currency, driving the pound to historic lows. The Bank of England had to spend an estimated $250million in an effort to support the currency. It fell, by more than 1 cents against the dollar to $2.3195. [Page 1, Column 5.]

title: 1,000 TeenAgers Enjoy A Holiday on the Mayor
description: It was 9 A.M., an hour when most high school students are bent over their desks, pens poised, noses buried in their textbooks. But yesterday about 1,000 Bronx teenagers went to a Manhattan movie theater, where many of them were bent over the candy counter, munching popcorn and sipping soft drinks.

title: American Can Extra Payout
description: Directors of the American Can Company declared yesterday a yearend extra of 20 cents a share, along with the regular quarterly dividend of 55 cents a share, making a total of 75 cents, payable Feb. 24 to holders of record Jan. 10. W. F. May, chairman, said the extra dividend reflected the ninemonth earnings, which exceeded the record for any full year's profits.

title: Connors Is Ranked No. 1 and Smith 2d
description: Jimmy Connors made it certain this year.

title: Bliss and Chapin: On a Collision Course?
description: When Anthony A. Bliss was named executive director of the Metropolitan Opera on Nov. 21, it clearly was a vote of no confidence in Schuyler G. Chapin, the general manager. Since then there has been silence from the principals and the board of directors. Mr. Bliss says he will move slowly, learning more about the house before any major decisions are made. Mr. Chapin says he can work with Mr. Bliss.

title: John Gordon, 84, Editor in Chief Of The Sunday Express, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (UPI)John Gordon, editorinchief of The Sunday Express, died last evening, He celebrated his 84th birthday the day before.

title: State Must Borrow Money To Pay Jobless in January
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)The state will have to borrow some $38million from the Federal Government to make its jobless benefits payments in January, the Labor and Industry Department said today.

title: FORD STILL INSISTS ON HIS JOBLESS AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said today that President Ford was willing to negotiate a broader public service employment program with Congress but the President still insisted on a trigger mechanism to start and stop the program when the unemployment rate reached specific levels.

title: I.T.T. BAKING UNIT ACCUSED BY F.T.C. OF ILLEGAL ACTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, Inc., the nation's largest baker of bread, was accused by the government today of attempting to monopolize the wholesale baking business through the use of a large number of illegal predatory practices.

title: TV: Lively Tony Orlando and Dawn
description: The Tony Orlando and Dawn series, which has replaced Sons and Daughters on the CBSTV schedule for Wednesdays at 8 P.M., offers a fascinating primer in packaging a musiccomedyvariety format for the broadest possible audience. Produced by Saul Ilson and Ernest Chambers, it's mildly hip, in a safe middleoftheroad sort of way. It's slick. It's disarmingly hokey. Imagine, if you will, Sonny & Cher filtered through Lawrence Welk.

title: History Returns To Boston
description: BOSTONI have in mind one night in 1965.

title: Carey to See 3 Upstate Mayors On Fiscal Problems Tomorrow
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey announced yesterday that he would visit Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo tomorrow to discuss the fiscal problems of those cities with their Mayors and other public officials.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: People in Sports
description: As an indication of today's uncertain, economy Bobby Unser, the 1974 driving champion of the United States Auto. Club and winner Of the California 500 race, received a ??

title: Islanders Set Back Blues, 32
description: UNIONDALE L.I., Dec. 10 It's getting harder lately to get the Potvin brothers straight. The Islander defensemen keep appearing in tandem in the scoring summary.

title: Insurers Assail Proposed Rule To Back Up RepairShop Work
description: Spokesmen for New York State's automobile  insurance companies registered opposition yesterday to a proposed regulation that would oblige an insurer to name a repair shop and to guarantee its work when it gives a policyholder with an autocollision damage claim an estimate below that of reputable body shops.

title: NETWORKS SUED OVER PRIME TIME
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10The Department of Justice reinstituted antitrust suits today against the three national television networks, charging them with monopolizing evening programing.

title: Groups Rehearse for Free Series
description: Practicing for Lincoln Center community holiday festival, clockwise from top. Chiang Ching Dance Company of Chinese Artists Intercultural Movement; Shirley Rushing of the Rod Dodgers company of the Harlem Cultural Council and Elizabeth Kelsch and Philip Clapp of Project Grow in Brooklyn. Two weeks of shows begin on Monday.

title: Ginsberg Witness Revises Testimony
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 10Contradicting his previous testimony, timony, the chief witness for the prosecution in the trial of Martin Ginsberg, a suspended family court judge, said today that the defendantwho was then an assemblymanhad returned $5,000 of an alleged $7,500 bribe.

title: Knicks Win 6th In Row
description: Walt Frazier took on the Kansas. CityOmaha Kings in the second half last night and the Knicks' winning streak grew to six games.

title: Rally Reflects Hope for U.S. Action to Fight Recession
description: Stock prices staged a strong rally yesterday, buoyed by expectations of Government action to combat the deepening recession. Analysts noted that the advance reflected the growing convictions of investors and traders that President Ford would announce new stimulative programs for the economy in an address at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: New Jersey Is Among States Seeking an Equitable Way to Pa or Schools
description: The New Jersey Legislature, struggling to meet a State Supreme Court deadline of Dec. 31 to find a more equitable way of financing public schools, finds itself with plenty of company. Within the last two years a dozen states have taken major steps to restructure their system of school finance, and at least 10 others have made modest efforts in the same direction, Court cases that could lead to a whole new financing system are pending in seven states, including New York and Connecticut.

title: Can Less Drinking Lead to Less Starvation?
description: While Americans are being urged to eat less grainfed meats in order to free grain for the world's hungry millions, a companion grainsaving measure has been suggested that hits at another American institutionalcohol.

title: Advertising
description: Last April the American Management Association's session on inhouse advertising agencies attracted some 60 interested parties. The current threeday seminar has 16.

title: Big Board Hints at Court Fight to Keep Fixed Rates Unless It Gets Safeguards
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The New York Stock Exchange hinted strongly before the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it was prepared to fight in the courts to keep fixed brokerage commission rates unless the switch to negotiated rates is accompanied by safeguards for the exchange's auctionmarket system.

title: Record Flow of Pilgrims to Mecca Is Taxing the Saudis
description: JIDDA, Saudi ArabiaThis is the time of the sacred hajj, the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, and hundreds of thousands are thronging through this Red Sea port to the birthplace of the Prophet Mohammed.

title: Jews Host In U.S. Tells Of Problems
description: Julia Coopersmith, whose Soviet relatives left Philadelphia after two months and two days, said yesterday that the couple had found it difficult to learn English and to adapt to the American way of life.

title: Ehrlichman, Crying, Tells How Nixon Bade Him Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 John D. Ehrlichman, testifying in his own defense, continued today to implicate former President Richard M. Nixon in the Watergate coverup.

title: Mills Quits as Chairman; Young Democrats Advance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, relinquished today the chairmanship of the House Ways and. Means Committee that he has held since 1958. House Democrats began making good on promises to name younger Congressmen to important committees.

title: Solzhenitsyn Collects Nobel He Won in '70
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn took possession today of the Nobel Prize for Literature that he was unable to claim when it was awarded to him four years ago.

title: The Theater: Parades
description: PARADES SHALL FOLLOW, a play creaied by Gary Nebiol and Donald Marcus, written by Donald Marcus. Setting by Kert Lundelt; lighting by Michael Watson; production stage man. ager, William Yaggy; technical director, Steve Crowley. Presented by the Ensemble Studio Theater, Curl Dempster, director. Jerry Zacks, producer, at 549 West 52d street.

title: PUBLIC TRIAL OF 170 BEGINS IN ETHIOPIA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 10 (Reuters)A courtmartial today began trying the first of some 170 former Ethiopian officials and military leaders held in the cellars of the Grand Palace.

title: VILLARD KINSMAN HEARD ON HOUSES
description: A surprise witness yesterday at a hearing on a plan to build a 52story hotel and office building behind the landmark Villard Houses was a greatgrandson of Henry Villard, the railway magnate, for whom the Italian Renaissance brownstones were built in 1886.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: WIDOW FOUND DEAD IN BRONX APARTMENT
description: An 83yearold widow who had lived in the same Bronx building for 32 years was found dead yesterday in her apartment off the Grand Concourse after what the police said may heve been a burglary.

title: PRICES OF FUTURES INGRAINS STEADY
description: Commodity futures were marked by dull trading on most exchanges yesterday, and there was little news or even rumors reported by commodity men as affecting their markets. Grains were relatively stable as traders awaited the crop report due after the close.

title: TROOPS RECOVER BODY OF THANT
description: RANGOON, Burma, Wednesday, Dec. 11 (Reuters)Some 1,000 soldiers and policemen using tear gas and a crane raided the campus of Rangoon University early today and took the body of the former United Nations Secretary General U Thant, from a studentbuilt mausoleum to a tomb constructed by his relatives in the city center.

title: CITIES AGAIN USING CHRISTMAS LIGHTS
description: Cities and businesses across the country are lighting up for the holidays this year, after a Christmas cutback in 1973 prompted by the energy crisis.

title: Theater: A Fleeting Praise of Love
description: Terence Rattigan's play In Praise of Love, which opened at the Morosco Theater last night, is sentimental, facile and inconclusive, but it does have Rex Harrison and Julie Harris being their customary charming selves, which may well be enough for some theatergoers.

title: Taiwan Ignores a Major Anniversary
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 10Few noticed and those who did averted their eyes as a major milestone in the history of this embattled island passed by today without commemorative speeches, editorials or public recognition of any kind.

title: H. MALCOLM GILLETTE
description: H. Malcolm Gillette, who had served 40 years with the Rockefeller Foundation, died yesterday in a hospital in Wakefield, R.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Wakefield and formerly lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: In Defense of Mr. Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10  President Ford is being criticized severely and sometimes even savagely these days. Even his supporters are giving him what Damon Runyon used to call medium hello. But in fairness, there is another side to the Ford story, which has to be balanced alongside the charges against him.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Joffrey Ballet Acclaimed At Opening in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (Reuters)New York City's Joffrey Ballet received a tumultous ovation here tonight when it opened a sevenperformance moderndance engagement in the Operetta Theater.

title: People in Sports
description: As an indication of today's uncertain economy Bobby Unser, the 1974 driving champion of the United States Auto Club and winner of the California 500 race, received a prize yesterday afternoon not in the form of a check or cash, but in gold coins  $8,500 worth  plus a trophy of two goldplated eagles. The occasion was presentation luncheon at Gallagher's Restaurant, where Unser was honored as Martini & Rossi Driver of the Year, a designation he had won a couple of weeks'go from a panel of autoracing writers engaged for that purpose. Purses of $1,000 and gold medallions were awarded to three runnersup, Cale Yarborough and Richard Petty of the stockcar circuit, and Johnny Rutherford of the USAC Championship Trail, winner of the Indianapolis 500.

title: 3,000 MORE CITY WORKERS EXPECTED TO BE LAID OFF, INCLUDING 400 IN UNIFORM
description: Mayor Beame is expected to announce today the dismissal of 3,000 more city workers, including an estimated total of 400 members of the city's three uniformed services and 125 highlevel appointed provisional employes.

title: 10 Recreational Projects Approved by State Agency
description: TRENTON, Dec, 10 (UPI)The State Environmental Protection Department approved 10 outdoor recreation projects today that will generate up to 300 new jobs through more than $2million in construction.

title: Ford Policy Under Fire
description: Now, with the economy slithering deeper into recesson, housing stuck deep in its slump, auto sales falling off frighteningly, in the view of auto industry leaders, banks and businesses worrying about their liquidity, unchallenged bears prowling a stricken Wall Street and the unemployment rate (already at 6.5 per cent) climbing steeply, President Ford is being assailed on all sides over his economic policies.

title: Thant Body Recovered
description: Burmese troops and policemen raided Rangoon University and took back the body of former U.N. Secretary General U Thant. Page 13.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Judge John Hanrahan, 57, Of Connecticut Pleas Court
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 10Judge John M. Hanrahan of the Connecticut Common Pleas Court died yesterday of a heart attack while walking near his home. He was 57 years old and lived at 112 Michael Road.

title: HENRY SCHLENGER
description: Henry Schienger, cofounder of the R & S Auto Accessory chain stores in New Jersey, died Monday at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in West Orange, N. J.

title: Music: OneAct Operas
description: At the age of 29, Thomas Pasatieri has composed 11 operas, including a oneact comedy, Signor Deluso, which is currently on a double bill at the Manhattan Theater Club along with Holst's Savitri, also a oneact work.

title: U.S. MILITARY AID TO TURKEY CUT OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  The State Department said today that it was cutting off military aid to Turkey immediately, in line with legislation approved in October.

title: U.S. Sues 3 Networks
description: The Justice Department reinstituted antitrust suits charging the three television networks monopolize primetime programing. Page 91.

title: Ehrlichman, Crying, Tells How Nixon Bade Him Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 John D. Ehrlichman, testifying in his own defense, continued today to implicate former President Richard M. Nixon in the Watergate coverup.

title: Record Flow of Pilgrims to Mecca Is Taxing the Saudis
description: JIDDA, Saudi ArabiaThis is the time of the sacred hajj, the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, and hundreds of thou, sands are thronging through this Red Sea port to the birthplace of the Prophet Mohammed.

title: DR. WALTER CADY, A PHYSICIST, DIES
description: Dr. Walter G. Cady, professor emeritus of physics at Wesleyan University, died Monday in an East Providence (R. I.) nursing home on the eve of his 100th birthday. A centennial lecture in his honor was delivered at Wesleyan on Thursday by Dr. Warren P. Mason of the Bell Telephone. Laboratories.

title: Backers of Equal Rights Amendment to Concentrate 1975 Drive in 10 States
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Representatives of 26 national organizations that support the equal rights amendment announced today that they had picked 10 states in which to concentrate their ratification efforts, under a plan drawn up for them by one of the nation's most successful political consultant companies.

title: FORD IS PLEASED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Senate approved today the nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller to be Vice President, by a vote of 90 to 7.

title: N.E.A. Hears Parents Back Plea to Remove Textbooks
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 10 (UPIDrawing an outburst of cheers from antitextbook forces, Elmer Pike, owner of a chemical plant, told a National Education Association research panel today that disputed school books would trigger a breakdown of the American system.

title: ROCKETS IN BEIRUT HIT P.L.O OFFICES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 10Rockets fired today from automobiles parked in crowded streets here caused heavy damage to three offices of the Palestine Liberation Organization, but only minor injuries were reported.

title: ASCAP and Soviet Sign Royalties Pact
description: The first agreement between the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and the Soviet Union's new Copyright Agency obligating the Russians to pay royalties for live performances of American music was signed here yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)The House today passed a bill authorizing $2billion in Federal loan guarantees for the nation's railroads and sent it to the Senate for further action.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The radio rights to New York Mets baseball have been purchased by WNEW, Metromedia's 50,000watt local outlet, for a threeyear period. George Duncan, president Metromedia Radio, said that except in instances where prior programing commitments prevent broadcasts of weekday afternoon games, WNEW will carry the entire schedule, in addition to a number of preseason games, from its 1130 position on the AM dial. And to insure unbroken continuity of Mets' baseball on radio, added Duncan, arrangements will be made to utilize other facilities for weekday afternoon games, and possible preemptions created by other sports carried by the stations.

title: The Chemise, Loose and Easy, Slips Back Into Fashion
description: It was the fashion of the flappers during the middle of the nineteentwenties and the dominant style in the early nineteensixties. Now it looks as if the chemisetechnically any dress that is cut without a seam at the waistlinestands a good chance of becoming the prevailing fashion of the late nineteenseventies.

title: New Militancy Bringing Gains for Japan's Outcasts
description: OSAKA, Japan, Dec. 4After centuries or discrimination, Japan's little known outcasts the Burakumin, have begun to gain a measure of political power and economic progress through a resort to increasingly militant, often violent tactics.

title: Growth Is Reported in Public Payrolls
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) In the last 10 years an average of 1,200 persons a day have been hired for public jobs.

title: Syracuse Sets Back St. John's
description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 10 (AP)  Rudy Hackett pumped in 25 points and Chris Sease added 17 tonight as unbeaten Syracuse downed St. John's, 7566, for its fourth college basketball triumph. The Redmen have a 22 wonlost mark.

title: PRISONER IN SOVIET IS SAID TO END FAST
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (Reuters) Valentin Moroz, an imprisnned Ukrainian historian, has vended a 20week hunger strike after Soviet authorities promised to improve his prison conditions, family sources said here today.

title: Golfers Pay Dey A 40Year Debt
description: From the JonesHagenSarazen era into early 1974, Joe Dey Jr. was golf's prime administrator, the Mr. Golf who supervised the big tournaments, who knew and worked with thousands of golfers, the great ones and the unknowns.

title: 20Year Slush Fund . . .
description: In 1952, exactly twenty years before the 1972 Presidential campaign, Richard Nixon's political career was threatened by the disclosure of a secret slush fund which he, as General. Eisenhower's VicePresidential running mate, had established with the help of some personal friends and supporters. Mr. Nixon survived the charges then leveled against him, not by disproving them but by diverting public attention with the demagogic triumph of the Checkers speech.

title: WALPOLE INMATES HOLD 3 HOSTAGES
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Wednesday, Dec. 11Eight inmates of the Walpole State Prison, believed to be armed with knives, were holding three hostages early this Morning.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Delivery of Milk Cleared For Schools and Hospitals
description: The striking deliverers and the milk industry agreed yesterday to provide milk for hospitals, nursing homes, daycare centers and schools to the degree that they are able, reopening three processing plants to provide the milk.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Operators of nursing homes charged that a state plan to limit their profits from real estate dealings was an unconstitutional confiscation of their property, and implied they would challenge it in court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Edtor: The drafting of an unprecedented charter by the Democratic party, as your Dec. 1 Week in Review article The Democrats and Reform conveys, could have a decisive influence on whether or not a wellcoordinated third party enters the 1976 Presidential contest.

title: 5% Levy on U.S. Income Tax To Be Weighed by Jersey Senate
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  The State Senate will vote Thursday on a 5 per cent state tax on Federal income taxes.

title: Bald Eagle Charge Dropped
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10 (UPI)A Federal appeals court upheld yesterday the dismissal of charges against an Indian who shot at a bald eagle on the Red Lake reservation in Minnesota.

title: 43 Heed Appeal for the Neediest
description: The first contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since the annual Christmas appeal began Sunday have arrived at The Times and the eight private social agencies that are helped by the campaign.

title: Forum Is Warned by State Next Riot Will Halt Boxing
description: Following the third riot in four months at the Felt Forum, the chairman of the State Athletic Commission warned Madison Square Garden last night that he would halt boxing at the Forum if there were one more disturbance there.

title: P.B.A. to Give City Its Demands Today For Officers' Raise
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is scheduled to submit salary demands today in its contract dispute with the city.

title: SUIT CHANLLENGES ADIRONDACK PLAN
description: A major Southwestern land developer sued New York State for $36million yesterday in the first test of the state's power to control development of Adirondack Park, one of the Iargest tracts of undeveloped land east of the Mississippi.

title: PRIMATE IS TOPIC OF TV TALK TONIGHT
description: WNET/Channel 13 will televise a discussion this evening at 7:30, of the controversial documentary Primate, which was broadcast last week on the public television station.

title: STRIKERS DELIVER MILK TO SCHOOLS
description: City schools and daycare centers began receiving emergency milk deliveries yesterday as negotiators for the milk industry and its striking workers continued to grope for a formula to settle the sevendayold walkout.

title: Prices Continue To Move Downward On N.Y. City Bonds
description: Prices continued to slip yesterday on New York City bonds, but a firm tone prevailed in the corporate market and Government securities. Dealers estimated that losses on longer maturities for the city's Oct. 16 bond sale now approximate as much as 20 per cent on trades at current prices.

title: Campanella to Join Black Hall
description: Roy Campanella, former Brooklyn Dodgers catcher, is among 14 persons who will be inducted into the Black Athletes Hall of Fame at Caesers Palace in Las Vegas on March 13, it was announced yesterday.

title: Market Place Public Equity Move Draws Concern
description: If the Public Equity Corporation manages to get the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission and go public as planned, there will be little joy in the executive suites of the nation's major corporations but a little hope, perhaps, for individuals who have found the cost of litigation prohibitive.

title: Three Building Inspectors Indicted for Taking Bribes
description: The city's chief construction inspector in Manhattan and two of his subordinates, were indicted yesterday on charges that they took a total of $4,000 in bribes and unlawful gratuities to overlook building violations and expedite documents in a number of separate incidents this year and last.

title: Layoffs Are First for Police in Decades
description: The layoffs announced yesterday in the Police Department will be the first since the turn of the century, a spokesman said, but, they are expected to have little immediate impact on the public, primarily because they include only slightly more than 1 per cent of the 30,900man force.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: New Jersey Sports
Three Building Inspectors Indicted for Taking Bribes
description: The city's chief construction inspector in Manhattan and two of his subordinates were indicted yesterday on charges that they took a total of $4,000 in bribes and unlawful gratuities to overlook building violations and expedite documents in a number of separate incidents this year and last.

title: Academy to Help Train City Workers Dedicated
description: Mayor Beame formally dedicated the Urban Academy yesterday as a training school for civil servants and predicted it would make the city bureaucracy more responsive, more responsible, more efficient and more effective.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A move by Sports Illustrated magazine to have the $2.25million damage suit brought by Joe Namath of the New. York Jets thrown out of State Supreme Court was heard yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer. He reserved decision.

title: Mexico Halts Vaccinations As Rumors Upset Parents
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11 (AP) Rumors that persons disguised as inoculation teams were giving schoolchildren shots that sterilized them forced health authorities to suspend all vaccination drives today and to post policemen outside Mexico City schools.

title: City Health Agency Scored at Hearing
description: The city's threeyear old Comprehensive Health Planning Agency came under fire from the City Planning Commission yesterday for asserted failure to grapple with such pressing problems as poor distribution of hospital beds, improper placement of nursing homes, and community unrest over the location of domiciliary care facilities.

title: Notes on People
description: Three brothers of the President, Thomas, Richard and James Ford, represented him yesterday at the dedication of the Gerald R. Ford Freeway, the first public facility to be narked for him. The $105million freeway, from Grand Rapids, Mich., southwest to Interstate 94 north of the town of Benton Harbor, was begun three years ago. It runs through part of Mr. Ford's old Congressional district. He was unable to be on hand for the dedication because of the press of official business.

title: Two $750,000 Gifts To Establish Chairs At Barnard College
description: Pledges to endow two $750,000 chairs at Barnard College were accepted by the college's board of trustees last night.

title: Pay Offer Rejected, Construction Men Press Cod Strike
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec, 11 (AP)  The United Mine Worker's 38  member bargaining council voted tonight to send a tentative contract for 4,500 construction workers back to the bargaining table.

title: Met Museum Serves Up A Feast of Impressonism
SHOP TALK
description: Only 11 shopping days until Christmas and you haven't yet checked off every name on your list? And you still don't have a clue what to get for Aunt Millie or even Uncle Ed? Well, there's always jewelry, where there's something for almost every taste and most pocketbooks.

title: Ford Predicts House Will Give Rockefeller Big Victory Margin
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) President Ford predicted today that the House would vote overwhelmingly next week to confirm. Nelson A. Rockefeller as Vice President, although the President said that there could be as many as a hundred votes against the nominee.

title: ExJersey Treasurer Convicted Of Fostering Income Tax Fraud
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 11Joseph M. McCrane Jr., a former New Jersey State Treasurer, was convicted here today on four counts of assisting corporations to file fraudulent incometax returns.

title: Vote on StripMine Control Bill Delayed Again by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11A report that the Federal Energy Administration has switched from opposition to a willingness to live with the controversial Federal stripmine cone trol bill delayed action on the measure again today before the House Rules Committee.

title: SAXBE REPORTED NEXT INDIA ENVOY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec., 11 Attorney General William B. Saxbe is expected to be named United States Ambassador to India soon, Government and diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: Arabs and Africans at U. N. Reply to U.S. on Tyranny
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11Delegates from Arab states and other developing nations today rejected American charges that the United Nations General Assembly was shackled by the tyranny of the majority.

title: FIGHTING GOES ON IN MEKONG DELTA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11Fighting was reported from the Mekong Delta for the sixth day today as Communist units apparently kept up the pressure on embattled Government forces.

title: DUTCH AND U.S. PLAN MORE AIRLINE TALKS
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 11The United States and the Netherlands agreed today, during a meeting here between Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Max van der Stoel, to reopen deadlocked talks over a reduction in the number of flights to America by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.

title: Advertising
description: Since rock music is such a strong and lasting part of our youth culture, it is not surprising that there are any number of companies around anxious to profit from the phenomenon.

title: The Menace of Oil
description: Environmental dangers inevitably trail after oil, wherever and however it is transported, a recent joint report by three Senate committees points out.

title: Hotel Stake for Insurer
description: Hilton Hotels Corporation in Beverly Hills, California has agreed to sell a 50 per cent interest in six of its hotels to the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $83.35million. Under terms of an agreement in principle, Prudential will pay $65.95million in cash and will accept existing mortgage indebtedness of $17.40million. Hilton Hotels said the transaction would result in a nonrecurring gain after taxes of approximately $27.27million equal to $3.26 a common share based on 8.37 million shares outstanding.

title: TV: NET Documents 2Part Life of Adolf Hitler
description: At first glance, or shock, a twopart documentary study of Adolf Hitler seems like singularly inappropriate programming for the period in which Jews are celebrating Hanukkah. Upon further reflection, however, and especially after seeing the film, I believe Channel 13's method has a valuable point to it, most notably as a devastating reminder and somber warning of a madness that was able to grip a large part of the world in this century.

title: Con Edison Reiterates Tax and Dirty Fuel Plea
description: To ease the burden of sharply rising electric bills the Consolidated Edison Company called again yesterday for cutting sharply the taxes it pays and for the burning of dirtierand cheaperfuel.

title: SAXBE REPORTED NEXT INDIA ENVOY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Attorney General William B. Saxbe is expected to be named United States, Ambassador a India soon Government and diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: Primary Result of Effort to Improve Nursing Homes Is Frustration
description: Every investigation of the nursinghome industry  and there have been many over the Fears sooner or later raises the question: Why are the laws not enforced? A Senate committee last month said Medicaid standards had never been enforced. Nobody seems to have denied it. A mood of helplessness and frustration pervades the corps of dedicated civil servants whose job is to assure decent care to the indigent aged and to block the looting of Medicaid funds. Whether they work for the. Federal Government, the state or the city, they report that their efforts at firm enforcement have consistently been blocked by appointees in key positions.

title: People and Business
description: Reports circulated in the airline industry yesterday that Edward E. Carlson, the onetime hotel bellman who worked his way up to the presidency of UAL Inc., parent company of United Airlines, would be elected chairman of the board of directors in. Chicago today.

title: Ease of Gains in Talks Pleases European Common Market Officials
description: PARIS, Dec. 11European officials expressed gratification today over the ease with which leaders of the European Common Market countries had agreed this week on a series of measures to strengthen the market's institutions.

title: Three Illinois Men Charged in Inquiry On Illegal Dogfights
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 11Two men were indicted by a Cook County grand jury and a third man charged in a criminal complain today do connection with illegal dogfighting in Chicago's southwestern suburbs.

title: Dillon to Investigate Cahn's Alleged DoubleBilling
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 11Denis E. Dillon, the Democratic District Attorneyelect of Nassau County, said today that upon taking office he would investigate allegations of doublebilling that have been made against William Cahn, the incumbent prosecutor.

title: Bid for Pardon Deferred
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)  A Federal judge refused to order immediate processing today of a pardon application from a paroled bank robber who cited former President Richard M. Nixon's pardon as a precedent for his lawsuit. Judge William Bryant of United States District Court here deferred a ruling on the pardon aplication of C. Edward Lawrenson, who was paroled two years ago after serving 12 years of a 20year sentence for bank robbery.

title: Books of The Times
description: Recominending 10 outstanding children's books used to be so easy when the reviewer didn't know anything about children and didn't much care. But now that he's reminded almost daily that the books he thinks least of are the most successful when put to the acid test, and vice: versa, the reviewer knows enough to be aware he knows nothing at all. So here are 10 picture books that the reviewer found visually appealing, funny, silly, touching, or fascinating, but will no doubt spend the next months collecting dust while Bugs Bunny at the Easter Party (a gift) gets read over and over and over....

title: Black Professor Sues Rutgers, Charging Racism in Dismissal
description: NEWARK, Dec. 11 (UPI)A $1.5million suit was filed against Rutgers University today by a black business professor who says he was dismissed because of his race and his criticism of alleged racism at the school.

title: U.S. Steel Plans to Expand
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (UPI) The United States Steel Corporation's chemicals division plans to double production of maleic anhydride, a major component of the resins used for molded plastic products, at its Neville Island plant.

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: TVCHANNEL 9, 8 P.M.

title: House Votes for Rise In Antitrust Penalties
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The House of Representatives, by a voice vote, completed Congressional action today on legislation making criminal violations of the antitrust laws a felony, subject to a maximum prison sentence of three years. Such violations are misdemeanors now and the maximum sentence, which is rarely given, is one year.

title: FRANK H. HEISS DIES; LAW PARTNER HERE
description: Frank H. Heiss, a partner in the New York law firm of Kelley Drye Warren Clark Carr & Ellis, died yesterday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived at 1 Fairlawn Court, Rye, N.Y.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Sean Connery and Michael Caine will costar in the film version of Rudyard Kipling's short story The Man Who Would Be King, which will be coproduced and distributed by Allied Artists and Columbia Pictures. The story, a pet project of John Huston since 1953, will be directed by Mr. Huston and produced by John Foreman.

title: Mrs. Meir, at Princeton, Offers Her Views
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 A 76yearold institution named Golda Meir came here to 228yearold Nassau this week, and in two days devoted mainly to answering Princeton University students' questions, became a onewoman faculty on the problems of the Middle East.

title: HEALTH UNIT ASKS $5.4MILLION MORE
description: TRENTON, Dec. 11 (AP) The State Health Department requested today that its budget text year be increased by $5.4million for a total expenditure of $24.9million.

title: Paul Richards, Actor, Dies at 50; Appeared in A Hatful of Rain
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (UPI) Paul Richards, who had important roles in several television shows, died yesterday of cancer. He was 50 years old.
