title: French Premier Will Visit Iran on Cooperation Accord
description: PARIS, Dec. 11 (Reuters)Premier Jacques Chirac of France will visit Iran from Dec. 21 to 23 to start a giant economic, and industrial cooperation program that will include construction of five nuclear power, plants, it was announced today.

title: TOUR OF JAPAN SET FOR U.S. NEWSMEN
description: Ten United States newsmen will be making a threeweek study tour of Japan from March 3 to 23, the American Committee of the International Press Institute announced yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The eighth group home for adolescent children, the first in Manhattan, was opened yesterday by the city at 107 West 85th Street. It will be the home for 10 girls between the ages of 12 and 18 who have been committed to the city's care for reasons that include a lack of parents, who cannot cope with them, school difficulties because of behavior or learning disabilities and court committal.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The 13yearold boy accused of the murder last weekend of 7yearold Danielle Hunter of Rockaway Township was committed to the State Diagnostic Center in Menlo Park for psychiatric and neurological testing for at least 90 days. Judge Kenneth MacKenzie of Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court also ruled at a hearing in Morristown that psychiatrists appointed by the prosecution and defense could examine the suspect.

title: School Board Asks Delay, As It Remaps 7 Districts
description: The Board of Education unanimously adopted a plan yesterday redrawing lines in five Manhattan and two Brooklyn school districts. It then asked the Legislature for twoyear moratorium on the actual redistricting.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES EMERGENCY JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today legislation that would provide for several hundred thousand federally financed jobs for the unemployed and make up to three million other workers eligible for unemployment compensation.

title: How Much It Costs to Run Appliances
description: How much does it cost to run electric home appliances? The City Consumer Affairs Department, using data supplied by the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and the Consolidated Edison Company, provided these estimates yesterday and said the typical cost of electricity in the New York area was 9 cents a kilowatt hour.

title: GEORGE R. FARLEY
description: SOUTH NAPLES, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP)George R. Farley, retired production manager for The Daily News in New York, died yesterday in Naples Community Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: With Charity for Few
description: WASHINGTONJoe Smith avoided the draft during the Vietnam war but does not know whether he technically broke the law or, if he did, whether the Government has any case against him. He is living a quiet life in Indiana now, but he worries that some day he could be prosecuted. If he does face that, he might rather take up President Ford's clemency program. So he decides to ask the Justice Department what his status is.

title: Marcos Frees Hundreds Held Under Martial Law
description: MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 12 President Ferdinand E. Mar cos has ordered the release of 622 of the 5,234 people arrested since he proclaimed martial law in September, 1972.

title: Mrs. Meir, at Princeton, Offers Her Views In Talks Marked by Humor and Grimness
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 A 76yearold institution named Golda Meir came here to 228yearold Nassau this week, and in two days devoted mainly to answering Princeton University students' questions, became a onewoman faculty on the problems of the Middle East.

title: Drop in Price of Red Meat Cuts Market Basket Cost
description: Price decreases for many cuts of red meat reduced the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City by 0.3 per cent last week, the City, Department of Consumer Affairs announcer yesterday.

title: OneYear Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 6.625 per cent.

title: Newcombe Fights Back to Defeat Borg
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 11 (AP)John Newcombe bounced back to defeat Bjorn Borg in two tiebreaker sets today, 76, 76, and kept alive his hopes of reaching the semifinals in the $100,000 Commercial Union Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament. The match was twice delayed by rain and lasted 4 hours.

title: CITY, IN DISMISSING 3,725, INCLUDES 1,100 IN SCHOOLS, 900 IN UNIFORM; WILL FORCE 2,700 OTHERS TO RETIRE
Karate Finals Oct. 45
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dep. 11 (UPI)The 1975 world karate championships will be held Oct. 4 and 5 at Lang Beach, Calif. The Amateur Athletic Union sanctions the event.

title: ATMOSPHERE SEER IN POSSIBLE PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Mankind may some day need to engineer earth's atmosphere to preserve its ability to support life despite the harmful effects of manmade pollution, a scientist told a hearing before the House today.

title: Civil Rights Extortion Laid to 4 More
description: A Federal grand jury here his indicted four more persons, including the executive director of a Bronx antipoverty organization, on charges of shaking down contractors and bombing building sites throughout the city when their extortion demands were not met.

title: Hurricane Carter Denied New Trial on Recantations
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 11Dedaring that recanted testimony by two former prosecution witnesses lacked the ring of truth, a judge today rejected an appeal by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and his codefendant, John Artis, for a new trial on triplemurder charges.

title: Walter Wheeler Jr., 77, Dead; ExChairman of PitneyBowes
description: Walter H. Wheeler Jr., honorary chairman and director emeritus of PitneyBowes, Inc., manufacturer of meters and stamping machines, died yesterday of a stroke at Stamford Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived on Sound View Avenue, Stamford, Conn.

title: RHODESIANS AGREE TO HALT WARFARE DETENTION TO END
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 11  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced today that an immediate ceasefire had been agreed upon by his whiteminority Government and black nationalists after prolonged fighting on the northern frontier.

title: Minister Is Kept Busy In Pulpit and Show Ring
description: Perseverance and devotion are cornerstones in the credo of the Rev. Raymond Kelly Jr., a determined and busy man. He has master's degrees from Loyola and Howard in education and religion and the Baptist minister has organized a mission in Baltimore. He and his wife, Barbara, are junior high school teachers. He is also an Afghan breeder, exhibitor and judge. Kelly also served two terms as president of a specialty club and has helped form another, of

title: A Partial Eclipse Of Sun Tomorrow Will Be Seen Here
description: A partial eclipse of the sun will be visible tomorrow in New York and, to varying degrees, in most of the United States.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Smaller '75 Social Register Adds Two Kennedys
description: The Social Register, New York, 1975, is on the way to its subscribers, and in it are Caroline and John F. Kennedy Jr., listed for the first time, as juniors under the name of their stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Aristotle Onassis.

title: Trap Injures Officer
description: A 22yearold police rookie was seriously injured on his first tour of duty by a booby trap explosion in Harlem. Details, Page 36.

title: New York Reports Lottery Sales Rise; Jersey Gains Also
description: The official in charge of the New York State lottery reported yesterday that creation of a $250,000 top weekly prize had increased ticket sales by about $1million in one week.

title: Buckley and McCarthy Joining To Fight Campaign Reform Act
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Senator James L. Bucklei, of New York, a ConservativeRepublican, and Eugene J. McCarthy, a former Senator from Minnesota and a liberal Democrat, announced today that they would jointly challenge the constitutionality of this year's Campaign Reform Act

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: AT WASHINGTON

title: ... Help From Uncle
description: One avenue of needed help for New York and other bardpressed cities is being opened in Washington. President Ford and the Democraticcontrolled Congress are now moving more or less in tandem on a vastly expanded program of public service employment, with the double purpose of stimulating the economy and easing joblessness.

title: 7 MORE FOOD SPOTS TERMED VIOLATORS
description: Seven more food establishments have been cited by the Health Department for failing followup compliance inspections after violations were found at initial inspections. The findings by the department follow:

title: Officer on First Tour of Duty Injured by BoobyTrap Blast
description: A rookie police officer responding to an apparently spurious call was seriously injured last night when the boobytrapped front door of an abandoned Harlem tenement blew up in his face.

title: Boom Roam Ends Sunday
description: In the Boom Boom Room, the David Rabe drama produced by Joseph Papp for the New York Shakespeare Festival, will end its run at the Public Anspacher Theater on Sunday after 31 performances. The new version, presented last season A the Beaumont Theater, was directed by Robert Hedley.

title: Passaic Vocational School Manager Is Indicted
description: TRENTON, Dec. 11 (AP)The state announced today the indictment of Alex Smollock, manager of the Passaic County Vocational School, on charges that he accepted $40,000 in bribes from companies that did business with the school.

title: Prices Climb in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 11 (AP)The rate of price increases in Canada during the last 12 months was the fastest since wartime price controls were being taken off after World War II, Statistics Canada, a Government agency, reported today. The consumer price index, rose by 1.1 per cent in November to a level 12 per cent above that of a year earlier.

title: Sports Today
description: Seton Hall vs. St. Bonaventure and Manhattan vs. Rutgers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street. First game, 7 P.M. (Television Channel 10 (cable), 7 P.M.) (RadioWSOUFM, 6:45 P.M.)

title: Bill to Protect a Clean River Is Stalled by Rules Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11By a vote of 13 to 2, the House Rules Committee refused today to allow the House of Representatives to consider a bill designed to place 70 miles of the New River on the VirginiaNorth Carolina border in the Wild and Scenic Rivers System.

title: Dance: Feast of Ashes
description: There are at least five contemporary productions of ballets based on Lorca's The House of Bernarda Alba, none of which are totally satisfying but each of which has some interesting touches. Alvin Ailey created Feast of Ashes, his dance version of the story, in 1962 and presented a new production of it on Tuesday evening at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Air Collision Explained
description: DENVER, Dec. 11 (UPI)A Federal investigator says the collision of a jet fighter and light plane over Utah last month, which killed one of the pilots, was a result of Capt, Peter A. Granger thinking he was hooking up his F111 jet with a tanker for an aerial refueling. The collision took place at night.

title: Consumer Notes
description: A study of electricity conservation has found that the way for the individual household to make the biggest energy saving is to reject such modern marvels as electric can openers and electric knives.

title: Lanier Hits 37, Pistons Topple Bullets, 103 to 89
description: DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP)Bob Lanier scored 37 points and grabbed 20 rebounds tonight as Detroit broke a threegame losing streak by defeating Washington, 10389, in the National Basketball Association.

title: Bar Urges Wider Clemency
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) The American Bar Association's board of governors announced approval yesterday of a resolution urging President Ford to extend his clemency program for draft resisters and deserters. The board said the resolution was approved at Monday meeting, and asks that the program be extended to Sept. 16, 1975.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Tomorrow, Dec. 13

title: Security Force Is Proposed For Garment Center Buildings
description: The Mayor's Office of Apparel Industry Planning and Development announced yesterday a proposal to expand its sanitation and information program to include a security force to patrol major buildings in the garment district.

title: Met Museum Serves Up A Feast of Impressionism.
description: Just about the best parties in town are the ones given by the Metropolitan Museums Cinderella doesn't have to watch the clock, the guest list is ideally inventive, the food and drink are far better than one might expect, and the show is usually good enough to make people say, I'll come back tomorrow.

title: Campanella to Join Black Hall
description: Roy Campanella, former Brooklyn Dodgers catcher, is among 14 persons who will be inducted into the Black Athletes Hall of Fame at Caesers Palace in Las Vegas on March 13, it was announced yesterday.

title: New Policy Is Urged for Stimulating the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Two leading Democratic economists told Congress today the time had come for a major switch in national policy toward stimulus for the sagging economy.

title: Motorola to Lay Off 1, 550 Additional Workers in Phoenix Plants
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Motorola, Inc., said today that it would, lay off 1,550 ernployes at semiconductor plants in Phoenix, Ariz. in the next 10 days.

title: Schlesinger Calls AArms Vital to Guard Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 11Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger today championed tactical nuclear weapons as indispensable to the defense of Western Europe and reportedly blocked a Dutch proposal that the weapons be deemphasized.

title: COURT REAFFIRMS LOUISVILLE BUSING
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reaffirmed today its previous decision that could require busing of school children between Louisville and its suburban areas.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Hartfield May Shut 25 Units
description: HartfieldZodys, Inc., a retail chain currently operating under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said yesterday here that it was considering closing 25 of its Zodys discount stores in Miohigan due to weak sales.

title: Film About A Woman At Whitney
description: A FILM ABOUT A WOMAN WHO Directed and written by Yvonne Ralner; photogra her, Babette Mangolte. At the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Strect. Running time: 105 minutes. This film has not been classified. Through Dec 17.

title: CHINESEFOOD CANS ARE BEING RECALLED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that 9,500 restaurantsized cans of Chinese vegetables were being recalled because of underprocessing that could cause dangerous organisms to grow in the food.

title: Butterfield of Ithaca Named Top Coach
description: Jim Butterfield who converted his Ithaca College football team from the wishbone offense to the veer attack this fall, was named Eastern smallcollege coachof the year yesterday by the New York Football Writers. Association. The 47yearold graduateof the University of Maine, where he was a guard, will receive the Stan LomaxIrving T. Marsh Award at the writers association's annual presentation ceremonies on Jan. 23 in the New York University Club.

title: Tourney in Queens Is So Popular It Requires a Satallite Event
description: Christmas tournamentshave made winter vacations a season within a season for many basketball teams. Several of the. New York area's high schools are set for tourneys and those that aren't want in One of the most prestigious, tournaments is the. High School Christmas Classic run at St. Sohn's University in Queens by Elmcor Youth and Adult Activities, Inc. The demand for one of the eight spots in this event has been so great that the sponsors are adding a minitournament to accommodate four of the 86 schools that applied and were turned away.

title: IRWAN A. COHEN
description: Irwan A. Cohen, a manufacturer of upholstered furniture, died on Tuesday in the Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx, He was 59 years old and lived in Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Fuchs, Excels in each and Martinu
description: Joseph Fuchs, who is now 74 years old, has long been an institution in American violin circles, as both teacher and performer. He has never. achieved mass adulation, but he has been an attraction for violin connoisseurs for decades, and a healthy number of them turned up on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall to hear him in recital.

title: Most of Creditors Approve Ancorp's Repayment Plan
description: Ancorp National Services, Inc., said yesterday that its plan for repayment of about $50million of debt has received approval from a majority of its creditors.

title: On West 57th Street, a Beauty Shop Revival
description: Hairdresser country, in the nineteensixties, used to be fairly evenly divided between the West and East 50's. Then salons such as Norbert, Revlon and Enny of Italy closed their doors and the wellcoiffured seldom crossed Fifth Avenue, except to go to Bendel's or Bergdorf's.

title: Surviving Sextuplets Gaining
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 11 (UPI)The doctor of the three surviving Lange sextuplets said today that they may be slightly improved but would probably be kept in the hospital for months. Dr. James Harrod, neonatal care director at the Valley Medical Center, said he was concerned about possible brain damage to the three surviving infants  Brian, Jason and Jolenewho were born three months' prematurely Sunday to Mrs. Charlotte Lange, 26yearold wife of an armored driver.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1974

title: Kings Lift Road Mark To 11 it Row
description: TORONTO, Dec. 11 (UPI) Butch Goring scored a secondperied shorthanded goal and set up Danny Maloney with a firstperiod goal to help the Los Angeles Kings defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 41, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Diding and Mike Corrigan.

title: Two Positions: Moving Backward on Arms Curbs, Forward With Energy
description: McLEAN, Va.President Ford has confirmed the worst fears of those who had hoped that the next round of negotiations on the limitation of strategic arms with the Soviet Union would finally bring to an end the continuing buildup in offensive strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Kennecott to Reduce Net
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation announced yesterday that earnings for the first nine Months would be reduced by about $8.5million, or 25 cents a share, because of a change to the lastin, firstout (LIFO) method of valuing coper and certtain other metals inventories. The company had previously reported net income of $158.6million, or $4.78 a share, for the 9 months ended Sept. 30.

title: Energy Agency Chief Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) The nomination of Robert C. Seamans Jr. to be chief of the new Energy Research and Development Administration was approved today by the Senate Interior Committee and the Joint Atomic Energy Committee.

title: Whalers Triumph Over Saints, 3 to 1
description: WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP)Tim Sheeby Scored a pair of goals on the only two shots he had in the first period to lead the New England Whalers to a 31 victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints

title: PAROLEE IS GUILTY OF BRUTAL KILLING
description: A 28yearold man wio fatally beat a 75yearold woman in the course of a $17 robbery committed within five weeks his parole from prison after serving four years for a similar, but nonfatal, assault has been convicted of murder and other crimes by a Bronx jury.

title: Protesters Burning Buildings in Burma
description: Students and workers roamed the streets of Rangoon, the Burmese capital, this morning, setting fire to public buildings. They withdrew when the Governmente sent convoys of troops to back a declaration eof martial law, a United States Embassy official there reported.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the fog surrounding Joe Naniath's future, the iceberg of reality has been hidden New York is the National Football League's disaster area.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: South Boston Schools Shut in Clashes Over Stabbing
description: BOSTON, Dec. 11Racial violence linked to the school busing controversy erupted in South Boston today as a white youth was stabbed by a black in a high school corridor. South Boston schools were closed down and hundreds of whites battled with the police.

title: 200Mile FishingExtension Bill Clears Senate but Faces Doom
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) The Senate voted 68 to 27 today to extend United States fishing rights from 12 to 200 miles off shore, but the bill apparently is already doomed in the House of Representatives.

title: Armistice Day Returns To Its Traditional Date
description: TRENTON, Dec. 11 (AP)Governor Byrne signed legislation today that designated Nov. 11 as Armistice Day.

title: COPPER FUTURES SHOW PRICE DROP
description: Copper futures dropped 2 cents a pound yesterday on the Conimodity Exchange here amid reports that East Germany had sold a large amount, of the metal in London, depressing prices.

title: WAYS AND MEANS IN LIBERAL SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The House Democratic and Republican leaderships named to the Ways and Means Committee today 16 new members who are collectively far more liberal and urban oriented than the current panel.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1974

title: European Football
description: TEXACO CUP

title: Aiken Uses A Farewell To Confess
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, who has been in the United States Senate longer than any other present member, made his farewell speech to that inattentive body today.

title: Stride Piano Style, Played by Dunham, Is Surprise at Cafe
description: The SherryNetherland Cafe, which has one of the most fascinating streetlevel views in New York, looking out across Fifth Avenue toward lower Central Park and the Plaza Hotel, is not quite the place Where one would expect to hear a strong and vivid performance of James P. Johnson's great stride piano classic, Carolina Shout. But it happens. All you have to do is ask the resident pianist, Keith Dunham, and he will get into that part of his extensive musical bag that he likes best.

title: New York Congressman on the Move Charles Bernard Rangel
description: One day last summer, a Representative's secretary answered the office telephone, turned to her boss and said, I don't know if someone's trying to put us on, but the President's on the phone. When the Representative put the receiver to his ear, the voice he heard saying, Hi, Charlie, was that of President Ford.

title: U.S. STEEL CHAIRMAN OPTIMISTIC ON 1975
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday he remained rather optimistic concerning his company's operations in 1975.

title: Karate Finals Oct. 45
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 11 (UPI)The 1975 world karate championships will be held Oct. 4 and 5 at Long Beach, Calif. The Amateur Athletic Union sanctions the event.

title: Met Pairs Bluebeard's Castle and Gianni Schicchi
description: The newest of the Metropolitan Opera's double bills, Bluebeard's Castle and Gianni Schicchi, received its first performance of the season last night. This was the somewhat unlikely pair that was introduced last June during the house's off season. At that time it received anything but a flattering reception, and one wondered if the producers had done anything in the way of change since then. Apparently not.

title: Stock Index Gains by 1.48; Early Advance Trimmed
description: Stock prices finished higher yesterday for the second consecutive session in active trading, although some of the earlier gains were trimmed during the afternoon. Quotations on the New York Stock Exchange moved higher from the opening until shortly after 12:30 P.M., when they began to fall gradually until the close. The late weakness occurred after the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, indicated that President Ford might not disclose any new policies in his evening address on the economy to the Business Council in Washington.

title: PRESIDENT BARS MAJOR NEW MOVE TO CURB RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 President Ford conceded tonight that the economy is in difficult straits, but he declared that he had no intention of introducing any major new antirecession programs.

title: ANDRE GERAUD, 92, WRITER, IS DEAD
description: PARIS, Dec. 11  Andr Graud, who under the pseudonym of Pertinax was one of the most influential French editorial writers between the two world wars, died today at SegurleChteau in central France at the age of 92.

title: J. DIXON EDWARDS
description: J. Dixon Edwards, a former State Department career officer and second attach under General of the Army Douglas MacArthur during the occupation of Japan, died of cancer Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Mohawk, N.Y.

title: PHILLIPSPROSECUTOR DENIES ANY COVERUP
description: The deputy prosecutor in the murder trial of William R. Phillips, a former police officer, testified yesterday that there had been no attempt to cover up the fact that a juror on the panel had applied for a job in the District Attorney's office.

title: Son's Example Is Cited in Gift to Neediest
description: A father recalled that his young son had stimulated his interest in The New York Tithes Neediest Cases Fund when as a students at Horace Mann School for Boys he had served on a committee that delivered the school's annual contribution to The Times each December.

title: A SenateHouse Group Modifies Eximbank Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) A SenateHouse conference committee reached agreement today on a modified version of a bill extending the life of the ExportImport Bank for four years.

title: 200,000 Walk Out in a Protest in Basque Region
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Dec. 11Some 200,000 workers and students deserted their factories and classrooms today in three Basque provinces of northern Spain in support of political prisoners now being held in Spanish jails and of political freedom in general.

title: 2 Killed in Tel Aviv By Grenades Hurled In a Movie Theater
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday, Dec. 12Two men were killed and 52 people were injured when several hand grenades exploded in the balcony of the Chen Theater during a movie last night.

title: ExJersey Treasurer Convicted Of Fostering Income Tax Fraud
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 11Joseph M. McCrane Jr., a former New Jersey State Treasurer, was convicted here today on four counts of assisting corporations to file fraudulent incometax returns.

title: Fear of Quick Price Rise Fades as OPEC Gathers
description: VIENNA, Dec. 11 (AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to open a meeting here tomorrow to decide whether to raise oil prices again.

title: Voronel, Jewish Scientist, Told By Russians He Can Emigrate
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 11A Jewish scientist who helped organize an unauthorized seminar for other unemployed Jewish scholars barred from emigrating said today that the Soviet authorities had informed him he would be allowed to leave for Israel.

title: Ways and Means Shift
description: House leaders named 16 new members of the Ways and Means Committee who are more liberal and urban oriented than most present members. Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan becomes the panel's first black. Page 38.

title: Award for Photographer
description: A New York Daily News photographer, Dan Farrell, was named yesterday winner of the top prize of $250 in the New York Racing Association's annual photo journalism contest. Farrell's entry, Pounding the Turf, shows a running thoroughbred kicking up dirt in the foreground of a picture of Ron Turcotte riding Miss Martle across the finish line.

title: WALPOLE INMATES
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP)Two guards and a prison medical corpsman were released unharmed tonight after being held captive for 26 hours by eight inmates in a cellblock of the Walpole state prison.

title: French Lawyer Is Victor In Case Over Crucifixion
description: PARIS, Dec. 11The Romans, not the Jews, killed Jesus. This was the thrust of a court decision today in which a judge ruled that an outcast Roman Catholic priest had libeled a famous French lawyer in their dispute over who was responsible.

title: Carter Reacts Stoically To Denial of New Trial
description: TRENTON, Dec. 11Rubin Carter expected nothing as he walked across the sunny prison yard today. He had lost decisions beforesometimes in the boxing ring, once in a murder trial.

title: BRITAIN'S POUND SLUMPS FURTHER
description: LONDON, Dec. 11A crisis of confidence in the British pound gripped foreignexchange markets today as sterling weakened anew following the disclosure that Saudi Arabia no longer desired to receive any portion of her oil payments in British currency.

title: South Boston Schools Shut in Clashes Over Stabbing
description: BOSTON, Dec. 11Racial violence linked to the school busing controversy erupted in South Boston today as a white youth was stabbed by a black in a high school corridor. South Boston schools were closed down and hundreds of whites battled with the police.

title: FIDELITY DAILY TRUST INSURED ON ITS C.D.'S
description: Fidelity Daily Income Trust, a mutual fund that invests in moneymarket instruments, said yesterday that it had received a ruling from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that bank certificates of deposit in its portfolio would be fully insured.

title: Beame's Cleaner Gets Pink Slip
description: The dismissal of 1,510 city workers ordered by Mayor Beame three weeks ago has struck closer to the Mayor's office than he realizes.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts 2 On Payoff Charges To 7 Union Officials
description: Two former officers of the Stirling Homex Corporation were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Rochester, on criminal charges of making payoffs to seven carpenter union officials in violation of the TaftHartley Law.

title: Giants' New Field Taking Shape in Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 11Even with a dismal wonlost record of 211, the New York Giants are still No. 1 in New Jersey.

title: Notre Dame Five Beaten By Indiana
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 11 (AP)  A 10point burst in the first half tonight and the shooting of Scott May and Kent Benson gave thirdranked Indiana a 9484 college basketball victory over Notre Dame.

title: Business Briefs
description: Panel Clears Futures Bill Changes

title: Payless Furloughs Used To Weather '34 Crisis
description: The last time mass layoffs were used to help New York City through a budget crisis, in 1934, the city also imposed payless furloughs on its 140,000 municipal employes, ranging from seven days to a month.

title: Soviet Sets Missile Tests
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 11  The Soviet Union plans to conduct new missile tests in two areas of the Pacific Ocean between tomorrow and Dec. 30. The announcement of two areas, each 80 nautical miles in diameter, instead of a single area, suggested that independently targetable multiple warheads might be tested.

title: TV News Units Plan Specials Upon Release of Nixon Tapes
description: The news divisions of the television networks have begun planning for specials to be televised the week the White House tape recordings on the Watergate coverup become available for air play which they have been advised will be no sooner than Jan. 3 and, in any case, not until the coverup trial ends.

title: Son's Example Is Cited in Gift to Neediest
description: A father recalled his young son had stimulated his interest in The New York Times Neediest Cases: Fund when as a student at Horace Mann for Boys he had served on a committee that delivered the school's annual contribution to the Times each December.

title: Burma Acts to Quell Wave of Youth Riots
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 11Street rioting broke out in Rangoon today after troops and policemen forced their way ciao the Rangoon University campus, smashed a studentbuilt Mausoleum and removed the body of U Thant, which had been seized by protesting students Dec. 5.

title: Distillers Corp. Net Rises
PRESIDENT BARS MAJOR NEW MOVE TO CURB RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11President Ford conceded tonight that the economyis in difficult straits, but Oared that he had no intention of introducing any major new antirecession programs.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Carey to Ask Fiscal Disclosure By Gubernatorial Appointees
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that his appointees would be required to disclose all income sources, assets and liabilities during their service, and he pressed Assemblyman Stanley Steingut, the next likely Speaker, to have the Legislature do the same.

title: MUTH JERSEY GAS SEEKS A RATE RISE
description: FOLSOM, Dec. 11Plagued by steady decreases in natural gas allotments, South Jersey's principal supplier of gas petitioned the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for rate increases that could reach as much as 42 per cent.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Attorney General to Investigate Police Slaying of Official's Son
description: FREEHOLD, Dec. 11The New Jersey Attorney General's office today took over an investigation into a policeman's shooting of the son of a former Long Branch City Councilman.

title: Schub, Piano Prize Winner, Performs
description: A pianist who takes first prize in the Naumberg Competition, as AndrMichel Schub did this year, is on the face of it a gifted instrumentalist. That prize simply does not go to people who look at their fingers and count out loud. But what happens now? Mr. Schub is a big talent, but what kind of big talent?

title: Scuba Divers Assail Los Angeles Law
description: LOS ANGELES  Los Angeles County has enacted a scuba diving ordinance, the first law of its kind in the nation, and local divers are complaining that the new regulations are poorly drawn.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Sometime between now and the adjournment of the 93d Congress, Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative of New York, hopes to offer as an amendment to a pending bill a measure that would, if enacted, mark the beginning of the end of Federal regulation of natural gas prices at the wellhead.

title: Women FreeStylers Gain Firmer Footing
description: Word that the ColgatePalmolive Company will sponsor the women's professional freestyle championship series at six sites this winter, while offering $90,000 in prize money, indicates that the female stylists are making progress in their quest for monetary recognition. A purse of $12,500 is being offered by the sponsor for each of six programs, plus a Grand Prix award of $15,000 at the season's end. The competition gets under way next Thursday at Aspen, Colo.

title: Prof. Allen Flouton Dies at 87; Taught at Brooklyn Law School
description: Allen Brown Flouton, who taught thousands of law students in a career that spanned nearly four decades, died on Dec. 4 in Ridgefield, Conn., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: Palestinians Still Israel, but Hopes Grow for a State of Their Own
description: NABLUS, Israeli  Occupied Jordan, Dec. 6  Confidence that an independent Palestinian state will eventually be established appears to be growing rapidly among the approximately three million Palestinian Arabs living in what they consider exile in Lebanon, Syria and Jordan, here on the Israelioccupied West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip.

title: Ehrlichman Testifies Nixon save Him False Impression in Four Instances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 John D. Ehrlichman insisted today, in the face of openly skeptical crossexamination by the Watergate prosecution, that he had been deceived by President Nixon.

title: 117 NURSING HOMES LINKED TO BERGMAN
description: The Temporary State Commission on Living Costs reported yesterday that it had uncovered links between the Bernard Bergman syndicate and 117 nursing homes.

title: Genevieve Wisner, 33, Wife Of State Department Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Genevieve de Virel Wisner, wife of the executive director of the State Department's Bureau of Public Affairs, died of cancer last night at the National Institutes of Health. She was 33 years old.

title: Insurance Claim Backed
description: TRENTON, Dec. 11 (AP)The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled today that insurance companies who paid off on boats lost in a boatyard fire could sue the boatyard for its losses. The decision overruled a lower court, which dismissed the suit on the ground that the owners were responsible for their own boats stored at the Wilson Boat Works in Long Branch.

title: Muslim Found Guilty
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 11 (AP)Arthur Lewis was convicted today of firstdegree murder in the shooting death of a white security guard prior to the Oct. 12 takeover of radio station WAPX in downtown Montgomery. Mr. Lewis, a Black Muslim who calls himself Arthur X, was sentenced to life in prison after a jury of four blacks and eight whites in Montgomery Circuit found him guilty.

title: ExBank Official Arrested
description: BOSTON, Dec, 11 (AP)  A former vice president of the Coolidge Bank and Trust Company of Watertown was arrested today and charged with embezzling approximately $175,000, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. He was identified as Richard L. Maunder of Boston's West Roxbury section, a former vice president in charge of operations at the bank.

title: Skitch Henderson Guilty in Tax Case
description: Skitch Henderson was found guilty last night of filing a false tax return involving a large deduction that he claimed for his donation of a music library to the University of Wisconsin. He faces three years' imprisonment.

title: Sylvia Dlugasch Bauman, A Therapist and Teacher
description: Sylvia Dlugasch Bauman, for many years a therapist with the Child Development Center here and a clinical instructor in psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died yesterday at her home, 300 Erskine Road, Stamford, Conn. She was 64 years old and also lived here and in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: KNIGHTRIDDER SETS 10% RISE IN AD RATES
description: KnightRidder Newspapers, Inc., is planning advertising and circulation rate increases in the range of 10 per cent next year. Lee Hills, chairman and chief executive of the newly merged company, told financial analysts here yesterday.

title: Hurricane Carter Denied New Trial on Recantations
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 11Declaring that recanted testimony by two former prosecution witnesses lacked the ring of truth, a judge today rejected an appeal by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and his codefendant, John Artis, for a new trial on triplemurder charges.

title: BROOKHAVEN HOLDS PLANNING HEARING
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L.I., Dec. 11  The preservation of undeveloped, areas with ecological significance  including moraines, major wetlands, stream valleys and headwaters  was among the recommendations presented here tonight at the first of three hearings on a draft of the overall policies sections of the Brookhaven Master Plan.

title: U.S. HEALTH OFFICIAL OUSTED FROM POST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) Dr. Robert S. Stone has been dismissed as director of National Institute of Health, a spokesman for the institute said tonight.

title: Bridge: Many Great Players Shun Psychic Bidding at All Times
description: For a variety of reasons, serious players have little use for the psychic bid, an intentional effort to mislead the opponents by pretending to have strength or length that one does not possess.

title: Cops or Robbers? Manager of Lundy's Shoots First
description: A twicerobbed manager of Lundy's Restaurant in Brooklyn held scores of policemen at bay with a shotgun yesterday morning, apparently mistaking them for masked gunmen who had tried to hold him up earlier in the day.

title: Chess: Benko Gambit, Success. Story Of a Formerly Risky Sacrifice
description: If there remain any skeptics who refuse to trust positional sacrifices, let them delve into the Benko Gambit. In the midnineteensixties, Pal Benko, the United States grandmaster, turned what had previously been considered an eccentric experiment into an incredibly successful system.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe McDonald, the general manager of the Mets, continnued his efforts to bolster the club yesterday, when he dealt Teddy Martinez, 27 years old, to St. Louis for Jack Heidemann, 25. It was the fifth trade McDonald had made since replacing Bob Scheffing as general manager last Oct. 1. Heidemann, shortstop insurance for Bud Harrelson, hit .271 for the Cardinals in 47 tames and also spent two weeks in Tulsa of the American Association, where he hit .296 in 14 games. Heidemann, who broke into the majors with Cleveland as the Indians' top draft choice in 1969, also played with Oakland. Martinez hit, .219 in 116 games with the Mets while playing second base, third, shortstop and the outfield. The Cardinals also sent Mike Vail to the Mets. Vail, a 23yearold outfielder from Tulsa, was assigned to Tidewater, the Mets' farm in the International League.

title: Award for Photographer
description: A New York Daily News photographer, Dan Farrell, was named yesterday winner of the top prize of $250 in the New York Racing Association's annual photo journalism contest. Farrell's entry, Pounding the Turf, shows a running thoroughbred kicking up dirt in the foreground of a picture of Ron Turcotte riding Miss Martle across the finish line.

title: U.S., SOVIET AGREE ON ARMSTALKS MEMO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The State Department said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had finally agreed on the language of the memorandum summing up the armscontrol agreement reached at Vladivostok last month

title: TV Deal Puts $100,000 Mile Race Closer to Reality
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System has purchased the television rights for a $100,000 professional mile at the Houston Astrodome next year, thus moving the race one step closer to the starting line.

title: 6 HighPaid Lindsay Appointees Ousted
description: Six of the high paid executives dismissed by Mayor Beame in his latest round of budget economies are appointees of former Mayor John V. Lindsay who earn more than $20,000 a year in the Office of Neighborhood Government which Mr. Beanie has been attempting to phase out since he entered office, city officials said yesterday.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC MIXED
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday in slightly decreased trading as those in the overthecounter market finished higher for the second day in a row.

title: Personal Finance: Move Under Way In State to Simplify Insurance Policies
description: The small print in which insurance policies are writtan does not add up to the most easily understood prose. Their provisions and qualifications are more easily understood by lawyers and insurance agents than by poll icyholders.

title: Artless Chinese
description: Quite apart from the obvious issue of freedom of the press, China's studied refusal to admit journalists from certain countries to a press preview of Chinese art in Washington only makes the Chinese look silly in the eyes of the entire world. The press of Taiwan, South Africa, South Korea and Israeltargets of the bansuffer no grievous damagebut China does.

title: BRITAIN REJECTS A DEATH PENALTY
description: LONDON, Dec. 11After daylong debate stemming fron increased terrorism in England by the Irish Republican Army the House of Commons tonigh rejected a move to restore the death penalty.

title: SUGAR ACT LAPSE SLATED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) The House Agriculture Committee agreed today not to seek an extension of the Federal. Sugar Act in this session of Congress.

title: Reichhold's New Plant Set
description: Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., announced yesterday that it had begun construction of a new polyester resin plan at Morris, Ill. The plant will have a capacity of 100 million pounds a year and is scheduled for completion by the middle of 1976.

title: Congress Backa Bill to Reformt Real Estate Closing Procedure
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The House of Representatives gave final approval today to legislation that would require advance disdlosure and other reform in the handling of real estate closing costs.

title: Arabs and Africans at Reply to U.S. on Tyranny
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11Delegates from Arab states and other developing nations today rejected Ameripan charges that the United Nations General Assembly was shackled by the tyranny of the majority.

title: MIKI SEES FAILURE ON INFLATION GOAL
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 12Premier Takeo MM of Japan indicated today that his new Government would be unable to hold consumerprice increases down to a critical target set by the previous government, thus risking heightened economic and political troubles.

title: CYPRUS REFUGEES VEX BRITISH BASE
description: EPISKOPI, Cyprus, Dec. 11About 8,500 Turkish Cypriotes, shivering in unheated tents in this British military base area in the south of Cyprus, represent a critical issue in the tense relations between the Greek and Turkish. Communities and a vexing problem for British di

title: Exile for Salassie Ruled Out By Ethiopia Military Leader
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 11 (Reuters)The head of Ethiopia's military government ruled out today the possibility that former Emperor Haile Selassie would be allowed to leave the country to live in exile.

title: S. E. C. CHIEF CITES SUSPICION ON FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Suggestions that the New York Stock Exchange acted in bad faith in pretending to go along with the ending of fixed brokerage commission rates while doing everything possible to defeat authorizing legislation was placed today in the record of a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing on the controversial issue.

title: U.S. to Require Warning Devices on All Airliners by Next Dec. 1 to Curb Landing Accidents
description: The recent crash of an airliner into a hillside west of Washington has brought a Government decision that will require the nation's airlines to install in all jets a cockpit warning device that most experts believe would have prevented the disaster.

title: HOUSEAPPROVES FOREIGN AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) The House tonight approved by a vote of 201 to 190 a $2.6billion foreign aid authorization bill that reduces military assistance to Cambodia and extends the present cutoff of military aid to Turkey until June 30.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE REAL McCOY Maxine's (9249880), a restaurant and bar at 21 Seventh Avenue South, is a welcome splash of color, nourishing in both food and atmosphere, that is steadily gaining popularity in a bleak stretch of Greenwich Village. Nearby, around the bend, are a cluster of superior eating placesMary's and Tetley's Pub, with their fine Italian specialties, and a tidy little restaurant called Bingo that matches tasty fare with some of the most exquisite courtesy in town.

title: RHODESIANS AGREE TO HALT WARFARE; DETENTION TO END
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 11  Prime Minister Ian D. Smith announced today that an immediate ceasefire had been agreed upon by his whiteminority Government and black nationalists after prolonged fighting on the northern frontier.

title: Harold K. Philips, Newsman And PublicRelations Figure
description: Harold K. Philips, a former publicrelations executive and correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune, The Baltimore Sun and The Associated Press, died Wednesday at Largo, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Wednesday, Dec. 11, 1974

title: Bailing Out the City . . .
description: The nearly 4,000 new layoffs ordered by Mayor Beanie yesterday represent a painful but necessary response to the gravity of the city's fiscal crisis. The harsh fact that, even when added to the first round of layoffs last month, the savings they represent fall far short of what has to be done to avert disastrous new recourse to borrowing in a money market already saturated with New York City obligations.

title: Jaycee Unit Admits Women
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI)Chicago Jaycees voted 107 to 43 yesterday to allow women to join the chapter as full voting members. Women had been allowed to become associate members, but could not vote or hold office in the state or national organizations.

title: Orderly Searches
description: The Supreme Court refused this week to relax any further the constitutional requirement that official searches and seizures be conducted pursuant to a Courtapproved warrant. In view of the Court's recent history, this is good news.

title: Kiner on Hall Ballot 5th and Last Time
description: Ralph Kiner, former National League home run king who is eligible for election for the last time, heads a list of 37 explayers appearing on baseball Hall of Fame ballots mailed yesterday to voting members of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: $18,200 HELD NEEDED FOR FAMILY BUDGET
description: An analysis of family budgets over the last six Years indicates that an urban family of four now needs about $18,200 a year to maintain a comfortable standard of living,, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: Excerpts From U.N. Assembly Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from statements by delegates during General Assembly debate today on the role of the United Nations:

title: A STUDY CAUTIONS ON TRANQUILIZERS
description: Two widely used mild tranquilizers may cause serious birth defects if the drugs are taken during the first six weeks of pregnancy, according to the findings of an extensive study published yesterday.

title: Buckley Balking at Supporting Javits
description: Senator James L. Buckley said yesterday that he would not support his fellow New York Republican, Senator Jacob K. Javits, for the chairmanship of the Senate Republican Conference despite outside pressures from New York Republican leaders that he do so.

title: Hospital Abortion Ban Wins
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec11 (UPI)A judge of the Federal District Court declined today to order the Charleston area medical center to drop its policy forbidding abortions. The judge, Dennis R. Knapp, said the hospital was a private one and it would not be legal to force it to follow guidelines governing public hospitals.

title: Kuwait Has No Plans To Ban Sterling Use
description: VIENNA, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Kuwait has no plans to bar the use of sterling in oil operations, the Kuwaiti Finance and Oil Minister, Abdel Rahman Salem alAtiqi, said today.

title: F.E.A. IS SHIFTING OIL ENFORCEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11The Federal Energy Administration admitted to Congress today that it has not been checking closely on the possibility of evasion of crudeoil price controls by producers.

title: JOSEPH H. BROWN
description: Joseph H. Brown, who retired in 1960 as Eastern regional manager of the Linde Air Products division of the Union Carbide Corporation after 40 years with the company, died Tuesday evening at the home of his daughter, Audrey Bollet, in Sands Point, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

title: No Comment by De Beers
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 11 (Reuters)A spokesman for De Beers Consolidated Diamond Mines, Ltd., declined today to comment on United States charges it conspired to fix prices of industrial diamond grit. The company has not had time to study the charges or discuss the situation its lawyers, he said.

title: Nets Rout Spirits; 6 in Row
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 11 Neither Marvin Barnes, the highpriced rookie, nor Fly Williams, the rookie from Brooklyn, nor the pleas of the 8,772 fans at Nassau Coliseum could move the Spirits of St. Louis tonight.

title: Sunday Racing Gets Approval
description: As expected, the State Racing and Wagering Board flashed the official sign yesterday for Sunday racing next year at Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: Anker Sees Limited Effect From Teaching Staff Cuts
description: The reduction in teaching positions announced by Mayor Beame yesterday is part of moresweeping economies, including tight controls on headquarters spending and possible cutbacks in afterschool adulteducation programs, that are being instituted by the Board of Education to save $20million to $30million.

title: AUSTERITY AHEAD, GREEKS ARE TOLD
description: ATHENS, Dec. 11Premier Constantine Caramanlis told the Greek people tonight that they faced a year of austerity and sacrifice as his new Government tried to battle the problems of inflation and stagnant industrial growth.

title: Tisch Is New Chairman
description: Elmer L. Nicholson, who last May opposed the Loews Corporation's takeover of the CNA Financial Corporation only to see Loews succeed in its bid late last month, yesterday resigned his posts as CNA's chairman, president and chief executive officer. He resigned also as a director.

title: Doctor Calls Willowbrook Moderate Tragedy Now
description: An expert presented by the state testified yesterday that there had been substantial improvements at the Willowbrook Development Center, but that major problems remained in overcrowding, the center's architectural design and the need for more competent behavior specialists and middlelevel managers.

title: ExNixon Aide Admits Campaign Guilt
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Harry S. Dent, the special counsel for four years under President Nixon, pleaded guilty today to taking part in an illegally organized political committee in 1970 and was placed on one month's unsupervised probation.

title: New Fugitive on F.B.I. List
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation placed Thomas Otis Knight, wanted for the kidnapmurders of a Miami industrialist and his wife, on its list of ten most wanted fugitives

title: For a Weary Traveler, the Dream HotelWith Fine Food, Too
description: SAN FRANCISCOIf you travel from Texas to Timbuktu and sleep in enough chain operated hostelries, it is possible to surmise that there is one gigantic machine somewhere in this universe that turns out hotels like so many animal crackers or gingerbread men and ships them all over the universe along with a standard Manual of Operating Procedures, ice and Coke machines, and a million white bands that say Sanitized for your protection.

title: Issues in the Milk Strike
description: PARTICIPANTSLocal 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing 3,000 drivers and plant employes who process and deliver milk to 10 million consumers in the metropolitan New York area.

title: Three Paths of Glory
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Leaving the question of innocence to the jury and the subject of fairness to the appeals courts, it may be instructive to observe the effect of the Watergate trial on the three key defendants and to see how their personalities have determined the contrast of their defenses.

title: UNOFFICIAL RECOUNT SHOWS YOUNG AHEAD
description: BISMARCK, N. D., Dec. 11 (AP)An unofficial recount completed today showed Republican Senator Milton R. Young the winner over his Democratic challenger, William L. Guy, by 186 votes in the North Dakota Senate race.

title: Other News Of Sports On Pages 6670
description: Other News Of Sports On Pages 6670

title: Chile Expropriates Phone Unit of I.T.T.
description: Chile's military Government expropriated yesterday the investments of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in the Chilean Telephone Company.

title: INQUIRYEXTENDED IN COAST SWINDLE
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec.11The investigation into the pia defraud the Los Angeles city treasury; of several million dollars hag been extended to New York and Europe.

title: ALLON RULES OUT P.L.O. GENEVA SEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11Foreign Minister Yigal Allon of Israel said today that his country would use its veto to prevent the Palestine Liberation Organization from taking part in the Geneva conference on the Middle East if it ever is reconvened.

title: Gold Markups of 3% to 6% Expected by Merrill Lynch
description: Brokers' markups on purchases of gold bullion on the United States market next yearare likely to range from 3 to 6 per cent, Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith, Inc., the country's largest brokerage house, said yesterday.

title: Youth Guilty in Casey Slaying
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP) An Orange County Court jury found 18yearold Wayne Peterson guilty today of murder and attempted robbery in the shooting death of a Newburgh taxicab driver. The victim, Richard Moore, 58, was slain on Dec. 31, 1973. Another Newburgh youth, Mack Brown, 17, is awaiting trial in the case.

title: Katz, Under Indictment, Resigns Garbage Posts
description: NEWARK, Dec. 11 (AP)George Katz, the garbage contractor who is under indictment, has resigned his. executive positions with the Jersey Sanitation Company and the J & B Disposal Company, which have merged and hold the garbage collection contract for New Brunswick.

title: Manhattan, Rutgers On Garden Bill
description: Madison Square Garden opens its 41st season of intercollegiate basketball tonight with an attractive doubleheader in which Manhattan plays Rutgers after Seton Hall opposes St. Bonaventure in the first game beginning at 7 o'clock.

title: School Board Urges Court To Back Publication Rules
description: WASHINGTON, DEc. 11 (AP)  The Indianapolis school board asked the Supreme Court today to declare its regulations for high school publications constitutional.

title: God's Favorite Is Simon's Job on L.I.
description: GOD'S FAVORITE, a comedy by Neil Simon. Directed by Michael Bennett; settings by William Ritman; costumes by Joseph G. Aullsi; lighting by Theron Musser; production stage manager, Tom Porter. Presented by Emanuel Azenberg and Eugene V. Wolsk. At the Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street.

title: SHORT LIFE SPANS TIED TO MIGRANTS
description: Migrant farm workers in the Garden State are suffering from pesticide poisoning and undernourishment, factors that have helped cut more than two decades from their life expectancy, according to a study by the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey.

title: New Jersey Sports Upsala Is on Upswing
description: NEWARK, Dec. 12In an attempt to upgrade its basketball program, Upsala failed the first test this season, but passed the second last week with an upset victory over Armythe first against a major team in 15 years.

title: PRESIDENT URGED TO AID CAR SALES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Leaders of the automobile industry and labor urged President Ford today to consider an income tax cut and a pause on Federal emission and safety standards to bolster sagging auto sales and the economy.

title: Braves Trounce Rockets by 124113
description: TORONTO, Dec. 12 (UPI)Bob McAdoo Scored 32 points and Randy Smith contributed 29 to lead the Buffalo Braves to a 124113 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets at the Maple Leaf Gardens tonight before a disappointing crowd of 4,519.

title: 4 Boston High Schools Hit by Walkouts
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12After 15 weeks of courtordered busing for school desegregation, this is a city divide by fear and hatred.

title: Bridge: Regional Tourney Starts Today at New York Hilton
description: Tournament enthusiasts who returned from the fall Nationals in San Antonio, Tex., earlier this week have just had time to draw breath before launching into the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regionals at the New York Hilton Hotel starting today.

title: A Beefy Sum for Statue
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 12 (UPI)Lorene, Rogers, University of Texas president has recommended the: school accapt a donation of $50,000 to build a statue of Bevo, the Longhorn mascot. She said in a letter to Chancellor Charles Lamaistre that a former Texas student who wants to donate the $50,000 insisted the money go for the statue and would not be used for scholarships.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A deadlock of 50 years over the 1925 Geneva protocol on chemical warfare was ended yesterday when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously to send the treaty to the Senate for approval. The United States is the only country among the major powers that has not ratified the treaty, which bans the use of chemical and bacteriological warfare. It appears virtually certain that the treaty will be approved by the Senate and ratified by President Ford. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: BONN ADOPTS PLAN TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: BONN, Dec. 12The West German Government dropped the remains of its antiinflation program today and announced an anti  unemployment and antirecession economic policy instead. It did so with fingers crossed, as one official said, that the United States will soon follow suit, to avoid a world depression.

title: British Open Golf Increases Purse
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Dec. 12 (AP)Prize money for the 1975 British Open golf championship will be raised to $180,000, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club announced today.

title: Fraud Charges Filed
description: Thirteen personsten of them officers of the HomeStake Production Companyhave been charged in Los Angeles in a 39count Federal indictment with bilking investors of tens of millions of dollars in a fraudulent taxshelter scheme. Page 69.

title: Beanie, in Shift, Asks City Pension Funds to Buy Municipal Bonds
description: Mayor Beame yesterday urged the huge cityemploye pension funds to change their longstanding investment policies and buy some of the city's own bonds.

title: DARRELL J. DRICKEY, PHYSICIST, 40, DEAD
description: Darrell J. Drickey, associate professor of physics at the University of California at Los Angeles and an internationally known experimental physicist, died in a Chicago hospital Tuesday after a brief illness. He was 40 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that no city official should use official stationery on behalf of private causes. The board said, No official should permit himself to be placed in a position where his public office may be considered as a lure or as pressure by those to whom the letters are addressed.

title: Driver of Deer Is Killed In South Jersey Mishap
description: DENNISVILLE Dec. 12 (AP)  A North Wildwood police sergeant was killed in a hunting accident here yesterday.

title: PRICES IRREGULAR ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market closed irregularly yesterday in decreased trading.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Black and Hispanic Group Urges Layoff Alternative
description: Leaders of a coalition of more Pan 60 black and Hispanic orAanizations contended yestertray that layoffs would imperil already inadequate city services to poor areas, and urged graduated pay cuts or payless workdays or vacations instead.

title: Gordon Maltzberger, 62, Pitched for the White Sox
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP)Gordon Maltzberger, a Chicago White. Sox pitcher in the nineteenforties who spent more than 20 years in baseball as a player, coach and minorleague manager, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: CITY WORKS OUT PLAN TO SAVE JOBS OF 860 EMPLOYES
description: After daylong negotiations yesterday between Mayor Beame and the leaders of the city's labor unions, a plan was worked out that could result in the retention of 860 permanent Civil Service employes. Some of them were among those ordered dismissed by the Mayor on Wednesday and others were in the first wave of dismissals announced on Nov. 22.

title: Georgia's Gov. Carter Enters Democratic Race for President
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 12 Jimmy Carter, the moderate Georgia Governor who is regarded by supporters as a Southernstyle Kennedy and by skeptics as just another Democratic dark horse, announced his candidacy for President tonight.

title: TV. Special on U.F.0
description: Television, particularly television news, has several problems but one is peculiarly sensitive. In devoting unusual space to highly speculative, potentially sensational, subjects, the medium can often endow those subjects with more credibility than they had or deserved in the first place. A good example of this dilemma can be found Sunday evening at 10 in UFO's: Do You Believe?, produced, written, and directed for NBC News by Craig Leake.

title: Dividend Omission Voted by Board
description: Directors of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. voted yesterday to omit the fourthquarter dividend and elected J. L. Scott as a vice chairman and a director.

title: Hostess Service In Skiing
description: When the Powder Ridge ski area at Middlefield, Conn., installed the East's first fourinaseat chairlift several years ago, Herman Zemel, the president of the resort, nicknamed it the 747 after the Boeingmade jumbo jet planes. In keeping with that over  all theme, Powder Ridge, this season, is instituting a complimentary Ski Hostess Program. Available on the slopes will be hostess who will tour the area's modestlysized slopes trying to make life easier for skiers who have questions or problems.

title: Carey Criticizes Sales Tax as Unfair
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 12Criticizing the sales tax as severely unfair, Governorelect Hugh L. Carey said today his fiscal advisers were working on a thorough tax analysis in order to more fairly equalize the tax burden in the state.

title: Bangladesh, at Age 3, Is Still a Disaster Area
description: DACCA, BangladeshAfter three years' existence Bangladesh has a bankrupt economy. Thousands of her people have died of starvation, and corruption, entwined with a chaotic bureaucracy, is continuing to thwart development. There are political killings and violence.

title: For Mother Seton, Sainthood Crowns Career in Church
description: Elizabeth Ann Bayleyn Seton, whose sainthood was formally decreed yesterday by Pope Paul VI, once stood in the festive Wall Street throng that saw George Washington sworn in as the nation's first President.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and, Index Page 47

title: Dave Crowley Dead at 64; A British Boxing Champion
description: LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP)Dave Crowley, one of Britain's most popular international boxers in the nineteenthirties, died Tuesday night at the age of 64.

title: Where Does Mayor Trim Now?
description: In three slices of roughly $109million each, Mayor Beame has cut the city's projected budget deficit of $430million to $138million, and the big question ahead for him and the city now is what more he possibly can do to close the remaining gap.

title: FUEL UNIONS TO VOTE ON CONTRACT SUNDAY
description: Members of Local 553 of the teamsters' union, representing about 3,000 tanktruck drivers and servicemen in the fueloil industry, are scheduled to vote Sunday on a proposed twoyear contract with 188 oil companies in the city.

title: Opera: A Smart Tosca
description: The Juilliard School has been staging operas for many years, repertory operas ands offbeat operas. But for Some reason Tosea never had been put on, and last night the Juilliard American Opera Center rectified the omission With a smart little production.

title: Booby T rap, Called Retaliation, Wounds Officer Facing Layoff
description: A policeman who was on his first patrol and was among those expected to be laid off in the city's economy campaign was critically injured late Wednesday night when he set off a booby trap reportedly set in retaliation for the death of a Puerto Rican musician in police station this month. end second new lead.

title: Protesters Win Sympathy in Rangoon
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 12The students and monks who seized the body, of. U Thant, the former Secretary General of theUnited Nations, and then unsuccessfully resisted government efforts to take it back, appear to have tapped a broad and profound vein of sympathy among the Burmese public.

title: Can Congress Govern?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12One of the odd paradoxes in Washington these days is how well President Ford gets along with the leaders of Congress in private and how quickly the old White HouseCapitol Hill battles are renewed when the private talks are over.

title: Big Board Revises Gold Trading Rates
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had revised its rules to allow member firms to buy gold bullio n for their customers for cash or on margins under regulations setting standards of purity, safe storage, and insurance for the gold.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Pape

title: Ferry Workers End Strike
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 12 (AP) Washington's 10 Puget Sound ferries were back on their regular routes this morning after negotiators representing deck hands and engine room workers accepted a tentative agreement with the state, ending a fiveday strike by about 700 employes.

title: 2 Carter Witnesses Insist Recantation Was Truthful
description: Two witnesses whose recantations in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case were disbelieved by a judge insisted yesterday that they had testified truthfully when they tried to clear the former boxer and a codefendant of triplehomicide charges.

title: Peking Issues Fewer Exit Visas After Hong Kong Bars Fugitives
description: HONG, KONG, Dec. 12In apparent response to Hong Kong's decision to return fleeing refugees to China, the Chinese authorities are slowing down the flow, of legal immigrants into the British colony.

title: Paul Richards, Character Actor In Movies and Television, Dies
description: Paul Richards, an actor who had had important roles in several television shows, died of cancer Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 50 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: She is approaching her seventieth birthday. For the past forty years she has, been residing in a rentcontrolled tenement, with her sole source of income a meager widow's pension. On the first of December she receives a notice from her landlord which states bit her monthly rent has, been increased by a series of 7 per cent additions retroactively for three years, making her liable for an arrears of hundreds of dollars.

title: Pound Rebuff Held LongerTerm Trend By Oil Exporters
description: LONDON, Dec. 12The Bank of England indicated today that Saudi Arabia's decision to accept sterling no longer in payment for any direr oil was part of a longerterm trend among oilexporting countries.

title: The Schmidt Proposal
description: The imaginative economic strategy West German Chancellor Schmidt has put, before the Ford Administration and his Common Market partners suggests to the industrial nations a way of defeating the twin dangers worldwide depression and soaring inflation that have been triggered by the oilmoney crisis.

title: Jersey Bill Aid to Trot, Flat Tracks
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12The New Jersey Senate passed today by a 370 margin legislation aimed at aiding the state's horse breeders and race tracks and providing a greater tax yield. The bill was supported by Gov. Brendan Byrne's administration.

title: Changes by Dow Jones To Reduce 1974 Profits
description: A writedown in the carrying value of equity investment in the last six months of 1974 and two accounting changes effective in the fourth quarter will reduce 1974 earnings of Dow Jones & Co., Inc., about 10 cents a share or $1.5million, the company announced yesterday.

title: Concert An Evening of Works by Dana Suesse
description: In 1932 Dana Suesse was much in the news. Although barely 20 years old, she was already a composer of hit songs (among them, Whistling in the Dark and Ho Hum) and she'had made her New York debut at Carnegie Hall as piano soloist in her Concerto in Three Rhythms with the Paul Whiteman Orchestra. Not bad for a Kansas City girl who had just moved to New York.

title: NEWS INDEX
5 Die in a Brooklyn Fire Laid to a Neighbor
description: Five persons, including four children, were killed yesterday in a fire in Brooklyn that the police said had been set by a neighbor after a quarrel at a party Saturday between members of two families.

title: Stock Market Irregular As Average Rises 1.02
description: The stock market moved narrowly yesterday and finished mixed as uncertainty over the economic outlook and growing tensions in the Middle East weakened many issues.

title: Faisal Pledges 7Million For a Mosque in Rome
description: ROME, Dec. 12 (UPI)King Faisal of Saudi Arabia will contribute at least $7 million toward building a mosque here,, the Sandi Arabian Embassy said today.

title: Carey Assailed by G.O.P. For Not Naming Key Aides
description: ALBANY, Dec. 12 (UPI)Richard M. Rosenbaum, the Republican state chairman, today criticized Democratic Governorelect Hugh L. Carey for failing to name top aides for his incoming administration.

title: COAST GUARD POWER IN, SEARCH WIDENED
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) Coast Guard patrols are empowered to board and detain or seize foreign vessels catching any of four species of fish outside the 12mile fishing limit under a new enforcement policy, Coast Guard spokesmen said yesterday.

title: NATO Foreign Ministers Argue Over Oil
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12Foreign ministers of the Atlantic alliance countries opened a twoday meeting here today with dispute over oil diplomacy and gloomy predictions about the economic outlook for the West.

title: Upstater Named as Judge
description: President Ford said yesterday he would nominate Ellsworth A. Vangraafeiland, a Rochester lawyer, as a judge in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second District to succeed Henry J. Friendly, who retired. He also nominated Henry Bramwell of Brooklyn, a New York City Civil Court Judge, as United States District Court judge for the Eastern District of New York. Judge Bramwell, nominated to succeed John R. Bartels, who retired, would become the Eastern District's first black judge if confirmed by the Senate.

title: CONGRESS WIDENS PAY HELP FOR IDLE; BACKS PUBLIC JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The House and Senate approved by large margins today legislation designed to reduce the effects of the nation's rapidly growing unemployment.

title: Much Ado on TV, But About Nothing
description: Of the 13 games that complete the National Football. League's regular season this weekend, six will be seen on television here, three tomorrow and three on Sunday. Overexposure? All eight playoff teams have been determined so the games have little effect on postseason play. The video bonanza begins tomorrow at 1 P.M., with Cincinnati at Pittsburgh, Channel 4, followed by Minnesota at Kansas City, 3:45 P.M., Channel 2, and Dallas at Oakland, 9 P.M., Channel 7. On Sunday it will be Giants at St. Louis, 2 P.M., Channel 2; Jets at Baltimore, 2 P.M., Channel 4, and then on the same channel, Buffalo at Los Angeles, which will be picked up in progress. The kickoff for the latter is 4 P.M. Here is a preview of all games with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: 2 Legislators to Offer 12 Kuh Measures to Alter Criminal Law
description: A Republican State Senator and a Democratic Assemblyman announced yesterday that they would sponsor a dozen measures for changes in the criminal, law, including a provision for mandatory prison sentences for the illegal sale of guns.

title: Distribution Group Will Cut Aid Slightly For Jews Overseas
description: The Joint Distribution Committee, the major American agency that aids needy Jews overseas, yesterday adopted a budget of $29,935,000, slightly less than outlays this year, to carry out humanitarian programs for 400,000 peolpe.

title: Red Smith
description: Onemonthold Keystone Race Track in Cornwells Heights, Bensalem Township, Bucks County, Pa., is the youngest gambling hell in the land but already far gone in wickedness, There op the outskirts of staid Philadelphia, and nowhere else in America this year, a man can win a $100,000 race and lose his immortal soul on the same weekend. The Heritage Stakes, the last $100,000 event in this country for 1974, will be run there tomorrow afternoon, and 24 hours later Keystone will conduct its first program of Sunday racing, plunging the community headlong into sin. It is curious that Philadelphia, the most pecksniffian of American cities, according to Henry L. Mencken, should precede New York into iniquity, but by the time Belmont and Saratoga start desecrating the Sabbath next summer, horseplayers in William Penn's greene countrie towne will be hardened characters, probably beyond redemption.

title: Infant Girl Kidnapped Briefly From Hospital
description: A 4monthold girl with a high fever was kidnapped from the pediatric ward of Jamaica Hospital yesterday afternoon, touching off a frantic twoandahalf hour search that ended when a practical nurse entrusted with the care of the infant became suspicious and called the police.

title: Abducted Jersey Boy Rejoins Family
description: A 7yearold Rutherford;. N.J., boy was reunited with his family by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last night after twoandahalfmonth odyssey in which a 23yearold friend abducted him for a sightseeing and fishing spree down the East Coast to Florida.

title: Martin Puts Across A Trio of Winners
description: Frank (Pancho) Martin, still awaiting a hearing on his court  delayed suspension, saddled three more winners yesterday at Aqueduct. The winners were the Cubanborn trainer's 138th, 139th and 140th of the New York thoroughbred season. Martin had surpassed the previous New York record even before his recent 60day suspension.

title: Home Ec  Moving Out of the Kitchen and Into the World
description: ITHACA, N. Y.  She's the best looking chick on campus, but she's kind of dumb; She came to college not to find herself but a husband. And while shesearches for him, she is learning to make the perfect white sauce, coordinate curtains and carpets and sew a neat hem.

title: NATO AIDES MEET ON CYPRUS ISSUE
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12Secretery of State Kissinger and other officials of NATO countries continued efforts today to find common ground between Greece and Turkey on the deadlocked Cyprus issue.

title: Victim's Cost in FoodPoisoning Case Put at $230
description: When food became contaminated with salmonella bacteria in a restaurant in a small Minnesota town recently; 125 customers developed gastrointestinal upsets lasting an average of five days.

title: Advertising
description: Months ago when they sat down to decide on a topic for yesterday's annual Association of National Advertisers Media Workshop, the committee certainly was in spired. They chose Planning and Working With Media in Uncertain Times.

title: Unions Not Ready for Beame's Trims
