description: As early as September, Mayor Beame began warning that a big budget deficit was developing this year. But it was hardly a surprise to him or anyone else, mayoral aides said yesterday, that nobody seemed to believe him.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Books of The Times
description: Books on esoteric collectibles (fans, picture postcards and such) continue to appear with frequency. But far more im pressive this year are the serious, sometimes scholarly studies on Oriental wares and American folk art. As for nostalgia, at least one candidate is noteworthy.

title: CITY WORKS OUT PLAN TO SAVE JOBS OF 860 EMPLOYES
description: After daylong negotiations yesterday between Mayor Beame and the leaders of the city's labor unions, a plan was worked out that could result in the retention of 860 permanent Civil Service employes. Some of them were among those ordered dismissed by the Mayor on Wednesday and others were in the first wave of dismissals announced on Nov. 22.

title: $38.3Million Loss For Year Is Slated By Tishman Realty
description: The Tishman Realty and Construction Company, Inc., expects to show a $38.3million loss for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. The company also announced yesterday that directors have postponed dividend action for the December quarter, it first fiscal quarter of 1975.

title: N.I.H. Head to Quit in a Policy Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Within, approximately the last two years the National Institutes of Health has lost at least a halfdozen of its top administrators through resignations and is soon to lose another, the present director, Dr. Robert S. Stone.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Rise in Wholesale Prices Slowed Again Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The nation's inflation, as measured by the sensitive Wholesale Price Index, abated further in November though prices were still going up, the Labor Department reported today. The overall index, after adjustment for normal seasonal changes in some prices, rose by 1.2 per tent last month, one of the smallest increases this year and only half the October rise.

title: 30 Students Held in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  About 30 students were arrested here today when the police tried to break up a demonstration of a few hundred students calling for demoratic reforms and the release of other arrested students.

title: Soviet Police Search Home Of Unofficial Art Backer
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12  The secret police today searched the apartment of Aleksandr Glazer, a poet and art collector who helped organize nonconformist art exhibits in Moscow this fall, Mr. Glazer said.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOLLYWOOD. By Garson Kanin, 393 pages. Viking. $8.95

title: Texas Woman, 115, Dies
description: TYLER, Tex., Dec. 12 (UPI)Celia Roberson Black, born the daughter of a slave in Smith County, Tex., on Sept. 10, 1859, died yesterday after a short illness. She was 115 years old and lived in a nursing home here. Survivors include 4 daughters, a son, 15 grandchildren, 45 greatgrandchildren and 10 greatgreatgrandchildren.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Towering new office buildings seldom provide space for small, intimate restaurants, but Il Gattopardo has been an exception on West 56th Street's restaurant row for almost two years now.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
TaxExempt Issues Weaken
description: The recent severe weakness in prices of New York City bonds manifested itself yesterday in other hardpressed areas of the taxexempt market. State agencies and other forms of yieldoriented instruments were noticeably weaker. As for the city's issues, trading was rather quiet on the heels of sharp losses experienced in the last several weeks, You, can say with utter accuracy there is a lack of great retall interest, one dealer.

title: Plea by City to Cut 551 on Staff Is Refused by Hospitals' Board
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation refused yesterday to cut 551 provisional jobs from its payroll, despite the Mayor's request to the quasiindependent body, according to the corporation's president, Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr.

title: St. Clair River Cleared
description: ST. CLAIR, Mich., Dec. 12 (AP)The St. Clair River channel leading to Lake Huron was clear today after two vessels that collided on Wednesday in early morning fog were reoved from the site of the accident.

title: Soviet Ready for Space LinkUp But Secrecy Won't Be Lifted
description: ZVEZDNY GORODOK, U.S.S.R., Dec. 12Soviet space officials declared today that they were fully ready to undertake the joint space rendezvous with the United States next July, following the successful rehearsal mission flown last week by Soyuz 16

title: Old Pleasures for the China Watchers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The romance of archeology, compounded by the carefully orchestated pieties of political policy, has created an at mosphere of high expectation for the exhibition of recently evacuated Chinese antiquities that has now come to the National Gallery of Art. The display has already drawn recordbreaking crowds in London, Paris, Stockholm, Vienna and Toronto, and this too has contributed to the air of excitement surrounding the exhibition, which consists of 385 objects unearthed by Chinese archeologists between 1949 and 1972.

title: Swiss Legislators Approve Treaty Easing Bank Secrecy
description: GENEVA, Dec. 12The lower house of the Swiss Parliament approved a treaty with the United States today that will permit the lifting of Switzerland's banking secrecy law to aid in the fight against organized crime.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The Department of Commerce said today that department store sales were an estimated $1.069billion, up 1 per cent from the year earlier $1.067billion. Total retail store sales were an estimated $10.139billion, up 6 per cent from the year earlier $8,686billion.

title: BONN ADOPTS PLAN TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: BONN, Dec. 12The West German Government drop ed the remains of its antiinflation program today and, announced an antiunemployment and antirecession economic, policy instead. It did so with fingers crossed, as one official said, that the United States will soon follow suit, to avoid a world depression.

title: For Mother Seton, Sainthood Crowns Career in Church
description: Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton, whose sainthood was formally decreed yesterday by Pope Paul VI, once stood in the festive Wall Street throng that saw George Washington sworn in as the nation's first Presidents

title: 2 of Sextuplets Weaken
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP)Two of the three surviving sextuplets of Charlotte Lange lapsed into critical condition today as doctors found their respiratory functions weakening. The threemonthpremature infants, who have been in respirators since shortly after their delivery Sunday, are suffering from hyaline membrane disease in which the lungs fail to absorb sufficient oxygen, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Banishing Legislators
description: The Greek historian Diodorus Siculus has some interesting things to say about governing. He relates how, in India, an adviser to the state was permitted three errors before he was banished from public life.

title: Miss Proell Wins Downhill
description: CORTINA d'AMPEZZO, Italy, Dec. 12 (UPI)  Annermarie Proell zipped down the icy Caprioli Olympic course in the fastest time today for her first downhill victory of the young World Cup ski season. She triumphed by half a second over Cindy NelSon of Lutsen, Minn., the runnerup and increased her overall Cup lead.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ASSIGN FRESHMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The House Democratic leadership selected 20 newly elected Representatives today for seats on major committees.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)The Business Council issued a forecast today showing a significant improvement in the rate of inflation during the next six months, but said the economy would continue its weak performance.

title: ROUSE UNIT, 2612, BACKS ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The House Judiciary Committee recommended today, by a voter of 26 to 12 the confirmation of Nelson A Rocke

title: WHISKY AND COINS, S. E. C. SUITS FILED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit here yesterday against Brigadoon Scotch Distributors, Ltd., the Federal Coin Reserve, Inc., both of Great Neck, L. I., and 26 others on charges of violating Federal securities laws.

title: 11,000 Concerns Must Disclose Data
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) A Federal District Court Judge has ruled that more than 11,000 corporations should disclose the environmental impact of their activities and any knowledge of job discrimination, court records showed today.

title: 3 SENATORS BACK SOVIET ARMS DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Senator Edward M. Kennedy and two other Senators introduced a resolution today expressing broad support for the Vladivostok arms control agreement but calling on President Ford to try to negotiate lower ceilings for Soviet and American force levels before submitting the accord for Senate approval.

title: GREECE MAY KEEP MOST U. S. BASES
description: ATHENS, Dec. 12Greece intends to allow the United States to keep military bases here that serve mutual defense interests, but may request the removal of those that serve only the United States, wellinformed Greek sources said today.

title: Girls Given Equality In N.J. School Sport
description: Girls in New Jersey high schools are about to get an even break in athletics. A estate law and a ruling by the New Jersey State Interschogestic Athletic Association will give girls the right to participate in the same sports that boys do.

title: Excerpts From Second Day of Debate on Role of U.N.
description: UNITED. NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12  Following are excerpts from statements by delegates during General Assembly debate today on the role of the United Nations. The translation of the Venezuelan delegate's statement from Spanish is unofficial.

title: Senator Votes Maritime Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Senate approved a bill today authorizing $562.9million for Federal maritime programs, most of it to subsidize United States shipbuilders and steamship lines. The bill, passed by voice vote, now goes to conference with the House.

title: The Skimp: Conspicuous by Its Absence
description: The short and merry life of the skimp is just about over, at least chez Halston. Remember the skimp? It's Halston's revival of the minidress, which riveted store buyers when they first saw it at his spring readytowear showings on Seventh Avenue a month ago.

title: Court Limits Laws That Exclude Big Families From Apartments
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12 (UPI)The New Jersey Supreme Court today cleared the way for challenges to local apartmenthouse ordinances that effectively exclude members of minority groups and poor people with large families.

title: Pentagon Calls Plan Success On Foreign Defense Roles
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP)  The Pentagon said today, that its present system for mon= itoring possible foreign investment in the crucial United States defense industry appeared to be effective.

title: The Coldest Warrior of All
description: The nomination of Nelson Rockefeller to be Vice President was in deep trouble a month ago, but now it is speeding through Congress, with the House likely to vote final approval next week. A majorif generally unspokenreason for the turnabout is the growing belief on Capitol Hill that President Ford is so inept that if his Administration is to stay, afloat it needs the help of a vigorous and experienced political leader like Mr. Rockefeller.

title: Ferris to Succeed Carlson at Airline
description: Richard J. Ferris, a 38yearold native Californian who switched from the hotel business to the airline business just three years ago, was named president yesterday of United Airlinesthe nation's largest airlineseffective Jan. 1.

title: Vincent A. Caso, a Reporter At City Hall for II Progresso
description: Vincent A. Caso, who had been a political reporter, covering City Hall for II Progresso, the ItalianAmerican daily, for 40 years at his retirement in 1970, died Tuesday at Community Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: 5 Die in a Brooklyn Fire Laid to a Neighbor
description: Five persons, including four children, were killed yesterday in a fire in Brooklyn that the police said had been set by a neighbor after a quarrel at a party Saturday between members of two families.

title: Complaint Is Filed Charging a Fraud By Coin Exchange
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a fraud complaint today against the Pacific Coast Coin Exchange and proposed that a receiver take over immediate control of the exchange's assets.

title: Those Getting Jobless Aid Up 3,700 to 2.4 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Labor Department reported today that 2,436,100 persons received unemployment insurance benefits for the week ended Nov. 23, an increase of 3,700 over the previous week.

title: Market Place Another View on Going Private
description: These days when a publicly owned company goes privatebuys back its shares from the public ownersit does so knowing that the Securities and Exchange Commission is watching for violations of its antifraud provisions. A. A. Sommer Jr., a member of the commission, made this clear a while back, when he spoke at the Notre Dame Law School.

title: Prices of Soybean Futures Rise on Chicago Board
description: Soybean prices moved up in active trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Senate Votes to Vote on an Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12The New Jersey Senate amended Governor Byrne's state incometax proposal tonight so that it would become a simple tax on Federal income taxes and agrees to take a final vote on the measure Monday.

title: S.I. Site Picked for Transit Power Plant
description: The State Power Authority yesterday designated an undeveloped Staten Island area near Arthur Kill as the primary site for a coal or oilfired power plant to generate electricity for subway and commuter rail lines.

title: DELIVERERS PROTEST DECISION IN BIAS SUIT
description: More than 100 newspaper deliverers who hold shaper stattis rather than a regular situation and union membership picketed outside The Daily News and The New York Times Yesterday to protest a compromise settlement in Federal Court of a discrimination suit.

title: A Tale of 2 Forgotten Giants
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 12While New York Giants fans try to figure out why their football team can't win, Larry Jacobson and Don Clune have been sitting on the bench wondering what happened to their season.

title: 2 Hoboken Officers Charged With Usury On a $16,000 Loan
description: NEWARK, Dec, 12 (AP)Two Hoboken policemen who allegedly lent a New Jersey businessman $15,000 and then collected $78,000 in interest over 23 months were indicted today for loansharing.

title: Music: Rieti Symphony
description: Vittorio Rieti is one of those compgsers who were deeply and lastingly influenced by the neoclassical revival of the nineteentwenties, when Stravinsky, Hindemith, Prokofiev and so many other musical movers and shakers were looking backward in hopes of avoiding the chaos that the future seemed to offer.

title: L.T.T. Sets Asset Transfer Of 126Million to Insurer
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday it was transferring assets valued at more than $126million to the Hartford Insurance Group, an I.T.T. affiliate.

title: The New Suit Uncle Sam Gave Ma Bell
description: WASHINGTONThe Justice Department, in Challenging once again the incestuous corporate relationship between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its mammoth manufacturing subsidiary, the Western Electric Company, Inc., fired the opening fusillade what promises to be another long, and probably unproductive engagement between lawyers.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Scoters Hardy, Unpopular
description: Heavy bodied and slow on the take off, but fast powerful and direct in flight, the scoter, whether common, surf or white winged is held in low esteem by most Eastern waterfowl hunters.

title: A Phony Physician Confesses Forging Real Doctor's Name
description: As a physician, Vladimir Owens was too good to be true he made house calls, and this aroused his patients' suspicions. After taking a close look, detectives arrested him for not being the doctor he pretended to be.

title: Byrne Names Education Aide
description: TRENTON, Dec, 12 (AP)Governor Byrne nominated Bryant George of Teaneck today to succeed the State Board of Education president, Calvin Hurd, as a member of the education panel, Mr. George is a Presbyterian minister and a program officer with the Ford Foundation in New York.

title: 54 SAIGON SOLDIER DIE IN COPTER CRASH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 13 (Reuters)A helicopter crashed in the western Mekong Delta yesterday and first reports said that 54 South Vietnamese soldiers had been killed, according to a Saigon command announcement today.

title: Most Coal Mines Resume Production Despite Deadlock
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 (AP)Despite rejection of a new contract for mine construction workers, most of the nation's coal mines were in production today.

title: New Books FICTION
description: The Best Nature Stories of Paul Annixter, selected and with an introduction by Ruth Robinson (Lawrence Hill, $6.95).

title: MAKARIOS SHIFT ON TALKS IS SEEN
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 12Archbishop Makarios was described by a highly placed source today as sobered and saddened by the Cyprus he found on his return last Saturday from the exile he began after the coup that deposed him from the Presidency last July 15.

title: Door on L.I.R.R. Electric Cars Seen Hazardous in U. S. Inquiry
description: The automatic doors of the Long Island Rail Road's 770 electric Metropolitan cars were described as hazardous yesterday by a Federal investigator studying the Dec. 1 accident in which a man was dragged to his death.

title: RICHARD S. JACKSON, PUBLISHER, IS DEAD
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12 (AP)Richard Seymour Jackson, former president and copublisher of the Register Publishing Company, died today at the Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: M'CORD CONVICTION IS UPHELD BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 12 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia upheld today the conviction of James W. McCord Jr., a Watergate burglar who contended that perjured testismony had prevented as fair trial.

title: Vermeer Quartet Is Welcomed Back At Hunter Concert
description: When the Vermeer Quartet first played here a few years back, it was welcomed for its intensity but with reservations about roughness of tone and a tendency to overpower the music. Last season, however, the group, which is in residence at Northern Illinois University, appeared with a new violist and cellist, and was greeted much more warmly. And Wednesday night the quartet was at the Hunter College Playhouse, and offered a performance of a quality to place it among the to quartets active today.

title: Bomb Scare in Tokyo Evacuates Mitsubishi
description: TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 13, ReutersThe offices of the giant Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Company in central Toyko were evacuated today after a telephone warning that a bomb had been plandted planted in the building.

title: THIRD WORLD SAYS U.N. MUST CHANGE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12Delegates of developing countries said today that changing; global relationships must be mirrored in the way the United Nations works.

title: Georgia's Gov. Carter Enters Democratic Race, for President
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 12Jimmy Carter, the moderate Georgia Governor who is regarded by supporters as a Southernstyle Kennedy and by skeptic as just another Democratic dark horse, announced his candidacy for President tonight.

title: HOUSE UNIT, 2612, BACKS ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The House Judiciary Committee recommended today, by a vote of 26 to 12, the confirmation of Nelson A. Recitefeller as Vice President

title: O.E.O. Director Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Burt A. Gallegos of California as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: TED PATRICK FREED IN COAST ABDUCTION
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 12 (AP)Ted Patrick of San Diego was acquitted of kidnapping charges yesterday in connection with the nationally televised abduction of a 19yearold woman from a religious sect known as the Love Family.

title: Group of Nursing Homes Defies Subpoenas by State Commission
description: Alleged members of the Bernard Bergman syndicate of nursing homes yesterday defied subpoenas of the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs and moved to challenge its jurisdiction in court.

title: BRITISH DEFICIT IS HIGHEST EVER
description: LONDON, Dec. 12  The Government reported today that Britain ran a visible trade deficit equivalent to $1.23billion in November, the highest monthly imbalance in British history, despite a slight improvement in the oil trade position.

title: CONGRESS WIDENS PAY HELP FOR IDLE; BACKS PUBLIC JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The House and Senate approved by large margins today legislation designed to reduce the effects of the nation's rapidly growing unemployment.

title: Bruins Subdue Kings, 81
description: BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP)Phil Esposito's 24th goal of the season and Bobby Orr's 17th led the Boston Bruins to an 81 victory over Los Angeles tonight, the Kings' first road loss of the season.

title: People and Business
description: A rift over prices between the Ford Motor Company and a large dealer organization known as the Ford Dealers Alliance appears to be widening.

title: Meany, in Fight With Strauss, Is Reported Ready to Declare Labor's Break Democratic Party
description: WASHINGTON, Dec.12The nation' largest alliance of organized workers is on the verge of formal disengagement from the Democratic party, union officials said today.

title: U. S., Europe, Oil, Gold
description: PARIS, Dec. 12After prolonged tension the United Sates and, Western Europe are Moving toward compromise and undertaking a concerted effort to deal with the economic problems that both consider a menace to themselves and much of the rest of the world.

title: Savings Checks Barred
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday in Rochester that savings banks in New York State do not have the right to offer checklike accounts to their depositors, the Associated Press reported.

title: DELAY ON GAS BAN HELD OZONE PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12A threeyear delay In banning the propellant gases used in aerosol cans might cause a reduction of nearly 5 per cent in the atmosphere's protective ozone layer, a scientist's calculations indicate..

title: Nassau Supervisors to Adopt Budget Cutting Caso Tax Rise
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 12The Nassau County Board of Supervisors announced today that it would adopt a county budget for 1975 that will reduce the propertytaxrate increase proposed by County Executive Ralph G. Caso by 57 cents.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: About Real Estate
description: At such a price, Aaron Ziegelman could not resist. So he recently bought the two apartment buildings at 2300 and 2320 Bronx Park East, in the largely Jewish and Italian Pelham Parkway area, from Milton and Peter Kimmelman.

title: Fraud Charges Filed
description: Thirteen persons  ten of them officers of the HomeStake Production Companyhave been charged in Los Angeles in a 39count Federal indictment with bilking investors of tens of millions of dollars in a fraudulent taxshelter scheme. Page 69.

title: Rhodesian Blacks Hailed On Return From Meeting
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec, 12 (Reuters)Two freed black nationalist leaders, Joshua Nkomo., and the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, were given a rousing welcome by more than 1,000 blacks today when they made their first public appearance in whitegoverned Rhodesia for more than 10 years.

title: VIRGINIA S. KEYSER
description: Virginia Speare Keyser, an economic consultant and for the last five veers director of development for the Madeira School, a private school for girls, in Greenway, Va., died Wednesday in Greenway. She was 64 years old and formerly lived here.

title: Indictment Names 13 at HomeStake
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12Thirteen personten of them officers of the HomeStake Production Company, in which a long list of show business stars, prominent business executives and politicians have investedwere charged in a 39count Federal indictment today with bilking investors of tens of millions of dollars in a fraudulent tax shelter scheme.

title: Caspian Shore Flooded
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (Reuters) About 1,500 people were evacuated when galeforce winds hit the north shore of the Caspian Sea this month and caused flooding inland, the newspaper Pravda reported today. It said winds had driven water 19 miles inland over a 125mile front, but there was no loss of human life. The flooded area extends from the Volga delta east to the town of Guryev.

title: Israeli Planes Strike 2 Palestinian Areas at Beirut After Theater Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec, 12 Israeli planes attacked two Palestinian areas in the southern outskirts of Beirut today, less than 24 hours after a guerrilla grenade attack in a Tel Aviv movie theater

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOOD AND LOUD A brashly inventive quintet of young rockpopballad belters who call themselves The Changing Scene are a welcome addition to the holiday entertainment orbit. They may not be carolers, but their spirited flash, rhythmic coordination and cheerful determination to please make a winning earful and eyeful on the podium of Le Jockey Club, the sublevel discothque of the Americana Hotel. Nightly, except Sunday, they perform at 9:30, 11:15 and 1:15 in this tastefully appointed room, with its lowkeyed, greenanddark color scheme, framed horse prints on the walls and tables ringing a center parquet for disco dancing between shows.

title: School Board Cuts Capital Plans Of $450Million to $130Million
description: The Board of Education, facing what its president called the grim fiscal reality in the city, yesterday scaled down from $450million to $130million its request for money to build new schools in the 1975 76 capital budget.

title: Newcombe, Mastase Gain Semifinals
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 2 (AP)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina defeated Bjorn Berg of Sweden 75 61, today and gained the semifinals of the Grand Prix masters tennis tournament.

title: State Reports Clam Sales
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12 (AP)The State Department of Environmental Protection reportled today that 17 million clams had been marketed for $1.5million as the result of a fiveyearold program of transplanting the shellfish in the Atlantic City area.

title: 'Godfather, Part II' Is Hard to Define:The Cast
description: The only remarkable thing about Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather, Part II" is the insistent manner in which it recalls how much better his original film was. Among other things, one remembers "The Godfather's" tremendous narrative drive and the dominating presence of Marlon Brando in the title role, which, though not large, unified the film and transformed a super-gangster movie into a unique family chronicle."Part II," also written by Mr. Coppola and Mario Puzo, is not a sequel in any engaging way. It's not really much of anything that can be easily defined.It's a second movie made largely out of the bits and pieces of Mr. Puzo's novel that didn't fit into the first. It's a Frankenstein's monster stitched together from leftover parts. It talks. It moves in fits and starts but it has no mind of its own. Occasionally it repeats a point made in "The Godfather" (organized crime is just another kind of American business, say) but its insights are fairly lame at this point."The Godfather, Part II," which opened yesterday at five theaters, is not very far along before one realizes that it hasn't anything more to say. Everything of any interest was thoroughly covered in the original film, but like many people who have nothing to say, "Part II" won't shut up.Not the least of its problems is its fractured form. "Part II" moves continually back and forth in time between two distinct narratives. It's the story of the young Vito Corleone (who grew up to be played by Marlon Brando in the first movie) seen first around the turn of the century in Sicily and then in 1917 in New York, where he's played by Robert De Niro, and it's the story of Vito's son, Michael, played again by Al Pacino, the new Mafia don who sets out to control Las Vegas in the late nineteen-fifties.One story doesn't necessarily illuminate the other, it's just additional data, like footnotes. I can't readily imagine what Mr. Coppola and Mr. Puzo were trying to do, except to turn their first film into a long parenthesis that would fit between the halves of the new movie.Even if "Part II" were a lot more cohesive, revealing and exciting than it is, it probably would have run the risk of appearing to be the self-parody it now seems.Looking very expensive but spiritually desperate, "Part II" has the air of a very long, very elaborate revue sketch. Nothing is sacred. The photography by Gordon Willis, so effective originally, is now comically fancythe exteriors are too bright and glowy while the interiors are so dark you wonder if these Mafia chiefs can't afford to buy bigger light bulbs.Nino Rota's old score keeps thumping away like a heavenly juke box. The performers, especially those repeating their original roles, seem locked into waxily rigid attitudes. Mr. Pacino, so fine the first time out, goes through the film looking glum, sighing wearily as he orders the execution of an old associate or a brother, winding up very lonely and powerful, which is just about the way he wound up before. Mr. De Niro, one of our best young actors, is interesting as the young Vito until, toward the end of his section of the film, he starts giving a nightclub imitation of Mr. Brando's elderly Vito.There are a couple of nottble exceptions. Lee Strasberg, the head of the Actors Studio, makes an extraordinarily effective screen debut as Hyman Roth, the powerful Jewish mobster (reportedly modeled on Meyer Lansky) with whom Michael attempts to take over the Havana rackets under the Battista regime. Mr. Strasberg's Roth is a fascinating mixture of lust, ruthlessness and chicken soup. Michael V. Gazzo, the playwright ("A Hatful of Rain"), is also superb as a Corleone captain who crosses the Family. Another more or less nonpro, G. D. Spradlin (a former politician, according to publicity sources) is absolutely right as a crooked, very WASPish United States Senator from Nevada.The plot defies any rational synopsis, but it allows Mr. Coppola, in his role as director, to rework lots of scenes that were done far better the first time: family reunions, shoot-outs, ambushes and occasional dumb exchanges between Don Michael Corleone and his square, long-suffering wife, Kay (Diane Keaton). "Oh, Michael," says the slow-to-take-offense Kay when Michael is about to sew up the Vegas rackets, "seven years ago you told me you'd be legitimate in five years.""Part II's" dialogue often sounds like cartoon captions.

title: Renoir Stolen From Brooklyn Museum
description: A small Renoir painting, Still. Life with Blue Cup, was stolen yesterday afternoon from the Brooklyn Museum.

title: SANE POST HINTED FOR COLLEGE HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Edward H. Levi, president of the University, appeared today to be the leading contender to succeed William B. Saxbe as Attorney General.

title: Colleges Warned on Reverse Job Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 12 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that colleges receiving Federal contracts may not discriminate against white males while trying to improve employmerit opportunities for minority groups and women.

title: Wingate's Son Shot in Head In Fight at Bronx Bar
description: Anthony Wingate, the 24yearold son of Livingston Wingate, executive director of the New York Urban League, was shot twice hi the head last night in an altercation with another man at a Bronx bar, the police reported.

title: Gifts to Neediest Honor the Dead
description: The Christmas celebration has always been an expression of joy in living and hope for the future, but for many donors to the 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund it is also the time they choose to contribute in memory of a departed one.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: CHICAGODenny Moyer, 160 pounds, Portland, Ore., knocked out Rocky DeFazio, 155, Chicago, 10 rounds; Angel Mayoral, San Diego, outpointed Johnny Copeland, Joplin, Mo., 10, lightweights.

title: 2 From Jersey Die in Florida
description: MIAMI, Dec. 12 (AP)A New Jersey man and his wife vacationing in Florida were killed last night when they were struck by a car. The police said that William Farness, 77 years old, and his wife, Betty, 69, of Irvington, N.J., were hit as they walked.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: The. World Football League, its future clouded by huge debts and lack of credibility, convenes a meeting of owners and potential investors in New York today. Chris Hemmeter, the Hawaiian land developer who is the league's new president, said yesterday that the meetings would be another step in his efforts to find new investors willing to lose millions over the next several years in order to guarantee the W.F.L. a strong future.

title: Yugoslavia to Try Writer. For Propaganda
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 12Mihajlo Mihajlov, the author of critical essays on Communism, is to face trial on charges of hostile propaganda against the state.

title: Top Police Seized in Detroit. Suburb
description: ECORSE, Mich., Dec. 12 The Chief of Police, the chief of detectives, the superintendent of public works and three other top police officials of this suburb of Detroit were arrested today on charges of protecting $5millionayear gambling operation in return for payoffs of up to $2,000 a month.

title: Explosion at Paris Ministry
description: PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)An explosion damaged the Education Ministry late last night and the police said it was caused by a bomb. There were no injuries, but 66 offices were totally or partly wrecked and the damage was estimated at $330,000. Police sources said no notes were found and there was no immediate speculation on who might have been the target of the blast.

title: 2d Tentative Pact In the Milk Strike Is Reached Here
The Pop Life
description: Manhattan Transfer, which opened at Reno Sweeney's on Tuesday for a month, is clearly going to give a lot of people a lot of live, inperson pleasure. And the group is likely to give a lot more pleasure very soon, since it has just signed a record contract with Atlantic. In fact, it had its first formal recording session yesterday for its first album, which is being coproduced by Ahmet Ertegun, Atlantic's chairman.

title: Burma Reports 9 Killed in Outbursts Over Thant Burial
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 12 (Reuters)  The Burmese Government reported that nine persons had been killed when policemen opened fire on crowds yesterday but that conditions had returned to normal by tonight.

title: OPEC's Nigerian Head
description: VIENNA, Dec. 12The new head of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries says he wants to begin a dialogue with consumer countries because we are both striving for the same goals to conserve resources and insure that the world community gets its energy supplies at reasonable prices. Chief Meshach Otokiti Feyide (pronounced FAYeed), 48yearold director of Nigeria's Petroleum Resources Department, was named today as OPEC's 10th secretary general,

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS STRIP MINE BIL??
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Th last of numerous legislative bottlenecks that have held bad passage of a strong Federal lam to control the environmenta abuses of strip mining for coa was broken today. The meas we seemed headed for fina passage this week.

title: House Bill Would Tie Medical School Aid to Service to Needy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The House approved today a $1.6billion healthmanpower bill that would require schools of medicine, dentistry and osteopathy to Spend at least one quarter of the money training students for service in areas of need.

title: People in Sports
description: Columbia University's quarterbacks will receive coaching, help next summer from Weeb Ewbank, former head coach of the New York Jets and Baltimore Colts. Ewbank, who was fortunate enough to have Johnny Unitas as quarterback at Baltimore and Joe Nemeth with the Jets, has agreed to assist Coach Bill Campbell of Columbia by working with Lion quarterbacks in preseason drills in August and September. The primary Columbia signalcallers and passers for 1975 are expected to be Mike Delaney, currently a junior, and Kevin Bunrs, now a freshman.

title: HENDERSON GUILTY ON 2 TAX COUNTS
description: Skitch Henderson has been convicted on two charges that he filed false incometax returns for 1969 and 1970 by reporting that a music library he donated to a university was worth $356,000.

title: City U. Adopts BudgetCut Measures
description: Small closses will be combined, professors will assume larger teaching loads and college presidents and other administrators will have to take on teaching responsibilities as to result of a $18.9million budget cut ordered yesterday for the City University by Dr. Robpert J. Kibbee, the chancellor.

title: Gulf & Western Sees Continuing Gains
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., thriving from all its diversified activities except financial services and leisuretime products, told its shareholders yesterday that its net income soared 40 per cent to a record in the first quarter ended Oct. 31.

title: Let Them Eat
description: When President Ford unveiled his proposed antiinflation budget cuts, his press secretary said that he was calling on all Americans to share the burden and divide the misery. When it came to paring the food stamp program, however, the President advanced a plan, possibly designed by Marie, Antoinettes, which increases the burdens of Americas poor and compounds their misery.

title: Ford Is Planning 16,000 More Layoffs
description: DETROIT, Dec. 12The Ford Motor Company announced today layoffs for nearly 16,000 more workers next week, while the Chrysler Corporation said that its assembly plant in Newark, Del., would remain closed until Feb. 3.

title: 8 Latin Nations Declare Intention to Limit Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Eight LatinAmerican countries, after a threeday meeting in Peru, have issued a declaration of agreement to limit armaments and to stop acquiring offen sive weapons. The eight were Peru, Chile, Bolivia, Ecuador, Venezuela, Argentina, Colombia and Panama.

title: Prosecutor Says Ehrlichman Admitted Playing Role in CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The chief prosecutor at the Watergate coverup trial contended. today that John D. Ehrlichman was blaming former President Richard M. Nixon for the coverup when, in fact, Mr. Ehrlichinan had confessed his own role in it to Mr. Nixon in the spring of 1973.

title: Senate Committee Votes 1925 Chemical War Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today ended a halfcenturyold deadlock over the 1925 Geneva protocol on chemical warfare by voting unanimously to send the treaty to the Senate for approval.

title: 8 Latin Nations Declare Intention to Limit Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Eight LatinAmerican countries, after a threeday meeting in Peru, have issued a declaration of agreement to limit armaments and to stop acquiring offensive weapons. The eight were Peru, Chile, Bolivia, Ecuador, Venezuela, Argentina, Colombia and Panama.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1974

title: Drug Use Is Called on Upswing in U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12Although heroin consumption in the United States decreased slightly in late 1972 and early 1973, drug use is once again on the upswing and promises to get even worse, Dr. Robert L. DuPont, director of the White douse Special Action Offict on Drug Abuse, declared here today.

title: LOANS BY BUSINESS CLIMBED IN WEEK
description: Business loans of major New York City banks increased $341million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Renoir Stolen Here
description: A small Renoir painting, Still Life With Blue Cup, was stolen yesterday afternoon from the Brooklyn Museum, The painting was said to be worth about $50,000. Page 57.

title: House Rules Panel Sets Back A Small Tax Cut for 40 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The House Rules Committee took an action today that probably kills for this Congress any chance of enactment of legislation that would increase the taxes of the oil industry and give a small tax cut to 40 million lowandmiddleincome individuals.

title: NEW DECLARATION VOTED IN THE U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12The General Assembly today approved a new and controversial economic declaration, championed vigorously by third world countries and supported by Communist members but opposed by major industrial powers.

title: LAWYER IS REBUKED ON SECRET BIDDING
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court today reprimanded Juan J. Ryan, a New Providence lawyer, who used inside information to outbid another man on a tract of land in Atlantic County. Mr. Ryan paid $3,000 and less than a year later sold the land for $7,000.

title: EastWest Talks on Force Cuts Are Recessed
description: VIENNA, Dec 12. The EastWest talks on force reductions in Central Europe were recessed today until January with both sides admitting that no concrete progress has been made.

title: Recent Simon Estimates on Oil Are Challenged by 2 Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12Experts at two major oil companies have privately challenged as exaggerated recent intelligence estimates given by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon of new oil discoveries outside the oilcartel countries and production that, could be expected from them in 1980.

title: GEORGIA POWER NET OFF 95.5% IN MONTH
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 12 (AP)The Georgia Power Company said today that earnings plunged in November for the fifth straight month and that the utilities financial condition had become a major crisis.

title: 2d Tentative Pact In the Milk Strike Is Reached Here
description: Negotiators for milk dealers in the metropolitan area and their striking employes reached anew tentative agreement last night, both sides reported.

title: Gifts to Neediest Honor the Dead
description: The Christmas celebration has always been an expression of joy in living and hope for the future, but for many donors to the 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund it is also the time they choose to contribute in memory of a departed one.

title: Athlete Held in Burglary
description: DALLAS, Dec. 12 (UPI)A former Southern Methodist University basketball star, Sammy Hervey, was arrested yesterday inside an elementary school and charged with seconddegree burglary. The police said they surprised Mr. Hervey, 23 years old, and Byron R. Sands, 23, after being alerted by a silent alarm.

title: Rise in Wholesale Prices Slowed Again Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12The nation's inflation, as measured by the sensitive Wholesale Price Index, abated further in November though prices were still going up, the Labor Department reported today. The overall index, after adjustment for normal seasonal changes in some prices, rose by 1.2, per cent last month, one of the smallest increases this year and only, half the October rise.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled that information from a computerized police information system that identified an allegedly stolen gun was inadmissible evidence. The court said that John E. McGee Jr. of Baltimore who was given a threetofiveyear suspended sentence and placed on probation for five years on a charge of bringing a stolen gun into New Jersey, was entitled to a new trial.

title: Byrne Issues Rules For Saving Energy
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) Governor Byrne today ordered thermostats lowered to 65 to 68 degrees during working hours in state buildings to save energy.

title: City Spurns a Regional TakeOver of Water Supply
description: New York City yesterday rejected a proposal by a state commission to take over the city's water supply and make it part of a regional water supply corporation.

title: Inquiry Unit Sends Data On Lindenwold to State
description: TRENTON, Dec. 12  The State Commission of Invesigation today sent the record of its inquiry into alleged official corruption in the Camden suburb of Lindenwold to appropriate state and county law enforcement agencies.

title: Renoir Stolen Here
description: A small Renoir painting, Still Life With Blue Cup, was stolen yesterday afternoon from the Brooklyn Museum. The painting was said to be worth about $50,000. Page 57.

title: Girls Given Equality In N.J. School Sport
description: Girls in New Jersey high schools are about to get an even break in athletics A estate law and a ruling by the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association will give girls the right to participate in the, same sports that boys do.

title: Blast Kills Hospital Aide
description: CAMBRIDGE, mass, Dec. 12 (AP)Charles Nordby 35 years old, of Watertown, died from injuries suffered when a boiler exploded yesterday in the basement of the HarvardRadcliffe Catholic Student Center.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: At this time of year, the whispering voice in the parental mind has taken on an urgent tone: Go to Herald Square, it says, and buy toys. The parental mind answers, Yes, of course, you know I will.

title: Erosion of the U.N.
description: The twentyninth United Nations General Assembly will wind up a tumultuous session next week with several firstsall of them damaging for the organization and probably for the cause of international peace and security as well.

title: Captains Heading Jet Rise
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 12 Should anyone look back on the New York Jets' 1974 season, and wonder what turned them around from, a 17 wonlost record to their current 67 before their final game Sunday, he'd have to give a lot of credit to the team captains.

title: Abducted Jersey Boy Is Home After 2 Months With a Friend
description: A 7yearold Rutherford, N.J., boys was reunited with his family by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last night after a twoandahalfmonth odyssey in which a 23yearold friend abducted him for a sightseeing and fishing spree down the East Coast to Florida.

title: GREECE TO ALLON MOST U. S BASES
description: ATHENS, Dec. 12 Greece intends to allow the United States to keep military bases here that serve mutual defense interests, but may request the removal of those that serve only the United States, wellinformed Greek sources said today.Greece won't be restored. In a speech to Parliament last night, Premier Constantine Caramanlis disclosed that he had sent a note to Washington formally asking for a review of the. American bases here. Today wellinformed sources explained and interpreted the note, which was delivered within the last few days.

title: People in Sports
description: Columbia University's quarterbacks will receive coaching help next summer from Weeb Ewbank, former head coach of the New York Jets and Baltimore Colts. Ewbank, who was fortunate enough to have Johnny Unitas as quarterback at Baltimore and Joe Namath with the Jets, has agreed to assist Coach Bill Campbell of Columbia by working with Lion quarterbacks in preseason drills in August and September. The primary Columbia signalcallers and passers for 1975 are expected to be Mike Delaney, currently a junior, and Kevin Bunrs, now a freshman.

title: Surgery Barred for Bullet Sought as Evidence
description: A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that a bullet could not be removed from the chest of a suspect in the murder of a police lieutenant because the surgery would constitute an unreasonable search and seizure and possibly endanger the suspect's life.

title: Fines Sought for Deliverymen, Repairmen Who Fail to Appear
description: The city proposes to get after the deliveryman or repairman who sets a date with the consumer for delivery or service and then, without notice, fails to show up.

title: Closure on Trade
description: The trade reform bill, always important as a needed step toward a more open world, hag takers on even greater urgency as a result of the imbalances in inter, national payments exploited by the oil cartel. There are increasing signs that a majority of Senator are prepared to approve this vital legislation if they are given an opportunity to vote it.

title: Giscarcl Meets Protests in Guadeloupe
description: POINTE  A  PURE, Guadeloupe, Dec. 12 (UPI)Hundreds of angry demonstrators forced President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France to cancel part of his program today shortly after he arrived in this Caribbean island on his way to a weekend meeting in Martinique with President Ford.

title: Notes on People
description: Disgruntled cattlemen yesterday herded 45 head of cattle up to the official doorstep of Dr. Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, to protest the high cost of producing meat. Here's our beef, Mr. Butz, said a sign near makeshift pens on the mall outside Agriculture Department headquarters in Washington. The cattlemen sent a delegation in to talk with the Secretary, and an attempt was made by the group to give Dr. Butz 10 of the steers so that he could feed them and learn firsthand how expensive it is to fatten cattle. Mr. Butz turned down the cattle on the ground that the law prohibits acceptance of gifts. The mall demonstration capped a sevenday crosscountry drive by truck of the cattle, which were brought from South Dakota by a meat promotion group to dramatize the plight of the cattlemen. The Consumers Federation of America joined the demonstration. A spokesman for Dr. Butz said, These people are wellintentioned, obviously very sincere and responsible.

title: ESTHER FOLEY
description: Esther Foley, who had been ?? food editor for several publications, including The New York HeraldTribune's magazine, The Ladies Home Journal and The American Home, died yesterday in Syracuse. She was 68 years old.

title: About New York
description: Albert Shanker said that he certainly hadn't agreed to any dismissals, and when someone asked John DeLury about a job freeze he said something like Freeze? No freeze with me, and suggested that everyone wear their woolies. Then Victor Gotbaum showed up, and when a radio reporter shoved a microphone at him Mr. Gotbaum said something obscene. The radio reporter had to excise it from the air of course, but Mr. Gotbaum had made his point. He meant that he was mad.

title: Rutgers Upsets Jaspers
description: George Bucci of Manhattan shoved Ed Jordan last night and when the Rutgers' backcourtman got off the floor, the tempo of the game changed. Rutgers, fired up by the incident, went on to upset highly regarded Manhattan, 8577, in the second game of the opening college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

title: OPEC DISCUSSING STABLE OIL PRICES
description: VIENNA, Dec. 12A ministerial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began discussion today of a new price system for crude oil that could stabilize the cost of oil to consumers for the first six months of 1975.

title: GREAT WESTERN TO PAY DIVIDEND
description: Pursuing its policy of clearing up back dividend payments, the Great Western United. Corporation said yesterday that its executive, committee would meet Dec. 20 and declare a dividend of $2.92 a common share, payable Jan. 15 to shareholders of record Dec. 31. Almost simultaneously with this announcement, Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt of Dallas, who are seeking to purchase 910,000 shares of Great Western common stock, said that the Federal District Court in Dallas had temporarily restrained Great Western from paying a dividend on its common stock.

title: Theater: Instinct and Reason in Rules of the Game
description: The New Phoenix Reper tory Company has selected Luigi Pirandello's The Rules of the Game for its second play in the current New York season at the Helen Hayes Theater.

title: Women's Super Event: No Room for Champion
description: Heide Rosendahl Ecker, considered, by many to be the world's finest woman athlete, said yesterday that she had first women sold uperrstars event because officials feared a foreigner might win the competition and further dampen America's international image.

title: Senate Committee Votes 1925 Chemical War Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today ended a halfcenturyold deadlock over the 1925 Geneva protocol on chemical warfare by voting unanimously to send the treaty to the Senate for approval.

title: Officer Wounded in Blast Faces Layoff as a Rookie
description: A policeman who was on his first patrol and was among those expected to be laid off in the city's economy campaign was critically injured late Wednesday night when he set off a booby trap reportedly placed in retaliation for the death of a Puerto Rican musician in a police station this month.

title: KARL ARNSTEIN, AIRSHIP DESIGNER
description: Dr. Karl Arnstein, who had designed more than 100 lighterthanair craft and was widely regarded as a leader in the field, died yesterday in Akron, Ohio, where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: NEW BATTERY HAILED IN HEART PACEMAKER
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12 (AP)Three scientists say they have invented a tiny enzyme batterry that may triple the operating life of heart pacemakers and have other farreaching applications as well.

title: McCrory Pledges Equity In Lerner's for a Loan
description: The McCrory Corporation, diversified retail chain controlled by the RapidAmerican Corporation, has pledged its equity in its 100 per centowned Lerner Stores Corporation, at the request of 12 banks in order to consummate a $125million loan. Lerner's, which has more than 440 stores, is the country's largest chain of women's and children's apparel shops.

title: Mardian and Sirica Join in Criticizing Amateurs in '72 Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Former Assistant Attorney General Robert C. Mardian denied from the witness stand today the allegations that had been made against him at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: PORTUGUESE HAIL OFFER OF U.S. AID
description: LISBON, Dec 13The United States announcement that it was willing to offer immediate economic aid to Portugal was welcomed here today as a vindication not only of the Portuguese Government but of Stuart Nash Scott, who was recently dismissed as the United States Ambassador after advocating such a move.

title: Nysfrom's Rough Style of Play Gives Islander Fans New Hero
description: At first Bob Nystrom wondered, Why me? It was his first full year with the New York Islanders and he was playing good, but not great, hockey. But, at a game in Toronto last March a dentist from Woodmere, L.L, surprised the tall Scandivanian right wing by asking if he would like to have a fan club.

title: E.P.A. Study Disputes Claims On Efficiency of a New Engine
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) A Government official said today that the experimental La Force auto engine Was no more mechanically efficient than standard engines and caused More carbon Monoxide pollution.

title: Stimulation of U.S.Soviet Trade Across the Pacific Ocean Is Sougl
description: Promoters of SovietAmerican economic relations have started a campaign to stimulate more trade across the Pacific Ocean between the West Coast of the United States and the Far Eastern region of Siberia.

title: Willowbrook Sending Patients of All Ages to 100 Staten Island Homes
description: Margaret Denny's 17th child arrived a few weeks ago at the Dennys Staten Island home. Mrs. Denny, who is 50, insists that there could very well be more.

title: Art: Fragments of Language That Delight the Eyes
description: As a lifelong addict of printed matter in all its forms, I have long regarded the work of the California artist William Dole as one of the unsung delights of the second half of our century. Mr. Dole's works are relatively small, no wild claims have ever been made for him, and to master their meanings, takes a considerable time. Nor has he been overexposed: His present show at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, through next Saturday, is his first in New York since 1960.

title: Sports News Briefs
President Praises Seton Canonization As Historic Event
description: President Ford hailed yesterday the canonization of Blessed Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton, who is to become the first nativeborn American saint of the Roman Catholic Church, as a milestone in our diverse spiritual history.

title: ABCTV Plans to Stress Serializations of Novels
description: Serialized dramatizations of novels, tried sporadically by the television networks the last two years, will be a major programing effort for ABCTV next season, according to Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, the division that embraces the network, the stations it owns and all other television operations.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: The Lambs, the centuryold theatrical club at 130 West 44th Street, has won a postponement in Federal Court of a foreclosure action by the Tremont Savings and Loan Association, which holds a first mortgage of $350,000. The extension was granted by Bankruptcy Judge Edward J. Ryan on being informed that Tremont Savings was not going to advertise a sale of the club's headquarters until after Tuesday.

title: Output of Nation's Industry Tumbled Again in November
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The output of the nation's factories and mines declined by 2.3 per cent in November as the economy clearly moved into a recession.

title: 335 Are Jailed in Burma Crackdown on Violence
description: RANGOON Burma, Dec. 13 (Reuters)Special military tribunals today sentenced 35 people to jail terms ranging from three to five years for destruction of public property during Violence this week.

title: President Praises Seton Canonization As Historic Event
description: President Ford hailed yesterday the canonization of Blessed Elizabeth Ann Bayley Seton, who is to become the first nativeborn American saint of the Roman Catholic Church, as a milestone in our diverse spiritual history.

title: 2D AVE. SUBWAY PUT OFF FURTHER
description: Mayor Beame yesterday proposed a sixyear, transitconstruction program providing no further money for the Second Avenue subway, but emphasizing instead the completion of new Queens trunk lines and modernizing the city's existing subway system.

title: Heart Patients Infected
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 13 (UPI)State health officials revealed today that eight open heart surgery patients in a Georgia hospital recently contracted a blood infection because of contaminated equipment used in the intensive care unit. The patients were treated with antibiotics and recovered after use of a transducer employed to monitor blood pressure, was discontinued.

title: POLICE DISMISS 4 IN AUTO THEFTS
description: Four policemen in Brooklyn have been dismissed following departmental trials in which two were accused of chauffeuring car thieves to the scenes of the crime, and afterwards to a hideaway and two others were charged with receiving stolen goods.

title: Beame to Reshuffle Neighborhood Unit
description: Mayor Beame agreed yesterday to a plan for the drastic reorganization of the Office of Neighborhood Government, a controversial innovation of former Mayor John V. Lindsay, with the likelihood of removing some Lindsay holdovers and replacing them with more compatible personnel, city officials said.

title: SOME COAL MINES CLOSED BY PICKETS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 13 (AP)Picketing mine construction workers closed virtually all coal mines in western Pennsylvania and a few in West Virginia early today as negoti ations resumed in Washington for a construction workers contract.

title: STEADY OIL PRICES FOR NINE MONTHS PROMISED BY OPEC
description: VIENNA, Dec. 13The major petroleumexporting countries said here today they were stabilizing world oil prices for the next nine months at about the existing Persian Gulf level.

title: LOTTERY
Rosi Mittermaier Ski Victor
description: CORTINA d'AMPEZZO, Itaty, Dec. 13 (UPI)  Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany, a sevenyear veteran of World Cup racing, skied in daredevil fashion today and won a special slalom rade by a two seconds. Fabienne Serrat, a teenaged French skier, was second.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Beame surprised 1,000 high school students from Queens yesterday morning when he appeared at the Astor Plaza Theater, at Broadway and 44th Street, to welcome them on the last day of the first annual Mayor's Holiday Program.

title: Books of The Times
description: WILLIAM PENN. By Harry Emerson Wildes. 469 pages. Macmillan. $14.95. WILLIAM PENN: APOSTLE OF DISSENT. By Hans Fantel. Illustrated. 298 pages. William Morro,. $8.95.

title: City May Cut Capital ProjectsIn Effort to Trim Budget Deficit
description: The city's Budget Director yesterday made public a list of more than 200 pending capital construction projects that can ben abandoded or postponed to help reduce the budget deficit in the current fiscal crisis.

title: Ski Conditions
description: PENNSYLVANIA

title: SENATE APPROVES. TRADE BILL GIVING BENEFIT TO SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Senate approved the Administration's sweeping foreign trade bill tonight by 77 votes to 4 after adopting a provision to authorize trade concessions for the Soviet Union in return for freer Soviet emigration policies, particularly as they affect. Jews.

title: Postal Service Lists Holiday Nail Deadlines
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)The Postal Service, faced with the usual mountain of holiday mail, urged today that regular mail Christmas cards be posted no later than Dec. 15 in the United States, including Alaska and Hawaii.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made pay. able to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and for. warded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: City's Forced Retirements May Be Illegal, U.S. Says
description: The Federal Government warned the city yesterday that it might be violating as antidiscrimination law if it went ahead with its proposal to force 860 municipal workers 63 to 65 years old to retire before the mandatory retirement age of 65, to save the jobs of the same number of younger employes.

title: Builders Tell Ford of Programs Needed to Save Home Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) Home builders proposed three Federal aid programs to give consumers quick purchasing power today and asked President Ford to pull the housing industry out of a rapidly worsening crisis.

title: Knicks' LineUp
description: AT GARDEN, 1:30 P.M.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1974

title: G.O.P. Runoff Bid Gains in New Hampshire Court
description: MANCHESTER, N. H.; Dec. 13 (UPI)Representative Louis C. Wyman, Republican of New Hampshire, won the opening skirmish today in his campaign for a courtordered runoff election with John A. Durkin, Democrat, for a seat in the United States Senate.

title: Inouye Election Unit Pleads Guilty on Gift From Steinbrenner
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) A political committee that raised funds for the 1974 reelection campaign of Senator Daniel X Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, pleaded guilty today to failing to report $5,650 in contributions from the American Ship Building Company.

title: Rhodesia to Allow Politics by Blacks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 13Black African nationalist leaders, released from long detentions, scattered to their homes in various parts of Rhodesia today, but the white minority Government relaxed its regulations slightly to permit the black leaders to hold some political meetings in advance of a planned conference on the future of the racially divided country.

title: Arrogance of Power in the Watergate Trial
description: Three of the most powerful political figures of recent timesJohn N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman, and John D. Ehrlichmanare currently being tried for involvement in the obstruction of justice that followed the Watergate burglary arrests.

title: Stores' Bank Terminals Are Held Not Branches
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)The cashier rings up your bill at the supermarket, inserts a plastic bank card into a slot, pushes a few buttons and you're $56 poorer and the supermarket is that much richer.

title: Richardson to Be Named As Ambassador to Britain
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Elliot L. Richardson, who resigned as Attorney General 14 months ago during Richard M. Nixon's Saturday night massacre, has been chosen to serve as President Ford's Ambassador to London,

title: DEMOCRATS IN AREA GET KEY HOUSE JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Thirteen Democrats from the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area, who will sit in the new Congress, were named by the party leadership to seats on major committees.

title: ITALY'S NEWSMEN START A WALKOUT
description: ROME, Dec. 13Italian journalists went on strike today in a nationwide action that will leave the country without newspapers for much of next week.

title: Kissinger Urges Accord By U.S. and France on Oil
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the differences between the United States and France over how to negotiate with oilproducing countries could be reconciled when Presidents Ford and Valry Giscard d'Estaing met in Martinique his weekend.

title: Woodall of Jets Getting Tired Of Playing the Waiting Game
description: For six football seasons, Al Woodall has dressed next to Joe Narnath, making him the envy of Namath groupies everywhere. For six football seasons, Woodall has played behind Joe Namath, making him the envy of no quarterbacks anywhere.

title: Braves Victors on Late Surge, 108 to 104
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 13  The Knicks, with an opportunity to take first place in the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division, wasted a splendid opportunity by going scoreless for more than six minutes in the final quarter tonight, enabling the Buffalo Braves to rally for a 108104 triumph at Memorial Auditorium.

title: RUTGERS ADOPTS AUSTERITY POLICY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 13Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers University, presented a series of austerity measures to meet a projected $7.2million budget deficit here for the 197475 fiscal year.

title: Strip Mine Curbs Voted In House in Face of Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The House of Representatives gave final approval today to a bill that would curb the most flagrant environmental abuses of strip mining for coal, but President Ford announced that he would veto it.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: . . . and Criminal Injustice
description: The criminal justice system of the State of New York is proceeding against a man named Daniel Carranza. It may even bring him to trial. Considering Mr. Carranza's confessed criminal history and his own story of his involvements with the police and prosecutors, it might be more appropriate if the criminal justice system itself were in the dock.

title: U.S. Official Voices Concern on Rights of Chileans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Assistant Secretary of State for InterAmerican Affairs said today that the question of human rights under the military government in Chile should be divorced from other issues in relations with that country.

title: LOTTERY
Article 3  No Title
description: SINGLES

title: Nyquist Is Concerned Over City U. Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY, Dec. 13The State Commissioner of Education expressed concern today over the possible effects of the cuts in the City University's budgetunder Mayor Beanie's austerity program.

title: Rescued Man Accused
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP)  A 23yearold man rescued from the second floor of a burning building was charged today with having burglarized the building before setting it afire. Detectives identified him as James Allen.

title: Republicans Plan to Combat Decline; Public Relations Hustle Is Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Mary Louise Smith, the Repub lican National Chairman, who says her party has a hard time communicating what it stands for, held another news conference today to explain plans to a $2million advertising campaign next year.

title: If You're Planning a Big Party, Here's a List of Caterers
description: Alfredo's Tavola Calda, 285 Bleecker Street, opening Christmas week, 9244789.

title: Pincay Sets Mark In Earnings for '74
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP)Laffit Pincay Jr., with a victory in the third race here yesterday, broke his own world record for money won by a jockey in a single year of thoroughbred racing.

title: 12 Go to Harvard To Study for Jobs In New Congress
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13Exuding youthful optimism and sincerity, the freshman class arrived at Harvard this week for orientation, but there was not a student among them.

title: 4 SUGAR REFINERS AGAIN CUT PRICES
description: Four of the nation's largest sugar refiners yesterday announced price reductions in grocery and industrial sugar. The new approximate 4centsapound reduction is the third price cut in sugar in about two weeks. The refiners are the Amstar Corporation, the Sucrest Corporation, the CPC International Corporation and the National Sugar Refining Company. The combined price reductions since the first one Dec. 2 bring the total reduction to about 13 cents a pound. The pricing actions reflect price declines in raw sugar in nine recent trading sessions on the commodity market. But raw sugar prices moved up slightly yesterday.

title: Egyptian Demands Israeli Ban On Immigration for 50 Years
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13Egypt's Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, declared today that Israel must freeze her present level of population and suspend immigration for the next 50 years if she wanted peace in the Middle East.

title: Text of Communique of NATO Foreign Ministers
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13 (Reuters)Following is the text of the communiqu issued by foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at the end of their twoday meeting here:

title: Kennedy Named Pilot
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP)John Kennedy was named today as manager of the WinstonSalem (N.C.) Red Sox. A Boston Red Sox infielder since 1970, Kennedy completed 10 years in the major leagues last September.

title: CITY INSISTS ON CUT IN HOSPITAL STAFF
description: Mayor Beam has told the presidents of the Health and Hospitals Corporation that 551 provisional jobs will still have to be cut from the corporation's payroll, despite a vote to the contrary by the corporation's board on Thursday, an official close to the president, Dr. John L. S. Holleman, said yesterday.

title: PornographicFilm Piracy Believed Disclosed Here
description: A new nationwide organizedcrime racket involving the pirating of major pornography films has come to light, according to police experts, with the arrest here of a film processor on charges of possessing a stolen negative and sound track of The Life and Times of Xaviera Hollander.

title: Questions and Answers on City's Bonds
description: Yields on New York City bonds climbed yesterday to their highest levels in recent financial history, municipal bond dealers reported.

title: Abductor's Return Pushed As Boy Relaxes at Home
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13Sevenyearold George Kalayerakis Jr. played happily with his younger sister, Brenda, and his mother in Rutherford today as Federal officials here made arrangements to bring his abductora friend of the child'sfrom Miami Beach for a bail hearing tomorrow.

title: Raspberries Band Offers Poppourri At the Bottom Line
description: Raspberries berries is a, young rock band whose four members come mostly from Cleveland. They didn't make much of an impact until this year, after two former members were replaced. But their fourth album, produced by Jimmy Ienner, has attracted a lot of attention, and Thursday night they opened s fournight run at the Bottom Line, their first New York appearances since the personnel changes.

title: MURPHY IS ELECTED BY NEWSPAPER GUILD
description: Thomas P. Murphy, the sect and vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York, was chosen president or the guild last night in its first contested election in 24 years.

title: City's Forced Retirements May Be Illegal, U.S. Says
description: The Federal Government warned the city yesterday that it might be violating an antidiscrimination law if it went ahead with its proposal to force 869 municipal workers 63 to 65 years old to retire before the mandatory retirement age of 65, to save the jobs of the same number of younger employes.

title: MARGOT B. HIGGINS
description: Margot Brill Higgins, an editor for the American Heritage Publishing Company'S book division, died yesterday on her birthday in childbirth in New York Hospital. She was 34 years old and lived at 122 East 82d Street.

title: Weeping With Nixon, Up and Down
description: Although Jesus wept, American politicians do not. When one of them violates the protocol, the event is so extraordinary that newspapers report it on front pages and television records it with the gravity due mysterious fireballs in the sky and diabolism in City Hall.

title: SAVINGS BANKERS HIT CHECKACCOUNT RULE
description: Savings bankers voiced disappointment yesterday over a state court ruling denying them the right to offer customers checking privileges  widely known as NOW accounts but forecast ultimate victory through the courts.

title: Japanese Save 35 in Grew
description: TOKYO, Dec. 13 (AP)  A Japanese tugboat today rescued all 35 crewmen from the sinking freighter Sacramento Venture 1,100 miles east of Japan; the Maritime Safety Agency reported. The 11,151ton freighter had developed a leak during a storm.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: New Hope in Rhodesia
description: Less than a week after the seeming collapse of a hopeful negotiation, the news out of Rhodesia is again highly encouraging: an agreed ceasefire between Rhodesian forces and African liberation fighters, the release by the white minority regime bf all African political prisoners including the two most prominent leaders, and the scheduling of a blackwhite conference to, discuss a new Constitution without preconditions.

title: 2D AVE, SUBWAY FACES NEW DELAY
description: Mayor Beame yesterday proposed a sixyear transitconstruction program providing no further money for the Second Avenue subway, but emphasizing instead the completion of new Queens trunk lines and modernizing the city's existing subway system.

title: House Votes Extra Airline Aid Benefiting Pan Am and T.A.T.W.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The House passed a bill tonight that may provide as much as $100million a year in extra revenue to United States airlines that operate internationally, mainly Pan American and Trans World Airlines. The vote was 221 to 54.

title: A Hurdle Is Removed for Cards' Sprinter
description: The axing tactic that used to frustrate wide receivers has been cut out of pro football this season, and no one is more relieved than Mel Gray.

title: Open Interest
description: Friday, Dec. 13, 1974 (in bushels, 000 omitted)

title: CROWDS CURBED IN SOUTH BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity banned today any gathering within 100 yards of racially troubled South Boston High School and prohibited the use of racial epithets on school grounds.

title: Ford to Abide by Law Barring Tapes to Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)President Ford has indicated he will accept the will of Congress to nullify his agreement that granted former President Richard M. Nixon custody of his Presidential tapes and papers.

title: People in Sports
description: Coach Tom Nissalke of the San Antonio, Spurs was discharged yesterday for conduct detrimental to the franchise of the American Basketball Association club. The announcement mentioned no specific comments or actions on the part of Nissalke.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: WINETALK
description: Did you know that the best time of day to taste wine is around 10 A.M.? And that the worst time is late in the afternoonwhen most wine tastings are held?

title: T.W. A., COCACOLA PARIS BOMB TAGETS
description: PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Bombs exploded early today outside Trans World Airlines and CocaCola offices here.

title: Police Believe 2 Daughters Have Joined Fugitive Father
description: MIDDLETOWN, Dec. 13 (AP) A former electronicscompany executive, Allen Abrahams, who escaped from a state prison farm last Dec. 4, has appatently persuaded his two daughters to share, his fugitive life, the police in this Monmouth County township said yesterday.

title: C. GEORGE WEBSTER.
description: C. George Webster, former head of the New York agency of the Bank of Nova Scotia and that bank's affiliates in the United States, died Wednesday at his home in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 67 years old and formerly lived in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Byrne Unable to Get Court To Reveal Plan on Taxes
description: TRENTON, Dec. 13  The State Supreme Court, declining to tip its hand refused today to tell Governor Byrne and the Legislature what it would do if they failed to enact a new system of financing public schools in New Jersey.

title: Fred Perkins, 84, Covered Labor for ScrippsHoward
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP)  Fred W. Perkins, a retired labor reporter for ScrippsHoward newspapers, died Wednesday. He was 84 years old and had been living in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: 5 Missing on Kodiak Flight
description: KODIAK, Alaska, Dec. 13 (UPI)An airplane carrying five persons and a corpse disappeared on a flight from Kodiak Island to the town of Kodiak on Wednesday. A search for the craft yesterday was unsuccessful. The craft had been chartered to transport the body of a drowning victim from the island to Kodiak.

title: NATO and Economic Troubles
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13For the first time in the history of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a meeting of the alliance's foreign ministers focused on economic troubles as the greatest danger to their countries.

title: OPEC Communique Text
