description: VIENNA, Dec. 13 (AP)Following is the text of the communiqu issued by the ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries after their twoday session ended today:

title: RCA States 3Week Layoff
description: HARRISON, Dec. 13 (AP)The RCA Corporation has announced a threeweek layoff of about 1,500 workers at its electronics  components plant here, starting next Monday. Company officials said yesterday that the layoff would last until Jan, 6 and would cost workers 14 working days.

title: CAREY SAYS STATE FACES '75 DEFICIT AS CRISIS LOOMS
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey yesterday raised for the first time the possibility that the state, like the city, faced a deficit in the current fiscal year, and he described the situation as the harshest government crisis since the Great Depression.

title: Ford Is Ready to Sign All on Drinking Water
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)President Ford has decided to sign legislation approved by Congress to impose the first Federal standards for home drinking water, his chief spokesman said today.

title: F. McGuire, Carlen Get Dietzel Job
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 13 (UPI)The University of South Carolina hired Jim Carlen of Texas Tech as head football coach today, removed the former coach, Paul Dietzel, as athletic director and upgraded the position of Frank McGuire, the basketball coach, in a massive internal shuffle.

title: Fordham Bows to Kansas
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 13 Kansas blew an 11point halftime lead but regained control to defeat Fordham, 7874, in the Jayhawk Basketball Classic tonight.

title: Each WFL Owner Told to Post $750, 000 by '75
description: The World Football League approved a reorganization plan yesterday in a stormy meeting here, and reportedly called upon any owner who intends to operate in 1975 to post $750,000 before the end of 1974.

title: Chief Domestic Adviser To President Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)Kenneth R. Cole Jr., a holdover from the Nixon Administration who said he was exhausted, submitted his resignation today as President Ford's chief domestic adviser.

title: Vassar to Close AllBlack Dormitory
description: Vassar College has decided to close Kendrick House, its allblack student dormitory, rather than face an expensive and what it views as an almost inevitably losing court fight with the State Education Department, which has charged that the dormitory violates anisegregation laws.

title: Chilean Soldier Is Killed In a Gunfight With Leftists
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 13 (AP)Leftist extremists shot and killed an army corporal during a gunfight in downtown Santiago early today, the armed forces announced.

title: 2 Sides in Bitter Strike Give No Quarter
description: KENSINGTON, Conn. Words like goon and scab may now seem merely the hollow echoes of labor's turbulent past, but to both sides in a bitter 14month strike here, those words are as packed with emotion as they were during the big labor battles of the nineteenthirties.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Dec. 14, 1974 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Siate Court Condemns Nadjari Methods
description: By a 3to2 vote, a state appeals court yesterday upheld the indictment of the United States Customs Court Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. but at the same times condemned Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, for the illegal, outrageous and intolerable methods used in gathering evidence in the case.

title: SAUDIS REASSURE BRITAIN ON POUND
description: LONDON, Dec. 13British and Saudi Arabian officials offered assurances today that Saudi Arabia was not considering a major liquidation of her sterling investments.

title: 8 Slated For Race At Big A
description: Two starters in this afternoons 36th running of the Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct will be seeking Victory No. 2 in the 1thmile event as eight thoroughbreds are schedduled to compete for a purse of $55,900. The winner, if all get to the starting gate, ill collect $33,540. The two seeking Gallent Foz doubles will be Elmendorf's Big Spruce and Mrs. Nelson Asiel's Crafty Khale. The ElMendorf colorbearer, topweighted with 126 pounds, captured the event last year. Mrs. Asiel's hopeful was named the winner in 1972 after the disqualification of Autobiography.

title: Major Oil Companies Are Seen in a Price Squeeze
description: VIENNA, Dec. 13  The squeeze is on the major oil companies, whose costs for oil have risen as a result of to= day's pricing decision by the 13nation, Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Senate, voting 77 to 4, approved the Administration's sweeping foreign trade bill after adopting a provision authorizing trade concessions for the Soviet Union in return for freer Soviet emigration policies, particularly as they affect Jews. The bill, which has been in Congress for 20 months, prepares the way for major new international trade negotiations planned for next year. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Egyptian Demands Israeli Ban On Immigration for 50 Years
description: CAIRO, Dec. 13Egypt's Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, declared today that Israel must freeze her present level of population and suspend immigration for the next 50 years if she wanted peace in the Middle East.

title: Cleaning Woman In Mayor's Office Will Keep Her Job
description: Dust rag in one hand and vacuum cleaner in the other, Mrs. Myorier Boykin worked quietly in Mayor Beame's City Hall office as usual last night, whisking the red carpet, wiping the ashtrays and the mantlepiece and trying to ignore all the fuss about her.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Famous Name Furniture at low unmentionable prices

title: Dr. David Kreuz, 30, Dies; Psychiatrist at Clinic Here
description: Dr. David S. Kreuz, assistant psychiatrist at the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic of New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, died Tuesday in New York Hospital. He was 30 years old and lived here.

title: New York Vs. Jersey In Garden Pair Tonight
description: Manhattan gets another chance tonight in Madison Square Garden when the Jaspers face an old rival, St. Peter's in the first game of the college basketball doubleheader. The game is scheduled to start at 7 o'clock.

title: Reasonable Probability
description: The cases of Rubin Carter and John Artis demonstrate that it can be pretty hard to obtain a new trial in New Jersey. The only eyewitnesses to link them to the triple murder for which they were convicted in 1967 have now sworn that they lied when they did so. Nevertheless, Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Lamer, who tried the case in the first place, has denied them a new trial because he did not believe the witnesses' recantations.

title: EDWIN M. STERN SR.
description: Edwin M. Stern Sr., chairman of the board of Stern & Stern Textiles, Inc., died yesterday in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 78 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: COURT CONDEMNS NADJARI METHODS
description: By a 3to2 vote, a state appeals court yesterday upheld the indictment of Judge Paul P. Rao Sr., of the United States Customs Court, but at the same time condemned Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecuter, for the illegal, outrageous and intolerable methods used in gathering evidence in the case.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 3.8% From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 216.9 from 220.7 last week.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Treasury announced yesterday it would sell $2billion of twoyear notes on Dec. 23 in a refinancing that does not call for raising any additional new cash.

title: 10085 Triumph Over Stars Is No. 7 in Row
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 13  Moses Malone, Utah's 6foot11 inch high school recruit, paid his second visit to the Nassau Coliseum tonight, swept the boards for a gamehigh 21 rebounds and put in 18 points to tie Ron Boone as the Stars' high scorer. But the New York Nets managed to win the game, 10085.

title: U.S., in a Major Policy Switch, Offers Portugal Economic Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The United States, in a major policy decision, announced today that it was launching an economic aid program for the new Government of Portugal as a positive demonstration of United States support and confidence in Portugal's future.

title: Informer in Court Offers Items Taken In a Separate Case
description: A 22yearold police informer who says that he has confessed to more than 100 crimes and who is a defendant in an armed robbery case arrived in court yesterday with some loot from a 1973 burglary and briefly created some consternation.

title: REED HADLEY DEAD; RED RYDER ON RADIO
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (AP) Reed Hadley, the actor who played Red Ryder on radio during the nineteenforties and then went on to star in a number of television series, died Wednesday of a heart attack. His age was 63.

title: THOMAS H. CARROLL
description: Thomas H Carroll, who retired in 1967 as managing partner of the Philadelphia office of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., accountants, died in Philadelphia on Monday. He was 69 years old.

title: 10DAY VOLUME FOR NEW CARS OFF
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13The auto industry's sales slump continued this month, with new car deliveries off 28.8 per cent in the Dec: 110 period:

title: Laser Beam Device Detects Air Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Traces of air pollution can be detected at considerable distances with a laser beam directed by an instrument patented this week for the Allied Chemical Corporation. Joseph J. Barrett, a staff physicist in the materials research center at Morristown, N. J., was granted Patent 3,853,404.

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor: It may be overoptimistic to seek a solution to our nation's current problems that will, at the same time, combat inflation, recession and unemployment. There may be such a solution, but it calls for a spirit of unity, selfsacrifice and subordination of individual selfishness to the, higher good of the community. Above all, it calls for the example to be set from above.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in EasternSterldard Time
description: Today, Dee. 14

title: Hans Bethe Urges U.S. Drive for Atom Power and Coal
description: Dr. Hans A. Bethe, the noted physicist, believes that Americans must cut down their growing dependence on foreign sources of energy by mounting an intensive drive to build nuclear power plants and to double coal output within 10 years.

title: Dow Off 3.60; Motorola and Xerox Fall
description: Prices closed lower yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Several glamour issues, including Motorola and Xerox, turned weak during the course of a lackluster day. Trading volume was light.

title: Soviet Helps Mongolia Shed Feudalism
description: ULAN BATOR, MongoliaThe flat brown prairie that stretches away into a rim of low mountains could be Montana or perhaps Wyoming. But the city set in a tidy grid that straddles the gravel banks of the Tola River bears the unmistakable spare, squat look of any growing Soviet provincial town.

title: Notes on People Betty Ford Cancels Her Martinique Trip
description: Betty Ford has suffered a recurrence of osteoarthritis, an ailment that has caused her periodic discomfort in the back and neck for 12 years, and will be unable to accompany President Ford to Martinique today for his meeting with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France.

title: UTILITIES' PRIORITY IN GAS CASE UPHELD
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 (UPI)A Federal appeals court declined today to review its ruling giving utility plants priority over other industries seeking scarce supplies of natural gas.

title: Ballet Feld's Consort
description: Eliot Feld's ballet The Consort has already gone through two manifestations, the first in Brooklyn for Mr. Feld's own company and the second in Stockholm for the Royal Swedish Ballet, which presented it here only last month.

title: Factory Output Falls
description: The nationwide coal strike and slumping automobile production dealt the nation's industrial output in November its most crippling blow of any month in more than four years, the Government reported yesterday. Page 39.

title: Nastase Crushes Newcombe
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 14 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania gained his fourth consecutive spot in the final of the Grand Prix Masters Tennis Tournament with a straightset victory today over John Newcombe of Australia.

title: Music: Glittering Ravel
description: Pierre Boulez returned to the podium of the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night after an eightweek absence, and as usual the orchestra took on a clean and gleaming sound under its music director. Mr. Boulez has the ear and the persistence to insure that the orchestra produces the most lucid sound it is capable of and Ruth Laredo benefited from that tremendously in her debut with the orchestra.

title: Rangers' LineUp
description: AT ST. LOUIS

title: Giants Become Drillers
description: LAFAYETTE, La. (UPI)The old Amarillo Giants of the Texas baseball league have been renamed the Lafayette Drillers in their new home city.

title: 17 Jobs Are Open but 100 Apply At CityLayoff Referral Center
description: The Job Referral Center, which was established last week by Mayor Beame to help find positions for dismissed city employes, had received more than 100 applications by yesterday but only 17 job openings offered by private industries.

title: Chief Says Air Force Cuts $300Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Gen. David C. Jones, the Force Chief of Staff, said today the Air Force would save $300million annually through reduction of headquarters, including elimination of private planes assigned to top commanders.

title: City Gets Liens Against Scofflaws
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau obtained liens yesterday against the homes or other real estate of parkingviolations scofflaws in an intensified dirve to collect $100million in outstanding fines.

title: Big Housing Project Resisted in Poconos
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa.The Aumnonthold zoning board of the Borough of Mount Pocono, hearing its first case, is embroiled in a classic confrontation between a wouldbe housing developer and opponents who want to preserve the environment.

title: Hans Bethe Urges U.S. Drive for Atom Power and Coal
description: Dr. Hans A. Bethe, the noted physicist, believes that Americans must cut clown their growing dependence an foreign sources of energy by mounting an intensive drive to build nuclear power plants and to double coal output within 10 years.

title: MILK STRIKE PACT BEING COMPLETED
description: Officials of the milk industry and striking employes met yesterday to complete the language of a tentative agreement that will be presented to the union's membership today.

title: Status of Ocean Grove Voided As Separate Municipal Entity
description: FREEHOLD, Dec. 13A Monmouth County Superior Court judge, responding to the plea of a man who wants the freedom to deliver newspapers, today declared unconstitutional the state law that permits religious organizations to establish communities functioning as municipalities.

title: Piggyback in Jersey
description: By the notsoartful dodge of amending Governor Byrne's proposed state income tax to make it a 'piggyback state levy on the Federal income tax, the New Jersey Senate has taken a timorous step toward solution of the state's deepening fiscal crisis. Considering, the Senate's record of stubborn resistance to an income tax. in any guise, Thursday's 16to15 vote for the Federal tax surcharge represents real progress.

title: Safety Board Sets Hearing On Crash of T.W.A Jetliner
description: The official public hearing on the recent crash of a Trans World Airlines jet near Washington, D.C., will open on Jan. 27, the National Transportation Safety Board announced yesterday.

title: MADELINE S. HOFFMAN
description: Madeline S. Hoffmann, a society figure here and in Chicago and Los Angeles, died.Thursday at Lenox Hills Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived at 136 East 76th Street.

title: Milk CoOp Resignations Held Unrelated to Scandal
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex, Dec 13 (AP)The new general manager of Associated Milk Producers, Inc., insisted today that a management shakeup (nothing the dairy cooperative had nothing to do with investigations of the milk fund scandals.

title: Dr. E. Vincent Askey Dies at 70; President of A.M.A. in 196061
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 13 (UPI)Dr. E Vincent Askey, president of the. American Medical Association in 196064, died Wednesday. He was 70 years old.Surviving are his widow, Martha, two sons and a daughter.

title: Israeli Guns Shell a Town in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 13Israeli artillery shelled the southern Lebanese town of Nabatiye early today, wounding 10 people, the Government announced.

title: CLOUDS HERE MAR ECLIPSE VIEWING
description: With the most populous parts of both the eastern and westem United States largely clouded over, yesterday's partial eclipse of the sun was a disappointment for many looking at it.

title: Toros End Streak In Overtime, 76
description: TORONTO, Dec. 13 (AP)Tom Martin's powerplay goal in overtime game the Toronto Toros to a 76 World Hockey Association victory over the Cleveland Crusaders tonight.

title: SENATE APPROVES O.E.O. EXTENSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Senate approved legislation today that would extend the life of the Office of Economic Opportunity  the antipoverty agencythrough next September and possibly beyond.

title: Each WFL Owner Told to post $750,000 by '75
description: The World Football League approved a reorganization plan yesterday in a stormy meeting here, and reportedly called upon any owner who intends to operate in 1975 to post $750,000 before the end of 1974.

title: The Dance John Jones's Nocturne
description: Nocturne, a solo by John Jones, was presented by the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater on Thursday night at the City Center as the company's sole world premiere of the season.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PROS It's a minor but distinct pleasure to watch a small, plucky theater company giving life to a bulky, overlong French play that already flopped here twice, on and oft Broadway. Just why members of the Floating Theater elected to tackle Jean Anouilh's eccentric, threehour conversation piece, Romeo and Jeannette, is their business. So is theater. They bring the play off.

title: British Leaders Plan Visits
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 13 (Reuters) Prime Minister. Harold Wilson of Britain and Foreign Secretary James Callaghan will visit Washington at the end of January for talks with President Ford and will visit Moscow later, an official British source said.

title: Malta Cuts Tie to British Crown and Gets a President
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 13 (Reuters)Malta became a republic tonight when. the Governor General, Sir Anthony Mamo, was sworn in as her first President.

title: SENATE APPROVES TRADE BILL GIVING BENEFIT TO SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Senate approved the Administration's sweeping foreign trade bill tonight by 77 votes to 4 after adopting a provision to authorize trade concessions, for the Soviet Union in return for freer Soviet emigration policies, particularly as they affect Jews.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Higher cash prices for soybean meal and soybean oil, based on export demand, encouraged a price rise in soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: CLARENCE T. MANNING
description: Clarence T. Manning, a retired vice president and director of the Reynolds Metals Company, died Tuesday at his home in Richmond. He was 75 years old.

title: Richardson to Be Named As Ambassador to Britain
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Elliot L. Richardson, who resigned as Attorney General 14 months ago during Richard. M. Nixon's Saturday night massacre, has been chosen to serve as President Ford's Ambassador to London.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A major machinetool company in New Jersey, accused by the United States Labor Department of discriminating against women employes, agreed to repay amounts up to $1,200 that they allegedly lost because of the discrimination.

title: EXG.O.P. OFFICIAL INDICTED UPSTATE
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 13A former Republican city chairman was indicted today on charges that he bilked county taxpayers out of more than $400,000 while serving as insurance adviser to the Niagara Country Legislature.

title: 3 Nobel Laureates Criticize UNESCO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13Three Nobel laureates met with Secretary General Waldheim today to protest what they called the corruption of UNESCO by recent discriminatory actions against Israel at the agency's recent Paris conference.

title: TALLAHASSEE SUED BY U.S. OVER JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 The Justice Department announced today that it had filed a civil suit against the city officials of Tallahassee, Fla., charging them with discrimination against black job applicants and employes.

title: Nuptials of Sally H. Stevenson And Karl H Fischer Are Held
description: Sally Hopkins Stevenson, daughter of. Mr. and Mrs. John R. Stevenson of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Karl H. Fischer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gunter P. Fischer of Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Red Cross Visits Selassie, Other Ethiopian Detainees
description: GENEVA, Dec. 13Four delegates of the International Committee of the Red Cross visited Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia where he is being held under arrest in the grounds of a palace in Addis Ababa, the privete Swiss humanitarian agency announced today.

title: U.N. Security Council Extends Mandate of Force in Cyprus
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 13The Security Council today extended the mandate of the United Nations force in Cyprus for another six months, and urged the parties involved to act with the utmost restraint.

title: WIFE SAYS SOVIET DOOMED EMIGRANT
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (AP)A Soviet Jew who received permission to emigrate to Israel has been sentenced to death on charges of taking bribes, his wife said today.

title: Sides in Bitter Strike Give No Quarter
description: KENSINGTON, Conn.Words like goon and scab may now seem merely the hollow echoes of labor's turbulent past, but to both sides in a bitter 14month strike here, those words are as packed with emotion as they were during the big labor battles of the nineteenthirties.

title: Henri de Monfried, 95, Dies; Adventurer Wrote.60 Books
description: PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP)Henri de Monfried, French adventurer and the author of some 60 books, died today at his home at Ingrandes in westcentral France. He was 95 years old.

title: Arab Princes Described as HighStakes Gamblers
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 13 (UPI)Members of the Arab royalty, accompanied by bodyguards and food tasters, are reported to be gambling wildly at the casinos these days, with $2,000 bets on the turn of a card or roll of the dice.

title: Art: How a Pop Talent Evolved
description: The exhibition of drawings and prints by the English painter David Hackney, currently occupying two floors at Knoedler's 21 East 70th Street, offers an interesting case history in the evolution of a talent. It also illuminates certain changes in the recent history of taste. Mr. Hockney is, at the age of 37, an artist with a large following on both sides of the Atlantic, yet he is not in any sense a really big artist. What, then, does his great appeal consist of?

title: The Democrats: Not Quite UptoDate in Kansas City
description: WASHINGTONIt may be viewed by some as sacrilege to shatter the aura of good feeling, the sepuchral sanctity of unity that seemed to envelope the Democratic party in the wake of its midterm convention in Kansas City..

title: Dave Anderson
description: The accountants who control Madison Square Garden have been threatening to abandon boxing except for certified spectaculars that will generate a generous bottom line. Oldtimers argue that the Garden was established on boxing. But that was half a century ago. Oldtimers remember when Friday night at the Garden was fight night. But that was 10 and 20 and 30 years ago. Friday night at the Garden is music night now. Stevie Wonder was there a week ago, Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons were there last night, George Harrison will be there next Friday night. In concert, not in satin trunks. And upstairs the accountants don't have to search for an excuse anymore to abandon boxing except for the spectaculars. Boxing has indicted itself. Sooner or later, it usually does. For the third time in four months, a riot developed last Monday night in the Garden's finished basement, the Felt Forum, after an unpopular verdict. The rioters protested in Spanish because Pedro Soto, from Puerto Rico, had lost a unanimous 10round decision to Mike Quarry, the California light heavyweight. The rioters also protested in Spanish the two previous times.

title: Music: IstominSternRose Returns
description: It seems almost yesterday but it has been almost 15 years since Isaac Stern, Leonard Rose and Eugene Istomin banded together to make music. Since then they have explored a good deal of the literature for Violin, cello and piano, playing it with the finesse expected of three such virtuosos. Last night in Carnegie Hall, before an adoring audience, the IstominSternRose Trio (so the program gave the order of priority) played Mozart, Beethoven and Mendelssohn in their usual high style.

title: Contract on Tocks Let
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) U. R. S. MadiganPrager Inc., of New York, has been awarded a $1,150,000 contract by the United States Army Corps of Engineers to conduct a study of the proposed Tocks Island Dam and reservoir on the Delaware River, it was announced today by the office of Senator Cliffor P. Case.

title: State Association for Retarded Says Carey Reneged on Program
description: The State Association for Retarded Children accused Governorelect Hugh L. Carey yesterday of backing down from his campaign pledge to separate programs for the mentally retarded from the Department of Mental Hygiene.

title: ROCKEFELLER VOTE FACES DELAY PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Despite the widespread view that Nelson A. Rockefeller's confirmation as Vice President is an allbutaccomplished fact, several members of the House of Representatives plan lastminute attempts, to stall approval until the new Congress convenes.

title: ISSUES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices again closed mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the fourth consecutive session. In the overthecounter market, prices were lower. Trading rose in both markets.

title: Bridge:
description: The best individual effort at the European Championships in Tel Aviv last month was by Benito Bianchi of Italy. He came close to pulling his relatively inexperienced team through to victory with a performance that was virtually flawlessif one discpunts the lastday cause clbre when he was forced to play by candlelight and mistook dummy's heart queen for the king.

title: Brazil's Inflation Said to Halve Real, Income of Poor in Decade
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 13The Leal family has given up fruits and vegetables and eats meat of inferior grade, but only on Sundays.

title: Rutgers Adopts Austerity Plan To Meet a Deficit of $7.2Million
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 13Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers University, presented a series of austerity measures to meet a projected $7.2million budget deficit here for the 197475 fiscal year.

title: Public Advocate Allowed In PrivateBeach Case
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 13Judge Edward V. Martino of Burlington County Superior Court ruled today that the state public advocate may intervene iita case that seeks, to open privately owned Atlantic Ocean beaches to the public.

title: Welcome To the Club,Boys
description: PARISNineteen seventyfour may conceivably be known in history less for such political sensations as President Nixon's resignation under fire, the Portuguese revolution and restoration of democracy to Greece than for the fact that this was the year when the United Nations Security Council lost all pretensions to control the spread of nuclear arms.

title: JAMES R. SLOANE
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP)James R. Sloane, president of the Berkshire Bank and Trust Company here, died of a heart attack last night. He was 55 years old.

title: Yosemite Plan Is Rejected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13The National Park Service said today that it had rejected its own master plan for Yosemite National Park because the plan and its accompanying environmental impact statement have been found to be deficient in several respects, and because there had been insufficient public participation in their formation.

title: Modest Contributions To the Neediest Add Up
description: It was only a modest contribution, Wrote Patricia MacManus of Manhattan, but in sending a $30 check to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Miss MacManus expressed a thought that is on the mind of many donors.

title: Ski Conditions
description: PENNSYLVANIA

title: U.S. Money Supply Up $2.5Billion in Week
description: The nation's money supply averaged $285.8billion in the week ended Dec. 4, up $2.5billion from the preceding week, the Federal Reserve Board xeported yesterday.

title: CAREY SAYS STATE FACES '75 DEFICIT AS CRISIS LOOMS
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey yesterday raised for the first time the possibility that the state, like the city, faced a deficit in the current fiscal year and he described the situation as the harshest government crisis since the Great Depression

title: In Switch, Nassau Panel Agrees To Accept Proposed Budget as Is
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 12The Republican majority on the Nassau County Board of Supervisors reversed itself today and said it would adopt the budget proposed by the County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, without change.

title: Factory Output Falls
description: The nationwide coal strike and slumping automobile production dealt the nation's industrial output In November its most crippling blow of any month in more than four years, the Government reported yesterday. Page 39.

title: Bullets' Rally Beats Celtics, 10889
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP)Elvin Hayes and Mike Riordan moved Washington into a 9point lead at the end of three quarters tonight and the Bullets went on to a 10889 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: U.S., in a Major Policy Switch, Offers Portugal Economic Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The United States, in a major policy decision, announced today that it was launching an economic aid program for the new Government of Portugal as a positive demonstration of United States support and confidence in Portugal's future.

title: A scholarly HomemakerFather Studies Others Like Himself
description: James Levine answered the door of his Park Slope home the other day with a bright green canvas baby sling bouncing against his stomach. Out of it hung one tiny flannel  wrapped arm and a small dark head. They belonged to Joshua Levine, 19 days old and the younger child of Mr. Levine and his wife, Joan. Upstairs, 4yearold Jessica was just finishing the lunch her father had prepared for her. Her mother was out for the morning, taking a class in creative writing.

title: Bronx Man Guilty Of Mother's Killing And Theft of $130
description: A 32yearold man from the Bronx has been convicted of killing his mother two years ago after she refused to give him $132.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Boy Sentenced to Death
description: FORT PIERCE, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)  A 16yearold boy convicted as an adult in the firstdegree murder of a 12yearold girl faces execution. The death sentence for George Thomas Vasil was recommended yesterday by a Circuit Court jury. Judge Wallace Sample accepted the recommendation. The boy was accused of the Sept. 14 strangulation of Pamela Vassar.

title: RedEye Special
description: When Gerald R. Ford was minority floor leader in the House of Representatives, he was indefatigable in making speeches around the country at political banquets and fundraising functions for his colleagues in the Republican party. To get back to Washington for the next day's business in the House he often had to take latenight or allnight flights from distant parts of the countryjourneys known among heavily traveled politicians and businessmen as redeye specials.

title: Modest Contributions To the Neediest Add Up
description: It was only a modest contribution, wrote Patricia MacManus of Manhattan, but in sending a $30 check to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Miss MacManus expressed a thought that is on the mind of many donors.

title: SIR EDWARD MAUFE, CHURCH ARCHITECT
description: LONDON, Dec. 13Sir Edward Maufe, the architect of Guildford Cathedral, one of the most modern in Britain, died yesterday, his 91st birthday.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: JEROME BELSON, know it or ant, we love you. CLI. Advtg.

title: Antiques: Carder Glass
description: Frederick Carder, the Brifishborn glass designer who died in 1963, made unparalleled achievements, mostly at the Steuben Glass Works, the concern he founded in 1903 and ruled until 1932.

title: Dye Companies Fined
description: A Federal judge yesterday levied maximum fines of $50,000 on two of the nation's largest dye manufacturing concerns for fixing prices and also fined six other companies for participation in the conspiracy. Details on Page 40.

title: Du Pont Acquisition Of Christiana Gets Approval of S. E. C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the merger of the Christiana Securities Company into E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., by an exchange of stock in which each Christiana common share would become 1.123 shares of du Pont common stock.

title: 12 Go To Harvard To Study for Jobs In New Congress
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13Exuding youthful optimism and sincerity, the freshman class arrived at Harvard this week for orientation, but there was not a student among them.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 13Not many rookie coaches inherit national caliber teams. But Dave Benjamin, Princeton University's new squash and tennis coach, is taking over a squash team that tied for the national crown last year and a tennis squad that dominated the Eastern college scene the last two seasons.

title: HARVARD BACKS GENETIC STUDY
description: A special Harvard University committee on medical research yesterday endorsed the continuation by Harvard professors of a controversial study of children with extra sex chromosomes. The study had been challenged by an independent Boston science group as unethical, unscientific and possibly harmful to the children involved.

title: Disbanding of Fire Units Is Delayed Until Monday
description: Eight fire companies that were supposed to be eliminated here today as part of Mayor Beame's austerity drive have won a twoday reprieve.

title: STEADY OIL PRICES FOR NINE MONTHS PROMISED BY OPEC
description: VIENNA, Dec. 13The major petroleumexporting countries said here today they were stabilizing world oil prices for the next nine months at about the existing Persian Gulf level.

title: Lawyers Say Army in Germany Spied on Their Work for G.I.'s
description: BONN, Dec. 13An can law firm in Heidelberg has charged that United States Army intelligence paid an American civilan to pose as a staff assistant last summer, to spy on its work defending soldiers in courtmartial cases.

title: Flyer Goal Near End Decisive
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 13 (AP)Rick MacLeish deflected a slap shot by Joe Watson into the net with 93 seconds to play tonight, giving the Philadelphia Flyers la 32 victory over the Atlanta Flames in a National Hockey League game.

title: DYE MAKERS FINED FOR FIXING PRICES
description: NEWARK, Del., Dec. 13 (UPI) A Federal judge levied maximum fines of $50,000 today on two of the nation's largest dye manufacturers for fixing prices and also fined six other companies for participating in the conspiracy.

title: Strip Mine Curbs Voted In House in Face of Veto
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13The House of Representatives gave final approval today to a bill that would curb the most flagrant environmental abuses of strip mining for coal, but President Ford announced that he would veto it.

title: Auto Repairs Outpacing Car Sales
description: DETROIT, Dec. 13  For many car dealers, the service and parts departments now have more glamour than the spiffy showroom.

title: Lyle Stops Jones
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 (AP)  Ron Lyle, the thirdranked heavyweight reported to be Muhammad Ali's next opponent, stopped Al Jones tonight at 1:43 of the fifth round.

title: Phone Rate Hearings Soon
description: ALBANY, Dec. 13 (UPI)The Public Service Commission announced today that it would begin hearing early in January on the New York Telephone Company's request for an annual rate increase of $488.8million. The hearing schedules and locations will be announce soon, the P.S.C. said.

title: Oliver H. Perry Home Burns
description: NEWPORT, R. L, Dec. 13 (AP)The Perry Mansion, the unoccupied home of Oliver Hazard Perry, a hero of the Battle of Lake Erie in 1812, was destroyed by fire today, fire officials said. A spokesman for the Newport Restoration Foundation said that the fire had not done enough damage to make restoration impossible.

title: Nastase Crushes Newcombe
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 14 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania gained his fourth consecutive spot in the final of the Grand Prix Masters Tennis Tournament with a straightset victory today over John Newcombe of Australia.

title: Police Offered: Course on Criminalistics'
description: PEMBERTON  Burlington County College and Sirchie Laboratories of Moorestown are participating in a confirming joint program under which three hours of college credit are given to those police officers who successfully complete a oneweek session of intensive training in crime detection. Entitled Criminalistics, the course is being taught by two Sirchie executives, Anthony Saggiomo and DonaldPenven.

title: Uncertainty Mounts as End of Gold Ban Nears
description: WASHINGTON  It is probably safe to assume that the great majority of Americans will not invest in gold bullion when its ownership becomes legal at the end of the year. But if this majority will have no direct stake in whether the price of gold goes up or down, it will matter to them if legalizing gold ownership somehow has an effect on the economy in general.

title: Washington Post to Reduce Its Mechanical Work Force
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Washington Post Company, citing a drop in advertising lineage for the newspaper, announced today a 20 per cent reduction in the number of guaranteed jobs in its press room.

title: Maine May Regain Scenic Wilderness In Big Land Swap
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 14The Great Northern Paper Company and the state of Maine have agreed to an exchange of land that would return to public control 58,726 acres of wilderness. In exchange, the paper company will receive 59,983 acres of public lots.

title: Oil Money for UNRWA?
description: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, charged with caring for displaced Palestinian refugees and their descendants for a quartercentury, has received a new threeyear mandate in the General Assembly Political Committee, but faces a deficit of $40 million in its $109million budget for the coming year.

title: Eugene Daniels is many kinds of outcast
description: This first novel is about the formation of the labor unions in the 1890's, a passionate and dreary episode in our history and one with obvious appeal to any lover of the melodramatic, of the largerthanlife hero or of moralizing for today. All of these temptations John Rolfe Gardiner eschews.

title: TV VIEW
description: Delving into the economics of broadcasting can be dangerous to one's mental health. On the rarified level of license renewals and record high prices for the purchasing of stations, the economic and political jockeying becomes surreal. Its effects, however, are felt on considerably more practical levels, particularly those affecting what will and what will not be included on the TV programing schedule. The inexhaustible quest to maximize profits is putting a serious crimp in the operations of producers, both at the major studios and among independents.

title: Vail, Colo., Tries to Stay Calm While It Awaits a Special Skier
description: VAIL, Colo.The pray for snow sign had been up for weeks when winter clouds finally got the message last week and dutifully dumped their first heavy loads of frozen white powder on the Alpine slopes that encase this increasingly less secluded rocky Mountain valley. Skiing started on Thanksgiving, but the new weekend snow signaled the beginning of a winter of serious play here. Jean Claude Killy and a, host of other colorfully sleek professional racers, accompanied by equally colorful and sleek females called racer chasers a phrase now preferred over ski bunnies  arrive to share the slopes with Denver families up for the weekend.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thomas Burns, accused kidnapper of 7yearold George Kaloyerakis, was returned to New Jersey from Miami yesterday in the custody of United States marshals. Mr. Burns, a neighbor of the Kaloyerakis family in Rutherford, was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigationin Miami last Wednesday and charged with kidnapping the boy from a Rutherford schoolyard on Sept. 23, and holding him for three months. Mr. Burns will be arraigned on abduction charges in Hackensack tomorrow. Mrs. Kaloyerakis said she believed George, who was returned Thursday, went with Mr. Burns willingly and considered the experience a vacation. I think they had a ball, she said.

title: Austrian Skiers Dominate Trials
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Austrians outskied the competition today in the two last practice runs before tomorrow's World Cup downhill race.

title: Warriors Fall, 9991, To Bullets
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 14 (UPI)Phil Chenier scored 29 points and Elvin Hayes 21 tonight as the Washington Bullets held off the Golden State Warriors for a 9991 victory in a clash of National Basketball Association division leaders.

title: Dave Anderson
description: After his last game as the New York Jets' coach a year ago, Weeb Ewbank wept and sniffled in the Shea Stadium locker room when Dave Herman, on behalf of the players, presented him with a gold watch. Herman had always battled Weeb the general manager in contract negotiations, as all the Jets had. But this was no time for money to intrude on the man. Hugging the pudgy little coach during that informal ceremony were Emerson Boozer and Winston Hill, each a stubborn holdout several months earlier. Herman and Boozer and Hill were, sniffling and so were most of the other players because Weeb Ewbank affects people that way. It's possible to disagree with Weeb's payroll philosophy as a general manager. But it's impossible to disrespect Weeb as a coach or to dislike him as a person. That's the Weeb to remember when he puts his hands into the pockets of his camelhair overcoat after today's game in Baltimore and puts his pro football career behind him.

title: Bouguereau Was No Foil For the Impressionists
description: Art/Visitors to the New York Cultural Center may find themselves developing a sneaking affection for a painter they have never really looked at before. (John Canaday)

title: CHESS
description: The world junior championship, while not a perfect barometer of future achievement (no one can tell when a player will level off), is still an important stepping stone in the career of a young master. Since 1951, when the series of competitions for prticipants under the age of 20 was originated, only one winner, Boris Spassky, went on to capture the senior title.

title: An Old Chestnut, Toasted To a Turn
description: I think I'd have been won over to the highly mannered revival of Dion Boucicault's 1841 London Assurance if only because of the eminently sensible attitude several of its characters take toward a thorny problem presented us by Women's Lib. Should the men at & dinner party be permitted to linger at table over wine while the ladies make do with one another? Grace Harkaway, the glistening ingenue whose pretty postures seem all to have been carved out of soap, detests the eustom and would abolish it if she could. Not so Lady Gay spanker, a matron composed of severe rectangles and a soft heart, looking in her riding costume rather as though Sarah Bernhardt had developed a fondness for shouting Yoicks! Lady Gay Spanker sees no harm in the custom, not a whit. Men, poor things, must be permitted to enjoy beir short liberty before returning to the bridles that gome with their brides. They are, as she reminds us, creatures of but an hour, and ought not be reined in too sharply for fear of damaging their delicate wings, I'm with her.

title: In Model Homes, Subtleties Abound
description: MOUNT SINAI, L. I.Model houses are, their creators insist, more honest than ever. No more mirrored walls, scaleddown furniture or lavish landscaping schemes, say the people who design and build the models. Just the truthin the best possible light, of course.

title: Cougars Sign Angotti
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP)Lou Angotti, a 10year Naearlier this season, was signed yesterday by the Chicago ey Association. Angotti, with 289 N.H.L. career points on 103 goals and 186 assists, was given a oneyear playing contract.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Title for U.C.L.A.
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 14 (AP)U.C.L.A. turned back Hawaii, 157, 158, today and won the women's national intercollegiate volleyball tournament. Cal StateSanta Barbara finished third by whipping Houston, 157, 1511.

title: South's Rising Political Stars
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 14 The rising new stars of Southern politics are a group of aggressive state attorneys genaral who are carving out repuations as leaders of the conminter and environmental movenents.

title: Each Man In His Time
description: Current biographies and autobiographies of Hollywood notables are marbled, simply marbled, with sex. If lovely women aren't ripping out bloodcurdling fourfetter words, Raoul Walsh, now 87 years of age, is telling about the canopied Napoleon bed he always slept.in on visits to San Simeon and the beautiful English countess he met there: (Raoul, San Simeon is your home, its seigneur, W. R. Hearst, had told him.)

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: JAVITS IS SILENT ON BUCKLEY CHOICE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 14Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican  Liberal, has indicated that he is displeased bus not ??urprised by the announcement by Senator James L. Buckley, New York ConservativeRepublican, that he would support Mr. Javits's conservative opponent in the contest for chairman of the Senate Republican conference. What else is new? Mr. Javits asked newsmen Thursday when they sought comment on Mr. Buckley's decision.

title: Mr. Ford's Old Friend Is a Key Man in Economic Policy
description: WASHINGTONL. William Seidman is the ultimate organization man in President Ford's White House. Or so, at least Mr. Seidman would present himself to the public.

title: Army Movie Aims to Avoid a My Lai
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) On the movie screen in an Army base theater, the figure of an officer treads slowly among the enemy wounded, their moans breaking the silence of a scarred battlefield.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Pro Basketball

title: TV for Rockefeller's Oath
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Senate voted today to allow a radio and television broadcast of Nelson A. Rockefeller's swearingin as Vice President if the ceremony is held in the Senate chamber. It would be the first telecast from inside the Senate. The House is expected to confirm the former New York Governor by the end of next week, but there was no indication where the swearing in would beheld.

title: Hugh Pollack to Marry Martha Heffner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Heffner of East Williston, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Martha Ann Heffner, to Hugh L. Pollack. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Pollack of Brooklyn.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The recent statement of the Democratic party on economic policy has advanced the important idea of combating inflation by controls on prices, and, more generally, by controls on wages, executive compensation, profits and rents. This list of items is both too comprehensive and not comprehensive enough.

title: Deer Hunt Highlights an Active Season
description: CHATHAM  The hotly contested deer hunt that was finally allowed in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge last week marked the high point of the various hunting seasons scheduled in New Jersey during the fall and winter months.

title: Susan C. Miller Wed To Dr. Barry Werner
description: Susan Carol Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin R. Miller of East. Hills, L I., was married last night to Dr. Barry M. Werner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Werner of Manhasset. Hills, L. I., and Lauderhill, Fla.

title: Fordham Sinks Temple On a Basket at Buzzer
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 14 Darryl Brown scored on a tapin at the final buzzer tonight as. Fordhatn beat Temple, 6765, to earn third place in the Jayhawk Classic.

title: After the Goat Man
description: Plain talk, moon talk and a toothless toothache

title: Southwest Conference Votes to Use. LieDetector Tests in Investigations
description: DALLAS, Dec. 14 (UPI)The Southwest Conference voted today to use liedetector tests in investigating possible league violations, It thus became the first collegiate group to take such action.

title: Drew Students Hail University's 9th President
description: MADISONWhen Dr. Paul Hardin, the 43yearold former president of Southern Methodist University, was named ninth president of Drew University here last week, The Drew Acorn, the student newspaper, put out an extra. In it, David Audretsch, a junior who served as student representative on the Search Committee, wrote:

title: Another Colt Game for Namath Today... and Another Crossroads
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 14In playing the team against which he achieved a legendary niche in professional football history, Joe Namath will make what could be his farewell appearance for the New York Jets tomorrow.

title: A Few Pertinent Questions About Finances
description: Governorselect Hugh L. Carey of New York and Ella Grasso of Connecticut campaigned on pledges to take the profiteering out of politics. They are now attempting fulfill their commitments as they search for talented people to fill upperlevel positions in the state governments, over which they'll preside beginning next month.

title: Recycling of a Con Ed Generating Plant Envisioned
description: Revised planning for redevelopment of the Sherman Creek area of tippet Manhattan envisions the renovation of the unused Consolidated Edison generating plant overlooking the Harlem River. Under earlier plans, the facility would have been demolished.

title: Alice Chase Engaged
description: Alice Shirley Chase, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Harry Eugene Chase of Tenafly, N. J., and Donald Wayne Howes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Howes of Chatham, Mass., plan to he married Jan. 18 in the Preshyterian Church of Tenafly, where the father of the bridetobe is pastor.

title: A Way to Provide Hope For a Better Tomorrow
description: Executive Vice President, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies

title: Miss Fiddler Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Fiddler of Youngstown, Ohio, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Danielle Michelle Fiddler, to Tobey W. Kaczensky of Washington, son of Mrs. Leonard P. Walsh, also of Washington, and the late Walter Kaczensky of Greenfield, Mass.

title: AirportStation PeopleMover Is Urged
description: NEWARKThe costly plan to extend the PATH transit line to Plainfield may be dropped in favor of a twopart substitute proposal that calls for the installation of, a people mover between, Newark's Pennsylvania Station and Newark Airport and the upgrading of the Jersey oral's mainline commuter route.

title: Mary Herrmann Is a Bride Here
description: Mary M. Herrmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Herrmann of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday, afternoon to Robert W. Schrijver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adolf L. Schrijver of New York and Bethel, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick Hill in St. James' Episcopal Church here.

title: COLUMBIA FACES FUND SHORTAGE
description: Columbia University, which expects to come close to a balanced budget this year for the first time in eight years, faces a projected shortage of nearly $6million in 197576 and this figure will spiral upward to $32.5million in 197980, according to several university officials.

title: Ford Aides Weigh Quick Cut Crude Oil Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Senior Administration energy planners went into seclusion at Camp David today to hammer out for President Ford recommendations on how to achieve a quick reduction in imports of crude oil.

title: U Conn Five Victor Over Rhode Island
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec. 14 (AP)Lee Otis, Wilson and Tony Hanson put in 20 points each today and Connecticut defeated Rhode Island, 8568, in a Yankee Conference basketball game.

title: A Lot of Work, But a Lot of Business, Too
description: The oilproducing states will accumulate perhaps $60billion, in surplus revenue this year, causing serious problems for the world's banking system. Margaret Reid, who covers banking and investment stories for The Financial Times of London, examines the ramifications.

title: MINE BILL BACKER SEEK TO BAR VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Sponsors of a Federal strip mine control bill opened a campaign today to persuade President Ford not to veto it and to muster enough support in Congress to override any veto.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: EDITOR: An article published last Sunday opened with the statement that New Jersey communities and industries along the Kill Van Kull, Newark Bay, Arthur Kill and Raritan Bay waterfronts must depend upon the marine companies of the New York Fire Department for protection because none have their own fireboats.

title: Curtises Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Peregrine Sacheverell Curtis of Richmond, England, on Nov. 26 in the Queen Charlotte Hospital in London. Mrs. Curtis is the former MarieAdele Smoot, daughter of Mrs. Francis LeBaron Smoot Jr. of Georgetown, Washington, and the late Mr. Smoot. The child, the couple's second son, is named William Francis. His father is regional director for SevenUp (Great Britain), Ltd.

title: Coach at Fairleigh Dickinson Also a Master of the Arts
description: TEANECKJoe Franchina is sort of a jack of all trades, master of arts.

title: MILK DELIVERIES START TOMORROW WALKOUT ENDS
description: Striking milk drivers and plant employes who had rejected a proposed settlement last Sunday ended their 11day walkout yesterday, clearing the way for the resumption of deliveries tomorrow to homes, stores and restaurants in the New York area.The vote to accept the new twoyear contract was 1,104 to604.

title: Horse Show Results
description: AT SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Miami Doctor Tunes Up For TransAtlantic Try
description: Dr. Bob Magoon, who wants to cross the Atlantic soon in his 40foot offshore powerboat, came out of a year's retirement to enter yesterday's Diplomat Ocean Classic in Miami. The race was a good tune up for U.S. 1, the boat in which the Miami Beach eye surgeon set a record of 55.4 miles all hour from Miami to New York last July. Magoon hopes to find a sponsor for an attempt at the transAtlantic record.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The NassauSuffolk Standard Metropolitan Statistical Area will no longer be among the country's fastestgrowing regions during the next five years, but its growth rate till exceed that of most of the Northeast, according to a recent analysis by Mass Muteal. Economic Se Realty Research, Inc.

title: Appeal Due in Abortion Ruling
description: TRENTONAs the Assembly prepares to vote on a measure that would bar Medicaid payments to poor women for abortions, the New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union is preparing to appeal a Superior Court decision upholding the right of private hospitals to prohibit physicians from performing abortions in their operating rooms.

title: Their Basic Support Came From the New Deal
description: The walking wounded of this recessionnow an army of six million and still growinghave a lot of crutches to lean on that were not available to the casualties of the Great Depression four decades ago. But, for all the multiplicity of new governmental and union support programs, the impact of unemployment on both the morale and living standards of its victims is no less fearsome.

title: Club Med: I Have Seen the Future; It Works
description: JULY 1, 1974: I was a lone American among 350 French men and women stampeding across the tarmac of the Bourget Airport outside Paris. My high school French (vintage '54) made no impression as I screamed my protests amid the shoving, stomping mob. I was embarked upon an odyssey of discoverysix weeks, 47,000 miles, visiting 22. European and African Club Mediterrane villages in eight nations.

title: KOREAN ASSEMBLY ERUPTS IN MELEE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 14A fight involving about 40 legislators broke Out on the floor of the National Assemblytoday after an opposition meanbee suggested that President Part Chung Hee relinquish power.

title: Children in Trouble: Salvage Them
description: The Children's Aid Society and other helping institutions make a crucial difference in the lives of needy children and their familiesthe difference between lives of hope, love, productivity and independence or lives of despair, anger, uselessness and dependence. Ultimately, since the future rests with children, the services we provide may even make the difference between this city's viability or its demise.

title: Talk Will Benefit Polish Foundation
description: SOUTH ORANGE  Two cultures will be discussed here tomorrow night, when Dr. Leon T. Blaszczyk, a professor and author, will speak on Poles in Russian Culture. The program will be held at the South Orange Library on Scotland Road, one block off South Orange Avenue, beginning at 8 o'clock.

title: Music in Review
description: Harumi Ebihara, a violinist from Tokyo who is studying with Joseph Fuchs at the Juilliard School, made her local debut Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, accompanied with unusual sensitivity by David Oei.

title: Vivian Elson Engaged To Marc Hammerman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo B. Elson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vivian R. Elsa; to Marc Z. Hammerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Hammerman of Oceanside, L. I.

title: Restic Coach of the Year
description: Joe Restic, whose Harvard team upset Yale in the season finale to tie the Ells for the Ivy League championship, has been named Eastern major college coach of the year by the New. York Football Writers Association. He will receive. the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award from the organization at the New York University Club Jan, 23.

title: PAUL BURNSIDE, 63, OF NORTON SIMON
description: Paul J. Burnside, a director of Norton Simon, Inc., and chairman of the board of Old Fitzgerald Distillery, Inc., died Friday in Garden City, L. L He was 63 years old and, lived at 6 Devereux Place, Garden City.

title: Braves and McAdoo Beat Knicks, 118102
description: Bob McAdoo, with the grace of a ballet dancer, has dazzled the Knicks with 79 points in less than a 24hour span. The Buffalo Braves' center scored 37 points yesterday afternoon in his team's 118102 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Slain Policewoman Seen Aid to Hiring Of Female Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The slaying of Gail Cobb, the first policewoman to die in the line of duty, prompted other police officers to accept women in law enforcement, according to an official of the Police Foundation, a nonprofit law enforcement research group.

title: I Want to Know About a Flight To the Moon
description: A certain young man I know, age 4 or thereabouts, chats matteroffactly about astronaut Al Worden the way he discusses his schoolmates, or his favorite books. His familiarity stems from having met astronaut AlCol. Alfred M. Wordenon public TV's Mister Rogers' Neighborhood. That's where this book began, and that, I suspect, is why it is written in such sensible, straightforward, nobabytalk language. Colonel Worden and Fred Rogers did a TV show, from Cape Kennedy prior to the launching of the Apollo 15 moon mission in 1971. The show was, in effect, a briefing for Mr. Rogers's young viewers, and it brought in so many questionsintriguing, inspiring and amusingfrom children who wanted to know more about space travel that Colonel Worden decided to put his answers into book form.

title: Feld Is the Classic Maverick
description: EliotFeld is a maverick among choreographers, a genetic sport from his tribe. He is a classic choreographer. As an American dancer, particularly of his specific 1942 New York generationLouis Falco was born in the same place and at the same timehe has been influenced and counterinfluenced by moderndance. However, his acceptance of his roots in classicism can never be questioned. But classic choreographers are good boys. They have not been trained to float happily, even if disastrously, in that freefalle of the ego known to dancers and, more especially, choreographers, as my own company. Mr. Feld is unique. among his classic brethren in insisting on his own company. Indeed, he has insisted on it so much that when his first choreographic mount became lame in Brooklyn a few years age, and had to be shot from under him, he came back after a few excursions on horses for other people's courses and quietly screamed to the world: A horse, a horse, my kingdom for horse. So far, he has been considerably more fortunate than Richard was at Bosworth. His luck should hold up, just like his steed.

title: YOUTH SYMPHONY OPENS 12th SEASON
description: The Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York began its 12th season of free concerts yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, with a stylishly played concert under the direction of its new music director, Kenneth Jean.

title: Seoul Ousts U.S. Clergyman Who Criticized Regime
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 14 The Scitith Korean Government today expelled an American missionary, accusing him of having disrupted social order and fomented antiGovernment demonstrations.

title: WORLD OF RETAILING
description: After almost 68 years of tranquil growth, the W. T. Grant Company is one of America's largest retail chainsand one of its most troubled.

title: NIGERIANS DEFEND CORRUPTION'S FOE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 14We plead with General Gowon to release Aper Aku today, a frontpage editorial in Nigeria's most influential privately owned newspaper said this week.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
Julia Gordon Kaupp Is Married To Sidney Swimmer in Jersey
description: Julia Gordon Kaupp, daughter of Mr: and Mrs. Clement Nathan Kaupp of Short Hills, N. J., and Argyle Head, Nova Scotia, was married yesterday afternoon to Sidney West Swinimer of Windsor, Nova Scotia; son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Swinimer of Argyle Head.

title: Some Opposition Winners of Brazilian Election Facing a Rightist Backlash
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 14Brazil's military leadership has apparently accepted last month's Opposition victory in congressional elections with good grace, but there are signs of rightwing reaction.

title: Economic Efficiency vs. Political Reality
description: One might say that, in terms of economics, we feel reasonably confident that we know what needs to be done. The question is, as a matter of politics, do we have what it takes to do it?

title: Albert's Toothache
description: Albert is a turtle with a toothache but no teeth. It hurts quite badly in any case, and this causes Albert's family to worry. He could be quite off nis beam, telling tall tales, or turning into a coward. He doesn't want to learn to throw a spitball, or eat black ants; he doesn't even want to fight with Dilworth Dunlap. He just wants credibility for his dental calamity. What he also needs is some real turtle warmth from his family, which is too busy being logical to give him any sympathy. Finally, Albert's grandma enters and furnishes him with the warmth and caring his predicament requires. She also breaks through his syntactical problems by asking him a long overdue question: WHERE do you have a toothache? And that brings Albert's left.

title: Vikings Win From Chiefs, 3515
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 14 (AP)  Fran Tarkenton and Bob Berry, sharing equal playing time, each threw two touchdown passes today as the playoffbound Minnesota Vikings breezed to a 3515 National Football League victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Methodists Reject Homosexual's Ordination Bid
description: MADISON, Wis., Dec. 14.A homosexual has failed to secure his local church congregation's support in a bid for ordination in the United Methodist Church here on the University of Wisconsin campus.

title: School Plans Set Back by Budget Cuts
description: Eight school construction projects, in Brooklyn and Queens, some of them in the planning pipeline for nearly a decade, are to be abandoned or postponed under a proposal by the Board of Education to reduce expenditures in the city's current fiscal crisis.

title: People/Business
description: Sandoz, Inc.; one of the country's leading drug manufacturers, has expanded by three buildings its 180acre research, production sand marketing headquarters on Route 10 in East Hanover.

title: Shane's Prince Wins Calder Race
description: MIAMI, Dec. 14 (AP) Shane's Prince, the second choice, easily defeated Commanding Lead, the favorite, in today's $25,000 Coral Gables Handicap at TropicalatCalder.

title: Vatican's ManyFront Battle
description: The movement toward change in Roman Catholicismauthorized, in the form of liturgical renewal, and unauthorized, as in attitudes toward birth control  is expanding into two more areas: marriage, with its tight proscriptions against divorce and remarriage; and abortion, with its total prohibitions against the direct termination of fetal life for whatever reason and at whatever stage.

title: A New Ship Brings More Jobs to Brooklyn's Docks
description: In a harbor as large as the Port of New York the arrival of a new cargo ship that will trade here regularly is the kind of event that usually goes unnoticed, but not in Brooklyn.

title: Humphrey Says He Plans No Race for Presidency
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 14 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he would not be a candidate for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination, although he did not rule out the possibility of accepting a draft at the party's convention.

title: Making Gifts of Plastic Is Funand Saves Money
description: Small tables, magazine racks, plant holders, picture frames, trays, book ends telephone stands, game boardsthese are only a few of the many items that can be easily made out of plastic. Many of these colorful, handmade creations scan provide an economical and unique solution to many giftgiving problems at this time of year, and Since most of these projects can be completed in just a few hours, most people will still have time to complete several in time for Christmas.

title: Cheers Fill Soviet Tour By Joffrey
description: MOSCOW, Dec, 13In Leningrad, the final ovation on closing night lasted 27 minutes. It was 30 seconds longer in Riga. In Vilna, eager young people without tickets broke down the theater doors to get into the performance.

title: Lists of Gift Books Available in Nassau
description: Four free lists of girt book suggestions are available to the public at all public libraries in Nassau County.

title: Rookies Enjoy Banner Season in National Football League
description: Rookie of the year? More appropriate would be rookies of the year because this has been a banner season for new names in the National Football League. Two reasons seem evident. The rosters were expanded from 40 players to 47 and, because of the strike of the veterans last summer, the coaching staffs had to spend more time working with the rookies who populated their training camps. Appreciation developed.

title: HEFNER IS SILENT ON DRUGS INQUIRY
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14Hugh M. Hefner, publisher of Playboy magazine, generally sought to maintain his silence this weekend as Federal officials looked into allegations of use of narcotics in Playboy mansions in Chicago and Beverly Hills, California.

title: ONION PRICES DROP TO A BARGAIN LOW
description: With the farm price of onions dropping to 4 and even 3 cents a pound, one of the lowest levels on record, they are being sold in New York area and lower New England retail food markets at the same bargain prices as potatoes, as low as 10 and 12 cents a pound. Just 18 months ago, onions sold here for 49 cents a pound.

title: Muffie Stone Plans Bridal in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Stone Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen R. Stone, to Desmond G. FitzGerald of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. G. FitzGerald of Washington. A May wedding in Greenwich is planned.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1974

title: Cathy J. Sulzberger Is Married
description: Cathy Jean Sulzberger of Washington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York, was married here early last evening to Dr. Joseph George Perpich, also of Washington. Dr. Perpich is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anton R. Perpich of Hibbing, Minn.

title: Caroline Loretta Singler Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Paul Vanston Singler of Brick Town, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Loretta Caroline Singler, to Lawrence Vincent O'Connor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Connor Jr. of Morristown, N. J.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: In modern art, including modern photography, there is a kind of Gresham's Law by which the very new drives out the not so new and makes it seem obsolete and oldfashioned before it has ever really established itself. To the vast majority in this age or democracy, Matisse is not even a name. He has never achieved the popularity of a Norman Rockwell or even a Van Gogh, much less the renown of a television commentator or a rock star. Yet his radical innovations in painting have long since been rendered oldfashioned by the drastic simplifications of Rothko and Stella, and the paintings which once drove art critics wild with fury are now accepted as classic by everybodyat least everybody in the tiny world that pays them any attention whatsoever.

title: STATE INQUIRY SET ON PROPERTY TAX
description: A state commission has called a series of public hearings starting in Mineola, L. I., on Tuesday to hear suggestions on altering or abolishing the property tax limit in the New York State Constitution for school districts.

title: Suzan Billig Engaged To J. N. Brauwerman
description: Suzan Carol Billig, a senior account supervisor in marketing services with Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, and Jeffrey Norman Brauwerman, a lawyer with the Department of Justice, plan to be married here Jan. 30.

title: Hail, Mary
description: When my generation was starting out in the parochial schools of the nineteenthirties, the older nuns used to tell a story of the Boss complaining to St. Peter about certain very disreputable characters he had seen walking the streets of the heavenly city. Why did you let those fellows get in? the Boss demanded of his gatekeeper.

title: BRIEF CLASH MARS MARCH IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14Chanting, We say, we say no to racism, 15,000 to 20,000 blacks and whites marched through the streets of downtown Boston today to protest the turmoil that has accompanied courtordered busing for school desegregation here.

title: Squash Racquets Match to New York
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Dec. 14, New York began its defense of the Lockett Cup today by scoring a 61 victory over Philadelphia at the Merion Cricket Club in a renewal of the annual tricity squash racquets matches. New York will play Boston in the deciding match tomorrow.

title: Maritime College Here Hails 100th Anniversary
description: A hundred years ago last Tuesday, Capt. Stephen Bleecker Luce sailed the U.S.S. St. Mary's up the East River, docked it at the East 23d Street pier, ushered 26 teenage boys aboard the 1,000ton retired war sloop and established the New York Nautical School.

title: CITY'S CHARITIES FEELING SQUEEZE
description: Many of the city's charitable organizations that depend on the Public to help them finance a wide range of social service are feeling the pinch of reduce contributions because of the recession and inflation, at atime when they expect these same conditions to increase the demand for their services.

title: Suffolk to Continue Special Vote Drive
description: HAUPPAGUEA voter registration program designed to reach Suffolk's estimated 262,281 eligible, unregistered voters will be continued for another year.

title: PERU TAKES OVER TELEGRAPH UNITS
description: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 14 (AP)President Juan Velasco Alvarado's leftist military Government announced today the nationalization of all privately owned international Telex and telegraph services in Peru, including an I.T.T. subsidiary, effective March 1.

title: Power to the People in 1 House
Britain's Town Criers: A Sound Investment
description: OWER SLAUGHTER, EnglandHalfway through a voluntary twoyear hitch in the soft green Gloucestershire countryside, my wife and I decided by the customary vote of onetoone that We couldn't possibly live without an outofprint Austin princess Vandenplas four liter with an engine signed by RollsRoyce.

title: Carey Names 2 Panels on Education
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey has appointed two panels, one on a state aid to education and the other on higher education.

title: Kodak Clinics, Colgate Games Spurring Women's Competition
description: It is a sure sign that women's sports are coming into their own when companies such as Eastman Kodak and ColgatePalmolive get into the act.

title: State to Increase Recreation Sites
description: TRENTON  The state's potential for outdoor activitiesfrom walking and bikeriding to outdoor chess and bird  watching  was advanced substantially last week with the certification of 10 additional recreation areas from Cape May to Hudson County.

title: Olympic Movement: Idea Is to Get People Together, Not Apart
description: Sport for a World of Peace was the motto of the International Olympic Committee Congress in 1973, and that the principal object of the Olympic Movement today. It is a movement which endeavors, to bring together people of all countries, no matter what their beliefs, religious or political philosophy, or racial origins may benot only at the time of the Games but also to reciprocate and assist each other in the intervening period.

title: Drug Search Yields Wine
description: MIAMI BEACH (UPI)Police searching for marijuana raided a school bus headed for Miami Beach Senior High and turned up two bottles of Mogen David wine and a pair of dice.

title: Six Houses Are Saved On Coney I.
description: Owners of a halfdozen small homes condemned by the city in the Coney Island Urban Renewal Area received word last week that their properties would be spared from demolition and they would be permitted to preserve and rehabilitate the houses.

title: Diagrantless, 19 by 19
description: ACROSS

title: Notes: Welcome for Bicentennial Guests
description: COMPANY'S coming, and America is rolling out the welcome mat. Some 35 million visitors from abroad are expected to arrive in the United States during the bicentennial years of 197576, end Government agencies are joining ranks with civilian organizations to help communities across the country gird for the invasion.

title: Audrey Jane Goldsmith Is Married
description: Audrey Jane Goldsmith, daughter of Mrs. Berkley Hill Jr. of Ridgefield, Conn., and Clifford H. Goldsmith of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to David Wilson Kuhie. Rabbi Daniel Wolk of Congregation EmanuEl in Rye, N. Y., performed the ceremony here at the home of the bride's father, who is president of Philip Morris U.S.A. and an executive vice president and a director of Philip Morris Incorporated.

title: MANILA SET BACK ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: MANILA, Dec. 14  The Philippines, whose population of 39 million is expected to double in the next two decades is running into problems in her voluntary campaign to reduce births and educate Filipinos in family planning.

title: Leonard Adler to Wed Priscilla Frank
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Frank of Scarsdale, N. Y., and London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla Lee Frank, to Leonard J. Adler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Adler of West Long Branch, N.J. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Lee Morgan Sets Nuptials
description: Mrs. Guion Case Morgan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lee Sheila Morgan, to Thomas Reynolds Megna, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Megna. Both families are of Lawrenceville, N. J., where the father of the prospective bridegroom teaches French at the Lawrenceville School. Miss Morgan's late father was on Lawrenceville's English faculty.

title: Jeanne Neary Wed To Richard E. Look
description: Jeanne Marie Neary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Neary of Crestwood, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard Edwards Look, a pianist and composer and son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Look of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: No more eating rats
description: When the Du Ponts arrived in America on Jan. 1, 1800, they were hungry, having made such a long voyage from France that their provisions ran out and they were at times reduced to eating soup made of boiled rats. Their first act on these shores was to enter home without invitation and to steal food from a family that was at church. Thus the Du Ponts, observes Gerard Colby Zilg, had entered American historyin their own peculiar way.

title: American Couple Wounded Outside a Hotel in London
description: LONDON, Dec. 14An American couple were wounded by shots fired apparently indiscriminately from a passing car at the Churchill Hotel in the West End of London tonight.

title: Suffolk Is Given 140 Acres
description: PORT JEFFERSONA spit of land dominating the eastern entrance to Port Jefferson Harbor has been donated to Suffolk County.

title: Inflation Christmas Trees
description: Holiday gift plants make colorful displays in florists shops and at garden centers. To keep them going when they arrive home, here are some pointers:
