title: The Nation
description: John D. Ehrlichman has now testified in his own behalf at the Watergate trial, and his defense essentially is this: That far from participating in any coverup, he had been kept deliberately in the dark by President Nixon.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Fiction

title: ENVIRONMENT LAW WIDENED BY COURT
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14The California Supreme Court, in case involving shoreline oil drilling, has significantly broadened the scope of the state's law requiring environmental impact assessments on both public and private development projects.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Joe Namath, discussing the famous $427,000 contract he signed with the Jets 10 years ago, says frankly: With what I know now, I would've signed to play in New York for half that much. It would've been worth my while for all the endorsements, publicity and everything else that resulted from my playing in New York.

title: Little Man on Campus
description: HAVERFORD, Pa.Clark Kerr once wrote that college presidents were supposed to speak like mice on their own campuses and roar like lions away from home. The mouse part of the message has carried so well that it now describes most of our utterances at home or abroad.

title: Headliner
description: Walter Lippmann died yesterday. He was 85 years old. This appreciation of him was written by Richard H. Rovere, a longtime friend and a staff writer on The New Yorker specializng in political affairs.

title: ARTS VIEW
description: A distinguished group of New Yorkers concerned with the arts, called the Mayor's Committee on Cultural Policy, has spent 20 months trying to find out how well, or badly, New York City handles its cultural affairs. The Committee's report, issued this fall, is a model of clarity and conviction. The conclusion it reaches is that the city could not be doing a much less effective job, and that without major administrative changes the situation, endangers both the city's economy and its cultural, institutions.

title: Maguire's Goal: Major House Committee
description: RIDGEWOOD  Andrew Maguire ran hard to win the Democratic nomination in the Seventh Congressional District primary, and he ran hard to win the House of Representative seat that had been safely Republican for more than a quartercentury.

title: INVESTING
description: While it's true that most interest rates, since reaching record heights last summer, have been coming down, yields on taxexempt bonds  especially lower  rated issuesremain as high as ever.

title: MILWAUKEE TAX SPURS RECALL BID
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 14 Widespread opposition to a 26 per cent increase in the school tax here has spawned a campaign to recall all 15 members of the Milwaukee School Board.

title: 2 Seek Campaign Gifts for '76 As Date for $1,000 Limit Nears
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14There are 17 days left before the new $1,000 limit on political contributions takes effect, and at least two Democratic Presidential aspirants are making the most of the opportunity.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market seemed to be in a mood to move higher last week but could not generate sufficient enthusiasm for a broad advance.

title: YOUNGER CYCLISTS FAULTED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Bicyclists under the age of 20 years are usually at fault in collisions with motor vehicles, but motorists are more likely to be at fault in collisions with older cyclists, a study published this week suggests.

title: TODAY AND TOMORROW
description: (One of Walter Lippmarin's regrets after the collapse of his two favorite New York papersThe World and The Herald Tribunewas that he never wrote a column for The New York Times. He died at the age of 85 yesterday in New York. Here is a collumn in his own words under his old flag in The Herald Tribune. He said it better than any of usJames Reston)

title: Saigon Reports Recapturing Village After Heavy Fighting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 14 (Reuters)Government troops today recaptured a vilrage from Communist forces after some of the heaviest fighting in South Vietnam for several months, according to reports from the area.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 14 Are the Los Angeles Kings finally travelweary? The National Hockey League's best road club which was undefeated away from home until Thursday night in Boston seemed to suffer from jet lag tonight. They dropped their second straight game, losing 30. to the New York Islanders before 14,000 persons. It was only the Kings' fourth defeat of the season.

title: Learning Theater Is HolidayBound
description: PATERSONThey open in Secaucus and then play Sea Girt. And after that, they open again in Holmdel.

title: Red Bank Man Is Charged With 2 Killings in Neptune
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., Dec. 14One man was charged today with killing two men after a gun fight in a private home on Eighth Avenue here last night.

title: Epilogue
description: Four Years to Stockholm

title: Julie Furman Married to Physician
description: Julie Furman of Highland Park, N. J., and Dr. Marvin Markowitz of Brooklyn were married here yesterday afternoon in the Cottage on the Park at Hampshire House by Rabbi Yakov Hilsenrath of the Highland Park Conservative Temple.

title: Oiling Up Old Friendship
description: PARISIt has become recent custom for United States and French Presidents to hold their private summits on midway islands to give the impression that neither is sacrificing face. Thus. Nixon and Pompidou met in the Azores and Iceland. Now Ford takes over with Giscard d'Estaing in Martinique, a French territory off the Americas.

title: O'er the Ramparts we watched was so gallantly spendingIf You Have a Lemon, Make Lemonade By Warren Hinkte 3d.363 pp. New York:G. P. Putnam's Sons. $8.95.
description: Certain circles in New York remember Warren Hinckle as the mad man from the West Coast who edited Ramparts magazine during the sixties. It was a preposterous decade and Hinckle was a man for his times. His notion of editing a revolutionary attack on the systemradical slick as he called it seemed to involve nonstop flights to and from California and running up large bills for cantaloupe at the Algonquin Hotel. More sobersided attackonthesystem buffs were driven crazy by his methods because they worked.

title: City's List of Building Projects That Could Be Cut to Ease Deficit
Europeans Get Queries
description: Europeans Get Queries But Extent Of Buying Enthusiasm Is Unclear PARISInto the vaults of the Paris branch of he Chase Manhattan Bank he walked, fingering the smooth chocolatebar sized gold bar in his trenchcoat pocket, afraid that the pocket lining might tear from the weight.

title: WALTER V. BENNETT
description: Walter V. Bennett, who retired in 1965 as sales manager for the southern region of U.S. News and World Report, died Friday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Convalescent Terrace. He was 94 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: MURPHY IS ELECTED BY NEWSPAPER GUILD
description: Thomas P. Murphy, the second vice president of the Newspaper Guild of New York was thosen president or the guild Friday in its first contested election in 24 years.

title: Meany Warns on Gas Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)  President of the American and Congress of Industrial Organizations, George Meany, warned President Ford today that deregulating prices of natural gas and crude oil would cost the American consumer $20billion a year. Mr. Meany said in a letter delivered to Mr. Ford yesterday and made public today: These inflationary proposals are unnecessary, unwise and unsupportable.

title: Hypnotism Leads to a HitRun Suspect
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 14The police have arrested a suspect in a hitand run accident after using hypnosis to help a policeman who witnessed the accident to recall part of the licenseplate number of the car involved.

title: Influx of HighQuality, BargainPriced Heroin Is Reported in Eastern Cities
description: A wave of lowpriced, highquality heroin is flowing into East Coast cities as major European suppliers release stockpiles of the illegal drug in anticapation of resumed Turkish production.

title: Emily Barclay Bride of John Hawes Jr.
description: Emily Morgan Barclay was married yesterday afternoon to John Bromham Hawes Jr., an architect in the Harvard University Planning Office.

title: A Cypriote Restaurateur Decides to Try Again
description: KYRENIA, Cyprus  Judy Findlay set at the piano and played a sad song. Scattered all around were the broken fragments of a business, of a life.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14A wild 15minute freeforall in the final period that led to two National Hockey League records for penalty minutes and left blood on the ice overshadowed the Rangers' 62 loss to the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: The Spirit of Fascism Lives in Mrs. Peron's Regime
description: BUENOS AIRESEarly last week, Ricardo Balbin, the leader of the parliamentary opposition, expressed an optimism of sorts about the possibility that President Isabel Pern might finish her term in office and pave the way for stable, constitutional, civilian government in Argentina.

title: Synagogue Gets New Head
description: MONTGOMERY, Dec. 14 Ala Warren Alpert, an Assistant Secretary of State during the Kennedy Administration, was installed yesterday as president of the Sutton Place SynagogueJewish Center for the United Nations, 224 East 52d Street Mr. Alpert is president of Warren Equities, an oil company.

title: Emilie Millett Bride Of Robert O'Malley
description: Emilie Huntly Millett and Robert Kevin O'Malley, who are studying art in Florence, Italy, were married there yesterday evening in St. James Episcopal Church (American) by the Rev. Edward Lee Jr.

title: Methodist Hospital Modifies Its Plans
description: Methodist Hospital, which recently abandoned its $135million expansion plan in Park Slope because of community opposition, still plans to build a new $60million, 354bed acutecare facility.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: JOHN M. COMLEY
description: John M. Comley, who retired in 1970 as a judge of the Connecticut Supreme Court, died yesterday ate a convalescent home in Stamford, Conn. He was 79 years old and lived at 98 Hoyt Street, Stamford.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in aviation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: MRS. HARRY SCHMIDT
description: Doris Korner Schmidt, widow of Gen. Harry Schmidt, who led the Marine Corps assault on Iwo Jima in World War II. died Wednesday at her home in Poway, Calif. Her age was 84.

title: MIKI SAYS JAPAN FACES HARDSHIPS
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14Premier Takeo Mild warned the Japanese people today that they were confronted by unprecedented trials from within and without the country and asked them to have courage, wisdom and perseverance to overcome the difficulties.

title: Prague's Botels270 Rms Riv Vu
description: MOST European capitals, faced with increasing numbers of foreign visitors, suffer from chronic lack of hotel facilities, but for Prague the problem of finfew baroque or Renaisiance churches or pading necessary space is particularly critical. You can't, simply scrap a laces, and Prague is, for the most part, built of architectural treasures preserved intact over 10 centuries.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Ron Kurz, formerly unknown to literature, makes a spectacular entrance with his first novel, LETHAL GAS (Evans, $6.95). It is about prison life, and as such comes under the category of crime fiction, but it has as much relationship to most crime fiction as Dick Tracy has to Daumier. What Kurz has done is write the Catch22 of prison books. He has much the same mordant wit, the sense of the ridiculous and contempt for phonies that Joseph Heller had in his famous first novel.

title: At Last We Can See More of Ashton
description: American, ballet goers are hardly unfamiliar with the name of Sir Frederick Ashton, Britain's leading choreographer and former director of the Royal Ballet. Audiences here have cheered his works season after, season. And yet, the presentation of Ashton's ballets in New York City has beenlimited mostly to the visits of the Royal Balletthe company he shaped and for whose greatness he was largely responsible. This season all that seems to be changing.

title: The Ancients
description: One need not go into history to find the reasons for veneration of the evergreen tree or bough as a part of the Christmas season. They are of the enduring things of this earth, and man has known them as long as man has been here. The pine, the spruce, the hemlock, the firall those conifers that know no leafless seasonhave been held in special favor when man would have symbols of life that outlast all winters. And even more enduring, in geologic time, are the ground pine, the ground cedar and the club mosses, most venerable all the evergreens.

title: The World
description: Renewed diplomatic efforts to advance Middle East peace negotiations have been complicated by a rising incidence of terror and counterterror between the Israelis and the Palestinians.

title: Swords Into Plowshares
description: At a time when the nations of the world are spending $240 billion a year on defense and the two superpowers have been able to agree only to freeze the nuclear arms race at even higher levels than those already attained, an encouraging declaration has been signed in Peru. Eight Latin American countries have agreed to limit armaments, to stop buying offensive weapons and to use the money instead for social and economic development.

title: DEBATE ON TERROR POSTPONED BY U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14The United Nations General Assembly today decided without any opposition to postpone debate on the problem of international terrorism until next year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: This year's king and queen at Wimbledon, Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert, were ranked yesterday as the top players in the world by Tennis Magazine.

title: FundRaising Effort by Ford Fell Far Short in California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)President Ford's major fundraising effort for California Republicans this fall raised only a third of its goat.

title: Mini Shopping Centers a Hub for Antiques and Crafts
description: RIVER VALEThe mini shopping center, a place where antiques are sold alone or in combination with crafts and boutique items, is cropping up all over the state.

title: O'Donnell Weighed for Post
description: Harry J. O'Donnell, the press secretary and a close adviser to Governor Wilson, is being considered for a position in the Democratic administration of Governorelect Hugh L. Carey, a political official said last night. Mr. O'Donnell, a respected strategist in the administration of Govs. Thomas E. Dewey and Nelson A. Rockefeller and once press secretary to former Mayor Lindsay, declined to comment on the report.

title: Circle Home Wins Heritage
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Dec. 14The first $100,000 thoroughbred race at the new Keystone race track resulted in a goingaway victory for John Olin's Circle Home in the Heritage Stakes for 2yearolds today.

title: The Region
description: New York City has again rejected a proposal that its water supply expanded into a regional system would include eight neighboring ties. Robert A. Low, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, that despite new revisions giving the city greater representation in a regional corporation the plan is still unacceptable.

title: Writers Honor Woman Pitcher.
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 14 (AP)  The Connecticut Sportswriters Alliance has named a women softball pitcher, Joan Joyce, recipient of its athleteoftheyear award.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Winter's Seven Sleepers
description: There is a persistent New England legend, which seems to surface most often in Vermont that when the land was in winter's cruel embrace, it often became necessarybecause of a shortage of food  to freeze nonproductive old folks in the woodshed where they would live in a state of suspended animation until the spring thaw.

title: Politicians Fight For 2 L.I. Posts
description: Two Suffolk DemocratsHuntington Town Supervisor Jerome A. Ambra and County Legislator Thomas J. Downey who, captured normally Republican Congressional seats in last month's election are now confronted with growing squabbles over their replacements in their present posts.

title: UNION GIFTS STIR STORM IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 14Heated debate has flared in Parliament over disclosures that four membars of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Cabinet received campaign contributions from a maritime union that has had a turbulent history.

title: A New Realism is on Display at Queens Museum
description: The Queens Museum's current show of realist art is one of a growing number of displays celebrating representational images at museums and galleries throughout the country.

title: Betsy Spalla, Editor, Wed To Sailmaker
description: Betsy Spalla, editor of The Pictorial, a weekly newspaper in Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Avery Whidden 2d, a partner of Sobstad Sailmakers in Old Saybrook. The Rev. Kenneth Thomas performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex, Conn.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Bay State Officer Acquitted
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 14 (AP)A Bristol County Superior Court jury has acquitted Police Lieut. Leonard Decunha of embezzling parking meter funds.

title: Sunday Observer
description: It is manoftheyear season over at Time magazine again and before they settle for anointing one of the bushleague politicians in which the planet abounds, I want to put in a word for Willy Brandt, who did something so rare in this era of bloated excess that the mind can scarcely grasp the grandeur of the deed. Brandt turned himself off.

title: Industry's Envoys to the 21st Century
description: The whole thrust of our society is toward greater individuality and better utilization of human potential. This is all but certain to continue and to have an influence on everybody in industry. Our people are going to need a great deal of personal breadth and versatility. Our institutions are going to have to be flexible and offer a diversity of incentives and rewards.

title: Joel A. Caplan, Charlotte Jack Plan Wedding
description: Charlotte Scott Jack, a descendant of John Jay and Mathew Clarkson, who served on George Washington's staff, and. Joel Anthony Caplan plan to marry. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jordan Thurlow Jack of South Salem, N.Y. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Caplan of Pittsfield, Mass.

title: Child to Mrs. Aldrich
description: A daughter was born Dec. 6 to Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Aldrich of BarrytownonHudson, N. Y., at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Aldrich, whose husband is a special assistant to the State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, is the former Katharine Delano Ryan of Rhinebeck, N. Y. The child has been named Margaret Livingston.

title: Rangers' LineUp AT GARDEN
description: CABLE TVCHANNEL 10, 7:05 P.M. RADIOWNEW, 7 P.M.

title: New Brookhaven Plan Stresses the Environment
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION  A call for conservetion through use of such techniques as cluster zoning, newtown centers and industrial transit corridors was presented here last week in a draft of a master plan for the Town of Brookhaven.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Tug at the Hear and Soul
description: To the Editor: Tug McGraw was the heart and soul of the Mets. Without him, we have no one left to root for, no one left to love.

title: Eight Contemporary Poets
description: This brilliant and idiosyncratic book sums up, in each of its chapters, one poethis individual accent, his best work, his flaws, the shape of his career. Some of these British and Irish poets are wellknown, especially Larkin, Davie, Hughes and Tomlinson; others, like W. S. Graham, will be new to most readers; and still others, like Stevie Smith and R. S. Thomas, have not been much noticed in the United States. Calvin Bedient writes about poems with an unfailing sense of the human being stationed in each one. Like Wallace Stevens, he sees the poem as the cry of its occasion, and in this book occasions and their cries are matched with uncanny perception. The animating beliefs of Bedient's essays are that poetic speech is unimaginable apart from its ground of feeling, that life is inherent in literature, and that literature is known life.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONThe minority Republicans in the Senate have quietly resolved their legislative leadership next year by reelecting the same people who presided this year, but the Democratic majorities in both houses are still a little unsettled.

title: Ocean County Sealing Wells
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP  A 10yearold girl, thirsty, after two hours of field hockey, opened the kitchen faucet and drank deeply. Her mother watched and smiled, knowing that water in the Pleasant Plains section of this township is safe again.

title: Dispute Curbs City Property Sales
description: The auction of properties in Manhattan taken over by the city for nonpayment of taxes has been halted by Borough President Percy E. Sutton in a policy dispute with the Beame administration.

title: Social Announcements
description: Births

title: REPORT UPDATED ON STATE'S BIRDS
description: The first new encyclopedic report on Birds of New York State since 1914 has just been completed by John Bull, a field associate at the American. Museum of Natural History, showing an increase of 44 species in the 60 years.

title: Mansfield, in China, Finds Impatience on. U.S. Policy.
description: PEKING, Dec. 14 (Reuters)Senator Mike Mansfield, the Montana Democrat, gained an impression from five days of talks with Chinese leaders here that they were impatient over a lack of progress in ChineseUnited States relations, American sources said today.

title: Princeton Blacks Act to Revive Cause
description: PRINCETON  Black undergraduates at Princeton University, admittedly dissatisfied with tie results of protests staged in the last decade, are seeking to revitalize the socalled Black Student Movement.

title: LettersCommunity Boards Criticized
description: Paul Selver's Point of View article on community planning boards (Dec. 1) was in teresting and contained some surprising admissions. The boards can be petty, vindicitive, obstructionist and sometimes even sophisticated. Above all, they are generally uninformed and unprogressive.

title: Cultural Programs Reduced In Nassau
description: MINEOLAFaced with a crippling budget cutback of nearly 50 per cent for the upcoming year, the director of Nassau County's nationally acclaimed arts and culture program is optimistically mapping out strategy to salvage as many events as possible and preserve the quality of those that must be scaled down.

title: Two In, One Out
description: The scramble for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976, left shapeless by the.unexpected withdrawal of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has begun to define itself a little with the subsequent retirement from the race of Senator Walter Mondale of Minnesota, the entry of Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona and Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia and the imminent entry of former Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma. Still unofficial but as good as announced are the candidacies of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and, already far advanced, that of Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: The references to my views, cited (Sept. 1) approvingly by Ronald Radosh, from Alonzo Hamby's book Beyond the New Deal, are slanderously false. He asserts that my views blurred the distinction between unpopular opinion and criminal subversion and agreed with the fundamental assumptions and tactics of McCarthyism.

title: Construction Workers Protest U. S. Policy on Nonunion Labor
description: Several thousand construction workers rallied in Foley Square yesterday morning to protest Government contract policies that allow nonunion labor on Federal projects.

title: A Store for the Season's Delicacies
description: GRIGGSTOWNChristmas is coming, and the Griggstown General Store, newly stocked with barrels of imported herring, lingonberries and lutefisk (a sundried cod), is ready.

title: Private Aid to Private Enterprise
description: LIMA, PeruFew multinational companies have had a stranger birth and childhood than ADELA, a fairly successful LatinAmerican investment group that will be 10 years old next month.

title: Barbara Nagel Bride of Dr. Reibel
description: Barbara Claire Nagel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond H. Nagel, of Kenmore, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Jay Steven Reibel, a New York psychiatrist. He is the son of Mrs. Jacob Reibel of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Reibel, a general practitioner.

title: GETTING EVEN
description: It was fitting that the Ford Administration's first important initiative in the foreignpolicy arena should have been its attempt to shore the Western industrial world against the crippling blow IT has suffered from the fourfold oilprice increase over the past year. For no country has reacted with such public outrage as the United States to this naked exercise in monopoly power by the small group of producers who call themselves the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (O.P.E.C.). Nor has any other country been more frank in spelling out the dangers the price increase holds for Western civilization.

title: Residency Job Rule Dropped
description: TRENTON  Rather than risk a legal defeat in the Appellate Division of Superior Court, the Civil Service Commission has agreed to drop its 12month state residency requirement for applicants for state jobs.

title: A Lady Tiger at the Keyboard
description: Some 20 years ago a diminutive, 16  year  old Detroitborn piano student named Ruth Meckler traveled to Marlboro, Vt., to audition for one of today's greatest pianists: Rudolf Serkin. With all the intrepitude of youth, she launched into Beethoven's difficult Sonata Op. 101, and followed it with Chopin's Aflat Ballade. When she had finished, Serkin paused, then said, I can see you play like a tiger.

title: 6 Years Later, Evidence in Sirhan's Case Is Questioned
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14More than six years after the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, a small group of criminologists, public officials and eyewitnesses to the shooting are questioning some of the evidence that led to the conviction of Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, a Jordanian immigrant, as the only assailant.

title: Intersession Courses In College Increasing
description: TRENTON  In keeping with a national trend, the number of intersession courses that will be available at New Jersey's private colleges this winter is on the rise.

title: Laura Burnett Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Gilbert Burnett of West Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Candace Burnett, to James Lloyd Kaye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lloyd Kaye Jr. of Acton, Mass. Miss Burnett was presented to society in 1971 at the Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball in New York and the Summit (N.J.) Cotillion. She is an alumna of the Northampton School for Girls and is a senior at New England College. Her fianc is a graduate of New England College.

title: Promotional Stamp Is Issued by C.Y.O.
description: PATERSON  A stamp bearing the words, There's a Place for You in the CYO, has been issued by the Paterson Catholic Youth Organization. The stamp, designed by Nicholas Jaworovich of Union City, will have an initial run of 125,000.

title: Cooking the Christmas Goose
description: In the United States, roast goose is more often sung about than sampled at Christmas. Its traditional edging ma northern Erma peenEnglish, French, German Russian Scandinavian These are the lands where for centuries a big fat goose, not a turkey, would be used to feed a festive crowd.

title: Public Advocate Branches Out
description: TRENTON  The state's new Department of the Public Advocate, stepping up the pace of its activity, has announced that it is prepared to take legal steps in two more areas involving the public interest.

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: ART

title: Senator Assails Tax Dodgers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)  Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said this week that some businesses were delaying sending in withheld Social Security taxes and happily paying the 6 per cent penalty  far less than the interest on money they would have to borrow from banks to pay the taxes. The choice for an unscrupulous businessman is an easy one, Mr. Proxmire said.

title: Hospitals' Use Called Uneven
description: TRENTONAlthough the state's Department of Health says that New Jersey has more general hospital beds than it will need for the foreseeable future, department officials have disclosed that plans are pending for new hospitals or additions to at least 17 institutions.

title: Jeanne Earley Sets August Wedding
description: Jeanne Earley, coach of the girls' varsity basketball team at the University of Notre Dame, and John Edward Appelt Jr., product manager with Seagrains Overseas Sales Corporation here, plan to be married in August.

title: Theater: The Old Ones
description: It is now nearly 20 years since the strange sobriquet angry young men attached itself, somewhat haphazardly, to a number of British writers and dramatists. They are now no longer particularly angry or for that matter particularly young. Among the more enduring reputations from that period has been that of Arnold Wesker. However, after an early success, notably with Roots and Chips with Everything. he later lost something in both public support and critical approbation.

title: Central MiMichigan Routs Delaware in Bowl, 5414
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Dec. 14 (AP)Dick Dunham ran 68 yards for a touchdown on the game's first play and plunged for three more scores today as Central Michigan routed Delaware, 5414, in the Camellia Bowl for the National Collegiate Division II championship.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor: The fact that Chuck Kraemer, in his article Fred Wiseman's Palmate Makes Monkeys of Scientists [Dec. 1], could write what he did is the greatest indictment the film could have. In his critique, Mr. Kraemer speaks of, among other things, vivisection and the callousness [and] obsessiveness of the scientists and researchers that he saw in the film. In fact, the film shows no vivisection, no cruelty, no pain caused to anyof the animals and no callousnessexcept the effects deliberately created by the camera tricks used Mr. Wiseman.

title: Mrs. Hearst in Plea To Daughter Tells Of Plans to Move
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)Catherine Hearst sent word to her fugitive daughter Patricia today that the family would move from its 22room mansion to get away from memories of Patricia and her kidnapping.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am disturbed about many aspects of the recent courtordered medical examination of former President Nixon. Now that it is clear that Mr. Nixon will not testify, these issues, like so many other aspects of this bizarre Watergate affair, will go unresolved and unanswered.

title: Attorney and His Wife Arraigned on Drug Charge
description: A Manhattan attorney and his wife were arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on a narcoticsconspiracy indictment.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: HENRY FORD 2d urged President Ford to develop a program to avert a prolonged and deepening economic crisis. ... President Ford said he would not introduce any major antirecession program even as economists Arthur M. Okun and Otto Eckstein were telling Congress there should be a major switch In national policy to stimulate the economy. . . . Ford auto dealers called on the Ford Motor Companly to cut the wholesale price to stimulate sales, but the company was cool to the suggestion.

title: Nets Top Colonels For No. 8
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.Julius Erving unveiled another of his many skills tonight as the New York Nets solidified their hold on first place in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division by beating the secondplace Kentucky Colonels, 9889.

title: Women's Groups Upset by Delay on a Replacement for Mrs. Kuykendall
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's nine women legislators demanded last week that Governor Byrne nominate a new director of the state's Division on Women to replace Mrs. Penelope Kuykendall, who removed herself as a nominee for the post.

title: Soviet Six Triumphs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14 (AP)The Soviet national hockey team, with two goals each from Valeri Kharlamov and Alexander Gusev, defeated Sweden, 52, today.

title: Sally Kil burn Bride Of John Deuchler
description: Sally Kilburn, daughter of Mrs. Russell Robert Kilburn of Mount Kisco, N. Y., and the late Mr. Kilburn, was married here yesterday afternoon to John Albert Deuchler, son of Mrs. Philip George Deuchler of Los Gatos, Calif., and the late Mr. Deuchler. Msgr. John J. Barry performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Rosemary Nicholls Is Wed to Richard R. Vietor
description: Rosemary Schmitt Nicholls and Richard Robinson Vietor, an investment officer with the First National City Bank, were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Lawrence Prast performed the ceremony.

title: Christmas vs. Inflation: Buying Is Off
description: WAYNE  As Christmas approaches, shopping centers across the state report improving sales, but many expect a lower volume of business than last year because of inflation and rising unemployment.

title: Idaho's Senator Church Weighs Presidential Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, said today he was considering making a race for the 1976 Democratic presidential nomination, but stressed he was not close to a decision.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Freshly cut wood burns very slowly because of its high moisture content and the heat given off is 60% of that from seasoned wood. Anywhere from onefourth to onehalf of live hardwood weight is water. For logs to burn efficiently, this moisture should be svaporated (a process called seasoning) before use in the fireplace. Green wood carries a much higher content of wood tar or creosote which condenses on chimneys and causes soot buildup.

title: S. R. Braun Fiance Of Pamela Piszel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Piszel of Rutherford, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Piszel, to Shelley R. Braun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Braun of Upper Brookville, L. I.

title: HOUSING IS TARGET OF ROME PROTESTS
description: ROME, Dec. 14On the Capitoline Hill, overlooking the Roman Forum, a Christmas tree festooned with photographs of slum dwellings stands not far from the entrance to City Hall.

title: Venezuelan Oil to Finance Coffee Price Plan
description: PUERTO ORDAZ, Venezuela, Dec. 14 (UPI)The presidents of six central American countries and Venezuela signed an agreement here today to cut coffee exports in order to increase world prices.

title: Stanford Raises Tuition
description: STANFORD, Dec. 14 (UPI)Stanford University trustees have increased tuition by $435 a year beginning next fallthe largest tuition increase in the school's history. Tuition rose from $3,375 to $3,810.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Seek Aid for Water System
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 14Declaring that the complexity and interrelated nature of Long Island's water  supply problems preclude piecemeal solution, Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso said this week that Nassau and Suffolk Counties had applied for a $9.6million Federal grant for a comprehensive planning and water management program.

title: BONUS FOR WORK GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP The Senate Finance Committee approved today a $600millionayear work bonus program of special Government assistance to the working poor.

title: VALD A SETTERFIELD AND GORDON REUNITE
description: David Gordon and Valda Setterfield, comic dance team of the early nineteensixties, reunited Friday evening at Paula Cooper's Gallery to present two of Mr. Gordon's newest pieces.

title: Ulster Policeman Slain
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 14 (AP)Guerrillas ambushed and killed a policeman today and critically wounded a British soldier, officials said. The policeman and soldier were leaving a house near Forkhill, 40 miles south of Belfast, after investigating breakin when they were fired on by machine guns and rifles, authorities said.

title: Banking's Cautious Colossus
description: TOKYODaiIchi Kangyo Ginko, the bank with a heart, recently marked the third anniversary of the merger that made it Japan's largest bank but it is just now getting around to going through the real pains inevitable in a merger.

title: Israelis Kill 4 Arab Raiders And Lose Sergeant in Battle
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 14Israeli forces intercepted and killed four Arab infiltrators today in a gun battle in the Galilean hills, the Israeli command said.

title: Psychoanalyst Says Nay To Equus
description: Why should a psychoanalyst like myself be analyzing Peter Shaffer's new hit play Equus? Simply because the play paints a picture of the psychoanalytic process that demands a professional response.

title: TUSKEGEE DISPUTE NEAR SETTLEMENT
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 14 (AP)A multimillion dollar damage suit filed, against the United States Government as a result of the Tuskegee syphilis experiment has for all practical purposes been settled out of court, a Federal Attorney says.

title: Future Social Events
description: A Rite of Rights

title: Concert: New Virtuosi
description: A new chamber orchestra, the Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York, introduced itself Friday night in a concert given in the Great Hall of the Cooper Union. The ensemble is made up of members of the New York Philharmonic and is conducted by Richard Kapp.

title: Rufus Davis, Actor, Dead; Petticoat Junction Figure
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI)Rufus Davis, a character actor who played an engineer on the old Petticoat Junction television series, died yesterday at the Little Company of Mary Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Sylvia Rubin Is Married
description: Sylvia Marcus Rubin of Scarsdale, N. Y., widow of David Rubin, a lawyer, was married here last evening to Victor Whitehorn of New York, a partner in the law firm of Whitehorn & Delman. State Supreme Court Justice William T. Cowin performed the ceremony at the Russell Hotel.

title: Motot Home Blues on A Shakedown Cruise
description: THE seven Statmans vacation in motels or on cruise ships. That's the way my wife, Dolores, wants it; there's never been any argument from our five boys or me. Then, last summer, egged on by friends, we decided on a change of pacea camping trip. So it shouldn't be too much of a cultureshock, we also decided to enter upon the nomadic life with a little bit of luxury.

title: What's Doing in WESTCHESTER
description: GETTING AROUND  The 435 square miles of Westchester County, bounded by New York City, the Hudson River, Connecticut and New York's Putnam County, is known largely as a residential region, but there's a lot mere to if than suburban homes and wellkept lawns. There, are hilly woodlands, country estates, lakes, restorations that bring to life the Revolutionary era, and post roads linking communities that once echoed to the tramp of British regulars, Hessian mercenaries and Washington's Continental Army. These days the county is laced with good highways, a boon to visitors who are hunting for houses or antiques, calling at historic sites or merely touring through the countryside. Unlike the county's Interstate highways, the older parkwaysthe Hutchinson River, Bronx River, Saw Mill River and Taconic Statewere intended for casual travel. The Bronx River Parkway, in fabt, was the world's first automobile parkway and is just 50 years old this year. Although parts of it ate being improved, much of its length from the Bruckner Expressway in the Bronx to the Hawthorne interchange above White Plains offers the same vistabridges, waterfalls, ponds, wildfowl and sculptured landscapeavailable a half century ago to the original Sunday drivers. Farther north, State Route 100 and U.S. 202 open the way to valleys and quiet villages, and convenient access to the parkways or highways for a quick return to the city. An interesting drive through somewhat busier villages is along U.S. 9, which follows the Hudson River and links several of Westchester's sights. You can follow the route north to the Peekskill area, branch off on US. 6 for the Bear Mountain Bridge, and return to New. York on the opposite Hudson shore (US. 9W) or, more speedily, via the Palisades Parkway. State Route 22 is an allseason scenic route, from Kensico Dam (north of White Plains) northward.

title: Economic First Aid
description: With the recession getting worse faster than almost anyone had anticipated, Congress took its first major step last week to help those who are being hurt the most: the nation's almost 6,000,000 unemployed.

title: This Orchestra has 24 Conductors
description: A program is coming to Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night called Music Minus One. It has nothing to do with the recordings that bear this titlerecordings with one part of an ensemble per formance missing so that the homegrown musician can play along in the missing part. The Minus One in this instance is the conductor, and what will make the occasion special is that the group to appear, the Orpheus Chamber Ensemble, is 24 players strong, There may be other ensembles as large who perform in public without someone to wave his hands or a baton at them, but if there are they have not made themselves known here.

title: The blue and the gray ran crimson
description: After writing five novels, one of which, Shiloh, dealt with the Civil War, Mississippiborn Shelby Foote was asked by a New York publisher to write a short, onevolume history of that conflict. Foote agreed. It seemed nice change of pace before his next novel. Now, 20 years later, the project is completed: three volumes (the third appears this month), 2,934 pages, million and a half words. It is a remarkable achievement, prodigiously researched, vigorous, detailed, absorbing.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Books on coin collecting offer an unbeatable combination for Christmas giftgiving: They are easy to buy, sure to please and less expensive than most coins.

title: Public's Right to Know: How Much? About Whom?
description: WASHINGTONIn a philosopher's ideal society, every citizen would be able to keep from general circulation strictly personal information. At the same time, The press would be free to report all facts, so long as the report was accurate and without malice, on the theory that the more knowledge available to the community, the better it can govern its affairs.

title: ROBERT HERWIG, 60, ALLAMERICA CENTER
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI)Robert J. Herwig, a member of the National Football Hall of Fame and twice an AllAmerica center at the University of California, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: Killings of Officers Studied
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 14, (UPI)More law enforcement officers were killed in Georgia this year than in any other state in the nation, the head of the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said this week. A bureau study shows that 12 officers were killed in Georgia in 1974, compared with 8 in 1973 and 6 in 1972, The figure included officers killed while off duty.

title: DR. ELMER KLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Dr. Elmer Kline, a fellow of the American Psychiatric Association, died today at the Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. His age was 78.

title: A Must
description: I read a book I'd like to recommend. is towering. It matters. Everything proved upon the pulses. It strikes at the center of our lives. You'll discover where you've been sexually and where you're going. So shattering is the book that raises numerous questions about the very future of books. The author circles you and hits you if you're not careful. The book is pure, that is to say, necessary. The author sees around corners. There's enough collapsing history in it. I had the sense of being taken for a wonderful ride. The book explodes the cherished notions. It is laced with trenchancy. You'll fall in love with Rimaldi, a little Italian hill town. What we have here are words that put their clothes on. The book is almost unbearably diverting. A sprawling threnody of suffused feelings. It is, quite simply, the book you and I have been waiting for.

title: INJUNCTION PLANNED TO END COAL DISPUTE
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 (UPI) Coal mining companies, including major steel manufacturers, plan to seek more court injunctions next week to force an end to picketing by mine construction workers. The picketing has snagged coal production, and idled thousands of miners.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The average American is a sucker for anything described as, homemade. Slap that label on candy, cookies, ice cream, canned soups and even though the American consumer is aware the product was turned out in a kitchen the size of Kankakee, and distributed by an organization as large and complex as General Motors, he'll buy it, no matter what it tastes like. Homemade answers a kind of longing. It evokes earlier, safer times when food preservatives didn't cause cancer, when moral codes were supposedly uncomplicated and when it seemed to be possible to get a definite fix on the identities of heroes and villains.

title: The 22yearold virgin who made up for lost time
description: There is almost nothing in this life of which you can say Hugh Hefner deserves better. The daffy Playmate of the Month captions apart, the editor and publisher of Playboy appears deficient only in unauthorized biographies. Hefner's Gonna Kill Me When He Reads This, last season's execrable expos by Steve Byer, shouldn't happen to Victor Lasky. When Hefner read galleys of Frank Brady's Hefner, he wanted to kill again. Rather than threaten millions in libel action, the bashful biographee would have been smarter to stay in bed.

title: Deborah R. Huff, a Geologist, Is Betrothed to F. C. Gevalt 3d
description: Deborah Robinson Huff, a staff geologist with Haley & Aldrich Inc., engineering firm in Cambridge, Mass., and Frederick Conrad Gevalt 3d, a candidate, for a master's degree in architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, have made plans to be married next June.

title: SOLID GOLD EVENING FILLS GARDEN AGAIN
description: Madison Square Garden was full again for an Evening of Solid Gold, with Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons as the headliners, supported by Jay Black, Tommy James and the Four Tops, The place was full the last time they appeared and the time before that. It will probably be full next time, too, because this exercise in creeping nostalgia is one of New York's really successful bubblegum rock attractions.

description: Tomorrow, Dec. 16

title: Point of View
description: The following article is by the president of Kreisler Borg Florman Construction Company, which is building the 625apartment Marcus Garvey Village lowincome housing in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: HOW TO RUN ON TV
description: Michael Dukakis, incoming Governor of Massachusetts, said recently, TV news is the most important part of the campaign. No one really believes the paid ads any more. Hundreds of candidates in the last election knew that and vied to get television coverage. Some got it; some did not. The ones who did understood TV. In coming elections, such understanding will be even more crucial because the new campaign reform laws impose spending limits so absurdly low that most candidates will be unable to afford TV advertising.

title: Air Force Six Romps
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Dec. 14, (AP)Chuch Delich scored three goals to lead Air Force to a 151 shellacking of Iowa State in college hockey today.

title: Aome Clinic
description: Q: My walls are made of gypsum board (dry wall) and were covered with wallpaper. I have speckled and painted over them several times, but each time the patches bleed through the paint after several months. Also small imperfections always show up. Is there some treatment or cover paint I can use to cover these before I paint again?

title: Marcos Frees 454 More Held Under Martial Law
description: MANILA, Dec. 14 (AP)President Ferdinand E. Marcos today ordered the release of 454 more martiallaw detainees. The action brought to 1,076 the number of detainees ordered released since he announced his regime's policy of reconciliation, solidarity and brotherhood on Wednesday.

title: New Limits on Smoking
description: MONTREAL (AP)Air Canada is increasing seating spacer reserved for non  smokers. Since 1971, 2535 per cent of its passenger seats have been off limits to smokers. That portion. is being increased to 4350 per cent.

description: At this time of year when holiday shows, burdened with sentimentality and tinsel, reach out from screens everywhere to grope for the heartstrings while hitting the pocket, the Film Forum has come up with what surely must be the season's most literal, provocative and refreshingly astringent example of the genre.

title: Delicious News: Breakthrough in Eliminating Apple Diseases
description: Apple diseases, particularly apple scab are difficult to control. Every home orchardist who has tried to grow apples in the Northeast knows how difficult it is. At the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station, Geneva, and at other experiment stations much work is in progress to produce apples that are resistant to scab and other diseases. Good progress is being made and is evidenced by the introduction of two scab resistant varietiesPrima and Priscilla.

title: Calder Stars in Fair Lawn Exhibition
description: FAIR LAWNAs part of its continuing, and often controversial, campaign to bring art out of the galleries and into the lives of ordinary citizens, the Fair Lawn Public Library is playing host to a major mobile by Alexander Calder.

title: Book Ends
description: Plathiana. Back in 1971, when her novel The Bell Jar appeared in this country and went on to best sellerdom, Sylvia Plath became a posthumous literary sensation. The tide of renown has ebbed somewhat but the interest perks on, and there are at least four books on her in varying stages of preparation. A biography by Edward Butscher is scheduled for August, 1975 publication by Continuum Books, and two others, one by Harriet Rosenstein (a critical biography for Knopf) and the other by Lois Ames (Harper & Row); are in the works. And next spring Harper & Row will publish a collection of Miss Plath's letters, edited by her mother, Aurelia Plath, and entitled Letters Home. Frances McCullough Mrs. Plath's editor, learned of the letters from Lois Ames and asked Mrs. Plath to let her read them. She thought they were a book and persuaded Mrs. Plath to allow publication. The next steps were winnowing down the mass of material (there were over 1,000 letters) to book size and getting permission from Miss Plath's husband, Ted Hughes. The selection process took two and in the meantime Mr. Hughes's imprimatur came through with minimal deletions of incidents relating to the couple's children. The final book wilt contain some 400 letters, almost all of them written to Mrs. Plath, plus 60 pictures, some from a scrapbook Miss Plath kept in high school. Miss Math was a prolific letter writer, averaging three or four a week, with many eight to 10 pages long, and enjoyed a close, open relationship with her mother. The letters, which span the period 1950 to 1963, the year of her death by suicide, speak freely of poetry in progress, love affairs, her married life, her fits of depression and elation. The letters have a fantastic sense of immediacy as if you'd just ripped open the envelope, Mrs. McCullough said. They also convey an obsession with death, and in one Miss Plath inquires about the proper dose of sleeping pills so that she won't take an overdoseat least not yet, she adds lightly.

title: U.N. REPORTS GAINS FOR BLACKS IN U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 14A United Nations report says that the economic situation of blacks and other ethnic minorities in the United States has improved significantly in recent years, diminishing the social basis of racial discrimination.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Senate Finance Committee, meeting in private, approved legislation today that would preserve beyond the present Dec. 31 expiration date some special tax advantages accorded to the railroad, coal and real estate industries.

description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIPAcquisition by the state of the 2,900 acres it needs in this Somerset County community in order to start building the longawaited Six Mile Run Reservoir is now 95 per cent complete, but construction funds are nowhere in sight.

description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 14President Ford, who arrived hire today for talks with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France, is reportedly prepared to reach an accommodation with the French on the touchy issue of cooperation among the major oilconsuming nations.

description: NEWARKA program designed to help offenders on probation has attracted about 200 volunteer workers since its inception a year ago.

title: Company Threatens Lockout
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP) The McDonnell Douglas Company said yesterday that it might lock out 18,000 union workers at five Southern California facilities before Christmas in an effort to move stalled contract talks. A union official said that the company had been warned that if workers were locked out the union would file suit contending that the action was illegal.

description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9The battle for the official nomination to succeed President Luis Echeverrfa Alvarez has come into the open, two years before his term expires.

description: The City Planning Commission is to announce a set of proposals this week aimed at preserving the Brooldyn community of Brighton Beach.

description: A proposal to help former mental patients from Creedmoor State Hospital return a normal life through the of supervised halfway houses in Queens is being considered by community boards in borough.

title: Poconos Resort Hotel Burns
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa., Dec. 14 (AP)A twoalarm fire early today destroyed the Blue Ridge Inn, a resort hotel in the Poconos closed for the winter. A fire official, said that area residents bad reported hearing an explosion shortly before the alarm was turned in at 2 a.m.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN their public statements and in private conversations recently, many leading businessmen, economists, labor leaders and other critics of the nation's economic policies have concentrated on one central theme: the lack of forceful leadership by the Ford Administration in addressing itself to the gravity of current problems.

title: Newspaper Strike Continues
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 (UPI)Members of the Newspaper Guild unit at the Cleveland Plain Dealer unit voted 111 to 94 today to reject a contract offer for a second time and continue the newspaper strike that is in its 44th day. Fiftythree guild members, dissatisfied with the voice vote rejection on Nov. 1 when the strike began, petitioned for the secret balloting.

description: The following public hearings and regular meeting will be conducted by City Council and Council committees this week:

title: GEORGE BALL SAYS ISRAEL MAY STRIKE
description: George Ball, former Under Secretary of State, warned yesterday of the possibility of preemptive Israeli military strike next spring against Syria and possibly Egypt.

title: Redmen, Jaspers Beaten
description: St. John's University has been playing basketball since the season of 190708, but the Redmen had never faced a Rutgers team before last night at Madison Square Garden. Now the Redmen probably wished it hadn't happened. Rutgers took command early and coasted to an 8574 triumph, the fifth victory in six games for Coach Tom Young and his Scarlet team. A crowd of 10,181 watched.

title: Hot to Trot
description: In John Lahr's first novel The Autograph Hound, published last year, his bus boy protagonist wins an employes' betting pool because the number punched on his timecard matches the Pentagon's Vietnamese body count for the week preceding. He splits the take with a fellow worker whose card is closest to the number of American casualties. Whether you think that idea is funny or just sickeningly glib will have a good deal to do with how you take Hot to Trot, which has all the virtues and faults of a genre in which Lahr may be the sole practitioner: the Hollywood novel about New York.

title: A Stylish Program On Piano Is Played By Murray Perahia
description: Murray Perahia had a cleverly conceived program for his piano recital Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum, and he dispatched it with the stylishness for which he has become known.

description: HICKSVILLE As long as the register in their new stereo component stone is rink ing, Stanley Bindas and ha partners will not mind the tired jokes:

description: When Arthur F. Burns said early this month that it would really not bother me if Middle Eastern investors acquired control of such nondefense companies as the Quaker Oats Company, the initial response of the Chicagobased producer of groceries and toys was casual.

title: Ford Foundation; To Stash, Grants Over Next 4 Years
description: The Ford Foundation, the wealthiest philanthropic institution in the country, announced yesterday that it would reduce its annual grants over the next four years from $208million to $100million.

title: SUPPORT IS SOUGHT FOR '75 U.J.A. GOAL
description: American Jews were asked yesterday to intensify their support of the newly established United Jewish Appeal pal for 1975 of $750million to meet Jewish needs the world over, including the expected influx of 60,000 Russian Jews into Israel next year.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 14 (AP)With temperatures soaring to a reported 125 degrees, Guillermo Vilas of Argentina defeated Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 46, 63, 62, 75, in a threehour battle today to reach the final of the $100,000 Commercial Union Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament.

description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 14President Ford arrived here today for talks tomorrow and Monday with President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France on a wide range of political and economic issues.

description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 14 In a split decision today, a threejudge Federal panel declared unconstitutional AlaMina's laws governing the commitment of mentally disturbed persons.

description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14In an unusual sort of way, the pressure again will be on the St. Louis Cardinals tomorrow afternoon at Busch Stadium against the New York Giants (2 P.M., Eastern standard time, Channel 2), which is fine with Coach Don Coryell.

description: MORRISTOWNThe Morris County Park Commission resumed yesterday its program of distributing free firewood. The next distribution dates are Jan. 18 and Feb. 15.

He is a son of Willard Porter Hovey Jr. of San Marino, Calif., and Armene Lamson Norris of New York.

title: Rocky Hill Show Lures Rail Buffs
description: ROCKY HILLThe curtain comes down today on the 11th annual Christmas show of the HOGauge Pacific. Southern Railway, New Jersey's largest model railroad, and the charity event hopes to set an attendance record. Last weekend alone, more than 1,200 youngsters and young  in  heart adults climbed aboard.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: When the Metropolitan Opera announced that it would stage a new production of the original Boris Godunovthe premiere is tomorrow nightthere were some knowing smiles. Nobody, after all, does the original. The last time the Metropolitan Opera announced an otiginal version of the great Mussorgsky opera, it was presented in a score heavily edited by Karol Rathaus. And, come to think of it, what original? There are two versions, those of 1869 and 1872, and there are substantial differences between those two original versions.,Thus, all Borislovers were entitled to some skepticism at the Metropolitan's announcement. In addition, experienced conductors for years have been telling us that the original orchestrations do not work. Mussorgsky, they say, genius though he may have been, was a rotten orchestrator, and the score needs to be touched up to make it sound.

description: SoltiThe Recorded Image Of a Powerhouse Conductor

title: Welfare and Pension Swindle Laid to Woman of Many Aliases
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14, (AP) A 47yearold Chicago woman, possibly using as many as 80 different names, allegedly siphoned hundreds of thousands of dollars from welfare and Social Security funds, the authorities say.

title: Man Forces, Florida Pilot To Fly From Tampa to Cuba
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) A twinengine aircraft was hijacked in Tampa late today by a gunman who forced the pilot to fly to Cuba, Federal officials said.

title: Child to Marshall Fields
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field on Wednesday at the PresbyterianSt. Luke's Hospital in Chicago. The child has been named for her mother, the former Jamee Beckwith Jacobs. Mr. Field is chairman of Field Enterprises, Inc., and publisher of The Chicago SunTimes and The Chicago Daily News. He is a greatgreatgrandson of the original Marshall Field, the merchant.

title: Walter Lippmann, Political Analyst, Dead at 85
description: Walter Lippmann, the retired columnist and author who was the dean of American political journalism in the 20th century, died of a heart ailment yesterday morning at a private nursing home at 755 Park Avenue, He was 85 years old.

description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14persistent drought in the most fertile grainproducing areas of Argentina has led to fears among agricultural experts here that the country will not be able to relieve significantly the worsening food situation elsewhere in the world.

title: Barbara Lassus Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Laurent M. Lassus of Wantagh, L. ?? have announced the enga??ment of their daughter, Barbara Joan Lassus, to William E. Schnitzel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Schnitzel of Bay Shore, L. I. Miss Lassus is a senior at Hofstra University, where her fianc received a degree.

title: Unnecessarily Cruel To Scientists
description: Primate, a new film for television by Frederick Wiseman, has raised a storm of controversy. The film deals with the work being conducted at the Yerkes Primate Research Center at Emory University in Atlanta, and it shows a number of laboratory experiments with gorillas, chimpanzees and monkeys, including some involving surgery and decapitation. It was first broadcast over the Public Broadcasting Service network on Dec. 5 and is to be repeated on Jan. 6 at 10 P.M. A debate between the filmmaker and Dr. Geoffrey H. Bourne, director of the center, scheduled for Dec. 9, was canceled when Dr. Bourne refused to dignify the film by discussing it on television. [A letter from Dr. Bourne appears on this page.]

title: Scolding The New Majority
description: The United Nations General Assembly, in its 29th session, has often acted unwisely and vindictively, and it is probably true, as Ambassador John Scali warned, that American support for the world organization is eroding. But when was. American support for the U.N.among the people and in Washingtonnot eroding? And whatever its provocation, Mr. Scali's scolding speech was an implicit threat to pick up the American marbles and go home, if the United States had to be part of an offended minority in the General Assembly.
