William Slavin of Troy, N. Y.

title: Matra Drops Out of Racing After a Decade of Success
description: PARIS, Dec. 14We have written a page of history. Now it is time to close the book. And so saying, Matra announced this week that it was retiring from racing. The French blue cars that have won the last three 24hour races at Le Mans and the last two world manufacturers' championships had run out of competition. We had nothing more to prove, said JeanLuc Lagardre, the company's director of racing, in making the expected announcement.

title: Moynihan, Leaving India Melancholy on U.S. Ties
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 14United States Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan is leaving India in a melancholy mood. He says that his own task is finished but that relations with India seem fragile and thin.

title: Anne Matson Edwards Fiancee Of Thomas Bayard McCabe 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. James C. Edwards of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have announced the engagement of their, daughter, Anne Matson Edwards, to Thomas Bayatd McCabe 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McCabe Jr. of Wallingford, Pa. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Let's hear it for the eager beaver
description: In Albany a bill has been introduced in the Legislature which would name the beaver New York's official state mammal. An authority on the beaver like Dr. Lars Wilsson, the Swedish biologist, doubtlessly would feel this does small credit to beavers. In fact, to anyone who contends that beavers are like people, Dr. Wilsson is apt to reply that such a statement flatters mankind. For, though some of us have acquired traits that have proved to have high survival value for beavers, all beavers are notable for cleanliness, diligence, community spirit, cohesive family life, adaptability, ingenuity and thrift.

title: Beame Will Seek More Control Over Hospital Agency's Budget
description: Mayor Beame has ordered his staff to prepare state legislation to give his offive more control over the budget of the city's quasi independent Health and Hospitals Corporation, which this week failed to respond to Mr. Beame's request to drop 551 provisional jobs to help meet the city's budget gap.

title: Key Words at Art Auctions: Let the Bidder Be Wary
description: RIVERHEAD  When Fay Millian and Rochelle Kerchner went to a charity art auction a year ago they had no intention of bidding on anything.

title: Best Seller List
ARABS DENY ROLE IN STERLING DROP
description: VIENNA, Dec. 14Ahmed Zaki Yemeni, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum, said today that it was the action of American oil companies, and not of Arab oil producers, that produced a sharp drop in the British pound this week.

title: For Christmas, Tips on Bike Safety
description: Bicycles rate high on Christmas lists for adults and children, and tile Foundation for Safety, Inc., an affiliate of the New Jersey Auto Club, has provided some guidelines for prospective purchasers.

title: David F. Merrall Dead at 70; President of the Rhodes School
description: David F. Merrall, president of the Rhodes School, died Friday evening of a heart ment at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at the Warwick Hotel.

title: Books on Dog Training Are Timely Presents
description: With the Yuletide season approaching, this is the time of year fanciers think of books that would make good presents. Several dogtraining works have made their appearance and they come at a particularly opportune time, since the revised obedience regulations for American Kennel Club trials go into effect Jan. 1. Then there are diversified volumes covering medical advice, grooming, and for the photo mindedpicture books.

title: Pearlman Art Collection: Eloquent
description: PRINCETON  The Henry Pearlman art collection, now on display at the Princeton University Art Museum, is an eloquent tribute to taste.

title: H.E.W. Study Finds Day Care Centers Endanger Children
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) Many children in day care programs are exposed to poisons and other dangers, Government report says.

title: New & Novel
description: It's an old, old story, but a continuing one: love of the land versus love of the buck. Here's a bright, resourceful, slightly depressed man carving out a life for himself and family on 50 rural acres of upstate land. Arne Markowitz has shucked a career in highenergy physics to paint and to build a home out of natural materials such as purloined paving stones, and live as close to the life cycle as he can get. Arne drinks homemade apple wine and has his antennae out for the unforeseen, which materializes as inevitably as Murphy's Law. (If something can go wrong, it will.) Land developers and highway planners are formidable enemies for a man who has only his Angst and an old college classmate for a lawyer. As the painter learns, to his mounting bitterness, America's roads are paved with conflicts of interest. Mr. Lieberman, who is shrewd enough to live in Sweden, develops his hero's fight against the highway interests into a tragicomedy of manners. He has a sharp eye for the incongruous and the humor that can accompany desperate happenings.

title: Music: 4 Sacred Pieces
description: Toward the end of his life, Verdi composed four short choral works. Two were written between his final operas, Otello and Falstaff, and two after, the last becoming his final creations. Like the operas, they are pieces of consummate beauty and extraordinary originality.

title: DR. E. L. ROTHENBERG
description: Dr. Eleanor Levin Rothenberg, a clinical psychologist who received a doctorate from Yeshiva University in 1968 at the age of 62, despite having been confined to a wheelchair since 1957 by multiple sclerosis, died Friday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Her age was 70.

title: Capitals Bow, 121, To Bruins
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)The Boston Bruins, behind twogoal efforts from Bobby Orr, Don Marcotte, and Andre Sevard, registered their fourth straight victory tonight in 121 rout of the Washington: Capitals in a National Hockey League game.

title: Insomniacs Of the World, Goodnight
description: No small art is it to sleep, Nietzsche candidly assessed, it is necessary to keep awake all day for that purpose. Sleep, like most basic, expected and even ritualistic events in life, assumes greater importance only when it is lacking. And for those who suffer from its chronic omission, sleep is of very great importance. Hilary Rubenstein, author and editor of Insomniacs of the World, Goodnight, calculates that people who have never had a bad night's sleep in their life cannot possibly imagine the sense of martyrdom of the severe insomniac.

title: The Ablest Mind ...
description: Lincoln Steffens went to Harvard in 1910 to recruit journalism the ablest mind that could express itself writing. The career of Walter Lippmann, Steffens's choice, who died here in the city of his birth yesterday at the age of 85, testifies to the extraordinary success of that enlightened quest.

title: Letters: Defenders of Martinique Speak
description: To the Editor: Edmund Morris's tale of woe in MarUnique: A Vain Quest for Quiet (Travel Section, Dec. 1) does little to disprove that Martinique has warm sunshine, haute cuisine and tranquillityas promised by his travel agent. It does suggest, however, that some people always get the soup spilled on them, whereas others, perhaps, lead a more charmed life.

title: Disclaimer Ordered or Drug Used in Antifat Clinics
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration has announced that a drug produced from the urine of pregnant women must bear a label saying that it is worthless for weight loss.

title: Isn't It About Time To Bring on The Girls?
description: The lady has vanished. In Hollywood's golden age, movis marquees glittered with the names of love goddesses like Garbo, Dietrich, Harlow, Hayworth, Lamarr, Turner and Grable. But in our less glamorous era, the goddesses have been dethroned by the gods, and the cinematic love object tend to have names liks Redford, Newman, McQueen, Eastwood, Nicholson, Hackman; Pacino, Hoffman, Beatty, Caan . . . and even Woody Allen.

title: HEFNER IS SILENT ONDRUGS INQUIRY
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14Hugh M. Hefner, publisher of Playboy magazine, generally sought to maintain his silence this weekend as Federal officials looked into allegations of use of narcotics in Playboy mansions in Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Stonecrops Grow Well With Little Care
description: Succulents (fleshyleaved plants) are found in a number of plant families. The stonecrops (Sedum) have over 350 species of them Some are hardy and grow well in rock gardens or among perennials. A number are excellent house plants for terrariums or hanging baskets.

title: Reverberations of 1971 Attica Prison Riot Persist 3 Years Later
description: ATTICA, N.Y. (AP)  Frank Strollo, a prison officer, squatted naked in the center of D yard, his eyes blindfolded, his hands tied. Fortyone others shivered alongside him on that cold September morning.

title: Data Processors Offer a Bill To Regulate Use of Computers
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 UPI][Growing concern about computer crime and peoples' right to privacy has led members of the data processing industry to sponsor legislation to regulate the use of computers.

title: LENINGRAD CALLED PARASITE SOURCE
description: Two Finnish doctors hay made a study that supports United States Public Healt Service warning that tourist to Leningrad stand, a risk picking up a stubborn parasitic infection that can cause chronic intestinal symptoms.

title: A Young Boxer From Glen Cove Keeps Adding New Titles
description: GLEN COVEHoward Davis Jr., an 18yearold boxer here, who added another championship to his string of titles when he won the featherweight title at the first amateur boxing world championships in Havana last August, is looking forward to the 1976 Olympics.

title: Racing Kap Wins In Jersey Futurity
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J. Dec. 14 (AP)Darrel McHargue was aboard five winners in eight races at Garden State Park today, including Bernadotte Stable's Racing Kap in the $34,360 New Jersey Futurity. McHargue also won both halves of the $21 daily double with Petrous ($4.20) in the first and Mitchell's Roman ($10.20) in the second. He then won the sixth with Gotoun ($4.20), the seventh aboard Game Lad ($4.20), and the feature for 2yearold Jerseybred horses.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Greece, Dec. 14 (AP)  Premier Constantine Caramanlis won his first vote of confidence today since his resounding victory at the polls three weeks ago.

title: Stanford Raises Tuition
description: STANFORD, Dec. 14 (UPI)Stanford University trustees have increased tuition by $435 a year beginning next fallthe largest tuition increase in the school's history. Tuition rose from $3,375 to $3,810.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: STOLports are an almost Indestructible grist in the paper mills of metropolitan New York planners. The idea of a downtown airport, to eliminate the long ground travel from jetport to center city, has wide appeal.

title: Diane Franklin Engaged
description: Mr, and Mrs, Daniel Franklin of Glendale, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Claire Franklin, to Robert E. Woods, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Woods of Valley Stream, L.I. Miss Franklin, a summa cum laude graduate of Queens College, is a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Yale. Her fianc, also a Queens graduate, expects to receive a degree in accounting from St. John's University this month. A January marriage is planned.

title: Study Finds Vocational Programs Are Deficient
description: Posthighschool vocational training programs, both public and private, are failing to lead substantial numbers of disadvantaged students into betterpaying and higherstatus jobs, according to a study published by the Center for Research and Development in Higher Education.

title: Inflation Hurts India's Middle Class
description: CALCUTTAFor 30 years, Nirman De Sil has struggled to earn a living in a shop on Beadon Street.

title: The central problem of the decade
description: There probably has not been a single year in recorded history where food shortages and famines have not occurred somewhere in the world; droughts, great natural catastrophes, locusts and blights, wars and civil disorders have been and will continue to be major causes of mass starvation. But even in the face of this melancholy record, 1972 stands as a landmark: crcps failed or were inadequate in sevaral major subcontinental areas: the Soviet Union, China, the Indian peninsula, the Sahel. The Soviet leaders, faced, if not with a caloric shortage for their people, at least with a sudden downgrading of a diet increasingly rich in animal products, went massively into the market. Aided by the recent (and probably, retrospectively, illtimed) devaluation of the dollar, the Soviet Union bought almost 30 million tons of United States grain, in secrecy and at an unreasonably low price level, supported by unwarranted Govern**ment subsidies.

title: Bitterness Grows Over Raid on Home
description: MINEOLAThe shooting and attempted murder of two Mount Vernon, N.Y. policemen last year during an attempted holdup has developed into a cause clbre in Nassau County involving court actions, bitterness and strained relations between some black groups and the county police.

title: Study Weighs Pros and Cons of Curbing Urban Growth
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The knotty problems involved in controlling land development are dealt with at length in New Dimensions of Man Planning: Growth Control, a book published recently by the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University.

title: Seeing Through the Subtlety
description: The people who design and build model homes have some firm ideas about how the potential buyer should approach such places. The customer's first consideration, they agree, should be the reputation and previous record of the builder. If that is satisfactory, they advise that the buyer take these steps in inspecting a model home:

title: Stores Turn to OldFashioned Displays for Holidays
description: OYSTER BAY  Flashing lights and silver trees are not much in evidence in village shop windows here this year. Nor is the main commercial thoroughfare, South Street, strung with its usual festival lights.

title: His Thought and Writings Are Very Much Alive Today
description: WASHINGTONThe news is that Walter Lippmann is dead, but the meaning of the news, which always interested him more than the headlines, is a little different. For Walter Lippmann lived for his thought. He merely used the news of the day to illustrate his philosophy of the age, and more than any other journalist of the 20th century, his thought and writings endure. In this sense, the news of his death Is wrong. His thought is very much alive, and even in his melancholy last years, this was his consolation.

title: book Unfolds nassau's Past
description: MUTTONTOWNFor any suburbanite bewildered by overlapping governments and special districts, at last there is a book explaining how things got this complex.

title: Problems Analyzed In Warren, Sussex
description: NEWTON  Faced with predictions of rapid growth, a federally funded conservation project has completed its initial analysis of the needs and problems of Warren and Sussex Counties.

title: 335 File as Archdiocese Ends Its 4Year Moratorium on Adoption Applications
description: NEWARK  Childless Roman Catholic couples in the Archdiocese of Newark, specifically those desiring to adopt youngsters, are the recipients of what for them may be the best Christmas present of all. The gift came in an announcement that, after a fouryear moratorium, Associated Catholic Charities is once again accepting applications for adoptions.

title: Letters
description: While Maya Pines (Meatless, Guiltless, Nov. 24) makes the obvious moral points with regard to eating meat in a world faced with unprecedented starvation, she only skirts an issue equally relevant which will have to be faced with the same moral poignancy. I refer to the tens of millions of dogs and cats in this country who consume three billion pounds of food yearly.

title: Sick Deer Destroyed
description: BUENA PARK, Calif., Dec. 14 (UPI)Move than half of the herd of 320 deer at Japanese Village, which closed last week because of financial difficulties, have been destroyed because they showed signs of tuberculosis. The remainder, park officials said, will be destroyed because buyers can not be found Or them.

title: Fleet Velvet Takes $113,400 Race
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)Fleet Velvet overhauled Al the Doctor in the stretch and won the $113,400 California Juvenile Stakes at Bay Meadows today by 2 lengths. Mr. Paul was second and Al the Doctor third.

title: At the Holiday Season, Remember the Neediest Cases
description: There are stretches of the city when need masquerades behind workingclass pride, and it takes a long second look to discover that the blue collar is frayed.

title: Delaware Basin Expert Doubles as Jazz Guitarist
description: WEST TRENTONDawes Thompson is the only rhythm guitar player in the world who has to worry about problems of water supply and electric power in four states.

title: Coalition Presses for Increased TV News Coverage of State
description: TRENTONThe New jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting is considering a court suit in an effort to force television stations in New York City and Philadelphia to provide more news coverage of the state.

title: AID TO WITNESSES BY U.S. DISCLOSED
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Dec. 14Prosecutors in a 1972 trial of three black activists for burning a stable have conceded that they did not disclose to defense attorneys the fact that two key state witnesses were each given $4,000 in cash from the Federal Government to obtain their testimony.

title: WE DEAL WITH EMOTIONAL FACTS
description: It's 6 o'clock, time for the evening news. Whose version do you prefer? Channel 2's Six O'Clock Report, with Jim Jensen? Eyewitness News on Channel 7 with Roger Grimsby and Bill Beutel? Or, NBC's brand new NewsCenter 4 with Chuck Scarborough and Tom Snyder. This last has already been on an hour, but its second hour is largely repeat of the first. About 2.8 million people in the metropolitan area are watching these three shows, and millions of others are watching shows much like them on other local stations throughout the country.

title: Ask and Ye Shall Receive
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Dec. 13 (AP)Most of the 38 residents who asked the police to crack down on speedsters in their neighborhood can attest to the cooperation of the police. In the last three weeks, 27 of the 38 have been issued speeding citations, the police said.

title: Fighting the F. T. C. Down to the Bottom Line
description: WASHINGTONA fierce battle between big business and the Federal Trade Commission is continuing right down to the wire.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1974

title: Korchnoi Chided by Soviet Body For Ridiculing Karpov's Chess
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14The Soviet Chess Federation publicly reproached Viktor Korchnoi today for disparaging Anatoly Karpov after their final Candidates Match last month in which Karpov became official challenger for the world chess title.

title: Napoles Wins On Knockout
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 14 (AP)Jos Napoles of Mexico retained his world welterweight boxing crown today by knocking out Horacio Saldano of Argentina in their title fight.

title: Christmas Lighting: EnergySavers And Safety Rules
description: Although government officials still emphasize the need for an active program of energy conservation by all consumers, this year the Federal Energy Administration is not requesting either voluntary or involuntary curtailment of holiday lighting. Unlike last year when the energy crisis resulted in a virtual abolishment of all home Christmas lighting, this year the lights will go on again in most homesthough the FEA still requests that homeowners use discretion and decorate tastefully, but not wastefully.

title: TRIP BY WHITLAM IRKS AUSTRALIANS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. (AP)Prime Minister Gough Whitlam set out on a fiveweek tour of Europe and Asia today in the face of criticism from newspapers, his political opposition and members of his own party who say, he should stay home at a time of economic and political crisis.

title: Chronology Covers the State's War Role
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Historical Commission, aided by a grant from the State Bicentennial Commissio, has published the first detailed chhonology of New Jersey a role in the American Revolution.

title: Program Here Finds 28% Of Surgery Unnecessary
description: More than one of four of the operations recommended to group of local union members by their original physicians were not warranted in the view of a second, consulting expert, brought in under a program aimed at preventing unnecessary surgery.

title: Big Spruce Takes Finale Easily
description: Big Spruce closed out an honest career yesterday with an easy victory under highweight in the $55,900 Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Seminar Series Celebrates Brooklyn
description: St. Joseph's College is the 19741975 host institution of a studies seminar aimed at popularizing the glories of BrooklynRest, present and future. Experts on every phase of Brooklyn's political, economic and social history are participating in the series, which, it is hoped, will be continued in future years at other host institutions.

title: ART VIEW
description: Readers of Edmund Wilson's The Shores of Light will recall the wonderful passage in his essay on Genevieve Taggard in which, to underscore the differences between the New England and the Californian temperaments, he invokes the figure of the young Californian girl who, when shown in a Spanish mission a painting of the agony of Santa Clara holding before her her severed breasts on a plate, asked innocently whether they were peaches. I thought of this story more than once whilereading Peter Plagens's new book, Sunshine Muse: Contemporary Art on the West Coast. The cultural landscape Mr. Plagens surveys is fairly strewn with peaches of this sortradical deprivations innocently, and sometimes not so innocently, mistaken for healthy growth. As a subject for criticism, the West Coast art scene is certainly not without its comic aspects, and Mr. Plagensa painter and critic who regularly reports on Los Angeles area exhibitions for Artforum in New Yorkis not the writer to miss them. He has the distinction, I believe, of being the only amusing writer ever to appear in the pages of Artforum, and while Sunshine Muse is neither as fresh nor as funny as some of his magazine piecesthe often pathetic vicissitudes of West Coast art manage at times to defeat even his capacity for high spirits he has nonetheless written a vivacious and valuable book subject.

title: Senate Cuts Off Filibuster; Voids House Busing Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Senate blocked an antibusing filibuster today and then voted to nullify a Housepassed amendment designed to curb Government enforcement of desegregation orders.

title: Rid Smith
description: It must have been 4 A.M. when Abe Saperstein lowered his round and aching carcass into bed. For weeks the Harlem Globetrotters had been playing onenight stands in the Deep South, sleeping and eating on the run, rattling through the canebrakes by day to clown the evening away in some airless armory or high school gym. There was little leisure for anyone and none at all for the fat little extrovert who was employer, father confessor and valet to the troupe. Abe Saperstein's imagination and enterprise had made a box office phenomenon of a homeless basketball team from the Savoy Ballroom in Chicago, and it was his inexhaustible energy that kept the show going. He made the bookings, handled the advertising and promotion, took care of travel arrangements, pushed tickets, counted receipts. When the others snatched a few hours' rest, their leader would be hustling around to the local newspapers and radio stations or conferring by phone New York Stockholm.** Sports of The Time

title: STAMPS
description: This is the time of year when the philatelic reference works that herald the coming of a new year have made their appearance and may now, before 1974 departs, pass in review here before taking their places as the invaluable handmaidens of the hobby.

title: Ullman Has Big Plans That Exclude Big Spending
description: WASHINGTONIt will be a new era for the Ways and Means Committee, says Representative Al Ullman, heirapparent to the chairmanship vacated by the ailing Wilbur Mills. But what kind of an era will it be?

title: Cambodia: No Light, Not Even a Tunnel
description: PHNOM PENH, CambodiaWhen a disheartened Emory Swank, American Ambassador, was finishing his tour in Cambodia last year, he held his first and only news conference and told the gathering that the war had lost all meaning.

title: That's the Way the Cooky Hangs
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y.Bear Mountain Christmas Festival is not responsible for any cooky that is Iast, stolen or damaged.

title: Slain Policewoman Seen Aid to Hiring Of Female Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The slaying of Gail Cobb, the first policewoman to die in the line of duty, prompted other police officers to accept women in law enforcement, according to an official of the Police Foundation, a nonprofit law enforcement research group.

title: College Combine Widens Aim
description: UNIONThe Consortium of East Jersey, an educational and, administrative cooperative Of Kean College, Seton Hall. University, Union College and the Union County Technical Institute, is expanding its program in the,face of New Jersey's tightening highereducation economy.

title: A Sun Bowl Loss
description: EL PASO, Tex., Dec, 14 (UPI)Harrison C. Kohl, 62year old executive director of the Sun Bowl football game for 12 years, has resigned, effective Jan. 15.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: As more and more amateur photographers become increasingly aware of the satisfaction and rewards of developing and printing their own pictures, the ranks of those who are setting up their own home darkrooms keeps increasing. Some do it because they are anxious to see the picturetaking job through from exposure to actual printing (modern color printing processes have made even this previously complicated technique simple emough for an amateur to handle easily at home); others do it because home printing gives them the chance to experiment with different types of printing papers, or with different croppings of the same negative.

title: BRIDGE
description: Many players of moderate experience are fearful about verturing into tournament play. I couldn't do it, they say, I don't understand all those modern conventions. Their fears are to a great extent. groundless, for two reasons. Even pairs who use numerous artificial devices find that they have few occasions to use Them  perhaps once or twice in a session. And when they do use them, they are required to alert the opponents. In an evening's play an average pair is unlikely anything more formidable than a negative double  that is, a takeout double of an overcall.

title: Roosevelt Handle Up As Fall Meeting Ends
description: WESTBURY, Dec. 14Roosevelt Raceway ended its fall meeting tonight and there was no cause for a wake when the final race was completed.

title: McCarron: At Laurel 4 Winners
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 14Chris McCarron, a jockey moving toward the world racewinning record of 515, rode four more winners at Laurel Race Course today and raised his total for the year to 507.

title: CONSULTANT DREW PLAN ON LAYOFFS
description: The idea of avoiding the threatened layoff of as many as 860 Civil Service workers by substituting the early retirement of older city employes was conceived by Jack Bigel, a 62yearold pension consultant who graduated from an early career as a farleftwing union organizer to become a recognized expert in labormanagement relations.

title: Kid Stuff at Christmas Time
description: Nothing could happen at this time of year that would bring youngsters as much pleasure as a real blizzardespecially one that heaps the snow in drifts, eliminates traffic, paralyzes the city for days, and turns the streets into a vast, peaceful playground. But short of thata situation which would fill the entertainment bill very nicely there are a good many shows and exhibits around New York which kids might like to go to over the Christmas holiday. Even if it snows.

title: Site Dispute On Hospital Continuing In Lawrence
description: LAWRENCE  The Village Board here is upset over what it considers a failure by Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center to accept as final the village's rejection of the hospital's proposed building site.

title: Jessica Rinaldi Is Bride
description: Jessica A. Rinaldi, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Rinaldi of Teaneck, N. J., was married yesterday morning to Julio E. de Arcos of North Yonkers, N. Y., son of Mrs. Cristina LopezOna de Arcos of Miami and the late Julio de Arcos y Romero. The Rev. John F. O'Connor performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Hackensack, N. J.

title: Chiropractor Bill Is Resisted
description: TRENTONThe state's 700 licensed chiropractors are meeting stiff resistance in their fiveyear effort to obtain legislation under which Blue Shield would pay for chiropractic services.

title: A fruitcake with Christmas spint
description: Although fruitcakes seem as American as pumpkin pie, they first came to this country with the early English settlers. Recently, in an attempt to trace the ancestry of a family fruitcake recipe that was given us years ago by a great aunt, we went browsing through Mrs. Beeton's Book of Household Management, first published in England in 1859. The dauntless Mrs. Beeton's Christmas Cake bore no resemblance to Nannie Craig's recipe, but then, a few pages later on, there was a recipe for Good Holiday Cake, which did indeed follow Nannie Craig's patternto a degree. Mrs. Beeton's recipe calls for two pounds of flour. Perish forbid! We prefer our Mississippi ancestress's version.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Religion, Privacy
description: An exhibit of Chinese archeological finds has opened at Washington's National Gallery of Art, but without the usual press preview. The gallery, on the advice of the State Department, canceled the preview rather than accede to Peking's demand that it control the guest list.

title: Oil Money Is Paying for Jets, Tanks, Ships
description: LONDONThe Middle East Problem is usually identified along the axis EgyptIsraelSyria, but another axis of tension is developing through the Persian Gulf, the result of the British withdrawal from the area in 1971. Involved are two national conflicts between Iraq and Iran and between Iraq and Kuwait, which necessarily affect other Gulf states, as well as internal insurgencies in Oman and Iraq which affect neighboring states too. These tensions create a demand for weaponry and, given the area's oil resources, are of importance to industrial nations far removed from the Gulf littoral.

title: Diagramless, 21 by 21
description: ACROSS

title: Lopsided Policy
description: Day by day it becomes more obvious that the economy is caught in a tailspin, which could become a crash if corrective action by Government is not taken in time. Yet the Ford Administration is still concentrating onesidedly on attempting to cure inflation by cutting dawn the speed of the economy even more, when recession in now as great a menace as inflation and an even more difficult one to grapple with.,

title: Labor's Pains
description: WASHINGTONOne of the givens in national politics has been the support of organized labor for the Democratic party and its candidates.

title: Most Stock Found Still Owned by Rich
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Despite a longterm trend toward ownership of corporate stock by persons in all income classes, the richest twotenths of 1 per cent of Americans owned 30 per cent of all the stock as of mid1971. The richest 1 per cent owned just over half of it.

title: Student's Forgery Perils Key Harvard Research
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15 In a bizarre twist of fate worthy of a Hitchcock film, the new law requiring colleges to allow students to see their files has indirectly led a team of Harvard biochemists to consider repudiating a major series of experiments they have performed over the last 18 months.

title: Giants Lose To Cards in 2d Half, 2614
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15In a game that seemed to mirror the season for both teams the St. Louis Cardinals recovered from a 14.0 halftime deficit and overwhelmed the Giants, 2614, today for their first Eastern Division title in the National Football Conference.

title: Hunter a Free Agent
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter, baseball's top pitcher in recent years, is now a free agent and can offer his services to any of the 24 major league clubs. Official announcement of an arbitrator's decision that the Oakland A's violated terms of Hunter's contract is scheduled to be made today. Details on Page 51.

title: Parseghian Resigns, Plans to Rest a Year
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 15 (AP)Ara Parsegian announced his resignation today as head football coach at Notre Dame and said he would take a oneyear vacation from coaching.

title: Don't Write Him Off, Says Dismissed Rabbi
description: Ousted from his job among the citywide budget cuts imposed last week, Samuel Schrage, the combative Hasidic rabbi who ran the Neighborhood Action Program since 1969, had something of a provocative announcement to make.

title: Recession Adds to Problems of Jobless Blacks
description: For Roderick N. Smith, a 26  year  old unemployed black man, the problem of finding a job did not begin with the current economic crisis.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Traffic Department's parkingenforcement agents (formerly known as meter maids) and trafficcontrol agents yesterday rejected, 97 to 62, the city's offer of a 14 per cent pay increase in a twoyear contract to replace the contract that expired last June 30. Their current salaries range from $7,900 to $8,800 a year.

title: FORD AND GISCARD CONSIDER ACTIONS ON ENERGY POLICY
description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 15President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France held extended discussions today on cooperation on energy policy and other key issues but failed to report any substantive agreement.

title: MATTHEW DANAHER, INDICTED DALEY AIDE
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP)Matthew J. Danaher, a close associate of Mayor Richard J. Daley who was scheduled to stand trial in a $400,000 kickback scheme, was found dead today in a hotel, the police said. His age was 47. He apparently died of natural causes in a room at the Ambassador West Hotel.

title: Laura Berman Is Bride
description: Laura Joan Berman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Berman of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Clifford R. Osinoff, son of Gerald K. Osinoff of Lido Beach, L.I., and Mrs. Jean Zisser of New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony at Temple EmanuEl. Mr. Osinoff is director of operations at Sun Harbor Manor, a healthrelated facility in Roslyn, L.I., of which his father is owner and executive director.

title: Hunter a Free Agent
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter, baseball's top pitcher in recent years, is now a free agent and can offer his services to any of the 24 major league clubs. Official announcement of an arbitrator's decision that the Oakland A's violated terms of Hunter's contract is Scheduled to be made today. Details on Page 51.

title: TV for Rockefeller's Oath
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) The Senate voted today to allow a radio and television broadcast of Nelson A. Rockefeller's swearingin as Vice President if the ceremony is held in the Senate chamber. It would be the first telecast from inside the Senate. The House is expected to confirm the former New York Governor by the end of next week, but there was no indication where the swearing in would be held.

title: SENATORS IN FRANCE BACK ABORTION BILL
description: PARIS, Dec. 15The French Senate approved a Governmentsponsored abortion bill by a vote of 182 to 91 early this morning.

title: Electric Typewriter Sales Are Bolstered by Efficiency
description: In a far from healthy national economic scene the electric typewriter business is showing robust vitality.

title: Capping Chemical War
description: Searing memories of trench warfare and bayonet charges through fields of choking mustard gas floated over the hearings of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Not France in the First World War but Vietnam many wars later inspired Senate action that is expected to lead to ratification of the 1925 Geneva Protocol outlawing chemical and biological warfare. It is a tribute to Senator J. W. Fulbright, winding up his distinguished career as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, that a compromise has been worked out so that the United States can at last sign this agreement.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France held extended discussions Yesterday, at their meeting in Martinique on energy policy and other key issues, but failed to report any substantive agreement. However, a White House official ment on energy policy today, when the talks said privately that it was still possible that the two sides would announce an agreeare scheduled, to end [Page 1, Column. 8.]

title: DON M'LEAN RETURN FROM HIS STAR TRIP
description: Don McLean has frankly admitted that the huge success of his song American Pie (apart from commercial reward and the attendant sta?? trip, it caused some to compare him to T. S. Eliot) unnerved him, so much so that he took a year's vacation from writing and performing.

title: Brazil's Auto Industry Is Growing Along With Market
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 15In the gloom of the Worldwide automobile crisis, Brazil's young vehicle industry is surging ahead with a rise in production, sales and employment and plans for expansion.

title: 21 Arms Resolutions Are Voted by the U.N. in Week's Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15The General Assembly approved 21 disarmament resolutions last weeka record for a United Nations session.

title: Hijacker Is Held in Cuba As U.S. Negotiates for Pilot
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP)A lone gunman who forced twinengine aircraft to fly to Cuba was in the custody of Cuban authorities today while United States officials negotiated for the return of the pilot, officials said.

title: BEIRUT SAYS SYRIA VOWS DEFENSE
description: BEIRUT, Dec. 15Premier Raschid alSolh of Lebanon last night reported a Syrian promise of military assistance against Israeli attacks such as the air raid on refugee camps in Beirut last Friday.

title: Books of The Times
description: I'm fairly sure these seven early privateeye stories by Dashiell Hammett could have stood alone, without the interpretive introduction that Steven Marcus, professor of English and comparative literature at Columbia University, has supplied for them. Of course it's true that a certain quaintness occasionally colors the stories'

title: Dance: By Sally Bowden
description: Sally Bowden, a dancer who has gone about her activities on the experimental scene quietly and without hullabaloo, is presenting a onewoman version of The Nutcracker this month. The miniature theater piece en, titled The Ice Palace, was seen Saturday night at 542 La Guardia Place and can be viewed at other dates by those with a taste for a touching and sophisticated modern fable.

title: Art by Soviet Dissidents Is Displayed at Synagogue
description: Paintings signed by nonconformist Soviet artists, many of whose works were suppressed in the violent disruption of an exhibition in a field outside Moscow last September, were shown yesterday in the peace of a synagogue in New Rochelle, N. Y.

title: 2 Canadian Policemen Slain During Kidnapping Inquiry
description: MONCTON, New Brunswich, Dec. 15 (UPI)Searchers today found the bodies of two policemen who disappeared Friday while investigating the kidnapping of a boy who was released unharmed after payment of $15,000 ransom.

title: 18 Killed as Fire Traps Elderly In a Nursing Home in Britain
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, Dec. 15 (Reuters)At least 18 people were killed early today when fire engulfed a nursing home in this city in England's east Midlands, trapping residents in their bedrooms.

title: Screen: Emmanuelle Rates Columbia's First X
description: Having arrived in a wave of eroticismasart fanfare, Emmanuelle, France's top boxoffice blockbuster and the first Xrated feature released here by Columbia, doesn't say a great deal for greats expectations. It had its premiere at the Paris Theater yesterday.

title: Cattle Infection Reduced Under U.S.Mexican Pact
description: MISSION, Tex., Dec. 15Confirmed cases of livestock infected by screwworms have been dramatically reduced to a new low in New Mexico and Arizona this year, and substantial decreases have been reported in Texas and California, according to the joint MexicoUnited States Commission for the Eradication of Screwworms.

title: Manhattan Towers Hotel Changes Name and Image
description: Manhattan Towers, described this year as one of the two most crimeridden buildings in the city, has evicted twothirds of its occupants, most of them welfare recipients, and has changed its name to the Hotel Opera as part of a $1million refurbishment.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Masters Title Won By Vilas
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 15. (AP)Guillermo Vilas, the 22yearold Argentine sensation of international tennis, captured the Grand Prix Masters tournament today with a marathon fiveset triumph over the defending champion, Ilie Nastase of Rumania. The scores were 76, 62, 36, 36, 64.

title: HLBB SETS RULES ON LOAN SEX BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced regulations today to carry out the 1974 law banning sex discrimination in home lending.

description: For Engine Company 203, yesterday was a typical day  almost.

title: Burma Waits Warily In Wake of Disorder
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 14Since the recent rioting here, hundreds of young people have not gone home. They are presumed to have been arrested or wounded but their families will not inquire. To do so would be dangerous, so they wait in silence.

title: GUERRILLAS PRESS DRIVE IN MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 15Despite the success of the government in finding and killing Mexico's principal rural guerrilla leader early this month, an extreme leftist organization in the cities continues to plague the authorities with assaults and other actions.

He moved slowly, aided by a cane; yet, he felt safe. As on every Sunday since the invention of the internal combustion engine, the 50footwide Main Street has been free of traffic. It's the law.

title: SUSPECTED LEADER OF DRUG RING HELD
description: A Bronx man who, posed as a physician but actually operated a $25millionayear cocaine smuggling ring, according to the police, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport Yesterday as he stepped off a plane from Peru.

description: Resting many of their starters, including Larry Csonka and Bob Griese, the Miami Dolphins spotted the New England Patriots a 240 lead yesterday before rallying to win their 31st consecutive borne game, 3427, in the Orange Bawl.

title: The New Image of Man
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.It is now becoining clear that Western society lacks the conceptual tools needed to solve its most pressing problems. Environmental pollution, scarcity of energy and other resources and inflatienwithrecession are among the problems involving interconnected systems that conventional approaches cannot solve.

title: Petsonal Finance: Cutting Income Tax
description: There is still time to do something about income taxes payable for 1974. And it will pay to do so in the next 15 days if there is likely ti be a significant difference in gross income between this year and 1975.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) About 150,000 tons of food stockpiled as a precaution against nuclear attack will spoil unles it is used within the next few years, an official of the Civil Defense Preparedness Agency said tonight.

description: The State Insurance Department told a large upstate Blue Shield plan yesterday that it could not automatically grant increased reimbursements to doctorsa move that the department said marked the first time that it had tried to restrain rising physicians' fees.

description: ACROSS

title: Saving the Wild East
description: As the 93rd Congress rushes toward adjournment there is danger that the House will fail for the second year act on an environmental bill, of particularly urgent interest to the majority of Americans who live east of the one hundredth meridianthe Eastern Wilderness Areas Act.

title: Glass Eye Is Shattered By a Ricocheting Shot
description: HACKETTSTOWN, Dec. 15. A 22yearold man was stack in his glass left eye while hunting yesterday. Charles Wright of Andover was listed today as in good condition in Community Hospital here.

description: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 15  William Walter Kilcoyne, retired assistant treasurer of the Bridgeport Brass Company, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 132 Stamford Avenue.

title: About New York The Season for Sadness and Nuttiness
description: It's amazing how they all got word of this, Louis Lefkowitz said. The Attorney General was standing on Fifth Avenue looking out from under his old fedora at a crowd. It reminded him that in the last campaign people had not shown up in abundance for outdoor rallies, and that there had been no profit for politicians who hoped they would.

title: Holiday Travel Expected To Take a Sharp Drop
description: The nation's depressed economywith widespread layoffs, inflation and apprehension about what lies ahead in the new yearwill apparently keep many Americans by their firesides this holiday season rather than on a warm beach or with relatives in distant cities.

title: Long Branch Is Still Tense Over Death of Black Youth
description: LONG BRANCH, Dec. 15The racial situation continues tense in this Monmouth County city, following the slaying early last Sunday morning of an unarmed 16yearold black youth, Wilbert S. Russell by a white policeman.

title: Karin Branzell, Met Contralto For 21 Seasons, Is Dead at 83
description: Karin Branzell, for 21 seasons a leading contralto at the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday of an emliolism while recovering from a pelvic fracture. suffered at her home in Altadena, Calif., where she had lived since 1969. She was 83 years old and the wife of Fedja Reinshagen who was an operatic stage director.

title: A's Hunter Ruled Free Agent
description: Jim (Catfish) Hunter, baseball's most successful pitcher in recent seasons, is now free to offer his services to any of the 24 major league clubs, including the Oakland A's, who failed to live up to the terms of his existing contract.

title: Ford Said to Pick Dominick To Be Envoy to Switzerland
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15President Ford has chosen Senator Peter H. Dominick of Colorado as the next United States Ambassador to Switzerland, according to an administration official.

title: Klan to Let Catholics And Immigrants Join
description: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Dec. 15 (AP)Ku Klux Klan leaders of one segment pf the white supremacist organization voted today to allow membership for Roman Catholics and immigrants.

title: MANHATTAN SCHOOL STAGES ABDUCTION
description: The Manhattan School of Music staged Mozart's The Abduction From the Seraglio this Weekendan odd choice for a student production, one would think. There are only five singing roles (three of exceptional range and difficulty) and no chorus to speak of, while the dreary libretto requires acting of unusual style and intelligence if the drama is to succeed.

title: Ponti Plays Iain Hamilton Piano Work
description: Michael Ponti is a pianist with a big technique, a formidable appetite for all kinds of music (especially if it's from the Romantic era) and an inclination to do things a bit differently from other pianists in his recitals.

title: Peter Beilin Weds Wendy J. Sarasohn
description: Wendy June Sarasohn, daughter of Shirlee Sarasohn of South Orange, N. J., and Ira Sarasohn of East Orange, N. J., and Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Frederic Beilin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Beilin of Hollis, Queens.

title: Gaullist Party Is Shaken By Change in Leadership
description: PARIS, Dec. 15  Premiers Jacques Chirac, who in a surprise move yesterday won control of the Gaullist party, issued a solemn appeal for unity to party members today.

title: Bankers Planning to Discuss Problems With Controller
description: With banks and brokerage houses suffering enormous underwriting losses on New York City bonds in recent weeks, prospects for future city borrowing have become increasingly uncertain.

title: A Second Italian General Arrested on Plotting Charge
description: ROME, Dec. 15An Italian Army general, Ugo Ricci, was arrested here last night and charged with political conspiracy, it was reported today. It is the second arrest of a general in the armed forces in six weeks.

title: Leaders Get Along Swimmingly
description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 15Even though today's talks between President Ford and Valery Giscard d'Estaing were described as substantive and in depth, the emerald waters and warm breezes of this island Seemed to make it difficult for the two officials to get down to the tough economic and political issues at hand.

title: Man Fatally Stabbed After Pursuit of Car Thief
description: A 21yearold Queens man was stabbed to death early yesterday morning by a car thief he had cornered after a twoblock chase by car and on foot along a Maspeth street, the police reported.

title: Film: A Too Charming 'Les Violons':Drach's Jewish Flight Lacks Substance The Cast Nostalgic War Views of French Family
description: For over a year, many movies have been insisting that the past was prettier than the present. But Michel Drach's "Les Violons du Bal"which nearly drowns you in a cataract of facile charmis the first picture that seems downright nostalgic about World War II. The film, which was the official French entry at the 1974 Cannes Film Festival, is a huge hit in France. Perhaps the French are grateful for this idylic view of their history, after the painful abrasions of Marcel Ophuls's "The Sorrow and the Pity," Louis Malle's "Lacombe, Lucien," and Michel Mitrani's "Black Thursday," all of which dwell on collaboration with the Germans. The movie opened yesterday at the Regency Theater.The film focuses on the director's childhood during the German occupation of France, when his Jewish family tried to live in hiding and then escaped to Switzerland. Misty shots of handsome people moving gracefully through pastel landscapes make it almost impossible to believe these are fugitives fleeing for their lives. The elegant camera angles, the lovely clothes, the comely faces and the lush colors combine to cancel out the suffering of the French Jews; the movie's style is just too lyrical to convey their desperation or pain. Since their survival, seems as miraculous as a fairytale  instead of being rooted in human experiencewe can't fear for them when the Germans approach, or when the bullets fly.In fact, the trouble with this sensitive but shallow movie is that it has bags of style but very little content. And the often-pleasing device of a film within a film only serves to weaken the material: the theme of a director who's determined to make a movie about his boyhood gives the wary potential investor some trenchant lines. The latter is meant to be appallingly commercial when he protests that this movie won't work. He's a clich figure when he says that it needs to be livelier, that some sex and death would supply the vitality that's lacking. But he happens to be right when he complains about the lack of substance.Mr. Drach begins by playing himself as the frustrated director; he then does a life-swap with Jean-Louis Trintignant, while Marie-Jose Nat (who's married to Mr. Drach) is cast as his mother as well as herself, and their small son plays Mr. Drach as a child. The present is filmed in cinema vrit style in black and white, and the past wells up in color. Mr. Trintignant has almost no acting to do: he merely responds to "his" memories with sad or fond expressions.Miss Nat, who won the Best Actress award at Cannes for her performance as the totally beloved, utterly magical mother, is very beguiling in a liquid way. But her role is so idealized that we just can't swallow such perfection. The child is engaging: however he has been directed to be too poignant and too winsome, as well as wise beyond his years. All in all, "Les Violons" is one of those movies that's so tasteful it makes you feel boorishand that's not a useful context for reflecting any kind of war.

title: Moral Bankruptcy
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15When the uproar over school busing began in Boston this fall, some thoughtful persons said that there was more to the white opposition than the old racist hatred of blacks. This time, it was said, the interest in integration conflicted with another public interestpreservation of a real urban community, South Boston, whose largely Irish population had deep roots there and felt its identity threatened.

title: Racing on Sunday: Bedeviling Delight?
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., Dec. 15  It almost seemed prearranged. Sunday thoroughbred racing, introduced today for the first time on a regular basis at a major metropolitan track, found Goliath winning the opening event and Demon Flight capturing the fifth.

title: HUGO ROGERS, 75, TAMMANY LEADER
description: Hugo E. Rogers, former Borough President of Manhattan and leader of Tammany Hall, died Saturday in Polyclinic Hospital of a, heart attack. He was 75 years old and lived at 1175 York Avenue.

title: The Traditional Farmer Is Africa's Hope
description: ITIOSE, Nigeria  SuberuAkanbi bent under broiling sun and chopped weeds from the jumble of corn, casava, yam and tomato plants on his halfacre plot, as his father taught him to do 50 years ago.

title: Physics in a Ferment of Theories Over Discovery of Two Particles
description: Hardly, if ever, has physics been in such an uproar as during the last three weeks, and ?? is not in sight.

title: Study on Drinking Yields a Paradox
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15Californians are ready and willing to denounce alcoholism, but they are against anything that threatens to interfere with their individual drinking habits. That is one of the findings in a comprehensive statewide survey here into public attitudes toward drinking measures to prevent alcoholism. The study found, for example, that 12 to 15 per cent of the population drank 75 per cent of the alcohol consumed, that the increase in women's independence had been accompanied by a rise in heavy drinking among women, and that most excessive drinkers are men between the ages of 18 and 24.

title: Carey Appointment Is Called Significant
description: The expected appointment this week of David Burke, a vice president of the Dreyfus Corporation, as Governorelect Hugh L. Carey's secretary and chief of staff has some highly significant political overtones. Mr. Burke, who is 38 years old and resides in Rye, is rated a firstclass administrator by many politicians. And, that, according to those in the know, is theprime reason for his selection by Mr. Carey.

title: TV: All Hail to WCBS
description: For television, the holiday season generally means still another opportunity to rerun an assortment of old chestnuts, those old movies and animated productions about Scrooge, Santa Claus and rednosed reindeer. The stations, however, are not, contrary to rumor, completely shameless, and a gesture toward original programing for young people is occasionally made. Tonight, at 7:30 it's the turn of WCBSTV.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures Tumbling
description: Although consumers might not yet be benefiting, the prices of a dozen basic commodities have been falling sharply in commodity futures trading.

title: COMMUTING BY BUS DROPS IN JERSEY
description: Though rail travel in New Jersey is up somewhat, fewer people are riding commuter buses despite the recession and higher gasoline prices.

title: Namath and jets Beat Colts in Finale, 4538, for No. 6
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 15In a fittingly furious finish to the team's bizarre season and perhaps the quarterback's playing career, Joe Namath fired the Jets to their sixth straight victory today, a 4538 decision in a passfest with the Baltimore Colts.

title: Miss Kaplan Marries Here
description: Elisabeth Ellen Kaplan, a member of the educational staff of the junior museum at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Scott Boas, a senior at the Cornell Medical School. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Lloyd Tennenbaum at the. Cornell Club here. The couple graduated with the class of '71 from Cornell University.

title: Blazers' Surge Defeats Lakers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 15 (UPI)7Barry Clemens and Lloyd Neal, reserves, led Portland in an incredible fourthquarter comeback today as the Trail Blazers rallied from an 18point deficit to defeat the Los Angeles Lakers, 10097, in a National. Basketball Association game.Trailing, 8163, going into the final period, the Blazers sent in Clemens and Neal and they went on a scoring binge before the 9,852 fans. Clemens hit 15 of his 24 points and Neal 10 of his 14 in the last period. At one point the Blazers were down by 26.

title: DAHOMEY DECREE FIGHTS SABOTAGE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 15 President Mathieu Kerekou of Dahomey, in the latest of series of moves aimed at extending the control of his military Government over that small West African country, has ordered the establishment of Defense of the Revolution Committees in all businesses to protect the revolution from sabotage.

title: Excess Hospital Construction Blocked
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Flexing relatively new muscle, health planning groups in 39 states disapproved $200million worth of hospital construction in nine months this year because they deemed the building unnecessaxy, according to a Federal health official.

title: Greek President Resigns To Allow New Appointment
description: ATHENS, Dec. 15 (Reuters) President Phaidon Gizikis of Greece resigned today. Parliament is to choose a provisional president following the referendum last Sunday that abolished the monarchy.

title: MOYNIHAN URGES ARAB AID TO INDIA Says U.S. Will Supply Food, but Oil Money Is Crucial
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 15Ambassador Daniel P. Moynihan said today that the United States would shortly supply 300,000 tons of food to India; but that major assistance by Arab oil producers was crucial.

title: B.B.C. to Cut Radio And TV Programs As Deficit Mounts
description: LONDON, Dec. 15The British Broadcasting Corporation in severe financial trouble will cut radio and television programs in the new year. The cuts will save 1million (about $2.31million), but the B.B.C. faces a deficit of 20million by next March.

title: VAN DEBUT MADE BY LYDIA HOLLANDER
description: Lydia Elisabeth Hollander has attended three of the nountry's major music conservatories and worked with several outstanding teachers, but it is difficult to imagine any of them condoning the cavalier rhythmic distortions and stylistic disregard the young pianist consistently displayed at her Carnegie Recital Hall debut Saturday night.

title: Kurt Hahn, Pedagogue, Dead; Founded Gordonstoun School
description: Dr. Kurt Hahn, the noted pedagogue who founded the Salem Castle School in Germany and the Gordonstoun School in Scotland, died yesterday at his home in Hermannsberg, West Germany. He was 88 years old.

title: A Jet's Jersey to Remember
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 15Quickly and routinely, the other members of the New York Jets had tossed their greenandwhite jerseys to the equipment handlers after their 4538 victory over the Baltimore Colts today, but Joe Namath quietly rolled up his dirtsmudged jersey with the green 2 and put it on the floor of his open wooden Jocker. Now he was telling newsmen, I don't know if it was or wasn't his last game with the Jets when Billy Hampton Jr., the blond son of the Jets' equipment manager, reached into the quarterback's locker and picked up the jersey. But seeing it rolled up carefully, the youngster showed it to him before taking it. Shaking his head, Namath reached over and took the jersey. I want to keep that, the quarterback said.

title: Turnpike Authority Weighs Suing State On Plans for Spur
description: HADDONFIELD, Dec, 15. (UPI)The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will consider several courses of action, one of which would be to sue the state, in settling the matter of the proposed 38mile Toms River Expressway, the authority's chairman said today.

During the 12 nights of racing left in the 1974 New York harness racing season, Filion will attempt to top his record of 605 victories in a year, set in 1972. Going into last night's card at Detroit Raceway, Filion was approaching the 600 mark.

title: Lack of Drilling Tools Angers Oilmen
description: San ANGELO, Tex.Ask a Texas oilman those days if he's out there looking for oll, and you'll bring in a gusher of bile.

title: DIPLOMACY FOCUS OF OPEC PARLEY
description: VIENNA, Dec. 15The oil exporting countries have squeezed a few more cents out of each barrel sold to the big Western companies, but they have indicated to consumers that they are ready to negotiate on future prices and international financial stability.

title: ISRAEL GENERAL GETS RESERVE, JOB
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 15 Ariel Sharon, the tank general who led the Israeli breakthrough to the west bank of the Suez Canal in the war last year, resigned his seat in Parliament today to take a reserve military appointment.

title: Dr. Abbas Ammar, 67, Dies; I.L.O. Aide, Anthropologist
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, Dec, 15 (AP)Dr. Abbas Ammar, former deputy directorgeneral of the International Labor Organization, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, in his hotel room here. He was 67 years old.

title: FORD AND GISCARD APPROACH ACCORD ON ENERGY POLICY
description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 15President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France moved toward an agreement on energy policy today that could help close the ranks of major oilconsuming nations.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Advertising
description: That fullpage ad for Cointreau liqueur you might have noticed in your favorite paper in the last few weeks is part of a sixnewspaper, $250,000 preChristmas effort that Renfield Importers is laying on top of its regular magazine advertising.

title: Job Outlook Hopeful for College Seniors
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15If you are graduating from college this year and looking for a job, you may find that with the recesssion your chances of getting one are less than they were last year, but not as bad as had been expected.

title: Silvery Fence Adds Glitter to 5th Ave.
description: Strollers on Fifth Avenue have been puzzled and bedazzled by a silvery reflective fence running along the edge of Central Park from about East 61st to 65th Streets.

title: Governmeot Revives Its Seaport Hospital System
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) In an unpublicized but dramatic policy reversal, the Government is revitalizing the network of Public Health Service hospitals and clinks, including one on Staten Island, that were once doomed by President Nixon.

title: SKILLFUL SHOWING BY CHARLIE RICH
description: Charlie Rich's is the kind a success story that inspiresi peo pie to keep on Plugging, nc matter how daunting the odd might seem. Mr. Rich has beer kicking about the poprock country scene for a good 20 years. He had his minor ups and his longlasting downs, bu?? nothing much seemed to be happening. Then, in the, las couple of years, he suddenly clicked, Now he sells million: of records, wins industry awards in bulk, and has a lov ing flock of tansenough to warrant two shows Saturday night at the heretofore under attended Country in New York

title: Music: Bright Idea for Two Pianos
description: Peter Serkin and Yuji Takahashi had a bright idea for their twopiano recital yesterday at Town Hall. Instead of sticking to the usual repertory for two pianos and pianofourhands, which is not overburdened with grip ping masterworks, they injected solo playing into their all20thcentury program.

title: Inmates' Release From Hospital Protested by Texas Prosecutors
description: RUSK, Tex., Dec. 15  Officials of the state hospital for the criminally insane here have begun releasing 190 patients over protests from Texas prosecutors and district attorneys.

title: Lena Horne's Apartment Robbed of, $50,000 in Jewels
description: The theft of $50,000 worth of jewelry was reported to the police yesterday by Lena Horne, the singer, who said she discovered the theft in her apartment at 21 East 90th Street.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DETROIT, Dec. 15 (UPI)The Detroit Red Wings traded Guy Charron a fiveyear veteran, and Claude Houde, a minor league player, to the Kansas City Scouts last night for three players. The Red Wings obtained Ted Snell, a right wing, Bart Crashley, a defensernan and Larry Giroux, also a defensenthn. Alex Delvecchio, the Wings' coach, said the team was happy to obtain Snell because of injuries to Mickey Redmond and Doug Roberts, forwards.

title: Carter Accuses Senators Of Violating Law's Spirit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter contended today that two of his undeclared competitors for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination were violating the spirit of the new campaign reform law.

title: Shampoo's Natural Ingredients Include Water, F.T.C. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)  The natural ingredients claimed for some shampoos range from coconut oil to plain water, according to a report released today by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: SUIT TIES DALLAS TO SEGREGATION
description: DALLAS, Dec, 15A former Dallas city planner has testified in Federal Court that the city is one of the most segregated in the nation.

title: Flyers Defeat Blues
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (UPI)Don Saleski and Bill Barber each tallied two goals as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the St. Louis Blues, 72, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Sa?? leski, who sometimes has been booed here, had his best night of the season, also getting two assists.

title: Student's Forgery Perils Key Harvard Research
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15 In a bizarre twist of fate worthy of a Hitchcock film, the new law requiring colleges to allow students to see their files has indirectly led a team of Harvard biochemists to consider repudiating a major series of experiments they have performed over the last 18 months.

title: Dr. Casalino Is Bride of Dr. Turkel
description: Dr. Marie Barone Casalino, director of neonatal services at the Metropolitan Hospital Center, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Witold Victor Turkel, an obstetrician and gynecologist. State Supreme Court Justice Jeremy Marks performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Big Two of Big Ten Win Handily
description: Bobby Knight, the 34yearOld Indiana coach, is fiery and intense. Fred Schaus, 47, the Purdue coach, is quiet. Their teams figure to battle for the Big Ten Conference title.

title: It's Holiday Time On Fifth Ave. Mall
description: Mayor and Mrs. Beam and thousand's of New Yorkers and visitors enjoyed the renewal of holiday spirits and a brief respite from traffic yesterday in the fifth annual holiday promenade on Fifth Avenue.

title: EACH COUNCILMAN TO GET PLEA TO CUT EXPENSES $2,500
description: City Councilmen will be asked by their leaders to give up $2,500 eachor half of their annual expense allowances, called lulus  as a contribution toward shaving the city's multimilliondollar budget deficit.

title: Stage: Rosmersholm at Roundabout
description: When Henrik Ibsen began writing Rosmersholm in 1886, he called it The White Horses. Throughout the play we sense the symbolic charging of those horses  an ??nseen presence signifying the torment of guilt. The white horses are the dead returned to haunt the living with questions of conscience.

title: CAMPISIS' TRIAL TO RESUME TODAY
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 15 (AP) The trial of eight member: of the Campisi family, accused of underworld murders, robber ies and rackets, begins its 14th week tomorrow and the jury has yet to hear a single wore of testimony.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes Bank's Warning of Risks Dims Glitter of GoldBuying
description: Although the First National City Bank of Jersey City is one of the first banks in the state to have announced that it will sell gold to all corners after Dec. 31, it does not seem overly eager to do so.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Job Outlook Hopeful for College Seniors
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 15If you are graduating from college this year and looking for a job, you may find that with the recesssion your chances of getting one are less than they were last year, but not as bad as had been expected.

title: BELGIANS BALLOT FOR CHURCH TOWER
description: NIVELLES, Belgium, Dec. 14 The voters of this bustling town 20 miles south of Brussels decided today to put squat Romanesque tower instead of a high Gothic steeple on the massive St. Gertrude's Abbey Church on the town square.

title: An Array of Gifts For Sporty Types
description: Tennis players. Skaters. Skiers, So many women are participating in active sports these days that on giftgiving occasions it's as appropriate to present them with a memento of their favorite game as it is to think of footballs or baseball bats for small boys. Sportsmen are constantly being endowed with ties or cuff links depicting their special enthusiasm. Now it's time for women to get into the act.

title: Boston Gas Denied Increase
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)The Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities, by a 42 vote, denied a $3.1million rate increase to the Boston Gas Compally. The department allowed a $6.2million increase last May, but approved only a $26,000 increase in its latest action, saying the increase sought by the company could have lead to excessive profits. pally. The department allowed a $6.2million increase last May, but approved only a $26,000 increase in its latest action, saying the increase sought by the company could have lead to excessive profits.

title: Washington Post to Reduce Its Mechanical Work Force
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  The Washington Post Company, citing a drop in advertising lineage for the newspaper, announced Saturday a 20 per cent reduction in the number og guaranteed jobs in its press loom.

title: 6,00 IN BOSTON PROTEST BUST
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15Thousands of whites protested on the Common today against courtordered busing for school desegregation, a day after probusing forces rallied in downtown Boston.

title: The Boston Sugar Party
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)  A band of about a dozen members of the People's Bicentennial Coalition boarded a facsimile of the Boston Tea Party ship today to dump bags of fake sugar into Boston harbor in a protest over high sugar prices. Tomorrow is the 201st anniversary of the ori. ginalBoston Tea Party.

title: ROY FERGUSON, 81, OF ST. REGIS PAPER
description: Roy K. Ferguson, chairman of the executive committee of the St. Regis Paper Company, which he had headed as president and chairman during its expansion from an upstate New York enterprise to a major national producer of paper prodacts, died yesterday at his home, Timber Ridge Farm, Oyster Bay, L. I. He was 81 years old.

title: Klammer Captures Downhill
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 15 (UPI)Franz Klammer of Austria and the Insurance company, Lloyds of London, emerged the big winners today and the disqualified West German team the big losers in the men's World Cup downhill ski race.

title: Silvery Fence Adds Luster to 5th Ave.
description: Strollers on Fifth Avenue have been puzzled and bedazzled by a silvery reflective fence running along the edge of Central Park from about East 61st to 65th Streets.

title: Harry Hershfield Dead; Humorist and Raconteur
description: Harry Hershfield, the humorist and raconteur, died last night at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 89 years old. Mr. Hershyield, who had been ill for many months, was admitted to the hospital a week ago.

title: Lowenstein Says Year's Study of Evidence Shows Sirhan Was Not Assassin of Kennedy
description: Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein said yesterday that a yearlong examination of the evidence bearing on the murder of Senator Robert F. Kennedy had led him to conclude that Sirhan B. Sirhan had not fired the fatal bullet.

title: Elderly but Fortunate Befriend the Neediest
description: Two donors from Washington contributed $50 to the 63d annual appeal Of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and asked that they be listed as anonymous.

title: ELLSBERG'S PAPERS HANDED TO LAWYER
description: MILL VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP)  Documents stolen from the home of Daniel Ellsberg were turned Over to an attorney for a Congressional subcommitfee yesterday after the lawyer served a subpoena on the police chief of this San Francisco suburb.

title: DR. ALTSCHUL
description: Dr. Alexander Altschul, internist here for over 50 years, died yesterday at his home, 315 Central Park West. He was 82 years old.

title: HAIG TAKES OVER AS HEAD OF NATO
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, Dec. 15 Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. took over today as the supreme commander of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Europe.

title: Minow Gets Advisory Post At Jewish Theology School
description: Newton N. Minow, former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was installed yesterday as chairman of the board of overseers of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America at Broadway and 122d Street.

title: CrimeRidden City Hotel Changes Name and Image
description: Manhattan Towers, described this year as one of the two most crimeridden buildings in New York City, has evicted twothirds of its occupants, most of them welfare recipients, has changed its name to the Opera Hotel as part of a $1million refurbishment.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: FROSTBOUND The last public image of Robert Frost, as millions of television viewers watched the Presidential inauguration of John F. Kennedy, was of the silyerhaired poet trying to read a work dedicated to the new President in a trembling voice, eyes blinking in the glare of the wintry sunlight, The poem is included in Mr. Frost's last collection, In the Clearing, a copy of which is on display with a touching personal inscription to Mr. Kennedy in an exhibition of Frost poems and memorabilia starting today at the main branch of the Public Library, Fifth Aveand 42d Street.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Energy Chief Says State Faces Gas Cut

title: Rangers Play to 33 Tie
description: Release, that's the idea, release. That bench  emptying brawl Saturday night in St. Louis released an enormous pool of pentup frustration among the New York Rangers and the result was tonic, especially for Greg Polis, who started it all.

title: U.N. Council Is Expected to Discuss Status of SouthWest Africa Today
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15The Security Council is expected to meet tomorrow afternoon at the request of black African delegates to consider the question of SouthWest Africa, which is called Namibia by the United Nations.

title: Cutting the Fat
description: Responding to demands from union leaders that political fat be cut from the city's deficit budget along with the civil service bone, Mayor Beame promised the other day that any personnel firings would go all the way up and would tap many political provisionals. He indicated that the latest round of layoffs would include 125 political appointees in the $25,000 to $35,000 salary bracket.

title: KENNETH CONDIT, 86, PRINCETON EXDEAN
description: Kenneth H. Condit, dean emeritus of the Princeton University School of Engineering, died yesterday in Boulder, Colo. He was 86 years old.

title: Second Week of Dock Strike
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP)As the Boston longshoremen's strike began its second week, Thorlas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, planned to come to Boston tomorrow, a spokesman said. About 1,000 members of the I.L.A. closed the port of Boston last Monday when they struck the Boston Shipping Associtaion

title: Safety Last
description: The investigation into the circumstances surrounding the recent fatal crash of a Trans World Airlines jet on its approach to Dulles International Airport in Washington points to a deplorable lack of Federal urgency on the question of flight safety.

title: Burglar PistolWhips a Priest In $12,000 Queens Robbery
description: A burglar pistolwhipped a priest in the rectory of a Roman Catholic Church in Queens last night, tied up the priest, a housekeeper and two laymen, and fled with $12,000 in bingo receipts, the police reported.

title: Bruins Beat Islanders, 52 for 5th in Row
description: BOSTON, Dec. 15The New York Islanders ran into a Mack truck tonight in the form of the Boston Bruins and were flattened, 52, before 14,058 in the. Boston Garden.

title: Elderly but Fortunate Befriend the Neediest
description: Two donors from Washington contributed $50 to the 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and asked that they be listed as anonymous.

title: . . . And in the Museums' Shops, Business Is Thriving
description: It's walltowall people and plenty of profit these days in museum shops across the land as the last surge, of Christmas shoppers descends to purchase everything from Christmas cards to Fieldcrest sheets.

title: One Dead, 24 Hurt in Seoul As Guns Fire On an Airliner
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 17A woman was reported to have been killed and 24 people wounded by falling shrapnel in downtown Seoul last night when South Korean antiaircraft gunners fired thousands of rounds at what was apparently a Korean Air Lines jet approaching the city's airport.

title: Wheat Futures Lead a Decline in Grains
description: Wheat futures led a decline in the grain market yesterday on a report by Senator Michael J. Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, who is in China, that the Chinese had said they did not plan to buy much more products from the United States. The Chinese were said to be disappointed because so far most of the trade between the two nations has involved exports from the United States.
