title: DRUG FOR CANCER CALLED ROMISING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Medical scientists reported today promising results from use of a new cancer drug against such difficult forms of the disease as bone cancer and recurrent breast cancer.

title: Madison Square Garden
description: GAME TIME7:30 P.M.

title: Job Favoritism Reported In H.U.D. Under Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Political favoritism played a major role in hiring practices of the Department of Housing and Urban Development during President Nixon's Administration, a government study charged today.

title: Subsidiary of Tenneco Widens Holdings in Albright & Wilson
description: Tenneco International, a wholly owned subsidiary of Tenneco, Inc., announced yesterday it had increased its holdings of Albright & Wilson, Ltd., an international chemical company based in Britain, from 10 per cent to just under 50 per cent by converting $40million of Tenneco's convertible loan into additional common stock of the British company.

title: United Agrees to 22% Rise For Pilots Over 31 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. (AP) United Air Lines and the Air Line Pilots Association have agreed to a new contract that will increase wages of the airline pilots by 22 per cent over the next 31 months, the union said today.

title: Parseghian's Staff Aides Bypassed
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 16 Dan Devine, who turned down two earlier offers to become the head football coach at Notre Dame, resigned from the Green Bay Packers of the National Football League today and accepted a fouryearcontract as Ara Parseghian's successor with the Fighting Irish.

title: One That Loves His Fellow Man Aids the Neediest
description: Mrs. Lucile Hays Bites of the East Side enclosed the refrain from a poem with her check far $5 to the 63d annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest. Cases Fund. The excerpt, from the poem by the 19thcentury English writer Leigh Hunt, on Abou ben Adhem, read:

title: Housing Discrimination Laid to Federal Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The United States Civil Rights Commission charged today that the Federal agencies responsible for improving housing conditions had failed to combat discrimination against) women and minority groups in housing.

title: Ford's Energy Aides Prepare Report Outlining Measures to Make U.S. Less Dependent on Imported
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 16President Ford's energy advisers put the finishing touches today to an option paper that outlined a combination of conservation and supply measures intended to make the United States less dependent on imported oil. Achievement of Mr. Ford's goal of a cut of oil imports of one million barrels a day by next autumn remained in doubt.

title: Rescue of 8 Bankrupt Railroads Is Upheld by Supreme Court, 72
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Supreme Court upheld today the 1973 railroad reorganization plan that Congress enacted to rescue eight bankrupt carriers in the Northeast and Middle West and merge them into a single private selfsustaining system. The vote was 7 to 2.

title: Market Place
description: Major New York City banks and other financial institutions have been criticized in recent years for conentrating their stock market holdings in a few favored stocks.

title: ALBERT J. FELDMAN, FURRIER HERE, DIES
description: Albert J. Feldman, long prominent in the fur and furcleaning industry, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 75 East End Avenue.

title: Sale of Reactors to Egypt And Israells Now in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Because of a lack of interest on Israel's part, there are serious doubts that the United States will be able to carry through with its offer to provide Egypt and Israel with atomic power plants.

title: Man With 2 Hearts Doing Very Well
description: Dr. Christiaan N. Barnar said yesterday that a 58yeasold man in whom he implanted a second heart from a 10yearold girl three weeks ago is doing very, very well without evidence of the rejection phenomenon and that both hearts were pumping effectively and independently.

title: A.M.C. TO LAY OFF 13,000 FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16  The American Motors Corporation, with a backlog of 112 days' supply of cars, announced production cutbacks today that will affect 13,000 workers.

title: WOUNDED DETECTIVE PUT ON CRITICAL LIST
description: A detective sergeant was isted in critical condition yeserday after a shoot out in Brooklyn with a 24yearld suspect in the attempted murder of two policemen and the robbery of a bank.

title: Met stages a Stark and Strong Boris.
description: As everybody interested in music knows, Mussorgsky's Masterpiece, Boris Godunov, is seldom presented as it originally was written. Ever since 1908, the reorchestration (and, often, reharmonization) by RimskyKorsakov has been in use. Only recently has the original orchestral score been made generally available. But the back  to  Mussorgsky movement is taking hold. Only last year the San Francisco Opera staged an original Boris. Indeed, it was the same version that came to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera Last night, and it also had Martti Talvela in the title role.

title: Dollar Is Weak
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 16 (UPI)Gold hit a twoweek high on international exchanges today, pushed well over the $180 mark by reports that oilrich Arab states plan to buy all or most of the bullion the United States will put up for sale Jan. 6.

title: Pope Says Dissent Threatens Church
description: ROME, Dec. 16Pope Paul VI today appealed for unity and reconciliation in a church threatened by what he termed the polarization of dissent.

title: In Soviet Union, Day Care Is the Norm
description: KIEV, Soviet UnionZoya Idenko is the model of the young Soviet mother liberated by a local day care center that permits her to hold a job. With her 3yearold son in a state nursery, she works as a guide for Intourist and sometimes also teaches English at a night school.

title: Judge Bars F.B.I. Watch Over Parley of Socialists
description: A Federal judge has ordered the F.B.I not to conduct any surveillance of a national convention of the Young Socialist Alliance.

title: MORE COMPANIES SHIFTING TO LIFO
description: Several companies announced yesterday plans to change to the LIFO (lastin, firstout) method of inventory accounting from the FIFO (firstin, firstout) basis.

title: Senate Sends Back Bill On Embank to House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 Legislation to extend the life of the ExportImport Bank was again thrown into doubt today as the Senate voted to send the bill back once more to conference with the House of Representatives on two controversial issues.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VIVA FREADA! She is a big woman who surpasses her star billing, on the window outside, as 6 foot one and a ton of fun. Every Monday through Friday from 10:30 o'clock until closing Freada Wallace perches at her corner piano in Duke's Vogue Room (PL 34782), a friendly, intimate night spot at 120 East 57th Street (the south side, west of Lexington Avenue, with a bright red canopy) and makes magnetic music, stabbing the keys in a full but unfrilly embroidery and singing blues, rock, new and old ballad favorites and gospel (her real love, and it shows) in a honeyed voice that can project a yearning heart or a whiplash of fury. Or both.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The closer it gets, the greater the desperation. Lastminute shopping is never fun, and lastminute Christmas shopping is, according to current phraseology, the pits.

title: For Lovers of Crafts
description: With the crafts boom going full tilt, that special present you find under the tree this, year might well be the work of a professional craftsman. Places to find these things are everywhere. In neighborhoods all over the city and throughout the suburbs, there are shops, galleries, crafts schools and museum shops carrying the work of the American craftsmen.

title: Court Weighs Restaurant Right Amplify Copyrighted Music
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a resthurant owner must obtain a license to hook up a radio to loudspeakers and amplify broadcasts of copyrighted musieal compositions.

title: The Unwanted Children
description: A threejudge Federal court has ruled that the New York State child placement system, as laid out in the State Constitution and in state statutes, does not on its face violate the Constitution of the United States. One need not dispute the technical correctness of that decision to recognize that the actual operation of the system in New York City can in no way be deemed fair.

title: Month of Victories Marks Herbert Hill's 25th Year as N.A.A.C.P. Labor Director
description: For Herbert Hill, who has been quietly marking his 25th year with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the last month has been one of vindication.

title: A.M.A. REQUESTS END TO TOBACCO SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) An article in the Journal of the American Medical Association today accused Congress of subsidizing increased death and disability by paying subsidies to tobacco growers, and an accompanying editorial urged an end to such payments.

title: Canada Payments Gap
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Canada's current account balanceof payments deficit widened in the third quarter to $519million, seasonally adjusted, compared with a $205million shortfall in the second quarter, Statistics Canada said today.

title: Drivers Exceed Legal Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (Reuters)American motorists are driving more slowly than they were a year ago, but they are still exceeding the 55mileanhour speed limit on superhighways by an average of two miles an hour, the Department of Transportation reported today.

title: OFFICER CLEARED IN YOUTH'S DEATH
description: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday cleared a white policeman, Frank P. Bosco, of criminal negligence in the shooting death of a 14yearold black youth last September.

title: For the Holidays, Museums Offer Festive Bouquets ...
description: The holiday season, as celebrated at museums around the city, is a rich bouquet of Christmas and other festivals. While traditional displays are much in evidence, Hanukkah, Kwanza and. Three Kings Day are also honored, providing such extra added attractions as a show of antique menorahs, a Karamu feast and the sounds of plena, or Puerto Rican folk music.

title: REYNOLDS REBUFFED ON U.S. LINES BID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision holding that the Federal Maritime Commission did not have the authority to approve a longrange merger agreement between the nation's two largest container shipping companies.

title: U.S. Mediators Enter Coal Talks as Pickets Halt More Miners
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Dec. 16 (AP)Federal mediators entered the stalled contract talks for 4,400 United Mine Workers construction employes today, while pickets made idle nearly half the nation's 120,000 coal miners.

title: SENATE UNIT FINDS BIGOTRY ON AGED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16A Senate subcommittee cited to day numerous instances of maltreatment in nursing homes and attributed such treatment chiefly to the deeply negative attitude toward aging in the United States.

title: Funds From Los Angeles Check Forgery Taken Out of Dutch Bank
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16Cash withdrawals against a deposit resulting from the forgery of a $902,000 Los Angeles City Treasury check have been made at a Dutch bank, the Los Angeles County District Attorney, Joseph Busch, said today.

title: Falcons, Bears Expected to Make Shifts
description: With the dismissal of Nick Skorich by the Cleveland Browns yesterday and Dan Devine's resignation at Green Bay, two coaching jobs opened up in the National Football League and there will be at least two more. Arthur Modell, the Browns' president, dropped Skorich, 53 years old, on the heels of a losing season (10 defeats in 14 games), which was the first for the Browns since 1956 and the first since Modell took charge in 1961.

title: Data Analyst Faces Layoff In Worry and Frustration
description: I'm overaged, overexperienced and overeducated, Max Ferder said yesterday, explaining his problems as one of the 2,525 provisional city employes Mayor Beame intends to dismiss in his effort to balance the city budget.

title: Elusive Clemency
description: When President Ford announced his clemency program for draft resisters last September, he described his goal as a national commitment to justice and mercy, an effort to heal the scars of divisiveness. Though severely flawed in many of its details, the program least held out hope that a sincere beginning might be made to return its disaffected sons to the nation's fold.

title: Honeywell Wins Ruling On Keeping Trademark
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision that allows, in rare instances, a company to obtain a trademark for a product after its patent has run out.

title: Heavy Rain Hobbles Metropolitan Area
description: Umbrellas sprouted on the sidewalks and traffic crawled in the, streets yesterday as daylong rainstrom saturated the city, and suburbs with a near  record downpour that flooded low  lying sections, knocked down power lines and made some highways impassable.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Just a few years ago, ice hockey was a spirt New Jersey high school officials believed was played primarily in Canada as a substitute for basketball. The handful of New Jersey schools which launched formal hockey programs skated into such problems as rounding up enough players and finding a rink.

title: Sale of Reactors to Egypt And Israells Now in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Because of a lack of interest on Israel's part, there are serious doubts that the United States will be able to carry through with its offer to provide Egypt and Israel with atomic power plants.

title: Chess: 12 Flock to Houston Seeking Wealth, Fameand the Norm
description: The Houston International Tournament, sponsored by Lynne Babcock and the Houston Chess Club in conjunction with the United States Chess Federation, began Dec. 6 at the Seminar Centre of the Continental Houston Motor Hotel.

title: Joint Ventures Discussed By Disney With Japanese
description: Walt Disney Productions of Burbank, Calif., said yesterday that it was discussing with Mitsui & Co., Ltd., the Mitsui Real Estate Development Company and the Keisei Electric Railway Company, Ltd., the possibility of jointly developing an amusement park and related facilities in Japan.

title: Washing Machine Crisis
description: In this fantasy of mine the washing machine is broken and President Ford, Henry Kissinger and the President's experts have come to the house to deal with the problem.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: In slightly st??edup trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell yesterday, with declines almost doubling advances.

title: Alabama Named Top Team
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI)Alabama was named the college team of the year and its coach, Paul (Bear) Bryant, the coach of the year by the Washington Touchdown Club today. The awards will be presented at the club's annual dinner Jan. 1.8.

title: Suspected Kidnapper of Boy, 7, Agrees to Undergo Mental Tests
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16Thomas V. Burns, accused of kidnapping 7yearold George Kaloyerakis Jr. of Rutherford, was ordered today to undergo a twoweek psychiatric examination that will determine whether he will be prosecuted on Federal charges.

title: Excerpts From Communique on FordGiscard Tall
description: FORT DE FRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 16 (AP)Following are excerpts from a communiqu issued today after the conference between President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Employers Warned Not to Discriminate In Planning Layoffs
description: Private employers were warned yesterday by Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the city's Coinmission on Human Rights, that they must be prepared to prove in court that any recession layoffs do not discriminate against women or minoritygroup workers.

title: OilRich Nations' Aid Plan Is Unclear
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16Oilproducing nations have said here that they are increasing their assistance to needy countries, but United Nations officials say that they cannot find out where that assistance is going or under what conditions.

title: news Summary and Index TUESDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1974
description: International

title: 2 IRAQI FIGHTERS DOWNED IN NORTH
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 16Iraq said today that two of her fighter planes had been shot down over the northern part of the country near the border with Iran.

title: A Woman Will Head The Foreign Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 of State Kissinger has ordered shifts at the State Department, including the naming of a woman for the first time to head the Foreign Service.

title: OFFICER CLEARED IN YOUTH'S DEATH
description: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday cleared a white policeman, Frank P. Bosco, of criminal negligence in the shooting death of a 14yearold black youth last September.

title: MIMI RAND
description: Mimi Bushnell Lineaweaver, a partner in Jessup, Inc., interior decorators here and in Palm Beach, who was known professionally as Mimi Rand, died Sunday at her home, 720 Park Avenue. She was 69 years old.

title: GERMAINE WEILL
description: Germaine Weill, a former professor at the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes here and at Hamilton College during World War II, died Sunday in Paris. She was 90 years old.

title: State Unit Asks Court Aid In NursingHome Inquiry
description: The Temporary State Commission on Living Costs opened court proceedings yesterday to force members of the Bernard Bergman syndicate of nursing homes to respond to its subpoenas under penalty of criminal contempt.

title: FORD AND GUARD WILL COORDINATE POLICY ON ENERGY
description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 16President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France announced today that they had reached a compromise agreement to coordinate their energy policies.

title: No Victories for Filion As Wet Yonkers Opens
One That Loves His Fellow Man Aids the Neediest
description: Mrs. Lucile Hays Bates of the East Side enclosed the refrain from a poem with her check for $5 to the 63d annual appealof the New York Times Neediest. Case Fund. The excerpt, from the poem by the 19thcentury English writer Leigh Aboll ben Adhem, read:

title: College Basketball Ratings
description: COACHES' POLL

title: WEST GERMANMAKERS OF CARS SET LAYOFFS
description: BONN, Dec. 16 (UPI)  Five West German automobile makers laid off today more than 80,000 workers for limited periods to cut back production in the face of continuing low domestic and foreign sales.

title: Julius Rothman Dies at 60; Headed Labor Training Unit
description: Julius Rothman, president of the Human Resources Development Institute of the labor federation, died Friday of a heart attack in George Washington Hospital, Washington. He was 60 years old.

title: City Given Burd en of Blame in '70 Blast
description: The City of New York, the Consolidated Edison Company, a heating corporation and a master plumber have been found legally responsible for the gas explosion near City Hall four years ago that left 12 persons dead and 60 injured.

title: TV: CBS Dramas on Ben Franklin Going Smoothly
description: The Whirlwind, which will be shown on CBS at 9:30 tonight, is the second of four 90minute dramas based on the life of Benjamin Franklin. The first, written by Howard Fast, was The Ambassador, a recounting of the elderly Franklin's efforts to get French support for the cause of the American Revolution, This one, written by Loring Mandel, traces Franklin's development from early boyhood in a context of the technological and historical developments of the period.

title: Questions Are Raised On Lucky Luciano Book
description: Although The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano has not yet been published by Little, Brown & Co., the 461page book has already earned more than $1million.

title: Abel Charges ABCTV With Plagiarism
description: Elie Abel, dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism, has advised ABCTV through a lawyer of his contention that substantial portions of his book, The Missile Crisis, published by Lippincott in 1966, have been used in the network's threehour producdon, The Missiles of October, which will be televised tomorrow night.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Mexico City  Jose Napoles, 146 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Horacio Saldano, 144, Argentina, 3 rounds; Napoles retained world welterweight title.

title: Warriors Making an AllStar of Attles
description: Al Attles never made it as an AllStar in his 10 seasons as a player in the National Basketball Association, but he may be the first black coach of a major league AllStar team. The 25th annual N.B.A. AllStar game will be played Jan. 14 in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: SYDNEY HARNETT OF PYTHIAN ORDER
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec, 16Sydney G. Harnett, a leading figure in the Knights of Pythias, died yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old and lived on Harbor Island, Fla.

title: Woman Beaten to Death By Man in East New York
description: A 66year old Brooklyn woman was beaten to death with a cane last night by a 52yearold man in an argument in the woman's East New York apartment, the police reported.

title: General Mills Net Up 16% in Quarter; Sales Climb 22.1%
description: General Mills, Inc., reported yesterday records for sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended Nov. 24.

title: Music: Evalyn Steinbock
description: Many good musicians who can hold their own in ensemble playing find that solo work is another matter. Evalyn Steinbock, who gave cello recital on Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, seemed to be an instance of that, although the strenuous nature of the program she chose made things no easier.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Charles C. Edwards, the nation's chief health officer, has submitted his resignation to the White House. He expects to leave in midJanuary to become senior vice president of Becton, Dickinson & Co., a maker of medical and surgical supplies in Rutherford, N. J.

title: CHINA HINTS SHIFT IN TOP ARMY POST
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 16Needy seven years ago, a leading Chinese military figure, Yang Chengwu, was reviled as a counterrevolutionary doubledealer and reptile and was purged as acting chief of staff of the army.

title: House Bars Busing Curb, Sends Funds Bill to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Congress resolved a fourmonth battle over school desegregation today when the House followed the Senate's lead and nullified an antibusing amendIment in an education money bill, sending the measure on to President Ford.

title: PLAN BY VORSTER REPORTED GIVEN TO RHODESIANS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 16Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa has suggested a plan to settle the prolonged Rhodesian crisis that, if carried out, would appear certain to bring black rule to Rhodesia within a few years, sources close to the situation reported today.

title: Council Spurs Exemptions In Rent Rises for Elderly
description: Legislation that is expected to double the number of elderly persons exempt from rent increases in regulated apartments was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council's General Wtlfare Committee.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastem Standard Time

title: People in Sports
description: Arthur Ashe said yesterday that India was wrong to default to South Africa in the final of the recent Davis Cup.It was definitely a poor strategic move on India's part, he said. By not playing, India set back normalization of racial tensions two or three years. I'm sure there was pressure exerted on India's team. India has its own problems, such as the caste system. Ashe made his comments at a news conference here in which he announced he was the first player to sign for the $175,000 men's American Airlines Tennis Games next spring in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Mao Said to Tell China to Settle Down
description: PEKING, Dec. 16Chairman Mao Tsetung has declared that it is time for China to settle down after the Cultural Revolution, according to usually reliable sources here.

title: Blacks in U. S. Syphilis Program Settle Their Suit Out of Court
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 16 (AP)Black men who went without treatment for syphilis as part of a Government experiment would receive $37,500 each from the Government under a tentative outofcourt settlement filed today.

title: ONE OF SEXTUPLETS LIVES AS 2 MORE DIE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 16 (UPI)Two more of the Lange sextuplets died today, leaving one survivor among the 10 babies born in the last 13 months to a young mother taking fertility drugs.

title: JUDGE IN BOSTON DEFIED ON BUSING
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16  The School Committee defied a Federal Court order today by refusing to approve a new citywide plan for busing to achieve school desegregation next fall.

title: Season, Namath Started Poorly
description: As Joe Namath fades slowly into the sunset, perhaps never to return, the Jets closed the record book on Season No. 15. The record book, though, won't be entirely accurate; this year actually represented the Jets' 15th and 16th seasons.

title: Soviet Atom Test Detected
description: OSLO, Norway, Dec. 16 (AP) The seismic observatory at Norsar today registered seismic waves presumed to be from an underground nuclear explosion in the eastern Kazakhstan region of the Soviet Union. The observatory said the waves had registered 5.0 on the Richter scale at 1:30 A.M. Eastern standard time.

title: Anatole Litvak Dies at 72; Directed The Snake Pit
description: PARIS, Dec. 16Anatole Litvak, the film director, died last night at a hospital in suburban Neuilly at the age of 72.

title: 2 TeenAge Girls Missing for 3 Days
description: COLONIA, Dec. 16The familes of two teenagers missing since about 10 P.M. Friday said today that they feared the girls had met with disaster.

title: Canadians to Train in Warmer Climes
description: TORONTO, Dec. 16 (UPI)Canadian sports authorities announced plans today to send 229 athletes and coaches to sunshine training camps in Cuba and Arizona to sharpen their talents for the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal. The 139member group going to Havana also will take part in competitive events against, Cuban stars. The sports represented include soccer, water polo, diving, fencing wrestling, men's and women's volleyball and women's basketball. The group will be, in Cuba from Dec. 26 to Jan. 6.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: JUDY COLLINS SINGS IN GENEROUS SPIRITS
description: Judy Collins inspires an almost devotional rapture in her admirers, and it's always wise not to pick critically at people's religious beliefs. The second of Miss Collins's two concerts this weekend, Sunday night at Carnegie Hall, found the folk singer in marginally less secure voice than in the past, but with spirits undiminished. She offered a generous, twoandonehalfhour program, backed most of the time by a smooth septet and ranging all over her repertory, and her fans loved it.

title: U.S. Steel Price Rises
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday price increases averaging 8 to 10 per cent on about twothirds of its product line. Page 51.

title: Ellsberg Papers Said to Make A New Disclosure on Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) New documents collected by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg will disclose another instance in which the public was misled about the progress of the Vietnam war, Dr. Ellsberg and the chairman of a House subcommittee said today.

title: Rules Are Issued
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16With a few modifications, the Government's sale of two million ounces of gold early next month will be carried out in much the same way as sales of other commodities from the national stockpile.

title: Javits and Buckley Vying On Nominee to U.S. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 New York's two Republicans Senators, already embroiled in a public controversy, are now engaged in a second, behindthescenes, dispute involving a forthcoming Presidential appointment.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Job Favoritism Reported In H.U.D. Under Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Political favoritism played major role in hiring practices of the Department of Housing and Urban Development during President Nixon's Administration a government study charged today.

title: Questions Are Raised On Lucky Luciano Book
description: Although The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano has not yet been published by Little, Brown & Co., the 461page book has already earned more than $1million.

title: Rep. Chisholm in Drive for Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Representative Shirley Chisholm of New York, responding to a small but determined movement among some of her colleagues to delay House action on the VicePresidential Nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller, is mounting a campaign for speedy and favorable action.

title: Giants on Verge of Breakthrough
description: A combination of factors that surfaced as far back as summer training camp contributed to the second worse season in the Giants' history.

title: Books of The Times Thy Heart of the Fiction
description: DR. HEART: A NOVELLA AND OTHER STORIES. By Eleanor Clark. 294 pages. Pantheon. $7.95.

title: Appliance Shipments Off
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI)The association of HomeAppliance Manufacturers has reported a 28 per cent drop in November from the same month a year ago in the factory shipments of nearly all appliances except freezers, although all appliance shipments in the first 11 months of 1974 were only 9 per cent below the corresponding 1973 period. Home freezers were up 40 per cent.

title: Paintings by Dissidents Were Bought in Soviet
description: A show and sale of art signed by Russian dissidents that opened Sunday at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N. Y., has so far attracted no purchasers, according to spokesman for the temple. But yesterday some indications of its hitherto undisclosed origins began to emerge.

title: Grant for Dartmouth Project
description: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J., has given the Dartmouth Medical School a $1.5million grant to develop a model primary health care service and training program. The project will be developed with several Vermont and New Hampshire communities.

title: Jack I. Straus to Wed Mrs. Fowler
description: Jack I. Straus, chairman of the executive committee and former chairman and president of R. H. Macy. & Co., Inc., and Virginia Mcgear Fowler, widow of Thomas Powell Fowler, plan to be married here on Jan. 11. The ceremony will be performed in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church by the Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, retired Episcopal Bishop of New York.

title: U.S. STEEL RAISES MANY PRICES 810%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, yesterday announced price increases averaging 8 per cent to 10 per cent on about twothirds of its product line. Most of the higher prices will go into effect tomorrow. They cover a variety of products ranging from heavy construction steel used in buildings and tanks to tubes that transport water and oil.

title: Israel to Get U.S. Wheat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The United States will provide Israel with $9million worth of wheat next year under a new Food for Peace agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Mideast Ready to Explode, Sadat Says
description: CAIRO, Dec. 16 (AP)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt has warned that the Middle East is a bomb ready to explode and that definite progress, toward a settlement must be achieved if Secretary of State Kissinger wants to continue his negotiations.

title: Total Inventories Surged in October
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Total business inventories rose in October by $5.6billion, the largest monthly increase this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (TelevisionChannels 10 and H (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (Radio  WNBC, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Mardian Is Argumentative on CrossExamination
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Former Assistant Attorney General Robert C. Mardian held to his account at the Watergate coverup trial through several hours of crossexamination today, growing increasingly annoyed and argumentative as the examination progressed.

title: Opening F.B.I. Files
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y.A littleknown casualty of Richard M. Nixon's Saturday night massacre was remarkable policy decision to open the Federal Bureau of Investigation files on Alger Hiss, Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and Morton Sobell, and other controversial cold war cases.

title: Senate Ratifies 1925 Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The Senate ratified by a 90.0 vote today the Geneva Protocol of 1925 banning the use of poisonous gases and chemicals and bacteriological weapons in warfare. The treaty, which grew out of World War I experiences, has already been ratified by 103 other countries.

title: Emirates to Discus, 100% Oil TakeOver
description: LONDON, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  The United Arab Emirates will open negotiations with major western oil companies in January to take over 100 per cent of oil concessions, Oil Minister Mana alOtaiba said today.

title: Real Hunter Fuss Is on Bidding
description: Hysterical reactions aside, the Jim (Catfish) Hunter case was in a fairly understandable condition after yesterday's official announcement that the star pitcher no longer had a valid contract with the Oakland A's, and was a free agent able to entertain offers from any major league baseball clubs.

title: $690Million Nassau Budget With PropertyTax Rise Voted
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 16The Nassau County board of Supervisors today adopted a budget for 1975 that calls for a tax increase of $1.06 for each $100 of assessed valuation.

title: Treasury Bills Decline At the Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Dow Index Off by 5.94 After Early Gain
description: Depressing economic news continued to weaken stock prices yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Ali Wins Unanimous Decision as Fighter of the Year
description: Muhammad All was elected fighter of the year by the Boxing Writers Association yesterday. For the voters, it was easier than Ali's knockout victory over George Foreman: All was the only boxer nominated.

title: People in Sports she Faulting India's Default
description: Arthur Ashe said yesterday that India was wrong to default to South Africa in the final of the recent Dayis Cup.

title: Funds for Empty Beds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) Federal Medicaid funds will pay for empty beds in nursing homes while patients make threeday visits to friends and relatives, the Department of Health Education and Welfare announced today.

title: StockMarginDebt Quality Moved Lower in November
description: Figures released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange indicate that in November there was a substantial rise in the number of customers' margin accounts vulnerable to margin, calls.

title: People and Business
description: An a talk in New York last week, Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, urged President Ford to move quickly with a substantive program to cope with the recession.

title: Wright to Go to Civil Court In Transfer of Nine Judges
description: Criminal Court Judge Brucef M. M. Wright, who has become involved in a series of controversies because of his policy of setting low hail, has been reassigned to Civil Court.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Madness of War in Phnom Penh
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia Events in Cambodia have become misshapen in the image of the madness of this warlike the time, when, at an evening reception, the armed forces commander, Lieut. Gen. Sosthene Fernandez, was asked by an acquaintance what he planned to do if the United States Congress went ahead with its plans to cut aid to Cambodia sharply. The general smiled impishly, strode to the other end of, the room, threw his arms into the air in the posture of surrender and declared in French: I'll do this.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Triumph Aided By OldFashioned Bidding
description: The Swiss team championship, which concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Winter Regionals at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday, was a triumph for oldfashioned bidding methods.

title: Rabbi Shot Dead by Youths In Third Mugging Incident
description: A 69yearold rabbi was shot to death in an apparently unsuccessful robbery attempt last night as he was about to enter his apartment in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan.

title: Sweet'n Low to Be Listed as Trademark No. 1,000,000
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Trademark No. 1,000,000 will be registered by the Patent Office tomorrow in the name of the Cumberland Packing Corporation of Brooklyn. It will give protection against unauthorized use of part of the company's existing trademark for Sweet'n Low, a wellknown calory sugar substitute.

title: Sting Names Coach
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI)Bill Foulkes, a 40yearold Briton, was named coach today and Mike Pyle, a former Chicago Bears' center, was named general manager of the newly organized Chicago Sting of the North American Soccer League.

title: STATE BANK AGENCY PLANS NOW APPEAL
description: The New York State Banking Department will seek to appeal a court decision handed down last Thursday that savings banks may now offer checklike noninterestbearing payment order accounts.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thomas V. Burns, accused of kidnapping 7yearold George Kaloyerakis Jr. of Rutherford, was ordered to undergo a twoweek psychiatric examination that will determine whether he will be prosecuted on Federal charges.

title: Cowboys and Colts Flip for No. 1 Draft
description: DALLAS, Dec. 16 (AP)The Dallas Cowboys and Baltimore Colts will flip a coin on Jan. 20 during a National Football League meeting in Miami to determine which team selects the first player in the 1975 college football player draft on Jan. 28.

title: Tokyo Market Lists I.T.T.
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday its shares were now listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. It is the 11th United States corporation to have its shares listed there. Shares of American corporations have been listed on the Tokyo exchange for a year. In addition to I.T.T., others traded there included I.B.M., Dow Chemical, Citicorp and Chase Manhattan.

title: Informer Shifts to Guilty Pleas In Robbery and Burglary Here
description: A 22yearold police informer charged with armed robbery and burglary withdrew his notguilty plea yesterday and said he was guilty in both cases and would accept whatever sentence he deserved.

title: Campisi Trial Recess Set
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 16 (AP) Judge W. Thomas McGann, presiding in the Superior Court trial of the Campisi family, said today that the court would recess for two weeks over Christmas. Eight members of the Campisi family and an associate have been on trial since midSeptember on charges of conspiring to commit five murders and scores of robberies, and on drug and racket charges.

title: House Bars Busing Curb, Sends Funds Bill to Ford By RICHARD D. LYONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Congress resolved a fourmonth battle over school desegregation today when the House followed the Senate's lead and nullified an antibusing amendment in an education money bill, sending the measure on President Ford.

title: Ali Wins Unanimous Decision as Fighter of the Year
description: Muhammad Ali was elected fighter of the year by the Boxing Writers Association yesterday. For the voters, it was easier than Ali's knockout victory over George Foreman: All was the only boxer nominated.

title: Mr. Kuh's Proposals
description: Manhattan District Attorney Richard Kuh has unveiled fifteen bills containing significant and constructive proposals to change and modernize the criminal law. They will be introduced in the next session of the Legislature; most of them deserve support.

title: JACK GAVER IS DEAD; U.P.I. DRAMA CRITIC
description: Jack Gaver drama critic and Broadway columnist for United Press International, died yesterday in Gracie Square Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 7 Peter Cooper Road.

title: Appeal for Sirhan Is Planned on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16District Attorney Joseph P. Busch, whose office oversaw the investigation into the slaying of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, said today that he would reopen an inquiry into the murder only if a court, at the request of Sirhan B. Sirhan, Mr. Kennedy's convicted assailant, ordered it.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Legislation that would enlarge substantially the number of elderly people exempt from rent increases in New York City was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council's general Welfare Committee, which immediately asked the Mayor for a message of necessity so that the entire Council could adopt the measure today.

title: City to Urge U.S. to Back Early Retirement for 860
description: Mayor Beame directed First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh yesterday to lead a Delegation to Washington tomorrow to seek support for the city's plan to retire 860 city employes aged 63 to 65 in order to preserve the jobs of 860 younger civil servants.

title: State Unit Asks Court Aid In NursingHome Inquiry
description: The Temporary State Commission on Living Costs opened court proceedings yesterday to force members of the. Bernard Bergman syndicate of nursing homes to respond to its subpoenas under penalty of criminal contempt.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Dec. 17, 1974 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: 11 FOOD DISPENSERS CITED AS. VIOLATORS
description: The city's Health Department has listed 11 food establishments as having Health Code violations on two inspections. A food establishment that has not passed a third, or final, inspection is subject to closing.

title: Red Smith
description: Sunday afternoon when the National Football League wound up its season with some stadiums half empty, the more violent sport of rodeo was completing the biggest, busiest, richest and in all respects most successful year has ever enjoyed. Baseball is feeling financial pangs on both coasts, professional golf is resigned to a milliondollar drop in prize money, in addition to noshows and a slackening demand for season tickets in the N.F.L. there is the disaster of the World Football League, and rumors of economic decline seem to have penetrated close to the Oval Office in the White House. Still, if crisis is indeed upon us even Gerald Ford will hear about it before the news reaches guys like Tom Ferguson and Don Gay. They are among the youngsters who walked away from Oklahoma City yesterday bowlegged with loot.

title: Hofstra Topples Adelphi by 6665
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 16 Bernard Tomlin tallied 19 points and Bob Dowling grabbed 12 rebounds to lead Hofstra team to a 6665 basketball victory over Adelphi tonight.

title: EDWARD M'CABE, TOP POLICE AIDE
description: Edward J. McCabe, a Deputy Police Commissioner from 1960 to 1961, died Saturday in the Greater Baltimore Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Timonium, Md.

title: State Court Vetoes A Special Election In New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 16 (16)  The New Hampshire Supreme Court ruled today that a special election cannot be called in the state's disputed United States Senate race unless it ends up in a tie.

title: Business Briefs
description: Pan Am Air Quitting Aid Pact

title: Senators Vote to Allow Girls To Play Little League Baseball
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) The Senate voted today to give girls the same chance as boys to play Little League baseball.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Supermarket Chain Pays Fine for ShortWeighting
description: James Lack, the Suffolk County Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, reported yesterday that his department had exacted $1,500, which he called the highest penalty in its history, from the Hills Supermarket chain for shortweight violations.

title: Assorted Ills Plague Florida's Condominium Market
description: MIAMI, Dec. 13Hit simultaneously by inflation, tight money, overbuilding and scandal, the condominium market on southeastern Florida's Gold Coast has crumbled.

title: Stage: Revue Is Rediscovered in a Chic Pretzels
description: Whatever happened to revues? Were they eaten by television one dark night, or did the public just forget about them and let them starve from neglect? When did people stop writing them, and when did people stop going to them, and which people stopped first? In any event, it is a pleasure to welcome a member of that obviously endangered species, the revue, to Theater Four on West 55th Street. The specimen is called Pretzels, and it was discovered, alive and well, last night.

title: WOUNDED DETECTIVE PUT ON CRITICAL LIST
description: A detective sergeant was listed in critical condition yesterday after a shoot out in Brooklyn with a 24yearld suspect in the attempted murder of two policemen and the robbery of a bank.

title: Booing the Hockey Players Helps Sorne Work Harder
Jockey Ties Mark of 515 In Victories
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 16 (AP) Chris McCarron, who posted his first career victory a little more than 10 months ago, tied the world record for the most victories by a jockey in a year today. He rode two winners at Laurel Race Course and raised his total to 515.

title: P.U.C. Says Users of Gas Face Service Curtailment
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16  The State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners warned today that severe cutbacks imposed on New Jersey's gas utilities by their pipeline suppliers will make it impossible for us to make it through the winter without some customer curtailment. As a result the board issued a priority list for natural gas use this winter in the state.

title: On Energy Policy
description: From directors of large corporations as well as the chauffeurs who drive them to their boardrooms comes a common lament these days, that if the country had any real leadership its citizens would be willing and able to pitch in to solve problems. A year has passed in which everyone has become aware that, there is something wrong about the way energy is used in this country, yet the elected officials still find themselves flailing about in a pudding of vagaries without any clear definition of the problem.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Hunting Asset
description: After the supper dishes were washed and a coyote had ended his yelping from the mountainside, the conversation at a northern New Hampshire hunting camp last month turned to the merits of using a shotgun rather than a rifle for deer in the densely wooded Northeast.

title: Mine Deaths at Low
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UPI) The Mining Enforcement and Safety Administration reported that today 99 coal miners were killed on the job from January through Septemberrecord. low.

title: Train Hits Car, Snarling Traffic on L.I
description: South Shore commuters on the Long Island Rail Road were delayed throughout the evening rush hour yesterday after a 10car eastbound train with 700 riders struck a stalled car whose driver had struggled vainly to push it out of the way before jumping to safety.

title: Frank Dunne, Established Investment Securities Firm
description: Frank Dunne, who retired last year as head of Dunne & Co., investment securities, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Mineola, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP)  The United States Olympic Committee has adopted a bill of rights for athletes as part of the most sweeping constitutional revision in the organization's 50year history. The action was announced today by Philip O. Krumm, the president. He said the revisions approved unanimously at the biennial meeting yesterday, would protect the rights of all athletes to participate in international amateur sports competition without fear of action by any organization.

title: $5.3Million Added For Stales Purses
38 Hartford Nursing Homes Assailed
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 16A study by the Connecticut public Interest Research Group of 38 nursing homes in the Hartford region made public here today painted a picture of nadequate care, repeated violaions of state requirements and nadequate supervision by the State Department of Health.

title: Jobert Dazzles Voters in France
description: PARIS, Dec. 16  At first they laughed at me, former Foreign Minister Michel Jobert said of the reaction of most established French politicians to the political movement that he began last summer. Now they're afraid of me.

title: EARLIER OPENING SET AT MACY N.Y. STORES
description: The city's largest retailer, the New York division of R. H. Macy & Co., will take the unusual step starting this Saturday of opening its stores at 8:30 A.M., or an hour and 15minutes earlier than usual. The stores will also be open at that hour on Dec. 23 and 24.

title: PLAN BY YORSTER REPORTED GIVEN TO RHODESIANS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec, 16Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa has suggested a plan to settle the prolonged Rhodesian crisis that, if carried out, would appear certain to bring black rule to Rhodesia within a few years, sources close to the situation reported today.

title: Martinique Compromise
description: The FordGiscard meeting in Martinique appears to have brought about a significant change in France's position on oilconsumer cooperation from oddmanout to oddmanin.

title: LOWER RATE SEEN IN FEDERAL FUNDS;By Entering Money Market, Reserve Implies a Range of 88 Is Acceptable;CREDIT EASING PRESSED;Prices of Mott Corporate Bands Slightly FirmerTaxExempts Steady
description: The Federal Reserve apparently confirmed yesterday that it had chosen a lower trading range for Federal funds, a key indicator of monetary policy, in the central bank's current move toward easing credit. The Fed Credit stepped into the Markets money market to inject temporary reserves into the banking system when Federal funds (overnight loans between banks) were trading at 8 per cent.

title: FORD AND GISCARD WILL COORDINATE POLICY ON ENERGY
description: FORTDEFRANCE, Martinique, Dec. 16President Ford and President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France announced today that they had reached a compromise agreement to coordinate their energy policies.

title: F.T.C. Assailed for Ending FoodChain Price Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16A consumer representative attacked the Federal Trade Commission today for dropping an investigation here that she said had been well on the way to establishing a link between high food prices and a lack of competition in food stores.

title: Support for Portugal
description: The United States has finally abandoned its shortsighted waitandsee policy toward Portugal and launched a modest economic aid program aimed at helping the effort to build a free and democratic society in that country after forty years of dictatorship. This represents a turnaround by Secretary of State Kissinger, who had marked time on the aid issue presumably because the Communist party had demonstrated strength since its return to legality and because its leader is a minister in the present Government.

title: INCOMETAX PLAN LOSES IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16For the second time this year and for the third time in New Jersey's legislative history, the Senate Democratic majority has rejected in caucus a state income tax.

title: Patricia Hearst Is Named To Share in $2.5Million
description: Patricia Hearst, the fugitive heiress sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a member of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, was named yesterday to share in the estate, estimated at $2.5million, left by her grandmother, United Press International reported.

title: Mattel Turns Profit For the Nine Months
Fulton Freeman, 59, ExEnvoy TO Mexico and Colombia, Dies.
description: CARMEL, Calif, Dec. 16 (AP)Fulton Freeman, former Ambassador to Mexico and Colombia, and since 1969 president of the Monterey Institute of Foreign Studies died Saturday after suffering a heart attack during a golf game. His was 59.

title: Parseghian Move Surprise
description: Ara Parseghian's decision to resign as Notre Dame's football coach was a surprise and shock to his colleagues, many of whom felt it stemmed from his intense nature and the extreme pressures imposed upon a major college coach.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Golden State Warriors, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (TelevisionChannels 10 and H (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (Radio  WNBC, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Notes on Trade, etc.
description: The headlines suggest a few whimsies for the season of toys and tinsel:

title: 5LB. SUGAR PRICE DECLINES TO $2.79
description: The first break in the retail price of sugar since the sharp increases of November came yesterday when cost of a fivepound bag in some supermarkets dropped to $2.79.

title: Senate Sends Strip Mine Bill to Ford; Prompt Action on Veto Threat Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Congress today cleared the strip mine control bill that President Ford announced last week he intends to veto. The Senate passed the bill by voice vote, sending it to the White House.

title: Roadside Booby Traps Laid to Federal Agency
description: The Center for Auto Safety charged yesterday that widespread failures by the Federal Highway Administration were permitting continued construction of highway booby traps responsible for an estimated total of more than 18,000 deaths a year.

title: Edward A. Pierce Dies at 100; Helped to Found Merrill Lynch
description: Edward Allen Pierce, the last living original member of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the country's largest brokerage house, died here yesterday in his home. He had turned 100 last Aug. 31.

title: NIXON TO CHALLENGE! CONGRESS ON TAPES;
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (Reuters)Former President Richard M. Nixon plans to challenge the constitutional right of Congress to provide public access to his White House tape recordings and documents, his lawyers disclosed today.

title: 1.98Inch Rain Breaks Record for Date in City
description: Umbrellas sprouted on the sidewalks and traffic crawled in the streets yesterday as a record, daylong rain storm saturated the city and suburbs with a downpour that flooded lowlying sections, knocked down power lines and made some highways impassable.

title: TURKEY ASSESSES EXTENDED AID BAN
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 16Turkish and American diplomats here say they are convinced that relations between their two countries could deteriorate sharply if the United States Congress extended the ban on Military aid to Turkey.

title: Carter's Brass Quintet Has Premiere
description: Elliott Carter's Brass Quintet, which received its New York premiere Sunday at Alice Tully Hall under the auspices of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, is a relatively accessible work within the composer's oeuvre although from the coughing and program rustling by those who had come for the romantic part of the program, one wouldn't have thought so. Mr. Carter's piece, which was composed this summer for the American Brass Quintet, was performed by that group Sunday and had been previously heard in London and Washington.

title: Dr. Sokol Weds Dr. Robyn Deutsch
description: Dr. Robyn Helene Deutsch, a resident in pediatrics at the Beth Israel Medical Center, and Dr. Abraham I. Sokol, a resident in internal medicine there, were married yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Israel Rabinowitz performed the ceremony in the, Ohel Moisha Synagogue in the Bronx.

title: Connecticut Panel Clears Meskill's Name
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 16Prodded by United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Connecticut legislative panel investigating state leasing practices issued a statement here tonight saying that it had no evidence that Gov. Thomas J. Meskill had been involved in any illegal acts.

title: Raleigh, N.C., Jury Lists Mayor's Wife In Shoplifting Case
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 16The wife of Raleigh's Mayor has been indicted on charges of conspiring to receive stolen goods. The police said her name had been found in a notebook carried by an accused shoplifter, who reportedly took orders to steal expensive clothiing and meat.

title: BakedatHome Snacks To Munch and Crunch
description: Crackers cost too much? Wish you had some unsweetened wafers around the house to eat with soup, cheese or just as a snack? There's a waymake them yourself.

title: Advertising
description: Since the beginning of the month, 100 city busesmost of them on the West Sidehave been adorned with nothing but local retail ads each of which bears the tagline Making it in New York with Dalmatian's 100.

title: Vols Win On Late Pass. 73
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 16 (AP)Randy Wallace, a reserve quarterback, threw an 11yard scoring pass to Larry Seivers with 2 minutes 38 seconds left tonight to give Tennessee a 73 Liberty Bowl victory over the Maryland Terrapins.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Franklin State Bank, with headquarters in Somerset and 26 branches in five Central Jersey counties, announced that it had set aside $5million to be loaned at 8 per cent interest to stimulate the homebuilding industry in Central New Jersey. Anthony D. Schoberl, president of the bank, said the funds were earmarked to finance up to 80 per cent of the purchase price, of new homes and to cover both construction loans and permanent mortgages.

title: Harvard Man Admits Forgery; Denies He Falsified Research
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 Steven S. Rosenfeld, a senior who was forced to withdraw from Harvard College last week for fabricating letters of recommendation, issued a, statement today denying that he had also falsified results in a major biochemistry research project in which he was participating at the school.

title: Power Plant Fine Urged
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (UPI) Dr. Ronald Knuth, director of regulatory operations for the Atomic Energy Commission, recommended today a $25,000 fine for Commonwealth Edison Company for 18 apparent violations of commission regulations at the Dresden nuclear) power plant near Morris, Ill.

title: U.S. Steel Price Rises
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday price increases averaging 8 to 10 per cent on about twothirds of its product line. Page 51.

title: To Fugard, His Playwriting Represents Defiance
description: Whenever Athol Fugard leaves a country, he expects to have trouble with his passport. It is not a question of paranoia but of pragmatism. Five years ago his passport was, without explanation, removed by the Government of South Africa and the three years later it was, without explanation, returned. Now he travels freely but with trepidation.

title: Carey's Aides Setting the Tone of His Administration
description: While Governorelect Hugh L. Carey has yet to name his first state appointees, he has assembled a private hierarchy of advisers and technicians that already is setting the tone for his administration as a cautious one, very much under his control.

title: STEFAN PRIACEL, 70, INTERPRETER, DEAD
description: PARIS, Dec. 16  Stefan Priacel, one of the leading conference interpreters on the international circuit, died here today. He was 70 years old.

title: Pittston Lifts Dividend, Declares a Cash Payout
description: The Pittston Company, the nation's largest independent coal producer, declared yesterday an increase in its quarterly cash dividend to 20 cents a share from 15 cents.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: LAWYER ACCUSED OF DEATH OF FETUS
description: HOWELL TOWNSHIP, Dec. 16 (AP)A Massachusetts lawyer faces two charges of death by automobile here following a car accident in which he is alleged to have caused the death of a pregnant woman and her unborn child.

title: Buchanan Victor; Bout Ends in 14th
description: PARIS, Dec. 16 (AP)Ken Buchanan of Scotland bled for 13 rounds but successfully defended his European lightweight championship tonight when his fight against Leonard Tavarez of France was halted in the 14th round.

title: Rape Suspect Shot As a Policewoman Assists Roommate
description: A 30yearold Lower East Side resident with a record of 14 arrests was shot and slightly wounded by a policewoman early yesterday morning after what she said was an attempt to rape her roommate in an East Village apartment.

title: House Would Limit Funds For Homes of Presidents
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UN) The House acting in response to the $17million spent on former President Richard M. Nixon's homes, approved a bill today that would restrict any future spending on Presidential residences.

title: Snacks for Jail Inmates Urged at Mental Hearing
description: NEWARK, Dec. 16 Scores of suggestions were offered here today at the first public hearing of the State Mental Health Planning Committee, which is charged with developing a plan for comprehensive health services for all New Jersey residents. Included was a recommendation that nightly snacks be served to jail inmates with mental problems or those who might develop them. The theory behind the suggestion was that different nutritional needs may be found among persons in trouble with the law than with average persons.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Kuh, on the Stand, Defends His Aide On Juror's Letter
description: In a rare court appearance as a witness, District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan indicated yesterday that there was nothing improper in an aide's withholding of a possibly controversial letter from the court and the defense counsel in the murder trial of a former policeman, William Phillips.

title: And in the Museums' Shops, Business Is Thriving
description: It's walltowall people and plenty, of profit these ?? in museum shops across the land as the last surge of Christmas shoppers, descends to purchase everything from Christmas cards to Fieldcrest sheets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Burglars Shot, One Dies
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 16 (UPI)Roy Tuggle, Fort Lauderdale area man, shot and killed one burglar and wounded another today after they entered his house and tied up his wife.

title: Moscow Is Keeping Minister of Culture In Party Politburo
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 16The new Soviet Minister of Culture was removed from his post of national party secretary today as the party's Central Committee held a closed meeting here.

title: U.S. LIKELY TO VETO U.N. SANCTIONS BID
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16The United States indicated today that it would veto any Security Council resolution calling for sanctions against South Africa.

title: Britain's Economy Seerns to Be Losing Battle With Inflation and Trade Deficit
description: LONDON, Dec. 16The signs are increasing that Britain is losing the battle against her two most persistent and serious economic ailments  chronic inflation and an immense trade deficit.

title: Burma Sentences 24 to Prison For Violence Over Thant Burial
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 16 (Reuters)  Special military tribunals today sentenced 24 more people to three years' imprisonment, for their part in mob violence here last week, bringing to 87 the total convicted so far.

title: Cancer Grant to Columbia
description: The National Cancer Institute h??s awarded Columbia University a $5.8million grant to construvt a special laboratory area for ewer research. Total cost of the facility is estimated te $15.9million.

title: JUDGE IN BOSTON DEFIED ON BUSING
description: BOSTON, Dec. 16  The School Committee defied a Federal Court order today by refusing to approve a new citywide plan for busing to achieve school desegregation next fall.

title: INCOMETAX PLAN LOSES IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16For the second time this year and for the third time in New Jersey's legislative history, the Senate Democratic majority has rejected in caucus a state income tax.

title: For the Holidays, Museums Offer Festive Bouquets...
description: The holiday season, as celebrated at museums around the city, is a rich bouquet of Christmas and other festivals. While traditional displays are much in evidence, Hanukkah Kwanza and Three Kings Day are also honored, providing such extra added attractions as a show of antique menorahs, a Karamu feast and the sounds of plena, or Puerto Rican folk music.

title: STOCK UNIT FIGHTS CHANGE IN RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16The Securities Industry Association told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it opposed a change from fixed to negotiated commission rates on brokerage transactions under any conditions.

title: Blues Trounce Islanders, 84
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 17Ted Lindsay, the former Detroit Red Wing who played 17 seasons in the National Hockey League, watched tonight's contest between the St. Louis Blues and the New York Islanders and called it probably one of the worst games I've ever seen. The two coaches agreed their players had given terrible performances. The result was an 84 victory for the Blues in St. Louis Arena before a crowd of 17,249.

title: JOSEPH A. LIVINGSTON
description: Joseph A. Livingston, a retired sportswear manufacturer, died of a kidney ailment yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 70 East 77th Street.

title: CHESTER ROHRLICH, LAWYER AND AUTHOR
description: Chester Rohrlich, lawyer, legal author and teacher, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 22 East 88th Street.

title: U.S. to Boycott U .N. Fund To Aid Countries in Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Wednesday, Dec. 18The United States has decided to boycott a special fund being set up here to provide emergency relief and development aid to the countries hardest hit economically.

title: COURTS ARE DEFIED BY MINE WORKERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 (UPI) Striking mine construction workers defied court orders today to cease their picketing, which has virtually halted all coal production and made thousands of miners idle.

title: A. King McCord Is Dead at 70; Led Westinghouse Air Brake
description: A. King McCord, former chairman of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company, died yesterday in West Penn Hospital, Pittsburgh. He was 70 years old and lived in Fox Chapel, Pa.

title: Nixon's Bay Lane Opened, Rebozo's Bank Robbed
description: MIAMI, Dec. 17  Richard M. Nixon, for six years the most powerful person in the most powerful nation on earth, wag turned down today by the Dade County Board of Commissioners on a petition to keep tourists off the road in front of his house. The vote was 5 to 3.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Katherine Lilly Conroy, 83, Dies; Aided Training of Handicapped
description: Katherine Lilly Conroy, widow of William H. Conroy, an insurance executive, and daughter of Evan F. Lilly, a founder of the Eli Lilly Drug Company, died Monday at her home in Washington, Conn, was 83 years old.

title: Glen Cove May Reduce Teaching Staff
description: MINEOLA, L. L Dec. 17The Glen Cove school district may have to cut its teaching staff and educational programs because of a limit on its taxing power resulting from a court decision, the president of the city's Board of Education said today.

title: Pan Am and T.W.A. Set Austria Route Accord
description: Pan American World Airways agreed yesterday to give Trans World Airlines its authority to serve Austria from this country, in a revised plan for a global routeexchange agreement between the two United States flag airlines.

title: The Gold Trust Offering
description: The National Securities and Research Corporaton, investment managers with about $525million under management, reported yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of 1.5 million units of a gold trust to be sold at $20 each. National Securities, the issuer, said the offering would be managed by Loeb, Rhoades & Co.; Harris, Upham & Co., Inc., Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes, Inc. and Dean Witter & Co., Inc. The funds will be invested in gold bullion, the issuer said.

title: Wall Street in Red, But Bonuses Flow
description: Wall Street is flooded with red ink, but some of the biggest investment banking houses in the country are nevertheless paying yearend bonuses, a spot check of leading investment houses disclosed yesterday.

title: MORE WOMEN SEEK TO STOP DRINKING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17Nearly onethird of those who have joined Alcoholics Anonymous during the last three years are women, according to a survey announced today by the chairman of the board of trustees of the organization.

title: Satellite Launching Today
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP)A Symphonie communications satellite for France and West Germany is scheduled to he launched at 9:39 P.M. tomorrow following a oneday delay caused by a fuel leak.

title: Group Aids Defense of Reporters on Subpoenas and Gag Orders by Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 13 When a reporter receives a subpoena, or a judge issues gag order against the press, the, chances are that the first place a journalist or his lawyer will turn to for help is a littleknown, underfinanced, understaffed organization called the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract of about $40million has been awarded by Exxon, U.S.A. to Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan for the construction of a deep water semisubmersible drilling rig capable of drilling in depths up to 1,500 feet. Exxon said it hoped to use the rig for rough water deep drilling in the Gulf of Alaska and other areas off the West Coast of the United States.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec, 17Lou Guarini, an 18yearold college sophomore, may be the youngestcoach of a varsity high school team in the country. And a successful one at that.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Two Black Politicians Press Carey to Name Paterson Secretary of State
description: Two leading black politicians said yesterday they were pressing Governorelect Hugh L. Carey to appoint Basil A. Paterson as Secretary of State, arguing that the black community deserved a visible state post and that the frontrunner for the job, Mario M. Cuomo, was not so well qualified.

title: Uruguay Dentist Shot to Death in Robbery Near Queens Home
description: A former professor of dentistry at the University of Uruguay was found shot to death Monday evening on the sidewalk only three doors from his home in Jamaica Estates, Queens, in what the police said yesterday was an apparent robbery.

title: SCIENTISTS DECRY OFFICIAL'S OUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Six prominent scientists deplored today the forced resignation of the director of the National Institutes of Health, the nation's foremost biomedical research organization.

title: MORE EXPULSIONS BY SEOUL FEARED
description: A Methodist missionary, expelled from South Korea last Saturday for criticizing The Government of President Park Chung Hee said yesterday that he believed three other missionaries were under immediate threat of deportation and that 15 more might, also be forced to leave.

title: Monument Plans a Closing
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) The Washington Monument will be closed to the public Jan. 6 through March 21 for interior structural, mechanical and architectural improvements. Jack Fish, director of the National Capital Parks said today the closing was required to prepare for the millions of visitors expected in the bicentennial period.

title: Wizard, Lovingly Done, by Children for Children
description: The pendulum has been swinging back and forth between structure and freedom for children, between total adult authority over them and letting them govern themselves. Watching the Mori Mini Players seems to make it clear that it doesn't have to be a choice, that the two extremes can be moderated into reciprocal harmony.

title: GISCARD SURVIVES CENSURE ATTEMPT
description: PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The Government of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, which came to power in May, easily survived its first challenge in Parliament early today.

title: Australia Confirms the Use Of Soldiers as Guinea Pigs
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 17 (Reuters)Australian troops in World War II were used as guinea pigs in poison gas experiments, a federal minister confirmed today.

title: Egypt and Syria Divided On U.S. Peace Proposals
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 12 A serious rift has developed between Egypt and Syria over United States proposals for a second step in the disengagement of Arab and Israeli armies.

title: Red Smith
description: Fired by the pioneering spirit that distinguished Lewis & Clark, John C. Fremont and Walter O'Malley, a little band of explorers wearing hard hats of robin'segg blue struck off yesterday into the Bronx wasteland that was Babe Ruth's playground and may some day be Catfish Hunter's. The party included eight or 10 male members of the sportlog press, about the same number of photographers, one young lady and a reformed shortstop named Phil Rizzuto. They were led by the Yankees' publicist, Marty Appel, and an architect named Perry Green.  Show us where Hunter's going to work, an optimist suggested, Mr. Appelsmiled a silent, wistful smile and set out through a desolation steel and lumber and pipes and cables and concrete and mud. The selective demolition that began in October, 1973, has left only the bare bones Yankee Stadium. The area in the middle where Catfish Hunter would work if the Yankees were to outbid 23 other teams for the services of this emancipated pitcher is an abomination of muck and rainwater ponds.

title: WNBCFM Abandons Rock For Popular Music Format
description: WNBCFM radio has changed its musical format from rock to 24hours of lowkey popular music. John Lund, program manager for WNBCAM and FM, said the new format, Called The Love of New York, was geared to a younger audience than those of most easy listening stations in New York.

title: Nuclear Reactor Leak
description: MORRIS, Ill., Dec. 17 (AP)The Atonlic'Energy Commission ordered checks today at 14 nuclear reactors built by the General Electric Company, after leaks were discovered in a Dresden reactor's cooling systern near nere.

title: Reagan's G.O.P. Financial Backers, in Move Interpreted as Signal to Ford, Give Luncheon for Bentsen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Gov. Ronald Reagan's inner circle of Republican financial backers in California gave a quiet luncheon in Los Angeles last Friday for Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr., the Texas Democrat who is apparently on the verge of declaring his Presidential candidacy.

title: WILLIAM W. SHARP JR.
description: GREENSBORO, Dec. 17, N.C. (Ap)  William W. Sharp Jr., a founder and executive vice president of the National Association of Lefthanded Golfers, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: Proposal to Protect States On Lotteries Clears Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) The Senate Judiciary Committee today cleared leglislation that would permit 13 states to continue operating lotteries without fear of Federal reprisals.

title: Schaefer Seeks TakeOver Of a Portion of Piers Beer
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Brewing Company announced yesterday that it and Piel Bros., Inc., were engaged in negotiations which would permit Schaefer to assume the total manufacturing and marketing of about 1 million barrels of the Piel's and Trommer's brands of beer.

title: Moratorium on Use of the Poor In Medical Research Suggested
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17So ciety should consider a moratorium on use of the poor as subjects of medical experimentation, a doctor suggested today.

title: Advertising
description: If there is an earnings drop in 1975, I don't think it'll be anything like what some economists are forecasting, Cari Spielvogel, vice chairman of the Interpublic Group of Companies, told a smattering of securities analysts yesterday.

title: Limited Resource
description: Within limits Mayor Beame's proposal for largescale investment of cityemploye pension reserves in municipal bonds offers an easy and constructive way to steady the creaky market for New York City securities. It already has had a beneficial effect in that direction by enabling Controller Goldin to assure the banking community yesterday that the city would not have to go through with a new $500million bond issue next month.

title: Head of F.C.C. Weighing Hearing on TV Violence
description: With time running out on the Dec. 31 deadline Congress has imposed on the Federal Communications Commission for plans to deal with sex and violence on television, Richard E. Wiley, the agency's chairman, said yesterday that one of the commission's initiatives could be a public proceeding, This would mean open hearings on network practices with programs considered unsuitable for juvenile viewing.

title: Newark Archdiocese to Study Efficiency of Its 253 Parishes
description: NEWARK, Dec. 17 (UPI)The Newark Archdiocese is studying the efficiency of its 253 parishes to begin tightening up its finances, the Most Rev. Peter L. Gerety said today.

title: $1Million in Birth Pill Suit
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI)Mrs. Michelle Ahearn, 35 years old, and her husband, Dennis, have been awarded more than $1million damages in a suit over birth control pills that she said made her permanently blind. A Santa Clara County Superior Court jury awarded the woman $1,248,254 and her husband $105,668. The defendants were the Ortho Pharmaceutical Company, manufacturer of OrthoNovum, the Johnson & Johnson Drug Company, and Lucky Stores, owner of the pharmacy where the drug was purchased on a prescription.

title: LIONEL A RACINE
description: Lionel A. Racine, assistant controller of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 39 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Bomb Suspect Loses Plea
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (AP) A judge has denied the accused alphabet bomber, who says he is mute, the privilege of conducting his own trial. His inability to speak would probably hamper him in conducting his own defense, Superior Court Judge Raymond Choate said yesterday in denying the motion of Muharem Kurbegovic. The 31yearold Yugoslavian immigrant is stemming from six bombings.

title: Saigon's Setbacks Increase as Comrnunists Vary Their Attacks
