description: New York has not heard much of Charlie Ventura since he was the tenor saxaphone star of Gene Krupa's big band 30 years ago and later led the small bop combo that started the joint careers of Jackie Cain and Roy Kral. But he is back in action now at Michael's Pub, where he expands the Teddy Wilson Trio to a quartet.

title: Hershfield Service Today
description: Mayor Beame will head the honorary pallbearers at a funeral service today for Harry Hershfield, the humorist and raconteur, who died Sunday evening at the age of 89. The service will be held at noon at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West 88th Street.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: College scouts are knocking on doors and writing persuasive literature to the many football prospects produced by the recent New Jersey campaign.

title: Prolonged' Economic Slowdown Seen in Report on Industrial Lands
description: PARIS, Dec. 18A proounced and prolonged slowown involving the risk of a break in confidence was rojected today for the indusialized nations of the West by to Organization of Economic ??operation and Development.

title: Ford's Rental of a Ski Chalet Involves Him in a Controversy
description: DENVER, Dec. 18President Ford found himself in the midst of a controversy today over his decision to rent a larger and more secure home for his skiing holiday in Vail, Colo.

title: Better Cyprus Prospect
description: Conditions for realistic negotiations aimed at producing both a humanitarian and a political remedy for the agonies of Cyprus seem better now than at any time since midAugust, just prior to Turkey's massive invasion of the island. Even the fact that Turkey has only a caretaker Government no longer appears an insurmountable, obstacle to serious Cyprus talks.

title: Keynes and Unifinished Business
description: WASHINGTONAs the world staggers from one economic disaster to another, questions arise: Whose fault is it? Are economists or politician's to blame?

title: Port Authority Director Gets a $10,000 Raise
description: A. Gerdes Kuhbach, executive director of the Port Author,ity of New York and New Jersey, was given a 10,000ayear raise last week, increasing his salary to $80,000 a year, a Port Authority spokesman said last night.

title: Condor, 55, Spurned Here as a Suitor, Will Go Back to Milwaukee Zoo
description: A 55yearold South American condor named Long John Silver, who has been at the Bronx Zoo for 14 months, will be returned to the Milwaukee Zoo, from which he had been brought in the hope that he would mate with a condor at the Bronx Zoo named Miss MacNasty. The mission failedMiss MacNasty maintained her usual aloofness and Long John spent most of his time sulking behind a clump of bamboo.

title: Transit Priorities
description: Mayor Beame's decision to stop work on the Second Avenue subway in order to focus limited funds on higher transit priorities represents a realistic adjustment totard timeshard times for the city and for its deficitridden and deteriorating transit system.

title: Ford's Rental of a Ski Chalet Involves Him in a Controversy
description: DENVER, Dec. 18President Ford found himself in the midst of a controversy today over his decision to rent a larger and more secure home for his skiing holiday in Vail, Colo.

title: Bolt From Cairo
description: Cairo's latest statement of terms for making peace with Israel seem on their face illtimed in presentation and absurd in content. A sweeping official declaration came without warning last week, in the midst of a sensitive and far less ambitious mediation effort by Secretary of State Kissinger. Commanding all the headlines based on this statement was the ridiculous and presumptuous demand that Israel freeze her present population level and suspend all further immigration. American diplomats were understandably upset at this unexpected ploy; the Israelis can hardly be blamed for treating the immigration demand with contempt.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 47

title: U.S. Accepts Soviet Space Hitchhike
description: The United States has accepted its first opportunity to place a scientific experiment aboard an unmanned Soviet spacecraft.

title: Wilder's Uneven Film of 'Front Page':The Cast
description: It had to happen sooner or later that Billy Wilder, one of the most astringent wits of the American cinema, would make a movie out of "The Front Page," the great nineteen-twenties Chicago newspaper farce by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur. No matter that it's been very well made beforein 1931 by Lewis Milestone and in 1940 by Howard Hawks, who turned the play into his own movie classic.The property is a natural for Mr. Wilder and his screenwriting, collaborator, I.A.L. Diamond, who, despite all their comparatively "nice" hits ("Love in the Afternoon," "Some Like It Hot," "The Apartment" and "The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes"), have a special (and, to my mind, very appealing) appreciation for vulgar, brilliant con artists of monumental tackiness.This appreciation has resulted in at least one Wilder movie of such bad taste that its gaffs became its gaudy style ("Kiss Me, Stupid") and in another movie that ranks among their very best, "The Fortune Cookie.""The Front Page," which opened yesterday at the Coronet and Little Carnegie Theaters, falls somewhere between these two extremes. Even though the mechanics and demands of movie-making slow what should be the furious tempo, this "Front Page" displays a giddy bitterness that is rare in any films except those of Mr. Wilder. It is also, much of the time, extremely funny.The orginal place and time (Chicago in the late twenties) have been preserved, as well as the principal setting, the press room in Chicago's ancient Criminal Courts Building, The Wilder-Diamond screenplay updates and makes somewhat rougher the original tough-guy dialogue and wisecracks, but the story has not been violated. It's still about the efforts of Chicago's most brilliant, most ruthless managing editor, Walter Burns (Walter Matthau) to keep his star reporter, Hildy Johnson (Jack Lemmon), on the job long enough to cover the impending execution of a poor, shy left - wing innocent whom Chicago's yellow press has turned into a Red Menace from Moscow.The film contains at least two marvelous performances, Mr. Matthau's snarling, monomaniacal editor ("I picked you up when you were nothingcovering Polack weddings on the South Side!") and Austin Pendleton as the-condemned revolutionary who got his start stuffing fortune cookies with messages demanding freedom for Sacco and Vanzetti.Mr. Lemmon is comparatively reserved as the flamboyant Hildy, never quite letting go of his familiar comic personality to become dominated by the lunacies of the farce. He always remains a little outside it, acting.Carol Burnett has an even tougher time as Molly Malloy, the self-described $2 Clark Street whore who loves Mr. Pendleton. This role may well be impossible, however, since it requires the actress to play for straight melodrama while everyone around her is going for laughs. Two lines sum up the difficulty of the role as they define the spirit of the movie. When Molly, in a desperate effort to save her lover, jumps out the courthouse window to what could be her death, one reporter shakes his head and says, "All whores are a little goofy," while another races to his telephone to report, "Shady lady leaps for love!"Mr. Wilder has great fun with the period newspaper detailsuch as human interest stories about Admiral Byrd and penguinsand admires his various supporting actors to such an extent that he allows them to play as broadly as they could possibly desire. Some are better than others.I particularly liked Vincent Gardenia as an inefficient sheriff, Martin Gabel as a mad Viennese alienist and David Wayne as a prissy Chicago Tribune reporter, a performance that may bring down the wrath of the Gay Activists Alliance though it seems as much of a comment on what was considered funny in the twenties as it is a replayed homosexual stereotype.The hysteria is not as consistent as one might wish, nor, indeed, as epic as in Mr. Wilder's own "One, Two, Three." The cohesive force is, instead, the director's fondness for frauds, which, I suspect, is really an admiration for people who barrel on through life completely intimidating those who should know better.

title: U.S. Tells U.N.. It Boycotts Aid Fund
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 The United States, joined by West Germany, formally told the General Assembly today it would not serve on the board of a new special fund to assist the most economically distressed countries and said it saw dim prospects that the new body would get adequate resources.

title: New Orleans Transit Struck
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 (AP)  Some 370,000 commuters, and Christmas shoppers took to their cars and to taxis today because of the city's first transit strike in 45 years.

title: Letters to the Editor The Great Gold Sale: Our Treasury's Desperate Bluff
description: To the Editor: I was very surprised to read your Dec. 5 editorial praising the U.S. Treasury's plan to sell two million ounces of gold on Jan. 6. I realize that it is to the Government's advantage to prevent a further deterioration in our balanceofpayments position; however, I don't think you really analyzed the magnitude of the situation.

title: Tuesday's Fight
description: Orlando, Fla.Gene Wells, 161 pounds, Houston, knocked out Renie Pindser, 168, Bahamas, 4 rounds.

title: Bearne Asking Rent Rises To Offset High Fiel Costs
description: Mayor Beame proposed legislation yesterday that would permit landlords of as many as 900,000 rentcontrolled apartments here to get monthly rent rises of up to $3 a room next year, if they can show that this year's sharply higher fuel costs have exceeded a certain level.

title: Fordham Beats CC.N.Y., 8577
description: Darryl Brown's 28 points and 16 rebounds led Fordham to an 8577 victory over City College last night in the losers' gym.

title: At Least 20 Are Injured In 2 Blasts in British City
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (UPI)Two bombs exploded within few minutes of each other tonight on a busy shopping street in the port city of Bristol. At least 20 persons were injured, and the police said they suspected the Irish Republican Army.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN AMEX TRADING
description: For the second consecutive session, volume gained in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices also were higher. Volume was down on the overthecounter market but prices were up.

title: BRENNAN REJECTS CITY RETIREMENT OF 860 EMPLOYES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 Secretary of Labor Peter J. Brennan today ruled illegal the city's plan to retire 860 city employes aged 63 to 65 before their mandatory retirement age of 65. The plan would have saved the jobs of 860 younger civil servants.

title: TRW Increases Dividends
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (UPI)TRW, Inc., announced today that it was raising its quarterly dividend on common stock to 30 cents a share from 28 cents. The dividend is payable March 15 to shareholders of record Feb. 14.

title: Black AllStar Team Honored
description: The team that gets no respect until it's time for the National Football League draftthe Black College allAmerica team  was announced at the Essex House yesterday, and this year's featured attractions were Walter Payton, Jackson State running back; and Gary (Big Hands) Johnson, Grambling defensive tackle.

title: ELF IS SOLD UNITS OF OCCIDENTAL OIL
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation in Los Angeles said yesterday that it was selling the major part of its European retail marketing assets to Elf Union, S. A., of. France for about $25million. The assets consist of. 700 service stations and related facilities in Britain and West Germany. Occidental said that it would retain the receivables and inventory associated with the operation of the service stations and upon liquidation in the near future, they will provide more than $43million for other investment opportunities.

title: Prosecution Witness Is Rebutted At L.I. Trial of Judge Ginsberg
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 18A second key witness for the defense in the perjury trial of Judge Martin Ginsberg said today he had been alone with Judge Ginsberg, then an Assemblyman, at the time he allegedly received part of a bribe.

title: Bordeaux Vintners Are Found Guilty Of Doctoring Wine
description: BORDEAUX, France, Dec. 18 The heads of one of the proudest and oldest wine houses in France were found guilty today of illegally doctoring their product and falsifying the pedigrees that went with the wine.

description: The Soviet Union denied yesterday having given any specific assurances of easier emigration in return for American trade benefits and government credits. An official Tass statement said leading circles rejected as unacceptable any attempts to attach conditions to United States tariff reductions or otherwise interfere in internal Soviet affairs. It published a letter, dated Oct. 26, from Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to Secretary of State Kissinger rejecting any interpretation that emigration from the, Soviet Union would increase. It has in fact shown a tendency to decline, Mr. Gromyko said. [Page 1, Columns 68.]

description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that the would seek the impaneling of a special grand jury to investigate alleged crimes in the nursinghome industry.

title: Imports of U.S. From Arabs Show Rise
description: Although the Ford Administration has repeatedly emphasized its intention to reduce United States dependence on unreliable sources of oil, the nation imported more oil, from the Arab countries from June through October than it did during the same period last year before the Arab oil embargo, according to a study by an industry  supported research group.

title: Individual Income Slumps; More Layoffs Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The slowdown in the nation's economy cut sharply into individual income in November, with industrial payrolls down 2.5 per centor $7billion at an annual ratefrom the October, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Dec. 18 (UPI)Oilrich Arab countries led by Saudi Arabia have bought more than $134million in Japanese bonds over the last year, a Japanese financial source disclosed today.

title: 6 City Fire Engines at a Premiere
description: Half a dozen fire engines, manned by firemen, were on hand in Times Square last night for the benefit premiere of a new motion picture, The Towering Inferno, at the National Theater, 1500 Broadway.

title: WOODSON TAULBEE, WALLPAPER LEADER
description: A. Woodson Taulbee, president of Woodson Wallpapers, Inc. died Monday at his home, 172 East 61st Street. He was 66 years old.

title: Bordeaux Vintners Are Found Guilty Of Doctoring Wine
description: BORDEAUX, France, Dec. 18 The heads of one of the Droudest and oldest wine louses in France were found guilty today of illegally doctoring their product and falsiying the pedigrees that went with the wine.

title: Four Communities in Nassau Turn Down Bids by O.T.B. to Set Up Betting Parlors
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 18Nassau County's OffTrack Betting operation, due to open Feb. 1, has run into strong community resistance that could hamper the early growth of O.T.B.

title: Bridge: Old Wives' Tales Have Meaning For Experts on Certain Deals
description: For more than half a century bridge teachers have been trying in vain to eradicate the old wives' tale that calls for the opening lead of the highest card of partner's suit. As a result of this failure, players in home games continue to hurl tricks at gratified declarers by leading unsupported kings, queens and jacks from threecard, or fourcard holdings in their partners' suits.

title: No Restraint on Hunter
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 18An Alameda County Superior Court judge rejected today Charlie Finley's request to restrain Catfish Hunter from negotiating with other teams. Judge Spurgeon Avakian also set Jan. 3 as the date for a hearing on the claim by the A's owner that the arbitration ruling making Hunter a free agent was not valid.

title: Amsterdam Official Names Lebanese as Figure in Plot to Defraud Los Angeles
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 18A police official in Amsterdam today identified a Lebanese citizen, Aim Nassif, 62 years old, as a key figure in, an attempt to defraud the City of Los Angeles of more than $800,000.

title: A.E.C. Studies 3 Accidents at One Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The Atomic Energy Commission is investigating three incidents, involving plutonium and uranium, that occurred at an Oklahoma nuclear facility on Monday.

title: Bicentennial Aide Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (Reuters)  The Senate confirmed today a Britishborn woman as deputy administrator of the agency in charge of the American bicentennial celebrations. She is Marjorie Lynch of Yakima, Wash., who became a naturalized citizen in 1948 after marrying an Ameican soldier.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In Trenton, State Superior Court, Judge George Y. Schoch held again that Gerardo Catena, a reputed Mafia leader who has been jailed for civil contempt for nearly five years, should be released on the ground that the imprisonment would not make him break his silence. Mr. Catena, who will be 73 years old next month, has been in prison since March, 1970, for refusing to answer questions about organized crime before New Jersey's State Commission of Investigation.

title: Harry Hooper of Red Sox Dies; Oldest Hall of Fame Member, 87
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Dec. 18 (UPI)Harry Hooper, the oldest member, of the Baseball Hall of Fame, died yesterday at the age of 87.

title: Convinced That Catena Will keep Silent, Judge Reaffirms Ruling He Be Released
description: TRENTON, Dec. 18State Superior Court Judge George Y. Schoch affirmed today his earlier ruling that Gerardo Catena, a reputed Mafia leader who has been jailed for nearly five years on civil contempt charges, should be freed on the ground that further imprisonment will not make him break his silence.

title: U.N. Closes 29th Session; 3d World, Arabs Gained
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y Dec. 18The General Assem bly recessed its 29th sessior tonight with its president, For cign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, declaring that it had been a historic, perhaps revolutionary, meeting.

title: Indictment of Mayor's Wife Shocks Raleigh
description: RALEIGH, N.C Dec. 18A month or so ago the police in nearby Pittsboro arrested a woman named Linda Jones and charged her with shoplifting.

title: Yanks, Mets Among 20 Clubs To Coctact Hunter on Contract
description: He wore out two telephones, Jim (Catfish) Hunter said with a laugh yesterday, his first as a free agent, as 20 major league clubs called to tell him they wanted him.

title: Christmas Tree Gift Falls
description: TRUCKEE, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP)  A volunteer effort to send California Christmas trees to servicemen overseas has failed, the United States Forest Service says. The service had permitted the cutting of about 2,500 Christmas trees from Tahoe National Forest under a supervised thinning and reforestation project. But the volunteer organization known as Operation Christmas was not able to arrange private transportation, the Forest Service said yesterday.

title: Israelis Repel Raid on Village After Lebanon Foray
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 18  Raids were reported today on both sides of the IsraeliLebanese border, and gunfire was exchanged by Israelis and Arab guerrillas late in the day.

title: LAYOFFS AT Gil TO RISE BY 16,000
description: DETROIT, Dec. 18The General Motors Corporation, reflecting one of the,severest declines in the automobile industry since World War II, announced today additional layoffs and production, cutbacks for the first quarter of 1975.

title: Mourners' Crowd Into Services To Hear Slain Rabbi Eulogized
description: An overflow crowd of more than 500 mourners paid finaliwith tribute yesterday to Max Koppel, the 69yearold. rabbi who was shot Monday night in an apparent holdup attempt.

title: Laxalt Sworn as Senator; Gains an Edge in Seniority
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 18 (AP) Paul Laxalt was sworn in today as Nevada's iunior Senator. The 52 year  old Republican thus became the first Senator elected last month to take office He gained seniority over the other freshmen Senators, who are scheduled to assume office Jan. 3.

title: Newspaper Talks Resume
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 (UPI)  Contract talks between the striking publishers of the City's the publishers of the City's two major dailies resumed today for the first time in five days. There was no immediate report of progress. The Guild went on strike against The Plain Dealer Nov. 1 and was locked out of The Pres Nov. 9.

title: Film: James Bond and Energy Crisis:'Man With Golden Gun' at Several Theaters The Cast Roger Moore Lacks Connery's Impudence
description: The throbbing information that "the energy crisis is still with us" isn't what you need or want to learn from a James Bond picture. But that poverty of invention and excitement characterizes Guy Hamilton's "The Man With the Golden Gun," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.The movie, which also explains that "coal and oil will soon be depleted," sets Bond in pursuit of a missing device that converts solar energy into electricity Bored already? That was predictable, Even Kingsley Amis, a great admirer of the late Ian Fleming, spoke of "the over-all inferiority" of the writer's last novel, and this movie is doggishly faithful to its model.There's a male villain with three nipples, but you can't milk much plot out of thator them. Amid the general lack of gumption, Roger Moore's large rigid figure appears to be wheeled about on tiny casters I always have a soft spot for statues that turn out to be alive, and there are a couple in this film.But an actor who appears to have been cast in clay is another matter, and Mr. Moore functions like a vast garden ornament. Pedantic, sluggish on the uptake, incapable of even swaggering, he's also clumsy at innuendo. (While Sean Connery wasn't the wit of the century, he did manage to be impudent, and there were those pleasing moments of self-parody.) But whether Mr. Moore is twisting a woman's arm to discover a fact that he already knows, or nuzzling an abdomen without enthusiasm, he merely makes you miss his predecessor.The script trundles out such lines as "Your steam bath is ready" or "A mistress cannot serve two masters" between the dullest car chase of the decade and a very routine explosion. The only energetic moments are provided by Herve Villechaize, as a midget gifted with mocking authority, and Christopher Lee as the golden gunmanboth have a sinister vitality that cuts through the narrative dough. (Yet if I were a midget, I'd rebel against the perky bass music that bubbles up at every entrance; cute bassoons did the same for the dwarf in "The Abdication." Can't small persons be filmed without coy theme tunes?) The movie also includes some beautiful glimpses of Thailand. But if you enjoyed the early Bond films as much as I did, you'd better skip this one.

title: Hidden Rites Keeps Its Secret Despite Polished Ailey Dancing
description: The faintly mysterious aura of Hidden Rites makes all of the dancers appear to follow the lead of some unknown urging. It's a little frustrating to be on the outside looking at an enigma, but the smooth polish of the company tends to occupy all of one's attention after a while. The Alvin Ailey City Center Duce Company showed the work on Tuesday evening for the first time in its current season.

title: New Gas Pipeline Seeking Route Permit From Arctic
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP)The Pacific Gas & Electric Company has applied to the United States Department of the Interior for rightofway permits to cross Federal lands with a new pipeline that would bring natural gas from the Arctic.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should he made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and for warded to, P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: Ford Termed Wavering on Veto Of Strip Mine Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Senator Henry. M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today that President Ford was giving serious consideration to signing the Federal strip mine control bill instead of vetoing it as promised.

title: Campbell Raises Dividend
description: The Campbell Soup Company announced yesterday that it gas raising its quarterly dividend to 31 cents a common share from 29 cents. The dividend is payable Jan. 31 to shareholders of record Dec. 31.

title: BOND YIELDS RISE AFTER EARLY DROP
description: Interest rates declined Yesterday and then moved back up as bond dealers and traders and their customers became a little disappointed that the Federal Reserve, wasn't doing more encourage a credit market rally. Prices on New York City bonds again rose moderately yes terday in a continued response to the city's decision to curtail its borrowing early in 1975. Most other prices throughout the credit markets tended to move up slightly, largely on the reasoning that the recession seems to be becoming so bad that interest sates next bound to fall.

title: Ski Areas. Prepare For Major Invasion
description: BONDVILLE, Vt., Dec. 18 All through this land, skiarea operators are preparing for their biggest preholiday invasion i at least five ears, Conditions in this southern tier region of the Green Mountain state are mostly excellent, thanks to a whiteflaked windfall Iast Monday that buried Stratton, Big Bromley and Magic Mountain, among others. A visitor to the snow  cloaked Christmas  cardthemed high country today had to be impressed with the abundance of white cover everywhere. Some of the snow piled along the highways was as high as the taps of passing automobiles. In most of the adjoining valleys, there semed to be only token snow coverage. Danby, for example, which is about a dozen air miles northwest of here, had depths of only three to four inches.

title: Major Split Reported in Lisbon Cabinet
description: LISBON, Dec. 18A major split has reportedly developed in the Portuguese coalition Government following the jailing of 11 prominent businessmen. President Francisco da Costa Gomes is said to be trying to prevent the Cabinet from breaking up.

title: AN ADMINISTRATOR ON HUNGER URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Sehator Mark O. Hatfield, assailing what he called a lack of leadership in the Administration, called today for an effort on the scale of that led by Herbert Hoover during and after World War Ito feed the hungry and starving in nations threattened by famine.

title: 2 Are Indicted in Theft of Funds From Brooklyn Democratic Dinner
description: A former secretary of the Brooklyn Democratic committee and a former Democratic party fundraiser have been indicted by a special grand jury in Brooklyn on charges that they stole more than $100,000 from the party's annual dinner funds, Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, announced yesterday.

title: Stocks on Hand Held Adequate for Present
description: A slowdown in world economic activity and continued conservation efforts whether voluntary or induced by higher priced petroleum products have combined to create a worldwide oil surplus..

title: Kathleen Smith Wed To Donald W. Carson
description: Kathleen Ann Smith was married yesterday to Donald Wayne Carson of the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. Edward Drury, president of the Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latterday Saints in Kensington, Md., performed the Mormon ceremony at the temple.

title: House Votes $4Billion for 111,000 Public Jobs and More Aid to Idle
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The House passed today a $4billion bill, to provide 111,000 public service jobs and to extend unemployment benefits to jobless workers.

title: CBS Inc, Donates $1Million to Assist Public Television
description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday a contribution of $1million to public television, largely to support fundritising, and efforts to increase contributions from viewers.

title: Review of Recount In New Hampshire Is Upheld by Court

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (Reuters)Ten large United States corporations showed profits of about $976million but paid no Federal income taxes in 1973, Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) Executives of the United Mine Workers approved a wagecontract proposal today covering 4,500 striking mine construction workers and submitted the pact for a vote, probably by this weekend, according to Federal mediation spokesman.

title: British Whip Resigns Briefly in a Dispute
description: LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP)Robert Mellish quit as chief whip of the Labor Government today but withdrew his resignation nine hour later after a meeting with Prime Minister Harold Wilson.

title: Jersey Soldier Who Balked At Haircut Given 60 Days
description: BERLIN, Dec. 18 (UPI) A United States military court in Berlin sentenced a soldier from Hoboken, N. J., today to 60 days at hard labor, fined him and stripped him of his rank for disobeying an officer's order to get a haircut.

title: Major Suez Work Ended
description: CAIRO, Dec, 18 (UPI)The United States has ended the major portion of clearing operations in the Suez Canal and has begun to remove units from the area, the United States Embassy said today. The eightmonth operation involved the French, British, Egyptian and United States navies.

title: E.P.A. to Survey Chemicals In 80 Cities' Drinking Water
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency announced today a survey of organic chemicals in the drinking water of 80 cities beginning with Philadelphia, Seattle, Miami, Cincinnati and Ottumwa, Iowa.

title: David Behrman's Synthesizer, Modified, Makes SoHo Music
description: Phill Niblock, a composer and film maker, has taken of late to giving different series of concerts in his loft at 224 Centre Street. It's a big, comfortable space, and the concerts have succeeded in establishing themselves as a part of the SoHo music scene. This week Mr. Niblock presented three consecutive evenings of music by David Gibson, himself and, Tuesday night, David Behrman. Mr. Behrman's program attracted a heavy assortment of SoHo composers and new music watchers, and deservedly so.

title: Cahill, Army's ExCoach, Will Pilot Union
description: Tom Cahill, who reached the heights but fell to the depths while serving as Army's head football coach from 1966 through 1973, was named yesterday as head coach at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y. The 55yealold Cahill, once considered The Man for the Cops, has been an assistant athletic director at West Point being relieved of his coaching job last December.

title: Water Main Break Snarls Rush Hour on West Side
description: A 36inch water main burst on the Upper West Side early yesterday morning and forced thousands of rushhour riders on the Seventh Avenue IRT to leave stalled trains and hitchhike, walk to work, or crowd on alreadyjammed buses. The main break also clogged street traffic and disrupted telephone and water service over a 20block area.

Ansky's Hasidic play, The Dybbuk, comes Pearl Lang's own variation on the theme, The Possessed, subtitled The Dybbuk, which is scheduled for its world premiere at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Jan. 6 at 7:30 P.M. by the Pearl Lang Dance Company.

What Mrs. Glasse really indicated in her recipe was Take your hare when it is cased, and make a pudding, the word in that meaning to skin.

title: Two Affectionate Family Portraits at the Whitney:The Program
description: In delving into their roots, Martha Coolidge and Amalie R. Rothschild, the young movie makers responsible, respectively, for "Old Fashioned Woman" and "Nana, Mom and Me," the documentaries that arrived yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, vividly illustrate the idea that personal history need not be a bore. If traces of self-indulgence occasionally surface in these family portraits, they depict meaningful personalities lovingly exposed by deeply concerned relatives.In both instances, the protagonists, as well as the film makers, largely speak for themselves in forthright, sometimes understated and occasionally funny terms that point up the color, joys and hardships of their backgrounds. Miss Coolidge's grandmother and Miss Rothschild's grandmother and parents evolve as people worthy of the attention they are being paid.Martha Tilton Coolidge, her granddaughter admits, "has been a small but intimidating old-fashioned woman." But in "Old Fashioned Woman," which, incidentally, had a screening at the recent New York Film Festival, the 86-year-old subject about whom she is so curious emerges, in a brilliant but gently hued cameo, as a charming, resolute Yankee who is old only in years.The tragedies and fulfillments of a life distilled from the past that dates back to Colonial days have enabled her to take time, life, family, friends and issues, old and new, such as abortion and morality, in stride and wisdom. Her grandmother comes across as much of a comfort to a viewer as she obviously did to her sensitively inquisitive granddaughter.Equally illuminating is Miss Rothschild's inspection of her antecedents, who, she says in a program footnote, helped her in "self-discovery." They also, it is almost immediately obvious, show an observer the subtle but definite influence they had on the dedicated researcher who focused color cameras and sound on them. Miss Rothschild's "Nana" is, like Miss Coolidge's grandmother, a forthright 86-year-old who, unfortunately, is not too willing to submit to questioning. But her parents, an artist-mother and an equally loving lawyer-musician father, indicate that the roots are strong and effective.The generation gaps in both films are made into bridges to an affectionate, perhaps biased, but always edifying look at unheralded individualists whose lives and values are worthwile and stir the heart and mind.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Several months ago, when Jim (Catfish) Hunter realized that Charles O. Finley had breached the stipulation in his $100,000 contract that $50,000 be paid to an insurance firm as deferred income, the Oakland A's righthanded pitcher phoned J. Carlton Cherry, his attorney in Ahoskie, N. C. Do you think, I'm a free agent? Catfish asked. What's a free agent? J. Carlton Cherry asked. J. Carlton Cherry knows now. J. Carlton Cherry, a 68yearold country lawyer for peanut and tobacco farmers, is handling the auction of Catfish Hunter that began yesterday. It's a situation that such celebrated sports agents as Bob Woolf, Mark McCormack and Irwin Weiner have dreamed of, but they are on the outside looking in at a country lawyer in the twostory brick office of Cherry, Cherry & Flythe on Main Street in a quiet town of 5,200 people near the Virginia border. The moral is that at least in Ahoskie, N.C., justice has triumphed Loyalty, too.

title: Being a Disquisition wherein were told whats happening to english including examples written by a man who no's;

Its true my students arent the good mannered middle class bunch who I went to school, with, there more often cops or shoesalesmens or garbagemens (pardon me, sanitationmens) sons and daughters, and yet there a sharp group, wary, skeptical bright.

Mr. Knowles, 28 years old, was shot after he freed one hand from his handcuffs and tried to snatch the gun of SheriffEarl Lee of Douglas. County, the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said? Both the sheriff and Ron Angel, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, fired at Mr. Knowles.

title: 'Steppenwolf' Emerges Dimly From Printed Page:The Cast
description: The recent vogue enjoyed by "Steppenwolf," particularly among the young, seems unlikely to be expanded by the film version of the 1927 Hermann Hesse novel that opened yesterday at the Eastside Cinema.Fred Haines, who wrote the screenplay and directed the movie, has approached the Nobel Prize-winning German author's exploration of the spiritual and sensual elements of human personality with the all-too-familiar translational reverence that preserves literature while creating stillborn cinema.But he has not failed for want of trying. And he has succeeded in keeping at least one wolf  utter boredom  from the door by recruiting the screen's most ascetic-looking actor, Max von Sydow, to impersonate the tortured, aging writer Harry Haller; and the screen's most enigmatic woman, Dominique Sanda, to portray Hermine, Harry's alter ego and cicerone to the unconventional.Mr. Haines has also marshaled an impressive battery of special effects  animation, Daliesque art, television superimpositions and color synthesizersthat divert the eye, while the mind and the emotions remain uncaptivated.Neither the stars nor the special effects can disguise the fact that "Steppenwolf" is a wordy, talky movie, stubbornly rooted in its printed origins.This might be tolerable if the talk were interesting or if Harry Haller's sufferings managed to evoke sympathy. The truth is that the talk ranges from the silly to the sententious, the philosophy is simpleminded, and Harry emerges as an insufferable case of attenuated adolescense.He probably should have been left forever to the printed page, an actor both in Hesse's "Magic Theater for Madmen Only" and in the inexhaustible theater of readers' imaginations. To trot him out in real theaters, with his 48-year-old's face and his 14-year-old's confusions, is a cruelty I suspect Mr. Haines never intended.

title: Yonkers Mayor,After a Year, Fights to Save Crumbling City
description: YONKERS, Dec. 18Several week's ago, in apparent response to critical comment about Yonkers, Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli issued a statemenmt to correct the considerable misunderstanding about his office and the city.

title: Real Snow Is Hailed at Ski Areas
description: LONDONDERRY, Vt., Dec. 19With another snowstorm expected before the weekend, the ski area operators in Vermont are in a happier mood. Heavy precipitation that deposited as many as 20 inches on some areas has changed their entire perspective. The snow we now have is of the best kind, said funminded Hans Thorner, the energetic operator of Magic Mountain. It didn't cost us $11 a pound like that machinemade snow does. Fourteen inches. dropped on Magiclike magicand I'm accepting it as a Christmas gift.

title: Pope Sees Progress On Peace but Warns Of Problems Ahead
description: ROME, Dec. 19Pope Paul VI said in a special message today that progress had been made toward unity and peace in the world. Nevertheless, many, very many problems still remain potentially open, he warned.

title: Analyst Picks Redskins, Vikings, Dolphins, Steelers
description: It wrenches his very soul but Bud Goode, the sports computer analyst from Los Angeles, believes the Washington Redskins are going to beat. his beloved Rams on Sunday in the National Football League's playoffs. After honing his numbers, Goode yesterday brought forth his selections for the four weekend games, selections different from yours and mine or even from the Las Vegas line. They are different because Goode and the CalComp computer have far more input106 different statistical items each with its own weight of importance. Furthermore, Goode has a good track record. In the last three seasons he has had the winner in 18 of the 21 N.F.L. playoff games.

title: Paying for the Damages
description: The decision of the United States to take no part in a special United Nations fund to aid developing countries hardest hit by the energy and economic crises reflects the realities of the monetary disequilibrium resulting from the quadrupled price of oil. Though it may be interpreted as mere reprisal against the tyranny of the majority, it is more to the point to consider it a salutary warning to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries member states as to where their responsibilities now lie.

title: The Polite Runaround
description: Teddy Topper, a salesman from Kew Gardens, Queens, bought a Chevy Nova last September for his daughter, Mrs. Jane Wolin. Mrs. Wolin was driving it along the Belt Parkway the other day when it sputtered, died, and refused to move. By the greatest of good fortune then, two Chevrolet mechanics came along in another car, stopped, and fixed the Nova. It was nothing, they said, only a small adjustment in the carburetor.

title: March of Dimes Urges a Ban For Now on Red No. 2 Food Dye
description: The National FoundationMarch of Dimes urged yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration suspend approval of the food dye known as Red No. 2 until further tests establish positively that it has no harmful effects.

title: 'The Towering Inferno' First-Rate Visual Spectacle
description: "The Towering Inferno" is a nearly three-hour suspense film for arsonists, firemen, movie-technology buffs, building inspectors, worry warts.The film, which opened yesterday at the National and Trans-Lux East Theaters, is a gigantic cautionary tale for people who want the worst to happen. It's this year's best end-of-the-world moviethe world in this case being represented by a 138-story, glass-and-steel San Francisco skyscraper that, on the night of its dedication, becomes history's biggest Roman candle. It doesn't burn down, just up.It's not a movie that bothers too much about the specifics of how it happened (something about cheap wiring). It's mainly concerned with what happens during the holocaust, that is with an almost interminable succession of rescue episodes involving lovers, frauds, villains, a little girl, a small cat, a mayor and his wife and other assorted characters whose life spans conform roughly to their billing: actors at the head of the cast live longest.Granting that end-of-the-world movies are not designed to test the intellect but, rather, to provide second-hand thrills of a visceral sort, "The Towering Inferno" must be everything its producer (Irwin Allen) and its two distribution companies (20th Century-Fox and Warner Bros., paired in a one-shot marriage-of-convenience to finance the film) could have possibly desired.The special effects are smashing, better than those in "Earthquake" even without the brain-bending Sen-surround effect of "Earthquake." The technological work is old-fashioned Hollywood make-believe at its painstaking best.I have absolutely no idea which scenes of crematory horror were filmed in life-size studio mockups, in real locations or in miniatures  and I don't particularly want to know. The fun in a movie like this is in being fooled by the talents of the stuntmen, the production designers and especially by the editors, the men who fit all the pieces together without the seams showing."The Towering Inferno" has an advantage over most movies of this sort in that it has a really classy cast. Though the actors are not required to do much except behave well according to type, their presence upgrades a secondary form of movie melodrama.They include Paul Newman (the architect), Faye Dunaway (the editor of a woman's magazine who goes through the entire fire in a dress so sheer but indestructible that it becomes an engineering feat in itself), Steve McQueen (the heroic fire chief), William Holden (the building's developer-builder), Richard Chamberlain (the man responsible for the faulty wiring who is also a cad to his wife, which may or may not be something to think about), Robert Vaughn (a United States Senator) and Robert Wagner (the building's public-relations man who gets somewhat more coverage than he dared hope for).Fred Astaire also shows up, benignly, as an old con artist out to bilk a rich, middle-aged woman played by Jennifer Jones, and O.J. Simpson is on hand as the building's security chief.Sterling Silliphant's screenplay, based on two different but similar novels ("The Tower" and "The Glass Inferno"), probably reads like a traffic control report, but it succeeds in presenting dozens of incidents without noticeable overlaps or collisions. The dialogue, especially at the beginning, is full of those portentous hints of things to come that make the audience giggle in nervous anticipation. "You forget," someone says early on, "the many modern safety devices we have today."John Guillermin directed the film, but it's difficult to know exactly what he might have done aside from suggesting a few line readings, perhaps. Movies like "The Towering Inferno" appear to have been less directed than physically constructed. This one is overwrought and silly in its personal drama, but the visual spectacle is first rate. You may not come out of the theater with any important ideas about American architecture or enterprise, but you will have had a vivid, completely safe nightmare.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: FORD SIGNS BILL ON NIXON PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19President Ford signed today a bill authorizing the Government to take custody of official tapes and papers of former President Richard M. Nixon and providing for a study of the ownership of the official papers of future Presidents.

title: Dayan Says U.S. Threatened to Fly Supplies to Egyptian Unit Trapped in '73 War
description: RAMAT GAN, Israel, Dec. 19 (Reuters)  Moshe Dayan, the former Israeli Defense Minister, charged tonight that the United States threatened in October, 1973, to fly supplies to Egyptian troops surrounded in the Suez Canal area if the Israelis refused to allow food and water through their lines.

title: U.S. Juniors Gain Tennis Semifinals
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 19 (AP)  The United States team had a doubles victory, a singles victory and a singles loss against West Germany today as it advanced to the semifinals of the Sunshine Cup junior tennis matches.

title: Borrowing by Cerro
description: The Cerro Corporation reported yesterday that its whollyowned subsidiary, Fetterolf Coal and Construction, Inc., will close today a longterm borrowing of $35million from Sumitomo Metal Industries, Ltd., and the Mitsubishi Corporation in connection with the purchase by them of a substantial portion of Fetterolf's production under a longterm contract.

title: Weekly Retail Sales Up 5%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Department of Commerce said today that department store sales last week were an estimated $2.042billion, up per cent from last year's $1.943billion. Total retail store sales were an estimated $10.15billion, up 5 per cent from last year's $9.674billion.

title: Bruins Defeat Rangers, 11 to 3, Scoring 3 Goals in 58 Seconds
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19And now back to reality. The New York Rangers, lulled by an easy 70 romp over Minnesota last night, were massacred tonight, 113, by the Boston Bruins before a crowd of 15,000 in Boston Garden. It was Boston's seventh consecutive victory.

title: Village Woman, 59, Is Beaten to Death In Her Apartment
description: A 59yearold woman employe of the City Department of Social Services was found bludgeoned to death yesterday in her Greenwich Village apartment, the police reported.

title: 45 Foreign Ships Seen Fishing Off Jersey Coast
description: LONG BRANCH, Dec. 19 (AP) The Coast Guard said today that 45 foreign fishing vessels were operating in the ocean off the New Jersey coast, taking mackerel, cod, whiting and herring by the ton.

title: ORVILLE SWETT POLAND
description: Orville Swett Poland, general counsel of the House Committee on Government Operations from 1955 to 1961, died Wednesday in Albany. He was 85 years old and lived in Blue Hill, Me.

title: U.S. Financial Institutions Swarm Into Mideast
description: American financial institutons are swarming into the Middle East, often with wellconnected Arabs as their principal operatives, in a bid to handle the petrodollar riches flowing from higher prices for oil.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two former parttime check delivery boys for the Chase Manhattan Bank and three other persons were charged with stealing $5,528,000 in uncanceled, negotiable checks from two of the bank's midtown branches, Federal and city law enforcement officials discosed.

title: The Whole Man Ray at Cultural Center
description: In the cultural history of the last 60 years Man Ray is not so much invisible as intangible. He is everywhere, and yet nowhere. He does everything, and yet most people would find it difficult to say who he is, or what he did, or when he did it. That is partly his own fault, since no one is more adept at covering his tracks, changing his disguise and generally throwing an admirer off the scent. But it is also the fault of the museum world, which has never been able to come to terms with Man Ray or known whether to regard him as painter, photographer or inventor.

title: 3 ARE FOUND GUILTY OF MAN'S KIDNAPPING
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19A county court jury convicted three men early today of kidlapping Carmine Tripodi, New Rochelle gambler involved in an investigation of alleged corruption in the Mount Vernon Police Department. corruption in the Mount Vernon Police Department.

title: About Real Estate
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J.  His name is Andrzej Moszynski (call him Andy), he is 28 years old and he came to this country from Poland 10 years ago. He went directly to what was then the Case Institute of Technology in Cleveland, where his halfbrother taught, and studied engineering.their carrying charge would not exceed their rent. Prices range from $26,990 to $49,990.

title: Wilson Is Cheerful as He Says Goodbys
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19It is relaxed and cheerful Malcolm Wilson who has been saying his goodbys to Albany these days.

title: Approval of Project In Queens Is Urged To Aid Mentally Ill
description: National, state and local officials met yesterday at the Board of Estimate to urge approval of a pilot project in Queens for the rehabilitation of released mental patients at a community level by a voluntary group that would take the profit out of mental health.

title: Russians Launch Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP)The Soviet Union launched another in its series of unmanned Cosmos satellites yesterday, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. Cosmos 698 will continue expolration of outer space, Tass said, but gave no details on the specific mission. It reported the orbit's maximum distance from the earth was 352 miles, the minimum 320 miles, the angle 74 degrees and the time of orbit 95.3 minutes.

title: Gifts That Save on Energy
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Handoperated can openers and wool bedsocks may seem like singularly unexciting gift ideas but, according to an energy specialist with the University of California physics department, both are energysaving good guysthe kind of Christmas presents consumers should consider.

title: College and School Scores
description: BASKETBALL

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FIELDS OF CLOVER It's good, better than good at Christmas, to have the Irving Fields Trio around town after 25 years. Year after year these dependables make fine, straightforward music centered on good, oldfashioned melody, easy on the ears and nice for dancing. At the trio's current roost, the attractive. Roman Pub of the New York Hilton Hotel, they hold forth Tuesdays through Saturdays from 9:30 P.M. until 2 A.M.

title: Two Dead Pilots Identified
description: GWINN, Mich., Dec. 19 (AP) The Air Force identified today the two officers whose plane crashed yesterday at the K.I. Sawyer Air base in Michigan's Upper Peninsula as Lieut. Robert Petrola, 22 years old, of Oceansidet, N.Y., the pilot, and Maj. George Hughey, 34, of Murfreesboro, Tenn., the copilot.

title: Carey Picks Cuomo As State Secretary; Schuler to Stay On
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey announced yesterday that Mario M. Cuomo, a longtime friend, would be appointed Secretary of State, and that Raymond T. Schuler, the incumbent Secretary of Transportation, would be retained in the new administration, which takes office Jan. 1.

title: LEGAL AID NAMES MURRAY AS CHIEF
description: Archibald R. Murray, the state's Commissioner of Criminal Justice Services since 1972, was named yesterday to head the Legal Aid Society of New York. Mr. Murray, a Republican, will take office Jan. 1, becoming the first person to hold the title of attorneyinchief of the society since Edward Q. Carr resigned two years ago.

title: CITY AND UNIONS SEEK RETIREMENT ON ELECTIVE BASIS
description: The city and a group of leaders representing the municipal unions agreed yesterday to seek voluntary retirements of city employes aged 63 to 70 to save the jobs of 860 younger employes. The latter are scheduled to be dismissed in the budgetcutting layoffs recently announced by Mayor Beame.

title: Cuomo Selected by Carey As His Secretary of State
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey announced yesterday that Mario M. Cuomo, a longtime friend, would be appointed Secretary of State, and that Raymond T. Schuler, the incumbent Secretary of Transportation, would be retained in the new administration, which takes office Jan. 1.

title: Business Loans at Big N.Y. Banks Up
description: Business borrowing at major banks in New York was up again in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The latest increase was $327million, compared with an adjusted increase of $305million in the previous week.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX EDGE UP ON RALLY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange staged a rally near the close to finish slightly higher after being off sharply earlier in the day. Declines, however, continued to outnumber advances. Prices fell in the overthecounter market while advances also were outnumbered by declines.

title: H. U. D RELEASES HOUSING FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Housing and Urban Development Department announced today that it was releasing $35million to local housing authorities for the upgrading of public housing projects.

title: Yanks Visit Hunter; Mets Keep Distance
description: While Gabe Paul was back in New York playing Santa Claus at a Yankee Christmas party, the team's scouting director, Clyde Kluttz, was in Ahoskie, N.C., yesterday telling Jim (Catfish) Hunter how wonderful the big city was for righthanded pitchers.

title: California's Conservative Governor
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In his classic study of American democracy, The American Commonwealth, Lord Bryce declared the political situation in California to be both peculiar and dangerous.

title: 6 Children, 6 to 14, Run A CutRate Mail Service
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, Dec. 19 (AP)  A cutrate Christmas mail service operated here by six children, aged 6 to 14, has drawn drawn the attention of their competitor, the United States. Postal Service.

title: Export Bank Credit Curbs Are Said to Anger Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Soviet Union has followed up yesterday's disavowal of a deal on emigration for trade benefits with a private denunciation of Congressional adoption of a ceiling on ExportImport Bank credits to Moscow.

title: AN EXNAVY OFFICER FOUND DEAD IN BRONX
description: The body of a retired United States Navy commander from Wyckoff, N. J., was found in a South Bronx parking lot early yesterday after he had been apparently strangled and robbed.

title: Sales Top Redemptions Of Mutual Funds Again
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)Mutual fund sales outpaced redemptions in November for the seventh straight month, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: Plans Approved For Tall Building At Lincoln Center
description: Plans for a controversial 30story office and apartment building opposite Lincoln Center were approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday by a 16to6 vote with the majority expressing misgivings and the minority charging that the board was taking part in a charade.

title: Shah Warns Oil Prices Will Soar if Gold Rises
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 19 (AP) The Shah of Iran warned Western powers today that any tinkering with the value of gold would result in oil prices so steep as to destroy the world monetary system. An increase in the official price of gold would effectively lower the value of dollars received by Iran and other oil exporters.

title: WILLIAM H. BOBRICK
description: William H. Bobrick, who retired last January as textile sales executive with the George A. Bobrick Co., Inc., died Wednesday of a heart ailment in University Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 41 West 83d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE CEREMONY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller was sworn in tonight as the 41st Vice President of the United States.

title: Business Briefs
description: The nation's railroadsother than the Chessie System, Inc., parents of the Chesapeake & Ohio and Baltimore & Ohio Railroadshave decided to file with the Interstate Commerce Commission for a 7 per cent general freight rate increase on Jan. 20, to become effective Feb. 5. The I.C.C. last month agreed to allow the railroads to make the filing.

title: Exploitation and Storytelling
description: LANCASTER, Pa.When one belongs to a minority group that is considered both culturally backward and religiously odd, one grows up with strong passions tearing at his spirit. That was my experience. I grew up conservative Mennonite in Lancaster County, Pa.

title: ELSIE D. HARPER
description: Elsie D. Harper, for many years director of public affairs for the Young Women's Christian Association, died Monday at a retirement home in Gwynedd, Pa. Her age was 83.

title: Court in Jersey City Bars Picketing in School Strike
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 19The Board of Education obtained court order today to force striking custodial and other school workers back to their jobs after a combination of cold weather and the strike brought about the closing of all public schools for one day.

title: FORD IS REPORTED IGNORANT OF LEASE
description: President Ford was quoted yesterday as having said that he had no advance knowledge that the owner of a house in Vail, Colo., that he is renting for the holidays could save, or be forced to pay, more than $100million, depending on the President's action on a coal strip mining bill.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: Today, Dec. 20

title: Two for the 25th
description: Nelson Rockefeller has become the second man confirmed as Vice President of the United States under the terms of the 25th Amendment, and some of his opponents are inclined to blame the amendment itself for having made his nomination possible. But the amendment also made possible what opposition there was, although the long Congressional inquiry left many questions unanswered and some virtually unexploredfor instance, the present views on detente of this renowned Cold Warrior.

title: The Pop Life
description: Anyone who goes regularly to rock concerts and who has even a slightly nervous disposition can only be astounded at the patience the audiences display.

title: Cavaliers Top Braves Despite 49 by McAdoo
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (UPI) Steve Patterson, a substitute, tossed in 18 points and picked off 11 rebounds to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 106104 victory tonight over the Buffalo Braves. Buffalo's Bob McAdoo scored 49 points in the National Basketball Association game.

title: Stage: Where's Charley? Is Revived
description: There is nothing quite so dated as a dated musical, unless it is an old election promise or an obsolete calendar. More than a quarter of a century ago George Abbott and Frank Loesser fabricated a musical out of the Englisp classic farce Charley's Aunt and called it Where's Charley? The project in the first place was just about as sensible and as sensitive as if Noel Coward had tried to make a musical out of Damon Runyari's Guys and Dolls. However, helped out by the gangling presence of Ray Bolger, it gave Mr. Loesser his first Broadway hit.

title: Thomas Jamieson, 63, Dies; Led U.N. Refugee Programs
description: GENEVA, Dec. 19 (Reuters)Thomas Jamieson, who supervised refugee emergency programs throughout the world for the United Nations, died here yesterday at the age of 63.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Farm Workers Begin a Fast
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19, (UPI)Seven members of the United Farm Workers union began a fiveday fast at dawn today to remind holiday shoppers of the hunger and injustice suffered by America's farm workers. The vigil, with about 200 persons in attendance, began at suburban shopping center that has three major supermarkets that sell lettuce, grapes and wine obtained from nonunion farm labor.

title: Hungry Flee Villages for Bombay and Find a Precarious Living
description: BOMBAY, India, Dec. 13She came to Bombay in search of food.

title: U.S AID EXPECTED TO OPEN JOBS HERE
description: The FederalEmergency Jobs bill nearing final approval in Washington would permit the creation of at least 20,000 new publicservice jobs in highunemployment areas of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Watergate Argument
description: The chief prosecutor at the Watergate coverup trial began his final argument to the jury yesterday after 46 days of testimony. The prosecutor, James F. Neal, mocked and scorned the five defendants. Page 18.

title: 5 Injured in London As Bomb Explodes On Shopping Street
description: LONDON, Dec. 19London's busiest shopping street was rocked tonight by a bomb blast. Acting on warnings telephoned to two newspapers, the police had cleared the area and only five persons were slightly injured.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
Watergate Argument
description: The chief prosecutor at the Watergate coverup trial began his final argument to the jury yesterday after 46 days of testimony. The prosecutor, James F. Neal, mocked and scorned the five defendants. Page 18.

title: Weekly Rail Freight Traffic Off 10.5% From '73 Level
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Association of American Railroads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Dec. 14 totaled an estimated 15.4 billion ton miles, 10.5 per cent below the corresponding figures of a year ago. The week, like the previous two, was effected by the coal strike.

title: 15 Defiant Nursing Homes Were Cited as Cheats in '58
description: A hitherto unpublished report reveals that 15 of the 27 nursing homes now defying subpoenas of a state investigation were found to be cheating patients and the taxpayers as early as 1958.

title: 16 SUGAR REFINERS INDICTED BY JURY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19Six major sugar refining companies were indicted today by a Federal Grand Jury on charges of illegal price fixing after an 18month investigation.

title: Frederic W. Smith Dead; Jersey Lawyer 60 Years
description: Frederic W. Smith, a lawyer in Newark and Maplewood, N.J., from 1904 to 1964, died yesterday at his home in Madison, N.J. He was 94 years. old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Twelve National Football Conference players, including Jim Hart, St. Louis quarterback, and Drew Pearson, Dallas receiver be making their first appearance in the Pro Bowl this season. They were among those named yesterday to the N,F.C.'s allstar team that will meet the American Conference in Miami's Orange Bowl on Jan. 20.

title: Britain Will Pay $92,000 In the Death of 13 in Ulster
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters) Britain will pay more than $92,000 compensation torelatives of 13 men killed by British troops in the Bloody Sunday riots in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, in January, 1972.

title: Attorney Indicted On Milk Coop Aid, To Senator Muskii
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI),  A private attorney who worked for the nation's largest dairy cooperative was indicted today in connection with helping funnel $13,400 in illegal contributions to the 1970 reelection campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.

title: A 16Year Political Career With White House in Mind
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19Nelson A. Rockefeller's political career has seemed to many to have been aimed at the Presidency from its beginning in 1958, when he was first elected Governor of New York.

title: NIGERIA AND KUWAIT REPORTED TO CUT OIL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Gulf Oil Corporation reported today that Nigeria was making a general, if temporary, cut in crude oil production.

title: Outlook for Rockefeller
News Summary and Index FRIDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1974
description: Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller was sworn in last night as the 41st Vice President of the United States. He took the oath of office with a hand on a family Bible and was sworn in by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger in a televised ceremony in the Senate chamber. Mr. Rockefeller was escorted by President Ford, and members of Mr. Rockefeller's family, Congress, the. Cabinet and New York State dignitaries were among those who attended the ceremony. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: $2.6Million Bail Is Set In $130,000 Bribe Case
description: Leroy Barnes, the 42yearold alleged drug trafficker, was held in lieu of $2.6million bail, set yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx after being indicted on a charge of offering two policemen a $130,000 bribe last Tuesday. The officers said they had discovered a gun in his MercedesBenz sedan in the South Bronx.

title: Chrysler Recalls Trucks With FrontWheel Defect
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation said today it was recalling 583 lightduty trucks because of a defect that has resulted in two reports of front wheels falling off.

title: Robert S. Rowe, 77, Dead; Expert in Banknote Field
description: Robert S. Rowe, since 1960 executive vice president of SecurityColumbian Banknote Company, a division of United Staes Banknote Corporation, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. He was 77 years old and lived at 865 Hillside Avenue, Mountainside, N. J.

title: Soccer Job Gives Cousy Sports Role
description: Bob Cousy knew he was not on familiar grounds yesterday because he was the tallest of the bunch. He acted that way, too, because he said he wasn't sure what his duties would be as commissioner of the American Soccer League.

title: State Told to Redraw Maps of Meadowlands
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 19 (UPI)  A superior Court judge ruled today that newly drawn maps of the Hackensack Meadowlands were invalid and gave the state 120 days to revise the 36 panels.

title: Flyers Trample Leafs, 51
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 19 (UPI)Bill Barber notched his 14th and 15th goals and Ross Lonsberry scored twice. within two minutes as the Philadelphia Flyers, defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 51, for their ninth straight triumph tonight at the Spectrum.

title: People in Sports
description: Ellis Rainsberger, the offensive coordinator at Wisconsin and the last of nine coaches interviewed, has accepted the head football coaching job at Kansas State, replacing. Vince Gibson, who resigned after eight years.

title: Owner of Laundry Confronts a Robber And Is Shot Dead
description: The 74yearold owner of a Brooklyn laundry was shot and killed yesterday as he strode out of his office, waving a hand gun at an armed man who was attempting to force his way into a locked room where a payroll was being prepared, the police reported.

title: Big Board Short Interest Shows Decline for Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the short interest position had declined to 21,769,000 shares from 23,006,000 in the month ending Dec. 13. This is the lowest figure since Oct. 15 of this year.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1974

title: Clear Copy Scores In Susweep Purse
description: Leon J. Hekimian's Clear Copy beat Summertide in a long stretch to score a victory by a head in the $25,000 Susweep Purse yesterday at Aqueduct. The 3  year  old daughter of Copy At the Chief  Half Tone, Race with Daryl Mon. toya in the sadTracks dle, covered the mile in 1:35 1/5.

title: Pioneering Public TV
description: The resignation of Dr. James R. Killian Jr. as chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's board, effective today, ends an era in a pioneering effort give American television viewerschildren and adultsa chance to see what mature broadcasting can provide without commercials, ratings or talking down to the American people.

title: MINISTERS FAIL ON AN OIL PACT
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 19The Finance Ministers of the nine Common Market member nations were unable to agree here today on plans for recycling the wealth of oilexporting nations.

title: SENATE CEREMONY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller was sworn in tonight as the 41st. Vice President of the United States.

title: The New Vice President
description: The countless banalities about the uselessness of Vice Presidents have been matched in recent years by the assurances of Presidents that they intended, at last, to make significant use of their first deputies. The dynamism of Nelson A. Rockefeller, who was sworn in yesterday, suggests strongly that in the Ford Administration that oftrepeated promise may become a reality.

title: MARKET DRIFTS IN DULL TRADING
description: The stock market drifted indecisively yesterday and finished mixed in slower trading.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: The Oyster Bar in Grand Central Terminal is back in business, under new management, following a gentle facelift to preserve its style and traditions, which span an incredible 62 years. Several former employes are back behind the bar turning out steaming bowls of creamy, paprikaflecked oyster stew according to the original recipe. And there's a new open window, with standup service counter, on the ramp going down to the lower level where a commuter can down halfadozen freshly shucked Bluepoints before boarding the 5:09.

title: Sugar Futures Show a Slight Decline
description: Following the weeks of sugar price turmoil on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, trading returned to more normal conditions yesterday. More than 2,320 sugar contracts changed hands, and traders found plenty of opportunity to buy or sell as they pleased. The closing price for the key March sugar delivery, the most active, was 40.6540.80 cents a pound, little changed from 40.90 the preceding day.

title: ERVIN BAILEY, 93, INVENTOR IS DEAD
description: Ervin Gebrge Bailey, an engineer, inventor and manufacturer, died Wednesday at his home in Easton, Pa. He was 93 years old.

title: Private Given 5 Months For Failing to Cut Hair
description: BERLIN, Dec. 19, (UPI)An Army private was sentenced to five months' confinement at hard labor today and was reduced to the lowest rank by a military court for failing to have his hair cut.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin is to be paroled March 18. The setting of a firm date by a parole board also gives Mr. Sherwin a chance for a threeday Christmas pass to go home for the holidays.

title: Export Bank Credit Curbs Are Said to Anger Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Soviet Union has followed up yesterday's disavowal of a deal on emigration for trade benefits with a private denunciation of Congressional adoption of a ceiling on ExportImport Bank credits to Moscow.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: It might seem that all department store Santa Clauses are created equal, but visits to a number of major department stores in the city dispelled that notion. Some of the places try hard, others try hardly at all.

title: City's Fire Alarm Boxes Are Called Undependable
description: The city's firealarm boxes, connected to a deteriorating network of cables laid more than half a century ago, are becoming dangerously unreliable, according to Fire Department dispatchers, maintenance men and fire fighters.

title: TEN ECONOMISTS FAVOR STIMULUS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19Government stimulus for the sliding economy was reported favored by a group of 10 leading private economists at an unpublicized meeting at the White House today.

title: Hearings Set on Requests For Rises in Rail Fares
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19The State Commuter Operating Agency today announced plans for public hearings on 25 per cent fare increases being sought by four debtridden railroads serving New Jersey commuters.

title: Trucking Dispute Threatens to Shut Coal Mines Again
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (UPI) Coal mine operations across the nation began returning to normal today for the first time in more than a month. But a dispute with truckers threatened to shut the mines once again.

title: Smith, Barney and Hornblower Reach Agreement on a Merger
description: Smith, Barney & Co., Inc., the investment banking house, disclosed here yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to take over Hornblower & WeeksHemphill, Noyes, Inc., the brokerage house. The surviving concern would be known as Smith Barney Hornblower & Co., Inc.

title: TEN ECONOMISTS FAVOR STIMULUS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19Government stimulus for the sliding economy was reported favored by a group of 10 leading private economists at an unpublicized meeting at the White House today.

title: Fishing for Trouble
description: Senate passage of a bill that would extend United States fisheries jurisdiction from 12 to 200 miles off shore is an understandable but illadvised reflection of the legitimate concern of American fishermen over the depletion of coastal stocks. Such unilateral action would encourage similar moves by other nations and seriously undercut United States efforts to negotiate a comprehensive oceans treaty that would protect a wide range of vital American interests. It would be in violation of existing international maritime law and could provoke dangerous confrontations with Soviet, Japanese and other foreign fishing fleets.

title: Giants Still Committed to Jersey Move
description: The New York Giants' decision to play their home games at Shea Stadium in 1975 has not altered the team's commitment to move to New Jersey the following season, Wellington Mara, the club's president, said yesterday.

title: Jersey's Legislature Quits Without Acting on Tax
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19. The Legislature adjourned for the year this evening without approving a new system of financing public schools in Pew Jersey, thus defying a State Supreme Court order to do so by Dec. 31.

title: School Board's Dealings With Company Are Halted
description: School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that all business dealings between Behavioral Research Laboratories, a major nationwide distributor of educational materials, and Community School District 9 had been suspended because improprieties were suspected.

title: Publisher Suspends Luciano Paperback
description: New American Library is suspending its plans to publish a paperback edition of The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano, for which it was going to pay $800,000, according to a company spokesman.

title: 40 Hostages Freed in Minnesota As Supermarket Gunmen Yield
description: RICHFIELD, Minn. Friday, Dec. 20 (AP)An armed holdup at a suburban supermarket that led to the taking of about 40 hostages ended early today when the gunmen freed their prisoners and surrendered, the police said.

title: Man, 98, Strangled In Brooklyn Robbery
description: A 98yearold former yeshiva principal was choked to death with his yarmulke early yesterday morning by thieves who climbed into his groundfloor apartment in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn as he slept, the police said.

title: Sweden's Communist Chief Plans to Quit
description: STOCKHOLM  Sometime soon, unless he changes his mind, a cheerful, cultivated man who wears pastelcolored jackets and palegreen shirts will retire as head of the. Swedish Communist party.

title: Senate Passes Bill Giving Exemptions To State Lotteries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Senate passed a bill today that would exempt state lotteries from Federal gambling laws.

title: Zoo's Photographer of Mites and Monkeys Retires
description: Though Samuel C. Dunton has been a professional photographer for 40 years, he has never asked a subject to Smile, please. And with good reason.

title: BESSIE KLENOSKY
description: Bessie Frenkel Klenosky, for more than 35 years a fundraiser and production chief for the American Red Cross, died Wednesday at Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. She was 75 years old and lived in Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: HERSHFIELD RITES ATTENDED BY 600
description: Harry Hershfield, the humorist and raconteur, who died Sunday evening at the age of 89, brought a sense of joy and laughter to his hearers, Rabbi William Berkowitz told some 600 mourners yesterday in a funeral service at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West 88th Street.

title: F.C.C. Aide Denies Application for Channel 9's License
description: An administrative law judge of the Federal Communications Commission has denied the application of an independent company, MultiState Communications, Inc., for the license to WORTV, Channel 9, now held by RKO General, Inc.

title: Miss Proell Captures Final in Parallel Ski Racing
description: SAALBACH, Austria, Dec. 19 (AP)Annamarie Proell, the World Cup leader from Austria, won the first women's parallel ski race in Europe today. She defeated Christa Zechmeister of West Germany in the final.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ALLENHURST, Dec. 19If Mike Burke Jr. fails to follow his father's footsteps as a golf pro, the elder Burke will have only himself to blame.

title: Ruling on Greystone Patients Due Today
description: MORRISTOWN, Dec. 19 (UPI)  A Superior Court judge reserved decision today on a suit filed by the State, Public Advocate's office to bar admission of new patients at Greystone Psychiatric Hospital.

title: Brooklyn Woman, 19, Is Raped on BMT
description: A 19yearold Brooklyn woman returning home from Christmas shopping was raped at knifepoint in midafternoon Wednesday as she rode alone in the last car of a Manhattanbound BMT train whose route runs from Queens through Brooklyn.

title: Knicks Topple Kings, 117 to 113, As Bradley and Frazier Execel
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 19The New York Knicks revived their familiar and deadly offensive patterns tonight and snapped a threegame losing streak, beating the Kansas CityOmaha Kings, 117113, at Kemper Arena.

title: Severe Boulez Leads the Philharmonic
description: Pierre Boulez put his fluoroscopic method on four scores last night in Fisher Hall. He led the New York Philharmonic in Handel's Water Music, Schumann's First Symphony, the Violin Concerto No. 2 by Szymanowski and Ravel's Bolero.

title: Soviet Jews Worried Over Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19The Soviet disavowal yesterday of any understanding linking American trade concessions to freer emigration from the Soviet Union has not caused noticeable panic among Jews here who have applied to emigrate, though some today expressed concern for the future.

title: Legislature Adjourns in Trenton Without Tax Action
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19The Legislature adjourned for the year this evening without approving a new system of financing public schools in New Jersey, thus defying a State Supreme Court order to do so by Dec. 31.

title: BANK RATE IS CUT TO 6% IN GERMANY
