description: GENEVA, Dec. 20 (AP)Emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel dropped by almost 50 per cent this year, according to official figures released today.

title: Oily Flag
description: White House officials deny persistent reports that Senate Democrats, as the price of yesterdays passage of the trade bill, extorted from President Ford a pledge to sign a separate subsidy bill pushed through by the ravenous maritime lobby that would cost the American taxpayer and consumer many billions of dollars.

title: Turkish Crisis Snarls Cyprus Talks
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 18The Government crisis in Turkey is now three months old, and there are few prospects for improvement.

title: Men's Race Canceled
description: SALICE DULZIO, Italy, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Officials today canceled tomorrow's European Cup men's downhill at this Alpine resort following complaints from Austrian and Swiss skiers that the course was not safe.

title: Peru Compensates Concern
description: The International Protein Corporation announced yesterday it had been recompensed for nationalization of its Peruvian plants. The company said the compensation totaled $9,368,000, including $468,000 in interest. It said it received the money from the United States Government acting on behalf of the Government of Peru. The Peruvian Government took over five plants and 85 fishing boats of the company in 1972.

title: Airlines Admit to Paying Travel Agents Kickbacks
description: More than a dozen foreign and domestic airlines have agreed to admit to Federal prosecutors that they made illegal rebates to travel agents, and now lace criminal prosecution and fines as a result.

title: A Correction
description: In Prof. Roy Schotland's letter published yesterday the figure for total pension funds should have read $250 billion, not $50 billion.

title: 5 LEFTISTS FOUND SLAIN IN URUGUAY
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 20 (UPI)  The bulletriddled bodies of five persons linked to the leftwing Tupamaro guerrillas were found near Soca, 134 miles east of here today, a day after a terrorist group. killed the Uruguayan military attach in Paris.

title: BYRNE, SENATORS TO MEET ON TAXES
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20  Although the Legislature has adjourned for the year, Governor Byrne announced today that a bipartisan majority in the Senate had agreed to meet with him Monday in a renewed attempt to draft a new system of financing public schools in New Jersey.

title: Yields on U.S. Bills Are Varied at Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Yields varied on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Nets Roll To Ninth In a Row
description: UNIONDALE, L. I. Dec. 20Marvin Barnes, the prize rookie of the St. Louis Spirits, was so discombobulated after tonight's 126102 triumph by the New York Nets that he didn't quite know his feet from his armpits.

title: Kissinger Visits U.N. Today for Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20  Secretary of State Kissinger will have separate meetings here tomorrow with Foreign Minister Abdelaziz Bouteflika of Algeria, the president of the justrecessed General Assembly, and with Secretary General Waldheim.

title: FIRST $250,000 WON BY INJURED WOMAN
description: LIVINGSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)A Blenheim woman, confined to a wheelchair as a result of an industrial accident nine years ago, became the first $250,000 winner in the Jackpot Drawing of the new state weekly lottery yesterday.

title: Durable Goods Orders Off; Depression Seen in Autos
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) New orders for durable goods declined 3 per cent in November, the Commerce Department said today. A department official described the drop as evidence slack demand in the nation's industrial sector.

title: USM's Net Declines as Revenues Rise
Rosenbloom Has Mild Heart Attack
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Carroll Rosenbloom, owner and president of the Los Angeles Rams, suffered a mild heart attack last weekend but is responding well to treatment and is expected to be released from the hospital early next week.

title: Francis Finds a Silver Lining After Rangers Turn Him Gray
description: The ratings won't show how many televisions were snapped off in disgust during the Rangers' awful performance in an 11.3 defeat at Boston Thursday night.

title: Voice Analyzer That Serves as Lie Detector Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 An engineer and psychologist was granted three patents this week for a new voice analyzer that serves as a lie detector. In operation, physical contact with the. person being examined is not required, and the sound can be transmitted by telephone and recorded. Fred H. Fuller of Chevy Chase, Md., received Patents 3,855,416 through 3,855,418. The equipment, called the Mark II Voice Analyzer, is being produced by Norton Electronics, Inc Washington, and distributed by Law Enforcement Associates, Inc., Belleville, N. J. It is reported that about 15 machines have been ordered.

title: Consumer Price Index Shows A Moderating Increase Here
description: The consumer price for the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area showed a rise in November, though at a slightly lower rate than in preceding months.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (Reuters)The Department Housing and Urban Development announced today that would temporarily liberalize its conventional home mortgage assistance program.

title: FOSTER GRANT BID MADE BY HOECHST
description: The American Hoechst Corporation, a chemical and textile fiber producer and subsidiary of Hoechst A.G. of West Germany said yesterday it was purchasing all 1,513,930 shares of Class A common stock of Foster Grant, Inc., from the United Brands Company for $69.9million, or $46.20 a share.

title: Finding of Dad Shell Halts Tunnel Traffic
description: Traffic in the Lincoln Tun nel, was halted in both directions for 30 minutes yesterday morning when a dummy mortar shell was found at the New York exit.

title: REV. SCIPIO IACINI
description: The Rev. Scipio lacini, pastor of Our Lady of Loreto Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, from 1952 until his retirement in 1967, died Sunday at the Carmel Richmond Nursing Home. His age was 84.

title: Israel Said to Curb Shelling of Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20The United Nations has reportedly arranged for a temporary halt in Israeli shelling of olive groves in southern Lebanon to permit farmers to complete their harvest.

title: RAPHAEL DISPLAYS COMMAND AS SINGER
description: No concessions were made by the singer Raphael in his first Broadway theater appearance, at the Uris on Thursday, when he opened a fourday concert series, His program was aast all Spanish, his usual mixture of blatant romanticism, occasional social comment, sentimentality, sexiness and the somewhat overblown gesture. A shadow of himself in crucifixion pose thrown onto the stage backdrop is hardly hiding one's light under a bushel.

title: Parents Guilty of Infant Son's Murder
description: NEWARK, Dec. 20Mr. and Mrs. Dennis DiRocco of Nutley, two former heroin addicts, were convicted of second degree murder today in the beating death of their 13monthold son, whose body was found in his playpen last June.

title: Nessen Corrects Statement On Ford's Vacation Fee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) A spokesman gave today a corrected report on the daily rent that President Ford will pay for the use of a sevenbedroom ski chalet when he goes to Vail, Colo., next week for a working holiday.

title: What Noise Does to Us
description: To the Editor:

title: In Memoriam
description: BECKERSadve J. Sadly missed by your loving daughters, sonsinlaw & grandchildren.

title: WRIGLEY RAISING GUM PRICE BY 14%
description: The recent wave of soaring sugar prices is forcing the nation's largest chewing gum manufacturer, the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company to raise its wholesale price by 14 per cent The big Chicago company said yesterday that the wholesale cost of a 20pack box of sevenstick packaged gum would be lifted from $1.50 to $1.72.

title: Pro Football Playoffs to Begin Today
description: OAKLAND, Dec. 20  The reigning champions and the perennially unsuccessful challengers square off today, in the person of the Miami Dolphins and the Oakland Raiders, with both sides convinced that the winner of this first round American Football Conference playoff game will go on to win the Super Bowl.

title: Major Bushfires Scorch 3 Million Acres in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (UPI)Major brushfires, fed by tinderdry grass and scrub, burned today in eastern and western Australia, destroying grazing land, cattle and farm outbuildings and threatening the town of Cobar, 450 miles west of here.

title: JEWISH LEADERS URGE FORD DELAY ON SOVIET TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20President Ford was urged by several leaders of American Jewish groups today not to use his new authority to grant lower tariffs to the Soviet Union until he was convinced that Moscow would ease its emigration procedures.

title: James H. Floyd, 54, Led Key Unit of Georgia House
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 20 (AP)State Representative James H. (Sloppy) Floyd, one of the most powerful and colorful members of the Georgia Legislature, died early today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 year's old.

title: ARGENTINA CLOSES MAJOR NEWSPAPER.;Tabloid Urged Invasion of Islands2d Daily Shut
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20The Government today closed down the newspaper with the largest circulation in Argentina and a small leftist daily.

title: FORD TO REPLACE C.A.B. CHAIRMAN
description: President Ford has decided not to reappoint Robert D. Timm as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board when his term expires Dec. 31, the White House announced yesterday.

title: Delay Is Seen on Plan for West Side Road
description: There will be no quick decision on the Beanie administration's proposal for a new sixlane interstate highway to tunnel through landfill along the Hudson waterfront and to be topped by a 190footwide promenade.

title: Miller Resigns as Head Of State Mental Hygiene
description: Dr. Alan D. Miller

title: People and Business
description: The management of the Great Western United Corporation, operator of the largest domestic sugar beet company, underwent a major upheaval yesterday.

title: 436 Discharged by City; Lag Laid to Some Agencies
description: Fewer than half of the group of 1,000 appointed provisional workers ordered dismissed by Mayor Beame as a budgetcutting measure on Nov. 22 left the city's service yesterday, the Budget Bureau disclosed last evening.

title: Pro Football Reserve Rule Held Illegal by U.S. Judge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20In a sweeping decision that almost certainly will be appealed, Federal District Judge (William T. Sweigert ruled toda that the National Football League's contract and playerreserve system was illegal.

title: WINE TALK
description: The Bordeaux wine scandal is over. Two men of illustrious name in the wine world, Ivan and Lionel Cruse, have been convicted of fraud, given suspended sentences and been ordered to pay a staggering $12million in taxes and damages. A third man, Pierre Bert, a wine broker, has been sentenced to a year in jail.

title: PARK SERVICE HEAD FACING A SUBPOENA
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) The chairmen of two House subcommittees today ordered that Ronald H. Walker, director of the National Park Service, be subpoenaed after he failed to appear at a hearing. It, was learned that he was in Denver to meet with his successor.

title: 13YearOld Girl Wins Slalom Run
description: STRATTON, Vt., Dec. 20 (AP)A 13yearold skier, Heidi Preuss of Laconia, N.H., outskied rine members of the U.S. women's ski team today and won the first run of the women's slalem in the Eastern Holiday Classic at Stratton Mountain.

title: Empathy of Elderly Benefits the Neediest as Senior Citizens Group Contributes
description: The elderly have long been aware of the problems that beset others of their age, and the Briarcliff, N. Y. Senior Citizens Center yesterday did its share to help, sending a check for $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Miss Hackley, Barnard Senior, Bride of Roman Martinez 4th
description: Helena Elizabeth Hackley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherlock D. Hackley of New York and Nassau, the Bahamas, was married here last evening to Roman Martinez 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martinez 3d of Miami Shores, Fla., formerly of Santiago, Cuba. The ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer was performed by the Rev. Rowland J. McCann. A reception for 300 followed at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: Redskins: Washington's Common Bond
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  The groundskeeper at George Washington's old farm at Mount Vernon leaves a gate open for one of the neighbors, Sonny Jurgensen, the Washington Redskins' ageless quarterback, who does his daily running in the backyard of the father of his country. But that is perhaps the least example of the way legend and politics, power and pro football are all entwined in the nation's capital  all the more so on the eve of the Super Bowl playoffs.

title: Shop Owner Wins The Right to Keep Tiger Skin on Wall
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 20The Bengal Tiger maybe an endangered species, but so is the small businessman who might want to hang a tiger skin on his wall, according to the defense lawyer in a test case resolved in Circuit Court here yesterday.

title: Some Ford Aides Project $35Billion Budget Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Some of President Ford's economic advisers are projecting a huge budget deficitas much as $35billionfor the next fiscal year, even without the tax cut that is under intense debate within the Administration.

title: Havlicek, Bradley to Meet Today
description: Bill Bradley is the old man of the Knicks and John Havlicek, the senior citizen of the Boston Celtics. Since Bradley joined the Knicks for the 1967  68 season his matchups with Havlicek in forecount have added an interesting dimension to the Knick and Boston rivalry.

title: Liberating Justice ...
description: The most encouraging aspect of the present search for a new Attorney General is that President Ford appears ready to break with the deplorable tradition of keeping the Justice Department under control of partisan politicians. Democratic and Republican Presidents alike have been guilty of promoting this indefensible practice which neither logic nor principle can excuse.

title: CONGRESS PASSES MAJOR TRADE BILL AND ENDS SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The 93d Congress adjourned tonight after giving final approval to a major foreign trade bill and several less significant measures.

title: Hope Reported as Geneva Talks On European Security Recess
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20The 35nation Conference on European: Security and Cooperation recessed today for a month with many delegates encouraged by the progress to date.

title: Minnesota Gunmen Held After Freeing Their 55 Hostages
description: RICHFIELD, Minn., Dec. 20 (AP)  Four young gunmen who held about 55 hostages for up to six hours when a policeman barred their escape from a Richfield supermarket were in jail today on armed, robbery and other charges.

title: Woman to Get Visa
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20  A woman born in New York City who has lived in Estonia since infancy has received permission to return to the United States after six years of waiting, American consular officials reported today.

title: Japan Opposes Revaluing
description: TOKYO, Dec. 20 (AP)Taroichi Yoshida, Vice Minister of Finance for International Monetary Affairs, said today that Japan does not favor widespread moves to revalue official gold holdings at the higher market price.

title: Eleanore Leavitt Is Bride in Capital
description: Eleanore Richards Leavitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edgar Leavitt of Westmoreland Hills, Md., was married yesterday afternoon in St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington to Domenico De Sole of Washington. He is a son of Brig. Gen. Gaetano De Sole, Italian Army, retired, and Mrs. De Sole of Rome. The Rev. A. Theodore Eastman performed the ceremony.

title: Eggs Aren't Bad for You After All, a Specialist Insists
description: People who have been keeping their cholesterol counts low due to concern about hardening of the arteries and heart attacks may be tempted to go back to their morning eggs, at least for the time being. A British nutritionist says that those worried about their hearts and arteries would do better to stay off sugar then shun the egg.

title: Joy and Shattered Hopes Follow Results of Bar Exam
description: In the public and private law offices throughout the city, less work than usual was being done yesterdaythe results of the bar examination had been published.

title: Interstate Link In Racing Asked
description: New York and New Jersey could avoid a disastrous parimutuel war by forming a Port Authority of horse racing, a top executive with racetrack experience in both states suggested yesterday.

title: Of the Peruvian Government's Objectives
description: To the Editor:

title: John A. Begg, Book Designer, Artist and Teacher, Dies at 71
description: John Alfred Begg, book designer and artist, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital, Yonkers. He was 71 years old and lived in HastingsonHudson, N. Y.

title: $30Million Water Plant Is Begun by Jersey City
description: PARSIPPANYTROY HILLS, N.J., Dec. 20Using a chromeplated spade, Jersey City Mayor Paul T. Jordan broke ground today for the construction of a $30million waterpurification plant at the site of the first chlorinated public water supply in the United States.

title: In Goa, Portuguese Heritage Slowly Fades Under Indian Rule
description: PANAJI, Goa, Dec. 14This sliver of land on the Arabian Sea is awakening from a long siesta. After 13 years of Indian rule, the people of Goa are gradually, and quite reluctantly, shedding their Portuguese style acquired from four and a half centuries as a colony.

title: 50 Detectives Seek Aged Man's Killers
description: Fifty detectives have been assigned to hunt for the intruders who strangled a 98yearold former yeshiva principal early Thursday, the police said yesterday.

title: U.S. Declines to Comment On Dayan's Accusation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The State Department said today that it would not be useful to discuss a charge by Moshe Dayan that the United States obtained Israeli consent to the passage of food, water and medicine to a surrounded Egyptian force last year by threatening to fly them in itself if necessary.

title: In Complex Negotiations With U. S. on Jewish Emigration, Soviet Insists on Flexibility
description: The exchange of letters between Senator Henry M. Jackson, Secretary of State Kissinger and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko appears to leave the issue of Jewish emigration pretty much where it stood before the socalled understanding was reached  subject to the general ebb and flow of SovietAmerican relations.

title: Civil Rights Groups in the South Find Inflation Stilles Their Work
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 18  The South's civil rights organizations are being squeezed by inflation and a shortage of operating funds, most of which come from foundations and wealthy people whose fortunes rise and fall with the nation's economy.

title: State to Set Up a Unit to Fight Corruption
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)The state of New Jersey is planfining to go after crooked public officials in the same way, that the Federal Government trapped Al Caponewith a team of accountants.

title: ROCKEFELIER LATE ON HIS FIRST DAY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Nelson A. Rockefeller, on his first day as Vice. President apparently ran afoul of holiday traffic in the capital today and showed up fiv minutes late for the only job the Constitution specifically assigns him: presiding over the Senate.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
The Gromyko Letter
description: Moscow's curious publication, seven weeks afterward, of Foreign Minister Gromyko's ambiguous letter to Secretary Kissinger on the tradeemigration understanding a letter ostensibly written to eliminate ambiguities about the Soviet positionfortunately has not interfered with Congressional passage of the critical trade bill.

title: Antiques: Vintage Cycles
description: Scores of cyclists on 10speed twowheelers sped swiftly past 399 Park Avenue this week, and most were probably unware of the wintage versions of their vehicles hidden behind a small forest of decorated evergreens in front of that building's entrance.

title: CITY SUES JERRY FOR RESTITUTION
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has decided that Gerald Rosenberg, of Hey Jerry, what's the story? television  commercial fame, still hasn't answered the question.

title: Opposition in Seoul Gains in Voice and Visibility
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 20 A year ago a prominent South Korean professor died mysteriously while under detention by the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Chile Plans to Pay I.T.T. $125Million For Telephone Unit
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday the Government of Chile had agreed to pay it $125.2 million for equity and debt in the Chile Telephone Company. About $21 million would be paid in cash and the rest in letters of credit and notes payable at various periods over the next 13 years, I. T. T. said.

title: DDay for Dolphins
description: Within the next few days, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the Department of Commerce will decide on life or death for tens of thousands of dolphins. Since 1960, an average of 200,000 to 300,000 dolphins have been inadvertently killed each year by the giant nets used by American and foreign fishing fleets to catch tuna.

title: Italy and Iran Sign Pact On Technology and Oil
description: ROME, Dec. 20Italy and Iran have signed an agreement expected to open the way for Italian technological aid to Iran in exchange for help in reducing the large deficit in the Italian balance of payments.

title: Tombs Closes as Last of Its Inmates Depart
description: After a tumultous 33year history, during which it symbolized the hopes and frustrations of New York City's penal system, the Tombs closed yesterday, with the last group of inmates leaving reluctantly.

title: Price Index Rises 0.9% As Real Incomes Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Consumer prices rose strongly again in November, the Labor Department reported today.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forWarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: QUINCY JONES MUSIC PLAYED BY JAZZ REP
description: The relatively slim claim to jazz fame of Quincy Jones was made to seem even slimmer by the New York Jazz Repertory Company's concert of his music at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening.

title: Giscard Sees Smoother U.S. Relations
description: PARIS, Dec. 20President Valery Giscard d'Estaing said tonight that there was a new, smoother tone in FrenchAmerican relations but that it was easier to deal on equal terms with the Soviet Union than with the United States.

title: Leone Meets With Sadat
description: CAIRO, Dec. 20President Leone of Italy and Foreign Minister Jean Sauvargnargues of France were in Cairo today, each eager to improve his country's, economic and political relations with the Arabs and to insure a continuous, flow of oil.

title: Israeli Express Surprise
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 20  The statement by Moshe Dayan last night that the United States had threatened to supply. trapped Egyptians last year evoked some expressions of surprise here today.

title: NursingHome Operators Issued Senate Subpoenas
description: United States marshals began serving Senate subpoenas here yesterday on members of the socalled Bernard Bergman syndicate of nursing homes, who have defied subpoenas of a state investigation unit.

title: Some Big Sugar Refiners Deny PriceFixing Charge
description: Several of the six large sugar refiners indicted Thursday by a San Francisco Federal grand jury on pricefixing denied the charges yesterday. Two of the companies pointed out that the alleged actions from 1970 to 1972 were unrelated to the dramatic rise in sugar prices that took place this year.

title: Surelco Reaches Accord in Surinam On a Bauxite Levy
description: The Surinam Aluminum Company (Surelco), a subsidiary to the Aluminum Company of America, and the Government of Surinam reached an agreement that will increase the bauxite revenues paid to that nation to about $10 a metric ton, retroactive to last Jan. 1.

title: How Not to Cut a Payroll
description: To the Editor: Professor Savas proposes that the city identify and dismiss the least productive employes [letter Dec. 7]. This is an old management slogan, invoked whenever times are bad, but he should know better than to support an approach which cannot succeed.

title: Prosecutor Says the Grand Jury Won't Get Heritage Hills Inquiry
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 30The Westchester District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said tody that a threemonth investigation into alleged irregularities at the Heritage Hills condominium site in Somers revealed that there is no basis for presentation of charges to a grand jury.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS
But at Gucci You'd Think People Had Money to Burn
description: Passerby looks at women's fashions in window.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More than 100 persons attended funeral services in South Bound Brook for 20yearold Thomas Smigelski, killed in an auto crash shortly after he allegedly stabbed his parents and sister. The Rev. John R. Hughes, assistant pastor of Our Lady of Mercy Church, celebrated a mass of the resurrection and eulogized Mr. Smigelski briefly before the congregation, which included the dead man's two sisters and his brother. Mr. Smigelski's parents, Frank Smigelski, 52, and his wife Jean, 50, who were still in Somerset Hospital in Somerville with stab wounds of the chest and stomach, were unable to attend the service. The dead man's sister, Gloria, 28, who Was stabbed in the arm during the incident at the Smigelski home early Tuesday, attended the services.

title: A PurseSnatcher Caught
description: To the Editor: When discussing crime in New York, much is said regarding the apathetic bystander, the cop who's never there and the offender who is rarely apprehended. Very little mention is given or thanks paid to the police force or the general public when their help has been successfully enlisted.

title: JAPANESE OILMEN PLEAD NOT GUILTY
description: TOKYO, Dec. 20  Thirty executives of 12 large oil companies and the Petroleum Association of Japan pleaded not guilty today to charges, of violating the nation's AntiMonopoly Law as the trial of what is known in Japan as the Blackmarket Cartel Case opened in Tokyo High Court today.

title: Dayan Links Peace To Yielding of Golan
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 20 (UPI)Former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that Israel would have to give the Golan Heights back to Syria if she wanted to avoid another war and reach a peace settlement with Egypt.

title: Russell D. Oliver, 64, Dies; Ford Teammate at Michigan
description: CULVER, Ind., Dec, 20 (AP) Russell Dwight Oliver, a football teammate of President Ford at the University of Michigan, died of cancer yesterday in South Bend Memorial Hospital. He was 64 years old. Mr. Oliver was director of alumni affairs at Culver Military Academy. He joined the Culver staff in 1935 and coached football, basketball and baseball until 1960.

title: Stubbs Is Winner In Squash at Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20John Stubbs of Milton Academy defeated fourthseeded Bruce Giamettei of Birmingham, Mich., 15.14, 1513, 1511, in the opening round of the United States junior 18andunder squash racquets championship today at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Figure beside Station Circle is temperature.

title: Bridge: Wrong Contract Can Prove Right One in Some Instances
description: The traditional jump shift response to an opening suit bid, suggesting slam prospects, is used too infrequently by average players. And when they do use it, they often choose the wrong moment.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Colson Gives Justice Office Another Plea for Clemency
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) Charles W. Colson the former White House adviser, once a in has petitioned the Ford Administration for executive clemency, Justice Department sources said today.

title: Art: Herbin's Limited Perfection
description: The paintings of Auguste Herbin (18821960) mirror a world that in almost every case is stilled and in equilibrium. One shape, one color, on strict rectangular compartment answers to another with all possible politeness. Clashes are rare, and tumult is, unknown. Everything, everywhere, looks as if it had been cut out with a pair of very sharp scissors and set down in exactly its intended place.

title: Storm In the Glass Menagerie
description: PARISWhen the United Nations General Assembly wound up this week, it left behind considerable diplomatic wreckage. In good logrolling tradition, Moscow, Peking, the Arabs and the underdeveloped states traded votes and brought in a series of decisions that rattled every window in the glass menagerie. Bruised in the process were Israel, South Africa and the United Statesplus a carefully builtup body of tradition.

title: Lord Fraser of Lonsdale, 77, Champion of the Blind, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Dec. 20  Lord Fraser of Lonsdale, a champion of the blind, died last night in a hospital here. He was 77 years old.

title: Canada Rail Crash Hurts 50
description: KINGSTON, Ontario, Dec. 20 (UPI)  A Canadian National train collided headon with a freight train tonight near here injuring about 50 people, four seriously. The police said there were no confirmed deaths but that four people were missing. The collision occurred on the main line between Montreal and Toronto, about four miles south of Kingston.

title: CITY SUES JERRY FOR RESTITUTION
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has decided that Gerald Rosenberg, of Hey Jerry, what's the story? television  commercial fame, still hasn't answered the question.

title: Miss Nadig Is First in Ski Drills
description: SAALBACH, Austria, Dec. 20 (AP) Marie Therese Nadig of Switzerland and Cindy Nelson of Lutsen, Minn., were the fastest skiers in both practice runs today for the third World Cup women's downhill race tomorrow.

title: MiniMet Season Is Postponed Until '76 as Bicentennial Event
description: The Metropolitan Opera's MiniMet season of chamber opera, which had been scheduled for revival in February and March, has been postponed again. Schuyler G. Chapin, the Metropolitan's general manager, confirmed yesterday that the decision had been made, but denied a report that the onagain, offagain series had been canceled. It has merely been put off until 1976, he said, when it will be a feature of the bicentennial season at the Met. Mr. Chapin added that he preferred not to comment further at this time.

title: FOUNDATION AIDE An EXOFFENDER
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 20A Federal official said today that an officer of an Illinois foundation that had offered to rescue a financially troubled Arizona college had been convicted twice for securities fraud.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL LAYING OFF 1,400
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, said yesterday that it was laying off 1,400 workers next week because of the uncertain coal situation.

title: Governments Can't Buy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (Reuters)The Treasury said today it would not accept bids from foreign governments when it auctions two million ounces of United States gold next month.

title: ETHIOPIAN RULERS PLEDGE TO BUILD SOCIALIST STATE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 20  The governing military council announced today that it would turn Ethiopia into a socialist country with a oneparty system, collective farms and direct Government control over all property useful for economic progress.

title: Georgia In Bowl Tonight
Miss Walsh Gains Final
description: CAPETOWN, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Thirdseeded Sharon Walsh of the United States advanced to the women's singles final in the Western Province tennis tournament today, defeating secondseeded Linky Boshoff of South Africa, 76, 57, 63. Miss Walsh will meet topseeded Ilana Kloss of South Africa, who beat Annette Du Plooy of South Africa, 63, 64.

title: Pro Football Reserve Rule Held by Illegal b U.S. Judge
description: SAN FRANCISCO Dec. 20In a sweeping decision that almost certainly will be appealed, Federal District Judge William T. Sweigert ruled today that the National Football League's contract and playerreserve system was illegal.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (UPI)The organizers of the 1976 Montreal Olympics have under wraps a report that shows construction costs for the summer Games will be substantially higher than original estimates, apparently leaving them with the decision of either finding new money sources or cutting back on planned facilities. The report, prepared by a Montreal engineering firm, shows that the [construction] costs are much higher than the 1972 estimates, a spokesman for the Olympic Organizing Committee conceded.

title: JURORS HEAR DEAN TERMED PERJURER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  H. R. Haldeman's chief defense lawyer told the jury at the Watergate coverup trial today that the prosecution's chief witness, John W. Dean 3d, was a mastermind of chicanery and a perjurer.

title: ILL WOMAN HELD PAROLE VIOLATOR
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 20A 20yearold woman with a congital heart defect, convicted last year for marijuana possession, began a twoyear prison sentence this week because she violated parole by living with her mother.

title: ...Qualifying a Judge
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee, the next Attorney General, and President Ford may yet shed themselves of an embarrassmentthe job of denying a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut. Instead of the planned effort to place Mr. Meskill's name before the full Senate, the Judiciary Committee has deferred his consideration without prejudice.

title: Operators of Nursing Homes Get Senate Subpoenas
description: United States marshals began serving Senate subpenas here yesterday on members of the socalled Bernard Bergman syndicate of nursing homes, who have defied subpoenas of a state investigation unit.

title: Bomb Goes off in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 (UPI) A bomb exploded in a police car today in Jerusalem's busy Zion Square, wounding bystanders, destroying the vehicle and shattering the front of a store.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Joint Commission on Acceritation of Hospitals has voted to reverse an earlier decision and renew the accreditation of Lincoln, Hospital in the Bronx for one year.

title: Notes on People Berlin and U.S. Envoys Show Credentials
description: Part of page from President Ford's high school yearbook, auctioned Thursday for $475

title: The Juggernaut
description: To the Editor:

title: Ox Ridge Indoor Season to Open on Friday
description: The Ox Ridge Hunt Club will conduct its first indoor horse show of the season next Friday.

title: The LastMinuteGift Business
description: Two shopping days remain before Christmas. The one item likely to be in equal demand at Gucci's and McDonald's is the gift certificate. It adds up to a multimilliondollar business whose actual size is really known to no one.

title: Manhattan Drops Final To Michigan Five, 7766
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 21 (AP)Joe Johnson scored a careerhigh 27 points tonight in leading Michigan to a 7766 basketball victory over Manhattan College in the final of the Michigan tournament.

title: They Made Him Two Offers He Couldn't Refuse
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Israel Shells South Lebanon. Says Guerrillas Struck First
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 21 (UPI)Israeli artillery shelled southern Lebanon today after Palestinian guerrillas fired several Sovietmade bazooka shells across the border, Israeli military sources said.

title: Susan Park Cooney, an Editor, Married to Carter Scott Evans
description: The First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Susan Park Cooney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bossert Cooney of Old Lyme, to Carter Scott Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carnot Wagener Evans of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Gregory Tweed performed the ceremony.

title: Mary C. Goodyear Is Married To Henry Buckland Sawyer 3d
description: St. Thaddeus Episcopal Church in Aiken, S. C., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Coon Goodyear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Goodyear of Aiken, to Henry Buckland Sawyer 3d, son of Mr. Sawyer Jr. of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Mrs. Sawyer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 16yearold youth was reported in satisfactory condition at Wyckoff Heights Hospital from a bullet wound in the stomach he suffered when shot Friday night by Police Officer George Phelps at Fresh Pond Road and 59th Drive, Ridgewood, Queens. The youth, Daniel Michel of 4818 54th Avenue, Fresh Meadows, Queens, was shot when he allegedly tried to run over the offduty officer after their cars had been involved in a collision. He was charged with the attempted murder of an officer.

title: Zoo
description: Today's zoos are institutions, and like all institutions they are involved in controversy, adjustment, selfjustification, relevance, change and focusing on The Big Picture.

title: Japanese Wonder if Their Democracy Can Survive
description: TOKYOThe new Premier Of Japan Takeo Miki, gently interrupted the opening question at a press conference the other day he had something he wanted to say about the Japanese people's distrust of their Government. We face the most difficult situation in the postwar years, he said. The mission of the moment is to restore the people's confidenee in politics. Unless it has the people's confidence, I believe the Government cannot carry on.

title: 93d Congress Set Historic Precedents
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The last two years were tumultuous ones politically, and the 93d Congress, which adjourned last night, was in the center of the storm.

title: The Earth Book
description: Eighteen years ago E. B. White allowed he'd feel more optimistic about a bright future for man if he spent less time proving that he can outwit Nature and more time tasting her sweetness and respecting her seniority. The pictures assembled here worry the same subject in a thin, lookthrough book styled like a color film strip, with limited text, perfect for today's TVtuned child.

title: New Day in House Foreseen by Florio
description: LACKWOODNew Jetspy's youngest Congressmanelect, 37yearold James J. Florio, sees 1975 as a new day for freshmen Representatives.

title: Donation of Bodies Aided
description: BATON ROUGE, Dec. 21 (UPI)Persons wishing to donate their bodies for science or research after death will be able to have that information recorded on their Louisiana driver's license starting next month. Hickley M. Waguespack, director of the Louisiana Department of Public Safety, said this week that the information would be placed on the back of the license after the driver completes the necessary forms available at driver's license offices.

title: Taiwan Golfer Triumphs
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 21 (AP)  Kuo ChiHsiung, a Taiwan professional, won the first Chum Professional Golf Association tournament today, shooting a oneunderpar 71 for a 72hole total of 285. The victory was worth $12,310.

title: Letters on the Rohatyn Proposal
description: The following is a collection of letters in response to Felix Rohatyn's article, A New R.F.C. Is Proposed For Business (Dec. 1), which is also discussed in the article above.

title: G.A.O. EXAMINING OPERATIONS OF F.B.I.
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UPI)The General Accounting Office is conducting a nationwide investigation into the daily operations of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Chicago Tribune reported today.

title: Jobs in the Great Depression
description: WASHINGTONI am not willing, Franklin D. Roosevelt told Congress nearly 40 years ago, that the vitality of our people be further sapped by the giving of cash, of market baskets, of a few hours of weekly work cutting grass, raking leaves or picking up papers in the public parks.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: ACTION ON ECONOMY URGED BY G.M. CHIEF
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21 (UPI)Prompt action by the Government to restore consumer confidence and stimulate the economy could lift the nation out of its recession by mid1975, the board chairman of the General Motors Corporation said today.

title: Mexico Promises Corruption Drive, but Mexicans Wait and See
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 21A Government initiative to investigate inexplicable fortunes among public officials has again caused Mexicans to wonder whether it is about to launch a genuine campaign against official corruption.

title: Patricia Gilhooly Wed to W. F. Duffy Jr.
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle in Brookville, L. I., yesterday afternoon, Patricia E. Gilhooly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Gilhooly of Montgomery, Ala., was married to William Francis Duffy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Duffy of Lombard, Ill., formerly of Garden City, L. I.

title: EXOTIC CONCERT BY TEITEL BAUM
description: Richard Teitelbaum, now based at York University in Toronto, is a composer with many disparate influences. Sometimes when that is the case the resultant works sound fragmented into a depersonalized eclecticism. But at Mr. Teitelbaum's concert Friday night at the Kitchen, there was much to admire.

title: Porter's Works on Display
description: HUNTINGTON  The retrospective exhibition of Fairfield Porter's art at the Heckscher Museum emphasizes that he is one of the most outstanding contemporary American artists.

title: U. S. Crews to Row on Nile Again
description: CAIRO, Dec. 21 The rowing teams of Harvard. Yale, Oxford and Cambridge Universities were airlifted into Egypt for races Monday and Thursday on the Nile.

title: Candlelight Tour Slated in Cape May
description: CAPE MAYChristmas in Cape May, a candlelight tour of more than a halfdozen homes decorated in distinctive yuletide motifs and finery, will be held next Saturday from 6 to 10 P.M.

title: Paris! It's Still Being Discovered
description: SURELY no one sleeps late in Parisnot with every street cleaner, delivery truck driver and early morning shopper out doing his thing. The clatter is five floors down on Rue Madame, but it is more effective than any alarm clock.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Books, Books, Books

title: One of the deepest inner lives any American has revealedand hidden
description: Interpreting the life and art of Emily Dickinson is a grueling task that requires Erik Erikson's psychological insight, Randall Jarrell's dexterity in reading poems, Siegfried's courage, and Daedalus's skill in getting out of labyrinths. No American has conversed with his or her soul as Emily Dickinson did. Allen Tate is surely right in saying that she had one of the richest and deepest inner lives that any American has ever revealedand hidden. For though she wrote that Garrisoned no Soul can be/In the Front of Trouble, like the flaming angel in Paradise Lost guarding the gates of Eden after the fall, she blocked access to her solitude of space. Or more accurately, she kept the door tantalisingly ajar.

title: The Trade Bill: Its Real Impact
description: WASHINGTON  After a twoyear struggle, Congress finally approved the trade bill last Fridaygiving President Ford the authority he needs to take part in next year's tradefreeing negotia tions with the rest of the industrial world.

title: CENSURE IS AIRED AT CITY COLLEGE
description: The longfestering dispute in the history department at City College was the subject of heated fourhour meeting last week of the Faculty Senate, which deferred until Feb. 6 any action against five professors involved in the controversy.

title: Christine Ann Gober Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Gideon J. Gober of Wallingford, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Christine Ann Gober, to Joseph Patrick Donelan 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X, J. Donelan of New Rochelle, N. Y. Miss Gober, daughter also of the late Mr. Gober, and her fianc, plan to be married in the spring.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: Vigil at Gitmo

title: Computer to Help Boat Buyers
description: Instead of casting its customers adrift in a sea of boats this year, manufacturers participating in the National Boat Show have hired a skipper to chart a straight course to specific boats.

title: Stephen Dedalus at Vassar
description: A few years ago when I was the editor of a pretty skimpy literary magazine at Vassar College 1 received a letter from a well known journalist whir was researching an article on the college littrateur for a prestigious national magazine. To be answered in 500 words or less he queried: As a successful college literary persona, what are some of the trials and tribulations you have experienced in the undergraduate oeuvre? Do you have future ambitions in the world of letters? Flattered, bemused, and oblivious to the implicit mockery in the questions, I was sorely tempted to rail against all the lower case poems from high school students, the odes to the menstrual cycle left anonymously at the magazine's door, the endless short stories in longhand, and the abysmal personality of my coeditor. Unable to explain those traumas in 500 words I wrote some wouldbe salty remarks about my intention to be the golden boy of American letters and enclosed one of our subscription blanks and a rejection slip I had recently incurred from The New Yorker.

title: Conducting Becomes Sarah Caldweli
description: Not too long agothe day before yesterday, maybea woman who said she wanted to be a conductor risked being put down with all the traditional snappy comebacks. (You want to know how to become a good conductor? Stand in the bathtub and put your finger in a light socket. You want to be a conductor? Try the Penn Central.)

title: Africa: The Agony of Western Ways
description: As the anthropologist Margaret Mead has pointed out, the term culture shock, once used to describe the good things one experienced on visiting a foreign country, soon came to be applied to the more contradictory sentiments of Peace Corps volunteers, who found the natives go to the bathroom in the streets. Now, it seems, there is a new kind of culture shock, that felt by the small number of Africans who weather the rigors of Western education in Europe or America and return home not to positions of honor and respect, but series of humiliations,

title: CHESS
description: The four game positions in the diagrams shown here are presented as exercises in tactical play for the reader. For maximum benefit, please cover the solutions printed below (or at least do not read them) before working the problems.

title: Recycling of Waste Is Recession Victim
description: Recycling, the idea nurtured by environmental awareness that brought millions of Americans into collection centers with their carefully separated newspapers, glass and cans, has been hit hard by the recession.

title: Art: Timeless Canvases in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRThe current exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum is strong evidence that treasure troves are often kept in museum cellars and attics.

title: Spain's Ticking Bomb
description: With Generalissimo Franco still nominally in charge at 82, the Spanish Government is pursuing a policy intensified repression that makes a mockery of Premier Carlos Arias Navarro's promise last February of modest liberalization.

title: Calendar of Horse Show Events
description: TodayNo shows scheduled.

title: An Urgent Need For National Unity
description: WASHINGTONAt the end of 1974, a time of economic and political turmoil in the world, a strong case can be made for the creation of a bipartisan Government of national unity in Washington.

title: Headliners
description: The hopedfor romance between Long John Silver and Miss McNasty has not developed. Long John is a 55yearold condor from South America who was brought to New York's Bronx Zoo 14 months ago in the hope that he would mate with Miss McNasty. The match was a disaster: Miss McNasty was cool, aloof and, well, nasty; Long John spent most of his time sulking behind a clump of bamboo. Long John has been returned to his home zoo in Milwaukee, while Bronx Zoo officials search for a more suitable mate for the testy Miss McNasty.

title: The Whole Family Digs This
description: Hey, Dad, what's this? I asked that question some 38 years ago when I picked up what I later learned was a small garnet crystal in my backyardand I've been an avid collector of crystallized minerals (minerals which are found in beautiful natural shapes) ever since.

title: List of Deaths of Outstanding Figures in the World of Sports During the Year 1974
description: Auto Racing

title: Colleges Advised To Recruit More Adults
description: FARMINGDALEThe future survival of Long Island's public and private colleges, according to an official of the State Department of Education, depends on the collective ability of the colleges to counter a sharp decline in the number of 18 to 22 year olds expected to enroll in the next decade by attracting older students.

title: FUND FINDS MANY DENIED SCHOOLING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The nation's public schools have pushed out or systematically excluded more than two million children who should be enrolled in classes, a report published by the Children's Defense Fund charged today.

title: State Rule On Chlorine Is Facing Showdown
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Environmental Protection and the Passaic Valley Sewage Commission have entered a crucial stage in their dispute over the state's regulation that the commission treat its sewagewaste discharge with chlorine 12 months a year.

title: There Was Enough Fuel, But the Money Ran Out
description: Auto racing began 1974 worried whether it would have enough gasoline and ended it worried whether it would have enough money to pay for the fuel.

title: Time Out
description: With Congress in recess, the controlling Democrats and President Ford are free of the need to protect political flanks for a month, but that respite will not improve the view of the economy from either end of Pennsylvania Avenue, nor will it alleviate the pressure to do something new, and more effective, about it.

title: Shop Talk
description: BARRINGTON  Science has always solved problems, but did you know that it can even solve shopping problems, especially at Christmas? Veteran stockingstuffers might find a visit to the factorystore of the Edmund Scientific Company the most profitable Yuletide shopping expedition of all.

title: Mary Farmer Sets Wedding
description: The engagement of Mary Katherine Farmer to Clinton Paulson Stephens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephens of Baltimore, has been announced by Guy Farmer, father of the future bride.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Good evening. I am Gaius Fulvius. My colleague is Marcus Fluvius and this is the XI P.M. FulviusFluvius Report brought to you on WSPQR Channel XVI, where the big story tonight is still that strange star hovering over the troubled Middle East. What do you make of that star, Marcus?

title: Miami (O.) 2110 Victor In Tangerine
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP)Sherman Smith ran for one touchdown and passed for another tonight to lead Miami of Ohio to a 2110 victory over Georgia in the Tangerine Bowl.

title: Honky Star Triumphs by 9 Lengths
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP)Dan Lasater's Honky Star burst to the front coming out of the gate and breezed to a ninelength triumph today in the $27,800 Mademoiselle Stakes at Keystone Race Track.

title: Cindy Nelson Takes Cup Downhill
description: SAALBACH, Austria, Dec. 21 (AP)Cindy Nelson captured a World Cup downhill race for the second time today and moved to within 13 points of Austria's ski ace, Annemarie Proell in the overall standing as the series broke for the Christmas holidays.

title: Raiders, Vikings Victors In Pro Football Playoffs
description: The Oakland Raiders defeated the Miami Dolphins, 2826, and the Minnesota Vikings beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3014, yesterday in the opening games of the National Football League playoffs.

title: Wanted: an original relation to theuniverse
description: When Whitman said O Pioneers  observed F. Scott Fitzgerald he said all. With Fitzgerald the cry had already become a groan, but the American urge to sing possible / changes / that might redeem, in A. R. Ammons's words, proves stubborn, and our writers'. wagons can still be heard heading out of town, creaking for joy. If not toward a greater America then toward eternal being, or heterocosm joyous, they make their dauntless way. The Romantic dream of returning at dawn wet / to the hips with meetings is quite dead in England, but our own Ammons and W. S. Merwin, among others, are out without their long boots. Like the more troubled Pound, Stevens and Williams before them, like Emerson, Thoreau, Melville, Whitman, they are poets of a possibly redeeming change, a change sought in what Emerson called an original relation to the universe.

title: Minnesota Pins 3014 Defeat on Cards
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 21  Jeff and Nate Wright, unrelated except in spirit, provided the big plays that lifted the Minnesota Vikings to a 3014 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today in the opening of the National Football League playoffs.

title: Odometer Resetting Costs Connecticut Dealer License
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 21 (AP)A Glastonbury Volkswagen dealership's license has been suspended for selling a used car whose odometer had been set back from 115,000 miles to 15.000 miles, according to the State Motor Vehicles Department.

title: Some Little Cities Don't Want to Be Big Ones
description: After assuming for years that bigger is better, American cities and towns are discovering that the process of getting big can produce growing pains. As a result, dozens of communities, ranging in size from the very small to the very large, have begun to close their gates against newcomers.

title: Letter to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The abhorrent hatchet job on culture for Long Island by the proposed Nassau County budget is one which strikes fear into the heart of every esthetically inclined resident.

title: Jackson Is Recuperating
description: TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 21 (AP)Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, was recuperating today from surgery in which a kidney stone and part of a kidney were removed the day before.

title: A TOWN IN CRISIS IN CONNECTICUT
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn.This small industrial city in Eastern Connecticut is on the verge of bankruptcy, and possibly radical political change.

title: Linda Layfield Married
description: Linda Jeanne Layfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paul Scaglotti of Pompano Beach, Fla., was married yesterday morning to John Randall Dudley Stephens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Page Prentiss Stephens of Westfield, N. J. and Martha's Vineyard, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of the Decatur (Ga.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Roe Calloway. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Court Verdict on Kapp Opens Battle on PlayerTeam Ties
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21 A Federal Court judge's decision that basic portions of professional football's reserve system are obviously unreasonable and therefore illegal under the antitrust laws is only the first step in a new struggle against the traditional arrangements that bind athletes to professional teams.

title: The World
description: The Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development has suggested that the nonCommunist Industrial world still has a long way to go to end its economic distress. The O.E.C.D. last week predicted the industrial nations face a pronounced and prolonged slowdown that involves the risk of a break in confidence.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It is no secret that Schuyler Chapin is a beleaguered opera manager. Currently he is having troubles on all sides. He not only has to operate a house that is in shaky financial condition, with an anticipated $9million deficit coming up. He not only is girding for a round of labor negotiations that promises to be nasty, what with the Metropolitan Opera hoping for a fourweek more shortening of future seasons. He not only has the daytoday operations to take care of. He not only has to act as a fund raiser. He not only has to act as a diplomat, soothing his temperamental prima donnas. On top of everything else, he is having monumental problems with his own board of directors, and he has an immediate superior looking right over his shoulder.

title: Ideas & Trends/Continued
description: The Federal Trade Commission wants to impose new regulations on private vocational schools that use what the agency calls fraudulent practices to lure students.

title: PANEL ON AGED NAMED BY CAREY
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Carey reamed yesterday a 28member committee to study conditions affecting the aged in this state and to make recommendations.

title: Israel as Sparta
description: HAIFA. Brooks Adams prefaced his classic study of civilization and decay with the observation that conscious thought plays an exceedingly small part in molding the fate of men. At the moment of action the human being almost invariably obeys an instinct, like an animal; only after action has ceased does he reflect. For Israel the moment of action is now, the instinct is selfpreservation, and the time for reflection is yet to come.

title: Christmas Music Is Offered in Park
description: PARAMUSPart of the Yuletide tradition among many North Jersey families is to visit George Washington Memorial Park here and listen to a vesper program of Christmas music emanating from the carillon atop All Faiths Memorial Tower, in the center Of the park.

title: Police Fund Solicitation Ordered Halted
description: TRENTONHome owners and merchants, many of whom are subjected to repeated requests to buy tickets to the traditional policemen's ball and to contribute to other police causes, may soon have fewer knocks on the door.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The headlines melt into history. But behind the headlines are the subtle scenes. And in 1974, as in every year, those are the memories that remain.

title: SUIT ON WELFARE IS WIDENED HERE
description: A classaction suit charging that the Department of Social Services had illegally denied or unreasonably delayed publicassistance benefits to welfare applicants and clients in the Bronx has been expanded to include all of the more than million such people throughout the city.

title: BRIDGE
description: Average players often suffer from the delusion that the expert is an automaton who never suffers from human weakness. But sooner or later all experts of international class forget about a convention. The bidding goes rapidly off the track, and the result is entertaining for the spectators and usually, but not invariably, for the opponents.

title: Bashie Beatrice Nails, Teacher, Is Betrothed to David C. Young
description: Mrs. Rudolph Nails Jr. of Florence, Ala., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Bashie Beatrice Nails of Boston, to David Cheatham Young, son of Mrs. P. Bernard Young Jr. of Norfolk, Va., and the. late Mr. Young.

title: INFLATION CURBS CHRISTMAS SALES
description: Inflation, unemployment, layoffs and concern over what the national economy holds next disappointing have produced generally disappointing Christmas sales so far for merchants across the country.

title: Judge Rejects Suit by a Couple Asking Return of Their Children
description: CHICAGOA suit by an Iowa couple who have been seeking the return of four of their children taken from them more than five years ago has been rejected by a Federal District Court judge on procedural grounds.

title: Ethiopia Holds Parade to Start A Big Rural Development Drive
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Government of Ethiopia, which announced yesterday that it was embarking on its own road to socialism, marked the official opening of an ambitious rural development campaign today with a parade of 20,000 uniformed students.

title: Phebe Miner Is Married to Ivan Goldman
description: Phebe TenBroeck Miner and Ivan Howard Goldman were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Lewis Miner 3d, in Andover, Mass. The Rev. James R. Whyte, chaplain of Phillips Academy in Andover, performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Goldman of Denver.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Dance Nureyev is surely Dionysus; Baryshnihov shows the purer face of Apollo. (John Gruen)

title: The Adventurer
description: It's frequently pointed out that there are no longer heroes in literature, only antiheroes and spoof heroes like 007, and that the reason for this is that writers and readers can no longer believe that there are heroes in socalled real life. In a world in which everything seems to have gone wrong, we long for heroes, secretly wish we could be heroes ourselvesthat by some incredible act of intelligence and daring we could make everything noble, as it used to beand on the slightest provocation we turn some quite ordinary moral mediocrity into a godly ideal: Dr. Kissinger, for instance, before we learned of his involvement in the murder of Chile. Hope springs eternal, but we know better now; and so the novel really is, in a certain sense, dead, and civilization has died with it. We wanly smile at the lastgasp humor of Barthelme, we laugh out loud at the outrageously engag, cartoonish Romantic heroes of Elkin, or, like Cato whiling away his last hours, we sniff out the tortuous windings of philosophical Gass.

title: ROCKEFELLER GETS KEY JOB GUIDING DOMESTIC COUNCIL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The White House announced today that President Ford was appointing Vice President Rockefeller vice chairman of the Domestic Council and expected him to play a major role in explaining the President's domestic and foreign programs throughout the country.

title: Here is a woman with a lot of trouble
description: Madness, despair, desertion. The ladies are ever busy telling us where it's at. Boring marriages, irrelevant children, casual divorces, coldturkey abortions, ineffectual lovers, these women seem to have feverish lives. And of course in their spare time there's the degree to be gotten. The magical degree that will free them from all this trivia and make it possible for them to escape their male captors forever. Diane Johnsonauthor of three previous novels and a wellreceived biography (Lesser Lives)  introduces even more exciting elements. Rape, murder, tireslashing and a strangled pet.

title: A Revolution in IranReport on the Progress
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21A kings's business is nothing but a headache, says Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi, who has been king of kings for more than 33 years now.

title: Patty Cake
description: Her assets include two small tires, a plastic bucket to jam on her head and a rambunctious chimp for a roommate. The walls are grubby, the lights flicker, the windows are barred, and a fundraising plea attests to the plight of this particular urban group. At feedingtime the babies drink their milk from battered twopound coffee cans. Look, says a mother. There's Patty Cake. She's all grown up. Inexplicably she plunks her own child before a pair of glum elderly gorillas. The child slips along the rail to the little apes, claps hands and croons Patty Cake.

title: U.S. Unemployment Is Clearly Affected by the Spread of Multinationals
description: WASHINGTONDuring the last 10 years, more and more Americancontrolled multinational companies based in the United States have shifted their production overseas, principally to lowwage areas such as Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Mexico and most recently West Africa, where cooperative, trainable Workers can be employed for under 30 cents an hour. The essential strategy of the global corporation is division of labor, and the drive to maximize global profits by combining the capital and technology of rich countries with the cheap labor or poor ones has been irresistible.

title: CARE FISHER DIES BROADWAY FIGURI
description: Carl Fisher, general managee of many Broadway hit shows, died yesterday at his home in Redding, Conn., at the age of 65.

title: Janice Sloan Fiancee Of Steven Jay Mann
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morton Sloan of East, Meadow, L.L., of the engagement of their daughter, Janice Meryl Sloan, to Steven Jay Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Mann, also of East Meadow.

title: Christmas in Turkey: A Visit to St. Nicholas
description: 'T WAS the night before Christmas, and rather than wait for St. Nicholas to visit us, my husband, son and I were visiting him insteadin a warm, dusty town called Demre on Turkey's southern shore.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LOTTERY NUMBER Dec. 21, 1974

title: STAMPS
description: The stamps for Christmas this year are more traditional than in recent years, with few innovative touches, but from all over the world they. express good will and good spirit to man.

title: Helping the People Hurt The Most by Hard Times
description: Executive Director, New York Catholic Charities

title: Bay State Golf Dates Set
description: BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The Massachusetts Golf Association announced today that the State open would be held June 23 through 25 at the Charles River Country Club, and the State amateur July 9 through 12 at the Winchester Country Club.

title: SIBERIAN GAS DEAL OPPOSED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) A Senate Foreign Relations Committee report said today that it would not be in the best interests of the United States to participate in development of naturalgas fleids in Siberia.

title: Maverick Radio Station Makes Waves  and Money
description: PITTSFIELD, MASS. Can a young radio station in a small, conservative city make money advocating the legalization of marijuana? Will merchants advertise on a station that repeatedly pokes fun at free enterprise and big business? Is there a broadcast audience for hard rock and other progressive music in a community where the city fathers discourage live music in its bars and taverns? The answer to these and similarly loaded questions is in the affirmative. Three years ago in this city of 55,000, dominated by General Electric (the local plant employs more than half of the city's working population) and a mill that manufactures the country's currency paper, a man named Jerry Graham obtained the license for a 1,000 watt, daylighthoursonly AM station with the call letters WGRG. He recruited a youthful and youthoriented staff to run it and began transmitting very hip music, community  service programs and leftward slanted newscasts and editorials.

title: What Makes Off Off Broadway Off Off?
description: Ten years ago, Off Off Broadway, the outer reaches of New York theater, consisted of a handful of downtown cafes and coffee houses that encouraged script and poetry readings almost indiscriminately. Ignored by the regular theater community, Off Off Broadway offered shoestring productions of unknown writers and was resolutely avantgarde. In violating almost every tenet of traditional theater, it seemed to take pleasure in shocking stray visitors from uptown. It also seemed resigned to its marginal existence, a fringe theater located vaguely in the dangerous East Village. But in the last half decade Off Off Broadway has exploded, and today it is a theater of very large ambitions indeed. At the latest count there were some 150 groups that fit into the general, illdefined category. The oldest is Ellen Stewart's La Mama, started in 1960, and a new one popi up almost every week.

title: Book Ends
description: Upwardly Mobile. A new member of the top 10 this week is Hefter Skelter by Vincent Bugliosi with Curt Gentry, which has sold 65,000 copies thus far, Norton says. It's a BookoftheMonth Club selection, and it's also about a sensational murder case  the TateLaBianca mass killings for which Charles Manson and some of his family were convicted. We talked with coauthor Bugliosi, the Los Angeles D.A. who prosecuted the case (he's now in private practice and finishing up another book), and he spoke of it as volubly as if it happened only yesterday. Although he had successfully prosecuted 14 other murders, it was Mr. Bugliosi's biggest case; but when he first took over, the evidence was so weak that a Los Angeles sheriff's deputy commiser?? with him on being handed a bummer. Mr. Bugliosi did his own investigating, working 100 hours a week, and prepared meticulously, concentrating on his final summation first. The three key elements of proof were motive (Manson's vision of helter skeltera race war triggered by the atrocious murders he ordered), domination (enabling Manson to order family members to out the killings) and the testimony of Linda Kasabian, the only witness to the murders who cooperated with the prosecution. He reminisced about his courtroom ttettes with Manson. We'd rap sarcastically, in off moments, he recalled and Manson once told him that he couldn't care less about his female codefendants on trial with him. I've had girls that made them look like men, he boasted. Mr. Bugliosi characterized Manson variously as evil, a sophisticated con man and, quoting his disciples, a heavy dude. He thought the family members had considerable homicidal rage inside them in order to carry out the murders; others in Manson's menagenotably Linda Kasabianrefused to kill. The Manson case was distinct in the annals of American crime because he importuned others to murder for him and because the victims were faceless, chosen as establishment symbols. Manson was an intelligent man (I.Q. 121), his mind aboil with Nazism, satanism, scientology and emanations from the Beatles' songs. Prison was his only home. When it was all over, he told Mr. Bugliosi, You haven't accomplished anything. You just sent me back to where I came from.

title: Notes: Bethlehem Appeals for Funds
description: THE Mayor of Bethlehem, Elias Freij, a Christian Arab who is a member of the Greek Orthodox Church, was in New York last week after completing a fundraising tour of the United States; he wants to beautify the city's Manger Square.

title: Christmas in a landmark village
description: In the early 19th century, when the whaling industry was at its peak, the village of Sag Harbor, a fanshaped square mile with a deep, wellprotected harbor on Peconic Bay, L.I., outranked the port of New York in importance. Today Sag Harbor's narrow lanes are tightly packed with architectural treasurestiny, onestory cottages and twostoried Federal and Georgian townhouses. At Christmas the village, which has been designated as a historic district, reaches a kind of perfection. Its doorways are decked with wreaths of local holly, pine cones and shells. Six of the town's houses will be on view during a house tour on Dec. 28 to benefit the Sag Harbor Historical Association.

title: Susan Heyniger to Marry in May
description: Susan Heyniger, a junior at the Parsons School of Design, and Mohammad Hussein, a senior, plan to marry in May. Both are majoring in architecture.

title: Vikings' Two Wrights Make Cards Go Wrong
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 21  As Nate Wright, Minnesota's cornerback, ran past the St. Louis bench in pregame warmups today, he stopped to Chat briefly with an old friend.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time

title: Israel and India: LongUnhealed Rift
description: BOMBAY, IndiaIn Israeli diplomatic circles, Bombay is called the loneliest post in the world.

title: Local Control Is Issue in SportsComplex Plans
description: Some basic skepticism toward public authoritieseven one that comes offering the chance for fun and games has created early hurdles for enthusiasts of proposed new sports complexes in Brooklyn and Suffolk.

title: What New York Needs Is a New Football Stadium
description: Startling developments this past week will put four professional sports teams into a stadium built for just one.

title: CANADA DEBATING THE QUEEN'S ROLE
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 21Should Queen Elizabeth II, as Canada's head of state, be invited to open the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal?

title: Forego Forgoes Little at the Track
description: Horse Racing

title: Economies of the Nations Can't Absorb More People
description: PARISOn the elegant Avenue Victor Hugo three black street sweepers are leaning, on their twig brooms in front of a shop displaying expensive sound equipment. They are discussing the relative merits of Grundig versus Sony tape recorders. Because they earn 75 cents an hour, the products in the Window are well out of reach.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: Ted Bates & Co., the advertising agency, has subleased a total of 63,000 square feet of office space at One Astor Plaza. The space was taken by three tenants for approximately 10 years at an aggregate rent of about $6million.

title: The trouble is you can go home again
description: The draft had become a canker of preoccupation for Brian since nineteen sixtyfour; it had become a part of him, something his flesh had enveloped. Its presence would be sharply felt only for a moment; daily it was dull cradled pain. In sixtyfour he had written a letter to his draft board refusing to be inducted; it was never sent.

title: To the women in the audience, Liv Ullmann is the woman they would be: to the men, all the women they would like to know
description: Autumn in London was chill and drenched, just as the summer had been, and as usual the airport was strikebound. Outside the icy rain, inside steam and sweat and frustration. According to the reports, the weather in Oslo was even worse.

title: Trifecta Pays $34,039
description: MIAMI, Dec. 21 (AP)One $2 ticket paid $34,039.80 in the 10.9.6 trifecta at Calder yesterday  the second largest $2 payoff in Florida racing history. The record was set Nov. 29 at Calder when a trifecta paid $38,495.40.

title: CORRECTION
description: In last Sunday's article on Associated Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Newark and its acceptance of applications for adoptions, the explanation for Msgr. Edward McHugh's opposition to the New Jersey law on adoptions was inadvertently omitted. The following statement clarifies Monsignor McHugh's stand: There are loopholes in the law through which dogooders and others are acting as intermediaries between the natural mother and a childless couple in are ranging private adoptions, which are in violation of our adoption law.

title: Shah Bids Americans Push For Big Contracts in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi challenged American businessmen today to become more aggressive and dynamic in competing for Iranian development contracts worth billions of dollars.

title: A scandale in Bordeaux has besmirched the reputation of winetasters. But the winetasting art is no myth: it is a joy.
description: PARIS.The crowd which packed Bordeaux's largest courtroom couldn't believe its ears. A Kamikaze defersel one spectator exclaimed. A suicidal defense it certainly was. Fratricidal, too.

title: Sad Season for LaidOff City Workers
description: A Christmas of austerity and a New Year of uncertainty were the disquieting prospects this weekend of 436 city employes who have lost their jobs under Mayor Beame's edicts to trim the deficitridden municipal budget.

title: TV VIEW
description: Thank Ormazd for WSNLTV on Long Island. (Ormazd, you will recall, was the Big Bopper of Zoroastrianism. According to the Zoroastrians, this world needs a surplus of good deeds over bad deeds if we're ever going to get a hammerlock on Evil.) Everybody bitches about TV criticism, but only WSNL has done something about it. WSNLchannel 67, New Islipis suing Newsday TV columnist Marvin Kitman for $15million in damages.

title: Soviet Reports U.S. Trade Action, but Notes Curbs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21  The Soviet Union reported with a hint of dissatisfaction today the adoption by the United States Congress yesterday of trade legislation extending credit terms and lower import tariffs to the Soviet Union.

title: HIGHWAY ON L.I. TO RAISE TOLLS
description: BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 21The toll rate on the Southern State Parkway will be increased from 10 cents to 25 cents on Jan. 1, the first increase since the toll was established in 1954.

title: Those Flickering Profits
description: Harvey Cooper, president of the Gem Electric Company of Hauppauge, L.I., will long remember Nov. 28, 1973. That's the day President Nixon suggested that Christmas lighting be sharply curtailed to conserve energy. Lights were dimmed, and so were profits in the $200millionayear Christmas lighting industryof which Mr. Cooper's company is a part.

title: Ford Asks Democrats For Ideas on Message
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  President Ford has written the top Democratic leaders of Congress soliciting their suggestions for his January State of the Union Mesage.

description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y.Vuko Tashkovich is doing well.

description: Representatives of 35 highrise apartment buildings and townhouses on the East Side voted last week to oppose the opening of any new offices of the Offtrack Betting Corporation in a section extending from 59th to 96th Street and from Fifth Avenue to the East River.

title: Acrostic puzzle
Transfers Flock to Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICKThe fiscal problems facing all state institutions of higher learning this year are compounded at Rutgers College, where there has been a sharp rise, in transfer and readmittance applications.

title: Home Handymen: Give Your Old Furniture a New Lease on Life
description: A batteredlooking piece of old furniture that is still structurally sound can almost Okays be given a new lease on life by restoring the old finish to give it a fresh look. In some cases this may mean merely touching up a few scratches or other blemishes: then polishing; in others it may mean stripping the original finish off completely and then applying a new finish. Either way; the task is one that can almost always be; handled by any home handyman or handywoman who is willing to devote the needed time and effort to the job.

title: Friday's Fight
description: BostonTony Petronelli, 139 pounds, Bridgewater, Mass., knocked out Johnny Copeland, 138, Joplin, Mo., 6 rounds.
