title: NoDance Champion
description: After more than seven years of exile and exasperation, Muhammad Ali regained the world heavyweight boxing championship with a spectacular victory in a spectacular setting for a spectacular sum. Before nearly 60,000 spectators in Kinshasa, Zaire, and a worldwide television audience, Ali registered an eighthround knockout of George Foreman in a bout that began at 4 o'clock in the morning October 30 there in order that it would be available in the United States at 10 P.M. October 29. Each received $5million.

title: Decentralization Also Spread Scandals Around
description: The 12story brick and stone building at 110 Livingston St. in Brooklyn that is headquarters for the New York City Board of Education has a fortresslike appearance. Lately though, as one financial scandal after another has exploded in the school system, even the sturdy structure has been unable to protect the sevenmember board and its administrative staff from bombardment.

title: The Nation
description: School busing has come to Boston with greater conflict than elsewhere since the struggle for desegregation moved North; the Boston School Committee is now in open defiance of Federal judge. The reason may be that Boston's ethnic minorities are packed more tightly into a smaller area than in any other of the nation's 25 largest cities.

title: GOLDIN ATTEMPTSTO CUT DISMISSALS
description: Responding to Mayor Beame's demand for layoffs of personnel, City Controller Harrison J. Goldin is preparing budget cuts that would avoid some dish missals by having his office move out of its rented space in private buildings, a spokesman for Mr. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Park Service Head Appears After Panel Issues Subpoena
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The head of the National Park Service says a misunderstanding caused him to miss Congressional hearing at which he was to have been the leadoff witness.

title: Counseling Families In Trouble
description: As social conditions have changed since the Staten Island Family Service was founded in 1919, so have the methods by which the nonsectarian agency helps troubled families.

title: Avalanche Hits Iceland Town
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 21 (AP)The worst avalanche in Iceland for more than a halfcentury has left nine persons dead and three missing in a fishing town on the country's east coast, officials here said today.

title: Green Gambados Wins Roamer by a Neck Over Jolly Johu and Pays $6.40 at Aqueduct
description: Harbor View Farm's Green Gambados, winner of a division of the Discovery Handicap two weeks ago, gained his third victory in a row at Aqueduct yesterday by defeating Jolly Johu in the $56.000 Roamer Handicap.

title: Germans Agonize Over Stand on Israel in a New Mideast War
description: BONN, Dec. 21A major preoccupation here both in the Government and among ordinary citizens in recent weeks has been the attitude West Germany would take toward Israel in the event of a new Middle East war.

title: HUGE C.I.A. OPERATION REPORTED IN U.S. AGAINST ANTIWAR FORCES, OTHER DISSIDENTS IN NIXON YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Central Intelligence Agency, directly violating its charter, conducted a massive, illegal domestic intelligence operation during the Nixon Administration against the antiwar movement and other dissident groups in the United States, according to wellplaced Government sources.

title: Collect a Great MansionIn Porcelain
description: Collectors of limited editions can now satisfy their seemingly insatiable appetites for objects and, in the process, help raise money to save one of the nation's historic mansions.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: College football attendance suffered its first national drop in 21 years, National Collegiate Sports Services announced yesterday. The decline, the first since 1953, was less than twotenths of 1 per cent and amounted to a total of 47,685 spectators nationwide.

title: Woman Will Head Environmental Group
description: EAST HAMPTON  Orga nized local environmental groups have now become an accepted part of the American scene. An so has equali ty for women. Combining the two trends, the Group for America's South Fork, Inc., has just appointed Nancy K. goell as its fulltime paid director.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Establishing a new Reconstruction Finance Corporation, proposed by Felix G. Rohatyn (A New R.F.C. is Proposed for Business Dec. 1) would be wrong. It would be an attempt to partially sore or alleviate some of our current financial problems by applying a Depression tactic of the 1930's. Unfortunately, the proponents of the new R.F.C. tend to forget that much has changed since the 1930's and the challenges facing us now are considerably different both financially and economically.

title: Crowds and TV Ratings Drop And New League Almost Does
description: What counted the most in pro football this year took place on picket lines and in cashier's cages rather than on the playing fields.

title: Celtics Win, 10991
description: The Boston Celtics made a strategic move last night. They pitted Don Chaney against Earl Monroe and it was a key factor in the Celtics' 10991 victory over the Knicks before a sellout crowd of 19,694 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Eric Weinmann, Mary Carothers Have Nuptials
description: Mary de Limur Carothers and Eric Weinman, both of Washington, were married in Christ Episcopal Church Georgetown, there yesterday. Only members of the immediate families of the couple attended the noon ceremony performed by the Rev. John Anschutz in the Chapel of St. Jude. The chapel was given by the bride's family in memory of her mother, the late Ethel Crocker de Limur.

title: Music in Review
description: The Symphony of the New World introduced the winners of its 1974 Young People's auditions last Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, and they gave good accounts of themselves.

title: The Old Celtics and Those Young Nets
description: John Havlicek walked around the Boston Celtic dressing room, champagne dripping from his hair, hugging and telling his teammates, Thanks for doing this for me. It was Havlicek's way of celebrating the Celtics' 12th National Basketball Association championship in 18 seasons, the Basketball first since Bill Russell retired in 1969. Boston defeated the Bucks and Kareem AbdulJabbar, 10287, in Milwaukee in the seventh game of their fourofsevengame series.

description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless other wise indicated:

title: Beth Solomon Fiancee Of David Lloyd Perkins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Solomon of Woodmere, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Solomon, to David Lloyd Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Lawrence Perkins of Westbury, L. I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Ford Gets Options to Improve Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. (UPI)President Ford summoned his top economic advisers to the White House today to receive final recommendations for new attack on inialtion and recession. A limited tax cut was said to be under consideration.

title: SubwayL.I.R.R. Link Urged
description: Why not operate subway trains on Long Island Rail Road tracks to provide a new super subway service and abandon construction of costly new subway lines paralleling the railroad in Queens?

description: Museums in Lincroft, Morristown, Newark, Montclair and Trenton are welcoming the Christmas season with a variety of exhibitions and entertainment for children and adults.

title: Endpaper Edited By Glenn Collins
description: Roaches are very friendly. You can always count on them being there. You never have to eat alone because they will walk right up to you, as if to say, move over and let's eat together. Even when you turn on the kitchen light in the middle of the night, they are there to welcome you Roaches are lovable, and cute

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 (AP)  A Lebanese military court today sentenced a Frenchman, Francois Ronget, to death on charges of aiding Israeli commandos who killed three Palestinian guerrilla leaders in a raid on Beirut last year.

title: Duran Stops Foe in First, Keeps Title
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 21 (AP)Roberto Duran of Panama retained the World Boxing Association lightweight championship tonight by knocking out Masataka Takayama of Japan in the first round of a scheduled 15round bout.

title: Prison Teacher Suspended in State Study of K.K.K.
description: Several months of investigation into possible Ku Klux Klan activities inside state prisons brought on the suspension late last Friday of a teacher at the Eastern New York Correctional Facility, a mediumsecurity prison in upstate Napanoch, near Syracuse, according to the State Department of Correctional Services.

title: INVESTING
description: Even in a down market there are stocks that move against the tide. Investors, observing this, often wonder if there is a way to predict such behavior.

title: Epilogue A Glance Back at Some Major Stories
description: IN There Is Always Beer

title: Les Levine, From Chewing Gum to Chou EnLai
description: For eight years, Les Levine has been a prominent gadfly of New York avantgarde art. His has been a role more or less inherited from Andy Warhol, whose creative energies waned abruptly at about the time his reputation peaked. But it is a role that Levine has had to play in increasingly lean times, as the pleasureloving art scene of the middle sixties has disappeared under waves of Vietnam politics, cultural breakup and now economic recession.

title: Ellen D. Reeder, C. T. Williams 3d To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Howard Reeder of Baltimore of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Dryden Reeder, to Charles Turner Williams 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Turner Williams Jr., also of Baltimore.

title: FUND FINDS MANY DENIED SCHOOLING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The nation's public schools have pushed out or systematically excluded more than two million children who should be enrolled in classes, a report published by the Children's Defense Fund charged today.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: This week New York will see the openings, within a few days and a few blocks of one another, of engagements by the world's two preeminent male dancers. Mikhail Baryshnikov will be appearing at the City Center during the American Ballet Theater's Dec. 23Feb. 6 season. Rudolf Nureyev opens a fiveweek engagement at the Uris Theater on Dec. 26. Whether or not either dancer wills it, the New York appearances of these two former stars of the Kirov Ballet invite comparisons.

title: L.I. CHURCH STARTS SAVEAHOME PLAN
description: The Rev. John G. Carew, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Ronkonkoma, L.I., has started a Save Home Fund designed to help inflation  trapped parishioners who face foreclosure on their mortgages.

title: Blair, a Black, Endures Scorn From Players, Then Retaliates
description: It would be nice to write about Pete Blair solely as a hockey player. He's a good onequick, smart with the puck, a clever skater perfectly suited to collegiate hockey. He scored 38 points last year as a sophomore at St. Lawrence and probably is the best player on the team. But Pete Blair is different. He is a black college hockey player, the only one in the, United States. Like many American collegiate players, Blair is Canadian. He was born in Woodstock, Ontario, 100 miles south of Toronto, the youngest of 10 children.

title: ExHospital Head Gets 25Year Term In $525,000Theft
description: MIAMI, Dec. 21Sanford K. Bronstein, former president of the federally financed and now bankrupt Cedars of Lebanon Hospital, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison for stealing $525,000 of the hospitals funds.

title: Dragoslav Protitch Dies at 72; U.N. Under Secretary 15 Years
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21Dragoslav Protitch, United Nations under secretary for 15 years until his retirement in 1969, died today at Huggins Hospital in Wolfboro, N. H. The diplomat, who lived in Wolfboro, was 72 years old.

title: Giscard: A Sense of Style
description: PARISIt should not be surprising to this elegant nation that its new President, Valry Giscard d'Estaing, should have brought with him to France's highest office a conscious and Intellectualized sense of style. For Giscard, as he is generally known, style is not only an expression of artistic grace but part of the technique ofgoverning.

title: Neighbors Give To Reimburse 11 Robbed in Harlem
description: Harlem residents, outraged by a recent holdup of 11 women employes at Hale House, a home for the children of drugaddicted mothers, have started a communitywide effort to replace $1,580, taken by three gunmen.

title: JUDGE WEIGHING LAW ON NIXON DOCUMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) A Federal judge says he is preparing to rule whether former President Richard M. Nixon is the legal owner of his official papers and tape recordings.

title: Fashion
description: Christmas is a time for families to reflect upon their strengths. In the adopted family of Mr. and Mrs. David Anderson, Mary, 7, Michael, 6, Sarah, 5, and Thomas, 1 find that there is strength in diversity, unity in difference.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Governor Byrne is still in trouble with New Jersey's Democratic county chairmen, and leading party officials here believe that the Governor's relations with the chairmen probably will get worse before they get any better.

title: Udall's Brother Takes Over As '76 Campaign Manager
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Stewart Udall, former Secretary of the Interior, has taken fulltime management of the Presidential campaign for 1976 of his brother, Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona.

title: Faraday Nye Burditt Is Married
description: Faraday Nye Burditt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederic Burditt of Bedford, N.Y., was married last evening to Manuel de la Cmara Hermoso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel de la Cmara Alvarez of Madrid. The Rev. Richard Mayberry performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco. N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. Joseph Faraone, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: And the War Toys Are Rolling Along
description: Bang. Boom. Bam. War toys, which have been keeping a low profile during the last five holiday seasons, mainly due to the Vietnam War and its aftermath, are making a comeback this season.

title: Christmas Cookies From Old Country
description: LOCUST VALLEY When Heidi Hostettler arrived here from North Carolina last week she had in her baggage six pounds of nutmeats. In her head were an assortment of recipes for Christmas cookies.

title: World's Greatest Jazz Band (Not Quite Yet) Still Adjusting
description: It is now six years since Bob Haggart and Yank Lawson began their presumptuously named 10piece jazz group, the World's Greatest Jazz Band. The band has since lived down much of its name. In the process, it has provided a launching pad for its youngest member, Bob Wilber, now 46 years old, who has finally emerged from the murky swamps of traditional jazz, to which he apparently had been consigned because of his overenthusiasm for Dixieland. He has become an outstanding and individualistic soprano saxophonist.

title: CasoPurcell Rift Strains Party Unity
description: MINEOLAWhen Francis T, Purcell, the Republican Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead and vice chairman of the G.O.P.controlled Board of Supervisors, recently discussed the county budget proposed by Ralph G. Caso, the Republican County Executive, his remarks indicated a crack in what hitherto had always appeared to be a solid Republican front.

title: Miss Stephens To Be a Bride
description: Carroll Underwood Stephens and Bruce Neal Vinik, seniors at Duke University, plan to be married June 1. Their engagement has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Wade Carroll Stephens of Lawrenceville, N. J., parents of the bridetobe whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vinik of New York.

title: HSIEN HSIEN CHOW
description: Hsien Hsien Chow, executive vice president of the Chunghua Trade and Development Corporation here, died on Tuesday. He was 69 years old and lived at 4125 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

The bride is the lawyer for the Day Care Consultation Seryice of Bank Street College of Education. Her husband is a lawyer with Financial Corporation. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

description: Englewood Cliffs, N. J., has $246,000 in assessed property value for every school chia As a result, with a tax rate of only 99 cents per $100 of property value the town is able to spend $2,000 a year educating every student. In Camden, N. J., there is only $18,000 of property value behind each child. Even with a tax rate of $1.94 and generous amounts of state aid, its schools can spend only $1,000 per pupil.

description: Twentyfive centuries ago, a deformed slave named Aesop concluded a fable with a sentence that pretty well tells the story of the sports year of 1974: Thinking to get at once all the gold the goose could give, he killed it and opened it only to findnothing.

description: NAPLES, Italy  The carrier Saratoga has been lying immobile here these days, prevented from venturing east of Italy as are other ships of the United States Sixth Fleet.

Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

description: Letters: On Mohonk And the Concord

title: U.C.L.A Is Just Good Not Great
description: The Walton Gang ran out of ammunition last winter. For the first time in eight seasons, a University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team watched a national championship final instead of winning it. Holes were punched into. the U.C.L.A. mystique long before David Thompson and North Carolina State defeated Marquette, 76.64, in the National Collegiate final in Greensboro, N. C. Notre Dame had ended the Bruins' 88game winning streak with a 7170 victory three years after the streak began. U.C.L.A. also spent a lost weekend in Oregon, where for the first time since 1966 the Bruins lost consecutive games.

title: INTENDED VICTIMS FOIL 2 ROBBERIES
description: A Washington Heights grocer who had been robbed eight times and a Bronx apartment superintendent turned the tables on wouldbe robbers over the weekend, killing one and seriously wounding another in separate incidents.

Beckwith of Abington, Pa., was married to Dr. Carl C. Hoyler of Princeton. The Rev. Mac C. Wells, associate minister, performed the ceremony.

title: State Quandary: New Revenues
description: WASHINGTON Although New Jersey ranks among the top twelve states in state tax revenues, It has to depend more heavily on sales and grossreceipt levies than just about every other state in the group. The only exceptions are Florida and Texas.

description: The Among Company is best known for performances of choreography by Carolyn Brown. Yet the members of this relatively new allwomen troupe have also occasionally presented their own work. Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio in Westbeth, the group showed five pieces by two of its dancers  Ann Darby and Joyce Morgenroth.

description: The following article and the letter below were written in response to a recent lecture by Profeisor John Kenneth Galbraith, excerpts of which were published in this section (The Economics of the Current Anxiety, Dec. 8). He discussed the malaise in the nation, and called inflation the parent of many other problems.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Just in case you don't trust your own laughter, I can suggest two ways of checking on whether or not Neil Simon's new comedy, God's Favorite, is working properly. Before digging in, though, I suppose we'd better dispose of the Number One, or Fussbudget, question: who says the Book of Job is funny?

title: ArabicGeorgian Dictionary
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (UPI)After seven years of work, philologists have completed a l0volume ArabicGeorgian dictionatry containing 200,000 entries, Tass, the Soviet press agency, has reported. The dictionary was compiled by the Institute of Oriental Studies of the Academy of Sciences in the Georgian Soviet Republic.

title: Mrs. Chesman Has Son
description: A son was born Nov. 25 to Mr. and Mrs. Michael Chesman of Washington at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. The child has been named Matthew Baum. Mr. Chesman, a lawyer, is with the office of the chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Those Legendary Ladies Speak Again
description: The Great Ladies of the Theater, legendary actresses whose personalities lit up the stages of the world's playhouses over the last century, are a vanishing breed. We still have our stars, but few of them inspire brilliant playwrights to create vehicles and even fewer would presume to shatter the dramatic illusion of a first entrance by stepping beyond the proscenium to acknowledge the thunderous applause of their admirers  as often as not, there isn't even a proscenium these days to step beyond! To be sure, some of the presence of these redoubtable women of yore is contained between the covers of books and, in some instances, on crumbling celluloid. But what about those charismatic voices that set the pulses of past audiences racing?

title: Kelbasy Is a Polish Christmas Must
description: LINDENThe celebration of Christmas also means a time for feasting, and PolishAmericans are no exception. For weeks now, they have been flocking to stores such as Matt's Meat Market, which like a number of others throughout the state, specializes in the meat products and imported  from  Poland grocery items necessary to set a bona fide Polish holiday table.

title: Russians Tell How to Foil Psychiatrists
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21Two imprisoned Soviet dissidents have prepared a survival guide for fellow dissidents to help them face psychiatric examination and possible detention in a mental hospital for their nonconformist attitudes.

title: In the Caribbean: A Family Yuletide, at Sea
description: CHRISTMAS Eve in the Caribbean. Wide awake, I lay in my sleeping bag in the open cockpit of our Cal 230 sailboat. Ned, my young grandson, slept opposite me. In the cabin behind us were his parents, other grownups and three granddaughters. Altogether there were nine of us on the 32foot chartered sloop.

title: Miss Horton Bride Of W. C. Benjamin
description: Karen Kay Horton, a teacher at the Dalton School, was married yesterday afternoon to William Chase Benjamin, lawyer with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton here. The Rev. Marcus Hall performed the ceremony at St. John's in the Mountains Episcopal Church in Stowe, Vt.

title: The TwoFaced Economy
description: There seems to be a growing consensus among economists that a stimulus to the economy to overcome recession should take priority over measures to bring down inflation. Ten leading economists have advised the White House to stimulate, although to differing degrees; so have the Big Four auto makers and the head of the United Automobile Workers; and former Budget Director Charles Schultze has given the same advice to the Senate Budget Committee.

title: The country is full of ideolects
description: Thirty scientific observers of the American religious scene have combined their efforts and the result, amazingly enough, is rich and readable, a guidebook to a colorful country fair of faiths. Along the midway we can sample spiritualist sermons, AfroAmerican rituals, urban witches, black Jehovah's Witnesses (yes, there are many), tongue speaking, Hare Krishnas, scientology (where the occult, psychoanalysis and science fiction meet), Mormons, Pentecostals and many more. Do not be misled by the claim of the writers that they have restricted the study to marginal movements. Such groups are always important as well as interesting. Not only do marginals give clues about future developments in religion, they also help us see where the whole society be heading.

title: America's Favorite Christmas Trees
description: Almost every American family buys a Christmas tree. Neighborhood vacant lots suddenly become small forests of cut evergreens and mother, dad and children will decide which tree they will choose to take home and trim.

title: Nets Lift Streak To 10
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 21The New York Nets survived the secondhalf absence of Julius Erving and a 6point Indiana Pacer lead in the fourth quarter tonight to post their 10th consecutive American Basketball Association victory, 134122. It set a club. record.

title: Muralist's Subject: North Pole
description: A series of window murals, depicting themes ranging from elves and Santas to quieter winter scenes, are adorning windows of stores at the junction of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday (Europeans Get Queries) Fritz Haueter, a gold specialist for the Swiss Bank Corporation, was incorrectly identified as being with the Swiss Credit Bank, and the corporation's three American branches were likewise incorrectly attributed.

title: ART VIEW
description: The Impressionist Epoch, which now fills 12 handsomely appointed galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is something new in the way of a major art exhibition. Although mounted as an anniversary celebration of the first of the Independent shows organized by the Impressionist painters in Paris 100 years ago, this exhibition is not primarily concerned to elucidate the Impressionist esthetic. It is certainly not a carefully selected anthology of Impressionist masterpieces. It contains a great many remarkable pictures, but quite a few of them are not really Impressionist pictures, and the primary emphasis of the exhibition is, in any case, on the epoch rather than on the art. And the epoch is conceived in terms of social historyin terms of rivalry and power, of manners and taste, of contending traditions and cultural combat. The old conviction that a painting has the power to speak for itselfthat, in other words, a museum is something different from a classroomis all but abandoned.

title: Resort Opens 100 Campsites. For EconomyMinded Guests
description: NEW ASHFORD, Mass., Dec. 18  Well aware that America's economy is receding and that skiing can be expensive, Jim Kelly, Brodie Mountain's enterprising operator, is trying to make overnight outings more attractive for the dollar conscious skier.

title: Kissinger Meets Waldheim and Bouteflika at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21  Secretary of State Kissinger spent two and a half hours with the Secretary General and the president of the General Assembly here today discussing a range of world issues and reviewing the Assembly session that ended this week.

title: Kate Haggerty Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Luther V. Haggerty of Fairmount, Tewksbury Township, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kate Graf Haggerty, to William Donald McEachern, son of Dr. and Mrs. George C. McEachern of Forest Hills, Queens. Miss Haggerty, an alumna of the Gill School, attended Skidmore College. She is a sudent at the Katharine Gibbs School here. Her fianc graduated from Lawrenceville School and Duke University. He attends the Fordham Law School.

title: White Exodus From the City Quickens
description: The pace of the outmigration of whites and families??om New York City quickened??on 1970 to 1973, producing a social fabric here of more elderly residents, fewer children under age 14, and a predominance of younger and poorer Hispanic and nonwhite families, according to a new study of Federal population statistics.

title: Nureyev: I Never Try To Compete
description: Given the timing of their New York appearances, it might seem that Nureyev is purposely pitting himself against Baryshnikov, engaging in a contest in which one or the other will emerge the artistic victor. But this encounter is pure coincidence. Nureyev's Broadway engagement was contracted last May, at a time when Baryshnikov had not yet defected to the West. What is more, Nureyev's experiment in performing with his own company had already met with great success in Europefirst, in Copenhagen, and last summer, at the Palais des Sports, in Paris. A New York engagement seemed the logical next step.

title: SPANISH IN DOUBT ON POLITICS LAW
description: MADRID, Dec. 21The Spanish Cabinet last night issued a decree on freedom to form political associations and the Minister of Information, Leon Herrera Esteban, termed be law an important step for the future of our fatherland and for the future of the Spanish people.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Paper recycling has become a victim of the recession. A number of dealers who used to buy those newspapers you stacked in the cellar don't want them any more.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have just moved into a house with a large but old bathroom that has dull finish ceramic tiles on the floor. These floor tiles are unevenly worn and dull in some areas. I have tried waxing but the wax spots floor, yet leaving it unwaxed seems to cause it to get dirty faster is titre some finish that will seal the tile and leave a soft sheen? M.M.S., Philadelphia, Pa.

title: Radical Changes Are Planned at Christian Science Monitor
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19The Christian Science Monitor, one of the world's most prestigious daily newspapers, is getting ready to undergo some startling changes, largely but not entirely due to the economics of newspaper publishing.

title: Dance: Louis Company
description: Our dance institutionseven our younger dance institutionsare becoming venerable! Nowadays dance is not merely established in the United States, it is long established. These intimations of hardening of the arteries were prompted by the opening of a season on Friday night by the. Murray Louis Dance Company at the New York University Theater.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Time May Be Catching Up With Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaThe whites of Rhodesia still walk along Salisbury avenues named for the great African empire builders, Stanley, Baker, Speke, Rhodes. An evening television show carries a commercial that advertises a benefit variety show for the families of men killed fighting black terrorists.

title: Dear Santa Letters Receive Loving Answers in Plainfield
description: PLAINFIELDEvery year, countless youngsters write letters to Santa Claus. Some, moved by the magic of the season, do it on their own. Others are encouraged by doting relatives. And still more list their requests as a result of classroom projects.

title: French Bettors Are Undeterred As Racing Scandal Is Disclosed
description: PARIS, Dec. 21It's called the tierc, and as an in institution it nearly replaces Sunday morning mass in France.

title: Young Voices Lift Holiday Spirits
description: FARMINGDALEFor the St. Kilian Boychoir here, Christmas is the best and busiest time of the year. It is the time that the boys have waited and worked for all year to bring cheer and warmth to thousands through their concerts on Long Island and in the metropolitan area.

title: Nature and Church
description: With today both the time of the winter solstice and the beginning of Christmas week, nature and the Christian church are in unmistakable harmony. This is the time when man, from far back in the misty past, has celebrated the birth of a new year, new life for the sun which had seemed about to plunge into the abyss. And this is the time the church chose to celebrate the birth of Jesus in the stable of the inn at Bethlehem.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: Jerry Herman has sometimes been accused of rewriting his Hello, Dolly! score in every subsequent show he has composed. If there have been similaritiesand there is certainly a common stylistic thread that runs through the title songs of Hello, Dolly!, Mame and Dear Worldthis repetition has not been to Herman's benefitas can be heard in the three successive scores' descending order of merit, Once having done something well, it is not as easy as one might think to create a close variation that is just as good. Comparisons become. all too odious.

title: Linda Castiglia Bride of S. C. Danford
description: Linda Roesanne Castiglia, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter C. Castiglia of Clifton, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Stephen Charles Danford, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Danford of Racine, Wis.

title: Bill Cobham Leads His JazzRock Band At the Bottom Line
description: Billy Cobham, the jaizrock drummer, and his excellent, band opened at the Bottom Line Saturday night, where they will be holding forth through Thursday (the club is closed Tuesday).

title: Lakewood Hotels Struggling
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J.Many towns believerightly or wronglythat they have been letter days. But in this modest community 10 miles inland from the Jersey Shore there is no doubt that the old days were better. They were, in fact, glorious.

title: MARTIN J. LIST
description: Martin J. List, a Brooklyn lawyer for nearly 50 years, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived at 45 Tennis Court, Brooklyn.

title: This Week in Sports
description: College Basketball

title: No. 1 Team Is Someone or Other
description: Archie Griffin of Ohio State was the overwhelming choice for the Heisman Trophy as college football's best player in 1974. Central College of Iowa won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III championship and Central Michigan won the N.C.A.A.'s Division II title. These were about the only definitive results of a season with many unanswered questions. The most important of these may be: Will intercollegiate football survive inflation and recession?

title: Dockers Light Up Piers for Holiday With Creches
description: The holiday season on the waterfront, with its many and varied manifestations, started last Monday for some 13,500 longshoremen who lined up at union headquarters to pick up special checks. To the average longshoreman the check is his Christmas bonus. Although he has been receiving it annually since 1960, this year's check was even more welcome because it was the biggest ever$666.67 a man.

title: Nigerians Awaiting a PayRise Decision
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 21Nigerian wageearners are eagerly awaiting their Government's verdict on proposals that may bring pay increases and the establislunent of a minimum wage.

title: Where It All Began
description: BERKELEY, Calif.Ten years ago during Big Game week at the University of California in Berkeley the pregame rally on the plaza in front of Sproul Hall came facetoface with a rally of the newly born Free Speech Movement.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: HILTON ACQUITTED IN POLICE BATTLE
description: Fred Hilton, who the police say was a member of the Black Liberation Army, has been acquitted in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on charges that he tried to kill two police officers by machine gun during a shootout in March 1973.

title: A Specialist Flourishes As M.B.R. Plan Falters
description: A new but possibly shortlived industry has been spawned by the city's Maximum Base Rent program for rentcontrolled housing.

title: Common Market Upbeat
description: As Dr. Johnson once said of a dog walking on its hind legs, the surprising thing about the unity of the nine old nation states of Europe's Common Market is not how well they toddle along together but that they do it at all. The recent summit conference in Paris should help the Nine do it better. Only two or three years ago, almost any of the measures now adopted would have been treated as a spectacular step forward. And if they work out as planned, these new procedural decisions could mark a constitutional watershed for the European Community.

title: SharpEyed Regulators Reign in Toyland
description: Santa's bag of toys has always been big. Now it is regulated, too.

title: The Historic 93d...
description: As the 93d Congress passes into history, it, commits to the care of its successor a nation vastly different from the one it found when it first convened on Jan. 3, 1973. In those two years, the United States has been transformed by an irresistible sweep of political and economic events. Shaken by constitutional crises and confronted by hitherto unthinkable challenges to the doctrine of unlimited growth and infinite resources, the American people have been brought up sharp against stern new realities. And so has Congress itself.

title: Child to the Van Derens
description: A daughter was born Nov. 2$, to Mr. and Mrs. John F. Van Deren of Barre, Vt., at the Central Vermont Hospital in Berlin. Mrs. Van Deren is the former Lauren Rossi of Barre. Her husband manages Wilson's Country Camera, a store in Montpelier, Vt. The child has been named Jessica Alice.

title: Extensive Abuses Found In CourtHiring Practices
description: The role of political patronage in the appointment of statecourt aides and employes has come under official investigation in connection with the indictments of five law secretaries.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The most Godcentered and otherworldly
description: Although we live in an increasingly secularized agein which even religious leaders often appear more interested in politics, sociology and the things that are Caesar's than in the Kingdom of Godthe Bible, a timeless record of man's search for that kingdom, remains a best seller. Paradoxically (or perhaps predictably) the Biblical book most familiar today, not only to believers but to professed nonbelievers, is the Book of Psalms, the most Godcentered, otherworldly of all. (Probably more people can quote portions of the 23rd Psalm than any other part of the Bible.)

title: In Ancram, N. Y.: A Holiday With a Victorian Air
description: PEOPLE want a nonneon Christmas, says JohnPeter Hayden Jr. Together with his cousin and partner, Donald Richard Chapin, Hayden has for three years been offering people just that  and more  in Ancram, N.Y.

title: Fleeing Convict Killed
description: McNEILL ISLAND, Wash., Dec. Dec. 21 (UPI)  Federal prison guards killed one convict and wounded another as the two ran through a searchlit area outside the main perimeter fence during an escape attempt last night. A prison spokesman, Lieut. Max Russell, said Broadus Mayes, 33 years old, of Beaverton, Ore., was fatally wounded. Listed in satisfactory condition was James William Bruce, 34, of Detroit.

title: Andrea Hintlian Becomes a Bride
description: Andrea Tarvis Hintlian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vahan S. Hintlian of Arlington and Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Gilbert Mendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Mendell of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: BiState Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: Dolphins' Reign Ends on Late Catch, 2826
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21 The Miami Dolphins' dominance of the National Football League ended today. The Oakland Raiders beat the league's twotime defending champions, 2826, with one of those big plays that always becomes so much a part of crucial football games.

title: The Champion Flyers: Good, Violent and a Team
description: A Kaiser Wilhelm helmet, the symbol of Philadelphia Flyer fans in the Dave Schultz Army, might well have symbolized the National Hockey League as it came to grips with violence. For the Flyers stood do top of the ice with Stanley Cup championship, and across North America hundreds of youngsters decided they wanted to grow up to be just like the Flyers. And that meant fighting and stickswinging and learning the art of the wellplaced elbow.

title: The search for a spiritual life in Washington and elsewhere: a country on its knees?
description: Prayer, which William James described us interCourse with an ideal companion, is either the primary fact or the want delusionGLORGE A Birramck, Prayer.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: HoHum Football/Michigan, Notre Dame and Ohio State
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan E. Richards, Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. Richards of Huntington and Westhampton Beach, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Richards, to Timothy Robert Harvey, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Harvey of Buffalo and Thunder Bay, Ontario.

title: Diana Beatty Wed in Britain
description: LONDON, Dec. 21Lady Diana Adrienne Beatty and Henry Nicolas Gage were married in the parish church of Mapledurham in Oxfordshire today.

title: 1974 Pitching Averages In the National League
Nancy Kelsey And John Carty Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kelsey of Gladwyne, Pa., Stone Harbor, N.J., and Montego Bay, Jamaica, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Eaton Kelsey, to John Rendleman Carty, son of Mrs. James B. Carty of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Dr. Carty. The wedding is planned for June 21 in Bryn Mawr.

title: 73 Young Women Presented At Annual Debutante Cotillion
description: Seventythree young women were presented at the 39th annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria last night.

title: Eric Knuffke Weds Betsy A. Salemson
description: Betsy Ann Salomon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Salemson of Glen Cove, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Eric Charles Knuffke.

title: Yule Bird Tally Is Under Way
description: MORRISTOWNIt was on Christmas Day 75 years ago that 26 birders across the nation responded to the call of Frank M. Chapman, editor of the National Audubon Society magazine, to abandon the old tradition of hunting and killing birds and start a new one: counting them.

title: Hawks Rally in 3d
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 21 A former New York Islander, Germain Gagnon, was in the right place at the right time tonight. He was in front of the Islander net during two power plays orchestratedby Stan Mikita to score twice as the Chicago Black Hawks tallied three times in the final period to tie the Islanders, 33. The 14,631 fans in Nassau Coliseum booed their team because of the twogoal lead the Islanders gave up.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: TV VIEW
description: This has not been the year for the Children's Television Workshop. The publictelevision organization, long admired for its successes with Sesame Street and The Electric Company, has proven itself mortal, as susceptible to mediocrity as any hack situation comedy.

title: School 2Mile To Dobrzynski
description: Dave Dobrzynski is a boy from Syracuse who enjoys visiting New York City because of his success in running here last fall. He won just about every time he entered crosscountry races at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Sometimes the Problems Are Almost Beyond Belief
description: For Mrs. R., the situation was devastating. Her youngest son, a 300pound giant at the age of 11, struck an unintentional blow that killed his alcoholically debilitated father and had to be sent to a state hospital; another son suffered psychotic damage from LSD and other hallucinogens; the oldest son needed treatment for addiction to hard drugs.

title: Lunch at Y for the Aged in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRThe man at the piano played Jingle Bells. The waitresses smiled and joked with the customers as they served spaghetti and meatballs, pudding and coffee. And the diners ate and en.

title: How a Tiny Union Made the Coal Industry Take Notice
description: MAN, W. Va., Dec. 19This is a story of David and Goliath. It will tell how a tiny and littleappreciated union that sometimes thinks of itself as an outcast brought the giant coal industry to its knees.

title: Study Due on Newark's Strife
description: NEWARK A psychologist has presented to the city a proposal for managing Newark's wellpublicized community conflicts and for channeling into moreproductive programs the energy spent on confrontation.

title: J.C. Sharts Weds Wendy O'Brien
description: Wendy Ellen O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert F. O'Brien of Short Hills, N. J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Clay Sharts, son of Mrs. Raymond Ellis of Green Village, N. J., and Paul Sharts of Winter Park, Fla. Mayor Thomas Thomas of Millburn, N. J., performed the ceremony at the O'Brien home.

title: Community Plays Santa To Help Injured Boy
description: Four painful months ago, Richard Kobel Jr. ??ay burned and perilously close to death in a Queens hospital. Last week, with recovery assured, he returned to his family to celebrate Christmas with hundreds of new friends.

title: FILM VIEW
description: If Francis Ford Coppola were a less Intelligent and less talented filmmaker, one might indulge the failed aspirations of The Godfather, Part IIif not the thick fog of boredom that settles in before the film is even one hour old. Clumsy directors may not be entitled but because their gaffs are not exactly unexpected, they are more easily accommodated. We snicker and laugh at multimilliondollar dreadfuls like The Valachi Papers and Crazy Joe. Our good spirits remain intact since there's no particular surprise or sorrow. The earnest confusions of The Godfather, Part II are something else again. They look like the solemn attempts to ripoff one of the best, most successful commercial American movies ever made, Coppola's original screen adaptation of Mario Paso's The Godfather.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: How to Build a Duck Blind That Becomes Neat Burlap Bundle When Not in Use
description: A fixed duck blind is undoubtedly superior to one that is portable, if only because it is a more or less a permanent part of the landscape, something that the birds become accustomed to seeing.

title: Executive Flair
description: The executive, or wouldbe executive, is advised on how to behave like one in a recent book by John Weitz, the menswear designer. Following are excerpts:

title: Chris and Jimmy and All That Money
description: The Wedding was postponed, but the Romance overshadowed money and politics as the most talkedabout tennis event of 1974.

title: Ruth Fitch Mason, 84, Dies; Author and Literary Agent
description: Ruth Fitch Mason, author and former literary agent, died Friday at her home in Riverside, Conn. She was 84 years old.

title: Anne Rossbach Is Bride Of E.R. Munch, Architect
description: Anne Rossbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard Rossbach of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Saranac Lake, N.Y., was married in the Bronx yesterday afternoon to Ernest R. Munch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius W. Munch of Freehold, N.J. The ceremony at the Edgehill Church was performed by the Rev. David Denison Cockcroft of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONPresident Ford's seemingly impossible dilemmas in making both economic policy and energy policy decisions in the next few weeks may not be quite so had as they seem.

title: Business Degree in Athletics Offered
description: Even during its days as the most famous basketball team in the United States, St. John's University did not try to recruit athletes from all over the United States because it was essentially a local school.

title: Paul Robeson
description: Mount Paul Robeson majestically stands in the U.S.S.R. just as Germany hosts the Paul Robeson Archives, but until recently it was rare to find an American under 18 who knew who Paul Robeson is. However, within less than a year, several of his old films have been revived, black students at Rutgers named their student center for him, and a three part series on Robeson, sponsored by National Educational Television, won an Emmy.

title: The Year in Sports: Farewell to Heroes
description: To clarify the baseball season: Henry Aaron broke Babe Ruth's record of 714 home runs, then was traded by the Atlanta Braves to the Milwaukee Brewers. Dick Allen led the American League in slugging, then was traded to the Braves by the Chicago White Sox. Willie Davis led the Montreal Expos in total offense, then was traded to the Texas Rangers, Dick Williams, widely regarded as the next manager of the New York Yankees, signed with the California Angels. And Frank Robinson, widely regarded as the next manager of the Angels, was traded to the Cleveland Indians and later signed as theirs.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE TRADE REFORM BILL passed by the House and Senate on Friday, replaces the present Tariff Commission with a new International Trade Commission that will make it easier for domestic industries to make a case for import restrictions, . . The Consumer Price Index rose 0.9 per cent in November to 154.3 (1987=100) and was 12.1 per cent higher than in November, 1973. . . . The nation's basic balanceofpayments deficit widened to $3.6billion in the third quarter from $2.5billion in the second quarter.

title: LETTER
description: To the Editor: In his letter to this section [Dec. 15] Dr. Geoffrey H. Bourne, director of the Yerkes Primate Research Center in Atlanta, accuses me of a variety of misrepresentations in my film Primate, which was filmed at the center. He did not always feel that way. When he first saw the film, Dr. Bourne, according to several people present at the screening, had no strong reaction one way or the other. His current attitude seems to be a response to the reviews rather than to the film. I regret that Dr. Bourne declined to discuss the film and related issues on public TV when offered the opportunity.

title: Best Seller List
description: Based on reports from more than ?? bookstores in 110 communities throughout the United States. Weeks are not necessarily consecutive.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Whatever else may have been on the rise during 1974 in the numismatic hobby, the boom did not include the 1974 U.S. proof set. The Bureau of the Mint reports that 2,595,403 sets were ordered, en appreciable drop from the 2,769,624 sets sold in 1973 and a substantial decline from the totals of 3,267,667 in 1972 and 3,224,138 in 1971. In fact, the 1974 sales figure represents the lowest number of proof sets ordered since 1960.

title: Justice and The Amount Of Bail
description: A judge who had made it his practice to release on low or no bail suspects charged with crimes of violence when he thought the facts of a case warranted it has been reassigned indefinitely. He himself views last week's transfer from Criminal to Civil Court as a banishment, imposed because of his unorthodox policy even though the subsequent acquittal and parole records of those he released seemed to justify his decisions.

title: Gail Stein Married To Robert S. Keiner
description: Gail Ellen Stein of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stein of Pittsfield, Mass., was married yesterday evening to Robert S. Keiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Keiner of Lake Success, L. I.

title: Rams Made Nervous by Redskins
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21George Allen, the Redskins' coach eternally in quest of an edge, tried to keep the Rams guessing as to the identification of the Washington quarterbackBill Kilmer or Sonny Jurgensenfor their playoff game here tomorrow. But the Los Angeles players were having none of it. They knew Kilmer would be the starter at kickoff time in the Coliseum (Channel 2, 4 P.M., New York time).

title: When the number of slaves reached critical mass
description: Negroes in Colonial South Carolina from 1670 Through the Stono Rebellion. By Peter H. Wood. 346 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.

title: Draftee Clemency Program Is Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21President Ford slid it was an acti of mercy when he offered a clemency plan Sept. 16 to Vietnam era draft evaders and deserters.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: I believe that manufacturersand not just apparel manufacturers  should emphasize higher production in order to bring production costs down, says Herbert Rounick.

title: But the President Wants a Liberal Democrat at Justice
description: WASHINGTON  It has been more than four months since President Ford took office, yet only in the past few days has it become apparent what kind of people he will put in key positions in Government. On the White House staff he will rely largely on longtime associates, conservatives like himself, and some of the more able and untarnished Nixon holdovers. For his Cabinet and other key positions it appears that he will seek to employ the full political range of the Republican party, with an occasional Democrat as well.

title: Insider Telling All About Bergen Politics
description: TEANECKThe graduate faculty at Fairleigh Dickinson University here will soon be getting a doctoral dissertation that could prove profitable reading for all politicians.

title: Expressway Dispute Persists
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Turnpike Authority has decided to go ahead with its plans to construct a $360million expressway between East Brunswick (Exit 9 on the turnpike) and the Garden Elate Parkway in Toms River, despite a pronouncement by Governor Byrne that the road will not be built.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We write of Christmas Past: 3:30 A.M., Dec. 22, 1972, a complex of fifty buildings one mile south of the center of the city of Hanoi. The largest medical institution in all Indochina, with 1,200 beds, and a major referral, teaching, and research center, it was almost completely destroyed by the third U.S. bombing it had sustained, part of the Christmas carpet bombing of Hanoi. After initial, denials it was finally identified by a Department of Defense spokesman as a hospital the enemy calls Bach Mai.

title: Barry Spodak Weds Elizabeth D. Andes
description: Elizabeth Dare Andes, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Sager Carlin of Carversville, Pa., and Charles Lovett Andes of Haddonfield,, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Barry Neil Spodak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Spodak of Manhasset, L. I., and Palm Beach.

title: Josephine Stettinius Plans Nuptials
description: Josephine Brodix Stettinius plans to be married in early June to Christopher BrundredMurray, a grandson of the late Thomas E. Murray, inventor.

title: ALFRED S. HOLMES
description: Alfred S. Holmes, a lawyer and owner of Jager House, 1253 Lexington Avenue, a wellknown Yorkville restaurant, died Friday in New York hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 820 Park Avenue.

title: It's Eclectic Christmas Time
description: When George F. Schutz, a producer of concerts, or one of his partners answers the phone, almost any kind of musician is likely to be at the other end. It may be the elegant flute player JeanPierre Rampal or the rather earthy comedienne Anna Russell. It may be a sober choral director like Richard Westenburg or a notsosober satirist like Peter Schickele, unearther of P. D. Q. Bach's music. It may be a representative of a musical group such as Oregon or that famous table player from India, Alla Rakha. It may even be William Lockwood of august Lincoln Center, calling to confer about a future Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Charities Deluged For Food, Clothes
description: NEWARKFor the second year in a row, charitable organizations throughout New Jersey are being deluged with unprecedented demands for food and clothing. Officials attribute the requests to the worsening economic picture.

title: Terriers '74 Best In Show
description: Among fanciers, 1974 will be known as the year of the terrier. This comes as rather a surprise, since for a halfdozen years the terrier has been pretty much in the background. Not since 1966 has a terrier won the silverware at Santa Barbara, the nation's largest show, when a Scottie showed the way. At Westminster, which celebrates its 100th anniversary in 1976, the last terrier to gain the top honors was a Skye in 1969.

title: Healthy holiday treats
description: The concerned cook who bakes for holiday munching and giving will stress food values this season over the traditional, luxurious (and usually emptycalorie) nibbles. The cooky recipes here, are festivelyalmost deceptivelynutritious and delicious. They are easy to make for lastminute gifts and are full of such good things as nuts and raisins, outs and honey, wheat germ and apples.

title: One Man's Experience
description: In the fall of 1936 I was out of work, but I was lucky. I was 27 years old and had no property, no savings and no rich relatives. So it was easy for me to get on Home Relief and soon after on W.P.A. Again I was lucky had a choice. I was an actor and a radio director. The actor's pay was $23.86 a week. The radio director's was $33. I went into radio.

title: MET COLLEGE HOCKEY
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: You Can't Win Them All
description: A funny thing happened in the United States and British Opens, the Masters and the Professional Golfers' Association championship: Johnny Miller did not win. But the 27yearold allAmerica boy from California, a nonsmoker, nondrinker and church elder, did win eight of the 40 events on the American tour (the last man to do that was Arnold Palmer in 1960), and he set a record of $353,021 in winnings.

title: IRAN CLARIFIES VIEW OF RULER ON GOLD
description: TEHERAN Iran, Dec. 21 (AP) A spokesman for the Shah of Iran has cautioned against pos. sible erroneous interpretation of the Shah's warning to the West about increasing the value of gold held by governments.

title: Amy Leos Wed To M. H. Urbel
description: Amy Judith Leos of Easthampton, Mass., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Leos of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Martin Howard Urbel, also of Easthampton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony John Urbel of Amsterdam, N.Y.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Art/ Two lawsuits threaten the entire structure of landmarks preservation in New York. (Ada Louise huxtable)

title: As Mao directed, the old serves the new
description: A coincidence, you might saytwo enormous books, each of which would lake up most of the surface of an ordinary coffee table, each about modern China, each full of photographs and information. Moreover, each is not simply a oneman or onewoman job, but the result of family cooperation. China Today was produced by a husbandandwife team, while China Day by Day goes it one better, being the result of three contributors: father, daughter and soninlaw.

title: NATIONAL TOPICS
description: SOUL CITY, N. C.Floyd B. McKissick seems a bit miscast as a Republican, a chairman emeritus of President Nixon's campaign organization, a millionaire, corporation president, real estate developer, city planner, civic booster, man with connections and creator of a whole new town going up in the middle of nowhere on 5,000 acres of North Carolina farmland just south of the Virginia line.

title: NURSINGHOME SALES UNDER U.S. SCRUTINY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  Federal investigators are studying bogus nursinghome sales in which hidden owners sell a facility to themselves to raise rates charged poor people, a practice that has come under fire in New York.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: ANTITRUST law is one of this country's oldest forms of business regulation, and it is no less controversial today than at the time of its origin in the late 19th century. The very existence of a basically strong antitrust code sets the United States apart from most other industrial countries. But, despite the fact that this code has been imbedded in the American legal system for 84 years, its enforcement is still unfortunately regarded by businessmen and politicians as a sign of hostility toward business.

title: 2D LONDON STORE IN 3 DAYS BOMBED
description: LONDON, Dec. 21A bomb, exploded today in Harrods, one of London's most exclusive department stores, and set fire to part of the third floor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As an architect who has designed many largescale housing developments, I was appalled at a statement made by Paul Selvers in his Point of. View article Community Boards Meet Vital Need [Dec. 1].

title: Children's Hospital Planned on Island
description: NEW HYDE PARKThe State Health Department has approved creation of Long Island's first children's medical center. It is to be built and operated by Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center on its grounds here.

title: Ideas &Trends Education, Research, Law
description: Skiers aren't breaking as many legs these days, but they're injuring more arms and shoulders, according to studies by three doctors, because of changes in equipment.

title: Marion Woodworth Raymond Bride of Robert Martin Bestani
description: Marion Woodworth Raymond, daughter of Mrs. Irving Woodworth Raymond of York Harbor, Me., and Daytona Beach, Fla., and the late Professor Raymond, was married yesterday noon to Robert Martin Bestani, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bestani of Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Like the music most of the writing about it is primitive
description: Rock music has a 20year history, but its relation to serious writing really only flourished in the late sixties. Most of the writing coming out these days about rock music and its ancillary institutions is dumb, but then again so is most of the music. There's some decent writing still, but much of it remains an exercise in personal style, more concerned with the sociology of the music than with its esthetics. And if all music is difficult to write about, rock is especially difficult: not only nonverbal but post or subverbal as well, and selfconsciously generational to boot.

title: He Was a Soccer Star, He Was Brave and He Died
description: September, October, November, 1970. It was three years since the diagnosis of his leukemia, and Eric was playing the best soccer of his life. Because of his height and hustle, he had been moved from forward position to fullback. There was less opportunity to score, but there was plenty of action and often the chance for assists.

title: HalfMiler, All Winner
description: In a year of uncertainty, from performances to politics, Rick Wohlhuter emerged as the most consistent figure in the world of track and field.

title: Miss Rowland Bride of Robert Ginn Jr.
description: Virginia Thomas Rowland was married yesterday afternoon in Cambridge, Mass., to Robert Jay Ginn Jr., associate director of Harvard University's office of career services and offcampus learning. The Episcopal ceremony in Harvard's Appleton Chapel was performed by the Rev. James Diamond, a chaplain of the University of Minnesota and classmate of the bridegroom at the Harvard Divinity School.

title: Son for Mrs. Yoo
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Yoo on Dec. 9 at the Lenox Hill Hospital. The child has been named Roger. Mr. Yoo is a management consultant with McKinsey & Co., Inc. Mrs. Yoo is the former Leslie J. Weiss.

title: Critics Seeking Curbs on Wiretap Laws
description: TRENTONAlthough the Legislature has extended the state's highly controversial wiretap law for another six months, critics of the surveillance statute are preparing to seek major revisions in its application.

title: Joanne Coombe Is Bride

Gordon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon of Englewood, N. J. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood by the Rev. David Gillespie.

title: The Host Won the Prize And Made a Profit, Too
description: On a sunny July afternoon in Munich, before 86,000 spectators and at least 800 million television viewers throughout the world, West Germany subdued the Netherlands, 21, to win the World Cup and become champion for four years in a sport dominant in 142 countries. In an electrifying atmosphere, the Dutch, the most surprising team in the quadrennial soccer competition, scored in the first minute of play. But the West Germans rallied, scored twice and repulsed a fierce Dutch attack.

title: Raiders' Frustration Ended
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21 It was a moment that had been building up for several years in the minds and hearts of the Oakland, Raiders. And when Phil Villapiano's interception sealed the victory over Miami in the National Football League playoff game today all the emotion overflowed.

title: Suzanne Jones, C. L. Cansler Jr. Marry Upstate
description: St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Suzanne van Dyke Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent S. Jones of Rochester, to Charles Lee Cansler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cansler of Phoenix, Ariz.

title: State Studying Klan
description: A teacher at an upstate state prison who allegedly identified himself as a local Ku Klux Klan leader, has been suspended in an investigation into alleged Klan activities by some prison employes, including guards. Details on Page ??.

title: Film: English Soporific:' That'll Be the Day' Is About Boredom The Cast
description: Movies about boredom aren't ever likely to make the blood leap, and "That'll Be the Day" proves that there's no such thing as a rousing soporific. Set in the late nineteen-fifties, this English moviewhich opened yesterday at the Cine Malibu and the Cinema Villageis lazily concerned with the ennui of a young provincial who balks at taking his university exams, leaves home to work at odd jobs, writes whimsical pop lyrics, and pines to enter the rock world. He also makes out with bland young women who beg him not to tell anyone. Eventually, he marries a hairdresser who blinks a lot, and the result is just as boring for us as it is for him.As the soundtrack churns out some elderly (even whiskery) rock music, this tame rebel without claws seems like a ghost of the defiant, adventurous English film heroes of the early sixties, when such splendid actors as Albert Finney in "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning" and Tom Courtney in "The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner" conveyed the impassioned energy that sprang from claustrophobia.It's a bit forlorn to think of David Essex, who plays the rock fan, as their descendant. He's rather beautiful but has been directed to be utterly passive: for him, acting takes the form of long, slow elfin smiles and dreamy stares, and he struggles to reproduce a particular English accent that's been scarce on screen of late: "fink" for think, "flay" for slay, "frow up" for upchuck.Ringo Starr makes a phlegmatic appearancehe looks a bit sheepish, as though apologizing for making no music at all. As a titillating conclusion for the movie, the young man buys a guitar; a sequel is promised. Let's hope that many strong stimulants were administered to everyone involved with the next picture.

title: GRENADE INJURES U.S. GIRL IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 22A 16yearold American girl on a Pilgrimage to the Holy Land was injured today when a grenade struck the bus in which she was riding.

description: On the surface of it, the program offered Saturday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. by the Sine Nomine Singers might have looked like a Christmas concert, or at least a holiday concert. But Benjamin Britten's Ceremony of Carols isn't devoted exclusively to the nativity of Christ, and the second half of the programapart from the encoresturned out to be downright steamy in its sensuality.

title: U.C.L.A. Shows Its Strength
description: U.C.L.A.'s basketball stock rose over the weekend, but so did that of Southern California, the Bruins' chief rival when Pacific8 Conference play begins next month.

title: SCHOOLS TO AUDIT BRONX CONTRACTS
description: At the request of Mario Merola, District Attorney of the Bronx, the Board of Education has revived a dormant 1973 audit of a nowdefunct computerized educational services concern, EduForce, Inc., that did nearly $1.5million worth of business with two Bronx school districts.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 22 (AP)  The Indiana Pacers, once a solid American Basketball Association franchise, are in serious financial trouble, according to John D. Weissert, president of Indiana Professional Sports, Inc., which controls the team.

description: McAFEEWinter officially arrived this weekend but the slopes of the Great Gorge ski area are still to get their first natural snow of the season. Still, 1,500 skiers may do with the manmade kind, and ski conditions were optimistically described as fair to good.

title: NEWS INDEX
When Chairman Mao Meets Karl Marx
description: There are many things I haven't studied. I am a person with many shortcomings, I am by no means perfect. Very often, there are times when I don't like myself. I have not mastered all the various domains of Marxist learning. And, for example, I don't know foreign languages well either. I have only just begun recently to study economic work. But, comrades, I study with determination, and I will go on studying until I die; when I die, that will be the end of it! In sum, as long as I am alive I shall study every day. Let us all create an environment of study. think I can learn a bit too; otherwise, when the time comes for me to see Marx, I shall be in an embarrassing fix. If he asks me a few questions and I am unable to answer, what will I do.? He is certainly very interested in all aspects of the Chinese revolution. I'm not very good either in natural science or engineering.

title: Unofficial Art Show Opened in Leningrad
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (Reuters) More than 1,000 young people crowded the opening of a fourday exhibition of nonorthodox art in a Leningrad Palace of Culture today. It was the first indoor exhibition of its kind in the Soviet Union since the nineteentwenties.

title: ...Minimal Response
description: To be sure, Mr. Ford appears prepared to give some ground to protect himself against what is sure to be a mounting Democratic charge that he is a donothing President who refuses to act against rising unemployment and a prolonged slump. For instance, it is now clear that the President is ready to sign the bill passed by Congress last week appropriating $1 billion for jobs for the unemployed. But this is truly minimal legislation; it provides for only 100,000 jobs nationwideand would chip only about onetenth of 1 percentage point off the unemployment rate.

title: Red Smith
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 22For the second time in eight days, inhabitants of this enlightened community get a chance next Sunday to prove they can keep their wits about them even when the local football team is winning. The first opportunity rose yesterday and they seized it. Although 3,830 of Metropolitan Stadium's 48,422 seats were available free, 3,796 remained empty while the Minnesota Vikings were flogging the St. Louis Cardinals, 3014, for the halfchampionship of the National Conference of the National Football League. When the Vikings play the Los Angeles Rams for the rest the title a week deeper into winter on the same snowy terrain, even more bright citizens may stay home beside the fire. The offer of free tickets was not due to the impulsive generosity of the Viking management but rather the civic spirit of Burger King, the national quicklunch chain owned by the Pillsbury Company, a Minneapolis flour mill. As a gesture of goodwill to cow meat consumers the area, Burger King paid $44,924 for all unsold tickets last Wednesday to make sure the game would be a sellout and therefore, under the rules laid down by Congress last year, shown locally on television. The tickets were to be distributed to any charitable organization that wanted them. It remains to be seen whether McDonald's will take reprisal action this week.

title: SCHOOLS TO AUDIT BRONX CONTRACTS

Miss Peppier, the playercoach for the El Paso, Tex., franchise in the International Volleyball League, won four events during the final day of the twoday event and finished first in Group I. Miss King won the Group II title and now will advance along with Miss Peppier and 10 others to the final competition in Rotunda, Fla., next month.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Today there is an important debate on priorities going on in the People's Republic of China. The winner will then go on to the Super Bowl in New Orleans on Jan. 12, meeting the American Conference champion, either Oakland or Pittsburgh.

title: CYANIDE KILLS A MAN AND OVERCOMES 17

title: ' Black Thursday' a Moving Film About Jews of Paris
description: "Black Thursday," the new French film that opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, solemnly commemorates one of the bleakest chapters in the history of Paris during the German occupation. On July 16, 1942, 9,000 French policemen rounded up 13,000 Jews, including 4,500 children, hustled them aboard city buses and carted them off on the first leg of a journey that eventually led to the Nazi death camps.For the most part, everything was extremely orderly. There was no panic. The policemen were, after all, French not German. The Jews, too, were polite. They were mostly French nationals and they had faith in the Republic. Also, there were no more hiding places. Some policemen were glad to see the Jews go. If at all conscience-stricken they could tell themselves their victims were simply being sent off to work in factories somewhere. Like in '14-'18."Black Thursday" is based on the haunted memoir, "Les Guichets du Louvre" (The Gates of the Louvre), by Roger Boussinot, published in France in 1960. At the time of the all-day roundup, Mr. Boussinot was a 20-year-old student at the Sorbonne. Having obtained advance warning of the raids, he spent that day in the Right Bank Jewish quarter, trying unsuccessfully to persuade Jews to hide, or to flee with him to the labyrinths of the Left Bank's student quarter, or just to remove the gold Stars of David they wore on their breasts.He was notably unsuccessful. He was a fresh-faced kid. He might be in the pay of the police. One preferred to take one's chances with one's family rather than to go off on a wild goose chase. A handsome Jewish woman in a pastry shop thanked him with a smile but pointed out that she really didn't know him well enough. She had heard stories about the wild lives the students led. He could have been inviting her to an orgy.Only one person listened to him, though reluctantly: a pretty girl who first found that her mother and younger sister had been arrested, and then watched as the policemen led away all the employes at the furrier's where she worked."Black Thursday" is the story of the efforts of the young man, named Paul in the film and played by Christian Rist, to persuade the girl (Christine Pascal) to save herself if not to let him save her. It's an agonizing film, both because of the complex emotions it evokes and because it so often slips into clumsily romantic movie attitudes that don't do justice to the subject.Michel Mitrani, the director, seems at times to be making one of those old Gerard Philippe tearjerkers of the late nineteen-forties, with lots of music on the soundtrack, swoopy, circular camera movements, and actors who look more like idealizations than real people. Everything suggests a softer kind of fiction than this really is.Miss Pascal is an exception. She has an irregular beauty that never denies or gets in the way of the successive waves of fear, hope, resignation and despair she experiences during her day-long flight to nowhere. She is especially fine in the film's quietest, most terrifying scene, when she at last allows a friend to snip the stitches attaching the Star of David to her coat. She has suddenly become anonymous.Like Marcel Ophuls's "The Sorrow and The Pity" and Louis Malle's "Lacombe, Lucien," "Black Thursday" examines a moment in history that most Frenchmen have preferred to ignore until now. It's not very interesting movie-making, but I suspect that for many (including the French) the subject itself is transforming enough.

Rockefeller. Yesterday, on his first working day in Washington since being confirmed by Congress, Mr. Rockefeller had a full schedule of activities, all assigned to him by Mr. Ford, and he has been given plenty to do in the future.

description: MONTREAL, Dec. 22Nearly 100 years after he was hanged for treason, Louis Riel has become a hero in Canada, where national heroes are few.

title: Crosscurrents Are Sweeping China' as She Prepares Next Steps
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 22Anyone trying to gauge the direction of political winds in China these days ends up talking about crosscurrents. On the one hand there is a new dictum from Chairman Mao Tsetung calling on the country to settle down and unite after eight years of political revivalism and struggle. On the other there is a steady buildup to a new movement in the countryside that has already been branded the leap forward.

title: World Trade Reform

title: Minimal Economics...
description: As the economic situation continues to deteriorate, pressures are building up on the Ford Administration to shift its fiscal and monetary policy from restraint or mere neutrality to stronger stimulus. These pressures are coming from many sidesfrom leaders of the automobile industry, fearful of an utter collapse of their market; from the housing industry, whose rate of production has now fallen from 2.5 million units at the start of 1973 to 990,000 last month; from labor, as the unemployment rolls, already at six million, continue to grow, and from independent professional economists, both liberal and conservative, who fear that the Administration is needlessly risking too long and deep a recession with only small extra gains to be scored against inflation.

To these evenings can be added Mr. Brown's rapt and magical production of Eugene O'Neill's Ah, Wilderness! given for the first time Friday night. This, in its way, is a perfect O'Neill staging, sensitive in its perceptions, loving in its evocations and remarkable in its reverberations of both poet and period.

title: CORRECTION

The 27 per cent figure applies to both nuclear and nonnuclear capacity. According to a recent survey, the delayed or canceled capacity totals 132 billion watts, of which 89 billion were for nuclear and 43 billion for nonnuclear plants.

Friedman, is the vertiable image of the shrewd, cigarsmoking lawyer, wellacquainted with the inner workings of city Hall. For eight years, Mr. Friedman was associate counsel to Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader, and he came to be something of a surrogate for Mr. Cuitea position that endowed him with more power than many of the Councilmen themselves.

This despite the fact that most formal compositions in which jazz is attached as a qualifying adjective to any of the customary European musical forms tends, at best, to use jazz as an occasional, selfconscious coloration.
