title: Ranking of Schools by District as Rated by Citywide Reading Tests
description: Following is a table showing the ranking of elementary schools by districts as measured by the citywide reading tests given last spring. Also shown are the ranking of junior high Schools and intermediate schools in the city. The percentages show the proportion of pupils in each school at or above grade level. AcCording to national standards, the average school would have half its pupils at or above grade level and half below. A line indicates the Board of Education's cutoff point for the purposes of identifying those schools listed below the linethat are eligible to use alternative methods of selecting new teachers because of their pupil reading scores. Not all districts have Such eligible schools. Since the April tests were given, another districtDistrict 32 in the Bushwick section of Brooklynwas created out of parts of Districts 16 and 19.

description: New York's biggest business is Christmas, and business in this Christmas of recession, inflation, high unemployment and civic austerity is not bad, considering.

title: Finley Accused of Perjury
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP) Richard Moss, general counsel for the Major League Baseball Players' Association, accused Charles O. Finley today of committing perjury during the Jim (Catfish) Hunter arbitration hearing last month.

title: Linda Muller Wed To W. V. Vasu Jr.
description: Linda Muller, daughter of Mrs. Anita G. Muller of New York and Morton S. Muller of Kitchawan, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to William V. Vasu Jr., son of Mrs. Lucille Claudatos of Rockport, Mass., and the late William V. Vasu of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: 9 Michigan Banks Held Up
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UPI)Gunmen held up nine banks in Michigan during a fivehour period today. An F.B.I. spokesman said there were no reported injuries in any of the robberies. He declined to disclose the total amount of money stolen. Four holdups occurred in Detroit, one in Dearborn, one in Dearborn Heights, one in Lansing, one in Bay City and one in Hamtramck. Gunmen held up nine banks in Michigan during a fivehour period today. An F.B.I. spokesman said there were no reported injuries in any of the robberies. He declined to disclose the total amount of money stolen. Four holdups occurred in Detroit, one in Dearborn, one in Dearborn Heights, one in Lansing, one in Bay City and one in Hamtramck.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ski Resort Owner Reports 1974 Progress in Depth
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 23  Crazy Mike Brandt, head of West Mountain, was looking over the ski reports for the northeast today. And, although they revealed conditions in upper New England were mostly good to excellent, he showed no envy. Why should I? he asked. I keep remembering last Christmas we were shut out completely. In fact, we didn't open until after New Year's Dayand that was strictly on manmade snow on our beginner's area. This season, we've already been open three days and our main slope has 15 inches, eight of it natural. We could use more snow on our other slope, but I guess we can't have everything.

title: HAITI AND REYNOLDS REACH TAX ACCORD
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 23 (Reuters)  The Reynolds Metals Company said today it had accepted a new tax by the Government of Haiti of $9.33 per long dry ton of bauxite with a realized price of 32 cents per pound of processed aluminum.

title: PRESIDENT TELLS COLBY TO SPEED REPORT ON C. I. A.
description: President Ford today ordered William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, to report within a matter of days on the published allegations of illegal C.I.A. spying on American citizens.

title: Mayor's Order on Layoffs Resisted by City Officials
description: The Board of Education, the Board of Higher Education and most of the city's elected officials yesterday resisted Mayor Beanie's request for immediate personnel cuts.

title: Gracie Mansion Gets Portrait of O'Dwyer
description: The memory of the city's 100th Mayor, the late William O'Dwyer, was honored with Christmas carols and generous helpings of Irish warmth and wit yesterday when his official portrait was unveiled at a Gracie Mansion ceremony.

title: Harvard Wins First Leg of Nile Regatta
description: LUXOR, Egypt, Dec. 23Harvard won the first race of the International Regatta on the Nile today amidst the pomp and magnificence of the Pharaohs. The regatta's host is the Egyptian Rowing Federation with Harvard, Yale, Oxford and Cambridge Universities as invited guests.

title: Excursion Into Maudlin
description: Christmas in Washington in the old days had a quality that set it apart from Christmas in any other place I have ever known. We had the conventional Christmas trappings familiar to Americans everywhere, of course. Kate Smith roasting on an open fire, Jack Frost nipping at the gin. That sort of thing.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: DR. KATE B. WINTON
description: Dr. Kate Barber Winton, who with her late husband, Dr. Andrew L. Winton, published several books analyzing the structure and composition of foods, died Saturday in the Hewitt Memorial Hospital in Shelton, Conn. She was 92 years old and lived on Ridgefield Road in Wilton, Conn.

title: Sports Today
REPORT ABOUT RISKS, S.E.C. BIDS BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  The nation's corporations were told by the Securities and Exchange Commission today that they should report significant business risks, such as shaky investments, in their financial reports to the Government and to the public.

title: Trinity Church Is Selling 10 Properties
description: Trinity Church is offering for sale 10 of its 24 commercial properties in Lower Manhattan because they are losing money.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 23 (Reuters)Evonne Gbolagongis future with the Pittsburgh Triangles of World Team ?? still in doubt.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The consultant in charge of preparing the environmental impact statement of the convention center proposed for Manhattan's West Side said that he had been ordered by center officials to come up with a statement favorable to building the center and had been threatened with bodily harm if he failed to do so.

title: REGENTS WILL ASK $425MILLION RISE
description: ALBANY, Dec. 23The State Board of Regents will ask the new Legislature to increase the state's education appropriation by nearly $425million next year, most of the money committed to help communities avoid higher taxes because of sharply rising school costs.

title: Jordan's Queen Gives a Christmas Party
description: AMMAN, JordanOne of the most unusual Christmas parties in the world will be celebrated this year in the residence of King Hussein Ibn Talal and his young Queen Alia of the Hashimite kingdom of Jordan.

title: NASA Urged to Include Telescope in Shuttle Plan
description: Leading scientific advisers to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have recommended an immediate start, despite budgetary stringency, on a longdiscussed Large Space telescope intended to be flown aboard the manned shuttle system in the nineteeneighties.

title: B1 Bomber Makes First Flight and Air Force Hails
description: The B1 intercontinental bomber, designed to replace the aging B52 at a cost of $76million a plane, took to the air for the first time yesterday over the California desert test area.

title: Sex Attractant Chemicals From Women Isolated
description: Atlanta medical researchers have isolated aromatic sex attractant chemicals from the vaginal secretions of healthy young women. Such chemicals, called pheremones, have been found in virtually all animals, from insects on up, but their presence in humans, though long suspected, had not previously been confirmed.

title: PRICES OF SUGAR AND COCOA CLIMB
description: Sugar, cocoa and silverall internationally traded commodities  showed sharp gains yesterday, and traders attributed the strength to a record price for gold abroad.

title: Clearing the Track
description: The Supreme Court's validation of the Northeast rail reorganization law removes the last legal roadblock creation of a viable transportation network out of the Penn Central and other bankrupt roads. But the interpretation the Court has given to the law makes it probable that the eventual cost to the taxpayers will far exceed the original estimate of $558 million in Federal grants, plus $1.5 billion in Governmentguaranteed loans.

title: William Eckenberg Dies at 76; Times Photographer 41 Years
description: William C. Eckenberg, a staff photographer on The New York Times from 1922 to his retirement in 1963but who continued to teach his art among his neighbors in Leisure Village, Ridge, L. I.died yesterday in the Sunrest Nursing Home, Port Jefferson, L. I. He was 76 years old.

title: PAUL S. WINGERT, ART HISTORIAN, 74
description: Dr. Paul S. Wingert, professor emeritus of art history at Columbia University and an innovator in treating the art of primitive peoples as a part of art history as well as cultural anthropology, died Sunday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N. J. He was 74 years old and lived at 117 Highland Avenue, Montclair, N. J.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 23 (AP)About 8,000 photographs taken by the late Margaret BourkeWhite and stored beneath a staircase in her Darien home will go to Syracuse University under a court settlement.

title: Net Deficit Widens As Sales Gain 8.6% At Gimbel Brothers
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates a nationwide chain of 69 department stores, reported yesterday its net loss widened in the quarter ended Sept. 30 to $503,000 from an $87,000 deficit in the similar three months last year.

title: Advertising
description: Convinced that this blackcloud economy might have a silver lining for their favorite medium, leaders of the radio industry have embarked on a program aimed at building a fighting selling spirit at local stations.

title: Holiday Parking Rules In Effect Tomorrow
description: Holiday parking regulations will be in effect on Christmas Day, tomorrow, and New Year's Day, next Wednesday, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzof announced yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Suit Charges 2 Improperly Used Kalvex, Inc., Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, charging misappropriation of company funds, filed suit here yesterday against Emanuel L. Wolf, chairman of both Kalvex, Inc., a manufacturer of motor homes, and the Allied Artists Pictures Corporation, and against Robert L. Ingis, a former executive of both companies.

title: JULES R. BREUCHAUD
description: Jules R. Breuchaud, retired president and hoard chairman of the Underpinning and Foundation Company here, died Sunday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 92 years old.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In his Miami Dolphins' office yesterday, Don Shuia called out to a passerby: We've got, those tickets for you to the Super Bowl... I mean the Orange Bowl. Understandably, the Super Bowl: is sunk deep in Don Shula's subconscious. But after two victories and three consecutive appearances, the Dolphins won't be there this season. They were eliminated from the National Football League playoffs in a 2826 victory for the Oakland Raiders that deserves an Emmy as the best TV dramatic special of theyear. But the Dolphins lost as they won, with dignity. No alibis. No hysterics. No recriminations. They remained in the character that Shula had formed since his 1970 takeover. Through his five seasons as a coach, the Dolphins dominated the N.F.L. as no team ever had, with a regularseason wonlosttied record of 57121 and a postseason record of 83, including Saturday's defeat. When they won the. Super Bowl last season to join the Green Bay Packers as the only twotime winners, they performed so perfectly that some critics considered it a dull game. But to the purists, it was exciting and beautiful, an unflawed masterpiece. They even had bored some critics with their 17.0 record the season before. But that perfect season is a treasure that belongs in a time capsule.

title: New Hampshire Panel Declares Wyman Victor in Senate Contest
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 23 (UPI)  New Hampshire reversed the results of a United States Senate race recount today and awarded an unofficial, twovote victory to Representative Louis Wyman, a Republican, over John Durkin, a Democrat. The figures will become official tomorrow morning when they are reported to the Governor and the Executive Council.

title: Leaders in State Regents Examinations Take Honors in Stride
description: The top winners in the annual Regents Scholarship examinations have been announced, and the state and city's high scorers are regarding their achievement with equanimity.

title: G.M. Belgian Unit Denies E.E.C. Antitrust Charges
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation's Belgian subsidiary issued a statement today denying antitrust charges levied by the European Economic Community. But a spokesman for the Antwerpbased company said we have not made up our mind yet whether to appeal the Common Market ruling and fine of $120,000.

title: AIDE TO HUMPHREY INDICTED ON FUNDS
description: Jack L. Chestnut, former campaign manager for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on a charge of arranging an illegal corporate contribution from the Associated Milk Producers, Inc.

description: William Henry Finkeldey, founding partner of Singmaster & Bryer, consulting chemical and metallurgical engineers here, died Sunday in New Haven. He was 82 years old.

title: Kaiser Industries Net Off
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 23 (Reuters)  The Kaiser Industries Corporation said today it had settled its claims for the construction of the Gun hydroelectric projects and as a result 1974 earnings would be reduced by about $10million, or 36 cents a share. For the nine months, Kaiser earned $2.03 a share compared with $1.30 a year ago.

description: Extra trains will operate on both Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve to handle the expected early departure from Pennsylvania Statiqn of regular commuters, the Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 Steve Mix scored 26 points and Billy Cunningham 25 tonight in leading the Philadelphia 76ers to a 10088 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: FRANCES CARROLL
description: Frances JoAnne Carroll, daughter of Luke Carroll, executive director of Chicago Tribune Charities in Chicago, and Mrs. Carroll, died Sunday of injuries suffered while driving home Friday from Barrington (Ill.) High School. She was 17 years old.

description: A player who emerges from silence to double a notrump game or slam usually has a leaddirecting motive in mind. He is asking for a lead in partner's suit, or his own suit, or dummy's first suit, in that order of preference.

description: LONDON, Dec. 23Londoners are reacting to the bombings in this normally peaceful capital with unease and defiance.

title: POLLUTION IS LAID TO 2 COMPANIES
description: NEWARK, Dec. 23  The United States Attorney's office announced today that two chemical companies, in Linden City and in Woodbridge Township, had been charged with dumping large amounts of chemical wastes into the Arthur Kill, the channel between New Jersey and Staten Island.

title: $25Billion, 5Year Health Plan Downplays National Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) The way to better health for Americans over the next five years may be through safer working conditions and special medical projects, rather than a national health insurance plan, according to a report issued today by the Department of Health Education and Welfare.

title: Blast on Argentine Warship In English Channel Kills 2
description: HASTINGS, England, Dec. 23 (AP)  An explosion in the boiler room of the Argentine warship Candido de Lasala in the English Channel today killed two sailors and seriously injured three, the British Coast Guard reported.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts, who leaves office Jan. 2 after a sixyear term, will spend several months as a fellow of the Institute of Politics at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. Expressing a desire to reflect on his future plans, the 59yearold liberal Republicandefeated by Michael Dukakis last monthwill direct a noncredit political seminar for students as well as pursuing subjects of his own special interest energy policy, the environment, privacy and freedom of information. The departing Governor is a graduate in architecture of neighboring Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: 535th Golden Gate Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (UPI)An unidentified, blueeyed, brownhaired man in his late 20's yesterday became the 535th known person to leap to his death from the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: New Urban Approach
description: The phrases urban crisis and the plight of the cities have become commonplace capsule descriptions in discussions of urban America, particularly since the midnineteensixties when the seething anger in many ghettos boiled over into riots.

title: Ethiopians Report Clash With Rebels in Eritrea
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 23 (Reuters) Fighting broke out between Government troops and secessionist guerrillas in Eritrea, Ethiopia's northern province, the military council of the north announced today.

title: WARREN FINNERTY
description: Warren Finnerty, an actor who won an Off Broadway Obie award in the Living Theater production of The Connection, died Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

description: HOUSTON; Dec 23 (AP)North Carolina State rallied to gain a 31.31 tie with Houston tonight in the AstroBluebannet Bowl football game.

description: CAIRO, Dec. 23  Foreign Minister Jean Sauvagnargues, of France has ended a visit here with public warnings to Arab countries that they mustrecognize Israel's right to exist just as Israel must recognize that the Palestinians have a right to a national home.

title: POLICE CHIEF UNHURT IN ARGENTINE BLAST
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec 23 (AP)  Guerrillas rolled a pickup truck loaded with explosives into a car escorting the federal police chief of Argentina tonight, killing a corporal and wounding two officers.

description: The consultant in charge of preparing an independent report on the environmental impact of the convention center waterfront said that he had proposed for the Hudson River Waterfront said that he had been ordered by center officials to come up with a report favorable to building the center and had been threatened with bodily harm if he failed to do so.

title: 5 of 6 U.S. Auto Workers Dislike Swedish System
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 23After working four weeks in a modern Swedish auto plant incorporating group assembly of engines, five of six American auto workers have declared a preference for the conventional production line they were used to in Detroit.

title: Radioactive Cargo Limited
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 23 (UPI)Delta Airlines said today it was banning all shipments of radioactive material not intended for medical use, effective immediately. The airline said it recently had experienced another minor incident involving a shipment of industrial radioactive material. The Atomic Energy Commission and the health authorities in Louisiana said there bad been no hazard to passengers or crew. Delta Airlines said today it was banning all shipments of radioactive material not intended for medical use, effective immediately. The airline said it recently had experienced another minor incident involving a shipment of industrial radioactive material. The Atomic Energy Commission and the health authorities in Louisiana said there bad been no hazard to passengers or crew.

description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (UPI) In contrast to the hectic trading in gold, the European money markets remained relatively calm in a preChristmas lull and the dollar fluctuated only slightly today.

description: It was billed as the first public appearance of the Orr baby. No, 6monthold Robert Orr didn't skate out by himself to greet Santa Claus at Boston Garden yesterday. He had a little help from his father as hockey celebrated Christmas intersession with parties.

description: President Ford has assured the American people that the Central Intelligence Agency is not now conducting domestic political surveillances in violation of its charter, and that no such activities will be tolerated while he is President.

description: A senior administrative official of New Jersey's Greystone psychiatric hospital in Morris Plains said yesterday that while every effort would be made to tool up to achieve reinstatement of our accreditation, [withdrawn by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals last month] handicaps within the budget limitations as they now stand make the effort extremely difficult.

title: Unguarded Intelligence
description: Yet another conspiracy under the Nixon Administration to defy the law and infringe upon the constitutional rights of American citizens has now sprung into the open. The domestic intelligencegathering operation of the Central Intelligence Agency, the maintenance of secret files on several thousand American citizens suspected of political dissidence were flatly illegal activities: there is no alternative now to invoking appropriate legal procedures against the officials responsible.

title: Magic of AbdulJabbar Not Healing Bucks' Wounds
description: No, everything is not all right for the Milwaukee Bucks with Kareem AbdulJabber back. The Bucks have shown little winning consistency since his return and continue to play like the lastplace team they are, instead of the firstplace team they are supposed to be. AbdulJabbar, the Bucks' center and oneman show, missed the first 16 games and everybody blamed the Bucks' 313 wonlost start on his broken hand and eye injury. Since his return Milwaukee has won nine and lost six after last night's defeat by the Washington Bullets, who have the best record in the National Basketball Association.

title: Kansas, 18th, Loses by 37
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP)Kentucky, ranked No. 20, used a solid defense and Kevin Grevey's 29 points to wallop 18thrated Kansas, 10063, in college basketball tonight.

title: Stabler Vs. Bradshaw: Edge Given to Raiders
description: Oakland is the team to beat. They've got the best record and they have had the best allround performances. They beat Miami, which is still a damn good club any day.

title: Stocks in a Broad Retreat As Turnover Accelerates
description: Heavy yearend tax selling and concern over the widening recession sent the stock market into a broad decline yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: ROBERT F. MEYER
description: Robert F. Meyer, president of Yankee Silver Smith Inn, Inc., a wellknown restaurant in Wallingford, Conn., died Saturday In New England Deaconess Hospital, Boston. He was 63 years old.

title: Kuh Asks Tribute to Hogan
description: Richard H. Kuh, the outgoing Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday urged Mayor Beame to rename the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street the Frank S. Hogan Criminal Court Justice Center, in honor of his predecessor. A spokesman for the Mayor said Mr. Kuh's proposal would be taken under advisement.

title: Bullets Defeat Bucks
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23 (UPI)The Washington Bullets took advantage of a bad shooting night by Kareem AbdulJabbar to hand the Milwaukee Bucks a 106103 overtime defeat in an N.B.A. game tonight.

title: Dr. Ellen D. Ellis, 96, Dies; Teacher of Political Science
description: Dr. Ellen Deborah Ellis, founder and first chairman of the political science department at Mount Holyoke College, died Friday in Wallingford, Pa., where she lived. Her age was 96.

title: URBANUNIT STUDY PLANNED BY CAREY
description: Warning that the State Urbar Development Corporation could run out of money in the next few weeks, Governor  elect Hugh L. Carey announced yes. terday that he would set up a task force to examine the seri. ous financial difficulties faced by the controversial housing agency.

title: JURY HEARS NIXON TERMED MAESTRO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  Lawyers for John N. Mitchell and John D. Ehrlichman suggested today in their final arguments at the Watergate coverup trial that Richard M. Nixon had been the maestro and the orchestra leader of the Watergate coverup.

title: Hanson Sued by United Artists Theatre
description: United Artists Theatre Circuit, Inc., operator of 511 movie theater unit properties and a considerable amount of commercial real estate, filed a suit yesterday to enjoin a British investment c o m p a n y, H a n s o n Trust Holding, Ltd., from purchasing United Artists Theatre stock. In an action filed in the Unites States Court of the Southern District of New York, United Artists Theatre charged that Hanson had acquired about 28 per cent of the movie exhibitor's 1,859,976 common shares.

title: Financial Disclosure
description: Responding reluctantly, but nearly unanimously, to public pressure for reform, the City Council his adopted a financial disclosure bill that is a landmark for the city and should become a guidepost for the State Legislature.

title: 3D DEPUTY MAYOR NAMED BY BEAME
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Mayor's legislative representative in Albany, will replace Judah Gribetz as Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Relations, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

title: People in Sports
description: The University of Washington hired Don James, Kent State football coach, yesterday to replace Jim Owens, who retired Nov. 26 after 18 years with the Huskies.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday stated incorrectly that American electric utilities had canceled or delayed construction of 27 per cent of nonnuclear plant capacity scheduled for completion in the 1974.83 period. The 27 per cent figure applies to both nuclear and nonnuclear capacity. According to a recent survey, the delayed or canceled capacity totals 132 billion watts, of which 89 billion were for nuclear and 43 billion for nonnuclear plants.

title: CHRYSLER SHIFTS BANK CREDIT LINE
description: The Chrysler Corporation which is facing critical financial problems in the face of drastic sales declines, yesterday announced that the nation's biggest banks had agreed to convert most of the company's lines of credit to single $400million revolving line due Jan. 31, 1978.

title: Kentucky Coal Mine Set
description: Pickands Mather & Co., a subsidiary of Moore McCormick Resources, Inc., along with the Ford Motor Company, the Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and Interlake, Inc., announced yesterday they would open a 1.25 milliontonsayear coal mine in about two years near Pikeville, Ky. Pickands Mather will develop and manage the joint venture.

title: USE OF AN AIRPORT DISPUTED 111 TEXAS
description: DALLAS, Dec. 20The Texas Supreme Court has refused to hear an appeal of a ruling that tiny Southwest Airlines could continue to use Love Field in Dallas. Both Dallas and Fort Worth legal officials said that efforts would continue to force the small commuter airline to transfer its operations to the DallasFort Worth regional airport.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Inexpensive gifts and stockingstuffers  costing less than $10 and suitable for the beginning, budding or experienced cookare among the easiest things to scoop up as time for Christmas giftbuying starts to fade.

title: Big Board and Others To Close Early Today
description: The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange will close at 2 P.M. today because of the Christmas holiday tomorrow. Other securities and commodities markets also plan early closings:

title: Toyota Cuts Spending Plans
description: TOKYO, Dec. 23 (Reuters)The Toyota car company will cut its planned capital expenditure in half in the next fiscal year because of a slump in domestic car sales, the company announced today. It said it would cut capital outlay to between $230million and $282million.

title: South Bronx Is Burning
description: As the South Bronx goes, it had been a quiet Friday night for the firemen of Engine Company 73.

title: MRS. HANAN POLIACOFF
description: Brain Abougoff Poliacoff, who with her late husband, Hanan Poliacoff, operated the former Poliacoff's kosher restaurant at 121 West 45th Street, near Broadway, died yesterday in Long Beach, L. I., where she lived. She was 84 years old.

title: SINGER CLOSINGS TO AFFECT 20,000
description: Plant closings for periods of up to three weeks affecting 20,000 workers here and abroad were announced here yesterday by the Singer Company. The moves are in addition to actions previously taken involving major reductions for indefinite periods, affecting employes both in plants and other facilities.

title: Justice A. Quinn, 14 Years On State Supreme Court, Dead
description: Justice Peter A. Quinn of the State Supreme Court, serving in the Appellate Term, died yesterday of cancer at Einstein Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived at 1 Metropolitan Oval, the Bronx.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1974

title: Christmas, 1974
description: In the year, of the darkness, In the year of the words, The millions of words, Accusing, excusing, breaking, Demanding, lying, refusing, In the year of the desert, In the year of the burning, In the year of the bombs When hatred pollutes the air, What we long for is silence.

title: Southend United Drawa
description: SOUTHEND, England, Dec. 23 (Reuters)Southend Unit 23 (Reuters)Southend United and Aldershot drew 11 in an English Fodtball League third division match tonight.

title: Brazil Beats Argentina In Tennis Despite Vilas
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 23 (Reuters)Brazil qualified for the Davis Cup South American tennis final by beating Argentina, 32, today.

title: Lions Rehire Forzano
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UPI) Rick Forzano, who took over the Detroit Lions' head coaching job when Don McCafferty died last July and directed the team to a 77 season signed a threeyear contract today.

title: COURT BLOCKS MOVE TO CUT LEAD IN GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) A Federal appeals court set aside today ruling by the Environmental Protection Agency that would have required the nation's oil companies to reduce the amount of lead in gasoline after the first of the year.

title: GOLD PRICE SETS NEWHIGHS ABROAD
description: LONDON, Dec. 23The price of gold climbed to record levels on the European bullion markets today, reflecting continued speculative interest in anticipation of the legalization of private ownership of gold by Americans on Dec. 31.

title: Continental Metals Unit Distributing Soviet Gold
description: The Continental Gold Corporation, a newly formed subsidiary of Continental Metals of New York, said yesterday it would become the sole United States distributor of Sovietgold to the American market. Previously the Soviet Union sold its gold on Western markets largely through Zurich gold trading banks.

title: 4 HELD IN KILLING FOLLOWING HOLDUP
description: DEPTFORD TOWNSHIP, Dec. 23 (AP)Four men were held on homicide, kidnapping and conspiracy charges today in connection with a holdup in Camden that was followed by a murder here.

title: Foreign Chiefs Find Ford to Their Liking
description: BONN, Dec. 23The foreign leaders who have met with President Ford in recent months say they have been impressed with his honesty, his personal warmth and his grasp of the issues.

title: Ford Signs Antitrust Bill; 2 Vetoes Attack Spending
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 23President Ford signed today legislation designed to strengthen the national antitrust laws and give the Government more authority to act against companies with inflationary policies.

title: Stars Win, 10399; Malone Scores 33
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 23 (UPI)  Utah's star rookie, Moses Malone, scored 33 points and grabbed 25 rebounds tonight to put the Stars in third place, 9 percentage points ahead of Indiana in the A.B.A.'s western division. The Stars won, 10399.

title: Theater: History of Squire Jonathan
description: After giving his hilarious, jumpingjack performance as the short apoplectic father in Scapino, Ian Trigger, the young British actor, moonlights on weekends Off Off Broadway in the title role of John Arden's mockheroic oneact comedy, The True History of Squire Jonathan and His Unfortunate Treasure.

title: 11 Are Presented at Cornelia Cotillion
description: Elevent young women, communicants at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L. I., students at the Cathedral School of St. Mary there, were presented to the Right Rev. Jonathan Goodhue Sherman, Episcopal Bishop of Long Island, at the Cathedral last evening. Then with their families and friends they went to the WaldorfAstoria for the reception, dinner and Cornelia Cotillion in the hotel's Grand Ballroom that completed the evening. Proceeds will go to the Charity of the Bishop's Call.

title: 7Hour Siege on S.I. Ends as Man Who Fired Shots Falls 6 Stories
description: A sevenhour siege that began when a 27yearold man fired two shots from his Staten Island apartment window into adjacent apartments ended at dawn yesterday when he jumped or fell six stories to the ground.

title: REGENTS WILL ASK $425MILLION RISE
description: ALBANY, Dec. 23The State Board of Regents will ask the new Legislature to increase the state's education appropriation by nearly $425million next year, with most of the money committed to help communities avoid higher taxes because of sharply rising school costs.

title: High Court Rules Utility Service May Be Cut Off Without Notice
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23Private utility companies have no constitutional obligation to give customers notice or a hearing before cutting off their service, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: MONTCLAIR STUDENT SETS HIMSELF AFIRE
description: MONTCLAIR, Dec. 23A. 21MONTCLAIR, Dec. 23A. 21yearold freshman at Montclair State College doused himself with charcoal lighter fluid an his dormitory room early this morning and lit a match in an apparent suicide attempt.

title: Alabama Defeats Va. Tech
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Dec. 23 (AP)Alabama's unbeaten eighth  ranked Crimson Tide, led by the inside scoring and rebounding of Leon Douglas, took the lead early in the first half and held off Virginia Tech's Gobblers for a 7773 basketball victory tonight.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL ROSE 2% FOR WEEK
description: Steel production has continued to rebound from the effects of the coal strike, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

title: Flagpole Sitter Toppled
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP) Vernon Woodrich's attempt to break the world record for sitting atop a flagpole ended prematurely when a strong gust of wind sent him toppling from his 35foot perch yesterday. Mr. Woodrich, 49 years old, was reported in satisfactory condition at Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital. He had spent 68 days on top of the ?? in his effort to surpass the 115day record.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
CHESTER D. TRIPP
description: Chester D. Tripp, a mining and metallurgical engineer who was president of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation until it was acquired in 1959 by the Cerro de Pasco Corporation, died Sunday in Passavant Hospital in Chicago. He was 92 years old.

title: Textile Unions Get $50,000 to End Suit
description: CHERAW, S.C., Dec. 23The nation's thirdlargest textile company has paid $50,000 to two labor organizations in an outofcourt settlement of wiretapping suit of 1973.

title: NIXON PAYS TAXES ON CITY HOME SALE
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon has paid $11,544 in taxes, penalties and interest owed to New York State from the sale of his cooperative apartment here in 1969, State Tax Commissioner Mario A. Procaccino disclosed yesterday.

title: KlansmanTeacher Is Ousted by State From Prison Post
description: Earl Schoonmaker, the Ku Klux Klan official who also teaches at a prison in the Catskills, was dismissed yesterday by the State Department of Correctional Services, a spokesman for the department in Albany said yesterday.

title: John W. Ryan Jr., 69. Dies; S.I.C. Member 1958 to 1972
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 23 (AP) John W. Ryan Jr., who was Chief Judge of the Buffalo City Court from 1950 to 1958, and then until his retirement in 1972 a member of the State Investigation Commission, died Friday at his home in suburban Orchard Park. He was 69 years old. John W. Ryan Jr., who was Chief Judge of the Buffalo City Court from 1950 to 1958, and then until his retirement in 1972 a member of the State Investigation Commission, died Friday at his home in suburban Orchard Park. He was 69 years old.

title: TEXAS GAS SET TO AID WORK ON SYNTHETIC
description: OWENSBORO, Ky., Dec. 23 (UPI)  The Texas Gas Transmission Company here plans to invest heavily in an Ann Arbor, Mich., company's research to develop a process to turn ordinary water into synthetic pipeline gas.

title: Shoplifting Rises Sharply, Costing $5Billion Yearly
description: Shoplifting, once considered a minor problem mostly involving juveniles and kleptomaniacs, has become one of the country's fastest  growing crimes and is costing merchants chants $5billion a year.

title: VENEZUELA SETS NATIONALIZATION
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 23 (UPI)Venezuela moved today to nationalize her oil and iron ore industries next year.

title: ARTHUR KRAMER
description: Arthur Kramer, who had been law secretary to the late Justice Bernard Botein and a writer of light verse for periodicals, died here Sunday' at the age of 71 He lived at 299 West 12th Street.

title: Dead Detective's Note Deplores Racism, This Terrible Injustice
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP)It was signed simply, A Human Being.

title: Iona Defeats Wagner
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 23Kevin Bass scored 22 points and grabbed 12 rebounds to lead Iona to a 7269 victory over Wagner tonight. Jim Garceau paced Wagner with 18 points. Iona has a 24 record. Wagner stands 35.

title: In Tense Rangoon, Burmese Are Grumbling Now Over Their Lot
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 23 By dusk Rangoon is a silent capital. Birds swirl around the goldenroofed pagodas and mongrels howl but the streets are empty and eerie.

title: MRS. MATT CLARK
description: Kathryn Speckman Clark, widow of Matt Clark, a magazine illustrator, died Sunday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital, She was 72 years old and lived at 400 East 55th Street.

title: Warriors Conquer Suns
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 23 AP)  Rick, Barry scored 26 points in the third quarter and 43 in the game to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 11194 N.B.A. victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

title: People and Business
description: Nathaniel Samuels, Deputy Under Secretary of State for economic affairs from 1969 to 1972, has been elected chairman of the Louis Dreyfus Corporation, a leading New York commodity firm. Mr. Samuels, who is 66, has been a general partner in the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb & Co, since leaving his Government post.

title: Saigon Has Holiday Glow Though War Intensifies
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23  The shopping streets of Saigon are choked with Christmas shoppers and Christmas onlookers, for this city masks its suffering well.

title: Leaders in State Regents Examinations Take Honors in Stride
description: The top winners in the annual Regents Scholarship examinations have been announced, and the state and city's high scorers are regarding their achievement with equanimity.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: STEEL TRIMS PRICE RISE BYE UNDER PRESSURE
description: In a surprise move, the United States Steel Corporation announced late yesterday that it was reducing by about 20 per cent the price increases announced a week ago. The increases had been challenged by the Ford Administration.

title: Linda Muller Wed To W. V. Vasu Jr.
description: Linda Muller, daughter of Mrs. Anita G. Muller of New York and Morton S. Muller of Kitchawan, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to William V. Vasu Jr., son of Mrs. Lucille Claudatos of Rockport, Mass., and the late William V. Vasu of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: Border Patrol Shifts Focus To AlienSmuggling Rings
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., Dec. 23 Unable to stem the flood of illegal Mexican aliens piuring across the border, the United States Border Patrol has stopped, arresting and prosecuting smalltime offenders in order to concentrate on the kingpins of large, professional smuggling rings.

title: Five Months for Namibia
description: A unanimous United Nations Security Councila rarity latelyhas given the Republic of South Africa five months to begin withdrawing from Namibia (SouthWest Africa), the former German colony it has controlled for more than fifty years. The United States, Britain and France, which vetoed a drive to expel South Africa from the U.N. in October and deplored its suspension from the General Assembly, supported the withdrawal resolution.

title: GOING OUT Guise
description: GOOD AND LASTING The enterprising Elgin Cinema on Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, begins today a threeweek revival of 27 specially selected, international features with Greetings (1968) and Hi, Mom! (1970), both by the young American director Brian De Palma, to be followed by works from Italy, France, Germany, Czechoslovakia, Japan and by other American entries. The program has five features directed by Akira Kurosawa, including Yojimbo (1961) and Throne of Blood (1957), next Sunday and Monday, and his Red Beard (1965) and Drunken Angel (1948) on New Year's Day. The festival concludes with a threeday presentation, Jan. 1214, of Fellini's La Strada (1954) and Pabst's Three Penny Opera (1931). For further program information, call 6759229 or 6750752.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Yankee Coaching Staff Retained

title: 3D DEPUTY MAYOR NAMED BY BERME
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Mayor's legislative representative in Albany, will replace Judah Gribetz as Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Relations, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

title: Aging Stars Play Jan. 2
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 23 (AP)  The Tennis Grand Masters, with headquarters here, announced today that the group of 45yearsandover stars would hold its first 1975 tournament Jan. 2 at Melbourne, Australia. The players, including Frank Sedgman, Pancho Segura and Pancho Gonzales, will be competing for $21,500.

title: Mayor's Rabbi Quits City Job; He Cites Unjustified Criticism
description: Mayor Beanie accepted the resignation last night of Rabbi David Haymovitz as a $32,000ayear mayoral appointee in the Human Resources Administration. The appointment had been assailed by sgme city union leaders.

title: Chess: A Strong Center Is a Plus First, Last and Always
description: The advantage of a strong pawn center usually shows up best either in the middle game, exerting a cramping effect on the defender's pieces, or in the opening, permitting line, opening thrusts that yield sudden attacks. Yet even in the end game the control of important terrain it gives can be a vital factor in determining the outcome.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: Enthusiasm

title: Nursing Homes Call State Inquiry Illegal
description: Lawyers for 48 nursing homes and operators in the city argued in State Supreme Court yesterday that the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs had no right to investigate their clients, had not legally served them with subpoenas and, in fact, did not legally exist.

title: Top Newspaper in Brazil Is 100
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil  Bra zil's leading newspaper, O Es. tado de So Paulo, will cele. brate its centennial Jan. 4, proudly defiant of economic and political pressures.

title: Not Guilty Plea Is Entered On Payment to Union Aides
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 23 (UPI) A former official of a bankrupt modular home compan pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here today to charges of making illegal loans and stock transactions to labor officials.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1974

title: I.T.T., IN A SNIFF, TAKES AVIS PLAN
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday reversed its stand and offered in Federal Court in Hartford to accept a Justice Department proposal for the divestiture of its remaining 52 per cent interest in Avis, Inc.

title: FMC to Increase Prices Of FoodGrade Phosphates
description: The FMC Corporation announced yesterday that its foodgrade phosphates would be increased by 50 cents to $5.80 per hundredweight effective Jan. 1 to noncontract accounts and as terms permit to contract accounts.

title: NEW TACK TAKEN TO SAVE HOEING
description: In what city officials announced yesterday as an unprecedented approach to stemming housing decay, the city has successfully pressed the owner of 200 deteriorating, violationridden Manhattan apartment buildings to give up managing them for at least 18 months.

title: Market Place
description: The conventional wisdom in Wall Street is that if you plan to buy shares of only one company within an industry you can hardly go wrong by choosing the leader.

title: Westchester Budget Approved As Appropriations Are Reduced
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 23The Westchester Board of Legislators approved a 1975 budget of $307million today, reducing the appropriations proposed by Alfred B. DelBello, the Democratic County Executive, by $500,000 and finding $3.4million in new revenues.

title: Successor to Mills Pledges to Speed Sizable Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. (AP) Representative Al Ullman, acting chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that the panel would move early next year to approve a sizable tax cut.

title: Ashe Downs Gorman
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 23 (Agence FrancePresse)Arthur Ashe fought back to defeat a fellow American Tom Gorman, 36, 63, 76, in the final of the Galaxy Cup tennis tournament yesterday. The victor received $12,000.

title: The Other News
description: International

title: Books of The Times
description: THE EUROPEAN DISCOVERY OF AMERICA: THE SOUTHERN VOYAGES, 14921616. By Samuel Eliot Morison. 758 pages. Oxford University Press. $17.50.

title: Carol in a Time of Nontente
description: Once more 'tis the season of Handel and hollyAway with unreason, away with old folly. Go toss on the embers some A.T.&T., A sprinkling of Exxon andwhy not?G.E., All other debris of the brokers' bright fustianWhat else is so gay as a blue chip's combustion? So pile on the Chrysler and then the du Pont, Add slats from the cratethat was labeled Dtente, The shreds of the Charter, the flotsam of NATO, The frame of a world as delenda as Cato, The clay from the insteps of J. Edgar Hoover, The day of our Captain as shaker and mover, The beams of the ceiling we set for our spending, The seams of all budgets now current or pending... Enough! Though the flames cast a circle of cheer, Yet the prospect beyond isLord help us!austere. Old Santa may bring us no ashes and switches But a twelvemonth will put a keen shine to our britches. The moral is plain: Curb that fancy to roam: This Christmas let's nurture the habit of home.

title: Ford Signs Antitrust Bill; 2 Vetoes Attack Spending
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 23President Ford signed today legislation designed to strengthen the national antitrust laws and give the Government more authority to act against companies with inflationary policies.

title: No Gas Shortage Forecast
description: SPRINGFIELD. Dec. 23 (UPI) Jerry Ferrara, president of the New Jersey Gasoline Retailers Association, says tat residents should not experience shortages comparable to last year, but that gas prices may soon rise. However, he said that a survey of gas stations showed that the current down ward trend in the price of gaswould be reversed.

title: JURY HEARS NIXON TERMED MAESTRO
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  Lawyers for John N. Mitchel and John D. Ehrlichman suggested today in their final arguments at the Watergate cover up trial that Richard M. Nixon had been the maestro and the orchestra leader of the Watergate coverup.

title: SUN GARDEN SUING 3 SUGAR REFINERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP)A class action civil damage suit was filed today by a food processor against three of six sugar refining companies indicted last week by a Federal grand jury on charges of illegal price fixing.

title: Hanson Sued by United Artists Theatre
description: United Ariists Theatre Circuit, Inc., operator of 511 movie theater unit properties and a considerable amount of commercial real estate, filed a suit yesterday to enjoin a British investment company, Hanson Trust Holding, Ltd., from purchasing United Artists Theatre stock. In an action filed in the Unites States Court of the Southern District of New York, United Artists Theatre charged that Hanson pad acquired about 28 per cent of the movie exhibitor's 1,859,??976 common shares.

title: Syrians Order a Full Alert During the Holiday Period
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 23 I(AP)Syria has put her armed forces on a maximum alert as is precaution against any Israeli attack during the Moslem feast of Al Adha and the Christmas holiday, the Beirut newpaper Al Liwa reported today.

title: Trinity Church Is Selling 10 Properties
description: Trinity Church is offering for sale 10 of its 24 commercial properties in Lower Manhattan because they are losing money.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page ??

title: Find the Airport
description: Investigations of recent plane crashes suggest that there has been an unacceptable relaxation of precautions at the controls. The airlines superb safety record of recent years may itself have contributed to a more cavalier attitude toward the safety manual. This year's record of 461 fatalitiesthe worst since 1960underscores the need for instant tightening of procedures.

title: Tunisian Feasting Assailed
description: TUNIS, Dec. 24 (UPI)  A newspaper here complained that 450,000 sheep were sacrificed in Tunisia today, according to estimates, for the Moslem holiday of Id alAdha, decimating the country's flocks. Tunisians on this religious holiday ate 6,000 tons of meat, or a tenth of the country's annual meat consumption.

title: A Living UNESCO
description: The selfdestruct button that was pushed in Paris by the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is having repercussions throughout the civilized world. One by one, UNESCO is losing its intellectual resources. No amount of petrodollars can replace the scientists, scholars and academicians who are withdrawing their names and skills because of the action taken barring Israel from receiving a minute amount of aid or even having a voice in the heretofore nonpolitical agency.

title: Recession or Depression and How Deep?
description: Are we in a recession or a depression? Obviously the question is not one of mere semantics. But before the question can be answered, the terms recession and depression must be defined. Among economists, unfortunately, there are no standard definitions of the terms. Back in 1936, when Prof. Gottfried Haberler_ wrote his classic study, Prosperity and Depression, for the League of Nations, he did not use the term recession at all.

title: The Little Boy at Christ's Christmas Tree
description: A boy still very small, six years old or even less, awoke in the morning in a damp cold cellar. He was dressed in a sort of little long coat, and he shivered. His breath flew away in white steam, and as he sat on a chest in the corner, out of boredom he purposely blew this steam from his mouth, and amused himself by watching how it flew away. But he was very hungry. Several times since morning he had gone up to the cot where his sick mother lay on mattress thin as a pancake, with sort of bundle under her head instead of a pillow. How did she feel now? Apparently she had come with her little boy from a strange city and suddenly fallen ill.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Dec. 24, 1974

title: Cosmos 99 for Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Dec, 21 (UPI) The Soviet Union today launched Cosmos 699, a satellite designed to carry out orbital science experiments, the Tass news agency said. The unmanned satellite, Tass said, is circling the earth every 93.2 minutes and all components aboard the craft are functioning normally.

title: State Loans Seek to Spur Upswing in Industrial Jobs
description: BERGENFIELD, Dec. 24The state's recently formed Economic Development Authority expects to complete six to eight new industrial financing deals in the next 30 days, and is negotiating the terms on 30 othersall in the hope of helping to reverse a trend that has seen New Jersey lose 70,000 manufacturing jobs in the last three years.

title: MAN REPORTED FREED FOR 100,000 RANSOM
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP)A reputed Detroit criminal figure was kidnapped for four days last week and released only after friends paid $100,000 ransom, top Michigan law enforcement sources said yesterday.

title: Holiday Shopping Ends Briskly
description: The Christmas shopping season wound up yesterday after three strong days, fulfilling many retailers' hopes that the brisk finish of the 22day season would offset a persistent earlier lag.

title: Safety Unit Warns Of Child Car Seats Sold in Three Cities
description: About 1,300 child car seats sold in New York City, Philadelphia and Chicago do not provide adequate protection in crashes and sudden stops, On Department of Transportation warned today.

title: Carey's Press Chief Now Serves Wilson
description: Just three months ago, Harry J. O'Donnell, speaking on behalf of Governor Wilson, publicly described a speech my Hugh L. Carey as a perfect example of political pollution.

title: Syrian Mosaic Returned By the Newark Museum
description: NEWARKWith the blessing of Secretary of State Kissinger and the State Department, the Newark Museum has quietly returned an important art work that had been stolen in Syria and then smuggled out of that country.

title: Victim Is Identified And 3 Are Accused In Insurance Killing
description: LEXINGTON, S. C., Dec. 24 (AP)  Lexington County authorities say they have identified the real victim of what they say was a murderforinsurance scheme.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OLD FAITHFUL One of the best, cheapest and most novel goingout diversions in New York is the very takenforgranted Statue of Liberty. On a day when most museums and many other places are closed, and families tend to cluster snugly around the home hearth, it's good to remember that it's there, only a 15minute boat ride from the tip of Battery Park, and open every day of the year unless the weather is ruled fierce at Liberty Island by the custodians, the National Park Service.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court reduced the sentence of Louis Hodges for armed robbery but upheld his conviction. He had been convicted of the armed robbery of a Mercer County supermarket in 1971 and been sentenced to a total of 32 years in state prison on charges of robbery, armed robbery and illegal possession of a gun. The appeals court reduced the term to a maximum of 15 years.

title: Market Place Gold Will Test Investor Courage
description: The prospect of trading in gold, whether directly through the purchase of bullion or indirectly through the various commodities exchanges, is perhaps the most exciting new investment game to come alone since silver was freed for trading on June 12, 1963.

title: Children, Too, Are Heeding Appeal of the Neediest
description: Busisness people, married couples and children were among the contributors yesterday to the 63d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 2 HardtoPlace Boys Get Real Home
description: EAST MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Dec. 24For the first time in their lives, John and Keith are home for Christmas.

title: REV. DANIEL KELLEHER
description: (AP)The Rev. Daniel J. Kelleher, a wartime chaplain at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., died Saturday in Boston. He was 66 years old.

title: FAMILY FOOD COST PUT AT NEW PEAK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The retail cost of a year's supply of farmproduced groceries rose $19 in November to another record; with all of the increase due to higher middleman charges, new figures by the Agriculture Department indicated today.

title: Memories, Bitter and Sweet, of Christmas in the Depression
description: Eva. Kilburn, an East Sider in her 50's, remembered how her family went on drinking Christmas syllabub from silver punch cups during the Great Depression, just as though her grandfather's bank had never failed.

title: Markets Idle Today
description: All securities, commodity and currency exchanges in the United States and Canada will be closed today, Christmas day.

title: Court Status Is Disputed By Figure in Agnew Case
description: An attorney for I. H. Hammerman, who said re collected money for former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew in an extensive Maryland kickback scheme, says the threejudge Federal court panel that sentenced his client was unconstitutional.

title: College Basketball Polls
description: The top 20, with points figured on a 201816141210987654321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace vote in parentheses) and wonlost records through games of last Saturday:

title: Cyprus Mines Writing Off Island Copper investment
description: The Cyprus Mines Corporation announced yesterday plans to write off its entire investment in the copper mine or Cyprus and will take an aftertax charge of $3million in the fourth quarter. The mine was closed shortly after the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in July and the company said it had been unable to reach agreement on reopening on a marginal operation. The mine provided about 4 per cent of the company's net income of $32.5million in the first half.

title: Maple's Double: $1,316
description: Eddie Maple turned out to be a Santa Claus disguised in jockey's silks yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Soviet Reneges on Visas for the Leviches
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24A Soviet emigration official has proposed that Veniamin G. Levich, the highest ranking Jewish scientist to have applied to emigrate, pledge that he will not seek to join his two sons if they are allowed to emigrate.

title: People in Sports; Woman Boxer (230) Is Suing for a License, Won't Fight Men
description: I've never boxed a man and have no desire to, said Jackie Tonawanda, a 26year  old light  heavyweight, who filed a suit with the State Human Rights Commission yesterday against the State Athletic Commission. She said the commission had violated her constitutional rights by refusing to act on her application for a boxing license, which she submitted Oct. 8.

title: Baby Cereals Halted
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 24 (AP)  The H. J. Heinz Company says it has temporarily stopped shipment of all instant baby cereals while it investigates how twisted metal slivers reportedly got into two boxes of instant rice cereal.

title: Japan Fighting Her Biggest Oil Spill
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24The biggest oil spill in Japan's history spread through the scenic Inland Sea today, polluting an area more than 80 miles long and 20 miles wide.

title: JULIUS RYKOVICH MERRILLVILLE, Ind Dec. 24
description: (AP)Julius Rykovich, a former Chicago Bears football player, died yesterday of cancer. He was 51 years old.

title: MANY PHONE UNITS SEEK RATE RISES
description: Telephone companies from coast to coast are seeking rate increases for everything from payphone calls to installation charges, contending they need the extra money to keep up with inflation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly stated that the Texas Supreme Court had refused to hear an appeal of a ruling involving Southwest Airlines and Love Field in Dallas. The United States Supreme Court refused to hear the appeal.

title: STATE BOARD BARS PARITY INCREASES FOR PUBLIC UNIONS
description: In a decision that could ultimately upset New York City's labor contracts with its sanitationmen and firemen, the State Public Employment Relations Board has ruled that one public employe union cannot be guaranteed higher wages simply because another union gets more.

title: Banks to Hold State Funds
description: TRENTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The state announced today that 21 banks had bid successfully for a total of $7.8million in state deposits to be placed lin accounts Jan. 2 at interest rates ranging from 8.1 per cent to 8.8 per cent. The deposits were awarded to the banks under a bidding system instituted this year by State Treasurer Richard C. Leone to protect state deposit practices from political influence.

title: City Opens Inquiries On Impart Report For Planned Center
description: The city began two investigations yesterday into charges that an environmental impaot, statement on the convention center that is proposed for the West Side was altered to make the statement favorable to the center.

title: Three North Carolina Men Killed in. Texas Plane Crash
description: VIDOR, Tex., Dec. 24 (AP) rnvestigators rummaged througn Christmas presents and wreckage today in an effort to determine the cause of a plane crash yesterday that killed three North Carolina men on their way to Houston.

title: Christmas 1974
description: Traditional institutions, religious and secular, are most severely tested in times of stress and uncertainty, times when they must demonstrate their capacity to respond the human yearning for renewed confidence and strength. Such a time is now, at Christmas.

title: Bridge: Optimism About a Contract Needs Modest Assumptions
description: In playing an optimistic contract, a declarer should assume that the opposing cards will lie favorably. He must assume a distribution that will allow the contract to succeed, but he should still keep his assumptions to a minimum.

title: Ford Accepts Resignation Of Eberle as Trade Official
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24President Ford accepted with deep regret today the resignation of William D. Eberle from his twin White House jobs of Special Representative for Trade Negotiations and executive secretary of the Council on International Economic Policy.

title: LOTTERY NUMBER
6 NATO COUNTRIES PLAN OIL DEFENSE
description: LONDON, Dec. 23Six member countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are planning a defense of pumping rigs in the oil and gas fields of the North Sea against possible attack by such terrorist groups as the Irish Republican Army and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Ghost of Tax Not Passed Shuns Quiet State House
description: TRENTON, Dec. 24On the day before Christmas, the State House here probably is very much like other capitols in other states. There's a big wreath above the massive front entrance on West State Street and there is a tree in Governor Byrne's outer office that rises almost 15 feet, much too tall for anyone's living room.

title: Seattle Sets an Example In RevenueSharing Role
description: SEATTLEWhen the Federal program of general revenue sharing was approved by Congress in 1972, it was accompanied by a large amount of rhetoric about how it would enhance community participation in allocating the money.

title: Roche, Once Future Net King, Is Playing Like a Prince Again
description: With his first tournament victory in almost three years, Tony Roche may be coming back. The 29yearold Australian southpaw was regarded as the heir to Rod Laver as the world No. 1. Then he hurt his elbow and shoulder in 1969 and went into a decline. He tried all kinds of cures, but nothing helped until, in desperation, he went to a faith healer in the Philippines. Since then, he has made steady progress.

title: Pontiff Opens Holy Year, Offers Prayers for Peace
description: ROME, Wednesday, Dec. 25 Pope Paul VI solemnly opened the 25th Holy Year of the Roman Catholic Church late last night, and in a Christmas mass after midnight prayed for peace on earth.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALL PEOPLE ARE FAMOUS. By Harold Clurman, 327 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $8.95.

title: STATE BOARD BARS PARITY INCREASES FOR PUBLIC UNIONS
description: In a decision that could ultimately upset New York City's labor contracts with its sanitationmen and firemen, the State Public Employment Relations Board has ruled that one public employe union cannot be guaranteed higher wages simply because another union gets more.

title: ROCKEFELLER PANEL TO BE CONTINUED
description: President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller have agreed to continue the operations of Mr. Rockefeller's National Commission on Critical Choices for Americans, a Rockefeller spokesman said yesterday.

title: U. S. OIL INDUSTRY IN EGYPTIAN DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 United States companies have signed 12 oil exploration agree ments with Egypt in recent days, a Treasury official reported today.

title: Maker of Auto Carpeting To Shut Plant Two Weeks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP)  Slumping automobile sales have forced. C. H. Masland & Sons, one of the nation's largest carpet manufacturers, to Shut down its Carlisle, Pa., plant for two weeks. The action. taken yesterday, forced 850 employes at the plant, devoted exclusively to the manufacture of carpets for automobiles, to take a Christmas vacation without pay.

title: 155,900 More Join Ranks of Jobless Filing for Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The Labor Department said today that 155,900 more persons sought unemployment benefits in the week ended Dec. 7 an increase of threetenths of 1 per cent from a week earlier.

title: Toyota Cuts Spending Plans
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Toyota, the auto manufacturer, will cut its planed capital expenditures in half in the next fiscal year because of a slump in domestic sales, the company said yesterday. Capital outlays will be cut, between $230million and $262million.

title: Contract Awards
description: The PhilcoFord Corporation, a unit of the Ford Motor Company received a $17.1million Navy contract for guidance and control equipment for Sidewinder airtoair missiles.

title: Court Rules SeatBelt Use May Affect Cash Damages
description: In its last group of decisions this year the State Court of Appeals ruled that the failure of a person injured in an automobile accident to wear a seat belt might limit his recovery of damages.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: North Carolina Five Wins in Spain

title: Civil Rights Optimism Rekindled
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 24When the United States Supreme Court ruled last July against busing students between city and suburban schools in the Detroit area, many civil rights lawyers became pessimistic about further progress in classroom desegregation in America. These lawyers had seen involuntary exchange of students between school systems or forced merger of systems as the ultimate way to keep whites from fleeing to the suburbs to escape integration in the cities, where most blacks live.

title: Ondine III Favored In Hobart Sail
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 24 (Agence FrancePresse) The 91foot American aluminumhulled ketch Ondine III is favored for both line honors and the race record in the SydneyHobart sailing race, which starts Thursday.

title: Mystery Still Surrounds British M.P. Arrested in Australia
description: LONDON, Dec. 24An intriguing chapter in the story of the British Member of Parliament who disappeared from Miami Beach more than a month ago has opened with his arrest in Australia, where he has turned up under an assumed name.

title: November Sales Off 20.6% For Used Machine Tools
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) Sales of used machine tools were down 20.6 per cent in November from October and the dollar volume was down 11.6 per cent, the Machinery Dealers National Association said today.

title: CHRYSLER TO CUT WORKER BENEFITS
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to suspend costofliving benefit payments to 18,000 of its 39,000 whitecollar workers in the latest of many recent efforts to cut operating costs.

title: Dollars From Heaven Go Unclaimed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP)  Nearly $600 remained Unclaimed today after the money, all in crisp dollar bills, floated over Chicago's business district.

title: Giscard: II And Uncle Sam
description: PARISPresident Valery Giscard d'Estaing likes to describe French foreign policy with the grandiose label of globalism, meaning both a desire to be friends with everyone and also to join in safeguarding world resources plus protecting the ecological balance. Yet, in fact, he has quietly taken pains to steer France to course of closer friendship with the United States.

title: U.S. Aide in Gurney. Case Completes Term for Bribery
description: GREEN COVE SPRINGS, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP)A former Federal housing official, William Pelski, a key witness in the bribery case against former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, has been released from jail.

title: HELMS DISAVOWS ILLEGAL SPYING BY THE C.I.A IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The State Department said today, that Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence and now the Ambassador to Iran, had categorically denied that the C.I.A. conducted any illegal domestic spying under his leadership.

title: Clean Air Code on Airports And Stadiums Is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The Environmental Protection Agency postponed today for six months the enforcement of cleanair standards that would require a review of plans for shopping centers, highways, stadiums and airports.

title: BETHLEHEM RITES TIGHTLY GUARDED
description: BETHLEHEM, Dec. 24 Under rigorous security precautions, thousands of Christian pilgrims celebrated today the birth of Jesus.

title: Officially, New Hampshire Has Senator
description: CONCORD. N. H., Dec. 24Now it's officialsort of.

title: Bluebonnet Excitement Buds Late
description: One of the smallest crowds in the AstroBluebonnet Bowl 16year history and a national television audience saw two games for the price of one at the Astrodome last night.

title: HOYT BRAWNER
description: DENVER, Dec, 24 (AP)Hoyt Brawner athletic director at the University of Denver since 1962, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: Famous fur trader

title: People and Business Steel Makers Look to AEnergy
description: The world steel community has placed top priority on the use of nuclear energy to produce steel, Charles B. Baker, secretary general of the International Iron and Steel Institute, said in a recent interview here.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
About New York
description: Christmas came reluctantly, and sometimes it seemed that it ought not to have come at all. The economy was in a mess, and the Mayor was laying off in Civil Service. Traffic had never been worse, and the weather wasn't much, either. Christmas was coming up a bummer.

title: Greece's Draft Constitution Is Denounced by Opposition
description: ATHENS, Dec. 24 (Reuters) Greece's proposed new constitution giving the president extensive powers was condemned today by opposition leaders as a charter for totaliItarianism.

title: Marks S. Shaine, Physician And Editor, is Dead at 92
description: Dr. Marks S. Shaine, a retired physician and former associate editor of The Review of GastroEnterology, died Sunday in a nursing home in Westfield. N. J. He was 92 years old and lived at 50 Riverside Drive.

title: Unions Complain of Lockout In McDonnell Douglas Move
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)Unions complained to the National Labor Relations Board today that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had revived the lockout as a bargaining technique, shutting off Christmas Week pay to 21,000 workers.

title: LOTTERY NUMBER
Alerted by Victim in Underwear, Citizen Catches Holdup Suspect
description: When Harry Ryttenberg spotted Jay Robbins running out of his Bronx realestate office at 200 East 170th Street in his underwear yesterday, it immediately aroused my suspicionseven though it was Christmas Eve.

title: Clown Lets Children Get Into the Act
description: The clown with the mixmatched shoes, as one child described him, set up his hoops and scarves and magic tricks at the sea lion pool at the Central Park Zoo. Giggling children began to gather, and 45yearold Joseph Gitnig, alias Pegasus, put on a free show.

title: PANEL CRITICIZES FORD ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) A United States Civil Rights Commission staff report on the Boston school busing controversy asserts that the situation may mark a critical turning point in American racial history. It adds that President Ford has contributed to the problem.

title: HOMES FOR AGED LINKED TO CRIME
description: Investigations into the New York nursing home industry turned yesterday to allegations of underworld ties and political protection, and the report that an alleged associate of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed underworld figure, had lived in the penthouse of a nursing home for the indigent:

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (TelevisionChannels 10 and H (cable), 7:30 P.M.) (RadioWHEW, 7:30 P.M.)

title: Price of Seat Declines
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported a seat sale yesterday at $70,000, down 0,000 from the day before,

title: CANADIAN CHARGES U.S. INTERFERENCE
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 24 (AP) Alistair W. Gillespie, Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce, accused the United States today of intolerable interference in Canada's business affairs after a United States company had ordered its Canadian subsidiary to halt a sale of $500,000 worth of office furniture to Cuba.

title: W. R. Grace Shifts to LIFO
description: W. R. Grace & Co., the diversified industrial concern, is changing substantially of of its domestic chemical operations to a lastin, firstout method, of inventory valuation for 1974 results, the company has announced. Changing to the LIFO basis wil reduce earnings by about $15million and cut the company's incometax liability by about $12million.

title: Marven Gardens Pass Go for Monopoly Fair
description: MARGATE, N. J., Dec. 24 (AP)The city commission has voted to change the spelling of the Marven Gardens section of town for one day in honor of the coming International Monopoly Day in nearby Atlantic City.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 24 (AP) A State Department spokesman said today that Litton Industries had decided not to go ahead with the sale after informal inquiries at the Treasury Department.

title: EDWARD M'NALLY, 80, RAN TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: Edward T. McNally. general superintendent of the New York City transit system from 1947 until his retirement in 1958, died on Monday in WilkesBarre, Pa. He was 80 years old and lived in White Haven, Pa. Mr. McNally, who began as railroad telegrapher on the Lehigh Valley Railroad, was named train clerk and telegraph operator of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit System in 1911.

title: KARL F. MILDE
description: Karl F. Milde, a former business executive and active farmer and conservationist in Litchfield, Conn., died there Monday at the age of 73.

title: UTILITY SHUTOFFS UP 11% OVER '73 FIGURE
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 24 (AP)Northeast Utilities says the number of service terminations for nonpayment of bills has increased 11 per cent this year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly stated that the Texas Supreme Court had refused to hear an appeal of a ruling involving Southwest Airlines and Love Field in Dallas. The United States Supreme Court refused to hear the appeal.

title: City Statue Gets a Gold Coating
description: The neoclassic, 25foot, female figure call Civic Fame which crowns the tower of the Municipal Building, has been shined up with 2,800 squart feet of new goldleaf at a cost of $42,000.

title: 2 HardtoPlace Boys Get Real Home
description: EAST MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Dec. 24For the first time in their lives, John and Keith are home for Christmas.

title: Ford Jests That He'd Trade Presidency for Job in Vail
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 24  A light snow was falling and the temperature was 12 below this morning when President Ford  surrounded by about 20 skiers who included a couple dressed as Mr. and Mrs. Santa Clausskillfully descended Simba Trail.

title: NOMES FOR ACED LINKED TO CRIME
description: Investigations into the New York nursing home industry turned yesterday to allegations of underworld ties and political protection, and the report that an alleged associate of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed underworld figure, had lived in the penthouse of a nursing home for the indigent.

title: Jewish Group Says Rabbi Was Hounded Out of Post
description: The New York Board of Rabbis said yesterday that Rabbi David Haymovitz, who resigned a $32,000ayear position with the Human Resources Administration, had been literally hounded out of office, and suggested that the attack upon him was an attack on the Jewish community.

title: Proxmire's Working Holiday
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 24 (UPI)  Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, will spend Christmas day working for eight hours in the kitchen of a Salvation Army center here. He also plans to work on New Year's Day, when he will offer his services to the Madison police department in an effort to learn about the program there for the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration.

title: Dance: Witty and Supple
description: Murray Louis has trained himself and his company to move in a witty and superlatively supple way. The dancers always seem to be vaguely surprised by spurts of motor energy that propel them about. Mr. Louis's natural creative inclination is for amusing observation of people and events, and the combination of humorous mind and muscle at the top level of his work is delightful. When only the superb training is evident, as in Monday night's program at New York University's School of Education auditorium, the display is intriguing but vaguely unsatisfactory.

title: Democratic Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 24 (UPI) Lieut. Gov.elect Robert K. (Killian of Connecticut has been (named to the executive committee of the newly formedi National Conference of Democratic Statewide Elected Officials, the group announced. The conference was established to give the Democratic officials other than. Governors a chance to influence party strategy.

title: A Holy Year Starts
description: Enacting a ceremony introduced by Pope Paul II in 1475, Pope Paul VI opened the Holy Year yesterday in Rome by tapping the huge marble door of St. Peter's Basilica. The event, viewed by millions around the globe on television, initiated what promises to become a critical year of selfscrutiny by Catholicism and its sister branches of Christianity.

title: Goldman's Finances Investigated by U.S.
