description: A Federal grand jury is investigating the finances of Irving Goldman, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, and has heard testimony that he used the Jola Candy Corporation, a family business, to criminally evade income taxes, according to a Federal prosecutor's affidavit disclosed yesterday.

title: Watergate Jury Has GiftShopping Day
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The jurors at the Watergate coverup trial were permitted to purchase gifts today before spending Christmas with their families.

title: GOULD INCREASES ITE STAKE TO 13%
description: Gould, Inc., of Chicago, has increased its stake in the ITE Imperial Corporation to more than one million shares and now owns 13.3 per cent of ITE's common stock, the company said yesterday. Its latest purchase of 112,674 shares of ITE gives Gould a total of 1.08 million shares, worth more than $13million. Gould said, however, that it had agreed with ITE's management not to purchase any more ITE shares until the companies have had an opportunity to meet and discuss the situation. Gould said such a meeting would take place early next year.

title: SALES BY CHAINS SHOW SLIGHT RISE
description: Sales of the nation's leading chain stores in November gained 5.5 per cent from November, 1973, the smallest increase since April, 1972, when the gain was 5.1 per cent.

title: Petty Corruption Worries the Burmese
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 23The Burmese, overwhelmed by inflation and frightened by their repressive Government, are embarrassed, even demeaned, by the petty corruption and black marketeering they are forced to engage in.

title: F.C.C. Asks Extension of TV Violence Deadline
description: Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has asked Congress to extend the agency's deadline for regulatory action designed to protect children from television programs with excessive violence or obscenity.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1974
description: International

title: Matthews Jazzmen Serve The Big Sound Rousingly
description: Over the last decade there hav,e been many attempts to start what might be termed instant big jazz bands. The technique is to begin as at a rehearsal band meeting once a week, stock it from the pool of skilled studio musicians available in New York and play charts by arrangers who have mane some reputation writing for other big hands. The resuit, almost invariably, is a band that gains instant anonyibity because, not surprisingly, it sounds like every other band that uses these same musicians and arrangers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There is clear evidence that, as chief U.S. delegate John A. Scali warned the U.N. General Assembly on Dec. 6, support for the U.N. among the American people is eroding. One reason for this is the fact that in the past year the U.N. General Assembly has practiced selective outrage at violations of human rights.

title: MOHAWK COUNCIL CONVENING TODAY
description: The council of nine chiefs of the Mohawk nation will hold an inquiry today into shootings that have taken place on a 612acre Adirondack site that the Indians claim as their sovereign soil and thus beyond the jurisdiction of United States and New York law.

title: $3.7Million Sought in Death
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) The survivors of a Beaumont man who was sucked out the broken window of an airplane flying over New Mexico have filed a $3.7million suit against National Airlines, Inc. The suit, filed in Federal District Court yesterday, said that G. F. Gardner, 45 years, old, had been sucked out a broken window while flying from Houston to San Francisco Nov. 3, 1973.

title: Ballet Theater Sparkles With Coppelia
description: This Christmas New York is getting more than trees, baubles and boxes. American Ballet Theater has come to town at the City Center 55th Street Theater, and it opened on Monday night, for a six weeks' season. Ballet Theater is also celebrating its 35th anniversary. That is by no means bad. Let us hear a moment of silence for Ballet Theater's glorious 35th.

title: 3 Concerns Agree to Build Large Sugar Mill in Sudan
description: TOKYO, Dec, 24 (Reuters) Companies in Britain, Kuwait and Japan have reached an agreement with the Sudanese Government to build what they say will beone of the world's biggest sugar mills in Sudan, it was announced here today.

title: Stocks Edge Up in a Technical Rebound
description: A technical recovery enabled the stock market to show a modest gain yesterday on lower trading because of an abbreviated session.

title: United Air Lines P??ots Bar Pact With 31Month Rise to $80,616
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) Representatives of United Air Lines pilots have rejected a proposed contract that would have increased pay for senior pilots by $14,000 to $80,616, over the next 31 months.

title: In Christmas Gesture, Wilson Commutes 5 Murder Sentences
description: Exercising traditional Christmas clemency, Governor Wilson yesterday commuted the life sentences of five killers, including John Cruz, a lower East Side gang leader who shot to death a 15yearold girl in 1959.

title: Vikings' Page Shoulders Aside A Hege OfftheField Problem
description: To the millions of television viewers, who watch him methodically stalk opposing passers and running backs, Alan Page is a study in cold efficiency, perhaps the premier defensive player in profootball.

title: BulldozerMaker a Success in Japan
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24Perched precariously high above the roof of the Komatsu Building in downtown Tokyo is a giant yellow bulldozer, visible for blocks. It is not pop art.

title: BETHLEHEM RITES TIGHTLY GUARDED,
description: BETHLEHEM, Dec. 24 Under rigorous security precautions, thousands of Christian pilgrims celebrated today the birth of Jesus.

title: Cache of Cocaine Is Found In Table Leg on Freighter
description: About 11 pounds of cocaine with a street value of $2.3million were found by United States Customs officers yesterday morning in a routine search of a Colombian freighter berthed at a pier in Brooklyn.

title: About New York Despite All, It's Still Christmas
description: Christmas came reluctantly, and sometimes it seemed that it ought not to have come at all. The economy was in a mess, and the Mayor was laying off in Civil Service. Traffic had never been worse, and the weather wasn't much, either. Christmas was coming up a bummer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A fireman trimming the firehouse Christmas tree on his own time last Friday evening volunteered to ride with his comrades to help fight a fivealarm fire at 83d Street and Broadway. Over the weekend he complained of chests pains and yesterday the department announced that he had died Monday, apparently of a heart attack.

title: Leonard S. Schleifer Weds Harriet Partel
description: Harriet Linda Partel and Leonard Steven Schleifer were married last night at Congregation Ohr Torah of the North Woodmere (L. I.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Theodore Jungreis.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
Goldman's Finances Investigated by U.S.
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating the finances of Irving Goldman, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, and has heard testimony that he used the Jola Candy Corporation, a family business, to criminally evade income taxes, according to a Federal prosecutor's affidavit disclosed yesterday.

title: Blasts Block Descent Into Antarctic Volcano
description: SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Scientists hoping to make a descent into the crater of Mount Erebus, an active volcano, have abandoned the attempt because of violent explosions.

title: Seoul Amnesty Frees 3,000
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 24 (Reuters)About 3,000 prisoners were released on parole today in the largest Christmas amnesty ever proclaimed in South Korea. Not included were two Japanesea freelance journalist, Masaki Tachikawa and a college lecturer, Yoshiharu Hayakawawho have been sentenced to 20 years in prison on charges of participation in an antiGovernment plot. The Supreme Court is to rule on their appeals.

title: Judy Klemesrud Awarded $1,000 Prize for Reporting
description: Judy Klemesrud of The New York Times has been named winner of a Pant Myhre Award for excellence in reporting for a story on wives of striking coal miners in Kentucky.

title: YOSWEIN NAMED TO ALBANY POST
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Leonard E. Yoswein, his former Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner, as his legislative representative in Albany, effective Jan. 1.

title: Ford Chassis Recalled
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was recalling about 7,100 bus chassis and trucks in which an air brake supply line could become disconnected: The auto maker said the model years of the bus chassis are 197375 and the trucks are 197275.

title: School Board Studies Loyalty Issues And May Bar Jobs for P.T.A. Officials
description: The Board of Education is thinking about outlawing the widespread practice that allows Parent Teacher Association officers to work as employes in their own schools, a spokesman said recently.

title: Exotic Asian, African Game Will Be Hunted in New Mexico
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., Dec. 24 A small group of sportsmen were preparing today for a trek into the remote mountains and desert plateaus of southeastern New Mexico to participate in what is described as the first licensed hunt in the United States for two prized Asian and African big game speciesthe Iranian ibex and the Kenyan gemsbok.

title: ECONOMIC REPORTS FOR EUROPE GLOOMY
description: The European Common Market issued a gloomy report today showing lagging production, higher unemployment and soaring prices in the ninenation bloc.

title: Miss Toohey Has Nuptials
description: Patricia Straus Toohey was married in Essex, Conn., at noon yesterday to George Raymond Harrah. The ceremony at the bridegroom's home was performed by Mrs. Carl Hanor, a justice of the peace.

title: Sadness Tinges Greystone Park's Holiday Celebration
description: MORRIS PLAINS, Dec. 24The mirth of some patients was met with tears by many of the workers here today at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital.

title: Midnight Mass Dropped In a Hartsdale Church
description: The parish council and priests of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Hartsdale, N. Y., canceled the traditional Christmas midnight mass last night and scheduled instead two masses this morning so that families with small children could attend Christmas services together.

title: Steeler Front Four Is Forefront of Hope
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 (AP) Terry Bradshaw of the Pittsburgh Steelers says that the only way to defeat the Oakland Raiders in the American Football Conference game Sunday is to stop their quarterback, Ken Stabler.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF SILVER CLIMB
description: In dull, preholiday trading yesterday on the nation's commodity exchanges, silver rose here by 4.9 to 7.9 cents an ounce for the various deliveries.

title: INFORMANT NAMED IN COAST SWINDLE
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24A convicted stock manipulator who turned Government informer and imputed wrongdoing to judges in New York and Boston has been revealed as the informant who exposed a scheme to defraud the City of Los Angeles of millions of dollars.

title: Business Briefs
description: Big Board Seeks Trading Rule

title: Red Smith
description: God rest, merrie gentlemen, and merrie ladies, too, From Ali, to Yepremian, the season's best to you For Chrissie Evert, Billie Jean, and Shirley Babashoff A Yuletide snifter of poteensalut! Mazeltov! Ring out, wild bells, for Bowie Kuhn, that tall and stately czar;

title: Oregon Adapts to Mild Marijuana Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) A majority of Oregonians approve of the state law that makes the penalty for possessing small amounts of marijuana to about the same as that for parking ticket, a Drug Abuse Council survey shows.

title: Toll in Philippines
description: MANILA, Dec. 24 (UPI)The death toll from a tropical storm that lashed the central Philippines last Friday rose to 17 today with a report of five drownings in Sorsogon Province, about 200 miles southeast of Manila.

title: Starr Is Named Packer Coach
description: Recalling Winston Churchill during England's dark days and asking, for divine guidance, Bart Starr accepted yesterday the dual posts of general managercoach of the tarnished Green Bay Packers.

title: Concessions on Berlin
description: The package of concessions on Berlin offered by East Germany in exchange for a fiveyear extension of traditional trade credits from West Germany represents breakthrough of major importance. It is further evidence, already reflected in Bonn's negotiations with the Soviet Union, that Chancellor Schmidt's insistence on linking the problems of Berlin to negotiations on trade and technology with Communist countries is paying off.

title: Team Tennis Searching For Help
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 Owners of World Team Tennis will be searching for new money under their Christmas trees tomorrow to avoid folding before the league's second season, which begins in May.

title: NICHOLAS B. SHABBY
description: SHREWSBURY, Mass., Dec. 24 (AP)Nicholas B. Sherry, New England's No. I ranked doubles tennis player for more than 20 years, died today when the car he was driving left the highway and struck a tree. He was 58 years old.

title: Coast Group Says H.U.D. Is Keeping Houses Empty
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 24Early last September, the twostory house at 440 Stoneford Street in East Oakland was put up for sale by the Department of Housing and Urban Development here. The price of the house was only $11,500 because it had been vacant for more than a year and needed repair work.

title: ThaiChinese Trade Accord
description: PEKING, Dec. 24 (Reuters) Thailand, which earlier this month lifted a 15year ban on trading with China has reached agreement on establishing trade relations, a Thai trademission leader said today.

title: Police Bend the Law For Boys With a Tree
description: ANDERSON, Ind., Dec. 24 (UPI)Two patrolmen found two 10yearold boys sneaking from a city park with a freshly cut evergreen tree in tow, local policemen said today.

title: PRICES OF BONDS REGAIN STABILITY
description: With much of the credit markets closed, as bond dealers and their customers took time off for Christmas, prices stabilized yesterday after their sharp decline Monday. The Federal Reserve came into the Government securities market to lend funds to dealers until Friday and until Jan. 2 to alleviate any pressures that might develop in the money markets over the holiday season and push interest rates upward.

title: Clean Air Code on Airports And Stadiums Is Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The Environmental Protection Agency postponed today for six months the enforcement of cleanair standards that would require a review of plans for shopping centers, highways, stadiums and airports.

title: Wilson Picks Union Leader
description: Governor Wilson yesterday nominated Howard Coughlin, a labor union president from Yonkers, as an unsalaried member of the State Banking Board for a term ending March 1, 1977. The appointment is subject to confirmation by the State Senate. Mr. Coughlin is president of the Office and Professional Employes International Union, The Governor said the nominee was the first labor union official appointed to the Banking Board in modern times.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1974

title: Soviet Lew Ends Long Wait
description: Viktor Polsky, a Soviet physicist and civil rights activist, arrived in Israel today and tearfully greeted friends and relatives. Mr. Polsky, who is 44 years old, waited four years for an exit visa arrived in Israel with his wife and daughter and five other relatives after a twoday stopover in Vienna.

title: Salesman Slain. During $10,000 Brooklyn Holdup
description: Two armed men and their accomplices shot to death one of three men taking more than $10,000 in cash from a bank to a Brooklyn army and navy store yesterday, seized the money and escaped in two automobiles, one of which they seized on the spot after removing its two occupants.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
Rebellious Soldiers in Laos Seize Town After a Clash
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 24 (AP)Several hundred rebellious Laotian Army soldiers shot their way into a provincial capital in northwestern Laos today and took over the town for the second time in less than three months after exchanging fire for more than an hour with loyal troops, military sources said.

title: COURT BACKS F.B.I. IN SOCIALIST CASE
description: A Federal judge's decision to prevent surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of a political convention of young Socialists was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary ans Index, Page 20

title: Ticket Sales at Cannon Resort Rise by 52%
description: FRANCONIA, N.H., Dec. 24 Bill Norton, the manager of the stateowned Cannon Mountain ski resort, was singing a happy tune on this evening before Christmas. And it wasn't because of the holiday spirit. It was his season's ticket sales, which already show an increase of 52 per cent over last year. He is convinced these statistics will get even brighter.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: HAPPY 25th ANNIVERSARY GLORIA W. L. You're the greatest. L. A. L.  Advt.

title: L.I. BANK SUSPECT ARRESTED BY F.B.I.
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that it had arrested a 23yearold man who lived in the Santa Cruz Mountains near San Jos, Calif., and whom it described as the commuter bandit who flew from California to New York to rob banks.

title: CAPE MAY COUNTY GETS DISASTER AID
description: 1 TRENTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) President Ford has approved emergency Federal assistance to repair sand dunes in Cape May County that were damaged by a severe wind and rain storm earlier this month, Govlernor Byrne said today.

title: ACCOUNTING FIRM IN CONSENT ORDER
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission reported yesterday that it had obtained a consent judgment against the New York accounting concern of Westheimer, Fine, Berger & Co. and six former officers of the Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas.

title: SpunSteel Santa
description: United States Steel has a Christmas present of sorts for the nation. It is not going to raise prices on its major products quite as much as it originally intended. Since steel is so basic to the cost of thousands of other products, the trimming of the projected increase represents a moderate victory for the moderate approach to an incomes policy on which President Ford relies to curb inflation.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Feet Across the Sea
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 24 (AP)  The Vancouver Whitecaps said today that at least two British soccer clubs had agreed to lend players to the North American Soccer League club for 1975. Denny Veitch, general manager of the team, said Celtic of Glasgow and. Stoke City of the English First Division had agreed to make players available to Vancout ver.

title: Track Strike Averted
description: TORONTO, Dec. 24 (AP) A strike by horsemen at Greenwood Race Track, scheduled for Jan. 1, was averted today when the Ontario Racing Commission granted the Ontario Jockey Club a fifth day of racing at the track. A strike by horsemen at Greenwood Race Track, scheduled for Jan. 1, was averted today when the Ontario Racing Commission granted the Ontario Jockey Club a fifth day of racing at the track.

title: RADAR UNIT GOING TO MITCHEL FIELD
description: A key radar control room now housed at Kennedy International Airport, which guides instrument flights within a radius of 50 miles of New York City, will be moved to Mitchel Field, Hempstead, L. I., in 1979, a Government official said last night.

title: NADJARI BLAMES LAWYER IN PLOT
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, has charged that a Brooklyn lawyer was involved in a wellintegrated conspiracy to thwart a special grand jury's inquiry into the $70million French Connection heroin theft from the Police Department Property Clerk's office.

title: Violence in Capital of Eritrea Leaves 7 Dead and 3 Injured
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Dec. 24 (Reuters)Six people were strangled with steel wire and three others were injured last night in a wave of violence in Asmara, capital of the province of Eritrea, travelers said today.

title: HELMS DISAVOWS ILLEGAL SPYING BY THE C.I.A. IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The State Department said today that Richard Helms, former Director of Central Intelligence and now the Ambassador to Iran, had categorically denied that the C.I.A. conducted any illegal domestic spying under his leadership.

title: 70 Flee an Apartment Blaze
description: BROCKTON, Mass., Dec. 24 (AP)At least 70 persons were driven to the street today when a general alarm fire destroyed an unoccupied fivestory apartment building in a congested apartment house area and spread to six other buildings. Officials, who said arsonists set the blaze, reported two firefighters were treated for minor injuries.

title: Gas in a Pipeline to Be Diverted To Bar South Jersey Shortage
description: NEWARK, Dec. 24The Public Service Electric and Gas Company explained today how its new synthetic gas plant in Linden, in the northern part of the state, would be able to help avert a gas shortage of the South Jersey Gas Company this winter.

title: Senate Confirms 2 Named As Federal Judges Here
description: Ellsworth Van Graafeiland, former president of the New York State Bar Association, and Henry Bramwell, a Brooklyn Civil Court Judge, were both confirmed as Federal judges by the United States Senate last Friday.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Carl F. Stover has been appointed Director of Bicentennial Resources Development for the National Endowment for the Arts. He will be responsible for guiding the Endowment's involvements in the observance of the bicentennial of the American Revolution. In addition to being the Endowment's representative on committees developing and supporting bicentennial artistic activities, he will also serve as a source of information for corporations, foundations and individuals seeking artistic and cultural projects to sponsor.

title: Pontiff Opens Holy Year, Offers Prayers for Peace
description: ROME, Wednesday, Dec. 25 Pope Paul VI solemnly opened the 25th Holy Year of the Roman Catholic Church late last night, and in a Christmas, mass after.midnight prayed for peace on earth.

title: U.S. CHURCHGOING IS CALLED STEADY
description: Churchgoing in the United States in 1974 remained at the same level as in the three previous years, with 40 per cent of adults of all faiths attending a place of worship in a typical week, the Gallup Poll reports.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Cloudy and colder today; seasonable tonight and tomorrow. Temperature range: today 3542; Tuesday 4048. Details on Page 44.

title: JERSEY GOLD BROKER ADMITS FRAUD GUILT
description: An Englewood Cliffs, N.J., silver and gold broker who advertised precious metal coins as a hedge against inflation has admitted defrauding his clients by more than $200,000.

title: No Recession at Track
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)Bay Meadows set a northern California racetrack record of $1,205,995 for average daily wagering at its 56day fall meeting, which concluded yesterday. The total handle for the meet was $67,535,721, and the total attendance 514,399, an average of 9,186 daily.

title: California Court Limits DoctorTatient Privilege
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24The California Supreme Court has ruled that doctors who believe one of their patients intends to hurt or kill someone must notify the potential victim, his relatives, friends or the authorities.

title: Japan Fighting Her Biggest Oil Spill
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24The biggest oil spill in Japan's history spread through, the scenic Inland Sea today, polluting an area more than 80 miles long and 20 miles wide.

title: Miki Meets Rival Party Heads to Discuss Inflation
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24  Premier Takeo Miki met with leaders of Japan's four opposition parties today in an unusual move apparently designed to win support for his efforts to control the country's damaging inflation.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time
description: SAILING TOMORROW

title: Maurice Fischer Is Dead; Chicago Newsman Was 71
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (UPI)  Maurice Fischer, former city editor and assistant to the editor of The Chicago Daily News, died yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: 6 State Units in Dispute Over PowerLine Safety
description: ALBANY, Dec. 23Six state agencies are involved in a controversy about whether 765kilovolt power transmission lines are safe and should be constructed in New York State.

title: Ban on Dumping of Cyanide is Fought
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 (AP)Three major steel companies say they will fight proposed Government regulations that would force them to stop dumping more, than a ton of cyanide a day Into the Monon. gahela River.

title: No Clues to Brooklyn Killing
description: The 50 detectives searching for the intruders who killed 98yearold former yeshiva principal in his Crown Heights apartment in Brooklyn last week have uncovered no leads yet. Detective Arthur Lasky called on anyone with even the slightest bit of information to telephone 2724777.

title: Korchnoi Apologizes for Insult To Karpov, His Victorious Rival
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24The Soviet grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi publicly apologized today for his disparaging remarks last month about his victorious rival, Anatoly Karpov, following their match, which left Karpov as the challenger for the world chess title.

title: Gold and Dollar Off In Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 24 (UPI) The price of gold dropped a fraction today but still was holding to high levels in anticipation of an American rush to II buy the precious metal when the ban on private ownership is lifted Jan. 1.

title: CYCLONE STRIKES AUSTRALIAN CITY
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 25 (Reuters)At least seven people were killed and many injured today as a cyclone struck the principal northern Australian city of Darwin with winds up to 125 miles an hour.

title: Knicks' Porter Sent to Pistons
description: Howard Porter left his home in Hartsdale, N.Y., yesterday morning a New York Knick and went back a Detroit Piston.

title: Notes on People
description: In Paris early yesterday, the four men who collect garbage on Avenue Marigny next to the Elysee Palace were stopped by a uniformed guird, only to be led into the palace to join President Valery Giscard d'Estaing for a breakfast of caf au lait, croissants and toast. Besides the French truck driver, there were two emigres from Mali and one from Senegal; the conversation was about the garbage problem and about Africaof which the President said he was fond. After 25 minutes everybody went back to work, the garbage collectors each carrying a presidential gift of a bottle of champagne and a turkey.

title: ALLEGED BRIBER GETS REDUCTION OF BAIL
description: Bail for Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, who was arrested last week after allegedly offering two policemen a $132,000 bribe, was reduced yesterday by Acting State Supreme Court Justice Louis Cioffi from $2.6million to $500,000.

title: British M.P.'s Badly Need a Raise, but Are Reluctant to Vote for It
description: LONDON, Dec. 24Members of the House of Commons, among the ldwestpaid legislators in Western democraces, are about to be asked to vote themselves a raise. The trouble is that many are too embarrassed to say yes.

title: Iceland Town Victim Again
description: REYKJAVIK, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  A blizzard yesterday buried the eastern Iceland fishing town of Neskaupstadur, where 12 people were killed by avalances last Friday.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
I Am Curious Star Recalls Struggle
description: STOCKHOLMThere is a wet snow about and it brushes the dark windows. Nothing in a Stockholm winter morning compels the use of sunglasses but Lena Nyman sits in her apartment with a pair perched on her nose, a white shawl around her shoulders.

title: State Farmers Reap Bumper Crops, But Inflation Puts Income Below '73's
description: Production and y??ds of major crops in 1974 set or approached records in New Jersey, and farm income was well above that of last year.

title: C.I.A. MAN FEARS FADING OF VALUES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) For 31 of his 57 years, James Angleton protected the Central Intelligence Agency's secrets and agents from prying foreign powers, and now he worries that the values that guided him have passed out of fashion.

title: Chess: The Forma Wasn't All Pro At the Houston Onternational
description: Robert Huebner, a 26yearold West German grandmaster, added a new triumph to his laurels by winning the Houston International Tournament. Huebner, the pretourney favorite (he was a world championship candidate in the 1971 elimination cycle), did not suffer excessively from his recent lack of practice, but battled undefeated through difficult games to post a score of 83.

title: Oil Leak Spreads Over Sea in Japan, Harming Fisheries
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (AP)Crude oil leaking from an industrial refinery task continued to spread over a wide area of Japan's scenic Inland Sea today, causing damage to fisheries estimated by various officials at mare than $20.6million.

title: MRS. GEORGE ROSEN
description: Lee Goodman Rosen, wife of George Rosen, former manager of public affairs for the National Broadcasting Company, died Tuesday at St. Clares Hos. pital. She was 69 years old and lived at 415 East 52d Street.

title: Mexico Again Seeks Foreign Investing
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 25Eighteen months after Mexico's controversial new law on foreign investment went into effect, the dust of economic nationalism is beginning to settle and foreign investment is again being sought.

title: Police Working as Tellers Kill Suspect in Bank Theft
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Two offduty policemen working as bank tellers today chased three men who robbed a Bank of America branch of more than $10,000. One suspect was killed and another was captured.

title: EVERGLADES CITY CO ONCE MORE
description: EVERGLADES CITY, Fla., Dec. 21In 1969, the Dade County Port Authority was planning to build a 38squaremile jetport 35 miles south of Everglades City near the DadeCollier County line, within the Everglades region.

title: Holiday Closes Markets
description: All securities, commodity and currency exchanges in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday for the Christmas holiday.

title: Role of Appointed Law Secretaries Is Under Scrutiny
description: For several months, Federal judges in Manhattan have been interviewing the t talented thirdyear law students fro some of the most coveted jobs in the Federal systern Across the street, at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, the justices also have available to themclerkships clerks, who are called law secretaries. They tend to be middleaged or close to retirement, and some acknowledge that they have received their jobs through political connections, not scholarly achievement.

title: House Fire Kills 5 Children
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 25 (UPI)A Christmas morning fire near a decorated tree killed five children as it spread and destroyed a onestory frame house. Iwo adults and three other children escaped by jumping from windows.

title: Lehman Sets Abraham Accord
description: Lehman Brothers, Inc., the wellknown 124yearold Wall Street concern, announced yesterday the conclusion of an agreement to acquire most of the assets of Abraham & Co., Inc., a 60yearold brokerage house. The closing date is scheduled for Jan. 17.

title: Board of Education Facing FireViolation Summonses
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the Board of Education had failed to correct fire violations in more than 200 public schools throughout the city, and he threatened to serve summonses on the board.

title: Concern on OilMoney Flow Causes Scrutiny of Controls
description: PARIS, Dec. 23While welcoming investments from the new wealthy oilexporting nations, the industrial nations of the West have started taking precautions to keep them from buying up large sections of sensitive industries.

title: Excerpts From '47 Law Creating C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 25Following is an excerpt from the 1947 law that created the Central Intelligence Agency. Title 50. Section 403 of the United States Code:

title: Makarios Offers Prayer For Lasting Cyprus Peace
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Archbishop Markarios, in a Christmas message read in all Greek Cypriote churches, offered a prayer that permanent peace, would be established in Cyprus.

title: Women in Congress May Form A Caucus to Increase Influence
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) The women in Congress are talking about establishing their own caucus to increase their influence and unify their strategy.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25 (UPI)Ancient Title, the Strub Series winner, can pick up where he left off last year in tomorrow's $30,000 added Palos Verdes Handicap, the openingday event of Santa Anita's 40th season.

title: Horse Hits Car on L.I.
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 25 (UPI)A runaway horse, one of two that had broken away from stalls in Lawrence, suffered chest abrasions after it ran into a car here about 7:35 P.M. yesterday, the police reported. The driver of the car, Sam Frieer, 54 years old, of Woodmere, was not injured, but the windshield of the car, a 1973 Pontiac, was broken and a front fender was dented. The police said the horse's owner, Barney Vance, retrieved both runaways.

title: 4 BLACK LEADERS CRITICAL OF CAREY
description: Four prominent black civic and business figures have urged Governorelect Hugh L. Carey to correct as soon as possible his failure to appoint any blacks or other minoritygroup members to highlevel posts in the incoming state administration, or to include them in his inner circle of advisers.

title: Predawn Fire Kills 4 in Jersey Family
description: KINNELON, N. J., Dec. 25 Four members of a family died here today in a predawn fire believed to have been caused by faulty wiring in an artificial Christmas tree. Two others escaped with only minor injuries.

title: Senate Study Finds A Drop in Medicare Hurts the Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI) Because Medicare fails to pay all health costs, 11.2 million elderly people spend about half a billion dollars a year on additional insurancesome of it shoddy, a Senate committee said the other day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The logic of Senator Abraham Ribicoff's OpEd article on Dec. 5 was curious, to say the least. He seemed to be contending that our development of nuclear power over the last thirty years has actually worsened our energy situation.

title: Sailor on Lakes Carrier Gets Christmas Carol
description: PORT HURON, Mich., Dec. 25 (AP)  Victor Schwartzkopf was not home for Christmas, so his family gathered at the Blue Water Bridge here and sang We Wish You a Merry Christmas as the Great Lakes sailor passed by aboard the ore carrier Champlain.

title: Ford Rating in Poll Slips to Low of 42%
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 25Widespread concern over the nation's economy has caused President Ford's popularity with the American people to slide to its lowest point since he took office less than five months ago, according to the most recent Gallup Poll.

title: Playoff Gimmick: 14 Men in Huddle
description: Each team is permitted 11 men on the field at the same time, the National Football League rule book says. Tell that to the Oakland Raiders and Minnesota Vikings.

title: Larceny Is Paying Off For Lafayette Quintet
description: A good deal of welltimed thievery has put Lafayette's basketball team on top of the Public Schools; Athletic League Brooklyn Division II. After missing the playoffs last season for the first time in five years, Lafayette has won its first five league games while averaging more than 100 points and 20 steals a game.

title: Nuclear Weaponry SelfTaught
description: MELBOURNE, AustraliaNow that any nation can develop nuclear weapons without serious worldwide protest or condemnation, no reason remains to suppress publication of this handy, stepbystep guide on Nuclear Weaponry SelfTaught. It is offered free, as a public service for all underdeveloped nations wishing to join the now nonexclusive nuclear club.

title: Secret Service Insists That Security at White House Is Adequate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25The man who crashed his car through a wroughtiron gate in front of the White House this morning was the second intruder this year into that enclave, but Secret Service officials maintained today that security was adequate.

title: Intruder in Car Smashes White House Gate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25A young man, dressed like an Arab and seemingly laden with explosives, interrupted the Christmas calm of the capital today when he crashed his car through a White House gate 7:07 A.M. and then stood for four hours a few feet from the executive mansion.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dave Anderson
description: As a TV analyst last Sunday in Los Angeles at the National Football League playoff game there, Bart Starr was dissecting a replay, when he suddenly confessed:

title: A Student Rescues 9 In Bronx Car Accident
description: A 23yearold student at Staten Island Community College suffered thirddegree burns of the hands and face last night when he rescued nine members of a family from a car that crashed, turned over and burned on the Bruckner Expressway in the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Down payments that customers make to furniture stores would be held in trust until the merchandise is delivered under legislation to be proposed by the State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz. In all too many instances furniture stores have closed their doors and the consumers who had placed their deposits with them and were expecting delivery of the goods lost their money, he said. Under the proposal, the money woul dhave to be returned to the consumer if the delivery was not made. Mr. Lefkowitz said reports filed with his office indicated that hundreds of dollars had been lost because furniture stores went out of business after taking deposits.

title: Mother and Her 3 Children Die As Car Blows Up After Crash
description: GRANBY, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP) Two adults and three children were killed early today when the car they were riding in exploded after colliding with another vehicle in Oswego County, the state police said.

title: Screen:' Abby,' About a Black Family and Exorcism
description: If "The Exorcist" luridly indicated that a white girl plagued by demons could be a problem, "Abby," which landed unsteadily at the Penthouse and RKO 86th Street theaters yesterday, illustrates that a black girl, if not an amused moviegoer, can also be unsettled by dire manufactured powers. As "the story of a woman possessed" who is finally cleansed of those devils, "Abby" is more silly than shocking even if it seems to take itself seriously.Blame all the ersatz deviltry on William Marshall, as the film's imposingly learned minister-archeologist who unwittingly looses evil forces by digging up an ancient religious artifact in Nigeria that invades the body of his young, lovely, decent daughter-in-law back home in Louisville, Ky. And, of course, Carol Speed, as Abby, his daughter-in-law, begins to behave more and more like a rampaging hooker than a loving bride, churchwoman and dedicated community worker.Her personal poltergeistwhich sets off a series of mysterious sounds and furies, including slamming doors and flying furniture, as well as sexual and physical assaultsthreatens to send the family, a hospital staff and the cops off the deep end. But not before Mr. Marshall, wearing exotic garb and intoning an exotic religious ritual, steps in climactically to exorcise and save the plagued Abby from her destructive alter ego.Mr. Marshall does manage to be dignified despite the mumbo-jumbo he's involved with. But Miss Speed, whose lips turn purple and whose voice turns basso profundo in spewing obscenities in her "possessed" state, is energetic, if unconvincing, as the afflicted Abby, Terry Carter and Austin Stoker are believably confused and frightened as her minister husband and cop brother, respectively.As her distraught mother, Juanita Moore delivers one of the film's most intelligent lines. She comforts her ailing daughter at one point with, "I'm gonna get you a cold towel for your head. It'll make you feel better." A cold towel could help a viewer, too.

title: Officials Are Encouraged by Prison Furlough System
description: TRENTON, Dec. 25 (AP)About onesixth of the 6,000 inmates in New Jersey's state prisons currently qualify for furloughs, and over half are likely to spend some time during this holiday season at home with their families.

title: Controlling the F.B.I.
description: From time to time since the death of J. Edgar Hoover, members of Congress and others have murmured quietly about the need to impose more reliable controls on the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Perhaps Congress will be jolted out of its slumbers by the revelations about the Central Intelligence Agency's illegal intrusions into the domestic security field, coupled with some devastating observations by William C. Sullivan, formerly Number Three man in the F.B.I., on its abuses and ineptitude handling this responsibilitya responsibility it botched from the start.

title: CLIFFORD FAVORS A SPECIAL INQUIRY INTO C.I.A. SPYING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25Clerk M. Clifford, the former Secretary of Defense who helped to draft the 1947 legislation setting up the Central Intelligence Agency, urged Congress today to form a special committee to investigate the published charges of domestic spying by that agency.

title: 2 Skiiers Killed in France
description: CHAMONIX, France, Dec. 25 (Reuters)An avalanche swept a group of skiers down a slope near this Alpine resort today, killing two men and injuring another, the police said.

title: Ahmed Ismail, Egyptian Leader In October War, Is Dead at 57
description: CAIRO, Dec. 25 (UPI)Field Marshal Ahmed Ismail, Egypt's Minister of War and Commander in Chief of the armed forces in the October, 1973, war, died today in London at the age of 57, the Government announced.

title: In Nation's Kitchens, Waste and Gluttony Are Becoming Passe
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 Doggie bags are in.

title: Advertising
description: Gerald L. Taylor, 39 years old, spent Christmas Day in the traditional way in his 254  year  old home in Redding, Conn., with his wife and four children.

title: BURMESE LEADER SERENE IN CRISES
description: RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 24The other morning Gen. Ne Win decided to play a round of golf. It was an Insignificant event but in the eyes of the Burmese the 63yearold president was pointedly reminding antiGovernment students that he was securely the boss and that recent demonstrations didn't interfere with his well  known penchant for the sport.

title: LONGHORN HERDS MAY GRAZE AGAIN
description: FORT WORTH, Dec. 25The international oil shortage may mean that the Texas longhorn will once again play an important role in supplying beef for the dinner tables of America.

title: Wallace Not Straining For Party's Nomination
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama leaned back in his wheelchair, puffed on a cigar and said: I'm not straining. I'm just going to sit back and see what they do about the Wallace problem.

title: MOSCOW CHARGES DECEPTION IN U. S.
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25A Soviet publication charged today that reports of Soviet concessions on emigration in return for United States trade benefits had been concocted by knights of the cold war in Congress.

title: JAPANESE FIRM ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25  Japan's Foreign Minister restated his Government's opposition today to allowing nucleararmed vessels to pass through Japanese waters. But he left ambiguous whether that applied to American warships calling at Japanese ports.

title: Steady Snowfall Greets New England Skiers
description: BARTLETT, N. H., Dec. 25 On this snowy afternoon Thad Thorne was going through the unusual process unusual for a ski area managerof riffling through index cards to check reservations. People keep telling me I look like a ticket seller at a theater who has a hit show on his hands, said Thorne, Judging from what the skies are hitting us with right now, I think we may have to put out the standing room only sign by Saturday.

title: Bullets, Led by Riordan, Set Back Hawks, 11092
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 25 (AP)  Mike Riordan scored 23 points in the first three quarters tonight to pace the Washington Bullets to a 11092 National Basketball Association victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Windgusher, $12.40, Scores by a Nose
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP)  Windgusher surged from behind to win the $15,000 Christmas Handicap by a nose today at the Fair Grounds.

title: Dirty Tricks' Disclosed In Kennel Club Voting
description: The dirty tricks era has carried over to the dogshow world. On Dec. 10 Mrs. Billie McFadden, who had been chosen by the Trenton Kennel Club to represent it as a delegate to the American Kennel Club, was rejected at the A.K.C.'s regular quarterly meeting.

title: RUSSIAN JEWS FIT INTO LIFE IN SOUTH
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 25 (AP)  Alexander Ehrenberg, formerly an electrical engineer in the Baltic seaport of Riga, speaks enthusiastically about his new homeexcept for those Southern accents.

title: Australia to Airlift 10,000 Out of CycloneHit Darwin
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 26  An airlift to evacuate at least 10,000 people from the cyclonedevastated city of Darwin began today, according to authoritative word reaching here.

title: Intruder in Car Smashes White House Gate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25A young man, dressed like an Arab and seemingly laden with explosives, interrupted the Christmas calm of the capital today when he crashed his car through a White House gate at 7:07 A.M. and then stood for four hours a few feet from the executive mansion.

title: 4 South African Policemen Slain by Rebels in Rhodesia
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Guerrillas have killed four members of the South: African police force serving in Rhodesia and wounded fifth, the South African Government announced last night.

title: SCHOOLS SEE HOPE FOR DISTRICT FIVE
description: Bernard R. Gifford, the Deputy School Chancellor, has expreged the hope that Community School District 5 in Central Harlem, which has been beset by troubles since the start of decentralization in 1970, could be turned into a model for, responsible local school operations.

title: How Firm a Foundation?
description: After earlier warnings concerning the depressed state of its assets, the Ford Foundation dropped the other shoe with its announcement of sharply reduced grant schedules. The projected slash in disbursement, from the present annual level of over $200 million to half that amount in each of the next four years, is even more serious when it is recalled that the foundation used to spend closer to $300 million in the affluent past.

title: Israel Tells El Al Workers Slowdown Will Close Airline
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 25 (Reuters)The Israeli Minister of Transport, Gad Yacobi, threatened to shut down El Al, the national airline, if maintenance men did not end their goslow job action by midnight tomorrow.

title: Haden Key In the War Of Roses.
description: PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP)A year ago, Pat Haden threw so much against Ohio State in the Rose Bowl that he broke some passing records for the University of Southern California.

title: Michel's, in Brooklyn, To Serve Its Last Meal
description: Michel's, a Brooklyn restaurant on Flatbush Avenue near Grand Army Plaza that has been a favorite spot for local family banquets since 1910, will serve its final dinners Sunday, George Michel, the owner disclosed yesterday.

title: DISEASE RAVAGING FLORIDA COCONUTS
description: MIAMI, Dec. 25An effort to save Florida's coconut palms with injections of an antibiotic appears to have failed to stop the spread of the deadly disease, called lethal yellowing.

title: Bulldozer Hits French Jail
description: LIMOGES, France, Dec. 25 (Reuters)A Christmas reveler drove a bulldozer into the main door of the provincial prison here early today before escaping into a crowd returning from midnight mass, police officials said. The officials believed that the incident was not part of an organized escape attempt.

title: CF&I Steel Price Data Given to WagePrice Unit
description: The CF&I Steel Corporation announced yesterday that, in the wake of rollbacks by the United States Steel Corporation, it has submitted a statement to the Council on Wage and Price Stability with information and cost data to support its recent price increases.

title: Injured Jockey Improves
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Dec, 25Craig Bandoroff, an apprentice jockey, removed from the critical list today at West Jersey Hospital, two days after suffering injuries in a spill at Garden State Park in nearby Cherry. Hill. Bandoroff, 19 years old, was in fair condition with chest injuries a fractured right arm.

title: Kennedy Center Busy, Busy Despite Early Fear of Failure
description: WASHINGTONThe Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial are still drawing throngs, but a threeyearold attraction called the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is rapidly moving up as a prime lure for Washington visitors.

title: JAPAN SAYS PLANES OF SOVIET FLY PAST
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (UPI)The Soviet Union has stepped up reconnaissance activities around Japan for undetermined reasons, Japan's Air SelfDefense Force reported today.

description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1974

title: Value of Shipments Rises In Construction Machinery
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) A preliminary report by the Bureau of the Census shows that the value of the shipments of the nation's construction machinery plants during 1972 totaled $6billion, up 42 per cent from the 1967 total of $4.1billion.

title: Army Delaying Its Plan To Kill 14 Million Birds
description: MILAN, Tenn., Dec. 25Bowing to pressure from environmentalists, the Army is delaying its plan to kill 14 million birds at bases at Milan, Tenn., and Fort Campbell, Ky.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Museum Gets Hughes Plane
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif. (AP) A twinengine Convair 240 that was once the personal plane of Howard Hughes took to the air for the first time in 17 years recently. It flew from Santa Monica Airport to its new home at the Antelope Valley Aero Museum at Fox Field in Palmdale. The 45passenger aircraft was donated to the museum by Hughes's Summa Corporation.

title: Soviet Announces New Internal Passport System
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25The Soviet Union announced today that all its citizens from the age of 16 would be issued newt internal passports, in what was described as a simplification of travel and residence procedures inside the country.

title: French Oil Cooperation
description: Hard on the heels of the Martinique meeting between Presidents Ford and Giscard d'Estaing an informal mechanism has been set up to effect French cooperation with other major oilconsuming countries through the new sixteennation International Energy Agency la Paris. The new approach is akin to the methods devised to maintain effective French participation in the defense of Western Europe after General de Gaulle's withdrawal from the NATO military organization.

title: Wet Instead of White, but Still Christmas
description: Christmas was observed yesterday with religious fervor, the exchange of gifts and gatherings of families and friends.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The police continued their investigation into the shooting death of a retired truck company worker found at the foot of his cellar stairs in Piscataway. The victim, Albert Siergierj, 58 years old, was found in his ransacked home by two friends who were making a Christmas Eve visit, the police said. Mr. Siegierj, who had worked for Mack Trucks, Inc., in Plainfield, had been shot in the head and had been dead for some time, a police spokesman said, adding that it was undetermined if anything had been taken.

title: Australia Weighs Question of Refuge For a British M. P.
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 26 (AP)  A Melbourne magistrate ruled today that John Stonehouse, the British former Minister who vanished from Miami Beach five weeks ago, would be held until Australian immigration officials decided whether to deport him.

title: Idea for Creating a C.I.A. Grew Out of Pearl Harbor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25American political and military leaders created the Central Intelligence Agency after World War II as a needed instrument of global power.

title: ICBSTV LICENSE FACES CHALLENGE
description: TRENTON, Dec. 25The New Jersey Coalition for Fair Broadcasting threatened today to challenge the license renewal of WCBSTV if the New York network affiliate failed to improve its coverage of the news of New Jersey.

title: SoundBurst Hits Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 2?? (UPI)  Mysterious ?? phenomena boomed shock waves over this gambling resort yesterday shattering at least six large plateglass windows. Federal officials said that the phenomenon, an acustical burst, was probably caused by a temperature inversion deflecting the shock waves of an explosion hundreds of miles away.

title: Bridge: Thinkinh Can Untangle Web Spun by Deceptive Declarer
description: Many deceptive moves available to a declarer can be deciphered by defenders who take the trouble to think. But a little mental effort is needed: The defender must appreziate that his partner is on his side, and can be trusted, while the declarer is not, and should not be.

title: Hijacker Is Overpowered on an Airliner Over Rome
description: ROME, Dec. 25A hijacker took, over an Air India jumbo jet today and tried to force the pilot to go into a sharp dive over Rome, but the man was overpowered by the crew and the plane landed safely.

title: CRIME TASK FORCE TO GET NEW CHIEF
description: William I. Aronwald will be named today as the new chief of the Joint Strike Force Against Organized Crime.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE SEA CHANGE. The Migration of Social Thought, 19301965. By H. Stuart Hughes. 283 pages. Harper & Row. $10.

title: Screen:Police Team Is Focus of 'Freebie and Bean'
description: "Freebie and the Bean," this year's final cop comedy, seems the worst of the lot, probably because it has a cast of otherwise good actors doing bits of business (sometimes called acting) as if they thought they could upstage all of the movie's automobiles, which are seldom still. Cars tail one another endlessly. Sometimes they race and every now and then there's a very complicated, very dumb, all-out chase. Even a single parked car becomes something of a plot point.You finally get the feeling that a car directed the picture its as sensitive as a door knob and as witty as a bumper sticker  and maybe one did, though the title credits list Richard Rush. He is the man who directed the worst of the campus-revolution movies, "Getting Straight" (1970). Before that disaster Mr. Rush had earned a name in Hollywood for directing low-budget motorcycle films.The stars of the film are Alan Arkin, who plays Bean, a sensitive Mexican-born policeman who suspects his beautiful wife of infidelity, and James Caan, who plays Bean's all-American partner, Freebie. The best performance is that of Valerie Harper (television's Rhoda), who is seen briefly as Bean's wife. For a few minutes there is something very funny about the movie when Bean confronts his wife with his suspicions: the intensity of Miss Harper's tolerance of Bean's suspicions and the answers she has for every charge against her exactly matches Mr. Arkin's fury.The rest of the time the movie is serio-comic trash. It was written by Robert Kaufman and what story there isabout two lawmen trying to capture the Mr. Big of the rackets'is not at all dissimilar to "Busting," the much better Peter Hyams cop film seen earlier in the year. "Freebie and the Bean" opened yesterday at the Criterion, Beekman and 86th Street East Theaters.

title: 2d Inspection Finds Sanitary Violations At 17 Food Places
description: The city's Health Department yesterday released the names of 17 more food establishments that failed to correct firstinspection Health Code violations by the time a second. inspection was made. Results in four other cases were also disclosed.

title: Logue Offers 5Point Plan To Improve Urban Agency
description: The head of the financially beset State Urban Development Corporation, which was criticized by Governorelect Hugh L. Carey this week for apparent fiscal irresponsibility and mismanagement, proposed a fivepoint program yesterday to strengthen the controversial superagency.

title: Orphanages Vanishing For a Lack of Orphans
description: Christmas was the day you got chicken, you got an orange. Just a day off from school, and better eating.

title: MARKET BASKET DIPS AS SUGAR DECLINES
description: A sharp drop in the price of sugar, attributed to the power of organized consumer efforts, brought the cost of feeding a family of four in the city down 0.3 per cent last week, the Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday.

title: Kennedy Center Busy, Busy Despite Early Fear of Failure
description: WASHINGTONThe Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial are still drawing throngs, but a threeyearold attraction called the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is rapidly moving up as a prime lure for Washington visitors.

title: EMMA DUBINSKY, 80, WIFE OF UNION CHIEF
description: Emma Goldberg Dubinsky, the wife of David Dubinsky, died, apparently of a stroke, yesterday at her home, 24 Fifth Avenue. She was 80 years old.

title: Dr. K. Albert Harden Dies; Former Dean at Howard
description: Dr. K. Albert Harden, former dean of Howard University's College of Medicine, died Tuesday at Freedmen's Hospital, Washington. He was 69 years old and lived in the District of Columbia.

title: U.S. Girl Injured by Grenade In Israel Will Lose a Leg
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 25 (AP)  Doctors said today they would have to amputate the injured leg of a 16yearold American girl wounded in an Arab terrorist attack against a tourist bus.

title: Korea, Beset by Inflation and Sluinp, Tries Growth Cure
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 18While other nations have hesitated between fighting inflation or recession, the South Korean Government has recently adopted a strong program to stimulate the economy and avoid unemployment even at the risk of higher prices.

title: 4 in Family Killed In a Fire in Jersey
description: KINNELON, N. J., Dec. 25 Four members of a family died here today in a predawn fire believed to have been caused by faulty wiring in an artificial Christmas tree. Two others escaped with only minor injuries.

title: 3 Canadians on U.N. Force Die in Mideast Truck Crash
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 25 (AP)Three Canadian servicemen attached to the United Nations Emergency Force in the Middie East died in a collision of their vehicle with an Egyptian Army truck, a Canadian Defense Department spokesman reported today.

title: Briefs On the Arts
description: Francis Ford Coppola's production of The Conversation has been named the year's best film by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures. In addition, the public organization, which has been voting on films annually for 33 years, selected Mr. Coppola and Gene Hackman as the top director and actor, respectively, of 1974 for their work on the drama dealing with the activities of a pro fessional wiretapper.

title: Market Place
description: There has been so much talk about going private of late that every time a corporation seeks some of its own shares, some shareholders are inclined to view the move as the first step in eliminating all outside ownership.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Swedes, Flourishing, Feel Guilty About Their Wealth and Debate Obligations to Others
description: STOCKHOLM  There is tremendous value attached to light in the long nights now, from the candles that go flickering up the avenues on St. Lucy's Day to the blazing Christmas shop windows. The big stores display luxury with a grace and profusion that London stores have lostand New York stores may be losing.

title: Intruder's Letter Indicated a Need for Psychiatric Help
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25The young man who rammed his car through a gate into the White House grounds today had declared in a letter turned over to the State Department last week that he would denounce his United States citizenship on Christmas and seek political asylum in a third world country.

title: Rules Changes in the N.F.L. Helped Us, Say Raiders
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP)The National Football. League's 1974 rules changes made it a whole new game, according to the Oakland Raiders' managing partner, Al Davis, who helped draw them up.

title: OREGON STATE BAR ENDS FEB SYSTEM
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 25The Oregon State Bar, after suffering a setback in a Government antitrust suit against it, has abandoned its fee schedule for simple legal work.

title: Rigid Training and Inner Leadership Win Respect for West German Army
description: STETTEN, West GermanyThe impassive face of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, deal 30 years, looks down from the walls of headquarters and officers' clubs on a new generation of officers who are molding a German army into one of the most efficient forces in Europe.

title: Nigerian Culture, Old and New, Bolsters Unity of Nation and Africa
description: KADUNA, Nigeria Dec. 22. For as long as the Biro people of Nigeria's BenuePlateau State can remember, they performed their festival dance in April, just at the start of the rainy season, when the sorghum was planted and everyone hoped for a good harvest.

title: Islanders' Problem: Too Many Centers
description: There's a hockey lesson to be learned at the corner delicatessen. Any professional sandwichmaker will tell you never cut more than one day's worth of bologna in advance because the leftovers will dry and curl on the shelf waiting for tomorrow's customers.

title: Casino Owner Found Dead In Plane With 7 of Family
description: CHESTER, Calif., Dec. 25 (UPI) The bodies of a the owner of a Nevada casino and seven members of his family have been found in the wreckage of an airplane that crashed last weekend in a snowy, mountainous region in northern California.

title: Hasidic Sect Hurt by Unemployment
description: David Felderbaum, a 26yearold carpenter, went to the headquarters of the Orthodox Hasidic Satmar movement at 82 Lee Avenue, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, to seek help in finding a job.

title: U.S. Decision in FighterPlane Sweepstakes Is Due Jan. 15
description: LONDON, Dec. 20 The next major decision in what has come to be known, as the great fighter plane sweepstakes is due Jan. 15, now that the United States has rebuffed a French proposal that the two countries share in fighter sales in Western Europe.

title: Body of Woman Found by Maid In Bathtub of a Midtown Hotel
description: A 25yearold woman, nude except for a pair of boots, was found dead yesterday in the bathtub of an apartment at the Gorham Hotel, at 136 West 55th Strapt.

title: New York Magic
description: If New York can be a cruel, cold, hard, destructive, demanding and merciless city, at this time of year it seductively beautiful. An affluent fairyland, it gives the lie to poverty and need and defeat; a thousand towers shower diamonds in the sky. The trees so carefully planted by city planners are like multicolored sparklers tossed along Sixth Avenue. Wreaths and bells sway across streets in older neighborhoods, as in small towns. A million corporate light years away, Park Avenue touched expensively and elegantly with electric frost. The invisible barricades that fence off the five boroughs melt and momentarily the metropolis is at peace.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: TV: Assaying the Fairness Doctrine
description: One of the more venerable axioms of TV production holds that nothing is deadlier than talking heads. The viewer demands movement. Even reporters shouldn't be caught sitting still. They must stroll about the news location, or swivel in their chairs to gaze, on perfect cue, into another camera. Like most TV axioms, which tend to be banal crutches for banal imaginations, this one is riddled with exceptions. The results still depends on which heads are talking and what they are talking about.

title: A Time for Renewal
description: NEW HAVENIn 1970, Charles A. Reich's The Greening of America prophesied a youth revolution in which our enormous anger at all the warmakers and their wars would be wonderfully transformed into an enormous hope for a world of beauty and abundance.

title: New Chance for SALT
description: Rapid corrective action has followed the widespread criticism of the high strategic arms ceilings originally fixed for a decade by the Vladivostok accord.

title: A Preface To Liberty
description: BOSTON, Dec. 25The death of Walter Lippmann has provided an occasion for selfexamination in the profession that he chose and honored, the press. Editors and commentators, reflecting on his unique role, have thought about their own. That would have pleased Mr. Lippmann, for he believed in selfawareness in all institutions. He might indeed be said to have chosen journalism as a profession so that he could devote his life to clarifying society's vision of itself.

title: Cherry Orchard Weak In Hartford Production
description: HARTFORD  What is wrong with the Hartford Stage Company's production of Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard? Curiously enough, it is nothing very evident but a sad agglomeration of details, of missed chances and numbed nuances.

title: REGIMES' MOVES ON FOES STUDIED
description: GENEVA, Dec. 23An international agency that issues a steady stream of reports denouncing violations of human rights on all continents says that it is encouraged by the way some authoritarian governments have reacted when faced by social turmoil.

title: Old Friends Give to the Neediest
description: A number of longtime supporters of the annual appeal of the. New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were among Contributors who are marking the Christmas season with gifts to the fund.

title: Crew Boards Freighter Disabled in North Pacific
description: KODIAK, Alaska, Dec. 25 (AP)A Coast Guard crew has boarded the freighter Corina in an effort to repair the ship's engine and end a weeklong ordeal in the North Pacific.

title: Security Tight in Eritrea's Capital After Violence
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 25 (Reuters)  Soldiers with machine guns patrolled the main streets of the Eritrean provincial capital today following clashes between Ethiopian troops and guerrillas, and a series of murders there.

description: A number of longtime supporters of the annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were among contributors who are marking the Christmas season with gifts to the fund.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) A new health security bill will be introduced in Congress seeking to provide health insurance protection for everyone, Leonard Woodcock announced today.

description: ARDSLEY, N.Y.  High school girls use the money from summer jobs for all sorts of things: trips, clothes, college funds, bicycles; the list could go on indefinitely.

title: Rutgers Opens Festival Here

title: Safe Minnesota Best Gift of All For Belfast Boys
description: BREWSTER, Minn., Dec. 25For the Robert Haberman family, Christmas '74 will go down as the time of the miracle, when two Irish boys from embattled Belfast were allowed to join the Habermans on their farm near this tranquil southern Minnesota town of 500 to lead lives free from bombings, soldiers and fear.

title: Soviet Reports installation Of First Atomic Lighthouse
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP)The world's first atomic lighthouse has been put into service on the Baltic Sea, the Soviet paper Pravda said today.

description: HAIFA, Israel, Dec. 25 (Reuters)Two cruise ships with about 1,000 Christmas pilgrims abroad have cut short their visits to Israel, sailing this morning instead of tomorrow without a planned visit by passengers to Jerusalem.

title: Gift for All Seasons
description: A gift of a United States saving bonds always fits the occasion, whether given for a birthday, a graduation, an anniversary or the birth of a grandchild. And it always fits the giver's budget. Bonds come with a variety of price tags, from $18.75 up. Your bank carries all denominations. Make a habit of giving United States Saving Bonds on special occasions. You'll be joining millions of other Americans who have given and received bonds over the years. It's the closest thing to a sure thing gift.

title: Citibank Decides Against Retail Sales of Gold Now

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI) The public will be able to tour the White House by candlelight tomorrow and Friday evenings from 6:30 to 9. The visitors will begin the tour at the East Gate. The main attraction is the ceilinghigh Christmas tree in the Blue Room.

title: YONKERS STUDYING FIRES AT CARTER

title: Cuban Refugee Family Savors Best Yuletide
description: For the family of Manuel Alonso in Paterson the spirit of Christmas giving began three months ago, when they arrived here as refugees from Cuba. It culminated in a Christmas celebration that was made possible by the generosity of many persons who formerly had been strangers to Manuel and Graciella Alonso and their five children.

title: Board of Education Facing FireViolation Summonses
description: Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the Board of Education had failed to correct fire violations in more than 200 public schools throughout the city, and he threatened to serve summonses on the board.

description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (UPI) An accountant linked by Congressional investigators with the Mafia has confessed to helping a plot to loot the city treasury of millions of dollars, a court hearing was told yesterday.

description: LORTON, Va., Dec. 25 (AP)Armed inmates at Lorton Reformatory took nine guards hostage in a mess hall tonight, the authorities said. They said three inmates had escaped from the reformatory, taking another guard as a hostage.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Each time a merchant shortweights a consumer, the loss is small, but the pennies add up: The Department of Consumer Affairs estimates that New York City consumers bought $25million worth of nothing in 1974. And, despite the song, nothing isn't plenty for them.

title: WAY FOUND TO AVOID PLANE'S SONIC BOOM
description: CHICAGO (AP)  Computer demonstrations have shown that supersonic flights can be made without creating a sonic boom that would be heard or felt on ground, United Air Lines Says.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI) Snowmobiles can be serious health risks to children if operated recklessly, says the American Academy of Pediatrics.

title: Opera: Unfestive Revival

Perhaps that was why the Metropolitan Opera revived the work Christmas night, with the added hope that its bubbly tunes might at least keep, the audience in a festive mood.

title: Too Much Exercise Can Be Dangerous, A Physician Warns
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (AP)Even lazy people can be physically fit, says a Nebraska doctor who warns that too much exercise, like too much of anything else, is not good for you.

title: Alfred J. Francfort Dies; Social Security Aide, 62

Francfort, since 1963 regional representative of the Social Security Administration, in charge for the area taking in New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, died Monday, apparently of a coronary attack, at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 62 years old and lived at 15 Branch Road, Oakhurst, N. J.

title: Housewife in Texas Asks State to Bar Textbook Company

description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)Visitors often leave their hearts in San Francisco, but some of them are taking their favorite street signs in exchange.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 26The South Vietnamese military command today announced the fall of the fourth district capital since the beginning of steppedup Communist attacks three weeks ago.

title: SIRHAN IS HOPEFUL HE WILL BE FREED
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25 (UPI) Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, serving a life term for the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy on June 5, 1968, hopes, that he may be cleared of the murder conviction and given his freedom soon.

title: Recent Price Declines Are Recorded In Consumer and Industrial Products
description: Prices of scores of consumer and industrial products have been declining in recent weeks in the face of sluggish demand and growing inventories.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BOUNCY BACH Fans of the highly popular musical satirist Peter Schickele can welcome back the professor and his tongueincheek sideswipes at classics tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock in Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. (Tickets are $4.50 to $7.50.)

title: Aspin Reports Evidence Of Plans on Nerve Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) The Army may be in the process of trying to convince Congress to overturn its ban on the production of new lethal nerve gases, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you have decided to participate in the gold rush of 1975, you'll find it a lot more complex than the California miners did during the gold rush that began 127 years earlier.

title: MORTON W. STEIN, 68, EXMALVERNE MAYOR
description: Morton Willard Stein, a former Mayor of Malverne, L. I., died yesterday in Community Hospital in Naples, Fla. He was 68 years old.

title: BUILDINGS PARLEY RESUMING TODAY
description: Negotiations are scheduled to resume today in an effort to avert a strike or more than 25,000 buildingservice employes that could leave 90 per cent of the commercial buildings in Manhattan without heat and other services after midnight Tuesday, when the union's contract expires.

title: Argentine Killings Up to 195
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 25 (Reuters) The body of an Uruguayan student, Raid Darachnik, shot several times in the head, was found here today in what appeared to be the latest political murder in Argentina, the police said. The death raised to at least 195 the number of people known or suspected to have Men killed since July 1 in Argentina for political reasons.

title: Fire Victim Identified
description: Fire officials have identified a 65year old woman who died Tuesday night when a blaze engulfed her threestory building at 2807 MermaidAvenue in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn. They said the victim was Dorothy Chappelle. The fire broke out at 6:17 P.M.

title: Italian Flier Slain By East Side Thug
description: Mario Ienne, a 55yearold Alitalia Airlines flight engineer on a visit to New York from Rome, was stabbed to death last night on Vanderbilt Avenue when he resisted a mugger.

title: Graham Denounces Greed
description: MONTREAT, N.C., Dec. 25 (AP)The Rev. Billy Graham said in a Christmas message today that the world was paying a fearful price for 2,000 years of rejecting Christ's teaching and work. The world's problems are simply reflections of the sin and greed in our nearts, the evangelist said in a prayer for the world that he wrote at the request of The Asheville CitizenTimes.

title: Carey's Chief of Staff Is a Pragmatist With a Cause
description: The trappings of New York State power remain in the old gingerbread Capitol in Albany, but the real power is shifting day by day to a warren of offices at 270 Broadway where the desks have the word surplus taped to them, the paint is smudgy green and the dusty overhead pipes are exposed.

title: Australia to Airlift 10,000 Out of CycloneHit Darwin
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 26  An airlift to evacuate at least 10,000 people fpom the cyclonedevastated city of Darwin began today, according to authoritative word reaching here.

title: CAPE COD ISLAND TO BE PRESERVED
description: CHATHAM, Mass., Dec. 25Strong Island, a noted Cape Cod landmark and one of the few remaining unspoiled areas on the Cape, has escaped the threat of development with its purchase by a local conservation organization.

title: TRIBESMEN SEIZE KEY TOWN IN LAOS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 25 (AP)A group of rebellious Laotian Army soldiers have taken over the provincial capital of Ban Houei Sai in northwestern Laos, informed sources said today.

title: GALLEY, NOW FREE, SEEKS ANONYMITY
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 25 (AP)William L. Calley Jr. no longer haunted by the possibility of confinement for the My Lai murders, has taken up a new, private lifestyle.

title: Schneider's Orchestra Plays Mozart
description: Alexander Schneider's New York String Orchestra is six years old now, and already its Christmas. Eve midnight concerts at popular prices in Carnegie Hall have become a New York institution.

title: CRIME TASK FORCE TO GET NEW CHIEF
description: William I. Aronwald will be named, today as the new chief of the Joint Strike Force Against Organized Crime.

title: Knicks Lose to 76ers, 10497
description: Just before the National Anthem was played last night at Madison Square Garden, Gene Shue, the Philadelphia 76er coach, broke the news to Allan Bristow.

title: A Shrinkage of Linkage
description: WASHINGTONLinkagethat old Nixon policy toward the Soviet Union demanding tit for tatis dead. Its interment will take place when President Ford, in accordance with the trade bill Congress has passed, gives the Russians what they want most: mostfavorednation status, a lowering of tariffs, and an economic boost.

title: Buddy's Place Host To Illinois Jacquet And Four Friends
description: Illinois Jacquet has been so consistently associated for the last 25 years with endless repetitions of Flying Home and the honking of his Jazz at the ?? days, that it is a particular pleasure to find him at Buddy's Place, 64th Street at Second Avenue, surrounded by musicians with whom he can relax and show off the deeper, more subtle aspects of his work on tenor saxophone and his recently developed interest in the bassoon. With Hank Jones on piano, Tiny Grimes, guitar, Percy Heath, late of the Modern Jazz Quartet, on bass, and Panama Francis on drums, Mr. Jacquet has a wealth of jazz talent with whom he can share the spotlight.

title: Garage at Columbia Will Not Be Razed, Local Board Says
