description: A brilliant shooting performance by Phil Sellers was not enough for the Rutgers basketball team to overcome the awesome size and dazzling teamwork of Southern California last night in the semifinal round of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden. Despite a 32point performance by the junior forward, the Scarlet Knights fell to U.S.C., 8166.

title: Large gifts came in small boxes
description: Joseph Cornell, who died two years ago at the age of 69, is one of those artists destined to elude forever the revelations of biography. He was a legend in his lifetime, and a legend he is likely to remaina hermetic artist whose work effectively concealed an even more hermetic life that was lived, so far as we know, almost entirely within the confines of a carefully constructed mental labyrinth of his own devising. The small boxes and collages upon which Cornell lavished his immense gifts are now among the most highly prized of contemporary works of artthey have, indeed, the status of unquestioned classicsyet they bear little resemblance to the kind of art that flourished in New York in the heyday of his most inventive productions. Eccentric in his tastes and in the manner in which he conducted his personal and artistic affairs, Cornell produced an art that is itself an eccentric and inspired mutationa mode of visual discourse that is closer in method and feeling to the elaborate concealments of Symbolist poetry than to the customary stratagems of pictorial art.

title: Mrs. Juceam Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Juceam. of Manhasset, L.I., on Dec. 17 in the Long Island Jewish HospitalHillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. Mrs. Juceam, who is known professionally as Dr. Eleanor Pam is a professor in the department of student personnel services of Queensborough Community College. Her husband is a lawyer with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shrivar & Jacobson here. The child has been named Gregory Andrew.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1974

title: College Festival to Open Friday
description: If you're mad at the Rangers and not in the mood for the Islanders but still yearn for quality hockey, don't despair. An alternative exists and it isn't the return of the World Hockey Association to New York. This week topnotch college hockey comes back to New York.

title: Sag Harbor Holds a Candlelight Tour
description: SAG HARBOR  Only a few years ago it would have been unthinkable to hold a house tour in dead of winter here, but the Old Sagg Harbour Committee, a group that has been doing preservation work for more than 30 years, did just that with a candlelight tour last night.

title: PROTEST ON WRITER IS SENT TO MOSCOW
description: The president of the Association of American Publishers, Townsend W. Hoopes, sent a telegram to President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union on Friday to protest the possibly imminent jailing of Anatoly Marchenko, an author who already spent mine of his 36 years in prison camps.

title: Burger Urges More Judges at More Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called on Congress today to revitalize the Federal court system by increasing judges' salaries and creating 63 judgeships to help handle the steadily mounting judicial workload.

title: South Korea Veterans Ransack Offices of Opposition Party
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 28About 200 army veterans ransacked the offices of the opposition New Democratic party today in Taegu, a provincial capital, and about 300 policemen clashed with about 100 opposition party members who were attempting to march to the party's local headquarters.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: BQLI Bulletin Board
description: AlbertsonGeometric paintings by Pearl Rebhun, beginning Saturday, through this month, Shelter Rock Public Library, 165 Searingtown Road. For hours, call (516) CH 87363.

title: Libra's Last Triumph Decisive
description: For more than a month last fall, Dick London knew there was something wrong with his jumper, Libra. He fell at the North Shore Show, London said the other day, and he wasn't right again until he died. Libra was found dead in his stall just eight weeks ago, 10 days after his last appearance in the ring. When the points for the Long Island High Score Awards Association were added up in the preliminary intermediate jumper division, Libra had won the title. So for the first time, a dead horse captured a division championship of the association. Libra finished with 229 points to 212 for the runnerup, Ralph De Sanctis' Lord Raven.

title: ...And Another's Success
description: DETROITIs it possible for a young man to get a job in the middle of the Depression and, through perseverance, hard work and drive, become the head of the largest corporation in the world?

title: Private Funeral Will Be Held For Amy Vanderbilt Tuesday
description: A private funeral will be held for Amy Vanderbilt, the 66yearold syndicated columnist and authority on etiquette, who plunged to her death Friday night from a thirdfloor window of her townhouse at 438 East 87th Street.

title: Theater Benefits
description: Tickets for the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Music: Baroque Soloists
description: Since New York boasts a number of knowledgeable and gifted performers of Baroque music, visiting specialists must be of high quality to make an outstanding impression.

title: Miss Shoemaker Wed
description: Patricia Marie Shoemaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Shoemaker Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Ocean City, N.J., was married in Scarsdale yesterday afternoon to Edward Daniel O'Keeffe 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Keeffe Jr. of Yonkers. The Rev. Francis P. O'Malley performed the ceremony in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a senior at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y. Mr. O'Keeffe graduated from Manhattan College.

title: Scuffler
description: The wrapper of Scuffler tells us no more about its author than that he is vice president of Columbia Pictures, and the book is heavy with blurbs from Zero Mostel, Groucho Marx, Richard Burton and other literate men. And, of course, it very nearly is a film, starring, oh, Elliott Gould, say, as the rough kid on the make who scores big with women, makes a lot of money, keeps his whoring heart golden and adopts a Vietnamese war orphan on the last page.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Although dance, like the theater and music, measures its life in seasons that don't conform to the calendar, the end of a year does offer a special temptation for retrospection. What was dance like in 1974? Let's look brieflyaround the world in a thousand words.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Thursday is the opening day of the ordering period for the 1975 sixpiece cupronickel proof set, with orders to be accepted through Feb. 28. The Mint may, however, announce an earlier closing date if the flow of orders indicates that the production potential will be equalled before Feb. 28.

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: *** Caughey's, 64 Hoboken Road, East Rutherford. (201) 9394448.

title: Bruin Goalie Still Injured
description: VANCOUVER, Dec. 28 (AP) The Boston Bruins' goalie, Gilles Gilbert, will leave the club's road trip and fly to Boston tomorrow for more examination of his injured back. Gilbert, who hurt his back a month ago has played only two periods in 10 games since the injury.

title: Wilson Names 4 to Board On Unemployment Insurance
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28 (UPI)Governor Wilson today announced the appointment or reappointment of four members of the Unemployment Insurance Board.

title: Popularity Making Fireplaces Scarce
description: The chill winds that turn homeowners' thoughts to extra heatand fireplacesare turning dealers' thoughts to shortages.

title: Love Story, GermanStyle
description: It was, in some ways, a melodramatic, sentimental, overwritten first novel. A story of young love and starcrossed romance, climaxed by the melancholy death of an appealing protagonist, it quickly became a best seller. Teenagers and many long past their teens wept when they read it and made the story their own. It was translated, dramatized, imitated, hailed as a masterpiece, suppressed as immoral. The 25yearold author was an instant celebrity. His name, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. The novel, The Sorrows of Young Werther. The year, 1774.

title: For the waiting game
description: For the first time since the days of the tent dress, it is possible to be comfortably chic while pregnant. The big loose shapes of the new chemises and smocks are just what a woman needs to cope in style with nine months of her changing shape. Claire Martheleur and Naomi Sims, two former models, have found that pregnancy does not mean automatic dowdiness. They have been able to buy the same clothes they normally would have chosenjust a size (or two) larger. Here are some of their personal selections for partygoing and entertaining at home during the long winter wait.

title: LORD
description: Unhouse that calendar: her dates are done, Her whorings over. Get another one. Try to pretend a new year has begun. The diary, blank, apes sinlessness. This is The most pathetic of all fallaciesThe springseternal hope of a fresh start In the core of winter or, down under, heart Of summer (the same season, after all: Both lack the sharp lan of spring or fall, So very and oppressively much here). The church is realistic: Its new year Does not begin till Easter New Year's Day Is part of Christmas time, roughly halfway, Marked by the Circumcisionsnip and bless And bow halfheartedly to cleanliness, But we, who groan from drink or, showering, sing, Believe the first of January can bring Regeneration magically about Both in our psyches and the world without. On Jan. 6, 10in other words, a bit Later, we will, we vow, get down to it. Nonsenseit can't be done: that's definite. Spring brings the true new, nature's statements are Simple enough: all change is circular. The firm ascending straight progressive line Is dream geometry, that's all. In fine, This Nineteen Seventyfive will see us still Churning in Seventyfour's Satanic mill. Has any twelvemonth fed us more with fear? Was ever a more salutary year? At least we're learning and no more pretend That history moves to a Hegelian end.

title: Gilchrist in Final
description: Steve Ogilvy and Jim Gilchrist reached the final of the Eastern indoor tennis championship for men 55 and over yesterday at the Parade Grounds Tennis Center in Brooklyn. Ogilvy beat Len Hartman, 7.5, 6.0, and Gilchrist defeated Selwyn Freed, 6.1, 6.1.

title: Charles A. Lindbergh and the Battle Against American Intervention in World War II
description: By Wayne S. Cole.

title: ROBERT SANDERS, 68, A PIANIST, TEACHER
description: Robert L. Sanders, a conductor, composer and pianist who had been chairman of the music department of Brooklyn College from 1947 until his retirement in 1972, died Thursday at a hospital in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 68 years old and had homes in Delray Beach and Boothbay Harbor, Me.

title: New Zoning Asked in Part of Coney Island
description: A 14block area of Coney Island that has remained stable and strong amid the physical deterioration that has afflicted large sections of the resort peninsula has been proposed for special zoning protection by the Department of City Planning.

title: Broadway Limited Goes Off Track; 41 Injured Slightly
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 28 (UPI)Twelve cars of the Penn Central's Broadway Limited, carrying 430 passengers from Chicago to New York and Washington, went off the tracks today along the Juniata River about 40 miles northwest of this Pennsylvania capital city. There were no serious injuries.

title: Million Illegal Aliens In Metropolitan Area
description: A wave of illegal aliens into the metropolitan region  officially estimated at more than one millionhas overwhelmed the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service here, virtually paralyzing the enforcement of immigration laws.

title: PRYOR IS RETIRING FROM L.I.R.R. UNION
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 28After more than two decades as chairman of the United Transportation Union of the Long Island Rail Road, during which time he was denounced by commuters for strikes and lauded by his membership for benefit gains, Harold J. Pryor will retire next Tuesday.

title: The Region In Summary
description: New York State's sixyearold Urban Development Corporation, generally thought of as the most powerful state urbanimprovement agency in the country, is in a weakened financial condition, and both the outgoing and incoming governors of New York as well as officials of the agency itself, are trying to figure out how to help it.

title: Music: Vienna Boys
description: The Vienna Choir Boys have become a fixture on the American musical scenethis is the group's 31st United States tourand yesterday afternoon a contingent of 24 singers plus their pianist conductor, Anton Neyder, appeared at Avery Fisher Hall for the first of five performances there.

title: Speculative Debut of Gold Futures
description: Four major United States commodity exchanges will offer the public a chance to speculate in gold, beginning next Tuesdaythe New York Mercantile Exchange; the Commodity Exchange, Inc., also in New York; the Chicago Board of Trade, and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Redskins Set Tryout
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI)The Washington Redskins will conduct the first of several 1975 freeagent camps Jan. 9 through 11 at nearby Chantilly, Va.

description: In contrast to last week's hectic Bishop Loughlin Games with its almost 4,000 entries, yesterday's 21st annual Catholic High Schools Relay Carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory seemed like a dual meet.

title: A.E.C. STRESSES REACTOR'S VALUE
description: The schedule for building the nation's first demonstration breeder nuclear power plant in Tennessee by 1982 should not be relaxed as some have urged, high officials of the Atomic Energy Commission concluded after reviewing the commission's breeder program last fall.

title: AvantGarde Quality Marks DesignerCraftsmen Exhibit
description: MORRISTOWN  The annual exhibition of the New Jersey Designer  Craftsmen Association, which is now being held at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences, is not intended as a seasonal exhibition. It simply represents the fruits of a year's labor of 45 bf the state's most skilled craftsmen and craftswomen.

title: Charter for Caramanlis
description: Premier Caramanlis says his Government's draft for a new Constitution was made for Greece, but it bears striking resemblances to the charter fashioned for France's Fifth Republic by Charles de Gaulle. George Mavros of the Center Union opposition is right in saying the draft was made to fit the requirements of a single person [Mr. Caramanlis], and there is substance in Andreas Papandreou's charge that this Constitution could change Parliament into a secondclass branch of Government.

title: South Bronx Policeman Slain as Suspect Panics
description: A plainclothes anticrime officer investigating a robbery in the South Bronx was shot and killed early yesterday, apparently by a man unconnected with the robbery who panicked when confronted by the officer.

title: FORD IS FEARFUL OF MIDEAST WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI)  President Ford firmly believes there is a high likelihood of war in the Middle East unless the United States can get Israel and the Arabs to negotiate further military disengagements.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Dark Continent A to Z
description: A novel, even a first novel? A text in 26 chapters, each adding words that begin with the next letter of the alphabet until the entire range is represented; it begins, then, allowing all, allowing anyone . . . author's analytically aggressive anticipations. And then it takes the words away again, in 26 more chapters, after a climax between Z and Z1, a climax registered in the phrase: confirming my suspicions regarding Africa's shrinking land mass, only one single incident keeps recurring in my mind. It ends with the words another Africa another alphabet, having permitted the rudiments of a narrative, of characters, of whereabouts to be alphabetically intimated in a systole and diastole of increment and subtraction, like the rhythms of breathing and sexuality which are the cause of writing itself, and of this writting in particular.

title: Katharine Elliott Nafe Is Bride Of Christopher Kenah, Geologist
description: Katharine Elliott Nafe who is engaged in zoological research at Princeton University, was married yesterday noon to Christopher Kenah, a graduate student in geology there. The Quaker ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Palisades, N., Y., was under the auspices of the Providence Friends Meeting of Media, Pa.

title: St. Martin: Two countries for the Price of One
description: FRENCH St. Martin and Dutch Sint Maarten form a single island of 34 square miles shaped like a conch shell, lying just east of the Virgin Islands. The northern 20 square miles are French and the southern 14 square miles are Dutch, the two parts separated by a rather casual boundary something like a New England stone wall and in a similarly typical state of desuetude. What does it matter? The entire island is a free port anywayon customs, no visas, nothing at the border but sapodillas, frangipani, and at the main crossisland road, a stone marker erected in 1948 to commemorate 300 years of relatively peaceful coexistence between the French and the Dutch.

title: Marsha Baust Wed To R. A. Lonergan
description: Marsha Edith Baust, a trial preparation assistant in the District Attorney's office here, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert A. Lonergan. Both expect to receive degrees in June from the Fordham Law School. The Rev. Morris Dwyer performed the ceremony in, the Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Roxbury, N. Y.

title: New Books for DoItYourselfers
description: During the past year or so, numerous new books have been published which can be helpful to doityourselfers and home craftsmen, as well as to those readers on the lookout for new ideas and moneysaving suggestions on how to improve and maintain their homes and apartments. Although it would be impractical to try and describe all of them, here are some titles which should prove of interest:

title: Music
description: One day in 1946, Robert Mann, the first violinist of the Juilliard Quartet, was at home discussing a proposed string quartet concert on the phone. Could the Juilliard ensemble play on such and such a date? No, but Mann suggested in its place a young group then studying with him and his colleagues at the Juilliard School. What was this group's name? Since it had no name yet, Mann started to grope wildly for one. Looking out the window he saw the street signs on the corner where he lived: Broadway and La Salle Street. La Salle, he blurted hastily, and thus was christened the LaSalle Quartet. Twentynine years later, the quartet is returning to what is almost home, Alice Tully Hall in the Juilliard building, to present its famous fourconcert cycle of works by Schoenberg, Webern and Berg, beginning Jan. 13.

title: Searching for the present in the past
description: The Modern WorldSystem is one of the extraordinary publishing nonevents of the season. It also happens to be one of the important books of the year. Although its official publication date fell sometime in May, the book has not yet found its way into the publisher's catalogues. Despite such apparent neglect, the work had begun to gather an underground reputation while it was still in manuscript and its reputation has continued to grow. Such continuing official neglect is the more surprising since Fernand Braudel, the internationally distinguished French historian, declared in an advance comment that he could say without hesitation that it is the finest book of analytic history that I have read in the last ten years.

title: My doctor, the corporation
description: Mrs. Sophie Goldman is terribly proud of her son Martin, the doctor.*

title: Matthews to Stay a Packer
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 28 (UPI) The Green Bay Packer safety, Alvin Matthews, has decided to continue playing professional football rather than, accept an offer to join Fred Akers's staff at the University of Wyoming. Matthews, a former parttime coach at the University of Texas while Akers was offensive coordinator for the Longhorns, said he was enthusiastic about playing next year after talking to the new Packer coach, Bart Starr.

title: The Nation
description: The Watergate anticlimax will occur this week when 12 ordinary citizens of Washington debate the guilt or innocence of five men, including three of the highest former officials of the Nixon Administration, In the coverup of the Watergate breakin.

description: A compromise plan to build three 10story apartment towers on a Brooklyn site near the Verrazzano Bridge, has been rejected by the community board in Bay Ridge.

description: The flocking instinct among economists in the winter of the year is compelling. Like birds, the country's top analysts cluster to arrive as if by instinct at a consensus about the shape of the year to come.

description: Despite a dearth of bullish economic news, the stock market managed to finish with small gains last week in moderate trading.

title: The New Year Is Bright With Promise
description: There has been much for women in sports to celebrate this yearthe Little League ruling, the growing acceptance of women sharing with men, Title IX (which threatens nonacceptance), breakthroughs in professional golf and tennis and virtually every schoolboy sport. Women's professional football hit the magazines, a pro basketball league is in the making, television began to pay attention. Cyndi Meserve, an 18yearold fashion and design major at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, carved her name into national collegiate history by becoming the first woman to play in an N.C.A.A. basketball game. JoAnn Carver and Jane Blaylock made over $85,000 on the Laces Professional Golf Association tour and Billie Jean King signed a lucrative contract (You know I won't take less than a guy) with ABCTV as a sports commentator.

description: DARWIN, Australia, Dec. 28 Pieces of twisted metal hang grotesquely from shattered buildings. Sheets of corrugated iron are draped over telephone poles.

CHESS
description: One of the cardinal rules of defense is: don't advance pawns in the vicinity of your castled king.

description: About 100 colleagues, some of them weeping, converged on the 41st Precinct station house in the South Bronx early yesterday to mourn the death of Kenneth A. Mahon, slain in the line of duty.

title: Clues Sought in Deserted Area of Jersey Where 2 Girls' Bodies Were Found
description: MANALAPAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 28 The police searched for clues today in the area where the bodies of two badly beaten teenaged girls were found yesterday.

title: Remembering James Agee
description: How to account for what the novelist David Madden, editor of this collection of reminiscences, calls the legend of James Agee. Perhaps it arises out of Agee's agreeable ability to be, within somewhat ampler than mortal limits, anything you want him to be. Or, more particularly, anything you want to be: the author of a masterpiece both neglected and famous, a wellpaid critic proclaiming what was then the new art of film, a PulitzerPrize novelist, an intellectual, a lyric poet, a satirist of large promise, a scriptwriter with important Hollywood friends, a firstrate journalist with distinguished New York friends, a bewitching talker, an enthusiastic drinker, someone renowned enough (it often seems) for his kindness alone, handsome in youth, often tormented, and mourned even now, 20 years after his death. Among the young, especially, some might decline the torment and pass up the drink; but one wonders how many.

title: Old Ferryboat May Become a Restaurant
description: EDGEWATERThe ferryboar Binghamton, which for the last six years has been beached on the shore of the Hudson River, may become a restaurant if her new owners succeed in working out a satisfactory lease with the Borough Council.

title: Can Yankees Master Florida's Gardens?
description: Northern gardeners who move to Florida often wonder what they will do about pursuing their hobby. The richness and opulence of the tropical plant life staggers the mind. But cease to worry. Gardening in Florida will be easy.

title: Gift to Newark: Vignette of Past
description: NEWARKA pictorial record of a family living at Tanglewood, in Bayonne, from 1892 to 1908a rare vignette that survives from a time when the budding Industrial Age barely touched the many small towns dotting New Jerseyis a newly received gift of the New Jersey Historical Society.

title: The Ultra Secret
description: This book reveals the greatest secret of World War II after the atom bomb. It is a must for World War II and Intelligence buffs. But it has to be read with caution.

description: The Most Rev. Francis J. Mugavero, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, gave $100 yesterday to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, writing, May I express my prayerful gratitude for your concern for the poor and deprived.

description: This is the time of year to think of the less fortunate. It is a time to think of children in need, of the old and infirm, of the handicapped and the suffering.

I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hope Coleman, to Thomas Aquinas Reynolds 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds Jr. of Winnetka, Ill., and Harbor Springs, Mich.

description: BURLINGTON, Vt.American higher education stands on the brink of chaos. Never have so many spent so long learning so little.

description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 28 (Reuters)  President Ford today signed legislation authorizing $2.9billion for military construction, including $18.1million for expanding facilities on the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: UNESCO vs. Israel: Playing Politics With Culture
description: Not since Ezra Pound received the Bollingen award for The Pisan Cantos in 1948at a time when he was under indictment for committing treason during World War IIhas there been such tumult in cultural circles. The main source, of course, is the decision by the biennial General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) on Nov. 20 that Israel is so uncivilized that it must be banned from European regional membership and deprived of $26,000 in cultural assistance. In economic terms the interdict does not make sense, since Israel contributes more to UNESCO than it receives, but that, of course, is not the point. Israel cannot be admitted to the Middle East region because, as a Lebanese spokesman put it, it is a state which belongs nowhere because it comes from nowhere. Although legally speaking Israel has not been expelled from UNESCO, she is under a ban of cultural excommunication.

title: Mrs. Grasso Names Aide
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 28 (UPI)Governorelect Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut today named John N. Dempsey Jr., the son, of a former Democratic Governor, as her executive assistant. The younger Mr. Dempsey, 28 years old, of New Hartford, worked in her 1972 and 1974, election campaigns and has been serving for the last two years as district assistant for Mrs. Grasso while she served in Washington as a Representative.

title: Man cannot live by beauty alone
description: Before I met Yukio Mishima I had read four of his novels: Confessions of a Monk, The Temple of the Golden Pavilion, After the Banquet, The Sailor Who Fell From Grace With the Sea. I had also read his Five Modern No Plays and the sensational short story Patriotism. The novels and the short story fascinated me. When as a tourist I went to Tokyo for the first time, Mishima was the pefson with whom I was most eager to become acquainted. We had a brief conversation at the old Imperial Hotel. On my return to Tokyo in 1965 to direct Long Day's Journey Into Night Mishima greeted me as a friend, invited me to dinner and to see one of his No plays given by a theatrical company of which, I was informed, he was the guiding spirit. On another occasion he accompanied me to a performance of the Osaka puppeteers and to a nightclub.

title: Kissinger's Role in Mideast Evokes AntiIsraeli Mood Among Greeks
description: ATHENS  The German Jewish Secretary of State of America is making suspicious trips throughout the world for the purpose of destroying Cyprus. Someone should be found to put a violent end to his attempts.

title: Jan Revis, Dutch Vice Consul, Is the Fiance of Sukhreet Gabel
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton Gabel of New York have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Sukhreet Gabel, to Jan A. F. M. Revis, vice consul of the Netherlands In New York, son of Prof. H. A. J. Revis of Nymegen, the Netherlands, and the late Mrs. Revis. A spring wedding is planned.

description: The 23d annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival will conclude tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden. The losers of last night's semifinal will vie for third place in the opening game at 7 o'clock and the championship game will follow.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) More Americans moved out of the nation's largest cities than moved in during the first three years of the nineteensevlenties, according to figures released today by the Census. Bureau. But the pattern may have reversed itself in 1974.

title: Janice Deere Becomes Bride
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great in Harrison, N. Y., yesterday afternoon, Janice Elizabeth Decr was married to John Boretti by the Rev. William E. Williams.

title: Defense and Weather Seen Key As Vikings Play Host to Rams
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 28With one eye on each other and the second on a less predictable source, Mother. Nature, the Minnesota Vikings and Los Angeles Rams will meet for the National Football Conference title tomorrow (Channel 2, 1 P.M., E.S.T.) and a berth in the Super Bowl.

title: '35 MATERNITY BILL PAID WITH INTEREST

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Our company has been involved in the development of retirement communities for more than 10 years. We are familiar with the interactions and problems of such communities, and we have studied the effect they have upon the municipalities in which they are built.

title: Ballet: Toppelia Casts Perform Outstandingly
description: Cast changes this weekend in American Ballet Theater's production of Copplia produced not only a local notable debut by Fernando Bujones but also, quite simply, a performance of a lifetime by Cynthia Gregory the day before in the same ballet. And Ivan Nagy, who partnered Miss Gregory, and Eleanor D'Antuono, who appeared with Mr. Bujones, were no slouches themselves.

title: East Rallies to Take Shrine Game, 16 to 14

title: FILM VIEW
description: This the season to be nasty, to rip this town wide open, to admit biases and prejudices, to publicize wrongdoers and disasters, to celebrate frauds and freaks and mistaken projects. Next week there'll be a. Ten Best Films of the Year list, which will be put together rather soberly, even if a little arbitrarily. This week is for fun. The following awards are intended to offend. If they stir anything on the order of rational debate, they've failed. These awards are gut things. They aren't meant to be reasonable. In short, they're rotten, Thus, to:

title: Marleigh Dover a Bride
description: Marleigh Diane Dover, daughter of Mrs. Eric M. Goldsmith of New York and the late Lee D. Doter, was married here yesterday evening to Zane Alan Lang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Lang of Winter Park, Fla. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at Hampshire House. The couple are thirdyear students at the George. Washington Univerversity National Law Center.

title: RETAILING
description: Few retailers have maintained their prices unchanged for the last 15 years. In this respect the five 69  Cent Shops in New York stand out like a beacon.

title: What's Doing UPSTATE
description: STATE OF MIND  New York State is divided into three partsNew York City, the suburbs and upstate. Geographically, upstate begins where the pull of Albany is felt, somewhere north of Poughkeepsie, and extends to the Canadtan border and the Great Lakes. In politics, upstate is a countervailing force to downstate (which is a synonym for New York City and the suburbs). In newspaper headlines, upstate is a short word describing any place a fair distance north of the city line. But in reality, upstate is a state of mind in which dairy cows and apple trees are as important as the subway fare and rent control are in New York City. Upstate is no monolith; it has cities and suburbs (and their problems) just like downstate. But it also has farmland, fresh air, the Adirondacks, historic sites, the State Capitol and a vast assortment of recreational facilities. This article is a selective look at Albany and some areas to the north and west of. the capital.

title: The Pulitzer Prizes
description: When The New York World's Joseph Pulitzer first contemplated the awards that have honored his name for 57 years, the United States was well settled in the Age of Innocence. Muscles flexed (Puerto Rico and the Philippines had just been taken over), the country was being exhorted by Teddy Roosevelt to climb mountains, bust trusts, reform the politicians and pay attention to the finer things of life. What was lacking were prizes to celebrate this sense of national character, and it was this lack that Pulitzer set about to correct. Halfamillion dollars seemed about right for the task and this sum was set aside in his will for prize money. (Another oneandahalf million went to establish the Columbia School of Journalism, which would administer the awards.)

In a sense, there is the summary of winter in terms best known to those who lived on this land long before the Europeans came.

title: Food: Chicken and mussels
description: A new recipe, something simple, tasty and worth clipping, is one of the rarest of combinations. But occasionallyand usually under stress a fresh combination of foods results in an original dish. This was the case with the following recipe. My friend Lisanne, when living in a tiny hamlet in the south of France, suddenly had to produce a festive birthday dinner. All she had in the houseapart from the basicswere some mussels bought that morning for the family supper. Fortunately, a neighbor who kept poultry could be asked to supply a chicken. With these two ingredients, Lisanne summoned up her courage and her knowledge of cookery and made the marvelous dish that I call Lisanne's chicken with mussels. It is so good that when I submitted it as an entry in the food competition of The Times of London, it received the first prize. The second recipe is another unusual use of musselsthis time as a savory filling for pancakes.

title: New & Novel
description: Berton Roueche's New Yorker article on trichinosis forever altered my trust in spare ribs. Now I am afraid that Feral is going to chill my attitude toward the pussycat. Cats are essentially wild animals, which cat fanciers are fond of telling us. All right. Suppose that a band of strays and abandoned cats were allowed to proliferate and become predators in a wild habitat a stretch of Amagansett woods. It is not a pretty thought, as Mr. Roueohe develops it with his impeccable timing and stepbystep respect for suspense. These kitties are not the sort to whom you offer a saucer of milk, if you value your fingers. They are miniature tigers who have multiplied to the population density of rats. So when Jack and Amy Bishop buy the old Lester place on the fringe of the cat colony, they are in for an escalating series of shocks. The question of what to do about the cat problem introduces a faint strain of irony. A feline Jaws this. Be sure you know where kitty is for the night before you read this.

Most of the promises and programs, of course, would be diluted or abandoned as the new year went along, but there was always measure of conscientious concern and satisfaction derived from the annual exercise.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Revivals are never a waste of time. You always learn something, even when the entertainment being trotted out for a second go at the track is something as inconsequential as a musical version of Charley's Aunt. Certainly I didn't realize, when I first saw the Frank LoesserGeorge Abbott rearrangement known as Where's Charley?, precisely how delicatehow deliberately delicateMr. Loesser's gentlemanly score was.

He was Irwin Allen, Hollywood film producer who has been called the master of disaster, and his selfrequested move toward terra firma had a lot to do with his latest crisis epic, The Towering Inferno, about a holocaust in the world's tallest (138 stories) skyscraper.

title: For Example, Who Doctored the Tapes?
description: One of the arguments heard last summer favoring impeachment rather than resignation, and a trial for former President Nixon rather than a pardon, was that it was important for the whole Watergate story to be told. The very least that was needed, some asserted, was the appearance of the former President in open court giving testimony under oath and subject to crossexamination. Now that all the proof has been presented in the coverup trial, it is possible to assess what it is that the public still does not know and how much it has been hurt by the gaps in its knowledge.

title: Letters
description: The day after Birth Without Violence (by Steven Englund, Dec. 8) appeared, three obstetrical patients asked about Frederick Leboyer's attitude toward birth. It is interesting that medically unsophisticated people should be more openminded than scientists.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: The paint on the underside of the overhanging eaves around the outside of my house is peeling, but only on the areas that have been repainted. The original paint that was put on when the house was built does not peel, only the paint that was put on top afterward. What would cause this?Dr. M.S.M., Northumberland, Pa.

title: Headliners
description: Jack Benny, an institution in American show business, is dead. For 50 years, his offkey violin playing, pretended miserliness and exquisite comedic timing brought laughter to an everexpanding audience, from the vaudeville stage through movies and radio, and finally to television, where his show was a longrunning success. He was neither a miser nor a poor musician; he often contributed large sums to various charities, and just as often performed as a serious violinist in benefit concerts. Mr. Benny was suffering from cancer, though friends said he was not aware of his illness. His age at his death was listed as 80, but friends and fans prefer to remember the age he insisted upon in one of his longestrunning gags: 39.

title: U.S. Tightens Rules on Settlement Costs in Home Sales
description: President Ford signed into law last week a measure that requires the advance disclosure of settlement costs for residential real estate.

title: JOHN F. FENNELLY, INVENTOR, BROKER
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP)John F. Fennelly, an inventor, stockbroker and writer, died yesterday. He was 75 years old and was a senior partner in duPont Walston, Inc., until 1973.

One must also be poised within hearing distance of the rhythmdrenched current pop hit entitled Kung Fu Fighting. Almost 2million copies of this daffy d?? have been sold recently a statistic indicating that the 1970's have finally produced a dance craze to rival the Fish, the Twist, the Monkey and all of those other terpsichorean fantasias of yore.

title: AirportJob Unit Worried By Economic Slowdown
description: Three years ago next month, Benjamin Darden moved into an obscure office at the headquarters of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in Manhattan and was given a desk and a challenge: Help blacks and Puerto Ricans find jobs in what was then a booming aviation industry in Queens.

Levy of Richmond performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Hugo Lenk of New York and the late Mr. Lenk. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Wurtzel is chairman of the Wards Company in Richmond, a national chain of retail outlets. His first wife died.

title: JUDGE CAUTIONS ON WOMEN JURORS
description: The New York statute that automatically exempts women from jury service may be unconstitutional, an acting State Supreme Court Justice has warned.

description: SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Dec 28A spokesman for the bif. oil companies that are eager to resume offshore drilling along the Southern California coast hurried away from a hearing before the Santa Barbara Planning Commission, mopping hit brow and muttering.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mike Brandt, head of West Mountain ski area near Glen Falls, N.Y., talks about one of his responsibilities: Here I am in a venture that calls for me to be able to make snow faster than the Lord can melt it.

title: FORECAST FOR
description: A number of climatologists, whose job it is to keep an eye on longterm weather changes, have lately been predicting deterioration of the benign climate to which we have grown accustomed. They point to signs both great (a steady global cooling trend since World War II) and quaint (the southward retreat from Nebraska of the warmthloving armadillo) to support their claim that the coming years will feature colder, more erratic weather. Some recent warnings, from reputable researchers in Japan, Europe and the U.S., have so worried policymakers that last January certain scientists at a meeting of the National Academy of Sciences proposed the evacuation of some six million people from their parched homelands in the Sahel region of Africa.

title: Wendy Cadley Wed to John E. Stainer
description: In the FirstCongregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Wendy Lambert Cadley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lambert Cadley of Old Greenwich, was married to John Edward Stainer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Alan Stainer of Cowes, Isle of Wight, land. description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 28 (UPI)Twelve cars of the Penn Central's Broadway Limited, carrying 430 passengers from Chicago to New York and Washington, went off the tracks today along the Juniata River about 40 miles northwest of this Pennsylvania capital city. There were no serious injuries.

description: The Knicks' best move yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden was made by Coach Red Holzman.

description: SEOUL, South KoreaTwo and a half years after North and South Korea announced that they would begin talks, relations between the two neighbors have largely reverted to their former state of hostility.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: TV VIEW
description: Clippings for the past year having been reviewed for the annual best and worst exercise, two broad conclusions can be offered to the insatiably curious. Many of TV's more memorable or significant moments were embedded in news specials and documentaries. And public television, for all of its economicpolitical problems, managed to present a disproportionate share of the programs that could lay claim to the elusive label of quality. To begin, the best:

title: Mich. Tech Takes Title On Ice, 32
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28In their 152d meeting, Harvard beat Yale, 8?? in the consolation game of the Great Lakes invitation hockey tournament tonight before 8,107 people at the, Olympia.

title: The Rome Food Conference Is Forgotten
description: DACCAThe scenes are numbing. A woman howling with a dead infant in her arms. Naked, emaciated children sitting on pavements with tin begging cups. Old men lying on burlap bags outside markets, staring vacantly and openmouthed at strangers.

title: BRIDGE
description: Almost all bridge experts are determined to win. If they were not highly competitive and motivated they would not reach the expert category. And many of them are equally determined to win the postmortem. If their partnership has a disaster, or misses an opportunity, they try hard to exonerate themselves and pin the firmly on partner.

description: Mary Kemna Conklin was married in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday afternoon to Neil A. Upmeyer of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst A. Upmeyer of Clearwater, Fla.

description: It was W. H. Auden who remarked that if you can get to a youngster early where poetry is concerned, he may still end up on the gallows, but at least he won't have a tin ear.

title: Book Ends
description: January. Here we go againa new year, a new season, a new leaf. Overall, January's offerings include some solid, if unexciting, titles and a paucity of bestseller types. Two of the likeliest in the latter category are Martin Mayer's The Bankers, continuing his oneman cram course in American businesses and professions, and Elie Kazan's The Understudy, a novel with a showbiz center against a discordant contemporary backdrop. Lawrence Durrell has a new novel, Monsieur. dripping with romantic decadence and arcane lore, and Anthony Burgess serves up The Clockwork Testament or Enderby's End, in which the poet Enderby, of previous literary incarnation, crashes what passes for the New York literary scene.... Ask Farrar, Straus &. Giroux how to pronounce Mawrdew Czgowchwz (we can't even spell it), a campy novel about a Polish diva who upends the Mct. And a new MastersJohnson collaboration aimed at thegeneral reader, The Pleasure Bond.

title: Oil Slick Is Nearly Gone
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (UPI)A small patch of surface oil around a damaged Odeco well was all that remained today of a sevenmile oil slick in the Gulf of Mexico. Donald Solanas, supervisor for the United States Geological Survey, said yesterday: All of the slicks that had been in the area have been dissipated because of the north wind and the heavy seas. The well had been damaged by repair crews last Sunday.

title: Nets Victors By 10098 in Overtime
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 28 (AP)Julius Erving, who had problems at the freethrow line most of the game, hit two foul shots with 25 seconds remaining in overtime to give the New York Nets a 10098 victory over the Memphis Sounds in American Basketball Association tonight.

title: Okla. State Winner In Fiesta Bowl, 166
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 28 (AP) Oklahoma State knocked out Brigham Young University's quarterback, Gary Sheide, in the first quarter and went on to beat the Cougar's, 166, today in the Fiesta Bowl.

title: The Nation/Continued
description: WASHINGTONStarting Tuesday, United States citizens will be legally entitled to buy and own gold for the first time in more than 40 years. Does it make difference?

title: If There's an Old Painting In Your Attic, Please Speak Up
description: Imagine tens of thousands of paintings of sheep lowing in darkling Gothic pastures, mounted cowboys following the trail into the orangy, dusk, towering waves, crashing, into foreboding cliffs. Think of hundreds and hundreds of Irish setters gazing in rapt expectation at their masters, hunters in tweed and twill, rifles in their hands, heading into the glorious foliage of a mid  19th  century autumn woodland. Envision all those old whaling boats, those shining wheat fields in Kansas, those unbelievably purple Western mountainscapes. All this is but a tiny sample of the treasures being discovered and annotated by the National Collection of Fine Arts, whose incredible goal is to find and record in a computer data on every American painting in existenceanywherethat was made before 1914.

title: Design
description: Correspondence cards in Bristol blue and white are geared to masculine tastes. but women will like their bold simplicity, too. Cards on heavy stock from France are engraved with name or monogram in dark blue for $115 for 100, complete with contrasting tissuelined envelopes. Cartier. 2. Writing paper that folds up to make its own envelope comes in a pad of 50 sheets in a choice of four Art Deco borders. $6 at Mark Rodman. 1024A Lexington Avenue. 3.Laminated cardswhite on one side, blue on the otherspell out Thanks, Dinner, Lunch, or Fete in big cutouts. Private Papers for Saks Fifth Avenue. $5 for a box of 15. 4. The newest calling cards in town have designs(quaint to zany)of animals, still fifes, landscapes etc. from old engravings. Printed with name, address and personal message, they are $10 for 100 cards, ffolio 72 at 888 Madison Avenue. 5. Brown craft paper sports sleek, inchhigh names or monograms in raised, uninked letters. $51 for 50 notes with a matching envelopes. Private Papers at Bonwit Teller.

title: Living it up
description: ACROSS

title: Parley Planned On Offshore Oil
description: PRINCETONAccusing the Federal Government of deceit and of attempting to run roughshod over New Jersey and other coastal states, Governor Byrne has invited 12 of his counterparts to a meeting here next month in an effort to organize opposition to offshore oil development.

title: Auto Racing, Still Sputtering, Is Lining Up for Another Start
description: In auto racing, it is usually safe to operate on the premise that good news is no news. The holiday spirit, however, moves one to report that the 1975 season will begin on schedule in two weeks despite crises real and imagined.

title: Bar Defends Views on Judicial Reforms
description: TRENTONThe Byrne administration and the New Jersey Bar Association are trading jabs over judicial reform.

title: OTB Says Bets Reach High Of $772Million in One Year
description: Wagers at offtrack betting offices soared in the fiscal year ended June 30 and the city received a record windfall, according to a report by the Offtrack Betting Corporation to be made public soon.

title: THAI STUDENTS ASK ACTION ON THANOM
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sunday, Dec. 29Five thousand students gathered at Thammasat University last night to demand punishment or exile for former Premier Thanom Kittikachore who defied a Government ban and slipped into the country early Friday with the aid of a retired air marshal.

title: Man and Two Sons Found Shot To Death in Atlantic City Home
description: An Atlantic City contractor and his two teenaged sons were found shot to death yesterday afternoon in their home, and a third child, a 17yearold daughter was clinging to life last night under intensive care, suffering from a bullet wound in the head, the police in that New Jersey resort reported.

title: Where Are All the New Playwrights? Writing Plays
description: Probably the most longstanding lament of our theater critics and playgoers is that there are no new playwrights in America. Yet as a matter of fact, there are hundreds of them, scribbling away in rooms all across the country, and they send their manuscripts to every organization they can think of that produces new plays.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Many of the biggest, loosest, longest dresses in the stores right now bear Paris labels, but some of the prettiest are marked Pat Baron

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Resolutions
description: With the debris of another year nearly behind, but not forgotten, and in keeping with his everincreasing wisdom, this middleaged Huckleberry Finn resolves:

title: Newcombe Is Nearly Defeated
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 28Jimmy Connors had an easy victory but John Newcombe was almost toppled in the Australian open tennis championships today.

title: Thousands of Pounds of Material Usable in Nuclear Bombs Unaccounted For
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Atomic Energy Commission and the industry it nurtured are unable to account for thou sands of pounds of nuclear materials that could be fashioned into crude nuclear bombs, according to experts in business, universities and the commission.

title: TOUGH FORD STAND ON ECONOMY SEEN
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 28President Ford is planning to propose some fundamental changes in economic policy in his State of the Union Message Jan. 20, his spokesmen said today after a 4hour meeting between the President and his advisers.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Included in all copier distributed in New York City and the suburban area.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1RALPH STEADMAN

title: BETHLEHEM STOPS2 PRICE INCREASES
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (AP)Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's No. 2 steel producer, announced today a partial rollback of price increases scheduled to take effect Monday.

title: Mount Cranmore Ski Operator Terms Hot Dogging Perilous
description: NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Dec. 28  Herb Schneider, whose father, the late Hannes, started teaching skiing techniques in his native Austria shortly after the turn of the century, has become a solid antagonist of hot dog skiing. I'm happy my father is not here to see what some overzealous exploiters are doing to skiing, said Schneider, who operates the Mount Cranmore complex, one of America's first major ski resorts.

title: Nuptials Are Held For Anne Bermant
description: Anne Bermant and Charles E. Hancock were married yesterday evening in Rye, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David W. Bermant. State Supreme Court Justice Stewart F. Hancock Jr., cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Women's Athletics: A Conflict Over Regulations
description: Since June 18, 1974 when Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, had his press briefing, confusion has reigned over the proposed guidelines for Title IX. There are very few athletic administrators who are not apprehensive at the approach that H.E.W. seems to be taking to equalizing competition and physical education for women pew athletic directors quarrel with equal opportunity for women in athletics or the equal use of facilities for women's sports. In fact, many of the country's leading institutions began to move into intercollegiate athletics for women long before it became fashionable. For years, at the University of Michigan our women's field hockey team, for instance, has used our football stadium something like 45 to 50 per cent more than our men's football program. In the last few years, in National Collegiate Athletic Association schools at least, there has been a conscious effort to increase varsity teams and varsity competition for women. We simply course.

title: Dance: Scheherezade
description: Last February, at the Lyceum Theater, one of the principal events of Murray Louis's Broadway season was the premiere of Scheherezade, a Dream. This was an ambitious fantasy work in two acts. The form did not quite satisfy Mr. Louis, so he started extensive reworkings, revisions and expansions. The new production of Scheherezade, a Dream, is now a fullevening work in three acts, and it had its premiere Thursday night at the New York University Theater.

title: It Can Be Mind Over Matter If You Want to Shed Pounds
description: ELIZABETH  Groups of obese New Jerseyans have been using the psychological tool of behavior modification to cure their sickness and, according to the two psychologists directing them, have slimmed down at a rate confirming the results of similar programs at several universities.

title: Antarctic Chronicle: The Midsummer Sun Brings Bustle and Barbecues to Polar Life
description: Adm. Richard E. Byrd, broadcasting from Antarctica in the nineteenthirties, conveyed through the static a vivid sense of the breathtaking excitement of an enchanted placedeadly indeed, but also indescribably interesting and beautiful.

title: Autos And the Economy
description: MUNCIE, Ind.  Have automobiles been priced out of the market? Has the energy crisis scared off buyers? Are times too hard and uncertain for most folks to trade in the old car on a new one? Is the great American love affair with the horseless carriage fading at last?

title: Athene Lynn Chiriacka Is Married
description: Athene Lynn Chiriacka, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Chiriacka of New York and Kings Point, L.I., was married late yesterday afternoon to Richard C. Westergaard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl C. Westergaard of Palatine, Ill. The Rev. Brendan Riorden performed the ceremony in the St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Mary Corless Is Bride
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Mary Ellen Coxless, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Corless of North Bergen, N. J., was married to Donald Delmar FitzGerald, son of Dorothy Delmar FitzGerald of White Plains and the late Thomas A. FitzGerald, The Rev. John Ryan performed the ceremony.

title: Karen Wotiz Is Wed To Michael McManus
description: Karen Jean Wotiz. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Wotiz of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Michael Conway McManus, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. McManus of Llewellyn Park, West Orange. Mayor William F. Cuozzi Jr. of West Oratige performed the ceremony at the McManus home.

title: Wasted Life
description: The anguished cries and frantic legal maneuvering of Chicago's officialdom after a Federal judge halted the city's revenuesharing payments demonstrate not how unfairly the law is being applied to Chicago, but rather how difficult it is to enforce a law that requires public officials not to discriminate.

title: REFORM IN STUDY OF LAW IS URGED
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein proposed yesterday that law students get out of the classroom so that they and their professors can work part of their time to help good causes and individuals.

title: Truancy Seen Cutting Aid To Some School Districts
description: The Women's City Club asserted yesterday that high rates of truancy were causing some city school districts to be penalized through reductions in state aid, thus limiting their ability to remedy their problems.

title: Rozelle: We'll Win In Court
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minne., Dec. 29  Confident that the National Football League will overcome an unfavorable judicial ruling in the Joe Kapp case. Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today we have no plans to change any of our practices, including the draft, under the present circumstances.

title: Watergate Jury Gets Case Today After 13 Weeks, Testimony by 80 and Playing of Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29At 9:30 tomorrow morning Judge John J. Sirica will take the bench in Court Number Two at the United States Courthouse on Constitution Avenue. After summoning the jury, for two and a half hours he will explain to them the law on conspiracy and perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: 21 From U.S Are Killed In Guatemala Plane Crash
description: GUATEMALA CITY, Dec. 29 (AP)  Twentyone American tourists, including 19 from the New York metropolitan area, were killed last night when chartered plane crashed in flames in northern Guatemala. The three Guatemalan crew members of the plane were also killed.

title: Thinking the Unthinkable
description: BOSTON, Dec. 29The gravest development of the year 1974, it would now be generally agreed, was the exercise of monopoly power by the oilexporting countries. As the year ends, many weighty voices warn that the quadrupling of oil prices threatens a world economic collapse. Some speak of Western civilization being at risk.

title: Mideast: Danger...
description: At a time when President Ford and others are voicing increasing concern about the threat of a new war in the Middle East, the virtues of compromise and negotiation are losing their luster for the peoples of the region. From both sides come disturbing arguments that their respective interests might be better served by a new test of arms. Anyone in the Middle East or far away who can face such a prospect with equanimity simply has not thought out the implications.

title: Thousands Watch Hollywood Farewell to Benny
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29The allowbusiness world turned out today to say goodby to Jack Benny, the gentle comedian who charmed millions of Americans over a long career that carried him through the top ranks of vaudeville, radio, movies and television.

title: Watergate Jury's Day
description: Judge John J. Sirica gives the Watergate coverup case to the jury today after 13 weeks of trial. Details, Page 16.

title: Plight of Public Transportation Systems Mounts
description: When long queues of automobiles began backing up behind gasoline pumps in Portland, Ore., a year ago, Robert A. Orr, a city employe decided to switch to mass transportation.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LIFE OF EMILY DICKINSON. By Richard B. Sewall, 821 pages. Two volumes. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30.

title: 95% of 36,900 Recruits Called Average or Above
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)  The Defense Department says that 95 per cent of its 36,900 recruits for the armed services last month rated in the average and aboveaverage mental categories. That is the highest percentage for a single month since such records were begun 23 years ago.

title: Calendars '75 Will Delight Nature Lovers
description: Calendarbuying time is here again, and this year those stacks of calendars in the stores have been added to by a new sours: book publishers. Even if people turn out to be cutting down on bookbuying in these times, the reasoning seems to go, they still need to know what day of the year it is.

title: Herblock Says Drawing Nixon Was Unpleasant
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)Herbert Block, the syndicated cartoonist who draws his political satire as Herblock, said today that despite having spent more than a quarter century of drawing Richard M. Nixon he never really enjoyed it.

title: MOSTADMIRED LIST HEADED BY KISSINGER
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 29 (AP)For the second straight year, Secretary of State Kissinger heads the Gallup Poll's list of men Americans admire most.

title: KISSINGER SUGGESTS COMPROMISE ON OIL
description: Secretary of State Kissinger was quoted yesterday as saying that the United States would consider tying the price of oil to that of other commodities.

title: Detroit in Recession Reflects Fear and Strength
description: DETROIT, Dec. 29  This tough old factory towna rough, unfinished metropolis of browns and grays and tarnished brickredslooks like what some people say it is: the frontier of the industrial society. Detroit today, America tomorrow, is how. Mayor Coleman A. Young characterizes the position of the country's fifth largest city.

title: St. John's Former Coach Bows To ExTeam Using His Strategy
description: His friends call Lou Carnesecca, The Godfather. Yesterday, the St. John's basketball coach, and his team, went to see the movie, The Godfather, Part II, in SeaCock, Mass. Twelve hours earlier, the Redmen committed some larceny of their own. They stole a game from nationally ranked South Carolina, 7877, on two overtime free throws by Frank Alagia. The victory over Frank McGuire's team enabled St. John's to reach the final of the Ocean State Tournament against Providence College at the Providence (RI.) Civic Center tonight.

title: Widow Is Slain as Disabled Son Goes for Help
description: As her 17yearold son, a victim of cerebral palsy, struggled to la neighbor's apartment for help, a 57yearold widow was beaten and slain yesterday morning in her apartment in Woodside, Queens.

title: JobHunting Jars ModernLanguage Convention
description: Those graying pipesmokers, wearing tweeds and sensible lowheeled shoes, skulking in and out of seminars ranging from medieval drama to sciencefiction at the annual meeting of the Modern Language Association at the Hilton and Americana Hotels during the last four days were, it turned out, chairmen of college and university departments.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N. Y. 10249, or to any of the following eight organizations that certify these cases:

title: GIUSEPPE DOZZA, 73, MAYOR OF BOLOGNA
description: Giuseppe Dozza, Communist and Mayor of Bologna, Italy, from 1945 to 1966, died there Saturday, according to reports from Tass, the Soviet press agency. He was 73 years old.

title: Madrid Airport Reopens
description: MADRID, Dec. 29 (Reuters)Madrid's international airport returned to normal today after being fogbound for 50 hours the longest in its history. About 600 flights were suspended, affecting 40,000 travelers, airport officials said.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Nicaraguan Government agreed yesterday to release 26 political prisoners and fly them to Cuba in exchange for the lives of a group of prominent politicians and business leaders seized by leftist guerrillas at a Christmas party in Managua Friday night. Earlier in the day, the guerrillas released five remaining women hostages, but kept 13 men for bargaining purposes. [Page 1, Columns 12.]

title: Enrollment at 4Year Colleges Increases by 3.5% to 6,650,000
description: A dramatic rise in the number of freshmen and women students helped to push total enrollment at fouryear colleges and universities in the United States above 6,650,000 in the last academic quarter, according to the 55th annual study conducted by the University of Cincinnati for the American College Testing Program.

title: 3 MORE AIDES QUIT IN C. SHAKEUP; FACED TRANSFERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Three more highranking officials of the Central Intelligence Agency resigned last week in a major shakeup of the agency's counterintelligence division, wellinformed Government sources said today.

title: Detroit in Recession Reflects Fear and Strength
description: DETROIT, Dec. 29  This tough old factory towna rough, unfinished metropolis of browns and grays and tarnished brickredslooks like what some people say it is: the frontier of the industrial society. Detroit today, America tomorrow, is how Mayor Coleman A. Young characterizes the position of the country's fifth largest city.

title: Shipping/Mails Ail Hours Given In Eastern Standard Time
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Immigration Fraud Case Dropped in '72
description: Partly because unfavorable publicity might have resulted from an indictment, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York dropped in 1972 an immigrationfraud case against a former Commissioner of the John V. Lindsay administration.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HANDIWORK Theater, ballet and opera enthusiasts in the Lincoln Center vicinity, with spare time after matinees and before evening curtainsor any one interested in theater craftsmanshipwould do well to see the current ebibition Contemporary Stage DesignU.S.A., at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts.

title: BabySitting at New Year's Feels the Economic Pinch
description: The advertisment asked if anyone would care to spend New Year's Eve in Teaneck, N.J., with Matthew Diaz and his brother Jason, who drinks a little.

title: 50,000 Blessed by Pope At Start of Holy Year
description: ROME, Dec. 29 (Reuters)About 50,000 pilgrims and tourists today received blessings from Pope Paul VI in St. Peter's Square on the first Sunday in the Holy Year. The crowd was considerably larger than at a normal Sunday midday blessing from the Pope.

title: About New York
description: As everyone knows, the Sumerians were the first to celebrate the New Year, and they chose the spring equinox to do it. The Egyptians, Persians and Phoenicians preferred the autumn equinox, and the Greeks the winter solstice, while in medieval Europe most people thought that New Year's Day was March 25. Then England, after dithering about it for centuries, chose Jan. 1, and eventually the rest of Europe did, too. This is why Mr. and Mrs. Henry Erickson will entertain on Fort Hamilton Parkway in Brooklyn tomorrow night.

title: Borough Will Hold 7th Vote on School
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, Dec. 29The local Board of Education tomorrow will make its seventh attempt in three years to win voter approval for a new high school, and, for the first time, it is optimistic.

title: Barge in Mekong Delta Hits A Mine, Killing 22 Civilians
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 30 (Reuters) The Saigon command said today that 22 civilians died and 22 were wounded when a barge hit a mine on a canal in the Mekong Delta on Saturday.

title: ETHIOPIA PLANS TO MEET REBELS
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia, Dec. 29 (Reuters)  Ethiopia's military leaders intend to seek peace for the troubled northern province of Eritrea by direct negotiation with leaders of the guerrilla movements fighting for the region's secession, a member of the military Government said here today.

title: Minnesota and Pittsburgh Win and Will Meet in Football's Super Bowl
Nuggets Victors
description: DENVER, Dec. 29 (UPI)Dave Robisch, a reserve center got, 6 points in the final quarter to help the Denver Nuggets to a 124121 uphill victory over the San Antonio Spurs In an A.B.A. game tonight.

title: Kings 10399 Victors
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 29 PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 29 (UPI)  Nate Archibald and Jimmy Walker, hitting 50 points between them, lifted the Kansas CityOmaha Kings to a 10399 triumph over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight.

title: Waldheim Asks More Aid to Poor Lands
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29Secretary General Waldheim warned last week that the economic situation in the world's poorest countries was deteriorating and urged a radical increase in foreign assistance.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Aide to Mrs. Ford to Wed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) Nancy Lammerding, White House social, secretary, announced today that she ands Nick Ruwe, Assistant Chief of Protocol at the State Department, would marry in early February. Miss Lammerding is the daughter of Mrs. Frank Lammerding of Seagirt, N.J., and Mr. Ruwe is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Ruwe of Grosse Pointe, Mich. The bridetobe was chosen as social secretary by Betty Ford last October.

title: LATE CITY EDITION
description: Weather: Chance of rain today, clear tonight. Fair tomorrow. Temperature range: today 3245; Sunday 3243. Details on Page 48.

title: J. W. Ferman, 69, Published Science Fiction Magazine
description: Joseph W. Ferman, board chairman of Mercury Press, Inc., publisher of the Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction, died yesterday in South Nassau Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived at 20 Addison Place, Rockville Centre.

title: South's State Campuses Still Largely Segregated
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 28Though much has been done in the past decade to desegregate the South's elementary and high schools, the program is lagging on the campuses of the region's state colleges and universities.

title: Unlawful Aliens Use Costly City Services
description: Thousands of illegal aliens here are sending their children to public schools, using municipal hospitals and receiving welfare benefits while often paying minimal taxes and sending large amounts of money abroad.

title: ISRAEL PONDERS PLEA ON BERGMAN
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 29Interior Minister Yosef Burg dismissed today as irrelevant a request by Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of New York, that Israel refuse citizenship to Bernard Bergman pending the outcome of a United States Senate hearing next month on nursing homes.

title: Q's Beat Spirits
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) Travis Grant and Dwight Lamar led the offense and Caldwell Jones hauled in 20 rebounds and blocked seven shots in a 126114 victory by the San Diego Conquistadors over the St. Louis Spirits tonight in the A.B.A. Grant scored 33 points and Camar 28. The Spirits were led by Marvin Barnes, who had 28 points and 20 rebounds, and Fly Williams, with 26 points.

title: TREASON CHARGED TO PAPADOPOULOS
description: ATHENS, Dec. 29 (UPI)The Greek public prosecutor today charged former President George Papadopoulos and four of his closest associates in the former military junta with high treason and sedition. Both charges carry a possible death penalty.

title: Families Leaving Devastated Darwin Smuggle Out Their Pets
description: DARWIN, Australia, Dec. 29Families leaving Darwin in the airlift following the cyclone that smashed the city Christmas Day are told they can carry 50 pounds of possessions but no pets aboard the planes.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Two persons were killed in Newark when their automobile was struck by a car being sought in a highspeed police chase. The victims were identified as Eddie Lee James, 32 years old, and his passenger, Sarah Wells, 33, both of Newark. They were killed when Mr. James's car was struck at the corner of Madison and Jelliff Avenues by a car allegedly stolen by four juveniles.

title: State Aide Sought to Curb NursingHome Inspections
description: A secret memorandum from one top aide of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to another last summer warned of political repercussions that might arise from a minor inspection of the nursinghome industry.

title: Many Levels of Sadness Felt by Rams' Players
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 29Isiah Robertson was sobbing silently, Ken Meyer was whispering consoling words into James Harris's ear and Fred Dryer was calling the officials donkeys. The Los Angeles Rains were frustrated and they were angry.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Prestigious Aston Martin To End Auto Production
description: LONDON, Monday, Dec. 30Aston Martin, makers of prestige sports cars that sell for $25,000 to $35,000, announced plans tonight to end production.

title: Psychiatric Tests Slated for Suspect In Queens Slaying
description: The man arrested as a suspect in the Christmas Day murder of Sandra Zahler in Kew Gardens, Queens, was taken early yesterday to Kings County Hospital for psychiatric observation.

title: Stage: All Over Town Proves a Zany Surprise
description: This Broadway season is as full of surprises as a brightfaced monkey. Last night at the Booth Theater it said goodby to 1974 with a zany, Feydeaustyle farce by Murray Schisgal delivered by the director Dustin Hoffman with all the aplomb of a master chef whipping up a souffl.

title: JERSEY SESSION FINISHES IN LIMBO
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29The 196th session of the State Legislature, controlled, by lopsided and highly independent Democratic majorities in both houses, has finished its first year without resolving the major issue it confrontedapproving a new system of financing public schools in this state.

title: Rams Beaten by Own Mistakes and Penalties
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 29Because they were in the right place at the right time, the Minnesota Vikings will be in Super Bowl IX on Jan. 12 as National Football Conference champions for the third time in six years.

title: THE LEADERS CLASS A
Red Smith
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 29As the half ended, lady from Western Union said hopefully, The game is over now? Unfeeling males around her in the pressbox laughed. They did not know how truly she spoke. At the time the Minnesota Vikings led the Los Angeles Rams, 73, and for all practical purposes the travesty advertised as a contest for the championship of the National Conference of the National Football League was indeed over. Only because the rules required it, the bizarre business went on for two more periods before the Vikings qualified officially to represent the conference in the Super Bowl for the third time in six years. You could call it a comedy of errors, except that it wasn't funny. Perhaps never before since men started playing this game for pay has such a multitude of pratfalls been packed into a performance with a final score of only 1410. Things didn't seem to go our way, said the Los Angeles coach, Chuck Knox, and his words should live in history along with Calvin Coolidge's dictum that when many people lose their jobs, unemployment results.

title: Celtics Rout Sonic
description: SEATTLE, Dec. 29 (AP)The scoring and rebounding of Dave Omens and Don Chaney sparked the Boston Celtics to a 121101 rout of the Seattle SuperSonics tonight. Boston's defense kept Seattle's shooters outside most of the night.

title: The Screen:Indian Life Recalled in 'Shadow Catcher'
description: A dead man's obsession seeps over the screen throughout T. C. McLuhan's "The Shadow Catcher," and that fixation casts as strong a spell as the evocations of the North American Indians he studied.Between 1896 and 1930, the photographer and anthropologist Edward S. Curtis dedicated his life to recording the customs of more than 80 tribes, convinced that these "dispossessed people" were losing their way of life as rapidly as he could film them. This superb documentary, which recreates the years that Curtis spent among the Navajo, the Hopi, the Kwakiut???, the Eskimos and others, opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art and will run until Jan. 7.Theodore Roosevelt was impressed by Curtis's work, and J. P. Morgan agreed to finance some of the field work that resulted in 20 volumes and portfolios of photogravure??? plates, plus many 35-mm. films. Meanwhile, as you watch the dances of thanksgiving or supplication, or learn that the Hopi associated the movements of snakes with lightning flashes (hence the snake dance was a prayer for rain), the politi???an sensitivity of this film emerges: Long ago, when the Indians' culture was sacrificed in the name of "progress," Curtis felt that the destruction of their traditions showed "that there was something wrong with the American dream."Careful not to violate the Indians' privacy, Curtis nonetheless succeeded in participating in some of their rituals. He was also a dexterous interviewer. If an individual didn't want to talk with him, Curtis would discuss theology and deliberately make an error, so that the Indian would correct him, and that would lead to further conversation.Donald Sutherland becomes Curtis's voice, narrating from the journals and letters of 30 years. Mr. Sutherland conveys the delights of discovery, the fatigue, the discouragement and the determination that drove the man until his marriage, and then his health, collapsed. Inter???cut with Curtis's magnificent photographs and excerpts from "In the Land of the Head Hunters," his 1914 film on the Kwakiut???, there are modern sequences that focus on the landscapes and the descendants of the people he knew.Now and then, his stills pass too quickly, and occasionally the contemporary passages in color break the sepia mood of the past. But it's fascinating to hear three elderly Indians recalling how they performed in Curtis's film for 50 cents an hour. Subtly, the movie says as much about white America as it does about the Indians, and it also distills the nature of another kind of vanishing American: a person who loved his work.

title: 24 Space Flights Set for 1975; 14 Over '74 and Near 60's Level
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 29A welcome increase in activity has come to the nation's civilian space program with 24 launchings scheduled for 1975, 14 more than this year and near the recordsetting years of the mid1960's.

title: Laos Announces an Agreement With Rebels Who Seized Towns
