description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 29 (Reuters)A Laotian Government delegation and rebel troops who took over a border town last Tuesday have reached an agreement ending the tension there, the Laotian national radio announced tonight.

title: Barbados Enlarging Blacks' Role in Tourist Business
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados Officials on this lush West Indian resort island are taking steps to prevent racial tensions that have flared elsewhere in the Caribbean where tourists are mostly affluent and white and the local population is mostly poor and black.

title: 2 Women Meet the Challenge of Running a Farm
description: When Joan Moren and Joanne DeSimone bought the ramshackle 28acre farm in Monroe, Conn., six years ago, friends and relatives shook their heads sadly. Like D. H. Lawrence's heroines in his story The Fox, the two cousins traded city life for farm life and were determined to go it alone.

title: CITY RELIEF ROLLS ON UPSWING AGAIN
description: The city's welfare rolls have gone up for the fourth time in five months, with an increase of 8,645 persons during October, James R. Dumpson, the Human Resouices Administrator, announced yesterday.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page ?? ??

title: Nuptials Here for Susan M. Nassau
description: The marriage of Susan M. Nassau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Nassau of Mount Vernon, N.Y., to Jack L. Farber took place at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Cyrus Arfa performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Helen Farber of New York and Samuel Farber of Miami Beach.

title: Soviet Lifter Sets Mark
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (Reuters)Vasili Alexeyev, the Soviet Union's superheavyweight Olympic weightlifting champion, set the 69th world record of his career today. Alexeyev lifted 536 pounds to add one pound to the world superheavyweight jerk record he set two weeks ago.

title: Dentist Weds Mary L. Rider
description: Mary Louise Rider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Rider of East Greenwich, R.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Warren A. Fitzpatrick. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Fitzpatrick of Renton, Wash.

title: VikingsRams Scoring
Who Started Pollution?
description: A very nice couple in Portland, Ore., donated the downstairs of their house for our daycare center. Imagine, use of the ground floor, (from eight to five) for fifteen little children! Naturally we were anxious to keep the place in good condition and follow any rules.

title: Bridge Signaling Can Often Provide Vital Information to Declarer
description: Knowing when to signal some information and when to remain passive and uncommunicative is one of the most delicate defensive problems.

title: Simon and India: Battle on Idol Widens
description: A battle for ownership of the Nataraja, the bronze idol from India bought for $1million in 1973 by the Norton Simon Foundation, has spread to three continents, involving lawsuits in London, Los Angeles and New York, engaging Scotland Yard and the United States Customs Bureau in an intensive search for the sculpture and provoking a verbal attack by Mr. Simon on the intervention of Daniel Patrick Moynihan, retiring Ambassador to India.

title: 212 More Remember The Needy
description: A recent graduate of Fairfield University in Connecticut, who started work as a salesman this fall, made his first donation to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and wrote, I regret having to wait so long to make such a worthy contribution.

title: Washington's Willard
description: When this law aids and abets the destroyers of cities, something is wrong with the law. Or with the courts that interpret it. Either way, corrective measures are required when court decisions are as effective as the wrecker's ball in demolishing the environment,

title: Inflation Slows Growth Of West's Arms Budgets By JOHN W. FINNEY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Inflation is beginning to slow the steady growth in defense budgets of. the Western alliance and Japan, though not yet to the ?damaging degree that had been feared by defense planners of the United States.

title: Quake Hits Pakistan
description: At least 300 persons and perhaps up to 1,000 were feared dead in an earthquake that destroyed a mountain village in northern Pakistan. Details on Page 5.

title: NEW YORKERS PAY HIGHEST STATE TAX
description: When it comes to paying state taxes, New Yorkers have no equalsat least not in the fiscal year 1974, according to the Commerce Clearing House.

title: Miss Fisher Takes Slalom
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N. H., Dec, 29 (AP)Abbi Fisher, a 17yearold from South Conway, dominated a field of 60 racers today to win the women's division of the Sendoff Slalom at Waterville Valley ski area.

title: JAIL GUARDS HELD 6 HOURS BY I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 29  Irish Republican Army Provisionals in the maximum security prison at Portlaoise held 27 prison officers hostage for nearly six hours today, until soldiers and policemen moved in. The 27 were released unharmed.

title: Japanese Soldier Found After Hiding 30 Years
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 29 (AP)Teruo Nakamura, a Taiwanborn Japanese soldier who hid for 30 years in the jungles of Indonesia, arrived here today and was turned over to Japanese officials.

title: CAREY TAX PLANS ARE CHALLENGED
description: The State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, issued an economic challenge to the incoming administration of Hugh L. Carey yesterday, saying there should be no tax increases for whateverreason and promising scrutiny of the new Governor's budget to a degree never before undertaken.

title: JOHN E. KENNEY, 74, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: John E. Kenney, who retired in 1971 as chairman of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, designer and builder of power plants, refineries and heavy industrial equipment, died yesterday. He was 74 years old, and lived at 50 Sutton Place South.

title: Alabama, LaSalle Victors in Tourney
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP)Alabama's center, Leon Douglas, swept the boards and scored 25 points to lead the Crimson Tide to a 10588 victory ovr Houston in the opening round of the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament tonight.

title: Formal Links Reopened By Venezuela and Cuba
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP)Venezuela, which initiated the drive to isolate Cuba from its Latin American neighbors 11 years ago, signed an agreement today to resume diplomatic relations with the government of Premier Fidel Castro, according to a Venezuelan diplomatic source.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
Bronx Woman Found Slain With Her Throat Slashed
description: A 23yearold Bronx woman was found dead late last night her throat slashedon the top floor of the apartment building where she lived in the High Bridge section.

title: Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Morality Play
description: As the Watergate trial neared its end last week, the closing statements by defendants' counsel inspired an overwhelming feeling of anticlimax and weariness. Like all the earlier presentations, questions and crossexaminations throughout the sixtyday trial in United States District Court in Washington, these final arguments fell under the shadow of the unprecedented playback of so much evidencein the defendants' own voicesrecorded on the White House tapes. The proceedings concluded as they beganwith Richard Nixon's physical absence rendered less remarkable than his ghostlike presence by virtue of his own voice.

title: Ellen Gogolick Wed To David Freeman
description: Ellen Beth Gogolick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Gogolick of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married there last evening to DaVid John Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Freeman of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Lelyveld performed the ceremony at the Beechmont Country Club.

title: Death of 3 in Atlantic City Is Ruled MurderSuicide
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 29Detectives investigating the deaths here last night of an electrical contractor and his two sons have ruled the slaying a double murder and suicide.

title: Westinghouse to Sell Its Major Appliance Business
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which sold its first electric stove 60 years ago, is getting out of the major appliance business, it announced yesterday.

title: School on L.I. Offers a Course About City
description: Concerned that suburban youngsters may be developing fearful stereotypes about New York City, two young in structors at Northport High School on Long Island are teaching a course called New York City: Myth and Reality. The classroom, whenever possible, is the city.

title: Unlawful Aliens Use Costly City Services
description: Thousands of illegal aliens here are sending their children to public schools, using municipal hospitals and receiving welfare benefits while often paying minimal taxes and sending large amounts of money abroad.

title: RISE IN FRENCH CRIME IS REPORTED TO SLOW
description: PARIS, Dec. 29The increase in the crime rate hi France slowed to 5.24 per cent in 1973 compared with 14.36 per cent the previous year, according to a report compiled by the national police's central study service and made public yesterday.

title: East Germans Map Economic Austerity To Offset Inflation
description: BERLIN, Dec. 29East Germany, has proclaimed austerity and import restrictions for its economy to cope with worldwide inflation and spiraling prices on world markets.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
Size and Strength of Martti Talvela, the Met's Boris, Shield a Complex Intellectual Personality
description: Anyone who has seen Martti Talvelathe Finnish bass who is singing Boris Godunov at the Metropolitan Opera  knows that he is a big man: 6 feet 7 inches tall and 260 pounds, at last count.

title: JobHunting Jars ModernLanguage Convention
description: Those graying pipesmokers, wearing tweeds and sensible lowheeled shoes, skulking in and out of seminars ranging from medieval drama to sciencefiction at the annual meeting of the Modern Language Association at the Hilton and Americana Hotels during the last four days were, it turned out, chairmen of college and university departments.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
Computer for Groceries Does About Everything But Bagging
description: TROY, Ohio  As rapidly as she could, Kay Kinsinger, a cashier at the Marsh supermarket, passed each item over a small, rectangularshaped glass lying flat on her counter, triggering a red flash. Behind her, responding to the signal, the cash register displayed the price of the item.

title: Jeffrey S. Felder Weds Miss Siegel in Queens
description: Elinor Joan Siegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Siegel of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey Stephen Felder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan Felder of Encino, Calif. Rabbi David L. Algaze performed the ceremony at the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens.

title: Moody's Extends A Rating For New York City Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service has continued its A rating on the general obligation bonds of New York City, the rating service announced over the weekend. Last week, Standard & Poor's also extended its A rating for the city's bonds.

title: For 900 Elderly, an Early New Year
description: It was New Year's Eve in Canarsie yesterday for 900 members of various Brooklyn centers for the elderly.

title: Hawks Beat Blues
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 29, (UPI)Doug Jarrett, a defenseman, scored a goal and assisted on two others tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 52 N.H.L. victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: KUH, IN FAREWELL, CITES PROGRESS
description: Richard H. Kuh gave an assessment yesterday of his tern as Manhattan District Attorney in a farewell message that was interspersed with references to Albert Camus, G. K. Chesterton, Cassandra, Learned Hand, Sinatra and Alice in Wonderland.

title: Federal Spending Level Called Tax Cut Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The continuing explosion of Federal spending threatens to cut the size of any antirecession tax reduction that President Ford is expected to propose to Congress next month, according to high Administration officials.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29 (AP)A fourthquarter rally gave Kentucky a 125114 victory over the Memphis Sounds tonight and put the Colonels back in first place in the American Basketball Association's East Division. The Colonels lead the New York Nets by 2 percentage points.

title: As the World Turns
description: We are witnessing a fundamental turning in the experience of the Western World which closes a 500year span of economic history. The new era will be marked by constraints with which we will probably have to live for the duration.

title: RUGBY RESULTS
description: By Reuters

title: Antarctic Chronicle All the Polar World Is Their Laboratory
description: The handful of reporters and visiting scientists permitted to go to Antarctica each year travel and see more than almost anyone stationed there. After long periods of isolation the scientists and technicians living at remote posts all seem happy to talk with outsiders, including this reporter and five others who visited Antarctica for eight days in December under the auspices of the National Science Foundation.

title: BOSTON TO APPEAL ORDER ON BUSING
description: BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP)The City of Boston will finance an appeal to the United States Supreme Court of a Federal Court order to desegregate Boston schools, Mayor Kevin H. White said today.

title: QUAKE DESTROYS PAKISTAN VILLAGE
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Monday, Dec. 30 (Reuters)At least 300 persons and perhaps up to 1,000 were feared dead in a severe earthquake that destroyed a remote mountain village in northern Pakistan, officials said here last night.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplemental, weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Opium Poppy Growing in U.S. Is Urged as Guarantee of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The United States should start growing its own opium poppies to guarantee the nation longterm supplies of painkilling drugs, says an editorial in a leading medical journal.

title: A Packed Weekend for Ballet Theater
description: Continuing along on its actionpacked weekend, Amercan Ballet Theater preseted a revival of Kenneth McMilIan's 1967 ballet, Concerto as well as some new and familiar faces in La File Mal Gardee at the City Center.

title: Maura Moroney Bride Of John Henry Tobin
description: Maura Clare Moroney and John Henry Tobin were married yesterday afternoon in Astoria, Queens. The Rev. Vincent McShane performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: Advertising
description: Robert Leaf, president of Marsteller International, is planning to be in Beirut, Lebanon, in the spring to see about opening an office in an area where representation by international United States agencies is rare.

title: MOSCOW DISSIDENT TAKEN TO LITHUANIA
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29  Sergei Kovalev, a biologist and prominent dissident who was arrested here Friday, has been flown by Soviet authorities to Lithuania, apparently for trial, in the crackdown on an underground Roman Catholic journal, the nuclear physicist Andrei D. Sakharov said today.

title: SteelersRaiders Scoring
Goldman, Sachs to Admit 4 More General Partners
description: Four new general partners will be admitted on Wednesday in Goldman, Sachs & Co., a leading international investment banking and brokerage firm, it was announced over the week, end by Gustave L. Levy, senior partner.

title: TIME NAMES FAISAL MAN OF THE YEAR
description: Time magazine has named King Faisal of Saudi Arabia man of the year for 1974. The magazine said the king was a principal factor in quadrupling oil prices, and that he holds more power than any other leader to lower or raise, them in the future.Throughout 1974, Faisal's actions about oil prices and related matters touched in various degrees the lives and pocketbooks of virtually every human being on earth, the magazine said.

title: Knicks Lose, Held to 6 in 3d Quarter
FLORIDA TOURISM IS AIDED BY BOOM
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 29Florida's ailing tourist industry, troubled last year by the gasoline shortage and this year by tithe recession, found itself in the midst of a sudden and unexpected boom over the weekend.

title: CITY SCHOOLS ASK FOR $278BILLION, A RECORD BUDGET
description: Declaring that children are not expendable even in times of financial crisis, School Chancellor Irving Anker called yesterday for a record 197576 operating budget of $2.78billion to make possible some improvements in education, including greater services for handicaped and nonEnglishspeaking pupils.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A new caseevaluation point system designed to speed court action against major criminals is to be put into use next month in the Bronx, District Attorney Mario Merola announced. The procedure is expected objectively and uniformly to identify the career criminal for the District Attorney and to determine whether the case should handled by Mr. Merola's Major Offense Bureau.

title: Rooney Accepts Super Gift With Smile and a Twinkle
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 29  Outside the Pittsburgh Steelers' locker room, 73yearold Art Rooney was talking through lips that were chapped and puffed. During his team's 2413 victory over the Oakland Raiders for the American Football Conference championship today, he had chewed on cigars that created tiny specks of blood.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: Unemployment in New Jersey is much higher than the national average, which could be one of the reasons why a survey by the Mortgage Bankers Association has indicated that delinquencies on home loans in the state are not only higher than last year but higher than in the country as a whole.

title: Quake Hits Pakistan
description: At least 300 persons and perhaps up to 1,000 were feared dead in an earthquake that destroyed a mountain village in northern Pakistan. Details on Page 5.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 25

title: Jersey Police Find Man Slew Himself After Killing 2 Sons
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 29 Detectives investigating the deaths here last night of an electrical contractor and his two sons have ruled the slayings a double murder and suicide.

title: Patrolman Who Killed Boy, 16, Out of Job, Pending Jury Study
description: LONG BRANCH, Dec. 29Patrolman John Adams, whose fatal shooting of a 16yearold boy here on Dec. 8 sparked a racial controversy, will be without a job next Tuesday.

title: Carey Tax Plan Challenged By Senate G.O.P. Leader
description: The State Senate's majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, issued an economic challenge to the incoming administration of Hugh L. Carey yesterday, saying there should be no state tax increases for whatever reason and promising scrutiny of the new Governor's budget to a degree never before undertaken.

title: BREZHNEV MEETS CAIRO MINISTERS
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29 Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today received Egypt's Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, and the Mohammed Abdel Ghany alGamasy, for talks following their arrival here yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP)  Jim Choues scored 25 points and grabbed 15 rebounds tonight in leading the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 110103 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: 3 MORE AIDES QUIT IN C,I.A. SHAKEUP; FACED TRANSFERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Three more highranking officials of the Central Intelligence Agency resigned last week in a major shakeup of the agency's counterintelligence division, wellinformed Government sources said today.

title: Nicaragua Will Free 26 To in Hostages' Release
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 28The Nicaraguan Government agreed today to release 26 political prisoners and fly them to Cuba in exchange for the lives of a group orprominent politicians and business leaders seized by leftist guerrillas at a Christmas party here Friday night.

title: Baroque Concerts Given In the Met Museum Court
description: For a pair of holiday concerts around the spectacular Christmas tree in the Metropolitan Museum's Medieval Sculpture Court on Saturday, Melvin Kaplan, oboist and music entrepreneur, put together a program that combined his Festival Winds and Jean Hakes, soprano.

title: FORD SAID TO DROP SURTAX PROPOSAL
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 29President Ford has abandoned his proposal for an income tax surcharge to fight inflation, a high Administration source said here today.

title: Gail A. Harris Wed To Jerry L. Ellstein
description: Gail Ann Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Harris Jr. of Great Neck, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Jerry Lee Ellstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ellstein of Woodmere, L. I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple BethEl in Great Neck.

title: Economists Agree Tax Gut Is Needed
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29The nation's leading economists partly out of conviction and partly out of exasperationseem agreed that a major tax cut at the Federal level is needed to put a floor under the plummeting economy and to help stimulate a new burst of economic activity next year. The Ford Administration is currently weighing such an alternative.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 29. (AP)Reg Leach scored after only 13 seconds of play ta start the Philadelphia Flyers on their way to a 52 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: Watergate Jury's Day
description: Judge John J. Sirica gives the Watergate coverup case to the jury today after 13 weeks of trial. Details, Page 16.

title: Honorable Discharge Ratio Is the Lowest in 25 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) The United States armed forces have given fewer honorable discharges during the last year than at any other time in the quarter century such records have been kept, Pentagon figures showed today.

title: BRONX WOMAN DIES OF FOOD POISONING
description: A 27yearold Bronx woman who was hospitalized last week with 12 relatives after eating a mushroom preserve containing botulin died yesterday at Jacobi Hospital.

title: Messina Mat Victor In Post Tourney
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Dec. 29 Chris Messina, a junior at Slippery Rock (Pa.) State College, pinned Peter Ackerman of Rider College in 3 minutes 28 seconds today to take the 158pound event at the ninth annual C.W.. Post College invitation holiday wrestling tournament. The pin was Messina's fourth in five bouts in the twoday affair and earned the Hauppauge, L.I., native the most valuable wrestler award.

title: Connors, Newcombe Win at Net
description: Connors, the defending champion, beat Raz Reid of Greenville, S.C., 62, 63, 57, 60. Newcombe beat Bob Carmichael of France, 76, 63, 62.

title: Connecticut's OldFashioned SchoolTax System Faces Overhaul
description: The ruling last Friday by a Superior Court judge in Hartford that Connecticut's present method of financing public schools was unconstitutional means that its legislature must now join those in New Jersey and other states in overhauling its whole schoolfinance system. Given the circumstances in Connecticut, the task there will be more drastic but possibly less prolonged than in other states.

title: CITY SCHOOLS ASK FOR $2.78BILLION, A RECORD BUDGET
description: Declaring that children are not expendable even in times of financial crisis, School Chancellor Irving Anker called yesterday for a record 197576 operating budget of $2.78billion to make possible some improvements in education, including greater services for handicaped and nonEnglishspeaking pupils.

title: 3 Rare Gemsbok Are Killed In First New Mexico Hunt
description: ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Dec. 29Three gemsbok were killed yesterday by New Mexico sportsmen on the opening day c,e What state officials described as the first licensed hunt for the prized African biggame species ever held in the United States.

title: Eva Jean Davis Becomes Bride Of J. H. Holman
description: Eva Jean Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Davis of Ottsville, Pa., was married here yesterday at noon to Jonathan Harrison Holman, son of Eleanor M. Holman of Larchmont, N. Y., and Richard A. Holman of New York. Rabbi Julius Rosenthal performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club.

title: TREASURY PLANS BIG BORROWINGS
description: The corporate bond market, which already faces a record newissue calendar of $3.8billion irk straight debt for January, promises soon to be competing for investor money with the United States Treasury. The Treasury will tap the money market because, like many American families and municipalities, its budget prospects are deteriorating rapidly as a result of a slumping economy still bedeviled by inflation.

title: BANGLADESH ACTS TO CURB VIOLENCE
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 29 (AP)Operating under a state of emergency that was declared yesterday, Prime Minister Mujibur Rahman began a drive today against banditry and political violence, which have killed 3,000 of his followers since Bangladesh won independence in 1971.

title: 212 More Remember The Needy
description: A recent graduate of Fairfield University in Connecticut, who started work as a salesman this fall, made his first donation to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and wrote, I regret having to wait so long to make such a worthy contribution.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Dec. 29Helve Filion won two races today at Monticello Raceway and raised his record total of race victories this season to 631. Filion, who drew the outside post position in all 10 races, won the fifth and 10th races.

title: Office Pool, 1975
description: WASHINGTONThe steady rotation of the earth, on which timekeepers have relied since time immemorial, can no longer be depended upon.

title: Thais Again Expel ExPremier Who Returned From Exile in Secrecy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 29 A twoday political drama ended today for the Thai Government when former Premier Thanom Kittikachorn flew back into the exile from which he had returned Friday.

title: Rand, Former Olympian, Wins Lake Placid Ski Jump
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29Jay Rand, the former United States Oympian who has been schussing down local chutes ever since he was a 4yearold, registered a slight surprise today in the East's opening skijumping tournament featuring members of America's national squad.

title: Personal Finance: On Buying Gold
description: If you decide to buy gold when it becomes legal to do so Dec. 31, you should know precisely what you are purchasing and what the costs will be.

title: The Rapid, Quiet Termination of a Rape Case
description: A young woman, raped in daylight while jogging in a park in Queens last May, was left temporarily paralyzed below the waist after the attack. One of few rape victims willing to press charges and follow the case to court, Janet Rosenwach, 21 years old, learned last week that the case had already been concluded, although no one had consulted her.

title: Austrian, 19, Wins Jump
description: OBERSTDORF, West Germany, Dec. 29 (UPI)Willi Puerstl of Austria, a 19yearold high school student, scored a surprising victory today in the opening international skijumping meet of the season.

title: ...and Opportunity
description: Beyond the mechanics into which the diplomacy of Middle East mediation has so bogged down, a salient political fact has emerged from the whirlwind of Palestinian debate at the United Nations. This is that no outside power, not the Soviet Union, not the most proArab of western European nations, is ready to go along with the extreme Palestinian position of challenging the legitimacy of Israel's existence.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Hans Bethe was recently reported in The Times to favor increasing the development of nuclear power as part of a longterm solution to our economic and energy problems. Emphasizing the threat of economic disaster, Dr. Bethe said our whole mode of life may come to an end unless we find a solution. He argued that increasing energy consumption is inevitable and, indeed, desirable to maintain prosperity; that conservation is important but inadequate; and that alternative modes of energy production are impractical. The article mentions hazards of power generation by nuclear fission only briefly. On the breeder reactor, Dr. Bethe says, I personally like it. I have worked on it. I believe it be made safe.

title: COST TO OVERHAUL ASUB QUADRUPLES
description: GROTON, Conn., Dec. 29The cost of overhauling the Nautilus, the first nuclearpowered submarine in the United States fleet, has quadrupled, the Navy confirmed to day.

title: Rebels Attack in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 29 (AP)  Rebel forces attacked Government troops today near Prek Takau, 12 miles southeast of Phnom Penh. Reports from the field said 20 Government soldiers had been killed.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: State Aide Sought to Curb NursingHome Inspections
description: A secret memorandum from one top aide of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to another last summer warned of political repercussions that might arise from a minor inspection of the nursinghome industry.

title: Christmas Scrooge Ad Hoped to Bring Cheer
description: A most unusual classified appeared under Help Wanted MaleFemale in The New York Times Christmas Eve. The ad appeared thus:

title: Texas and Auburn Play Tonight in Gator Bowl
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla,, Dec. 29 (AP)The Texas Longhorns, who lost a sixyear New Year's Day lease on the Cotton Bowl, will make their first Gator Bowl football game appearance tomorrow night against the Auburn Tigers, who are here for the sixth time. And for the first time in many years, some of the stadium's 70,000 seats may be empty.

title: Miss Davison Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Laurie Nina Davison, a lawyer with Rhode Island Legal Services in Providence, R. I., to R. Scott Dyer, a medical student at Brown University, took place in Providence yesterday. The nondenominational ceremony at the bride's apartment was performed by the Rev. Richard Dannenfelser, associate chaplain at Brown.

title: Nicaragua Will Free 26 To Win Hostages' Release
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 29The Nicaraguan Government agreed today to release 26 political prisoners and fly them to Cuba in exchange for the lives of a group or prominent politicians and business leaders seized by leftist guerrillas at a Christmas party here Friday night.

title: Minnesota and Pittsburgh Win and Will Meet in Football's Super Bowl
Inflation Slows Growth Of West's Arms Budgets
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Inflation is beginning to slow the steady growth in defense budgets of the Western alliance and Japan, though not yet to the damaging degree that had been feared by defense planners of the United States.

title: Steelers Defeat Raiders, 2413, and Reach Super owl With Vikings, Victors by 1410
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 29  The Pittsburgh Steelers, who in their time fielded some of the most inept teams in the history of the National Football League, had one made of tempered steel today, a team that trounced the Oakland Raiders, 2413, to win the American Conference championship and advance to the Super Bowl. The matchup in that ultimate game of the pro football season will be a new one, Pittsburgh against Minnesota, in New Orleans on Jan. 12.

title: Rangers Top Scouts, 21; Islanders 70 Winners
FORD SAID TO DROP SURTAX PROPOSAL
description: VAIL, Cob., Dec. 29President Ford has abandoned his proposal for an income tax surcharge to fight inflation, a high Administration source said here today.

title: Glasgow's Youth Gangs Tamed a Little
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Dec. 29 (AP)Glasgow's youth gangs are still violent, but they appear on the retreat for the first time in half a century.

title: Blacks to Send Carey List of Appointee Candidates
description: A list containing scores of names of blacks and their resumes will be submitted this week to Governorelect Hugh L. Carey as candidates for appointment to toplevel and middlemanagement positions in his administration, black leaders disclosed yesterday.

title: Francis R. B. Godolphin Dead; Former Dean at Princeton, 71
description: Dr. Francis R. B. Godolphin, former dean and professor of classics of Princeton College, died yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., where he lived. His age was 71.

title: 2 Die and Boy, 7, Is Lost in Jones Inlet Boat Accident
description: Two men died and 7yearold boy was Iost and presumed drowned yesterday afternoon when their 25foot sportfishing boat struck an unknown object and foundered in the Atlantic Ocean a half mile off Point Lookout, L.I.

title: Rangers Top Scouts, 21; Islanders 70 Winners
description: In the maternity ward of North Shore Hospital at Manhasset, L. I., there is an infant boy, not yet 24 hours old, with the family name Fairbairn. He does not have a first name yet, but he already owns a National Hockey League pucka souvenir from his father, Bill, a New York Ranger right wing.

title: Rites Held for 2 Girls, Latest of 6 Slain
description: COLONIA, N. J., Dec. 30A Roman Catholic mass for two teenaged murder victims was celebrated here today as detectives from three counties began comparing notes on the unsolved killings of six teenaged girls in New Jersey this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: There Is Mush More to Drinking Than Quenching Your Thirst
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.My friends, in their cups, will be asking me tonight why I stopped drinking. It is a reasonable question, and I carry a number of stock answers.

title: KISSINGER OFFERS AIDE LIAISON POST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 Secretary of State Kissinger, concerned over increasing problems with Congress, has asked his closest and most trusted aide to consider taking over as the State Department's top liaison official with Capitol Hill.

title: Chess: The Gentle Art of Bluffing, A Flimsy Straw for Grasping
description: Bluffing, contrary to general belief, does have a legitimate place in the chess player's arsenal, but it has to be done sparingly. There is no sense in jeopardizing a winning position by a bluff: that would give the opponent chances he could never have obtained for himself. Assuming that your oppenent, for example, will not spot the incorrectness of your piece sacrifice and that you'll then score a quick mate is one way to lose a game that should be duck soup.

title: Business Briefs
description: SteelScrap Export Quotas Ending

title: Robert Jones, Ad Man, 64; Served McCann Ericson
description: Robert Haydon Jones, an advertising executive, died Thursday in Ronda, Spain, where he was visiting. He was 64 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: PRESIDENT VETOES STRIP MINING BILL, OIL TANKER PLAN
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 30President Ford refused today to sign two highly controversial bills. One would have put stringent new restrictions on strip mining of coal and the other would have required that 20 per cent of the oil imported into the United States be carried on United States tankers.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an obituary of Jack Benny in The New York Times on Dec. 28, it was incorrectly stated that he was unable to have his share of the proceeds of the sale of Amusement Enterprises to CBS classified as capital gains. Although the Internal Revenue Service had disallowed the classification, the Tax Court decided in his favor.

title: Take Your Scrubbers
description: A seething battle is now in progress on an issue that few people besides the principals can be expected to seethe about. Yet it is an important episode in the running war to spare Americans from the growing assault on their lungs and hearts by noxious gases discharged in the burning of highsulphur coal. Since that process may have to be endured if the country is to reduce its dependence on foreign oil, the focus of the controversy is on the coat scrubber, a complex and costly system for eliminating sulphur oxides before they float out of a power plant's chimney stacks.

title: Demonstrated Concern
description: In making his tentative selections for the initial board of the new legal services corporation, President Ford seems to have lost sight of the basic purposes of the legislation. The original legal services program was designed to give the poor access to the American legal system. As the effort evolved, the poor and their representatives became involved in litigation with government at all levels. The need to insulate the program from politics and to remove from the Federal Government the temptation to interfere in its operations quickly became apparent.

title: Nets Beat Sounds On Team Effort
Pakistan Estimates Quake Killed 4,700 in 9 Towns
description: PATTAN, Pakistan, Dec. 30The earthquake that struck northern Pakistan over the weekend killed 4,700 persons and injured 15,000 in nine towns, according to official estimates.

title: South Koreans Push Aid Drive For Paper Harassed by Regime
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 30  Voluntary campaigns are mounting to save Donga Ilbo, South Korea's most prestigious national daily newspaper, from withering under what many here suspect is a deliberate Government effort to suppress it.

title: Antarctic Chronicle
description: Anyone going to Antarctica, for however short a must pass a rigorous physical examination. The traveler is supposed to be able to carry a 30pound load at altitudes above 10,000 feet and in temperatures in excess of 50 degrees below zero and keep it up, if necessary, for several days with neither food nor sleep.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMENTHALDr. Emanuel E. In loving memory, never to be forgotten.

title: Mills Reveals Alcoholism; Plans to Stay in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30Representative Wilbur D. Mills, attributing his recent erratic behavior to alcoholism, pledged total abstinence today as he announced that he would retain his seat in Congress.

title: MATING OF PROTON BELIEVED PROVED
description: The existence or a shortlived substance formed by the brief mating of a proton and its opposite atomic particle, or antiproton, appears to have been confirmed by experiments at Brookhaven National Laboratory near Upton, Long Island.

title: Liggett's, a Landmark In Times Sq., Closing
description: The Liggett drugstore, a Times Square landmark for mire than 60 years, will close for good at 10:30 tonight.

title: Gold Reenters MarketPlace Today After 41 Years
description: From Boise, Idaho, to Portland, Me., Investors entered the nation's new golden era this morning with one hand on their wallets.

title: Eastland Protest Halted '72 Raids on Cotton Gins
description: Minutes after a protest from a senior aide to Senator James O. Eastland in 1972, the Immigration and Naturalization Service halted a raid against northern Mississippi cotton gins that employed illegal aliens.

title: Film Critics Cite Amarcord and Fellini
description: Amarcord (I Remember), the Italianmade comedydrama that evoked a year in the life of an Italian town in the nineteenthirties, was judged the year's best film and Federico Fellini the top director of 1974 for his work on that import, in the 40th annual poll yesterday of the New York Film Critics Circle.

title: LOTTERY NUMBER Dec. 30, 1974
description: N.J.Daily35336

title: U.S. Crop Exports Set. Record Level In Fiscal Period
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) The Agriculture Department has reported that in the fiscal year ended last June 30, United States farm exports reached a record total of $21.3billion, up from $12.9billion in 197273.

title: Parking Eased Tomorrow
description: Sunday parking regulations will be in effecttomorrow, New Year's Day. Alternatesideof. thestreet parking restrictions will not be in effect and parkingmeter regulations will apply only that those meters that normally operate on Sundays, Regulations that ban parking, standing or stopping at any time will be in effect,

title: Washington State Prison Revolt Quelled, 4 of 13 Hostages Hurt
description: WALLA, WALLA, Wash., Dec. 30 (AP)The authorities at Walla Walla State Penitentiary put down two inmate uprisings today, one in a cellblock and another in the prison hospital and set free 13 persons taken hostage. Four of the hostages were reported injured.

title: China Strikes Offshore Oil
description: TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP)China reported today that her first ship designed to drill for oil in deep water had successfully drilled a well in the southern Yellow Sea. China has raised oil production sharply in recent years and now exports oil.

title: Lapsing Subsidies Are Extended For State Rail and Bus Routes
description: TRENTON, Dec. 30  The State Commuter Operating Agency today extended on a piecemeal basis a series of subsidy agreements with New Jersey railroads and buslines that were scheduled to expire tomorrow night.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EXPLORING Safari, anyoneon New Year's Eve? Why not? It's good exercise, and even fun on a novel path, This is the specialty of Adventure on a Shoestring, an organization that arranges periodic visits for members and nonmembers to unusual places and people. Adventure gets around, and its agendas include a hypnotist, a liedetection expert, a handwriting analyst, a playwrightor the backstage Metropolitan Opera, a TV station, a witchcraft museum or a hydrofoil. Tonight's excursion calls for a stroll across the Brooklyn Bridge, a subway ride back to Manhattan for a tour of Chinatown and a snack at an allnight Chinese restaurant. The group will meet at 11:30 P.M. in front of the Municipal Building (corner of Centre and Chamber Streets). Nonmembers may attend at $2 a person. For further detalls, call CO 52663.

title: Armco Lifts Prices On Some Products
description: The Armco Steel Corporation, Middletown, Ohio, announced yesterday that it was raising prices on products reflecting about onethird of its total steel shipments. The increases involve plates, structurals, bars, tubulars, rods and certain wires and wire products. The company said the increases amounted to 2.2 per cent of total steel sales revenue.

title: BISHOP BIDS MANILA AIR TORTURE REPORT
description: MANILA, Dec. 30Archbishop Jaime L. Sin of Manila has called the attention of top military authorities to persistent and disturbing reports that certain persons detained under martial law had been tortured.

title: Building Contracts Drop
description: New construction contracts totaled $6.17billion in November, down 20 per cent from the same month a year ago, according to the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company. Details on Page 29.

title: Aiding Needy Becomes a Custom
description: Two brothers, William M. and Andrew D. Heineman, yesterday paid tribute again to the memofy of their language teacher at Horace MannBarnard School by contributing $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Excerpts From Sirica's Charge to CoverUp Jurors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)Following are excerpts from Judge. John J. Sirica's instructions to the Federal Court jury today in the Watergate coverup trial:

title: British Soccer Standing
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division

title: Advertising
description: Nobody knows the precise effect of television on the mores and manners of the nation, but most are willing to agree that it's tremendous. Just ask the advertisers.

title: Zaire Will Nationalize Industry And Start ReEducation Plan
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Dec. 30 (AP)The governing political party of Zaire announced today that it would nationalize industry, the building trades and distribution services and would institute other economic, educational and military measures.

title: Hunt Tells of Early Work For a C.I.A. Domestic Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 E. Howard Hunt Jr., a Watergate burglar who pleaded guilty, told the Senate Watergate committee last year in still unpublished testimony that he served as the first chief of covert action for the Central Intelligence Agency's Domestic Operations Division.

title: A PANEL IS NAMED TO REBUILD DARWIN
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 30, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia announced today the creation of the Darwin Reconstruction Commission to rebuild the city devastated by a cyclone on Christmas Day.

title: J. C. Penney Credit Set
description: The J.C. Penney Co. said yesterday it had completed a $200million revolving credit and term loan agreement with a group of 18 banks. Penney said the agreement provided for a threeyear revolving credit that could be converted into a fouryear term loan at the company's option.

title: SUSPECT GIVEN BAIL IN COPTER HIJACKING
description: David Kamaiko, 22 years old, charged with air piracy for the armed hijacking of a helicopter that landed on the Pan Am Building last May 23, was permitted yesterday to be released from a mental hospital under modified bail conditions.

title: Family Seeks Slump's Silver Lining
Notes on People
description: Governorelect Richard D. Lamm of Colorado hope to reach the 14,110foot top of Pikes Peak today and work there where the words to America, the Beautiful Were written  on his inaugural address for Jan. 14. The 39yearold Democrat began the climb yesterday as a guest with the 53d annual yearend ascent of the AdAmAn Club, which will set off more than $1,000 worth of fireworks at midnight. Mr. Lamm has already climbed 36 other Colorado mountains that exceed 14,000 feet. He walked 88 miles during his campaign and plans to emphasize physical fitness in his administration.

title: NEW BRIBERY COUNT CHARGED IN FT. LEE
description: NEWARK, Dec. 30 (AP)The sponsors of a multimilliondollar construction project in Fort Lee who have been indicted on charges of bribing local officials were accused today of having made an additional $200,000 payoff.

title: Martial Air Prevails As 50 Debutantes Bow
description: Fifty young women representing 13 countries, 15 states and the District of Cplumbia, made their formal bows at the 20th annual International Debutante Ball in the Grand Ballroom at the WaldorfAstoria last night.

title: VICTIMS SWITCHED TO DOOMED PLANE
description: The 21 people killed when their chartered plane crashed in Guatemala last Saturday had chartered the plane after deciding that the one originally reserved for them didn't leak safe enough, according to the Manager of the New York travel agency that arranged their trip.

title: City Health Code Violations Charged to 16 Food Places
description: The city's Health Department has made public the names of 16 more food establishments that have failed their second HealthCode inspection, and it has warned they may be closed if its inspectors find violations persisting in a third visit. The following are the results of its inspections.

title: U.S.BELGIAN GROUP SIGNS IRAN GAS PACT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  Iran has signed a memorandum of understanding with an AmericanBelgian consortium for the export of Iranian liquefied natural gas (L.N.G.) to the United States and Europe, the government owned Pars news agency reported today.

title: 8% JOBLESS RATE IS EXPECTED HERE
description: The recession will bite deeper and last longer in New York State than in the nation as a whole, producing an unemployment rate of 8 per cent or higher next year, the State Council of Economic Advisers warned yesterday.

title: Dave Anderson
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 30Across the Nimitz Freeway from the Oakland Coliseum, the switchboard buzzed today in the Oakland Raiders' offices. You know what the trouble with your team is, the caller complained, The trainer tapes the ankles too tight. The players can't run right. As politely as possible, Al LoCosale, the Raiders' executive assistant, terminated the conversation. Quietly, secretaries and assistant coaches walked through the offices decorated in silver and black, the Raiders' colors. Upstairs, the office where Al Davis directs the Raider organization was empty. He'll be in later, somebody said. Al Davis hadn't attended the team's usual postgame party at a nearby motel last night, but he never does. He doesn't like parties. Once the coach and general manager, once briefly the Commissioner of the American Football League, he has been the Raiders' managing general partner since 1966. He created their motto Pride and Poise and the slogan of being pro football's most dynamic oragnization.

title: About the Nets...
description: Wendell Ladner, the Nets' reserve forward who underwent right knee surgery Sept, 11, has been examined by Dr. Alan Levy, the Nets' doctor, and given a goahead to start scrimmaging with the team in about two weeks. John Williamson's five assists and six rebounds against Memphis Saturday night were both seasonhighs for him. ... The Nets are averaging 1,109 additional patrons a game this year than they did last season.... Only three games this season have drawn 10,000 or more fans. The top attendance was 10,562 for Kentucky Nov, 29. The season opener against Utah and Moses Malone was second with 10,463, and the Nov. 20 game against the Spirits of St. Louis attracted 10,223.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN HEAVY TRADING
description: In the most active trading in almost a year, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yesterday as yearend tax selling weakened the market. Prices in the overthecounter market closed mixed in heavy trading.

title: New Growth of Brazilian Cults Is Troubling the Catholic Church
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30 On New Year's Eve tens of thousands of Brazilians mass along the beaches, chanting and clapping, to make their annual offerings of perfume, ribbons, mirrors, soap, Jewelry and blossoms to Iemanja, goddess of the seas.

title: Paris: When Europe Was French and Louis XV Ruled
description: PARIS, Dec. 29It is unusual to find the preface to an exhibition of artifacts pointing out that Europe, then, was French and that France's rhythm of industrial growth was an average of 1 per cent anually. Unusual, that is, until one learns that the author of the preface is Valry Giscard d'Estaing that that the subject of the exhibition is art in the time of Louis XV.

title: Open Interest
CARTERAGAINASKS FOR A NEW TRIAL
description: The New Jersey judge who this month refused to grant a new murder trial for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter was asked yesterday to reopen an appeals hearing on the ground that he had misapprehended the issues.

title: Richard P. Dyckman, 78, ExMayor of Plainfield, N.J.
description: Richard P. Dyckman, who was Mayor of Plainfield, N.J., and a former vice president of he L.A. Dreyfus Company, maker of base materials for chewing gum, died Sunday in Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield. He was 78 years old.

title: Joint Panel Sees Big Deficits but No Spur to Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30Congressional staff experts estimated today that the Federal budget would have a deficit of $23billion in the current fiscal year and $36billion in the next even without any new programs, such as a tax reduction, to stimulate the economy.

title: PRICES OF SILVER DROP DAILY LIMIT
description: Silver prices dropped the daily limit yesterday, and it was reported that some of the selling reflecting a desire of traders to put themselves in cash position to buy gold futures when trading begins today. However analysts said the drop in silver also reflected some lack of followthrough when the London market, which opens earlier, failed to move up yesterday.

title: Ford Recalls 11,400 Trucks With Defect in Front Axle
description: DETROIT, Dec. 30 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company said today it was recalling 11,400 late model light trucks with front axle spindles that could crack under certain extended driving conditions.

title: Baylor Coach Is Voted Award As Team Drills for Penn State
description: DALLAS, Dec. 30Grant Teaff, Baylor's head football coach who turned the Bears into champions in three seasons, was named college coach of the year today by the Football Writers Association of America.

title: Market Place Kernnecott Shareholders Complain
description: Last week the Kennecott Copper Corporation disclosed plans for the disposition of its subsidiary, the Peabody Coal Company, as ordered last April by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Trading Pace Gains in a Mixed Market; Treasury Notes Sold for Additional Cash
Arcata Settles With U.S. On Land Taken for Forest
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Dec. 30 (UPI)The Arcata National Corporation said today it had agreed to settle its claim against the Federal Government for the timberlands taken from the company for the Redwood National Forest in California.

title: Virtue in Gold Leaf
description: Civic Fame was collapsing and corroded. Civic Virtue was dingy and ignored. Civic Fame was exposed to the elements on top of the Municipal Building and Civic Virtue was somewhat snugger on a basrelief inside. Both statue and stonework have been restored as part of a tpptobottom refurbishing of McKim, Mead and White's neoclassical skyscraper.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1974
description: It was officially announced in Moscow that Leonid I. Brezhnev had indefinitely postponed his visit to Egypt, Syria and Iraq, which he was to begin in about two Weeks. No explanation was given. The indefinite postponement, tantamount in diplomatic terms to cancellation, was regarded as a setback in the Kremlin's efforts to enhance its position in the Middle East. However, this was challenged by a SovietEgyptian statement issued in Moscow at the end of a threedayvisit by high Egyptian officials that stressed the firm friendship between the two countries. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: By appointment onlythe atmost in exelusive travel strictly deluxewrite Air France Dept. NYC.P.J. Boo 747, N.Y. 10011Advt.

title: LEON DANIEL
description: Leon Daniel, a cofounder of Pix, Inc., a leading independent agency supplying photographs to magazines and newspapers until it was dissolved on his retirement in 1969, died yesterday at his home, 200 East 78th Street. He was in his 70's.

title: Driving Down 3% InU.S.Daring 74; Drop 1st Since 44
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) Americans drove more vehicles fewer miles at lower speeds in 1974, statistics of the Federal Highway Administraion showed today.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BOX MAN. By Kobo Ab. Translated from the Japanese by E. Dale Saunders. 178 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: NATURAL GAS CUT IN JERSEY AGAIN
description: Richard Sigmund, a Vice president of the company, which serves a population of about 800,000 in South Jersey, said that supplies to industrial customers would have to be cut to 50 per cent of their current supplies if the pipeline reduction could not be made up from other sources.

title: FOOD PROFIT HELD EQUAL TO OTHERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) Congressional investigators say the food industry, which often says its profits can be measured in pennies, actually clears about as much money as other big United States industries. Food profits, the staff study reported over the weekend, are neither spectacular nor poor, when compared with others.

title: Normal Trading Hours Set for Stock Markets
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges will remain open today until 4 P.M., their regular closing time. Other major securities exchanges in the United States and Canada will also remain open for their normal trading hours.

title: WATERGATE JURY RECERIES CHAIR WEIGHS FATE ORB
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30A jury of nine women and three men began to deliberate today the case against the five. former White House and Nixon campaign aides, charged in the Watergate coverup.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified pages distributed in metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: Michel Alaux, 51, Coached Olympic Fencers for U.S.
description: Michel Alaux, coach of the New York Fencers Club and cocoach of the United States Olympic fencing teams in 1964, 1968 and 1972, died of cancer yesterday in Long Island Jewish Hospital; He was 51 years old and lived at 45 Tudor City Place.

title: Jazz Center Sidelined
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP)The New Orleans Jazz center, Rick Roberson, fractured his right ankle in the game against the New York Knicks Saturday and will be out six to eight weeks, the club said today.

title: 19 Americans Flee RebelHeld Town In Northwest Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 30 (AP)Nineteen American civilians crossed the Mekong River to safety Monday after spending seven days in a Laotian town being held by rebel troops.

title: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE
Newcombe and Connors Closer to a Showdown
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 (AP)Jimmy Connors and John Newcombe moved closer to their showdown today, while Margaret Court's quest for her 12th singles title in the Australian open tennis championships ended when she was upset by Martina Navratilova, the 18yearold champion of Czechoslovakia.

title: Rangers Top Stars for 3d in Row, 81
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 30The New York Rangers took advantage of the sadly 'inept Minnesota North Stars tonight, routing them, 8.1, Four of New York's goals were scored on power plays.

title: Birth Defects Month
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 30President Ford today designated January as Marc hof Dimes Birth Defects Prevention Month.

title: Few Banks Are Sold on Gold
description: New Yorkers, like other Americans, were able to buy gold bullion for the first time in 41 years today, but the sellers, a handful of banks and a major brokerage house, discounted the idea of any jetage gold rush.

title: SAUL LANDAU
description: Saul Landau, who retired several years ago as chairman of the mathematics department of James Monroe High School, died yesterday in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. His age was 67.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIALS ACCUSED IN TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 30A retiring Republican United States Attorney said today that stop Justice Department officials, whom he referred to as those yoyo's of Disneyland Northeast, blocked the proposed indictment of then Texas Gov. Preson Smith and several other state officials in a stock scandal.

title: Arctic Gas Files New Plans on Line
description: The Alaskan Arctic Gas Pipeline Company filed papers yesterday with the Federal. Power Commission in Washington indicating that its schedule for the construction of a 2,600mile line had slipped about a year and that the price of natural gas to consumers in the United States would be sharply higher than at present.

title: A & P. EARNINGS ADVANCE SHARPLY
Unemployment in State Rises to 9.5%
description: TRENTON, Dec. 30Unemployment in New Jersey rose to a rate estimated at 9.5 per cent last month, the highest since World War II and 2.5 per cent above last November, the Byrne administration announced today.

title: Gold Price Touches $197.50 but Wanes
description: LONDON, Dec. 30Speculative buying in gold continued today on the European bullion markets in advance of legalization tomorrow of ownership of gold by Americans.

title: ARTHUR H. QUIGLEY
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 29 Arthur It Quigley, retired president and chairman of the board of Anaconda American Brass Company, died today at the age of 92.

title: People and Business
description: Overall the demand for steel should remain relatively strong, especially from the capital goods and energyrelated markets, Lewis W. Foy, chairman, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday in a yearend statement.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Court Rules Against Landlords

title: Steel Production Slumps for Week On Coal Problems
description: After a brief rebound, steel production slumped again last week because of uncertainty over coal supplies, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute in Washington.

title: Cuba Cuts Sugar Ration
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30 (AP)  Beginning next month the Cuban Government will cut individual sugar rations from four pounds a month to three, according to the official Cuban press agency, Prensa Latina. The Cuban Ministry of Foreign Trade said the action was being taken to increase the amount of sugar available for export.

title: Democratic State Senators Seeking Minority Leadership
description: Ten days before the start of the new legislative session, the field of serious contenders for the Democratic Senate leadership has apparently been narrowed to three. But the task of picking the leader is no easier now than it was three weeks ago, when nearly a third of the 26 Senate Democrats considered themselves candidates.

title: Spying for Liberty
description: The evidence appears to be growing that the Central Intelligence Agency violated its charter and broke the law by conducting domestic surveillance within the United States. Since that charge was made in The New York Times Dec. 22, President Ford has said that he had some of the same information on which The Times story was based, and:

title: Seamans Takes Oath
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 30 (AP) Dr. Robert C. Seamans, former Secretary of the Air Force, was sworn in today as head of the new Energy Research and Development Administration.

title: U.S. Officials Pleased by Soviet Decision on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The postponement of Leonid I. Brezhnev's trip to the Middle East came as a welcome surprise to United States officials who feared earlier that the visit might lead to a resurgence of Soviet influence in Egypt.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: An appeals court upheld sixmonth suspensions given to two Elizabeth policemen who were accused of stealing paint and radios from a city storage shack.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 23

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Free Hostages and Fly to Cuba
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 30A group of prominent Nicaraguan businessmen and politicians, kidnapped by leftist guerrillas at a Christmas party here Friday, were freed unharmed today minutes before their captors flew to Cuba.

title: Connecticut to Build SolarHeating Plant In Housing for Aged
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 30Connecticut has been granted Federal funds to build a $1million, 40unit housing project for the elderly in which half the project will draw heat from the sun, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today.

title: Health and Safety, Survey Finds Violations in 90% of the Schools
description: The Health Department, in a joint effort with the Board of Education, has ended its first extensive health and safety inspection of the city's entire public school system, concluding that violations of varying degree existed in nearly 90 per cent of the schools.

title: Nursing Homes Here Live in a NeverNever Land Of Accounting, State Costs Commission Reports
description: A study of 25 nursing homes here shows that 21 are insolveat by their own accounts, the Temporary State Commission on Living Costs reported yesterday. But an official added that their figures appeared to arise from a nevernever land of accounting.

title: An Oracle Analyzes The Course Of Fashion
Texas Loses To Auburn In Gator
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP)  Underdog Auburn stunned Texas with two quick touchdowns midway through the first quarter and then survived its own case of jitters for a 273 victory tonight in the 30th Gator Bowl game.

title: CAREY TO OCCUPY MIDTOWN OFFICE
description: Governorelect Hugh L. Ca rey has reversed a policy of for mer Gov. Nelson A, Rockefelle and decided not to establish downstate gubernatorial office at the World Trade Center lower Manhattan.

title: KENYA LIKELY SITE OF ANGOLA PARLEY
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 30 (Reuters)  A constitutional conference between Portugal and liberation movements in Angola on the independence of the territory will be held in Mombasa, Kenya, this week, according to diplomatic sources.

title: WILSON & CO. SHUTS 3 BIG PORK PLANTS
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 30 (AP)Wilson & Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest meat packing and processing companies, announced today it was closing three major pork plants indefinitely and laying off 850 persons.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an obituary of Jack Benny in The New York Times on Dec. 28, it was incorrectly stated that he was unable to have his share of the proceeds of the sale of Amusement Enterprises to CBS classified as capital gains. Although the Internal Revenue Service had disallowed the classification, the Tax Court decided in his favor.

title: Klan Plans to Investigate Charleston Book Dispute
description: STONE MOUNTAIN, GA., Dec. 30 (UPI)The Ku Klux Klan plans to investigate school board members and textbook company executives in a West Virginia school book controversy. It says Communists are out to subvert American children with obscene books.

title: 3 on Boston School Panel Fined Over Busing Order
description: BOSTON, Dec. 30United States District Judge W. Arthur Garrity today ordered three Boston School Committeemen fined and barred from participating in desegregation matters for defying his order that they approve a new citywide busing plan to integrate schools.

title: Justice for the Judges
description: For the first time in its 184year history, the docket of new and old cases handled in the most recent term of the United States Supreme Court passed the 5,000 mark. Yet the Federal courts face serious problemsthe increased caseload with too few judges, a need to broaden the role of United States magistrates and reduce the demand for cumbersome threejudge courts, and, most urgent of all, the necessity to increase salaries that have fallen shamefully below the standard imposed by inflation and the rising cost of living.

title: Kent State Coach Reprimanded
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30 (AP)Rex Hughes, basketball coach at Kent State, has been reprimanded by the MidAmerican Conference and threatened with a onegame suspension as a result of his ejection from a Dec. game with Ball State University. Commissioner Fred Jacoby said today the action was taken for unsportsmanlike conduct after Hughes received three technical fouls for remarks he made to game officials.

title: Sales Agent for Chile
description: The Cerro Corporation said yesterday its sales subsidiary has been appointed by Chile as its exclusive sales agent for Canadian and United States markets for electrolytic and blister copper, as of Jan. 1, 1975. The appointment, made by corporacion del copre de Chile (Codelco), the Chilean government agency, follows the compensation agreements and settlement of all pending issues between the Chilean government and Anaconda, Kennecott and Cerro, the concern, said.

title: Aiding Needy Becomes a Custom
description: Two brothers, William M. and Andrew D. Heineman, yesterday paid tribute again to the memory of their language teacher at Horace MannBarnard School by contributing $50 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Canadian Paper Gains
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 30 (AP)Canadian companies produced about 22 million tons of pulp, paper and paperboard in 1974, a 1.3millionton increase from 1973, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association announced today. The 1974 shipments, which increased because of a 3 per cent gain in manufacturing capacity, were valued at $5billion, the association said in a yearend review.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Hong SooHoran, 117 pounds, South Korea, outpointed Fernando Cabanela, 117, the Philippines, 15 rounds, to retain World Boxing Association bantamweight title.

title: OFFICERS INDICTED IN MAN'S BEATING
description: PATERSON, Dec. 30Two Passaic patrolmen wee indicted here today by the Passaic County grand jury on charges of beating a 57yearold man, apparently without provocation, causing him to be hospitalized for 10 days.

title: WALFRED E. BOBERG
description: Walfred E. Boberg, a former agricultural magazine executive, died yesterday in St. Paul, where he lived. His age was 77.

title: F.A.A. Appoints a Panel To Study Safety Charges
description: Reacting to the barrage of coticism last week of its handling of air safety problems, the Federal Aviation Administration named a panel yesterday to review the charges and, propose what quick action can be taken to correct any deficiencies.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Italy Centralizing Her Investigation Of a Rightist Plot
description: ROME, Dec. 30A high court ruled today that investigations into alleged rightwing plots must be conducted from Rome.

title: Chile to Reopen Doors To Overseas Bankers
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 30 (Reuters)The Chilean Government has decided to allow foreign banks to operate again in this country, according to a decree in the official gazette published here today.

title: Rams Show An Interest In Namath
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 Do the Los Angeles Rams want Joe Namath? Not today, but tomorrow. Maybe.

title: People in Sports
description: Joe Thomas, the general manager of the Baltimore Colts who dismissed a couple of head coaches while rebuilding the former National Football League powerhouse into a team with a 212 wonlost record this season, got rid of another coach yesterdayhimself.

title: CARTERAGAINASKS FOR A NEW TRIAL
description: The New Jersey judge Who this month refused to grant a new murder trial for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter was asked yesterday to reopen an appeals hearing on the ground that he had misapprehended the issues.

title: Planning Commission Drops 22 Schools
description: The City Planning Commission sent its revised draft of the 197576 capital budget to Mayor Beame yesterday, proposing to drop 22 planned publicschool buildings and to shift money from construction of the Second Avenue subway to rehabilitation of existing rapidtransit lines.

title: A Tale of Two Vetoes
description: A President confronted by an unsympathetic Congress can defend the public interest and add luster to his name by a resolute and principled use of the veto poweras Grover Cleveland, Harry Truman and other embattled Chief Executives have demonstrated. President Ford in his brief tenure in office has shown himself notably aggressive in vetoing legislation but in his pocket veto of two important bills yesterday, it is difficult to discern his guiding principle.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary an??

title: Contractor Feared Dead
description: ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 30 (UPI)County officials say a Minnesota contractor had no chance of escaping an avalanche that carried him 300 yards down a mountainside and buried him under 10 feet of snow. The victim was identified as Morton Berland, 52 years old of St. Paul. His body was recovered about three hours after the accident Saturday.

title: DISMISSED DEAN FOUND IN NEW JOB
description: A former dean at a Bronx junior high school who was stripped of his teaching certificate after being accused last spring of beating pupils to enforce discipline, served one month as a Brooklyn high school's supervisor of school safety before being dismissed yesterday.

title: Text of the Statement by Mills
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)Following is a statement by Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, that was issued by his office today. Mr. Mills remains hospitalized in Bethesda Naval Hospital.

title: Stop Signs Uprooted; 2 Killed and 3 Injured
description: FAIRMONT, N.C., Dec. 30 (UPI)  Vandals upprooted the stop signs at five intersections near here Saturday night.

title: 2 More Companies Scheduled for Sale By Westinghouse
description: Just a day after announcing an agreement to sell its deficitridden major appliance operations, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it was also selling its two European elevator subsidiaries.

title: Pakistan Estimates Quake Killed 4,700 in 9 Towns
description: PATTAN, Pakistan, Dec. 30The earthquake that struck northern Pakistan over the weekend killed 4,700 persons and injured 15,000 in nine towns, according to official estimates.

title: G. S. Dutton Marries Alice J. King
description: Gardiner S. Dutton, president of the Ferro Union Corporation, the nationwide steel warehousing concern with headquarters here, married Alice Jordan King, daughter of Dr. Blanche J. Watrous, an anthropologist of Greenville, N.C., a week ago.

title: Dance: Kirkland's Elan
description: In her first season with the American Ballet Theater, Gelsey Kirkland has taken on the soubrette roles that were virtually nonexistent in the New York City Ballet, her former troupe. It was in this kind of part that she was seen Sunday at the City Center for the first time as Lise, the heroine of La Fille Mal Gardee.

title: Connecticut to Build SolarHeating Plant In Housing for Aged
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 30Connecticut has been granted Federal funds to build a $1million, 40unit housing project for the elderly in which half the project will draw heat from the sun, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill said today.

title: Ford Signs Aid Bill but Attacks Cuts in Funds to Help Indochina
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 30President Ford today signed the $2.7billion foreign military and economic aid bill, but complained that Congressional cuts in aid for Indochina threatened to undermine efforts to negotiate an end to the fighting in Cambodia and to retard efforts to bring economic stability to South Vietnam.

title: Few Banks Are Sold on Gold
description: New Yorkers, like other Americans, were able to buy gold bullion for the first time in 41 years today, but the sellers, a handful of banks and a major brokerage house, discounted the idea of any jetage gold rush.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Says Rich Lands Owe Debt
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 30Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that affluent nations had an obligation to assist poor countries such as India.

title: SPLIT RAIL BLAMED IN TRAIN DERAILING
description: THOMPSONTOWN, Pa., Dec. 30 (AP)Pend Central officials 30 (AP)Pend Central officials say that, a split rail caused the derailment Saturday of the Broadway Limited, a 17car Amtrak passenger train, resulting in minor injuries to 56 persons.

title: Allegheny to Cut Flights
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 (Reuters)Allegheny Airlines said today that it would reduce its total number of flights to 932 from 1,010 daily on Jan. 7 because of a 17 per cen drop in passenger boardings and a 19.6 per cent decline in passenger miles in November.

title: RESOURCE STUDY GETS $12MIILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The Ford Foundation announced today a fouryear grant of $12million to Resources for the Future, a research organization established by the foundation in 1952 to specialize in the economic and environmental problems of the development of natural resources.

title: Sports today
description: FOOTBALL

title: $170,000 in Illegal Gifts Admitted by Ashland Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30In second round of answering charges of making illegal corporate contributions to political campaigns, Ashland Oil, Inc., acknowledged today that it gave an additional $170,000 in company funds to prominent politicians of both major parties from 1970 to 1972.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LOTTERY NUMBER Dec, 30, 1974 N.J.Daily35336

title: Champagne at 12? Warning to Poppers
description: That champagne Pop! that partygoers like to hear on New Year's Eve could be the sound of a dangerous missile, according to Dr. Sherwin H. Sloan, a West Coast ophthalmologist.

title: NAME TO PROPOSE NEW FISCAL PANEL
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he would propose the creation by the State Legislature of, a permanent  City  State Fiscal Commission to discuss. on daytoday ongoing basis the broad spectrum of the fiscal problems lacing the city and the state's role in their solution.

title: VETERANS TO GET HIGHER DIVIDENDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) Veterans of World Wars and II will get higher G1 insurance dividends in 1975 and Koreanera veterans will receive dividends for the first time, the Veterans AdministraIlion announced today. Nearly 4.5 million veterans are affected.

title: MARKETS IN INDIA
description: Avail for representation & commission basis business consultant for markets in India. Woolen rugs, men's sports shirts, women's sportswear, brass Items, handle crofts, silver plated merchandise, home furn., lamp bases, scarves, textiles, hand tools, bicycles, sports goods, colf products, knit wear. The lest 7 years have serviced leading department stores all over U.S.A.

title: Evading the Demon Grog
description: Although millions of Americans will take alcohol tonight, nobody will get drunk.

title: OTB Looking to Go South for the Winter
Utility Project Is Set
description: OAKLAND. Calf., Dec. 30 (UPI)  The Kaiser Industries Corporation announced today it was joining subsidiaries of three major electric utilities in a venture to develop a 10million ton a year underground coal mine in southern Utah. The coal will be sold to the 3,000megawatt Kaiparowits power plant to be built next year. The three utilities, also partners in the power station project, are the Southern California Edison Company, the Arizona Public Service Company and the San Diego Gas and Electric Company.

title: KREMLIN CANCELS BREZHNEV'S VISIT TO MIDDLE EAST
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 30Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has indefinitely postponed his visits to Egypt, Syria and Iraq next. month, it was announced today.

title: EAST SIDERS FIGHT MORE OTB PARLORS
description: Paul R. Screvane, president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation, yesterday told East Side community leaders that he was determined to place more OTB branches in the area east of Fifth Avenue, from 59th to 86th Street.

title: 11 ARE INDICTED ON U.S. FINANCIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) Eleven individuals and companies were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in San Diego on charges they conspired to defraud investors in U. S. Financial, Inc., the Justice Department said.

title: Head of House Panel Asks Inquiry Into Missing Nuclear Substances
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The chairman of a House regulatory agency subcommittee called today for an investigation of why the Atomic Energy Commission was unable to account for substantial amounts of nuclear materials that could be fashioned into homemade nuclear weapons.

title: Panel Sees Jobless Rate Of 8% in State Next Year
description: The recession will bite deeper and last longer in New York State than in the nation as a whole, producing an unemployment rate of 8 per cent or higher next year, the StateCouncil of Economic Advisers warned yesterday.

title: STRIKE IS AVERTED IN BUILDINGS HERE
description: Union and employer negotiators yesterday accepted recommendations by the chairman of the State Mediation Board for a new threeyear contract and thus averted a New Year's Day Strike by 25,000 workers in 2,000 Manhattan commercial buildings.

title: Mills Reveals Alcoholism; Plans to Stay in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30Representative Wilbur D. Mills, attributing his recent erratic behavior to alcoholism, pledged total abstinence today as he announced that he would retain his seat in Congress.
