title: Deaths in Jab Injuries Down
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) (UPI)  number of deaths related to onthejob injuries dropped 7 per cent in 1973, according to the Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration, The agency said that jobrelated fatalities declined to 5,100 in 1973, down from 5,500 in 1972. The job safety office also reported a decline in Jobrelated illness from 210,000 in 1972 to 195,000 in 1973.

title: HARDWICKE PLANS FOR SALE OF PARK
description: Hardwicke Companies, Inc. announced yesterday it hac reached an agreement in prin ciple to sell about 95 per cent of its equity interest in the Great Adventure amusementpark to a subsidi ary of Rockwood & Co., a private firm controlled by the Pritzker fainily of Chicago.

title: FREDERICK ATHERTON
description: Frederick W. Atherton, a vice president and oil analyst for P.I.E.R. Associates, a Boston research brokerage concern, and a former vice president of the Continental Oil Company, died Sunday in Boston. He was 65 years old and lived in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Antiquities Dealers Fearing Suits, Restrict Activities
description: When I see an artifact from India, a New York dealer in Oriental antiquities said the other day, a little flag goes up in my headDON'T BUY IT.

title: Steelers Believed Able to Slow Vikings
description: Sounding like David Glasgow Farragut (the Civil War admiral), Francis Asbury Tarkenton (the Minnesota quarterback) intoned the Vikings' Super Bowl cry yesterday: Damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead!

title: In Britain, Equal Rights by Law if Not in Fact
description: LONDON (Reuters)Equal opportunity for women made great strides on the law books in Britain this year, but a Government report says the respective roles of men and women, both in the home and at work, have not changed fundamentally.

title: N.B.A. Not Making Its Points as Often
description: Scoring in the National Basketball Association is declining for the fourth straight season. Defense, rule changes and injuries have been responsible for the trend. Fieldgoal attempts and shooting percentages are also down, but turnovers are up.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Contract Awards
description: The BowenMcLaughlinYork Company has received a $34.6million Army contract for selfpropelled howitzers.

title: WATERGATE JURY RECEIVES CHARGE; WEIGHS FATE OF 5
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30AWASHINGTON, Dec. 30A jury of nine women and three men began to deliberate today the case against the five former White House and Nixon campaign aides charged in the Watergate coverup.

title: Suffolk Legislators Abandon Proposal To Raise Salaries
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 30 Reversing an action taken only 10 days ago, the Republican majority of the Suffolk County Legislature agreed today to rescind scheduled raises for themselves and County Executive John V. N. Klein.

title: $1Million in Art Stolen at Paris Home
description: PARIS, Dec. 30Art reported to be worth $1million was stolen on Friday night from the Paris home of a wealthy American landscape architect and his Frenchborn wife, it was reported by the police today.

title: Auld Acquaintances to Hear Lombardo
description: The fans of Guy Lombardo, who come here annually from as far away as Canada and California so they can be with the bandleader and his Royal Canadians on New Year's Eve, were back in town yesterday.

title: Providence Is Upset by St. John's
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 30 (UPI)Mel Utley scored 25 points and Kevin Cluess added 17 as thirdseeded St. John's upset secondseeded Providence, 9179, tonight in the final of the Ocean State Classic.

title: Theater: A Varnpiress
Hunter Spurns $2.6Million Bid
description: AHOSKIE, N.C., Dec. 30 (AP)Four teams can still hook Jim (Catfish) Hunter, one of the star pitcher's lawyers said today.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 0.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials last week fell to 209.8 from 210.5 the previous week.

title: Battle Expected on Tighter Laws to Curb Illegal Aliens
description: A major battle over illegal aliens that could have great consequences for this region is shaping up in Congress.

title: A Computer Error Can Restore Faith
description: Roy M. Green, circulation manager of The Atlantic Monthly, may have been let down by his computer, but he's been buoyed by some of his subscribers.

title: Gold Reenters the Market Place After 41 Years
description: From Boise, Idaho, to Portland, Me., investors entered the nation's new golden era this morning with one hand on their wallets.

title: Terror in Nicaragua
description: The weekend guerrilla attack on a social gathering in Nicaragua that resulted in four deaths and the holding of thirteen men as hostages for sixty hours proves yet again that no government or international agency has been able to devise an adequate defense against armed terrorism. In this instance, as in so many earlier episodes, guerrilla bravado, blackmail and ruthlessness regrettably paid off: the terrorists and a group of sympathizers, freed from jail on their demand, were flown safely to Cuba.

title: MORE CORPORATIONS ADOPT LIFO SYSTEM
description: The lastin, firstout method of inventory valuation is being adopted by a growing number of companies. These changes were announced yesterday:

title: $170;000. in Illegal Gifts. Admitted by Ashland Oil
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30In a second round of answering charges of making illegal corporate contributions to political campaigns, Ashland Oil, Inc., acknowledged, today that it gave an additional, $170,000 in company funds to prominent politicians of both major parties from 1970 to 1972.

title: NED E. DEPINET, 84, EXPRESIDENT OF RKO
description: Ned E. Depinet, who retired in 1952 as president of RKORadio Pictures, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 1035 Park Avenue.

title: RCA Global Unit Ordered to Transfer Satellite Operations;
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) RCA Global Communications, Inc., has been ordered to transfer its satellite operations from Canadian to American systems by no later than May 15.

title: JOINT OIL BIDDING DECRIED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 A House Small Business subcommittee said today that joint bidding by major oil companies for offshore leases was anticompetitive and should be prohibited.

title: 3 Killed and 9 Wounded By an Upstate Sniper, 18
description: A teenaged sniper described as honor student killed three persons and wounded nine others with rifle and shotgun fire in and around the Olean (N.Y.) High School yesterday before siurendering to state troopers and city policemen who stormed the school under a barrage of tear gas and gunfire.

title: Hunt Tells of Early Work For a C.I.A. Domestic Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30E. Howard Hunt Jr., a Watergate burglar who pleaded guilty, told the Senate Watergate committee last year in still unpublished testimony that he served as the first chief of covert action for the Central Intelligence Agency's Domestic Operations Division.

title: Cut in LongDistance Air Fares, Rise for Short Hauls Affirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI)Reaffirming an order issued last spring, the Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that longdistance domestic passenger air fares should be reduced and shorthaul fares should be increased to reflect more accurately the cost of the flights.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given in Eestern Standerd Times
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: George H. Earle 3d, 84, Dead; ExGovernor of Pennsylvania
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 30 (AP)George H. Earle 3d, former Pennsylvania Governor and diplomat, died today in the Bryn Mawr Convalescent Nome not far from his home in Villanova. He was 84 years old.

title: Fordham Wins Festival Crown
description: A lot of people said it was to be the Monday night massacreand it was, said a smiling Kevin Fallon last night after Fordham confounded a good many knowledgeable basketball fans by trouncing Southern California, 8366, in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES STRIP MINING BILL, OIL TANKER PLAN
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 30President Ford refused today to sign two highly controversial bills. One would have put stringent new restrictions on strip mining of coal and the other would have required that 20 per cent of the oil imported into the United States be carried on United States tankers.

title: Residents Deny Funds to Willimantic
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Dec. 30Angry voters of this small industrial city in eastern Consounding voted tonight, by resounding majorities to deny the city government the authority to borrow money to pay its bills beyond year's end tomorrow on even to pay salaries and heat the city buildings for two morel weeks.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Frank Pietrouskie, a skinny forward, took the spotlight from two of the best big men in metropolitan high school basketball yesterday as he led Long Island Lutheran of Brookville, L. I., to a 7977 victory over Taft and first place in the Elmcor High School Christmas tournament at St. John's University.

title: TRUDEAU SPEAKS OF HIS MARRIAGE
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 30Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau says that he considers the difficulties that his wife Margaret has had in adjusting to his political life to be typical of a problem that wives often have in assuming their husbands identity in the modern world.

title: Grappling With Multinational Corporations
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 The growth, power, and independence of multinational corporations has transformed the structure of the United States economy, undermining government efforts to control inflation and stabilize the business environment.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Wyman Is Appointed Senator for 3 Days
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. stepped today into the tangle of confusion surrounding this states recent Senate election and appointed Representative Louis C. Wyman Senator for at least three days.

title: Informer in '73 Muslim Killings Found Slain in Philadelphia Jail
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30, (AP)A defendantturnedinformer in the 1973 slayings of seven Hanafi Muslims in Washington was killed over the weekend in his cell at Holmesburg Prison.

title: The Old, in Albany, Gets Set to Ring In the New
description: ALBANY, Dec. 30After 36 years of governmental service, Malcolm Wilson stepped into an official limousine this evening and headed home for Yonkers, his tenure as Governor of New York to expire officially at midnight tomorrow, his power as the head of state, for all practical purposes, at an end.

title: Ozark Picketed Again
description: ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 30 Mechanics employed by Ozark Air Lines resumed today informational picketing of the company's headquarters at Lambert Field because of lack of a contract agreement. Federally mediated talks continued between Ozark and the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association. The picketing did not interfere with the airline's operations.

title: Minister Says Guerrilla Action Could Threaten Rhodesia Talks
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 30 (AP)  Rhodesia's white minority Government. said today that it may call off a scheduled constitutional confterence with black nationalists unless guerrillas cease opera ions in the bush country,Ted SuttonPryce, a deputy minister who coordinates antiguerrilla activities, said the guerrillas continue to operate in defiance of their leaders, who have agreed to a ceasefire. The truce was expected to be followed by a constitutional settlement that could lead to rule by the country's black majority.

title: Deaths From Fires Decline, But Property Damage Rises
description: BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP)Fire deaths declined, but property damage due to fires increased in 1974, according to the Na tional Fire Protection Association.

title: President's Son Helps In Rescue of a Skier
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 30 (UPI) President Ford's 22yearold son, Jack, and two Secret Service agents helped rescue a woman skier whose heart stopped when she became hysterical after she seemed to have broken a leg on Vail Mountain, Ron Nessen, White House press secretary, said today.

title: London Restaurant Closes
description: LONDON, Dec. 30 (UPI)The Caprice, one of London's most famous restaurants is closing. According to John Moroni, the manager, the reason is that diners no longer know nor care whether food is frozen or fresh. People don't feel they have the time to enjoy the sort of meal we do here, he said.

title: Opera, Nela, By Gonzalez, At Tully Hall
description: Nela, a Puerto Rican opera by Manuel B. Gonzlez, was first performed in May at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, and again last month in Union City, N. J., and Sunday night it turned up fully staged at Alice Tully Hall.

title: New Construction Orders Dropped 20% in November
description: New construction contracts totaling $6.17billion were signed last month, a drop of 20 per cent from the level of November, 1973, the F. W. Dodge division of, the McGrawHill information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: TOP MUSICIANS VOW TO BOYCOTT UNESCO
description: Leonard Bernstein and Isaac Stern led about 25 Principal musical artists in signing an agreenient yesterday to boycott the cultural activities of UNESCO because of its decision to withhold cultural aid to Israel.

title: Bridge: Game Is Not Always Certain With Opposite Opening Bids
description: Every beginner knows that an opening bid opposite an opening bid produces a game but unfortunately there are exceptions, as happens with most rules for beginners. This writer once had a pair of opponents who stopped correctly in a partscore with 29 highcard points: there was no markable or desirable game contract. But normally the game is bid if the combined strength is adequate, and if the resulting contract is poor the fates must take the blame.

title: KREMLIN CANCELS BREZHNEV'S VISIT TO MIDDLE EAST
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 30Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader has indefinitely postponed his visits to Egypt, Syria and. Iraq next month, it was announced today.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Less Gas Bought in '74 Bat More Paid for It
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)  Americans bought less natural gas but paid more for it in 1974, the American Gas Association said today.

title: TRIAL TAPE COPIES MAY COST BUT $88
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) The major broadcasting networks told United States District Judge Charles R. Richey today that the public could purchase complete copies of the White Souse tapes played at the Watergate coverup trial for as little as $88 or perhaps as much as $160.

title: Music: Polish Power
description: Bobby Vinton left nobody in doubt on Sunday at Carnegie Hall  musically Polish Power was the thing. Mr. Vinton currently has a millionselling recording, My Melody of Love, in which he has inserted several Polish language choruses. It has also apparently served to give him a new direction in his concerts.

title: Harvester to Resume Work At Its Plants Using Steel
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP)The International Harvester Company's plants that use steel from the United States Steel Corporation No. 4 open hearth shop at the Gary works will resume operations on a daybyday basis when the Christmas shutdown is over Jan. 2.

title: Beame to Ask for New CityState Fiscal Commission
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday he would propose the creation by the State Legislature of permanent City  State Fiscal Commission to dismiss on daytoday ongoing basis the broad spectrum of the fiscal problems facing the city and the state's role in their solution.

title: Experts Call Mills's Recovery Outlook Excellent
description: Experts on alcohol abuse give Representative Wilbur D. Mills an excellent chance for a successful battle against alcoholism, which he said yesterday had been responsible for his recent erratic behavior.
